title: Economic Scene; Reagan's Shift On the Deficits
description: WASHINGTON D O deficits really matter? Just a couple of weeks ago, the Reagan Administration appeared to be saying no, they did not; the important thing was the real growth of the economy, the conquest of inflation, the creation of jobs, the raising of productivity. So what if the Administration was submitting a budget with deficits of $180 billion or more for the next several years, coming down, on its own optimistic assumptions, only to $122 billion by 1989?

title: Redskins Say No
description: The Houston Oilers were keeping mum yesterday, but according to the Washington Redskins, the Oilers offered the star running back Earl Campbell in a trade, and the Redskins expressed interest until Houston demanded the all-pro offensive tackle Joe Jacoby in return.

title: Marcus Dupree Quits College;  Future Unclear ; Dupree Is Leaving
description: Marcus Dupree, the star running back who transferred from Oklahoma to the University of Southern Mississippi in October, has withdrawn from school, a move that seemed to raise the possibility of his trying to turn professional.

title: People

Egyptian Leader in Zaire
description: President Hosni Mubarak of Egypt arrived today on a visit that opens a four- nation African tour aimed at expanding Egypt's influence on the continent and signaling its interest in a larger role in the Organization of African Unity. Mr. Mubarak was welcomed at Kinsahsa airport by President Mobutu Sese Seko and other officials. The Egyptian President then went to the Palace of the People in Kinshasa for formal welcoming ceremonies.

title: JEFFERIES GROUP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included a gain of $1,396,000 from arbitrage activities and an investment position.

title: Iraq Says It Sank 5 Iranian Ships
description: The Iraqi military said today that its forces had sunk five Iranian vessels and shot down a Phantom jet fighter in a battle in the northern end of the Persian Gulf.

title: ASKEW PINS HOPES ON LIFT FROM IOWA
description: It was an evening gathering in this small agricultural town in northern Iowa, and Reubin Askew, after a day of long traveling to woo small audiences, was calm and relaxed as he repeated a theme of his Democratic Presidential candidacy.

title: Metromedia Sale Backed The sale of Metromedia Inc., the broadcasting chain, for about $1.6 billion to four of its top executives and an investment firm has been unanimously approved by the company's directors and a special committee of independent directors.
description: The principal barriers remaining to the deal, which would be the largest purchase to date of a broadcasting company, are approval by the stockholders, the Federal Communications Commission and other regulatory agencies.

title: PRICES PAID FARMERS UP 2.1%
description: Prices that farmers get for raw products rose 2.1 percent in January from December and were 12 percent higher than in January 1983, the Agriculture Department said today.

title: Tip Leads F.B.I. to Fugitive Accused in California Deaths
description: The Federal Bureau of Investigation arrested one of its 10 most wanted fugitives Monday after a citizen who had seen a bureau poster about him recognized him.

title: CORRECTION
description: A dispatch from Washington Jan. 17 on the satellite transmission of a television news conference by Henry A. Kissinger to United States missions misidentified the receiver site in Brazil. It was the United States Consulate in Rio de Janeiro.

EXTORTION TRIAL OF COUNCILMAN GETS UNDER WAY
description: A Federal prosecutor charged in court yesterday that City Councilman Luis A. Olmedo of Brooklyn and two community leaders conspired to extort thousands of dollars from two companies and illicitly received $12,000 from an undercover investigator.

title: Providence
description: Like Anita Brookner's previous two novels, ''Providence'' recounts, with elegance and precision, the story of a timid woman's thwarted efforts to create a new life for herself. A lecturer in ''the Romantic Tradition'' at a small English university, Kitty Maule is one of those well-bred, perfectly mannered women who is always perfectly dressed, perhaps a little too perfectly dressed - a woman who might be called pretty, were it not for the perpetual look of disappointment she wears on her face. She always looks as though she had just been stood up.

title: December Home Sales Up by 28.5%
description: Sales of new homes surged 28.5 percent in December from November, pushing up sales for the entire year by 53 percent from the depressed level of 1982, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: SELIGMAN & LATZ INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Net loss.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Associated Dry Goods Corp. , a diversified retail chain, has appointed Donald E. Ray president and chief executive of its Sibley, Lindsay & Curr division.

title: THOUSANDS JOIN MANILA PROTEST
description: Tens of thousands of Filipinos turned out today to welcome 300 joggers as they completed a 90-mile trek to Manila to protest the killing of Benigno S. Aquino Jr. at the airport here last August.

title: A 2-PIECE RAVIOLI MOLD
description: PASTA has taken on new importance in recent years as Americans discover that there is more to spaghetti, linguine and ravioli than marinara sauce and grated Parmesan cheese. To my mind, ravioli is the most fun to experiment with - the medley of fillings and sauces is limited only by your imagination.

description: b-Including tax credits of $973,000 for the quarter and $2,383,000 for the year. c-Including a tax credit of $370,000 for the quarter and year.

title: The Lebanon Commotion
description: A long year or two ago, the current news from the Middle East would have been eye-popping. The Arab League is moving to readmit Egypt, almost forgiving the crime of Camp David. Jordan's King Hussein and the P.L.O.'s Yasir Arafat are making positive noises about the Reagan plan for coexistence with Israel. Saudi Arabia is openly working with Americans for an accommodation in Lebanon and for a Syrian withdrawal.

Guilty Plea Entered In Meatpacking Inquiry
description: A former supervisor of Cattle King Packing Company, a meatpacking concern accused of selling contaminated ground beef to schools, pleaded guilty Monday to a charge of concealing a felony.

title: Q&A
description: Q.

title: THE POP LIFE
description: ''ELVIS: THE FIRST LIVE RECORDINGS,'' a new disk that is being released this week by the Music Works label, captures a 20-year-old Elvis Presley singing for a live audience on a country-music radio show called ''The Louisiana Hayride.'' Four of the five songs on the 12-inch disk date from 1955, when Mr. Presley was still largely unknown outside the South and had enjoyed only a modest regional success with a handful of record releases on the Sun label in Memphis.

title: Kenyon & Eckhardt Chairman Leaving
description: Ronald J. Moss, 53 years old, chairman and general counsel of Kenyon & Eckhardt, yesterday announced his intention to leave the agency in April.

title: Hundreds of Afghans Reported Killed in Month
description: Western diplomats said today that Soviet- led forces in Afghanistan killed hundreds of civilians this month in bombing raids on villages north of Kabul, the capital.

title: CALFED INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The company went public in April 1983 and year-ago share earnings are stated on a pro forma basis.

title: Consolidated Oil
description: Consolidated Oil and Gas Inc. of Denver said it had signed a letter of intent with a private company to sell 16 percent of its proven oil and gas reserves for $44.75 million. The buyer was not identified. The properties involved in the deal, which should be completed in March, represent half of Consolidated's interest in the South Laredo field in Webb and Zapata Counties, Tex.; half of its interest in the Ridge-Clearfork field in Crosby County, Tex., and 40 percent of its interest in currently producing wells in the San Juan Basin of New Mexico.

title:
TO THE LIVING SECTION;
Saving on Bulk Food
description: Shopping at food warehouses (''As Bulk Food Sales Grow, So Do Health Questions,'' Jan. 18) can be quite economical.

title: Holmes in Benefit
description: Larry Holmes, the unbeaten heavyweight champion, will box several members of the San Diego Chargers football team at Sea World Feb. 22 in a benefit for Stewart Darden, the welterweight who was critically injured in a fight earlier this month, the promoter Wes Wambold said today.

title: ANALYSIS OF A TRAINING CAMP
description: It is his ninth football training camp, and so far it is the most distinctive one Bob Horn can remember. The camp is that of the New Jersey Generals, and Horn, No. 66, is an inside linebacker formerly of the San Francisco 49ers and the San Diego Chargers of the National Football League.

title: Key Rates
description: Kenny Index, Kenny Information Systems Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: Reduction Asked
description: Willie Wilson, the Kansas City Royals outfielder who is serving time in a Federal prison on a misdemeanor drug charge, has asked a judge to reduce his sentence. A motion filed in Federal court by the player's attorneys asked for Wilson's release from the remaining six weeks of his three-month sentence because the player is ''no danger to society'' and ''any benefits of his incarceration have now been achieved.''

title: REAGAN PREVIEWS $925 BILLION PLAN FOR G.O.P. CHIEFS
description: President Reagan, saying he did not want his budget to become ''a political football,'' told Republican Congressional leaders today that he would propose only limited measures to reduce the Federal deficit to $180 billion next year.

description: b-Including securities gains of $149,000 for the quarter and $168,000 for the year. c-Including securities gains of $4,000 for the quarter and $5,000 for the year.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: PROVIDENCE. By Anita Brookner. 183 pages. Pantheon Books. $13.95. ALMOST PARADISE. By Susan Isaacs. 483 pages. Harper & Row. $16.95.

title: NEW YORKERS, ETC.
description: THERE are normal people, there are very organized and neat people, and there are pack rats. The pack rats of the world have a hard existence, but they are firm in their belief that someday some of their junk will come in handy. This makes them impervious to ridicule, laughter, threats and tears.

title: THEATER: 'ATLANTIC,' MIXED-MEDIA WORK
description: ''NORTH ATLANTIC,'' the new theater piece by the experimental Wooster Group, is an impressive display of theatrical and electronic skill - all in the service of a vapid cause. Set on some wayward allied- powers aircraft carrier off the Dutch coast, this mixed-media collage reminds us that military bureaucracies can be counterproductive and conspiratorial, that weapons systems can be Freudian fantasies and that today's uncoded cold-war jargon can mask a frightening secret agenda. If any of these stale insights were conveyed with the wit and inventiveness of, say, ''Dr. Strangelove'' or ''Catch- 22,'' perhaps the 90-minute show at the Performing Garage would not seem to drag on for twice that length.

title: Chris-Craft Deal
description: Chris-Craft Industries has increased its holdings in Warner Communications Inc. common stock, according to a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission.

title: Ulster Bomb Kills 2 Officers
description: Irish Republican Army bombers killed two police officers today when they blew up a police car with half a ton of explosives hidden in a roadside ditch. Reporters at the scene said the blast, detonated as the police car drove over the explosives on an isolated country road near Forkhill, South Armagh, was heard seven miles away.

title: Advertising; Campaign For Lice Treatment
description: IF only about eight million American homes out of the more than 83 million blessed with television are a target audience for a product, television would hardly seem an efficient medium to use.

title: Brock Critical Of Deficit
description: The United States trade representative, Bill Brock, said today that ''the heart of the problem'' of the American trade imbalance, which may cost two million jobs this year, is a Government budget deficit that has kept American interest rates high and strengthened the dollar.

title: KODAK VENTURE INTO VIDEO
description: The home video recorder industry has been shaken up by the announcement that Kodak will soon introduce a new video system that will be incompatible with all of the other systems currently on the market. The Kodak system, which is expected to be available within the year, is comparably priced in the $2,100 to $2,400 range, but will use a different size of tape cassette.

title: ALLNET COMMUNICATION SERVICES reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Judge Bars Construction Of Navy Radio Network
description: A Federal district judge issued an injunction today against construction of the Navy's Project ELF communications system in Wisconsin and the Upper Peninsula of Michigan.

title: NEWSPAPER GUILD VOTES TO ACCEPT TIMES CONTRACT EXTENSION
description: The Newspaper Guild yesterday became the 10th and final union at The New York Times to accept a three-year extension of its present contract.

title: Britain Bans Jockey
description: Billy Newnes , one of Britain's leading jockeys, was banned for three years yesterday, after he had admitted accepting money from a professional gambler following his fifth- place finish aboard the favorite in the Queen's Vase race at Royal Ascot last June. The action was taken by Britain's Jockey Club, which also ordered the gambler, Harry Bardsley , not to appear at a race track for 15 years.

title: EMIGRE RECOUNTS HIS K.G.B. TROUBLE
description: A Soviet Jew now living in Israel has asserted that the K.G.B., the Soviet secret police, threatened him and his sons in an effort to make him write a false incrimination of Anatoly B. Shcharansky, the prominent Jewish activist imprisoned in the Soviet Union.

title: PRETORIA REPORTS A MOVE IN ANGOLA
description: Prime Minister P. W. Botha said today that South African troops had started to carry out a ''disengagement'' of forces in southern Angola. It remained unclear, however, whether the operation involved an immediate withdrawal from Angola of those South African units that have been occupying parts of the former Portuguese colony for more than two years.

description: YOU know you should increase your calcium consumption to protect your bones. You're also concerned about heart disease and have decided to follow a low-fat diet. You look at the lists of foods recommended for each and find that what's good for one condition seems to be bad for the other.

title: E.R. MCKINNEY, 97, AIDED IN UNIONIZING PULLMAN CAR PORTERS
description: Ernest Rice McKinney, a labor leader, educator and writer who helped organize Pullman car porters, steel workers and sharecroppers, died Monday at St. Vincent's Hospital in Manhattan. He was 97 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: COOPER INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
U.S. Industry Woes Studied
description: If future economic growth is not to be ''severely hampered,'' the United States must deal with major problems that are undermining its manufacturing industries, according to a new study of America's manufacturing sector.

title: JAPAN AUTO SUCCESS ANALYZED
description: The Japanese auto industry owes its success more to its technical and human relations achievements than to assistance by the Japanese Government, according to a University of Michigan study released today. The study was sponsored by the auto industries of Japan and the United States.

title: REAGAN, IN CHICAGO SPEECH, ASSAILS CRITICS OF HIS TAX-CUTTING PLAN
description: President Reagan said today that his political opponents were trying to appeal to ''greed and envy'' in criticizing his tax-cutting program as favoring the rich.

title: Mets Invite Two
description: Mickey Mahler , a 31-year-old left- hander with a 12-24 major league record, and Rafael Santana , a 26- year-old minor league shortstop who played 30 games for the St. Louis Cardinals last season, have been invited to join the Mets at spring training as nonroster players. At the same time, the Mets announced that they had signed a number of players, including Sid Fernandez , the top pitcher in the Texas League last season, and Ron Gardenhire , who is expected to challenge Jose Oquendo for the role of regular shortstop.

title: ANDROPOV SENDS LETTER OF SUPPORT TO UNESCO HEAD
description: Yuri V. Andropov, the Soviet leader, expressed support today for the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization, which the United States is quitting in protest over the politicization of its programs and dissatisfaction with its budget.

title: U.S. IS INVESTIGATING REPORTS IN SALVADOR OF SALES OF FOOD AID
description: The Reagan Administration said today that it had sent a high-ranking official to El Salvador to investigate reports that some United States food sent to be distributed free is being sold in local markets.

title: Millet Canvas Found To Have Two Paintings
description: Researchers using X-ray equipment have discovered a painting by the French Impressionist Jean Francois Millet under another of his works, officials of the Museum of Fine Arts here said.

title: THE OLD OCEAN MINUET
description: In one of those ironies in which politics abounds, the Democrats now profess to be shocked - shocked - by President Reagan's budget deficit. Perhaps some of them are. The deficit, somewhere in the neighborhood of $200 billion, is a doozy; ''oceans of red ink'' is the time-honored cliche created years ago by the Republicans to describe debt of such grandeur.

title: U.S. STEEL'S LOSS LARGE IN QUARTER
description: The United States Steel Corporation yesterday reported a loss of $983 million in the fourth quarter, exceeding analysts' predictions by about $300 million because of unexpectedly weak steel and oil results.

title: MOROCCO'S WALL SEEMS TO TURN TIDE AGAINST REBELS
description: The Moroccan Army is pushing ever farther into the desert the Great Wall of the Sahara, now more than 400 miles long. It protects part of the territory that Morocco annexed eight years ago by keeping out the Polisario Front guerrillas who are fighting to make the Western Sahara an independent nation.

title: INTERSTATE POWER CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Team's Ad Is Protested
description: A member of the city's Board of Supervisors is concerned that billboard advertisements by the Oakland Invaders football team glorify violence. Supervisor Nancy Walker said Monday that she wanted the United States Football League club to remove or replace with a more subdued message a downtown billboard sign telling people to listen to radio coverage of the club, or ''we'll break your face.''

description: ''Star Wars'' still are wars. They must be avoided.

Wesray once owned Gibson Greeting Cards Inc., which is now publicly held. The American Greetings Corporation, a separate publicly held corporation, has no connection with Wesray.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: An article in Business Day yesterday about Monday's stock market trading misstated the change in Southwest Airlines stock. It fell 2 1/4 points.

description: The Houston Natural Gas Corporation, fighting off what it called a ''coercive and deceptive'' takeover bid by the Coastal Corporation, said yesterday that it would offer $42 a share for ''any and all'' of Coastal's nearly 22 million shares, or $924 million in cash.

title: Market PlaceVartanig G. Vartan Diagnostic Field Lags
description: D IASONICS INC., a maker of medical diagnostic equipment that went public early last year as a ''hot new issue,'' said yesterday that it expects to report a pretax loss of $60 million to $65 million for 1983.

description: Ann Satterthwaite, a city planner who is vice president of the Citizens Association of Georgetown, sees it as ''a pure David and Goliath battle.''

title: ADVERTISING
description: Matthew J. Hennessey, who guided his company from art studio to the world's largest health-care advertising agency, is retiring today as chairman and chief executive of Sudler & Hennessey.

title: Hutton Net Drops 79.2%
description: E. F. Hutton Group Inc., parent of one of the nation's largest brokerage houses, said yesterday that its profits in the fourth quarter plunged 79.2 percent from a year earlier, mainly because of lower securities trading volume. The company said it earned $8.5 million, or 33 cents a share, in the three months ended Dec. 31, compared with $40.8 million, or $1.70 a share, a year earlier.

title: CHILEANS DETAIN PURSUER OF NAZIS
description: A West German Nazi-hunter was arrested briefly here today after she led about 30 Chileans in a demonstration urging Chile to expel Walter Rauff, a former Nazi officer.

title: Careers; Pharmacy: A Past and A Future
description: PHARMACISTS are ready to play a more active role in the lives of drugstore customers, not only to build up their own self-esteem but also to be helpful in the growing trend toward self-medication.

title: BRIEFS
description: Bechtel Corp., an engineering and construction company in San Francisco, said it had received a contract from the Washington Public Power Supply System to provide support services for Unit No. 2in Hanford, Wash. The company said the contract could be worth up to $82 million.

description: Even in Division III, in which how one plays the game supposedly counts as much as who wins and loses, winning can make a difference.

description: The North American Philips Corporation, an electronics concern, posted a 24.9 percent increase in earnings for the fourth quarter, to a record $37.1 million, or $2.58 a share, from $29.7 million, or $2.14 a share, a year earlier, the company said yesterday. Sales rose 32 percent, to $1.1 billion, from $849.5 million.

title: WEDNESDAYSPORTS Basketball
description: Nets vs. San Diego Clippers, at Byrne Meadowlands Arena, 7:35 P.M. The often-injured Bill Walton makes his first appearance in New Jersey since he came to Piscataway with the Portland Trail Blazers six years ago.

title: Ban the Bad Bullets
description: When the police searched the Long Island home of David Schwartz, a bank robbery suspect, they found a dismaying armory containing one especially chilling store of ammunition. Among gun parts and tools, scopes, knives and a machete, they came upon 32 armor-piercing handgun bullets, the kind that can penetrate the protective vests worn by police officers.

description: Air 1 said it would extend its service from coast to coast with the inauguration this spring of flights to Houston and Los Angeles. Air 1, which is based here, said it would operate nonstop from St. Louis with connections to other airlines and other cities the airline serves. The carrier, which began service April 1, 1983, serves airports in Newark, Washington D.C., Dallas- Fort Worth and Kansas City.

description: A dispute over a report to the Conservative Party charging that it has been infiltrated by racist and anti-Jewish elements heated up today when the leader of an extreme right-wing group said 2 Cabinet ministers and 24 Tory Members of Parliament were ''very sympathetic'' to his organization's views.

title: U.S. WINS SUIT ON CLEANUP OF DIOXIN
description: A Federal district judge ruled today that the Environmental Protection Agency is entitled to recover some dioxin cleanup costs from a defunct chemical manufacturing company, its officers and a waste hauler.

description: With the appointment of Bishop John J. O'Connor as head of the Archdiocese of New York, Pope John Paul II broke a 65-year-old tradition of giving the archbishop the additional role of spiritual leader to Roman Catholics in the United States armed forces.

description: The stock market ended its biggest trading month in history yesterday with small price declines, despite some impressive economic reports.

title: U.S., PRESS BELGRADE
description: When, as expected, President Mika Stiljak of Yugoslavia requests American aid for his shattered economy today, his hosts in Washington should point out that certain changes would help Yugoslavia emerge from its economic crisis and garner additional Western support. By limiting the press, curtailing open debate and restricting participation in public life, Yugoslavia's leaders have cut off natural political forces that, in a freer country, could correct various errant policies and faulty economic plans and replace tired officials.

title: EAST GERMANY TRIES ACCOMMODATION
description: The alacrity with which East Germany has allowed two groups of asylum-seekers to go to West Berlin from East Berlin underscores the Communist Government's anxiety to sustain good relations with West Germany, according to officials and diplomats here.

title: A 'Blueprint' All Right -- for Segregation
description: President Reagan's Department of Justice so abhors mandatory busing that it does everything possible to avoid it in school desegregation cases, even to the point of tolerating continued segregation.

title: OPERA: MET 'STRAVISKY,' '81 TRIPLE BILL REVIVED
description: WHEN the triple bill that the Metropolitan Opera calls ''Stravinsky'' first appeared in 1981, it was the visual and theatrical aspects of the production that captured most attention. John Dexter's enterprising attempt to force some kind of esthetic unity on three disparate works - ''Le Sacre du Printemps,'' ''Le Rossignol'' and ''Oedipus Rex'' - was buttressed by the David Hockney sets and costumes with their audaciously vivid colors. At the season's first performance of the triple bill Monday evening, the admirable qualities remembered from the premiere were again evident. ''Stravinsky'' remains still one of the most eye-opening variety shows the Metropolitan has ever put on, sharing honors in that regard with the previous Dexter-Hockney triple bill, ''Parade.''

title: WEDNESDAY, FEBRUARY 1, 1984 International
description: A withdrawal of the marines from Lebanon was urged by House Democratic leaders in a proposed Congressional resolution. It would urge President Reagan to begin ''the prompt and orderly withdrawal'' of the force, but the leaders, rejecting protests within their ranks, declined to include a specific timetable for a pullout. (Page A1, Column 6.) The House Armed Services panel accepted a report criticizing the United States military in connection with the bombing of the Marine headquarters in Beirut. The committee has historically been strongly supportive of the military. The report was prepared by the comittee's investigations subcommittee. (A1:5.)

Williams, who was convicted in 1982 of killing two of 29 young blacks slain in Atlanta over a two-year period, was transferred today from a county jail 35 miles away to the Georgia Diagnostic and Classification Center here for processing and assignment to a state prison, officials said.

title: ALCOHOL POISONING KILLS MAN

He said Mr. Kelly had been unconscious for more than an hour before the police were called.

title: Norwest Offering Its First Eurobond LONDON, Jan. 31 (Reuters) - The Norwest Corporation, a bank holding company in Minneapolis, is offering a $50 million seven-year Eurobond, the lead manager, Salomon Brothers International, said. The issue, priced at par, matures on Feb. 15, 1991, and is callable in the fifth year at 101 percent, with the premium falling by five-tenths of 1 percent each year to par. Payment is due Feb. 21.
description: This is the first Eurobond for Norwest, which is offering it in the name of a subsidiary, the Norwest Overseas Capital Corporation. Norwest's outstanding debt is rated double-Ax by Standard & Poor's and double-A by Moody's Investors Service. Fees total 1 7/8 percent.

title: MUSIC: YOURI EGOROV, PIANIST
description: YOURI EGOROV'S biography, printed in the Carnegie Hall program book, says flatly that he is ''one of the great pianists of our time.'' That claim may be discounted as excusable hyperbole, but it is true that the young man is extremely talented and no doubt has a bright future. His Carnegie recital last night, the fourth he has given in the hall since his New York debut in 1978, left no doubt about Mr. Egorov's basic musical gifts or his audience appeal. He has both valuable assets, no question about it.

title: ROADWAY SERVICES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Debt Issues
description: * Bearings Inc., a producer of ball bearings and power transmission parts in Cleveland, is offering $40 million of 25-year convertible subordinated debentures due Feb. 1, 2009. The debentures carry an 8 1/2 percent coupon and are priced at par, through Merrill Lynch Capital Markets.

title: BANCTEC INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a tax credit of $663,000. c-After tax credits of $121,000 for the quarter and $1,030,000 for the 9 months. Year-ago results are restated to reflect the acquisition of Input Business Machines Inc. in June 1983.

title: Customs Officials Dismissed By New Nigerian Government
description: Nigeria's military Government said today that it had dismissed 240 customs officials for serious misconduct, including falsifying and forging documents and bribery.

description: An Air Force captain who faced discharge for taping and selling hundreds of copyrighted movies to his fellow officers won the right Monday to remain in the service.

Netherlands Prices
description: Producer prices for consumption and investment goods in the Netherlands rose one-tenth of 1 percent in November from October and were up 1.9 percent from a year earlier, the Central Bureau of Statistics said today. Prices for raw materials and intermediate goods rose seven-tenths of 1 percent from October and were up 1.5 percent from November 1982.

title: CONTI FOCUS: FINANCIAL PAPER
description: One of the nation's biggest commodities trading houses, the company that until 1980 advertised itself as ''Conticommodities . . . period,'' is now a lot more.

title: MACDERMID INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Including a gain of $648,000 on the sale of a subsidiary.

title: CHEESE IMPORTS: PRICES RUN THE GAMUT
description: IMPORTED 50 percent butterfat Brie was selling recently for $3.29 a pound at Fairway Fruits and Vegetables on the Upper West Side and $4.50 to $5 a pound at Rosemary Miller's on the Upper East Side. Balducci's in Greenwich Village had Swiss Emmenthaler for $4.79 a pound, while directly across town, at the East Village Cheese Store, a sign in the window advertised it for $2.99 a pound.

title: BLACK COLLEGES SURVIVE, BUT STUDENTS ARE FEWER
description: Black educators, long concerned with the survival of black colleges, now have an additional worry: the survival of black students.

title: Reynolds in Japan
description: R. J. Reynolds Tobacco International Inc. said it would spend $5 million to $10 million promoting Camel cigarettes in Japan.

title: Atlantic Richfield
description: The Atlantic Richfield Company said it would spend $575 million on the first phase of a development plan for the Lisburne Oil Reservoir on Alaska's North Slope.

title: Apple Computer
description: Apple Computer Inc. said it had signed an agreement with a Mexican company to make and market computer products in Mexico and to export them to Latin America through a new company, Apple de Mexico. Apple, which is based in Cupertino, Calif., said the agreement, its first joint venture, was part of a plan to become more aggressive in international markets. The new company will be owned 49 percent by Apple and 51 percent by Grupo Manzana of Mexico City.

title: 2-DAY CAR BAN IN CHINATOWN
description: The heart of Chinatown will be closed to all vehicles on Feb. 2 and Feb. 5 from 10 A.M. to 6 P.M. to make way for the celebration of the Chinese New Year. The Lower East Side area involved is bounded on the north by Canal Street, on the south by Worth Street, on the east by the Bowery and on the west by Baxter Street.

title: BANKING REGULATORY ACCORD SET
description: Senior Administration financial officials and Paul A. Volcker, chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, today resolved differences that had divided them for months by initialing a plan to reorganize the Government agencies that regulate commercial banks.

title: BUSINESS PEOPLE
description: Air Micronesia Drops Newly Hired President George A. Warde, a former president of both Continental and American Airlines, took a job last summer at the age of 61 as president of Air Mi cronesia, a seemingly pleasant, quiet post in which to close out a career.

description: The bodies of two young cousins were found last night in a refrigerator in a vacant apartment in Bayville, N.J., according to the police.

description: Year-ago fourth quarter share earnings include a writedown of 19 cents a share on the company's oil and gas investments.

SCENIC SUFFOLK, LAND OF SAXONS, SIZES UP THE ATOM
description: For 13 months, lawyers and environmentalists, scientists and economists have been meeting in an old malting house here arguing about the feasibility and desirability of building this country's first American-style pressurized-water nuclear power station at Sizewell, just a few miles up the East Anglian coast.

title: WRIGHT, WILLIAM E, CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Comings and Goings
description: Bill Gullickson , a right-hander who lost in salary arbitration with the Montreal Expos last year, has agreed to a new four-year contract, according to the club, which gave no financial details. . . . Juan Laporte will defend his World Boxing Council featherweight title against Wilfredo Gomez , the former superbantamweight champion, on March 31 in San Juan according to the promoter Murad Muhammad. Both fighters are natives of Puerto Rico.

title: Marietta Wins Contract
description: An industry group led by the Martin Marietta Corporation yesterday was named the winner of a five-year $684 million contract to provide technical and management expertise for the Federal Aviation Administration's $10 billion to $20 billion program to modernize the nation's air traffic control system.

title: PANEL OF HOUSE ACCEPTS REPORT ON BEIRUT BLAST
description: The House Armed Services Committee today accepted a report prepared by its Investigations subcommittee that criticizes the United States military in connection with the bombing of the Marine headquarters in Beirut.

title: NO 'AMATEURS,' MAHRE SAYS
description: Phil Mahre, the World Cup skiing champion, says that the term ''amateur'' is outdated in the Olympics, and that part of the game is getting in a plug for a sponsor.

title: TEXAS-NEW MEXICO POWER CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Slain Marine Identified
description: The Marine Corps said today that Lance Cpl. George L. Dramis of Cape May, N.J., was the man killed in Lebanon on Monday when United States Marine positions were attacked by what were thought to be Moslem gunners.

title: SPRINGS INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Including income from discontinued operations of $2,926,000 for the quarter and $5,597,000 for the year.

title: XEROX CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Michigan G.O.P. Gains Control of State Senate
description: Republicans today gained control of the Michigan Senate for the first time in a decade as voters elected two Republican legislators to replace two Democrats who were recalled after backing a tax increase.

title: Coastal Chief's Goal Sparks Stock Fight
description: Oscar S. Wyatt Jr., chairman and chief executive of the Coastal Corporation in Houston, wants very much to acquire a natural gas pipeline company that operates within Texas.

title: AN OFF-DUTY OFFICER IS SLAIN IN A DISPUTE ON A BROOKLYN STREET
description: An off-duty police officer was shot and killed early yesterday, possibly with his own gun, after he was knocked down during a dispute on a Brooklyn street, the police said.

title: Von B"ulow Witnesses May Leave the Case
description: Two important witnesses in Claus von B"ulow's effort to win a retrial on charges of attempted murder say they may tear up their affidavits and withdraw because of death threats against them.

title: Creative Arts Awards Given Four by Brandeis
description: Four persons were named yesterday as recipients of the 28th annual Brandeis University Creative Arts Awards, which recognize lifetime achievements in the arts.

title: BRICKTOP, CABARET QUEEN IN PARIS AND ROME, DEAD
description: Bricktop, the legendary singer and entertainer whose cafe society nightclubs in Paris in the 20's and in Mexico City and Rome in the postwar years drew royalty, writers and the fashionably riffraff, died in her sleep early yesterday in her apartment on West 68th Street. She was 89 years old and had been in fragile health.

title: AVON PRODUCTS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
CRITIC'S NOTEBOOK: CANDIDATES
description: THE campaign is now official, an avuncular President Reagan having announced his candidacy for re-election on Sunday night. The announcement, a five-minute paid television advertisement, was only a formality, although Mr. Reagan appeared to be speaking from the heart. John F. Kennedy possibly excepted, Mr. Reagan has used television more effectively than any other President. His appeal is not necessarily in his convictions, but in the strength in which he holds them and the way they are expressed, especially on television.

title: DEMOCRATS, IN FOREIGN POLICY DEBATE, URGE BEIRUT WITHDRAWAL
description: Seven Democratic candidates for President coalesced around their opposition to the continued presence of United States marines in Lebanon tonight in a debate at Harvard University.

title: MARQUEST MEDICAL PRODUCTS reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Maytag's Profit Rises
description: The Maytag Company said today that its earnings in the fourth quarter jumped 70.1 percent, to $14.8 million, or $1.06 a share, from $8.7 million, or 63 cents a share, a year earlier.

title: Caroline Kennedy Offers Aid to Senator Hollings
description: Caroline Kennedy has donated $500 to Senator Ernest F. Holling's Presidential campaign, saying he is more like her father, John F. Kennedy, than any of the other Democratic contenders.

title: WHAT THEY'RE BUYING AT A SELECTION OF STORES
description: ANUMBER of cheese dealers report that Brie is still the most popular cheese in New York. A glance at the buffet table at a typical social gathering readily confirms it. ''You can call Brie the new 'American' cheese, creamy and mild,'' said Rosemary Miller, who has a small cheese shop on the Upper East Side.

title: Moscow Calls for Talks To Curtail Maneuvers
description: The Soviet Union said today that it was ready to negotiate agreements on limiting military maneuvers in Europe, one of the goals of the 35-nation conference here on security and disarmament.

title: CHECKPOINT SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss.

title: Iranian Bids Lebanese Recruit Suicide Squads
description: The Speaker of the Iranian Parliament has urged the recruitment of more ''self-sacrificing youths'' to carry out suicide attacks against members of the four-nation force in Lebanon, the newspaper Islamic Republic said today.

title: SEALED AIR CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Share earnings have been adjusted for a 2-for-1 stock dividend paid in September.

title: NADER FAULTS PANEL'S REPORT ON CUTTING GOVERNMENT COST
description: A report issued today by the consumer activist Ralph Nader said that a Presidential panel last month vastly exaggerated how much the Government could trim costs and that the White House knew as early as last May that some of the panel's figures were overstated.

title: Dickerson Wins Prize
description: Eric Dickerson, the Los Angeles Rams' rookie running back who led the National Football League in rushing last season, has won a $10,000 prize after a computer determined that he was the league's most productive and consistent player. The award is sponsored by Seagram's, whose computer ranked Dickerson ahead of Joe Montana, the San Francisco quarterback, and Joe Theismann, the Washington quarterback.

title: TRW HAS 67% GAIN IN QUARTER
description: -quarter earnings climbed 67 percent, to $52.6 million, or $1.41 a share, from $31.5 million, or 83 cents a share, a year earlier. Sales rose 14 percent, to $1.38 billion, from $1.21 billion.

title: A RESTRUCTURED STEEL INDUSTRY
description: By the end of the decade, the United States steel industry will be far smaller and more concentrated, with more efficient plants more widely dispersed throughout the country producing specialized products better keyed to the individual needs of its customers.

title: SURVIVAL TACTICS OF 3 BROADWAY MUSICALS
description: The street wisdom on Broadway says that a show needs either raves or stars to succeed. With production costs in the millions of dollars and ticket prices reaching $45, there remains little of the middle ground that once existed between hits and flops. But this season three musicals are surviving in that risky territory.

title: TRUDEAU ASSAILED OVER NATO REMARK
description: Prime Minister Pierre Elliott Trudeau has run into a storm of criticism at home for remarks he made in Europe last weekend questioning the fundamental assumption of the North Atlantic alliance's nuclear strategy.

title: STAGE: NEGRO ENSEMBLE
description: in particular, blacks shunning Asian-Americans - is at the core of Velina Houston's ''American Dreams.'' The new play, which opened last night at the Negro Ensemble Company's Theater Four, has an authenticity of observation when concentrating on certain personalized family matters, but it carries with it a heavy burden of accumulated theatrical cliches.

title: O'NEILL ENDORESES MONDALE AS PRESIDENTIAL NOMINEE
description: House Speaker Thomas P. O'Neill Jr., the nation's highest-ranking elected Democrat, today endorsed Walter F. Mondale for the Democratic Presidential nomination.

title: NETS TURN BACK CLIPPERS
description: Buck Williams scored 5 points in the closing minute tonight and paved the way for the New Jersey Nets' 111- 106 victory over the San Diego Clippers at Byrne Meadowlands Arena.

title: FINDING WALLPAPER REPRODUCTIONS
description: Two small, handsome sourcebooks with information on locating historical wallpaper and fabric reproductions have recently been republished by the Preservation Press.

title: MAKING ROOM FOR BABY'S THINGS
description: ELLEN LIMAN's focus was on ''the baby space problem.'' ''When a new baby arrives, there's usually not enough space for the equipment,'' she said.

title: PEKING HEALS RIFT WITH THE DUTCH
description: China agreed today to restore diplomatic relations with the Netherlands to the ambassadorial level, after a decision by the Dutch Government not to sell any more military equipment to Taiwan.

title: TURNING ONE-ACT PLAY INTO FULL-LENGTH WORK
description: THERE are two plays entitled ''Open Admissions,'' one short, one long. The first was an explosive two-character, one-act play that ran less than 30 minutes and alerted audiences at the Ensemble Studio Theater to the dramatic intensity of the playwright Shirley Lauro. The second, which opened on Broadway this week, has two acts and 11 characters and runs more than two hours. The short play was a confrontation between a black student and his white teacher, with the student demanding that he be given an education. The new expanded version adds a narrative about the home lives of the two characters and about their place in an ineffectual open university system.

title: Air Vermont
description: Air Vermont, which grounded its planes in January under pressure from the Federal Aviation Administration and filed for bankruptcy protection this week, has been given permission to resume operations, a company official said. Joel Blumenthal, the company's vice president, said the company expected to be back in operation by Friday morning. The commuter airline voluntarily agreed to suspend operations Jan. 20 after an F.A.A. review uncovered maintenance problems that the agency said threatened flying safety.

title: Ben Zion Bokser, 76; A Rabbi and Professor
description: Rabbi Ben Zion Bokser, a leading figure in Conservative Judaism in the United States and spiritual leader for 50 years of the Forest Hills Jewish Center in Queens, died of heart disease Monday at New York Hospital. He was 76 years old and lived in Forest Hills.

title: NETWORKS' HELICOPTERSBATTLE
description: A helicopter wars update: As of two months ago, the television networks were going to recycle an idea that had worked at movie-theater box offices - new adventures featuring helicopters.

description: Kenny Index, Kenny Information Systems Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: A 'REDUCTION' ISN'T SO EASY TO PIN DOWN
description: One of the things that make the budget so complex, apart from the sheer size and scope of the Federal Government, is that the terminology related to the numbers is often used in confusingly different ways.

title: OUTLOOK FOR KEY DOMESTIC PROGRAMS
description: President Reagan's budget calls for a 3 percent overall reduction next year in spending for domestic programs whose costs are not mandated but would allow a few new or expanded ventures in areas deemed crucial to economic or technological growth or sensitive for political reasons.

title: Younger Executives Rise at Heilig-Meyers William C. Derusha, president of the Heilig-Meyers Company, a furniture retailer in the South, was named yesterday to the additional post of chief executive. The company also announced the retirements of Hyman Meyers, chairman and chief executive, and of two vice chairmen, effective June 30. The posts of chairman and vice chairman are being eliminated.
description: In a telephone interview from the company's offices in Richmond, Mr. Derusha, who is 34 years old, said the changes represented the second phase in a management transition. The first phase was in January 1983, when Mr. Derusha, who had held a variety of posts at Heilig-Meyers, was promoted from director of operations to president and chief operating officer.

title: Rozier Says He Got Alumni Assistance
description: Mike Rozier, the Nebraska running back who won the Heisman Trophy in December, acknowledged in an interview published today that he received financial help from alumni while a collegian.

title: Sperry Profit Climbs 84.3%
description: The Sperry Corporation said yesterday that higher volume in its military and aerospace operations and companywide cost-cutting contributed to an 84.3 percent profit increase in its latest quarter.

title: 1% FACTORY ORDER RISE IN MONTH
description: Orders for manufactured goods from factories rose 1 percent in December and a strong 10.6 percent for 1983, the biggest jump in four years, the Commerce Department said today.

title: ALL FEDERAL BORROWING IN '85 SEEN TOTALING $274.4 BILLION
description: The budget deficit, projected for the fiscal year beginning next Oct. 1 at $180.4 billion, represents only about two-thirds of what the Federal Government will have to borrow to pay its bills.

description: Norway today ordered five Soviet diplomats expelled and barred four others from re- entering the country, apparently for spying.

Mr. Emmerling said that both accounts together come to $1 million in billings. They were formerly handled in-house.

title: Helicopters Scarce
description: O.K., the Summer Olympics are less than six months away, you've ordered your tickets, you've picked out your wardrobe and you've made your hotel reservations. But have you reserved your helicopter? Well, you may be too late.

title: NISSAN WILL BUILD PLANT IN BRITAIN
description: The Nissan Motor Company, the maker of Datsun cars and trucks, agreed today to begin assembling cars here in 1986 in what would be the first such entry by a Japanese auto maker into the European Common Market.

title: CBS-TV Is First In Nielsen Ratings
description: The perennial CBS-TV favorites ''60 Minutes'' and ''Dallas'' led the way as the network took eight of the top spots to win the weekly Nielsen ratings in the week ending last Sunday.

title: JACKSON CANDIDACY REVIVES ALABAMA BLACK POLITICAL LIFE
description: Not long after the Rev. Jesse Jackson announced he was a candidate for the Democratic Presidential nomination, a black minister in this central Alabama river town asked himself a question.

description: The veil of mystery that surrounds the Federal Reserve's monetary policy may become a little harder to see through under a new accounting procedure that begins today.

description: Democratic leaders in Congress today derided President Reagan's efforts to reduce the budget deficit as ''tokenism'' and said they would propose their own package of spending cuts and new revenue worth at least $200 billion over three years.

title: THE DANCE: THARP TROUPE IN A PREMIERE
description: SOME choreographers might consider it just a big joke to call a new dance ''Bad Smells,'' but not Twyla Tharp, whose dance of that name received its New York premiere on Tuesday night at the Brooklyn Academy of Music. Miss Tharp was very much in earnest and, as performed by her company, Twyla Tharp Dance, ''Bad Smells'' proved to concern the stench of corruption and the exploitation of human misery.

A MICHAEL JACKSON DOCUMENTARY ON SHOWTIME
description: ON a recent trip to the Dominican Republic and Puerto Rico, this writer heard the name of one entertainer being mentioned over and over again - Michael Jackson. This, mind you, was among people who primarily speak only Spanish and really have no idea what the lyrics of the singer's latest recording hit with Paul McCartney, ''Say, Say, Say,'' are all about. They are responding to a sound and a personality. It is the kind of response that has made Mr. Jackson the top superstar of the moment.

title: Correction Post Goes to Gloria Lee
description: Gloria Lee, one of the first women in the nation to command an all-male jail, yesterday was named chief of operations of the New York City Department of Correction, the agency's highest-ranking uniformed officer.

GOING OUT GUIDE;
description: SCOPE James Van Der Zee, who died last May at age 96, was a formidable photographer whose lens captured scenes and portraits of generations of life in Harlem, in the arts, in whatever arenas he could reach. His artist's eye never failed, and much of what he photographed has become unparalleled historical evidence. An exhibition of his work opened yesterday in the City Gallery, in the city's Cultural Affairs Department's building at 2 Columbus Circle (974-1150).

title: Britoil Is Buying Amax Properties
description: The Amax Petroleum Company said it had agreed to sell 50 percent of some oil and gas properties to Britoil P.L.C. for $75 million. title: Marriott Sells Theme Park
description: The City of Santa Clara, Calif., has decided to buy the Great America theme park from the Marriott Corporation for a total of $101 million. Marriott said that, under an agreement approved by Santa Clara's City Council, the company would receive about $70 million in cash and $31 million in short-term notes in a transaction to be completed in early September.

title: MEDICAL AND THEFT COSTS GET SMALLER DEDUCTIONS
description: Taxpayers who hope to write off medical expenses or casualty losses incurred last year may be disappointed to find they either do not qualify for the deduction or will receive a much smaller benefit than in the past.

title: DEMOCRATS VOW TO REDUCE PENTAGON OUTLAY FOR 1985
description: Secretary of Defense Caspar W. Weinberger told Congress today that growth rates in military spending could be slowed after next year if Congress approved the big increase that President Reagan proposed for the fiscal year 1985.

title: BAZAARS OF INDIA ARE NOW A TOYLAND OF HIGH TECH
description: Inside the Music Shop here, there are the sights and sounds of a revolution. India, dominated by technologies dating from the 19th century to antiquity, seems to be on the brink of plunging into the age of electronics.

title: Dow Off 8.27 Points in Heavy Trading
description: Stock prices fell moderately yesterday in continued heavy trading as institutional money managers intensified their selloff of companies that have announced unfavorable developments. The Dow Jones industrial average fell 8.27 points, to 1,212.31, bringing its net loss for the last 11 sessions to 59 points.

description: President Ferdinand E. Marcos signed into law today the four constitutional amendments approved in a referendum last Friday, among them one restoring the office of vice president.

description: Foreign Minister Jaime Del Valle of Chile said today that it would be inappropriate to grant an Israeli request to expel former Nazi officer Walter Rauff.

description: A former partner in a New York law firm who disappeared in Peking in 1982 was arrested and sentenced to 15 years in prison for espionage, a Chinese official said today.

description: He was all decked out in the outfit matching that of his teammates: the gray sport jacket, light blue shirt, navy blue tie, gray slacks, brown boots. Brent Rushlaw, the driver of the No. 1 two- and four- man bobsleds for the 1984 United States Olympic Team, stopped in Manhattan yesterday morning for one last appearance before he and his teammates leave for Sarajevo, Yugoslavia.

title: FOOD HAVING EDB FOUND ON SHELVES
description: The State Department of Public Health said today that 96 food products commonly found on store shelves contain varying degrees of a pesticide known to cause cancer in laboratory animals, and it recommended that consumers return the products.

description: On the eve of a Securities and Exchange Commission vote, a key Congressional committee chairman has asked the agency to withold its approval of a proposal to start trading on the floor of the New York Stock Exchange in options of the shares of the seven regional telephone companies split off from the American Telephone and Telegraph Company on Jan. 1.

title: PRESIDENT SENDS HOPEFUL MESSAGE WITH 1985 BUDGET
description: President Reagan today proposed a $925.5 billion budget for the fiscal year 1985 that calls on Congress to continue cutting domestic spending for the rest of the decade, to delay major tax increases and to move forward with a military buildup.

title: CITY CLEARS WAY FOR A COMPANY RULED NEGLIGENT
description: The New York City Department of Investigation said yesterday that it had reversed a 1982 recommendation that the Bowman-Procope insurance brokerage concern be barred from city business. The department's head said that some of the original findings against the concern were ''unfair.''

title: Credit Arranged By Port Authority The arrangement of a $150 million revolving credit facility for the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey in support of its commercial paper program was announced by the Marine Midland Bank. The two-year credit renews the $100 million facility the bank arranged last November to support the sale of the Port Authority's tax-exempt commercial paper.
description: Besides Marine Midland, which is the lead bank, other banks participating are the Bank of New York, First Jersey National Bank, First National State Bank of New Jersey, National State Bank and United Jersey Bank.

title: MONDALE LEADS RIVALS IN FUND RAISING: REAGAN PACE FASTER
description: Walter F. Mondale raised $3.4 million in the last three months of 1983, easily topping his rivals for the Democratic Presidential nomination, but he still trailed President Reagan in raising campaign money.

title: Miami-Auburn in Opener
description: Coach Pat Dye, who asserted Auburn's claim to national football supremacy after last season but now concedes it to Miami, will get a chance to even the score at the start of next season. Auburn and Miami have accepted invitations to meet on Aug. 27 in the second Kickoff Classic at Giants Stadium.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: The Advertising column in Business Day on Tuesday included an erroneous identification by Young & Rubicam of Donald M. Casey's position there. He is director of business development worldwide.

description: A Long Way Since Syosset

title: Tenneco Net Off 16.3%
description: Tenneco Inc., hurt by lower prices for crude oil and condensate, said yesterday that net income in the fourth quarter dropped 16.3 percent, to $241 million, or $1.63 a share, from $288 million, or $2.04 a share, in the fourth quarter of 1982. Revenues slipped 1.5 percent, to $3.84 billion, from $3.90 billion.

title: PENTAGON REPORT RENEWS CRITICISM
description: A Pentagon policy analyst has prepared a study that may cast doubt on Defense Secretary Caspar W. Weinberger's prediction to Congress today that it should be possible to slow the growth of military spending significantly within two years.

title: VILLANOVA DOWNS ST. JOHN'S BY 64-63
description: Sometime this season Lou Carnesecca will get the victory he needs to become the top-winning basketball coach at St. John's. But not last night, when the Redmen suffered a 64-63 loss to Villanova at Alumni Hall. And probably not Saturday, when St. John's meets No. 2-ranked DePaul.

description: b-Net income. The company is listed on the Toronto and Montreal stock exchanges.

title: National Zoo Chief Named
description: Michael H. Robinson, the deputy director of the Smithsonian Tropical Research Institute in Panama, was named Tuesday to become director of the National Zoo. Mr. Robinson is an expert in animal behavior and a tropical biologist. He will succeed Dr. Theodore H. Reed, who resigned last year after 28 years at the zoo.

title: AMERICAN BUSINESS PRODUCTS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Share earnings are adjusted to reflect a 3-for-2 stock split paid Dec. 15, 1983.

title: THURSDAY, FEBRUARY 2, 1984 International
description: Democratic legislators were accused by the White House of ''playing politics'' on the Lebanon issue and drafting a resolution that ''aids and abets'' enemies of peace in the Middle East. President Reagan's spokesman issued a strong denunciation of the House Democrats' resolution, which would call on Mr. Reagan to begin ''a prompt and orderly withdrawal'' of the American marines from Beirut. (Page A1, Column 6.) Deploring ''Sadat,'' a mini-series about the life of Egypt's assassinated leader, Egypt has banned all films produced or distributed by Columbia Pictures. Abdel Hamid Radwan, Egypt's Minister of Culture, reportedly charged that Columbia's docudrama, which appeared on American television, contained ''historical errors that distort the accomplishments of the Egyptian people.'' (A1:4-6.)

title: CORRECTION
description: A brief report in Weekend on Jan. 27 about the exhibition ''The Precious Legacy: Judaic Treasures From the Czechoslovak State Collections'' gave an incorrect location. The show will be on view through March 18 at the Bass Museum of Art in Miami and will open April 15 at the Jewish Museum, Fifth Avenue and 92d Street.

title: DO THE LARGE DEFICITS MATTER?
description: Six prominent economists were asked by Kenneth N. Gilpin of The New York Times whether the Federal budget deficits, now near $200 billion a year, make a difference. Following are excerpts from their replies: Alan Reynolds Vice president, Polyconomics Inc. Little Cause for Worry

title: First Interstate
description: The First Interstate Bancorp filed a shelf registration with the Securities and Exchange Commission today for an offering of as much as $400 million in notes, with terms to be determined by market conditions at the time of sale. The Los Angeles-based company said it would use the proceeds mainly to invest in or to extend credit to its banking subsidiaries.

title: South Africa Trade Gap
description: South Africa recorded its first monthly trade deficit in a year and a half in December, the Commissioner for Customs and Excise said today. The deficit totaled about $158 million.

title: PROPOSED CURB ON BONDS WORRIES STATE OFFICIALS
description: New York City and New York State officials said today that a proposal in the Reagan Administration's budget to restrict the use of tax-exempt bonds could severely curtail plans for an array of construction projects ranging from low-income housing to facilities for disposal of solid wastes.

title: Antitrust Chief to Ease Regulations
description: J. Paul McGrath, the new head of the Justice Department's antitrust division, indicated yesterday that he would follow the lead of his predecessor, William F. Baxter, in easing the way for some forms of economic activity that have traditionally been regarded as anticompetitive.

title: NEW YORK'S FRINGE AIRPORTS REPORT PEAK GAINS IN TRAFFIC
description: The smaller commercial airports in the metropolitan area, from Hartford to Atlantic City, set air passenger traffic records last year.

Ripken Gets $4 Million
description: Just how valuable is a most valuable player? In current American League dollars, it comes to $4 million over a four-year contract. That's the deal Cal Ripken signed with the Baltimore Orioles yesterday, and according to the 23-year-old shortstop's agent, Ron Shapiro, the contract represents the biggest one ever negotiated for a third-year player.

title: For Leonard's Foe, A Dubious Benefit
description: He was introduced yesterday as ''the opponent,'' a harsh but fair assessment of Kevin Howard's chances Feb. 25 when, in all likelihood, he will go down in boxing history with Joe Rindone.

description: The worst fire here since 1976 swept three row houses in an impoverished neighborhood today, killing seven people, including four children, and injuring 15 others.

description: Marcus Dupree wants to play football in the 1984 season, preferably for a college team. But until he determines that such an opportunity exists, he will work part time at the Hall Mortuary in Hattiesburg, Miss.

description: Senator Jim Sasser, Democrat of Tennessee, said today that the Pentagon ''may be trying to subvert the Congress'' by building ''a military infrastructure in Honduras that is far beyond anything necessary for the military exercises being undertaken there.''

title: NICARAGUANS' HEALTH
description: The United States-supported war against Nicaragua hurts ordinary citizens of that country far more than its Government. The White House still contends that support for the ''contras,'' or counterrevolutionaries, will encourage negotiations and promote democratic reform. In fact, the death, disease and forced migration caused by the contras and paid for with United States tax dollars can only lessen the chance of reaching a workable solution to the problems of Central America.

title: E.E.C. Steel Plans Delayed
description: Belgium, Luxembourg and West Germany were the only three members of the European Economic Community to submit complete steel restructuring plans in time for the Jan. 31 deadline, a Common Market spokesman said today. France sent documents, but their content has not yet been examined, the spokesman said, adding that other members had either sent in partial restructuring plans or none at all. The deadline was set in June 1983.

title: Algeran Files Chapter 11

title: Pantry Pride Bid For Devon Stores
description: Pantry Pride Inc. said it had agreed in principle to acquire the Devon Stores Corporation, in a share swap and cash offer valued at nearly $84 million. Under terms of the proposal, each share of Devon's common stock would be exchanged for 1.478 shares of Pantry Pride plus $8.50 in cash, representing an aggregate of about 7,144,000 common shares of Pantry Pride, subject to adjustment, and approximately $41 million in cash.

title: PBS REPORTS ON A NETWORK ANCHOR
description: WHO is an anchor? What is he? He is front man for a network's news department, of course, a symbol of its hopes, aspirations and high moral and journalistic purpose. Beyond that, he (there are she's, but only on weekends and at odd hours) is charged with reading short sentences, usually written by someone else, while looking toward a camera. It is honorable, well-paid and interesting work.

title: Reporter Is Questioned By K.G.B. in Moscow

title: WEEKS OF RANGERS GOING TO FARM CLUB
description: With only a point separating them at the All-Star Game break, the first- place Rangers and the Islanders made their first moves of the second part of the season yesterday.

title: MUSIC: OZAWA LEADS BOSTON SYMPHONY IN MAHLER
description: THE idea behind the ''blockbuster'' programming that has become so much a feature of our concert life in recent years is to gather the full strength of a symphony orchestra plus attendant chorus and soloists for the recreation of some huge, seminal composition. It is meant to be a maximum effort by all concerned, and to be appreciated as such by an audience primed for the unconventional.

title: Reynolds Theme Line For Cigarettes in Japan
description: R.J. Reynolds Tobacco International, which announced Tuesday that it would be the first American company to market cigarettes in Japan under that country's new, relaxed regulations regarding foreign cigarette sales, will be using the theme line ''Discover the Camel Taste Experience.''

title: LEE ENTERPRISES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
NEW U.S. PANEL NARROWS DEFINITION OF CIVIL RIGHTS
description: What is a civil right? The new majority on the United States Commission on Civil Rights appears to be defining it narrowly as the right not to be discriminated against because of factors like race. For the old majority, the definition was broader, taking in certain social and economic programs without which, it was argued, true equality could not be achieved.

title: Louisville Gas
description: The Louisville Gas and Electric Company said it disagreed with the Energy Systems Research Group, Boston consultants to the Kentucky Public Service Commission, that work on a $680 million coal-fired plant for the utility could be delayed until 1991 because of available power from other utilities.

title: NEW TONE AND TILT ON LABOR BOARD
description: Donald L. Dotson, after a contentious first year as chairman of the National Labor Relations Board, insists he is still misunderstood by his critics and often misinterpreted by the press.

title: COUNTDOWN PROCEEDING FOR NEXT SPACE SHUTTLE
description: The countdown was proceeding smoothly, the weather forecast was favorable, and so, as they say here, all systems were ''go'' today for the launching of another space shuttle mission Friday morning.

title: WESTERN AIR LINES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Including an extraordinary gain of $100,000 for the quarter and $41.5 million for the year. c-Including an extraordinary gain of $15.9 million.

title: FONAR CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-No shipments were made in the year-ago periods and thus no sales figures were reported. c-Net loss.

title: Ha'penny Is Done For After Seven Centuries
description: For nearly seven centuries the halfpenny was one of the most useful coins of the realm, but it has been shrunk by decimalization, devalued by inflation and rendered nearly useless. Next month the Royal Mint will stop making it.

title: Landmark Works vs. Buildings
description: The New York Historical Society wants to use its landmarked building as the base of an income- producing apartment house. It says it must have more income or perish. St. Bartholomew's Episcopal Church wants to replace its landmarked Community House with a giant office tower to support the church and expand its works. The bitter arguments that these proposals evoke show that while landmarking has saved many valuable buildings, it has failed to provide a good way to judge the hardship it may impose on nonprofit institutions.

title: IDRIS SHAH, MALAY SULTAN, DIES
description: Sultan Idris Shah, the ruler of Perak state and the front-runner in the election next week of Malaysia's next King, died of a heart attack Tuesday, a palace spokesman said today. He was 59 years old.

title: BERG ENTERPRISES reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes income from discontinued operations of $59,564, or 1 cent a share, for the quarter, and $30,734, or 1 cent a share, for the 6 months. Share earnings are fully diluted.

title: Move to Dismiss Sims Suit Loses
description: A Federal judge refused today a defense request to throw out a lawsuit filed by the star running back Billy Sims against his former agent, Jerry Argovitz, and the Houston Gamblers of the United States Football League. The suit will determine whether Sims may stay with the Detroit Lions, as he wants to, or must report to the Gamblers if he is to continue playing professional football.

title: Charboneau Signs Pact
description: Joe Charboneau, the 1980 American League rookie of the year who had been reduced to playing semipro ball in Buffalo last year, has signed a minor league contract with the Pittsburgh Pirates. As an outfielder with the Cleveland Indians, Charboneau batted .289 with 87 runs batted in and 23 home runs in 1980, but was sent to the minors in 1981 and has never made it back.

title: NEW EMPHASIS FOR INTERGROUP
description: National Intergroup Inc. is a company that dropped the word steel out of its name last fall. Now it is seeking to drop out of steel altogether.

title: GENERAL PESTORED IN WEST GERMANY
description: Chancellor Helmut Kohl announced today that Defense Minister Manfred W"orner and a four- star general whom he dismissed had reached a gentlemanly reconciliation that permitted the Cabinet official to remain in office and restore the general to active duty.

title: CHYRON CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Share earnings reflect a 3-for-2 stock split paid November 1983.

title: TNot Just Mr. Nice Guy
description: ATLANTA - I visited Andrew Young here the other day, in his new role as Mayor, and found that he still says out loud what other people think to themselves. This time it was what many Democrats think about Walter Mondale: that he is going to be the candidate - but to be an effective one, he will have to show that he can be tough under fire.

title: KEARNEY-NATIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
TABLE LISTING DEFICIT GETS A REMOTE HOME
description: One of the curious things in President Reagan's budget for the fiscal year 1985 is the placement of the table that shows spending, revenue and the deficit.

title: Mortgages Set Record
description: The nation's savings and loan associations made loans to home buyers at a record pace in December, closing a total of $14.1 billion in mortgages, the Government said today.

title: NORTHERN INDIANA PUBLIC SERVICE reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
