title: UNIVERSAL DEVELOPMENT reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Buyout of Ticor For $271.3 Million
description: Ticor, the nation's largest title insurance firm, said it is being bought out for $271.3 million by a group of investors led by Harold Geneen, former chairman of the ITT Corporation. Besides title insurance, Ticor is one of the largest residential mortgage insurance firms and provides real estate tax services, home warranty insurance and life insurance.

title: TOP AIDE LEAVES METS
description: Almost two weeks after they lost Tom Seaver to the Chicago White Sox, the Mets lost a key executive yesterday when Lou Gorman left to become vice president in charge of baseball operations for the Boston Red Sox.

title: DOMTAR INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a special gain of $800,000 for the quarter and a special charge of $700,000 for the year. c-Net loss after special charges of $100,000 for the quarter and $10,700,000 for the year.

title: RECORD U.S. REFUNDING SET
description: The announcement of a $16.25 billion refunding by the Treasury Department, the largest Federal financing ever, was largely shrugged off in the credit markets yesterday. Interest rates fell slightly.

title: TOWARD A DEMILITARIZED CENTRAL AMERICA
description: To the Editor:

title: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES
description: American Can Plans Offering by Subsidiary

title: Celtics Win Seventh Straight BOSTON, Feb. 1 (UPI) - Larry Bird scored 32 points, grabbed 8 rebounds and made 7 assists tonight in pacing the Boston Celtics to a 119-110 victory over the Kansas City Kings.
description: It was the their seventh straight for the Celtics.

title: Two Lebanese Soldiers Killed in Beirut Clash BEIRUT, Lebanon, Feb. 1 (AP) - Shiite Moslem militiamen killed two Lebanese Army soldiers in a firefight today.
description: Walid Jumblatt, the Syrian-backed Druse leader, said that a new round of full-scale civil warfare was ''inescapable'' in Lebanon.

title: REAGAN SEEKING SMALL CUTS IN AID PROGRAMS FOR POOR
description: President Reagan's new budget proposes small reductions in Federal spending for food stamps, welfare, job training and social services. Federal health programs would continue to grow, but beneficiaries would be asked to pay more of the cost.

title: F.C.C. Is Petitioned To Continue Regulation
description: The National Association of Broadcasters has petitioned the Federal Communications Commission to continue regulating call signs - those four-letter combinations that identify radio and television stations.

title: SAVING OLD SHACKS IN SAN FRANCISCO
description: SAN FRANCISCO OCCASIONALLY you can see them on a San Francisco street: tiny, old wooden cottages, usually in clusters of two or three, set back from the sidewalk in leafy yards.

title: A CHINESE NEW YEAR DINNER IS A SALUTE TO THE ELDERLY
description: ''IVE never tried Chinese food,'' confessed Freda Gibson, poking at a mysterious- looking plate of meat-filled dumplings. ''It has always seemed so, well, foreign.'' For Mrs. Gibson, a native New Zealander, and more than a dozen other older people, it was a night of many firsts.

title: SYSCON CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Year-ago share earnings reflect a loss of 7 cents a share due to an adverse abritration ruling which the company is contesting.

title: SERVICE MERCHANDISE CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
VACU-DRY CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
TAR HEELS GO TO 18-0
description: -The reserve guard Buzz Peterson scored a career-high 19 points to lead unbeaten North Carolina to a 97-75 victory over Clemson in an Atlantic Coast Conference game tonight.

title: Reagan Campaign Style Is Aimed at Security
description: Concern about President Reagan's security is directing the style of his re- election campaign, which is aimed at appearances before smaller crowds and at less contact with voters.

title: SCOUTING
description: Student Aid

title: Bridge: Intrafinesse Is a Smart Play Requiring Some Explication
description: There is one maneuver in play that is virtually unknown to players below the expert level. It requires technique, distributional assessment and psychological awareness, and is called the intrafinesse.

title: EPSCO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss.

title: Coach's Job Is Safe
description: The Pirates' general manager, Pete Peterson, says he's not going to discipline Joe Lonnett for the strong criticism of the team made by the third base coach in an interview with Lonnett's hometown paper, the Beaver County (Pa.) Times. In the interview, Lonnett praised and criticized Pirate players, scouts and front-office decisions with blunt comments such as outfielder Lee Mazzilli ''cannot play defense any place,'' and Lee Lacy would ''hurt you wherever you put him.'' Peterson said Lonnett was entitled to his opinions, but Manager Chuck Tanner said he thought Lonnett had made a mistake and was not hired as the third base coach in order ''to make opinions on everybody for public consumption.''

title: RADIOACTIVE STEEL RODS RETRIEVED IN SOUTHWEST
description: Officials of the Federal Nuclear Regulatory Commission and state experts in New Mexico, Colorado and Arizona say they have found most of the radioactive reinforcing rods that were shipped here from Mexico, but state officials are waiting for word on how they will be disposed of. Some of them are already embedded in concrete in buildings in the Southwest.

title: FIRST FINANCIAL SAVINGS & LOAN (WISCONSIN) (O) reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Mass for Bricktop Saturday
description: A funeral mass for Bricktop, the singer and nightclub hostess who entertained cafe society at her clubs in Paris, Mexico City and Rome for more than 40 years, will be celebrated Saturday at noon at St. Malachy's Roman Catholic Church, 239 West 49th Street, between Broadway and Eighth Avenue.

title: Houston May Bid For Its Own Shares
description: The Houston Natural Gas Corporation, in a new step to fight off a takeover by the Coastal Corporation, said yesterday that it was ''contemplating'' an offer to buy ''a significant number'' of its own shares for more than $68 a share - the price being offered by the Coastal Corporation.

title: SCAN-OPTICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Including extraordinary credits of $95,000 for the quarter and $219,000 for the year.

title: New Bond Trust Keyed to Safety Paine, Webber, Jackson & Curtis announced the formation of a municipal bond trust composed entirely of municipal bonds secured by Federal Government securities that are being held in escrow. The brokerage firm said the fund was ''developed for investors seeking the highest degree of safety in tax-exempt securities.''
description: Municipal bonds are backed by Government securities held in escrow when a state or local government issues new bonds and invests the proceeds in Government securities, using the interest and principal to repay an old bond issue. State and local governments use this ''pre-refunding'' technique to reduce their interest expense or eliminate some restriction in the original bond issue.

title: Addendum
description: * BBDO International to purchase a substantial minority interest in the Hannaford Company.

title: YUGOSLAV PRESIDENT HOLDS A MEETING WITH REAGAN
description: President Mika Spiljak of Yugoslavia told President Reagan today that the Soviet Union would like to return to the suspended arms control talks and that American flexibility was needed to advance the dialogue, a senior United States official said.

title: NINA BRITO
description: Nina Brito, a former dancer in the National Ballet of Mexico and Ballet Folklorico of Mexico, died Monday at New York Hospital.

title: No Headline
description: Firefighter's Bias Suit In Iowa Goes to a Jury

title: RUSSIA ASSAILS BUDGET PROPOSED BY REAGAN
description: The official Soviet Government press agency Tass said today that President Reagan's budget was aimed at assuring ''military superiority'' over the Soviet Union.

title: Convertible Bonds Of Japan Advance LONDON, Feb. 1 (Reuters) - Japanese bonds that are convertible into equity rose in price amid very active trading in European markets following strength in Tokyo stock prices, dealers said today. The Orient Leasing 5 1/4 percent convertible bond, maturing in 1998, rose 12 1/4 points.
description: Fixed-interest bonds denominated in United States dollars were little changed in dull trading.

title: Quotations of the Day
description: ''The failure in the Administration's policy has led to widespread concern among the American people that continued participation by United States armed forces in the multinational force in Lebanon is not in the national interest.''

title: Key Banks Merger
description: The Depositors Corporation of Augusta, Me., said approval had been received from state regulatory authorities for Key Banks Inc., of Albany, to acquire Depositors.

description: b-Including a gain of $727,000 for the quarter and year from the sale of land. c-Net losses after losses from discontinued operations of $6,942,000 for the quarter and $9,525,000 for the year.

title: A Budget of Politics and Pretense
description: What President Reagan calls his fiscal 1985 budget is more like a sales pitch, a campaign speech. He claims economic achievement that isn't his. He promises unprecedented prosperity despite deficits that threaten to destroy it. And he evidently hopes that not many people will catch on, or care, before Election Day.

title: A Duracell Closing
description: Duracell Inc. said it would close its lithium battery manufacturing plant in North Tarrytown at the end of the year, leaving 200 employees without jobs. John Bergman, a spokesman at Duracell's Bethel, Conn., headquarters, said the plant had become unprofitable. Vito Gentile, president of Local 434 of the International Union of Electrical Radio and Machine Workers, which represents workers at the plant, said Duracell had told the union that the high costs of taxes, fuel and upkeep were responsible for the shutdown.

title: 2 Developers Sue On Shearson Deal
description: Two developers have charged in a suit that city officials violated a contract the developers had to arrange construction on a city-owned site.

title: DIGILOG INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a pre-tax charge of $153,674 for interest charges and legal expenses in connection with an ongoing S.E.C. investigation.

title: BRIEFING
description: Class War in Color

title: 2 From Soviet Better Marks
description: Sergei Bubka of the Soviet Union reached 19 feet 1 inch in the pole vault and his teammate, Igor Paklin, cleared 7-8 3/4 in the high jump to set unofficial world indoor marks at an international track and field meet today. Bubka bettered his two-week-old mark of 19- 3/4, and Paklin bettered the previous mark of 7-8 1/2 set by a countryman, Vladimir Yashchenko, on March 12, 1978.

title: Triathlon Plans
description: Although plans are incomplete for a triathlon in New York this summer, representatives of the Road Runners Club, which would coordinate the event, met last week with officers of the Manhattan Island Swimming Association for a briefing.

title: RECITAL: MONSERRAT ALAVEDRA
description: MONTSERRAT ALAVEDRA, a soprano from Barcelona, Spain, who also teaches in Seattle, gave half her song recital in Alice Tully Hall Monday night over to Rossini, Mozart and Wolf. The rest went to music from Spain, with items from Granados, Toldra and Rodrigo plus four 15th-century Sephardic songs.

title: U.S. STEEL SEEKS A RIVAL AT COST OF $975 MILLION
description: The United States Steel Corporation, the nation's largest steelmaker, announced yesterday that it had agreed to acquire the National Steel Corporation, the seventh largest, for close to $1 billion.

title: REPORTS OF INSIDER TRADING
description: The New York and American stock exchanges issued yesterday their latest reports of changes in the shareholdings of officers, directors and large stockholders in companies whose shares are listed on the exchanges.

title: Third-Party Candidate Wins Ruling on Funds
description: The Federal Election Commission ruled today that, for the first time, third-party candidates can qualify for matching funds for primary elections.

title: FLORIDA G.O.P. SEEKING CUBAN VOTES
description: For Maria Barros, who directs the Department of Latin Affairs for Dade County, the telephone calls have become an almost daily occurrence.

title: NEW FLAWS PUT 162 BUSES FROM GRUMMAN OFF DUTY
description: New flaws forced transit officials to take one-sixth of New York City's Grumman Flxible buses out of service yesterday for an indefinite period.

title: LOVE WAS IN THE AIR
description: Some people will remember the

title: FOUL PLAY AT MUSEUM AND HITCHCOCK DID IT
description: On Oct. 2, 1955, a caricature in profile of a rotund and baldish man appeared on television screens across the country to introduce the first episode of a new series. The caricature was followed by the shadow of the man, also in profile, and then by the man himself, who throughout the series would comment with macabre humor on the program the viewer was about to see.

title: Panel to Pay for Radio Talks
description: The White House, yielding to pressure from Democrats and radio broadcasters, announced today that President Reagan's regular Saturday radio address would now be paid for by his re-election campaign committee.

title: Thyssen Steel's Loss Wider
description: The Thyssen A.G. Steel Group, Europe's biggest publicly owned steel company, said today that its loss widened in the latest fiscal year to 550 million marks, or about $199 million.

title: RTE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
BancOklahoma Sets Merger Accord
description: The boards of Fidelity of Oklahoma Inc. and the BancOklahoma Corporation said they had approved a definitive merger agreement. Under the agreement, Fidelity shareholders would receive one share of BancOklahoma for each of the 2.61 million Fiedelity shares outstanding. Based on today's bid price of $19.50 for BancOklahoma in over-the-counter trading, the deal is worth about $50.8 million.

title: Bruce Curry Charged
description: Bruce Curry , who lost his World Boxing Council super lightweight championship to Bill Costello last Sunday, was arrested in Las Vegas, Nev., yesterday on charges he fired several shots at his trainer, Jesse Reid , following an altercation at a gym, the police said. Curry was booked for assault with a deadly weapon and carrying a concealed weapon.

title: Not This Season
description: Kenny Hutchinson , an Arkansas freshman, has finally passed a New York State high school competency test - but not in time to join the Razorback basketball team this season, according to a ruling by the Southwest Conference. Hutchinson, who attended Martin Luther King High School in New York but did not qualify for graduation last June, had begun practicing with the Razorbacks this week after learning that he had passed the test on his second attempt. According to Coach Eddie Sutton , however, conference officials informed him that Hutchinson could neither practice nor play with the team because he was not eligible at the beginning of the school year.

title: Sudanese Rebels Seize Chevron Oil Installation
description: Secessionist guerrillas overran the American-operated Chevron Oil Company complex at Bentiu in the southern Sudan today, killing three foreign workers and wounding at least seven others, Western diplomats said.

description: The Justice Department filed suit in Federal District Court today charging the city, Mayor Kenneth A. Gibson and other law enforcement officials with ''egregious and flagrant unconstitutional conditions'' in the city's jails.

description: They are Donald Malawsky, S.E.C. regional administrator for the New York region, and Edward Kwalwasser, associate director of the division of market regulation at the commission in Washington.

description: A labor dispute at The Times of London was settled today and the paper will reappear on Saturday after seven days off the streets, unions and management announced.

title: Views Divided on Rules on Political Broadcasts
description: The Senate Commerce Committee, after hearing nothing but endorsements earlier this week for a bill to repeal laws regulating broadcasters' treatment of politics and public issues, has been told that the proposal posed ''a serious danger to the proper functioning of our democratic system.''

description: The National Defense University, the nation's top military school, is in ferment as it seeks to illuminate critical issues for the makers of military policy as well as to educate the generals and admirals of tomorrow.

title: SANDINISTA PROMISES OPPOSITION WILL GET ELECTION ASSISTANCE
description: A high-ranking Nicaraguan official said today that the Government was prepared to grant financial subsidies and guarantee television and radio time to opposition parties in presidential elections promised for 1985.

title: Liquidation Plan Of Heizer Set
description: The Heizer Corporation will be liquidated and dissolved under a plan approved by the company's board, according to documents filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission. The plan calls for the sale of all assets with the proceeds distributed among stockholders.

title: AIR MIDWEST INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes a pre-tax gain of $243,000 from the sale of certain landing rights.

title: BRITISH COLUMBIA FOREST PRODUCTS reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The company is listed on the Toronto, Montreal, and Vancouver stock exchanges.

title: Eubie Blake Tribute
description: A concert marking the 101st anniversary of the birth of the composer, pianist and singer Eubie Blake will be given Sunday at 7 P.M. in St. Peter's Church, Lexington Avenue and 54th Street. Mr. Blake, who was born Feb. 7, 1883, died last February, five days after his 100th birthday. Performers at the three-hour concert, a retrospective of Blake songs and compositions, will include Gregory Hines, Honi Coles, Jon Hendricks, Ruby Dee, Ossie Davis, Frank Owens, Jeree Palmer, Dick Hyman, Emme Kemp, Terry Waldo, Max Morath and the Eubie Blake Children's Theater Choir. Voluntary contributions will be accepted.

title: A.F.L.-C.I.O. URGED TO STEP INTO UNION STRUGGLE
description: A New York-based hospital workers' union that has been involved in a bitter fight with its parent organization took the unusual step yesterday of asking the A.F.L.-C.I.O. to guarantee its independence.

title: JUDGE SAYS AILING MAN, 85, MAY FAST TO DEATH
description: An 85-year-old former college president who has been fasting in a Syracuse nursing home to hasten his own death should be permitted to die, a state judge ruled yesterday.

title: INTEREST RATES DOWN SLIGHTLY
description: Interest rates fell slightly in the credit markets yesterday in very light trading as traders awaited the auction next week of $16.25 billion of Treasury notes and bonds.

title: Indiana Hotel Fire Kills 3
description: A fire today in a downtown hotel killed three people and forced 25 to evacuate the building, the authorities said.

title: FELONIES IN SUBWAY FALL FOR FIRST TIME IN 4 YEARS
description: Major crime on the subways declined last year for the first time in four years, Transit Authority officials said yesterday.

title: Occidental Earnings Climb
description: The Occidental Petroleum Corporation, the nation's ninth-largest energy company, said yesterday that its fourth-quarter earnings jumped to $246 million, or $1.74 share, from $2 million a year earlier. Net income for the fourth quarter of 1982 translated into a loss on a per share basis after the payment of preferred share dividends.

title: Patrick Sky to Sing
description: The singer-songwriter Patrick Sky will make one of his infrequent New York appearances tonight at Folk City (254-8449), 130 West Third Street near the Avenue of the Americas. Shows begin at 8 and 11 P.M., and tickets are $6.

description: Source Perrier S.A., the French mineral water group, said today that its profit jumped 49 percent in the year ended Sept. 30, 1983. Perrier said it earned 176.8 million francs.

title: DESIGNER OF JEWELRY MAKE LOVE BRACELET
description: Aldo Cipullo, a jewelry designer who was perhaps best known for the Love Bracelet he designed for Cartier that locks around the wearer's wrist, died Tuesday at St. Vincent's Hospital after suffering two heart attacks Sunday. He was 42 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Rep. Shannon Enters Race for Senate Seat
description: Representative James M. Shannon today declared his candidacy for the United States Senate seat being vacated by Paul E. Tsongas, a Democrat, and said he had the backing of the House Speaker, Thomas P. O'Neill Jr.

title: HOUSE LISTS AS CHILD ABUSE DENIAL OF CARE TO NEWBORNS
description: The House passed legislation today expanding the definition of child abuse to include the denial of care to newborn infants who have life-threatening handicaps.

title: THE CHOICE IN BEVERAGES
description: Once upon a time, one could wander into a traditional Cantonese restaurant in Chinatown and find six or eight elderly Chinese men dining together, enthusiastically. In the middle of the table, as often as not, was a fifth of Four Roses or Early Times or some decent brand of Scotch or even a bottle of brandy. So much for what to drink with Chinese meals.

title: A.T. & T. SETS JOINT VENTURE
description: The American Telephone and Telegraph Company and the United Technologies Corporation said yesterday that they had agreed in principle to form a joint venture to provide telecommunications services to multi- tenant office buildings.

title: 'DEAR MAESTRO,' SET IN ITALY
description: ''Dear Maestro'' was shown as part of last year's New Directors/New Films Series under the title ''Chopin.'' Following are excerpts from Janet Maslin's review that appeared in The New York Times on March 21. The film opens today at the Lincoln Plaza 3, Broadway between 62d and 63d Streets.

description: DON'T fool around with gigolos, especially a gigolo whose fondest wish is to open a restaurant. Because this sort of gigolo is unreliable, it's best not to ignore his artichokes vinaigrette and, for heaven's sake, don't upset him when he's about to dazzle you with a spectacular entree. In anger, he just might flambe more than the steak Diane.

title: Chinese Program

title: NORTH AFRICAN THREAT
description: Outbreaks last month of bloody street violence in both Tunisia and Morocco were apparently set off by Government increases in basic food prices. Yet in both cases, the upheavals can be linked to deeper dissatisfaction among young people drawn to Islamic fundamentalism. The United States has a considerable interest in helping both countries deal with the economic and social problems that have nourished these fundamentalist movements.

title: CHAD APPEARS TO BE DRIVING REBELS BACK
description: Further indications that rebels in Chad were being pushed back in heavy fighting were reported here today by diplomats and French officials.

description: A vast tank, rocket and artillery battle erupted today between the Lebanese Army and anti-Government Druse and Shiite militiamen in Beirut and across the surrounding hills.

title: Radioactive Pedestals Going Back to Mexico
description: Workers at a restaurant supply concern today began loading thousands of radioactive metal table pedestals onto trucks so they can be returned to Mexico, where the metal was contaminated in a scrap yard, company officials said today.

title: DAVID C. NOYES 3D
description: David C. Noyes 3d, an All American intercollegiate sailor and a teacher of history, died of cancer Tuesday at the Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center. He was 34 years old and lived in Cold Spring Harbor, L.I.

title: A Winfield Gesture
description: Dave Winfield of the Yankees attended the Conn Smythe sports celebrity dinner in Toronto last night, and the only seagulls in sight were the two depicted in flight with another gull superimposed on a red maple leaf, all part of a painting Winfield commissioned in order to help the dinner raise money for the Easter Seal Society. The inscription, written by Winfield, read: ''To the Canadian people, committed to the preservation of their values and resources.''

title: 5 PEOPLE KILLED AND 18 INJURED IN JERSEY BLAZE
description: Five people were killed and 18 others were injured early today when a fire raced through a three-story rooming house here, forcing survivors to leap from windows and ledges.

Lawford, a founding partner in the former New York architectural concern of Brown, Lawford & Forbes, and president of the New York chapter of the American Institute of Architects in 1963-64, died of chronic lung disease Monday at his home in Jackson Heights, Queens. He was 80 years old.

title: PUBLISHING: 'SEARCH' HEADS 1983 HARD-COVER LIST
description: ''IN SEARCH OF EXCELLENCE,'' a book that had a modest first printing of 15,000 copies, was the biggest selling hard-cover book in the United States last year. This account of America's best-run companies by Thomas J. Peters and Robert H. Waterman Jr. far outsold even James A. Michener's ''Poland,'' the biggest- selling novel of 1983.

description: In a sharp shift in tactics, Senator Alan Cranston declared today, ''It is not likely that Walter Mondale will lead us away from the arms race and achieve enduring peace.''

title: U.S. Plant Considered
description: The Toyo Kogyo Company, which makes Mazda automobiles, expects to finish by the end of the year a study on producing cars in the United States, a spokesman for the auto maker's main banker said today. The spokesman for the Sumitomo Bank Ltd. said Toyo Kogyo is studying locations and suppliers for a possible United States plant. The Ford Motor Company of the United States has a 25 percent stake in Toyo Kogyo.

title: PHILHARMONIC: WEBERN AND 'DAS LIED' BY MAHLER
description: NO great composer's music more clearly reflects his temperament or more closely parallels his experiences than Mahler's. Not even Tchaikovsky is so insistently autobiographical and self-revealing. The love affair with death that Mahler carries on, in work after work, is perfectly consistent with his tragic view of human existence and he probably would have been astonished to think that anyone could overlook the personal message he is expressing in, say, ''Das Lied von der Erde.''

title: Talks Set on Hockey Dispute
description: The executive director of the United States Olympic Committee restated here today that he would protest the eligibility of three Canadian hockey players but had agreed to meet with Canadian officials on Sunday to discuss the dispute.

Hollings, former Senator George McGovern and the Rev. Jesse Jackson. Former Gov. Reubin Askew of Florida and Senator Alan Cranston declined to appear.

description: West Germany's economy is expected to grow 2.5 percent in 1984, but unemployment will probably remain steady at 2.2 million people, Economics Minister Otto Lambsdorff said today at a news conference. He said inflation would be 3 percent this year.

Although several National Football League players have jumped leagues, Grimm made clear that he preferred to stay in Washington and that he regarded the Mauler offer as a bargaining chip.

title: Thieves Return Holy Tunic
description: The church authorities announced today that thieves had returned a holy tunic that was stolen by a leftist guerrilla group to raise ransom money for the outlawed Solidarity union in Poland. The tunic, believed to have been worn by Jesus, was returned ''in good condition'' this week to the Basilica of St.-Denys, northeast of Paris, the parish priest said.

title: Ronco and Units In Chapter 11 Step CHICAGO, Feb. 2 (AP) - Ronco Teleproducts Inc. and its domestic subsidiaries have filed under Chapter 11 of the Federal Bankruptcy Code. Ronco was founded in 1964 by Ron Popeil, and produced a variety of gadgets that became popular through low- budget television commercials.
description: ''We want to reorganize; we think there's something here worth saving,'' said Maury Fisher, a lawyer who represents Ronco.

title: G.& W.-Esquire By Reuters
description: Gulf and Western Industries said it had signed a definitive agreement for the acquisition of Esquire Inc. that reduced the price to $23.50 a share, from the $25 a share originally planned. G. & W., a conglomerate, currently owns about 2.8 million shares, or 27 percent, of Esquire's common, and it announced on Dec. 5 an agreement in principle to acquire the remaining 7.7 million shares at $25 a share. Esquire publishes educational textbooks. G. & W. said the price had been reduced as a result of recent discussions between the two companies, but would give no further details. On the New York Stock Exchange yesterday, Esquire dropped $1.375, to $22.875.

title: THE SCREEN: 'RECKLESS'
description: ATITLE like ''Reckless'' is a challenge for any movie to live up to, especially when its accompanying screenplay treads the familiar territory of the defiant teen-ager. That this film, which marks the directing debut of James Foley, works even briefly is something of a wonder. Contrived and cliched as it turns out to be, ''Reckless'' has enough vitality to carry it for a while, although it never stops recalling other films. ''Breathless,'' ''Flashdance,'' ''Risky Business'' and ''All the Right Moves'' are a few of the more recent films of which it may remind you. And if it looks a bit like ''The Deer Hunter,'' that's because some of it was shot in the same West Virginia town (Weirton).

title: Coastal Rejects Houston Gas Bid After a board meeting in Houston yesterday, the Coastal Corporation rejected a takeover bid by the Houston Natural Gas Corporation of $42 a share, or $924 million, as ''clearly inadequate.'' It said it had based its decision in part on an opinion by E. F. Hutton & Company, its adviser.
description: Coastal, which had precipitated the bid by offering $68 a share for enough stock to give it nearly 51 percent of Houston Natural Gas, said neither the bid nor Houston Natural Gas's ''baseless'' lawsuits would stop Coastal from going ahead.

description: The Chrysler Corporation, continuing its return to normal operations, reinstated dividends on its common stock today, declaring a payment of 15 cents a share for the second quarter. It will be the first such dividend paid by the company since the second quarter of 1979.

title: Money Funds' Assets Up Assets of the nation's money market mutual funds reached their highest level in 10 weeks in the period ended Wednesday, but short-term yields declined, the Investment Company Institute and Donoghue's Money Fund Report said yesterday.
description: Total assets of the funds rose $690 million, to $166.11 billion, marking the fourth consecutive weekly increase, the institute said.

title: BITTER DAYS FOR WINE GRAPE GROWERS
description: Scott Simonson stood quietly in the bitter cold outside his barn here today and saw his dreams sold off. Until 11 A.M., Mr. Simonson had been a grape farmer. That was the moment when the auctioneer's gavel fell and the first bid was taken on all that he had spent 14 years building.

title: Ex-Firefighter Loses Her Bias Suit in Iowa
description: A jury ruled today against a former firefighter who sued the city for sex discrimination, contending that her civil rights were violated by male co-workers who harassed her after she breast- fed her son at work.

description: Even though Democratic attacks on President Reagan's foreign policy record are growing, Administration officials say they are in a good position to face an election-year onslaught if there are no catastrophes or surprises.

CAPITALS WIN, 2-0, PROLONG DEVILS SLIDE
description: The organist's efforts to elicit a chant from the crowd at Byrne Meadowlands Arena were almost as fruitless as the Devils' efforts to score against the Washington Capitals tonight. The Devils took only 14 shots on goal and lost, 2-0, on a goal midway through the last period and an empty- net goal with 19 seconds to play.

description: For anyone who still cares, there is only one more day to wonder whether All Along, Devil's Bag or Slew o' Gold was the American horse of the year in 1983.

description: The Federal Reserve Board today approved final rules requiring American banks to either write off portions of loans to countries that are deemed to be in serious financial trouble, or set up special reserves to cover the loans if they are not repaid.

description: Although Yuri V. Andropov has been out of public view for five months, the ruling Communist Party has been pressing on with a shake-up of regional party chiefs. The development is interpreted by Western diplomats as a measure of Mr. Andropov's continuing political power.

title: ART: CHARLES BURCHFIELD, A TIMELY RETROSPECTIVE
description: -1967) is an American original. Born and raised in the Middle West, he was a self-made artist who spent almost his entire life in Salem, Ohio, and Buffalo. He lived simply, avoided people, worked hard (''Paint until you drop,'' he once told himself), raised a family and devoted his artistic career to making paintings that would be a hymn to the natural world. He went about as far as an artist can go who is dependent upon the advantages of small-town American life.

title: REAGAN'S BUDGET: SOUND...
description: In his State of the Union Message and his budget message, President Reagan has stood firm with his supply-side economic policy. This is a resounding defeat for David A. Stockman, director of the Office of Management and Budget; Martin S. Feldstein, chairman of the Council of Economic Advisers; and Paul A. Volcker, chairman of the Federal Reserve. All three hoped that Mr. Reagan had been maneuvered into a corner in which he had no alternative but to abandon his supply-side policy and propose higher taxes in order to reduce the budget deficits.

title: BUFFTON CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
SCREEN: 'STUCK ON YOU'
description: TROMA INC., the outfit whose prior oeuvre includes ''Squeeze Play!'' (a smutty comedy about a women's baseball team) and ''Waitress!'' (a smutty comedy about a restaurant), has gone ever-so-slightly respectable with ''Stuck on You.'' Troma's style can't exactly be called distinctive, but at least it's identifiable. Dumb gags, food fights and bathroom jokes are accompanied, if not redeemed, by an overriding cheerfulness and a willingness to try just about anything. The humor never rises above the level of idiocy, but at least it's good- natured.

Clearly, the film is on the side of the osprey, described as ''one of the world's most splendid birds of prey.'' With a wing span of five feet, this is an imposing creature, and the documentary, filmed and directed by Hugh Miles, offers breathtaking views of its habits and habitats.

title: Yanks Sign Pitcher The Yankees yesterday signed Tim Belcher, the 22-year-old right-hander who was the No. 1 choice in the secondary phase of the winter free-agent draft. Belcher, a 6-foot-3-inch, 210- pounder from Sparta, Ohio, was the No. 1 choice of the Minnesota Twins in the regular phase of the summer draft last year. He did not sign, however, making him eligible for the secondary phase this winter.
description: ''I was close to signing with Minnesota but close only counts in horseshoes and hand grenades,'' Belcher said at a news conference in Yankee Stadium. ''I don't really want to get into it; I'm a Yankee now.

title: New Jersey's Plain Cloth Budget
description: An ambitious new program for road and bridge repair is the centerpiece of an otherwise hold-the- line budget presented by Governor Kean to the New Jersey Legislature. Unlike his fellow Republican in the White House, Mr. Kean has designed a budget with a prudent surplus.

SmithKline Acquisition
description: The SmithKline Beckman Corporation said its eye- and skin-care subsidiary, Allergan Pharmaceuticals Inc., had agreed to acquire Laboratoires Dulcis du Dr. Ferry S.A., makers of prescription ophthalmic products for the French and export markets. Terms of the agreement were not disclosed. Laboratoires Dulcis is based in Monte Carlo, Monaco.

title: Yugoslav Leaves Capital
description: President Mika Spiljak of Yugoslavia left for Los Angeles today after two days of meetings in Washington with President Reagan and other United States officials. Mr. Spiljak used his final day in Washington for meetings with Vice President Bush, Commerce Secretary Malcolm Baldrige and members of the House Foreign Affairs and Senate Foreign Relations Committees.

description: The Rangers, whose victory Sunday night vaulted them into first place in the Patrick Division by the All-Star break, returned to action tonight and sank to their poorest performance of the season, an 8-1 loss to the Calgary Flames at the Saddledome.

title: ACTION SET ON BIG AIR FORCE CONTRACT
description: Amid persistent speculation that the Air Force has decided to award up to 70 percent of a multibillion-dollar jet-engine order to the General Electric Company, Defense Secretary Caspar W. Weinberger said today that the contract would be awarded in ''the next few days''

title: Bridge: The Gain From Some Plays Is Not Immediately Obvious
description: Some plays at the bridge table should be made as matters of good technique, even if there is no obvious advantage to be gained. One of these is the early duck in a suit in which a trick must be lost sooner or later.

title: FRIDAY, FEBRUARY 3, 1984 International
description: The biggest battle in four months raged around Beirut as a vast tank, rocket and artillery battle erupted between Lebanese Army and anti-Government Druse and Shiite militiamen in the capital and across the surrounding hills. In many outlying villages, shells crashed into populated areas. (Page A1, Column 6.) U.S. policy in Lebanon was defended by Lawrence S. Eagleburger, the Under Secretary of State for Political Affairs. He told a House hearing that passage of a Democratic-sponsored resolution calling for a ''prompt and orderly'' withdrawal of the American Marines from Beirut would embolden ''the forces of radicalism and extremism'' in the Middle East. (A1:5.)

description: Consumer prices in Peru jumped 7.3 percent in January from December, the Government said today. The National Statistics Institute said prices rose 124 percent during the 12 months that ended Jan. 31.

title: CONGRESSIONAL FELLOWSHIP: UP A GOLDEN LADDER
description: Dick Cheney came to Washington in the fall of 1968 from the University of Wisconsin, a 27-year-old graduate student in political science. He had won a Congressional fellowship offered by the American Political Science Association, and was attached to the office of Representative Bill Steiger of Wisconsin.

title: PRENTICE-HALL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Du Pont and Dow Are Higher
description: The country's two biggest chemical companies, benefiting from an improved economy, yesterday reported sharply higher earnings for the fourth quarter of 1983.

title: MONDALE ACCUSES REAGAN OF LACKING COMPASSION
description: Walter F. Mondale accused the Reagan Administration of ''greed'' today and said its policies were marked by the ''biggest deficits and smallest amount of compassion'' in the nation's history.

title: OVER 100 DIE IN AFRICAN FLOODS
description: More than 100 people have reportedly died in floods in three southern African countries after a hurricane hit areas afflicted only a few months ago by drought.

title: SUIT TESTS PRIME'S DEFINITION
description: For Jackie Kleiner, a lawyer who dabbles in real estate, the exact definition of the prime rate has become a prime battle - and the outcome of his fight against the First National Bank of Atlanta could set an expensive precedent for many other banks.

title: DEMOCRATS LASHED BY REAGAN AGAIN
description: President Reagan asserted today that if the Democrats had retained the Presidency after the 1980 election American defenses would have weakened, the Soviet Union would have grown ''bolder'' and Grenada would have fallen to hostile forces.

title: A WAY TO HELP OTHERS AND TRY FOR CLOUD NINE
description: ON Calvin Levels's first morning in Manhattan, his agent told him to look into a script at the Ensemble Studio Theater. The next day, Mr. Levels auditioned for a part in that play, and since then the role has been his. Now, Mr. Levels has brought his portrayal of Calvin Jefferson in Shirley Lauro's drama, ''Open Admissions,'' to Broadway, winning raves from the critics and standing ovations from audiences at the Music Box.

title: City Opera Undertakes 5-Week 'Boh eme' Tour
description: The New York City Opera National Company has begun a five-week, 20- city tour of a new production of Puccini's ''Boh eme.''

title: ALABAMA JUDGE OVERRULES JURY, SENTENCES A KLANSMAN TO DEATH
description: A circuit judge, breaking a precedent in Alabama, overruled a jury today and sentenced a convicted member of the Ku Klux Klan to death in the electric chair for killing a young black man and hanging the body from a tree.

title: WAXMAN INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
FARMERS TOLD TO RELY LESS ON GOVERNMENT SUBSIDY AND MORE ON MARKETS
description: Although this country's farmers are among the most productive in the world, ''all is not well with American agriculture,'' President Reagan told Congress today in his annual Economic Report.

title: A CITY WITHIN A CITY WHERE OLD MEETS NEW
description: THE inflections will differ in Chinatown this weekend, depending upon where you happen to be - either the traditional singsong Cantonese greeting, ''Gung Hay Fat Choy,'' or the newer clipped accents of Mandarin,'' ''Gong Xi Fa Cai'' - but the words will convey the same wish for happiness in 4682, the Year of the Rat in the Chinese zodiac, which began yesterday.

title: Plane's Pilot Collapses And 4 Die in Crash
description: Three frightened passengers in a small plane pleaded for help by radio Wednesday as their pilot slumped unconscious at the controls, but they were unable to control the plane and it plunged into the ground, killing all four.

title: COUNTDOWN GOES SMOOTHLY FOR LAUNCHING TODAY OF 8-DAY SHUTTLE MISSION
description: The space shuttle Challenger is set to begin an eight-day mission Friday that will include critical tests of the abilities of spacewalking astronauts to repair orbiting satellites.

title: College Basketball; Illinois Tops Iowa in Overtime IOWA CITY, Feb. 2 (AP) - Bruce Douglas, an Illinois guard, scored 5 points in the second overtime as the Illini escaped with a 54-52 victory over Iowa in a Big Ten game tonight.
description: Douglas put Illinois ahead to stay, 53-52, with 56 seconds left in the second overtime when he picked up a loose ball and drove the length of the court for a short jump shot. He added a free throw with 15 seconds remaining for the final margin.

description: Yankees Hire Strength Coach

title: THE SCREEN: A MYSTERY FROM FRANCE
description: ETIENNE PERIER'S ''Investigation'' (''Un Si Joli Village''), the 1979 French film that opens today at the Thalia on a bill with Jean-Luc Godard's ''Breathless,'' is an unpretentious, amusing mystery film, a cat- and-mouse game in which the roles of cat and mouse are continually reversed.

title: AMETEK INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes an extraordinary gain of $5,700,000.

title: STOCKMAN DISCOURAGES BIG DEFICIT PUSH
description: David A. Stockman, director of the Office of Management and Budget, sought today to head off a Congressional push for a three-year plan of deficit reduction that would be much larger than the $100 billion ''down payment'' President Reagan has proposed.

title: PLAYSRoy S. Johnson; 'Get the Ball to B!'
description: DALLAS While he was missing his sixth straight game because of an ankle injury, Ray Williams decided to become a cheerleader. ''Get the ball to B!'' he yelled while standing in front of the Knick bench during the final seconds of the team's 105-98 victory over Dallas Wednesday night at Reunion Arena. ''Get it to B!'' the guard cried. ''Get it to him!''

title: ART: 'INTERVENTIONS,' ON U.S. LATIN ROLE
description: IDA APPLEBROOG, Honore Daumier, Francisco Goya, Jenny Holzer, Paulette Nenner and Diego Rivera are not the likeliest mix for an exhibition. Yet politics makes strange showmates, and they are among the contributors to ''Timeline: The Chronicle of U.S. Intervention in Central and Latin America,'' at P. S. 1, the alternative space in Long Island City, Queens, through March 18.

title: Shipyard Workers Battle Spanish Riot Police
description: Shipyard workers battled riot policemen today in Gijon, a northern coastal town hit by a general strike over Government plans to eliminate several thousand jobs.

title: Warsaw Accuses Walesa Of Financial Misconduct
description: The Polish Government, responding publicly to a letter from Lech Walesa complaining of harassment, today accused the founder of Solidarity of arrogance and financial misconduct.

title: U.S.I.A. PLANS SATELLITE NEWS PARLEYS
description: The United States Information Agency said today that it planned to use communications satellites to enable reporters around the world to question Reagan Administration officials in Washington or wherever they happened to be. It said the system would be called Worldnet.

title: Washington Post Profit
description: The Washington Post Company reported today that earnings rose 29 percent in the fourth quarter, to $28.6 million, or $2.02 a share, from $22.2 million, or $1.57 a share, a year earlier.

title: Gas Merger Talks
description: The annual meeting of the New Jersey Resources Corporation has been adjourned until Feb. 21 to count the votes in the proxy contest, a spokesman said.

title: Army Clergy Program Is Held Constitutional
description: A Federal district judge in Brooklyn yesterday upheld the constitutionality of the Army chaplaincy program, which provides Government-financed clergymen and programs for soldiers of various faiths.

title: THE OTHER FRITZ
description: Does President Reagan really worry about those enormous deficits, averaging $200 billion annually, that his tax and military policies will foist on the nation for as many years ahead as you care to look?

title: BAPTIST NEIGHBORS OPPOSE TEXAS BUDDHIST TEMPLE
description: Just three blocks west of the Fairview Baptist Church, one of 16 Baptist churches here, on a block lined with tidy, one-story frame houses, is an odd- shaped yellow house that has both a rusty basketball hoop and a Buddhist shrine in its yard.

description: BASEBALL

title: MILTON C. LEE
description: Milton C. Lee, a vice president of the Bank of China from the early 1930's to 1952, collapsed and died after swimming last Friday at the Vanderbilt Y.M.C.A. in Manhattan. He was 82 years old and lived in the Bay Ridge section of Brooklyn.

title: Plan to Lay Off 50 Rangers Fading
description: The Cuomo administration moved today to drop its plan to lay off 50 of the state's 114 forest rangers.

title: His Campaign, Everyone's Risk
description: President Reagan yesterday received an urgent message, one that mocks the budget he presented just the day before. ''The longer the deficits are allowed to persist,'' the message said, ''the greater are the risks to our economic future.''

description: b-Operating earnings. c-Net income.

title: BUSINESS PEOPLE

title: Black Democrats Quit Glenn Drive in Georgia
description: Key black Democrats in Georgia are abandoning Senator John Glenn's campaign for the Democratic Presidential nomination to join the rival campaigns of former Vice President Walter F. Mondale and the Rev. Jesse Jackson.

title: COMMISSION WILL STUDY STATE UNIVERSITY FUTURE
description: The State University of New York, facing financial difficulties and the prospect of declining enrollment, yesterday created an independent 15-member commission to study its future.

title: Irish Leader Plans U.S. Visit
description: Prime Minister Garret FitzGerald of Ireland will confer at the White House with President Reagan on March 16 during a working visit to the United States, a White House spokesman announced today.

title: COMEBACK OF A TRIMMER CONTINENTAL
description: Slowly, piece by piece, under the protection of the bankruptcy code, Frank Lorenzo, the chairman and chief executive officer of Continental Air Lines, is rebuilding the airline into what could well become the largest low-cost carrier in the country.

title: Warde's Role At Airline
description: George A. Warde will continue to run Micronesia's airline despite his dismissal by the board of Air Micronesia Inc., according to Continental Air Lines, which operates the carrier.

title: BRIEFS
description: Allnet Communication Services Inc., Chicago, said it had reached an agreement with Mobile Communications Corp. of America that permits Allnet to use Mobile's transmission facilities to start paging services in 30 cities throughout the United States.

title: NO COMMISSIONER, YET
description: The chairman of the committee searching for a new baseball commissioner said yesterday that the job had not been offered to anyone yet, even though Bowie Kuhn will step down as commissioner March 1.

title: ESSAY ; BIG BROTHER TRIUMPHS
description: For two days the Senate debated ''the Wick amendment,'' a proposal by Senators Howard Metzenbaum and Dale Bumpers to amend the Comprehensive Crime Control Act to make the secret taping of callers by Federal officials a punishable misdemeanor.

title: Jury Hears Words Of Slain Witness
description: The grand jury statement of a witness who was murdered last November hours before he was to testify in a Manhattan murder trial was read to jurors yesterday at the start of a new murder trial.

title: Israelis Close Campus Of West Bank School
description: The Israeli military authorities tonight ordered the downtown campus of Bir Zeit, the largest Arab university in the occupied West Bank, closed for three months.

title: ART: JASPER JOHNS SHOW IS PAINTER AT HIS BEST
description: PLAIN words are best. It is a long time since we have had an exhibition of new painting that compares to the one by Jasper Johns at the Leo Castelli Gallery, 142 Greene Street. What we see there is painting that for an hour or two makes every other sort of painting look superfluous. And if some of the pictures may take a lifetime to unravel - well, that lifetime will be well spent.

description: Italian steakhouse of old New York.

title: Diner's Journal
description: AN increasing number of restaurants around town, taking a cue from diners who are trying to cut down on salt or fat in their diets, are offering dishes low in one or both. The four-month-old Blue Willow on lower Broadway at Bleecker Street states on its menu that it ''does not add any salt to or in the preparation of food,'' and ''We have no salt, mustard, chutney, ketchup, etc.''

First, there was heat, thanks to ''Space Heat,'' the studio's first annual benefit in 1982, which netted P. S. 122 two gas heaters. Then there was light, with the proceeds from ''More Light,'' which raised money last year for an improved theater lighting system.

title: JewishMuseumtoClose Feb. 27 to March 18
description: The Jewish Museum, Fifth Avenue at 92d Street, will be closed from Feb. 27 to March 18 for renovations. The construction is being undertaken to allow for the installation of ''The Precious Legacy: Judaic Treasures from the Czechoslovak State Collections,'' which will open April 15 and run through Aug. 26.

title: SATELLITE IT CARRIED APPEARS LOST
description: Five astronauts rode the space shuttle Challenger into orbit today and deployed a communication satellite that later appeared to be lost in space.

description: Neat lines of chattering schoolchildren snaked across Lincoln Center Plaza yesterday morning on their way to becoming one of the New York City Ballet's most appreciative audiences.

Grandfather Finds Infant Of Couple Slain at Home
description: A hungry, dehydrated 7-month-old girl was found by her grandfather when he forced his way into his son's home and discovered the bound and gagged bodies of the child's parents, the police said today.

title: MOSCOW ISSUES A LAW ON OFFICIAL SECRETS
description: The Soviet Union has promulgated a new law providing prison terms for anyone passing economic, scientific, technical or other ''official'' secrets to foreigners.

title: Your Money; Limiting Cost Of Health Care
description: HEALTH care cost containment is a term widely used these days among government and corporate officials concerned with the continuing rise in medical and hospital expenses. But the concept of working toward maintaining the current level of health care costs - if not cutting back these costs - is important to individuals as well.

title: JACKSON GROUP'S ACCEPTANCE OF ARABS' FUNDS HEIGHTENS CONCERN OF AMERICAN JEWS
description: The disclosure that an organization closely associated with the Rev. Jesse Jackson received a major part of its funds from the Arab League has heightened the already strong concern in American Jewish organizations over his candidacy for the Democratic Presidential nomination.

title: SECRETS OF THE ATTIC
description: After the last of our family to live in the farmhouse died, we put off as long as possible emptying it. In the 100 years since Grandfather had bought 160 acres of northwestern Iowa prairie, two generations of children, 13 in all, had grown up there, and each had left something behind.

title: MUSIC: AUSTRALIAN WORK
description: The most fascinating work presented by the New York New Music Ensemble in Carnegie Recital Hall Tuesday night was neither from New York nor was it strictly new. But the 1971 composition, ''Incredible Floridas,'' was by an Australian composer, Richard Meale, who was a fresh voice to this listener and probably to many others.

title: FEDERAL SIGNAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Eligibility Issue
description: A history professor at the University of Kansas says that Larry Brown, the basketball coach, asked him to give Cedric Hunter, a freshman guard, a passing grade so the player could remain eligible, according to a report yesterday in the university newspaper. The University Daily Kansan reported that Prof. David Katzman said Brown had asked him to raise Hunter's failing grade in American History to a D-minus.

title: STATES AROUND U.S. PREPARE TO ACT ON NEW GUIDELINES FOR PESTICIDE
description: The Environmental Protection Agency's announcement today of maximum safe levels of the pesticide ethylene dibromide in grain products leaves to the states the questions of how and whether to enforce the limits.

title: Tharp Schedule Shifted
description: Performances of ''Nine Sinatra Songs,'' a dance piece set to songs by Frank Sinatra, have been added to the schedule of the Twyla Tharp Dancers at the Brooklyn Academy of Music, 30 Lafayette Avenue. The piece will be performed tomorrow at 2 and 7 P.M. and on Friday at 8 P.M., replacing the dances ''The Golden Section From the Catherine Wheel'' and ''Baker's Dozen.'' The remaining performances, which run through Feb. 12, are unchanged.

title: INFERTILE WOMAN HAS BABY THROUGH EMBRYO TRANSFER
description: The birth of the first baby conceived in one woman's womb and carried to birth in another's without the use of ''test tube'' fertilization was announced here today by a team of California physicians.

description: The Government gave the state airline and Polish fishermen permission today to resume business with the United States in areas opened up by the partial lifting of Western economic sanctions.

British Farm Income Off
description: British farmers' incomes fell 15 percent, to $2.18 billion, last year, the Agriculture Ministry's annual review said today. Of 243,000 farms in Britain, the average farm size is now 294 acres, up from 284 acres in 1978, the report said.

title: WOODMEN WHO CANNOT BE SPARED
description: To the Editor:

title: In Line to Play Lotto, MWo
description: A maintenance man from Brooklyn was buying a ticket for the state's Lotto game on Wednesday and was checking the winning numbers from the drawing last Saturday when he found out he was the winner of a $3.1 million jackpot.

title: Miss Hightower Takes 60-Hurdles
description: Stephanie Hightower easily outdistanced the field and narrowly missed breaking her American record in winning the 60-meter hurdles tonight in the 24th Mason-Dixon track and field games at Freedom Hall.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''Lebanon is a test not of how tough we are, but of how smart we are.'' - Speaker of the House Thomas P. O'Neill Jr. (4:6.)

Los Angeles Set to Settle Suit Over Police Spying
description: The City Council voted today to settle an American Civil Liberties Union lawsuit over reported police spying, just five days before the long-delayed trial was to begin.

title: PACIFIC EXPRESS
description: Pacific Express, a commuter airline serving five Western states, has halted operations and filed under Chapter 11 of the Federal Bankruptcy Code.

title: Governor Nominates Ex-Counsel as Judge
description: Governor Cuomo yesterday nominated his former counsel, Alice Daniel, to be a Court of Claims judge.

title: Layoff Outlook At Pratt
description: Executives of Pratt & Whitney, based here, said tonight that the Air Force's decision to end the company's lock on the fighter engine market could well have an effect on employment, although it was too soon to tell whether layoffs would result. Pratt's parent company, United Technologies, is Connecticut's largest employer.

title: STAVROPOULOS: CHIFFON AND ORGANDY
description: Chiffon for evening has been auspiciously revived by the French couture for spring and summer, but George Stavropoulos wasn't overly impressed. ''I've been using chiffon since the early 1960's,'' he said after his show for the same seasons at the Regency Hotel last week. ''Now I'm putting organdy under it to give it a different look.''

title: DELMARVA POWER & LIGHT CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
7.9% UNEMPLOYED IN JANUARY, LOWEST SINCE OCTOBER 1981
description: The national unemployment rate declined in January to 7.9 percent of the labor force, the Labor Department reported today.

title: DEMOCRATS AGREE WITH ONE ANOTHER, NOT WITH REAGAN, AT WOMEN'S FORUM
description: Six Democratic Presidential hopefuls gathered here tonight to debate women's issues - and found they had little to debate amongst themselves and more to argue with President Reagan.

title: College Basketball; Carolina Routs Furman CHARLOTTE, N.C., Feb. 3 (AP) - Michael Jordan scored 21 points and Brad Daugherty added 15 as unbeaten North Carolina trounced Furman, 83-48, tonight, for its 19th victory.
description: The top-ranked Tar Heels took a 42-21 lead at halftime as they pressured Furman into 18 turnovers. Jordan had 15 points before intermission on 6 of 10 from the floor.

title: ISLANDERS SEEK END TO SLUMP TODAY
description: As the Islanders went through a drill with inverted hockey sticks at the Nassau Coliseum today, one of Bill Torrey's assistants joked, ''Maybe we should play with sticks that have no blades.''

title: INFLIGHT SERVICES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes tax credits of $198,000 for the quarter and $307,000 for the 6 months, and a gain of $12,000 for the 6 months on the repurchase of $107,000 principal amount of the company's 6 percent convertible subordinate debentures. c-Includes tax credits of $110,000 for the quarter and $256,000 for the 6 months, and gains on the repurchase of $66,000 and $83,000, respectively, principal amount 6 percent convertible subordinated debentures of $18,000 for the quarter and $25,000 for the 6 months.

description: b-Includes an extraordinary gain of $2,426,000.

DATAVISION INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Third Ouster Movement Fails in Michigan
description: Voters seeking to oust a Detroit area State Senator for supporting last year's income tax increase voted by the Legislature failed to collect enough valid signatures to force an election on recalling him from office, according to state officials.

title: AMERICANA HOTELS & REALTY reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Results for the 1982 quarter and year are not comparable to the 1983 results because they represent only 8 weeks of operation following the initial funding of the company in November.

description: The Talk of Quartzsite

title: LEIDER RECITAL: EDITH MATHIS
description: The Swiss soprano Edith Mathis has been known to New Yorkers since 1970 when she made her Metropolitan Opera debut, but until Tuesday night she had not been heard here as a lieder singer. Now, those who attended Miss Mathis's recital at the 92d Street Y are aware that she has an undemonstrative way of singing art songs that can be quite persuasive.

title: Empty Bus Burns At 57th and 5th
description: A Transit Authority express bus from Brooklyn caught fire on 57th Street near Fifth Avenue shortly after 9 A.M. yesterday, just after its last passengers got off.

description: If The Times is as interested as it claims to be in seeing a new U.S.- U.S.S.R. arms agreement (editorial Jan. 28), it would welcome the recent report on Soviet arms control violations.

title: MICHIGAN ENERGY RESOURCES CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
BEATTY IS GIVEN 16 MONTHS FOR ELECTION FRAUD IN 1982
description: Former State Senator Vander L. Beatty was sentenced yesterday to one and one-third to four years in prison for election-fraud in his unsuccessful race for the House of Representatives in 1982.

ALL ALONG IS NAMED HORSE OF THE YEAR
description: All Along, the French filly who ran like the horse of the world last year but raced only twice in this country, was honored for her global triumphs last night by being named the American horse of the year for 1983.

title: WHEN GIFTS DEMAND SUBTLE HIGH DIPLOMACY
description: When Malcolm Fraser, former Prime Minister of Australia, visited the United States a few years ago, President Reagan gave him a custom- made bamboo fly-fishing rod.

title: Bonn Industrial Output
description: West German industrial production in December declined a seasonally adjusted five-tenths of 1 percent from November, but was up 6.3 percent from a year earlier, the Economics Ministry said today.

title: PatentsStacy V. Jones Security At Remote Terminals
description: WASHINGTON

title: Soviet Citizen Tells of Torture
description: A new message said to have been written by the imprisoned Soviet psychiatrist Anatoly Koryagin and smuggled out of Russia was made public yesterday. It reported he had been subjected to both mental and physical torture.

title: CORRECITONS
description: A picture caption on Thursday with a television-page article about helicopters in network programs misidentified two craft. The one shown at the top was used in ''Riptide''; the one below was in ''Airwolf.''

title: Chain-Reaction Accident Involves 70 Vehicles
description: About 70 vehicles, including passenger sedans, oil trucks and a garbage truck, piled up in a series of chain-reaction accidents today on the fog-shrouded Yolo Causeway, covering it with debris for two miles.

title: DIGITAL PRODUCTS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes tax credits of $160,000 for the quarter and $270,000 for the 9 months, and a charge from the writedown of a leveraged lease. c-Net loss. Corrected from yesterday's editions.

title: Iraq Reports Victories Over 2 More Iran Ships
description: Iraq said today that its navy had destroyed one Iranian gunboat, killing all the crew, and captured another when the gunboats tried to approach Iraqi waters in the Persian Gulf.

title: MAYORS PLEDGE TO FIGHT CUTS PROPOSED BY REAGAN
description: The United States Conference of Mayors pledged today to fight reductions in domestic spending proposed by President Reagan in his Budget Message. The group said the proposed cuts in such areas as housing, health and nutrition would impose new hardships on cities.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Take My Word . . .

title: Georgia Sets King Holiday
description: Ten years after the idea was first proposed, the Georgia Legislature agreed today to create a state holiday honoring the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr., the civil rights leader who was slain in 1968. The measure went to Gov. Joe Frank Harris, who supports it. The legislation would require the state to observe all Federal holidays, which will number 10 when Dr. King's birthday is added to the Federal list in 1986, plus two other days each year in honor of Robert E. Lee, Jefferson Davis or the Confederate war dead.

title: U.S. Fair Pavilion Sold In Knoxville for $1
description: The United States Pavilion at the 1982 World's Fair, a drafty, wedge- shaped structure that cost $12.4 million, will be sold to the city of Knoxville for $1 because nobody else wanted to buy it.

title: IN SOVIET, WOMEN EMERGE SUPERIOR
description: In allowing the emergence of Soviet society, God probably had it in mind to reveal some truths to mankind. He wanted, among other things, to propagate His view that woman is superior to man in many dimensions - physical, moral, cultural.

title: The U.N. Today; Feb. 4, 1984
description: ECONOMIC AND SOCIAL COUNCIL

title: CUTS AT REYNOLDS
description: -SALEM, N.C., Feb. 3 (AP) - The R.J. Reynolds Tobacco Company dismissed 422 manufacturing and shipping workers, saying increased Federal and state taxation has reduced the demand for cigarettes. Officials said the company's 9,000 regular full-time employees had not been affected by the action.

title: Inventors Hall of Fame Set to Induct Four
description: Four inventors will be inducted into the National Inventors Hall of Fame on Feb. 12, three posthumously. They will join 49 earlier inductees.

title: For the Defense
description: The New Jersey Generals continue to bolster their defense. They traded Victor Hicks , a starting tight end last season, and Thomas Lott , a running back, to the Denver Gold yesterday for Kyle Whittington , a linebacker, and Andy Poremba , a defensive end. They also received the rights to Steve Doolittle , another linebacker, and Jesse Johnson , a defensive back who formerly played for the Jets. . . . The world-class sprinter Stanley Floyd , attempting to earn a spot on the roster of the Los Angeles Express, underwent arthroscopic surgery on his knee Thursday and will be out for a month, the team said.

title: KEMPER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
PROVIDENT LIFE & ACCIDENT INSURANCE CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After capital losses of $6,528,000 for the quarter and $1,018,000 for the year. c-After capital gains of $75,000 for the quarter and $1,789,000 for the year.

title: IOMEGA CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
IN WASHINGTON, A NEW YORKER SEEKS CONVENTIONS FOR THE CONVENTION CENTER
description: Thomas F. Galvin, the new president of New York's Convention Center Development Corporation, came here today to convince hundreds of convention planners, who mean millions of dollars of spending to New York City, that the seemingly impossible was really possible.

title: Judge Sentences Fire Inspectors
description: Seven Fire Department inspectors and five plumbing contractors were sentenced yesterday in State Supreme Court in Manhattan after pleading guilty to bribery charges.

title: Comings and Goings
description: Giorgio Chinaglia , the former Cosmos star who purchased the Lazio soccer team of Rome last year, has been suspended for eight months for denouncing league officials after a game last December against Udinese. . . .The Boston Bruins traded Peter McNab , a center, to the Vancouver Canucks yesterday for Jim Nill , a winger.

title: Saxon Oil Option
description: The Saxon Oil Company of Dallas said its chairman, Bill D. Saxon, had granted Group Investors Inc. an option to acquire from him 51 percent of Saxon Oil's shares outstanding.

title: AIR FORCE DIVIDES JET ENGINE ORDER BETWEEN 2 RIVALS
description: The Pentagon, ending weeks of speculation, announced today that it would split a contract to build advanced jet engines for the Air Force's F-15 and F-16 fighters between two rivals.

title: SCOUTING
description: Remembering Chamberlain

title: REAGAN ROLE IN F.C.C. CASE ASSAILED
description: Congressional investigators charged today that President Reagan had ''acted improperly and undermined the fairness and integrity'' of the Federal Communications Commission by intervening in a case of great financial interest to Hollywood film producers and the television networks.

title: Mrs. Gandhi Bars Talks With Assam Protesters
description: Prime Minister Indira Gandhi toured Assam state today and said she would not resume talks with protesters seeking the expulsion of immigrant settlers.

title: Women and Children Last
description: Last summer North Carolina's Senator Jesse Helms asked the General Accounting Office to analyze the studies made of WIC (Women, Infants, Children), a Federal program for pregnant women and young children. It is one of many food programs Mr. Helms wants to slash. Now the G.A.O. has delivered its report, which reaches positive conclusions about the crucial issue of weight at birth. These alone justify maintaining the program - and resisting strenuously the cuts President Reagan is attempting to make in it.

title: Quartet at Soundscape
description: Commitment - the jazz quartet of Jason Hwang on violin and viola, Will Connell Jr. on alto saxophone and woodwinds, William Parker on bass and Zen Matsuura on drums - will perform tonight at 9 at Soundscape (581-7032), 500 West 52d Street. Tickets are $8.

description: b-Includes tax credit of $507,000. c-Net loss

description: To the Editor: As a long-time reader of The Times, I have not before written to differ with some of your more dubi

title: Black Union Chiefs Seek Unity Behind Mondale
description: Black labor leaders formed a coalition Thursday in an effort to see that 3.3 million black unionists back the Democratic Presidential candidacy of Walter F. Mondale, who has been endorsed by the A.F.L.-C.I.O.

title: EARNINGS Amax Loss Wider in 4th Quarter Amax Inc. announced yesterday that its loss in the fourth quarter of 1983 widened to $367 million from $244 million a year earlier.
description: Results for the quarter and for the full year were depressed by a provision of $309 million for losses on properties and investments, principally in molybdenum and copper, the Greenwich, Conn., company said.

title: AMAX INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a provision of $309,000,000 for the quarter and year for losses on properties and investments, principally in molybdenum and copper, tax credits of $3,300,000 for the quarter and $4,900,000 for the year, and a gain of $3,900,000 for the year on the sale of shares of a subsidiary. c-After a $100,000,000 partial writedown for the quarter and year of the Anamax Copper investment in Arizona, tax credits of $17,200,000 for the quarter and $34,100,000 for the year, and a loss of $8,100,000 for the year from the sales of interests in oil and gas properties.

title: MONEY SUPPLY OFF $1.7 BILLION
description: The nation's basic money supply fell $1.7 billion in the week ending Jan. 25, the Federal Reserve Board announced yesterday.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: Because of an editing error, a dispatch from Washington yesterday about the military budget for the fiscal year 1985 misstated the size of the increase President Reagan proposed. In terms of spending, the President proposed an increase of 14.5 percent, of which 5.2 percent represents keeping up with inflation and 9.3 percent represents expansion of the armed forces. In terms of budget authority, the appropriation by Congress of money to be spent in fiscal year 1985 and later, the President proposed an increase of 18.1 percent, of which 13 percent is for expansion.

title: SATURDAY NEWS QUIZ
description: Questions are based on news reports in The Times this week. Answers appear on page 15.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Presidents and Birthdays

title: DECISION BIG SETBACK FOR PRATT
description: The Air Force decision to end Pratt & Whitney's lock on engine orders for front-line fighters was a sharp setback for a company that had seemed to hold an unassailable position in the field.

title: Early Reward for Reed
description: Willis Reed , the 41-year-old former Knick captain, has had trouble making the transition to college coach.

title: O'CONNOR SPICES THEOLOGY WITH WIT
description: Promising to be a strong presence in the pulpit, Bishop John J. O'Connor mixed solemnity with humor yesterday as he made his first visit to the city since being appointed the next Archbishop of New York.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: * American Bankers Insurance Group Inc., Miami, said it had agreed to sell its headquarters building and surrounding properties in Miami to First Atlantic Capital Corp. for $23 million.

VICTORIA BANKSHARES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The year-ago figures were restated for pooling of interest acquisitions.

description: News Analysis

description: Companies
