description: Not Fast Enough

title: $6 Million Suit Reported Settled ; against a school for juvenile delinquents was settled out of court Friday, lawyers said.
description: A $6 million suit filed by the estate of a slain Reader's Digest editor Justice Lucille Buell of State Supreme Court in White Plains ordered the lawyers not to disclose the amount of the settlement.

title: 4 Blacks Plead Guilty In Alabama Beating Case
description: Four black men who were charged with beating two white police investigators last year pleaded guilty today to misdemeanor assault charges and drew suspended sentences.

title: Virgin Islands Send Skater to Sarajevo
description: The International Olympic Committee, despite bending a few rules, has failed in its effort to reach a round number of 50 nations for the XIV Olympic Winter Games, which get under way Tuesday.

title: NEW DETAILS IN MERRILL-TEAMSTER DISPUTE
description: New information has come to light in a bitter dispute over the value of the assets of an insurance company owned by the late Allen M. Dorfman, a longtime associate of organized- crime figures.

title: MILTON SMALL
description: Milton Small, a partner in the New York law firm of Kossoy, Small & Conrad and general counsel to the Muscular Dystrophy Association for nearly 30 years, died Wednesday at New York University Hospital of complications following heart surgery.

title: Bridge: Some Bid Problems Arose During Nationals Last Fall
description: In standard bidding methods there are two particularly awkward problems relating to uncontested auctions. One concerns hands on the responding borderline after a minor- suit opening. The other relates to the rebid with an unbalanced hand of 17 to 18 high-card points.

title: GENERAL PUBLIC UTILITIES CORP reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
FUND HOPES TO SHARE WEALTH
description: The administrators of the Buck Trust, a $360 million endowment whose income is dedicated to providing for the poor in affluent Marin County, announced Monday that after months of discussions they would seek to modify provisions limiting such care to residents of the county.

title: ERRANT SHOTS MARK CROSBY
description: The 43d annual Bing Crosby Pro-Am is obviously not the usual down-the- middle golf tournament.

title: 24-YearSuspension OfDriver'sLicense
description: A New Jersey man convicted of drunken driving four times has had his driver's license suspended for 24 years.

title: HON INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
PLAYERSMalcolm Moran
description: Wennington's Lean Season

title: CORDURA CORP reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
IN THE SHETLANDS, A NIGHT TO MAKE NORSE BLOOD STIR
description: At precisely 8:20 this evening, almost 1,000 men, clad in a zany assortment of costumes, let out a great cheer and threw burning torches into a Viking longship that some of them had lovingly built over 15 weeks.

title: TV: A SPECIAL TWO-HOUR STAR-FILLED 'LOVE BOAT'
description: The ''Love Boat,'' or the Pacific Princess, which is the name on the bow, docks in Hong Kong tonight. Ordinarily, it sails between Los Angeles and Acapulco, a kind of Flying Dutchman, but never in inclement weather. The sun always shines; at night, the sky is velvet. Watching ''Love Boat'' week in, week out is a secret, guilty pleasure. No one ever admits to seeing it, although it has been around, Saturday nights, prime time, since Sept. 24, 1977. Severely afflicted viewers turn on reruns, too.

title: STARLING-CURRY A LOW PROFILE TITLE BOUT
description: Bob Arum's ears must be very sharp. According to the promoter of the Donald Curry-Marlon Starling rematch in Atlantic City today for the World Boxing Association welterweight title, this is ''a fight everyone in the country is talking about.''

title: G.P.U. Profits Up 38.4% in '83
description: The General Public Utilities Corporation, the operator of the Three Mile Island nuclear plant and an electrical utilities holding company serving Pennsylvania and New Jersey, said its 1983 net income rose 38.4 percent, to $51.9 million, or 84 cents a share, from $37.5 million, or 61 cents a share, in 1982. Revenues rose slightly to $2.48 billion from $2.41 billion.

title: TUNISIANS TO IMPOSE AUSTERITY MEASURES DESPITE FOOD RIOTS
description: Prime Minister Mohammed Mzali said today that the Government would impose a wide range of austerity measures, including an 11 percent increase in the price of bread, despite last month's food riots.

title: SKETCHES OF CHALLENGER'S CREW OF 5
description: Vance Devoe Brand

title: NEWS SUMMARY ;  SATURDAY, FEBRUARY 4, 1984 International
description: Democrats agreed to softer language in a draft resolution being prepared by the House Foreign Affairs Committee that calls for the early removal of the marines from Lebanon. Much of the anti-Administration language will be removed, but the Democratic members of the committee will still call for the ''prompt and orderly withdrawal'' of the marines, Congressional staff members said. (Page 1, Column 4.) In house-by-house fighting in Beirut's southern suburbs between the Lebanese Army and Moslem Shiite militiamen, the Army said it had recaptured three bunkers it lost Thursday. The announcement was supported by Western military sources but denied by the leader of the Shiite Amal, Akif Heydar. He said his militiamen still held several tactical points that control a crossing area between Moslem and Christian areas. (4:3.)

title: SALANT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes expenses of $579,000, after tax benefit, relating to the termination of merchandising agreements with the company's major chain store customer and a gain of $501,000, after tax, on the sale of facilities closed in the second fiscal quarter. c-Includes a provision for plant closings and contract termination costs of $1,105,000, after tax benefit, and a gain of $1,296,000, after tax, from the reversal of the prior year provision for the disposal of the discontinued Salant & Salant division. The year-ago fourth quarter and year sales include an accelerated sale of $16,891,000 to its major chain store customer as part of the termination of the merchandise agreements.

title: U.S. Steel's Plan To Be Reviewed WASHINGTON, Feb. 3 (AP) - The antitrust division of the Justice Department announced today that it will investigate the United States Steel Corporation's proposal to acquire the National Steel Corporation. U.S. Steel, the nation's largest steel producer, plans to acquire National, the seventh-ranked steelmaker, for $575 million in cash and stock, in addition to absorbing National Steel's long- term debt of about $400 million.
description: The Justice Department already is reviewing the proposed merger between the LTV Corporation, whose Jones & Laughlin subsidiary is the third-largest steelmaker, and the Republic Steel Corporation, the fourth- largest. Mark T. Sheehan, a Justice Department spokesman, said the decision on whether to challenge the LTV-Republic deal is not expected until late this month.

title: STABLE FED POLICY VOTED
description: The Federal Open Market Committee, a group of Federal Reserve officials who set monetary policy, decided at the Dec. 19-20 meeting to hold monetary policy stable and said the panel continued to be guided more by the performance of the economy than by growth rates of various money supply measures.

title: Mitsubishi-Soviet Deal
description: The Mitsubishi Motors Corporation said today that it had signed a $12.8 million contract to supply 250 large tractors to the Soviet Union. A Mitsubishi spokesman, who declined to be identified, said the tractors, to be used for transporting lumber in Siberia, will be shipped to the Soviet Government- owned Avto Exports by the end of March.

title: SMD INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income after a loss from discontinued operations of $5,049.

title: 60-DAY LIMIT FOR HOLDING SUSPECTS REJECTED
description: The Senate today rejected a proposal that criminal defendants detained without bail to prevent them from committing new crimes be brought to trial within 60 days. The vote was 50 to 34.

title: DEMOCRATIC CANDIDATES SHARPLY SPLIT ON BILL TO HELP AUTO MAKERS COMPETE
description: The eight major candidates for the Democratic Presidential nomination disagree profoundly over foreign trade policy, protectionism and proposals to require the use of American parts and labor in imported automobiles.

title: MCGOVERN STANDS APART, CRITICIZING ISRAELI POLICY
description: Breaking with established election-year politics, George McGovern has challenged official policies of the Israeli Government, calling for the creation of an independent Palestinian state and criticizing some of its key actions.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE;
description: ON THEIR TOES Les Ballets Trockadero de Monte Carlo is indeed a ballet company, even though its description calls for some footnotes: it is an all-male troupe, it does not come from Monte Carlo and it has a sense of humor that is one big reason for its presence. This presence will be felt at 8 o'clock tonight at Lehman College's new Lehman Center, Bedford Park Boulevard and Paul Avenue, west of Jerome Avenue, in the northwest Bronx.

title: POLITICAL GROUP FACING CHARGES OVER MOYNIHAN
description: A conservative group that has run ''negative advertising'' against liberal politicians improperly spent $68,755 trying to defeat Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan, a Federal agency has charged.

title: MOST EDB IS USED IN FUEL
description: The chemical ethylene dibromide, or EDB, has been approved by the Government as a pesticide since 1948. But crop spraying and other agricultural uses account for only about 8 percent of the 280 million pounds of the chemical used annually, the Environmental Protection Agency reports.

title: PROGRESSIVE CORPORATION reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a securities loss of $862,000 and an extraordinary credit of $341,000. c-Net loss after securities losses of $5,774,000 for the quarter and $12,994,000 for the year. d-After a securities gain of $2,054,000 and an extraordinary credit of $3,664,000.

title: Run, Campbell Run
description: Earl Campbell and the San Antonio Gunslingers of the United States Football League are considering a court challenge to the exclusivity provision in National Football League player contracts in an effort to enable him to play in both leagues.

title: Gretzky Out of Action
description: Until last night, he had missed only one game in five years. But hockey is a rough sport. So now, after playing in 362 consecutive games, 23-year-old Wayne Gretzky is facing his first extended absence from the Edmonton Oiler lineup.

title: MATTEL IS COUNTING ON ITS TOYS
description: Mattel Inc. today ended its four-year roller- coaster ride in video games and electronics, selling those operations just as their mounting losses appeared to be pushing the company close to insolvency.

title: BONN SCANDAL: HOW KOHL HANDLED IT
description: NewsAnalysis

title: SKIERS FIGHT STATE TO KEEP A LOW-KEY MOUNTAIN OPEN
description: Belleayre is Eric and Gail Leef's favorite mountain. ''Skiing Belleayre is not like skiing one of those mountans that caters to the New York City, click-click-type commercialized jet set crowd,'' said Mr. Leef.

title: F.C.C. ACTS TO RAISE SOME PHONE RATES
description: The Federal Communications Commission decided today how business telephone customers will be charged for long-distance access, and the decision means that rates could go up substantially for users of Centrex multiple- line systems.

title: SHOT AT BUZZER SETS BACK NETS
description: Eddie Johnson, often overshadowed at his position by pro basketball's many outstanding small forwards, hit a 16-foot jumper at the buzzer tonight to give the Kansas City Kings a 114-112 victory over the Nets at the Byrne Meadowlands Arena.

title: WARNACO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Nova Cost Action
description: Nova, An Alberta Corporation, said it might absorb up to $120 million on certain accumulated costs for pipeline development and other projects.

title: Texas Bank Sale
description: The National Bancshares Corporation of Texas said it had signed an agreement to acquire the Parkdale Bank of Corpus Christi from Cullen/ Frost Bankers Inc. for $19.2 million.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Crossing the Line

title: WESTCHESTER'S SECURITY IS TIGHT FOR BRINK'S TRIAL
description: The Westchester County Courthouse, which starting next week will house what may be the final Brink's trial, assumed a fortresslike appearance today with the most elaborate security precautions ever seen here.

title: BEST OF THE METROPOLITAN IN NEW ART GUIDEBOOK
description: You can hardly miss the Temple of Dendur - which has a whole wing to itself - at the Metropolitan Museum of Art. But less easy to spot at the Metropolitan are such items as the oldest piano in existence, built by Bartolommeo Cristofori in 1720; a recumbent mouflon (or wild sheep) carved of marble from the Indus River valley, going back to the third millennium B.C.; a 16th-century parade helmet topped by a supine mermaid, wrought for Francis I, King of France, and Vermeer's small ''Portrait of a Young Woman'' (late 1660's), a kind of Dutch Mona Lisa.

title: METRO TEL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
G.E., Rolls Set Engine Agreement
description: The General Electric Company and Rolls-Royce Ltd. yesterday announced an agreement that could offer new competition for the Pratt & Whitney Group of the United Technologies Corporation in middle-size and large jet engines: Each of the two companies will participate in the development, production and marketing of one of the other's jet engines in exchange for 15 percent of the revenue.

title: BITCO CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Operating earnings c-Net income.

title: PENOBSCOT SHOE CO reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 25
description: b-Net income

title: ENGINEERS' NEGLIGENCE CHARGED IN KANSAS CITY HOTEL DISASTER
description: John Ashcroft, the Missouri Attorney General, filed a complaint today accusing two engineers and their company of being grossly negligent in the design and inspection of two suspended skywalks at the Hyatt Regency Hotel, where 114 people were killed in 1981 when the skywalks collapsed.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: A news analysis article in Metropolitan Report on Tuesday, about landmarks, misidentified a speaker at the opening of St. Bartholomew's Episcopal Church in 1918. He was David Hummel Greer.

title: CORRECTION
description: The final paragraph in Charles L. Schultze's article yesterday should have read, ''A test of the nation's maturity is not whether it can be mobilized to deal with crises. . . .''

title: MANAGUA REPORTS TWO AIR ATTACKS
description: Nicaragua tonight accused United States-backed rebels operating from bases in Honduras of carrying out two separate air attacks against Nicaraguan military and civilian installations, killing four soldiers and destroying oil storage tanks.

title: SATURDAYSPORTS Auto Racing
description: 24 Hours of Daytona , opening day, at Daytona Beach, Fla. (Television - WTBS, live one-hour telecast beginning at 3:05 P.M., to be followed by five-minute updates every hour until the conclusion tomorrow.) Basketball Knicks vs. Rockets , at Houston. (Television - Channel 9, 8:30 P.M.)

title: SAN/BAR CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss The latest 6 months net is after reversal of a $182,000 provision for deferred compensation which was reflected in the first-quarter results.

title: COLTS CALLED READY TO MEET WITH CITY
description: An official of the Baltimore Colts football team has agreed to meet with New York City regarding a possible shift of the team to New York, a city official said yesterday.

title:
PATENTS;
Radiation Shield
description: A transparent plastic material containing lead, which provides a shield from low-intensity radiation, was patented this week for Arthur D. Little Inc. of Cambridge, Mass.

title: A MATTER OF SECONDS
description: When the tax collector calls I whine as much as you do, but afterward I used to feel good. That was because of the warm feeling afterward brought on by the sense that I had done something for my country.

title: Widow Awarded $1.4 Million
description: Jurors awarded $1.4 million today to the widow of a ranch foreman shot to death by the police, who mistook him for a fugitive. The widow, Sharon Grandstaff, had sought $5 million in damages for the death of her 31-year- old husband, James C. Grandstaff, who was killed Aug. 11, 1981, outside his home in the Texas Panhandle. The jury deliberated for more than two days before deciding that the City of Borger was liable for 89 percent of the award, with the remainder to be split among four Borger police officers.

title: PRESIDENT ASKS 8 BILLION IN AID FOR LATIN AREA
description: President Reagan proposed a five-year, $8 billion program of aid to Central America today. It included $312 million in military aid to El Salvador over the next two years.

title: FOOD MANUFACTURERS NOT WORRIED
description: Manufacturers of grain-based products said yesterday that they expected new standards for the pesticide ethylene dibromide to have only a modest effect on them.

title: BRITISH COLUMBIA RESOURCES INVESTMENT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After special charges of $11,200,000 for the quarter and $12,900,000 for the year. c-After a special charge of $3,400,000. d-Net loss after a special gain of $7,100,000. There were no share earnings in the latest year due to preferred dividend requirements.

title:
PATENTS;
 Telephone Device
description: A new transducer, similar to a microphone, is covered by four patents issued this week to A.T.& T. Bell Laboratories, Murray Hill, N.J. The unit is expected to improve the sound reproduction in telephone conference systems by sharpening voice pickup and suppressing background noises. The invention is not yet in commercial use. The patent numbers are 4,429,189 and 4,429,191 through 4,429,193, and the inventors are David A. Berkley, I.J. Busch-Vishniac, Robert L. Wallace Jr. and James E. West.

title: G.O.P. Women HearPresident on Economy
description: President Reagan, defending his record before an audience of Republican women officeholders, said today that his economic recovery program was designed to help everyone.

title: The Hidden Olympic Game
description: One of America's foremost figure-skating coaches has complained that bad coughs are interrupting training for the Olympic Games. He said the athletes were fearful of cough medicine containing ephedrine because if traces of that chemical are found in tests by the Olympic Committee at the winter games in Sarajevo next week, they would be disqualified. To save Olympic athletes from dangerous drugs, it has become necessary to endanger their conditioning.

title: GRI CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
RIVER OAKS INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
FALL OF EAST SIDE EXPRESS
description: After an anxious week of uncertainty, an agreement has been reached to sell the East Side Express to a Brooklyn publisher, it was learned yesterday.

description: b-Net income

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Music's Charms

title: AIDING IRISH AGAINST BRITISH
description: Why do patriotic Americans, particularly those of non-Irish ancestry and young Irish-Americans several generations removed from Ireland, support the Irish Northern Aid Committee and kindred organizations seeking to end British colonial rule in Ireland?

title: PEOPLES RESTAURANTS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 1
description: b-Net income

title: Systems Company Faces Proxy Fight By Reuters
description: Leonard Levy, a private investor who said he owns 266,900 common shares, or 9 percent, of Information Displays Inc., said he planned to initiate a proxy battle for control of the company's board of directors. He said he had submitted a letter to the company's chairman, William Weskel, asking him to resign and seeking a list of all shareholders.

title: BALLET: A ROBBINS WORLD PREMIERE
description: What could any choreographer nowadays do with imagery of Ancient Greece that would not look like a cliche? Jerome Robbins supplied the answer at the State Theater with beauty and subtlety Thursday night in the world premiere of his ''Antique Epigraphs'' for the New York City Ballet.

title: Testimony Ends In Sims Lawsuit
description: Testimony ended today in the suit filed by Billy Sims against Jerry Argovitz and the Houston Gamblers, and the Federal judge hearing the case said he would rule next week on which team, the Gamblers or the Detroit Lions, Sims would play for next season.

title: Jersey Tightens Rules for Lawyers
description: The State Supreme Court announced today that it was toughening rules governing the conduct of 26,500 lawyers licensed to practice in the state.

title: JOB RATE STEADY IN NEW YORK AREA
description: The unemployment rates in New York and New Jersey were little changed in January, continuing the pattern of reduced joblessness in the two states in recent months, the Federal Government reported yesterday.

title: CABARET: MARILYN SOKOL SINGS
description: Much as Bette Midler used to do, Marilyn Sokol traverses the boundaries between stand-up comedy, hip improvisation and cabaret singing in her club performances. Staying true to form in her new act, which plays through tonight at Freddy's, 309 East 49th Street, Miss Sokol keeps the audience perpetually off-balance as she whizzes between comedy routines and torch songs, trying on different dialects, characters and confessional shticks.

title: New Suriname Cabinet Plans Liberalizing Steps
description: An interim Government charged with repairing Suriname's economy and restoring press freedom was sworn in today in Paramaribo, the Dutch news agency A.N.P. reported.

title: U.S. Denies Concealing Data on 6 Salvadorans
description: A State Department spokesman said today that it ''simply was not true'' that the Reagan Administration suppressed any evidence that Salvadoran exiles were living in Miami while directing the actions of death squads in El Salvador.

title: SCOUTING
description: High Hopes

title: CAR SALES JUMPED 62.6% IN FINAL JANUARY PERIOD
description: The nation's six major auto makers reported today that sales for the Jan. 21-31 period rose 62.6 percent from the dismal level of the year before.

title: Braxton at Sweet Basil
description: The saxophonist and woodwind player Anthony Braxton will make one of his rare club appearances tomorrow and Monday at Sweet Basil (242-1785), 88 Seventh Avenue South, near Bleecker Street. Sets begin at 9:30 and 11 P.M. and 12:30 A.M.; there is a $7.50 cover and a $5 minimum.

title: REPORT ASKS REPRIMAND FOR WICK FOR HIS TAPING OF CALLS AT U.S.I.A.
description: The House Foreign Affairs Committee, in a report released today, recommended that Charles Z. Wick, director of the United States Information Agency, be reprimanded for secretly tape-recording telephone calls but that no further punitive action be taken.

title: FOOD LION INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
CRACK FOUND AT NUCLEAR PLANT LEADS TO SEARCHES AT 5 OTHERS
description: A crack all the way through and completely around a steam pipe inside a critical safety system was discovered today at a shut-down nuclear plant in Georgia.

title: SEARCHING FOR THE PERFECT SUMMER CAMP
description: The summer before Daniel Maimin went to camp for the first time, his parents spent several weekends taking him - he was then 9 years old - to visit, unannounced, a list of camps in New York and Connecticut.

title: SOVIET POLITBURO TRIES TO COAX BETTER SERVICE FROM WORKERS
description: The Soviet leadership today approved a series of experimental measures designed to improve the performance of service industries such as restaurants, repair shops and hotels.

title: LEBANESE ARMY SAYS IT RETOOK POSTS
description: The Lebanese Army battled Shiite Moslem militiamen today house by house and street by street in the southern suburbs of Beirut and said it had recaptured three bunkers it lost Thursday.

title: U.S. PROHIBITS USE OF PESTICIDE TIED TO ANIMAL CANCER
description: Experts differ on the degree of hazard posed by the banned pesticide and those replacing it. Page 9.

title: King Hussein in Cleveland
description: King Hussein of Jordan arrived tonight for a series of medical tests at the Cleveland Clinic. About 20 Iraqi students demonstrated several blocks from the clinic as the King arrived with Queen Noor. Clinic officials said the King will undergo tests on his cardiovascular system and digestive tract.

title: 16.85 DROP SENDS DOW BELOW 1,200
description: Stock prices plunged yesterday on heavy volume, as the market ended one of its busiest but worst performing weeks in years.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Lincoln Center's Search

title: Cyclotron Corp.
description: The Cyclotron Corporation, which has been operating under Chapter 11 of the Federal Bankruptcy Code, said it had furloughed its employees and suspended operations because of liquidity problems. Cyclotron, which makes equipment used in nuclear medicine and chemistry, said directors are considering various alternatives.

title: TAX RATE CUT ENHANCES YIELD ON INVESTMENTS
description: Investors who sold securities at a profit last year will find their capital gains receiving more favorable tax treatment. So will taxpayers with interest and dividend income.

description: To the Editor:

title: 'THROW AWAY' FELDSTEIN'S REPORT, REGAN TELLS SENATE BUDGET PANEL
description: The dispute within the Reagan Administration over budget deficits erupted before Congress today when an infuriated Treasury Secretary Donald T. Regan told senators that they could ''throw away'' Martin S. Feldstein's Economic Report of the President.

title: REAGAN'S HOMELESS
description: On Tuesday morning, President Reagan said on ABC's ''Good Morning, America'': ''What we have found in this country, and we're more aware of it now, is one problem that we've had, even in the best of times, and that is the people who are sleeping on the grates, the homeless who are homeless, you might say, by choice.''

title: EXPERTS DISAGREE ON PESTICIDE RISK
description: Leading cancer scientists and health advocates disagreed sharply today over how great a threat consumers may face from the pesticide EDB.

description: With an Even Hand

title: SYRIA'S POLICIES A PUZZLE IN U.S. AND THE MIDEAST
description: Syria has long been viewed as crucial to any solution of the crisis in Lebanon, but its policies and interests continue to perplex many in both the Arab and Western worlds.

title: A Hint of Progress in Southern Africa
description: Can it be that South Africa sincerely wants to strike a deal with Marxist Angola? And is also willing to end a 17-year-old bush war in Namibia, the huge rich territory it rules illegally? That it will let a hostile United Nations supervise elections in Namibia even though its friends are likely to lose?

title: MONSTER COOKIES AND NEW TRICKS WITH PHYLLO
description: Little paperback cookbooks have a way of getting lost in a reviewer's stack of new books, especially during the winter holiday season, when the stack is so high. Some of the most charming and original recipes often make their way into such relatively inexpensive volumes. Those who want to pursue a single facet of cooking, such as making p^ates or pizzas, will find the compact books, when well crafted, all that is needed.

title: DEPAUL RALLIES TO BEAT ST. JOHN'S, 59-57, IN OVERTIME
description: In Ray Meyer's 42 years as the basketball coach at DePaul University, as his game has moved from gymnasiums to arenas and the innovators have come and gone, this is how much things have really changed:

title: HIGH PRICES FOR HEATING OIL PROVOKE CALLS FOR INQUIRIES
description: Home heating oil prices, which have soared more than 20 cents a gallon this winter, have leveled off and may begin to decline later this month, according to industry officials and analysts.

title: SALVADOR'S ECONOMY TAKES A HEAVY SHELLING
description: Four years of war in El Salvador have made economic prospects dim. Large expanses of farmland have been abandoned, and Salvadorans have taken about one billion dollars out of the country since guerrilla fighting began in 1979. Lack of confidence in the future discourages major new investment.

title: HELPING BURN VICTIMS ADJUST
description: Harry Gaynor flipped through a fire-safety report, looking for marketing ideas for a new fire alarm. A child's face grinned up at him, her eyes sparkling.

title: KNICKS WIN 5TH IN A ROW
description: Bernard King did not score 50 points tonight. That was not so surprising. The surprise was that Ray Williams, in his first appearance after missing six games with an ankle injury, was such a critical factor in the Knicks' fifth straight victory.

title: KEEP THE FAMILY TOGETHER
description: BACK in the Dark Ages, before the social revolutions of the 1960's and 70's, conventional wisdom decried that parents, no matter how unhappy their marriages might be, should stay together for the sake of the children.

title: Article 222380 -- No Title
description: The Silent Chase

title: IN DARK DAYS, CHILD'S TRUTH LIGHTS WAY
description: IT WAS a melancholy time, in between the vital warmth of summer and the chilling tests of winter, when I ambled over our slender estate with my 5-year-old son, Charles Aram. My mood lost not a moment seizing upon the age comparison: the father already treading in his autumn, the son barely embarking on his spring.

description: To the Editor:

title: MISS HIBBARD IS BETROTHED TO PHYSICIAN
description: The engagement of Claire Alexandra Hibbard, a member of the class of '84 at the Columbia University College of Physicians and Surgeons, to Dr. Christopher Wallace Fletcher, a resident in anesthesia at the Hospital of the University of Pennsylvania, has been announced by Prof. and Mrs. Howard Hibbard of Scarsdale, N.Y., parents of the future bride. Her fiance is the son of Wallace J. Fletcher of Chippenham, England, and the late Dr. Patricia Nolan Fletcher.

title: 'CALLOUS' REAGAN OFFERS 'DOUBLE DEAL,' MONDALE TELLS UNIONISTS
description: Walter F. Mondale told an enthusiastic labor audience today that Reagan Administration policies were marked by a ''callousness'' to the poor and middle class, and he accused President Reagan of offering a ''double deal'' to the nation.

title: KREMLIN,INSECURE, MIGHT INCREASE RISKS
description: When I visited Moscow in December, I found that the dominant mood among officials was one of anger. Among people outside official circles, it was fear - fear fueled by incessant, agitated and strident vilification of the United States. The combination of American insult and pressure is made more bitter by Russians' recognition of their own political and economic vulnerability. These different tendencies share one volatile ingredient - the desire to reassert Soviet greatness at home and abroad.

description: One day after President Reagan declared himself a candidate last week for a second term, the civil war in Lebanon claimed its 259th American service victim. The death of Lance Cpl. George L. Dramis in a bombardment at the Beirut airport, and the heavy fighting that persisted much of the week, underscored one of the President's biggest political liabilities - the miring of the marines in Lebanon's seemingly endless conflicts.

title: Argentine Says Britain Has Issued a Proposal
description: Argentina's Foreign Minister said Friday that Britain had put forward a proposal for improving relations between the two countries, but denied that secret negotiations were under way.

description: When Pope John Paul II ended months of speculation by naming Bishop John J. O'Connor of Scranton as the next Archbishop of New York last week, the 1.8 million Roman Catholics in the archdiocese were left with many questions and a few mysteries.

title: DICK BUTTON ON WHAT INFLUENCES THE SKATING JUDGES
description: D EVOTEES of figure skating will have a field day watching the television coverage of the 1984 Winter Olympic Games when they open in Sarajevo, Yugoslavia, Tuesday. For those who have watched skating for a long time, there will be many things about the competition that will seem new and different, yet the old saying holds that ''the more things change, the more they stay the same.''

description: A privately financed program will bring 12 journalists from third world countries to the United States in September for six weeks of study and work experience on American newspapers, the American Society of Newspaper Editors said Friday.

title: MAN DIES IN FAST ALLOWED BY COURT
description: An 85- year-old retired college president who a state court said had the right to starve himself to death has died, the family's attorney said today.

title: ARI, THE MOTORIST'S FRIEND
description: C ar stereo is strictly seasonal. It's all in the summer. According to the dicta of the trade, sound on wheels is peculiar to the warm season. How this notion grew is a puzzle. After all, the drive to the ski slopes my be just as long as the drive to the beach. And then there's always driving to work. So even midwinter may be a good time to catch up with what's happening on the road. A lot is going on.

description: I love to exercise vigorously (''Fitness,'' by Deborah Blumenthal, Jan. 8). My body craves the sweating, the heart pounding and the muscle fatigue produced by my regular weight workouts, just as a junkie craves her fix.

title: Miss Wiltshire to Wed Jacques Gordon

title: ALPINE RACE, OR NONE AT ALL?
description: A THLETES from the United States will probably do well in the Winter Olympics, which start Tuesday in Sarajevo, Yugoslavia. How well depends on how you define the word. The Americans will probably not win as many gold medals as in 1980. They will probably not win as many total medals. But they have strong gold- medal candidates in figure skating. They have potential gold medalists in Alpine skiing, ski jumping and Nordic combined skiing. They have medal candidates in hockey, cross-country skiing and speed skating. They have potential top-10 finishers on the three other sports - luge, bobsledding and biathlon.

title: '83 DEATH TOLL ON U.S. HIGHWAYS MARKED LOWEST LEVEL IN 20 YEARS
description: The number of Americans killed on the nation's highways declined 2.1 percent to 43,028 in 1983, the lowest level in 20 years, Transportation Secretary Elizabeth Hanford Dole announced today.

description: The head of a presidential commission investigating human rights abuses says that about 700 people were buried in a mass grave after being tortured and shot by officials of the former military dictatorship.

title: UNCERTAIN PRESENT FOR IN VITRO FERTILIZATION
description: The world's first ''test-tube baby'' will be 6 years old in July. The first American child born by the same process, known as in vitro fertilization, just turned 3. Nationwide, there may soon be as many as 100 clinics where doctors give life to children such as these, conceived in laboratories but carried in the wombs of their biological mothers. A clinic in Virginia has a waiting list of nearly 4,000 names.

title: To Grandfather's House
description: Two years after Cheri-Gay LaFrance Layton and Roger Foster married, Mr. Foster adopted her four-year-old son, Mark. Because the Fosters didn't want Mark to know of his adoption, they forbade his paternal grandparents, George and Catherine Layton, to see him.

title: Picture Services Combine
description: United Press International and the Kraus-Thomson Organization, owner of the Bettmann Archive, announced an agreement Thursday to have Bettmann manage the U.P.I. Photo Library.

title: KENTUCKY IS UPSET BY ALABAMA, 69-62
description: Alabama, led by Buck Johnson with 18 points and Bobby Lee Hurt with 17, used a tough pressing defense to come from behind in the second half today to upset Kentucky, 69-62.

description: It has become a truism for this depressed region: the first to feel a recession, the last to feel a recovery.

description: William Safire12On Language The Woid on -Oid Russell Baker16Sunday Observer Being Nice Theodore H. White22New Powers, New Politics Blacks and women, says the author, are altering the political landscape. Drew Middleton36Barring Reporters From the Battlefield A tradition of open coverage going back to the Civil War was shattered in Grenada, with wide implications for informed opinion in America.

title: M.T.A. STUDYING PHASE-OUT OF FLEET OF GRUMMAN BUSES
description: The Metropolitan Transportation Authority is studying ways to get rid of its trouble-plagued Grumman Flxible buses, including possibly selling them to other transit systems that put less strain on their vehicles, City Council President Carol Bellamy said yesterday.

title: WESTCHESTER JOURNAL
description: HE has been spending a great deal of time in supermarkets lately, but the newly installed County Legislator Paul J. Feiner is shopping for opinions, not groceries. Mr. Feiner, a Democrat who represents the 12th Legislative District, has been setting up a desk at a series of supermarkets. So far, Mr. Feiner, one of his legislative aides or a volunteer has been spending an hour or more weekly at an Elmsford Shopwell, a Dobbs Ferry Grand Union and a Hastings- on-Hudson A.&P.

description: ''I tell you,'' said Paul Berrettini, ''it's really exciting when a President admits he's from a place like this.''

description: JACQUELINE ROTTEVEEL can look out the window of her Piscataway home, see her son with his 6-year-old playmate, a girl, and feel rage.

title: SELECTING AN AUTOMOBILE CLUB
description: Agrowing problem for American motorists lies in getting emergency assistance while on the road. The number of repair shops is declining steadily as gasoline stations go out of business or as their owners find it more profitable to convert service facilities into food-and-sundry ''convenience'' shops than to fix cars. The American Automobile Association counted 226,000 service stations in the United States in 1972 and only 139,000 in 1983.

title: DREAMS MADE REAL FOR ILL CHILDREN
description: MANDY STIMMEL of Bethlehem wanted to go to Disney World, and she did last Tuesday thanks to the Connecticut chapter of A Wish Come True Inc.

title: FOLLOW-UP ON THE NEWS
description: It was an incredibly lucky hit last Aug. 19 on the electronic slot machine in Harrah's at Lake Tahoe, Nev.: $1,701,938, a new high. The casino wrote three checks for $500,000 and one for $201,938 and paid the winner, Constantine (Gus) Econopoulos, who said he was a retired San Francisco warehouseman.

title: SCIENCE AND MATHEMATICS NEED REGIONAL SCHOOLS
description: PRE-COLLEGE science and mathematics education in New Jersey, as in most of the country, is in serious trouble.

title: HOW SHOULD THE CRAFT OF CHOREOGRAPHY BE LEARNED?
description: C an choreography be taught? ''Of course not!'' some dance lovers may scoff. ''How can creativity be taught?'' The creative process is indeed mysterious and masterpieces cannot be willed into being. Nevertheless, conservatories teach musical composition and art schools teach painting. In fact, in most art forms, creative artists are expected to have some sort of training in how to go about doing what they do.

title: IN DEPTH OF WINTER, PLANS ARE MADE FOR SPRING AND FITNESS
description: STARTING this spring, the first of a dozen new public exercise trails will begin sprouting up on parkland and in school yards around the state, putting most people less than a half-hour drive from the fitness facilities.

title: LABOR BOARD STIRS UP A STORM
description: THROUGHOUT his 20 years at

title:
BUSINESS FORUM;
REFLECTIONS OF A DEPARTING COMMISSIONER
description: DRIVING to the Securities and Exchange Commission's offices each day, down Pennsylvania Avenue, one is repeatedly reminded by the granite-etched words in front of the National Archives building, ''what is past is prologue'' and instructed to ''study the past.'' Despite the turnover among S.E.C. commissioners of late (four of us have left our posts in the last 18 months) and the periodic change of leadership in the White House, this aphorism seems still to apply to the regulatory agency whose charge it is to protect the American shareholder. The Deregulation Myth. Viewed in the context of its 50 years of existence, the Securities and Exchange Commission, under the chairmanship of John S. R. Shad, has not changed the essential thrust of its policies. Despite some accounts to the contrary, the agency has not been a ''knee- jerk'' deregulator. Of more than 60 major actions taken since June 1981, only 31 involved the removal or lessening of government restrictions, 23 involved the creation of such restrictions, and seven were neutral.

title: FOR MCNALLY, A NEW SHOW AND AN OLD STRUGGLE
description: T here is a scene in Terrence McNally's play ''Broadway, Broadway'' in which a playwright and his producer are reading their opening night notices. All are pans and the producer decides to close the show. ''How can you do that to a playwright?'' begs the author, whose name is Peter Austin. ''You promised to keep it at least a week. A play running a week is bad enough, but a play that ran only one night - I'd rather die.''

title: MENTAL CLINICS FACE CUTBACKS
description: MENTAL HEALTH clinics on the Island are facing cutbacks in services because of changes in the state budget.

title: 2 ISSUES GET EARLY START ON ASSEMBLY
description: HARTFORD NEVER before has the issue of hospital costs attracted such widespread and powerful interests in Connecticut. On one side, the state's most influential business and insurance organizations are aligned with the state's top hospital industry regulator, elected local officials and groups for the elderly in a fight for a payment system in which hospital charges would be set in advance for all patients.

description: The story on the Poxabogue Pond development dispute (''Pond Fight: A New Round,'' Jan. 15) left out and understated several important points.

title: BVictiminDrownings
description: The body of a young boy, tentatively identified as the son of a woman who has been charged with pushing her four children off a bridge to their deaths in the Cooper River, was found on a bank of the river today by two passers-by, the police said.

title: NETS DEFEAT BULLS, 108-105
description: Micheal Ray Richardson stood at center court tonight, his two hands raised in victory and a huge smile on his face. The smile appeared after the talented guard had just hit a 24-foot, 3-point fadeaway jumper at the buzzer to give the Nets a 108-105 victory over the Chicago Bulls.

title: PAERDEGAT PROJECT
description: The owners of the Paerdegat Racquet Club, overlooking the Paerdegat Basin in the Canarsie section of Brooklyn, are putting about $2 million into an expansion project that will turn the eight-court facility into a threelevel swim, exercise, racquet and health club. The new Paedergat Racquet Club, expected to open early in April, will include 11 new racquetball courts, two swimming pools, a whirlpool bath, a Nautilus exercise equipment room as well as a bar and restaurant.

title: DESPITE THE FREEZE, CITRUS IS STILL AVAILABLE FOR COOKING
description: U NDER normal circumstances, the winter table is brightened by the assortment of citrus fruits that come to the market starting in late fall and remain available until spring. Oranges, tangerines, tangelos, temple oranges and grapefruits would be tasty and reliable choices for appetizers, desserts, salad ingredients and garnishes.

title: ANN SWAIN LANDRETH, EXECUTIVE, WED

The Rev. Stewart Barns , the Episcopal chaplain at Harvard University, performed the ceremony at The Vale, an estate in Waltham, Mass., owned by the Society for the Preservation of New England Antiquities of which the bridegroom is a director.

title: WHEN A WOMAN PUMPS IRON
description: On a night in January when it looked as if someone had swathed New York in miles of cotton batting, a young woman named Beverly May Francis sat gazing at a fire in one of those old Long Island houses that seem to listen to every spoken word. ''Dance was always my favorite activity,'' she said. ''But at 15 I became stocky. I was 5-5 and 140 pounds. I knew I'd never be a ballerina.''

title: KEEPING UP WITH THE ENGLISH
description: been. Today's New Romantic is tomorrow's businessman. If nothing is permanent in the universe of fashion, it is even less so in the rarefied, inbred world of young English fashion where the ebb and flow is determined as much by the style of the latest singing star or the leader of the latest social group or the owner of the latest club as it is by anything else. In 1976, for example, punk fashion was news in England, the credit for its creation going to Vivienne Westwood. Typically, the infatuation of the fashion-conscious with it lasted about two years. After that, they went on to other fashionable pastures. But punk remained, becoming, in turn, not only a style, but a stage that many of those growing up in England now pass through on their way to maturity or wherever it is they are going.

description: Maine's two top elected Democrats endorsed Walter F. Mondale for President today, but the former Vice President missed the occasion when his plane was unable to land because of fog.

title: REAGAN VS. THE MILITARY
description: It is well accepted in politics and public life that, with a certain kind of friend, one is not greatly in need of enemies. Everyone who observes the relationship between the Administration of President Reagan and the military establishment, in particular the armed services, should surely agree. The Administration, and notably its spokesmen, are strongly in support of the services, the Pentagon and the military budget in particular. This is taken for granted by all. At a deeper level, I would urge that no administration since 1815, not even those of the Vietnam years, has been more comprehensively damaging to the military's reputation. It is surprising that this has not been more discussed.

title: Showboats Get Lewis

No financial details were disclosed, but the agreement reportedly calls for a four-year contract worth $1 million with a $400,000 bonus for signing. . . . Dan Pastorini , who spent two seasons with the Philadelphia Eagles as their No. 3 quarterback, has been released by the club and is negotiating with several U.S.F.L. teams.

title: Detroit Sponsoring Fight
description: A sharply split City Council has voted to spend $100,000 and make the city the official sponsor of the World Boxing Council junior middleweight championship fight here next Saturday between Thomas Hearns and Luigi Minchillo. Councilman Jack Kelley protested that the move, adopted on a 5-4 vote Friday, would make the city ''the laughingstock of the state.''

But the addition of fanciful drawings and watercolors by the highly observant Saul Steinberg does not make a crowd, for Mr. Steinberg is a master of making his point discreetly.

title: TREASURES FROM THE CHINA TRADE
description: T he Bicentennial celebration of the departure of the Empress of China from New York, marking the sailing of the first American ship to China, began on an optimistic commercial note 10 days ago. A platter from George Washington's dinnerware that was made in China 200 years ago and brought back on the Empress's return trip, established a record price at auction in America for China Trade porcelain when it was purchased for $33,000.

title: ELECTRONIC WIZARDS SHOWCASE A PAIR OF POP SINGERS
description: T he joining of female voices with mechanistically insistent, electronically colored dance instrumentals has been a commonplace in popular music since at least the rise of disco in the mid-70's, and arguably back to Phil Spector and his ''girl groups''/''wall of sound'' of the previous decade. The union of these two forces - feminine singing as a vividly humanistic symbol for creativity and emotionality; electronic instrumentals played and produced by men as the masculine, physical, formalistically rigorous counterpart - is still very much with us.

title: SUNDAY, FEBRUARY 5, 1984;  International
description: The resignation of all Moslems in the Lebanese Cabinet and a refusal to fight by Lebanese Army soldiers was called for by the leader of Lebanon's Shiites, Nabih Berri. He made the appeal as street clashes in Beirut between the army and Shiite militiamen intensified. Government sources said Prime Minister Shafik al-Wazzan, in an emergency meeting with President Amin Gemayel, once again offered the resignation of his nine-man Cabinet of technocrats, hoping to pave the way for a new Cabinent representing all the factional leaders. title: Kings' Center Hurt

title: IS VIDEO AT ODDS WITH PHOTOGRAPHY
description: T here's no use denying that video has arrived - it's being seen in museums, bars, rock clubs, art galleries and, as broadcast via television, in millions of homes. Already it has infiltrated every aspect of visual culture, from commerce to fine art, and it even threatens to replace the amateur snapshot. The first widely ballyhooed cable network, MTV (Music TeleVision), got that way by showing snippets of audio- visual excess known as rock videos, Eastman Kodak, which made snapshot photography a universal language a century ago, last month introduced its first video products, including an 8mm taping and playback system clearly intended for the amateur market - a system that may become the Brownie of the 1980's. And in December the Museum of Modern Art, in one of its relatively rare ventures into contemporary art, brought us ''Video Art: A History,'' an exhibition that chronicled artists' use of video since the first portable video camera was marketed in the mid- 60's. If it wasn't obvious before, it is now: video (including commercial television) has replaced photography as the dominant method by which images are made and seen in today's culture.

title: Ski Lift Kills Michigan Man
description: A ski lift's operator was fatally injured when he became entangled in its cable this morning, and a subsequent derailment injured seven skiers, officials said. The operator, Harry Beckman, 33 years old, of Bessemer, apparently thought he had shut the lift down before climbing onto it about 10 A.M., said Louis Gheller, manager of the resort, Big Powderhorn Mountain.

title: SCREEN: AN INTRODUCTION TO THE LIVING THEATER

The film's appearance coincides with the Living Theater's current engagement at the Joyce Theater, the group's first extended New York engagement since 1969.

title: WOUNDED 76ERS BEATEN BY HAWKS
description: Dominique Wilkins scored 32 points and Dan Roundfield had 22 as the Atlanta Hawks defeated the Philadelphia 76ers, 102-97, and moved into first place in the National Basketball Association's Central Division. The Hawks, who have won 10 of their last 13 games, are a half-game ahead of the Detroit Pistons.

title: NEW HOPE FOR THE DISABLED
description: According to the most recent data compiled by the National Center for Health Statistics, the number of Americans with severe physical disabilities soared by more than 49 percent between 1970 and 1981. Some of the disabled are born with such handicaps as cerebral palsy, spina bifida and Down's syndrome. But five out of six of the handicapped develop impairments much later in life, including survivors of spinal-cord injuries, burn victims and many of the elderly whose proportion in the population has swelled from 3 percent in 1900 to 11 percent in 1980.

title: MISSING SATELLITE DELAYS LAUNCHING BY SPACE SHUTTLE
description: The launching of a second satellite by the space shuttle Challenger was postponed today as flight controllers, engineers and tracking stations around the world tried to find out what happened to a satellite that disappeared after deployment Friday.

title: G.O.P. RIFT RUFFLES SMITHTOWN
description: A REPUBLICAN party fight in Smithtown is providing a classic example of how party feuds can spill over into government at both the town and county level.

title: Montana Court Rules Poker Machines Illegal
description: The Montana Supreme Court has ruled that although poker is legal in this state, most types of video poker machines are not.

title: SUPPORT SERVICES FOR HOMELESS START
description: NEW program that provides long-term room, board and various support services for the homeless opened Wednesday in Westport. Meanwhile, the city's only emergency shelter for the homeless, situated in the Saugatuck Congregational Church, will close this week.

description: Ronald Reagan, who is the oldest man to be President of the United States and who now seeks another four- year term, will be 73 years old tomorrow, and his doctors say he is in good health.

title: CITY BALLET: ROBBINS SIGNATURE
description: Jerome Robbins's ''Afternoon of a Faun'' is an enduring little signature work that almost seems to dance itself. It was the turn, however, of Heather Watts and Ib Andersen to perform it when the New York City Ballet presented it Tuesday in the New York State Theater. And their performance suggested, once more, how open the ballet is to interpretation, 30 years after its creation.

title: G.O.P. Aide Sees Glenn As Toughest Reagan Foe
description: Lyn Nofziger, one of President Reagan's closest political associates, said today that Senator John Glenn would be the toughest candidate Mr. Reagan could face in the election. But no matter who wins the Democratic nomination, Mr. Nofziger says, the Republicans will face a united opposition in 1984.

title: CINDY DONEN TO MARRY JAY R. GOLDSTEIN IN JULY
description: Mr. and Mrs. Charles Donen of Norwalk, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Cindy Ann Donen, to Jay Ross Goldstein, a son of Mr. and Mrs. William Goldstein of Wilmette, Ill. A July wedding is planned.

title: Balloon Attempt Is Delayed
description: A last- minute change in the weather has delayed until Monday an attempt by a team of Englishmen to break the hot- air balloon altitude record. Mike Kendrick, 37 years old, and Per Lindstrand, 35, had planned to try for a height of 80,000 feet today in Operation Sky Quest, but high winds forced a delay. The current record of 55,134 feet was set in 1980 at Denver, Colo.

description: The Federal Parole Commission has decided to reconsider its decision granting early parole to Joseph M. Margiotta, the former Nassau County Republican leader, his parole lawyer said yesterday. Mr. Margiotta is serving a two-year sentence for arranging insurance kickbacks and is scheduled to be paroled April 14 after 10 months in prison.

title: 8 Hurt in Chicago Explosion
description: An explosion shattered two buildings on the South Side today, injuring eight people, one seriously.

title: Osborne Cites Damage
description: Nebraska's football coach, Tom Osborne , said the school's recruiting efforts had been hurt since Mike Rozier , the former Nebraska running back and Heisman Trophy winner, said early last week that he had received money and other help from Nebraska alumni while he was a student-athlete. ''I'm very confident that there's no problem here, but it's been very damaging,'' said Osborne, who has promised to resign if it is proved that he or a member of his staff had arranged improper benefits for Rozier or any other Cornhusker player.

title: NOTED WITH PLEASURE
description: Some passages from current and recently published books that we find particularly appealing.

title: HIGH-LEVEL SOVIET VISIT TO PEKING IS EXPECTED
description: A Soviet Deputy Prime Minister may come to China in the spring, according to East European diplomats here. The official, Ivan V. Arkhipov, would be the highest-ranking Soviet official to come to China since 1969.

title: THE SCIENCE-FICTION BOOM: A SHARED PASSION FOR 'WHAT IF...?
description: IN their leisure reading, Americans are increasingly looking at faraway places. A planet where human beings are struggling with environmental problems; outer space, where a Boss directs the exploits of an army created by genetic engineering; a distant land called The Land, to which a young man who had been shunned by his neighbors on Earth is miraculously transported and where he leads a war against evil - such are the locales and subjects of three recent best-selling novels, respectively ''God Emperor of Dune'' by Frank Herbert, ''Friday'' by Robert A. Heinlein and ''The One Tree'' by Stephen R. Donaldson.

title: IN STAMFORD, COMPANY BUILDS A SPECIAL GREENHOUSE
description: A NEW greenhouse at Champion International's corporate headquarters in Stamford is ''our way of returning something to the community,'' said Robert F. Longbine, president and chief operating officer of the company, ''and of being a good corporate citizen.''

title: CRITICS' CHOICES
description: As a kind of post-mortem to its current - and splendid - show of anatomical drawings by Leonardo da Vinci, the Metropolitan Museum of Art has mounted in galleries adjacent to the show ''Artists and Anatomists,'' a selection of some 60 prints, mainly from the 16th century. Not for the squeamish, they reveal the important relationship between human dissection and figure drawing, and the contributions of other Renaissance artists than Leonardo to the development of modern anatomy.

description: ''The murmurings of an economy returning to its healthy state,'' said a letter to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund, ''seem at times to be illusive when contrasted to the stark realities of people out of jobs, homeless and hungry - the truly needy ones.''

title: ARE NEIGHBORHOOD HIGH SCHOOLS SUFFERING A BRAIN DRAIN?
description: Prospect Heights High School and Clara Barton High School for the Health Professions face each other on President Street, near old apartment buildings in the Crown Heights section of Brooklyn, but academically they are miles apart. Clara Barton is regarded as one of the best schools in the city. Prospect Heights is considered one of the worst. It was among four high schools ordered last year to revamp curriculums because of poor academic performance.

description: In what is expected to be one of the year's most costly and closely watched political races, Gov. James B. Hunt Jr. of North Carolina formally declared himself a candidate today for the United States Senate seat held by Jesse Helms, a conservative Republican.

title: U.S. HOSPITALS TREATING GRENADIAN WOUNDED
description: A 6-year- old boy has been treated at a military hospital near here for severe wounds he received near his home in Grenada in the explosion of a grenade he had picked up thinking it was a toy.

TEST TUBES AND TEA ROSES AT MO"ET

title: Laundry-List Diplomacy
description: Last week, the United States accused the Soviet Union of violating arms control treaties. This week, Moscow replied in kind. The charges are less worrisome than the fact of the exchange. Such public acrimony serves only to undermine public support for arms control and the private channel long used to resolve complicated technical disputes. The blame for initiating this damaging laundry-list diplomacy rests squarely with the Administration.

title: Philadelphia Empowers School Guards to Arrest
description: The unarmed security guards who patrol public schools here have been given the power to arrest suspects, school officials say.

title: Justice Dept. Post Filled
description: D. Lowell Jensen has been named Acting Deputy Attorney General to replace Edward Schmults, who left Friday to become general counsel of the G.T.E. Corporation. Attorney General William French Smith said Mr. Jensen would also continue as Associate Attorney General. Mr. Jensen was a colleague in the Alameda County District Attorney's office in California of Edwin Meese 3d, who has been nominated to succeed Mr. Smith as Attorney General.

title: DUST CLOUDS HINT PLANET FORMATION
description: Astronomers have recorded dense clouds of dust around two distant stars and have concluded that they represent the strongest candidates so far for new planetary systems being formed. The observations, made with three large telescopes, were of infrared wavelengths beyond the red end of the visible light spectrum.

title: PORTS OF CALL WITH A DIFFERENCE
description: Some of the most exotic vacations being offered this year are at sea. With a comfortable stateroom as your temporary home, you can sail in often-luxurious surroundings to strings of colorful ports in relatively remote areas, some of which cannot be reached by air or land.

description: -area suburbs report that many homeowners are buying second and third houses as investments and tax shelters. Among the factors encouraging this practice, they say, are lower interest rates, a rise in house prices, lenders' greater willingness to provide mortgages on houses not occupied by owners and a growing awareness of the tax benefits of such investments.

title: MUSIC AND TV JUST DON'T MIX
description: T he other day, while I thought I was listening to some music on television, I found that I had been concentrating on Seiji Ozawa's suspenders instead. I don't mean that my ears wandered for just a moment, either. No, I was completely and helplessly involved in watching Mr. Ozawa conduct Schoenberg's ''Gurrelieder'' rather than paying attention to the sounds he and the Boston Symphony were delivering into my home. Though it could have been any one of many visual distractions, it was the suspenders that caught my eye this time. Each time the energetic Mr. Ozawa threw his arms into an upbeat, there the suspenders were, peeking out at me. Not that I was offended by these sartorial revelations. Not at all. Though Mr. Ozawa happens to be a somewhat unconventional dresser who favors a white turtleneck and beads with his tails instead of starched shirt and white tie, he looked quite neat and natty to me. However, as a constant concertgoer, I normally see the back of Mr. Ozawa as he works and have very little opportunity to observe how he holds his pants up. Thanks to the miracle of televised music, now I know.

The two black men were arrested in 1966 for the murder of three whites in a local bar. Both Mr. Carter, a former boxer and contender for the world middleweight championship, and Mr. Artis were later convicted by an all-white jury.

CREMONA, THE CITY OF VIOLIN MAKERS

description: Liverpool and Manchester United failed to score a goal in separate games today, and as a result there was no change at the top of the English League First Division standing.

title: CONCERT: ERA OF HOLBEIN AND MUSIC FOR A WHILE
description: The concert presented by the group Music for a While at Merkin Hall on Wednesday night was meant to be a musical counterpart to the exhibition of Holbein drawings shown at the Morgan Library last spring. The three-member early-music group selected drawings Holbein had made of the court of King Henry VIII - of Sir Thomas More, Erasmus, Nicholas Bourbon, Sir Thomas Wyatt, Anne Boleyn and Henry - and reprinted them in the program notes.

title: HEADLINERS
description: Presidential Party Crasher Gate crashing, as Charles R. Harris was accused of practicing it, is not only a breach of etiquette but also a violation of law. Mr. Harris was charged with smashing his pickup truck through a fence at the Augusta National Golf Club in Georgia while President Reagan and Secretary of State George P. Shultz were playing a few holes. Mr. Harris was also accused of taking hostages at the club pro shop, where he demanded in vain to speak to the President. Last week, his attorney announced Mr. Harris was changing his plea and admitting to charges of kidnapping and false imprisonment. He is to be sentenced next month.

title: MUSIC: WOODWIND QUINTET IN NEW WYNER WORK
description: The New York Woodwind Quintet is an exception to this city's usual racehorse chamber-music world. It has established a modest tradition in its 30-odd years of existence and, in the process, slowly earned its reputation as one of New York's truly distinguished ensembles. In other words, while so many groups we hear offer individual talents operating on perilously short rehearsal time, the members of the New York Woodwind Quintet, with time and effort, seem to have found ways to grow firmly together both technically and musically.

title: ROBIN ROSEN ENGAGED
description: Mr. and Mrs. Arnold Rosen of Fort Lee, N.J., have made known the engagement of their daughter, Robin Sue Rosen, to Kevin Mark Roseff, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Martin Roseff of Clifton, N.J. A May wedding is planned. Miss Rosen graduated from Syracuse University. Her fiance is an alumnus of the Boston University School of Management.

title: FAMILY RIVALS PROSPER IN RARITAN CENTER
description: RARITAN CENTER in Edison is already so large that it is more like a separate city than a mixed-use business park. And when several large projects - including a 9-story office tower, a 13-story hotel and more than 500,000 square feet of research and warehouse space - are completed this year, it still will only be one-third developed.

title: THE SECRET WORLD OF OPUS DEI --
description: Opus Dei is perhaps the most radical association in the church today - radical, in that it takes its inspiration from the very roots of Christianity, the hidden life of Christ; and radical, in that, with a new and unique juridical structure, it affirms the universal call to holiness taught by Vatican II.

title: 'GUEST' PLEASES MYSTERY FANS
description: AT the opening of ''The Unexpected Guest,'' the Agatha Christie thriller presented by the Arena Players Repertory Theater in East Farmingdale, a woman is holding a gun in her hand, the lifeless body of her husband is crumpled on the floor, and a stranger who has stepped in from the fog is demanding an explanation. The obvious question is ''who done it,'' and the answer, as in all good Christies, is found at the end of a tortuous trail of unfounded suspicions, innuendoes and red herrings.

title: WEEK IN BUSINESS
description: U.S. Steel agreed to buy National Steel in a $1 billion deal. The nation's No.1 steel maker is seeking to strengthen its position in the industry, while National Intergroup, National Steel's parent, is trying to get out of the steel business altogether. The proposed merger is similar to another between LTV Corporation's Jones & Laughlin steel unit and Republic Steel. If the Justice Department approves these deals, the U.S. industry, which has suffered considerably from foreign competition, is expected to shrink and become more efficient by the end of the decade. National Intergroup would be left essentially with financial services and aluminum operations. U.S. Steel has been closing inefficient plants to bolster its profitability and the acquisition of National's business, the seventh-largest in the steel industry, would be another step in that direction. National's operations are mainly in steel for consumer goods, a profitable area in which U.S. Steel is weak. Those plant closings were costly for U.S. Steel. It reported a widened loss of $983 million for the fourth quarter of 1983, primarily a result of the asset write-down from the closings, plus weak steel and oil results.

title: DEVILS WIN, 5 TO 3, END 8-GAME SLIDE
description: Tim Higgins broke a tie with his second goal of the game, at 16 minutes 46 seconds of the third period, and New Jersey went on to a 5-3 victory today over the Quebec Nordiques, ending the Devils' eight-game streak without a victory.

title: CABLE OPERATORS PUT WALL STREET IN THE SPOTLIGHT
description: L ast Monday, the Cable News Network introduced ''Your Money,'' a half-hour program devoted to personal money management. Yesterday was the scheduled premiere of ''Pinnacle,'' a half-hour series - also on CNN - of interviews with corporate chiefs.

title: EMPLOYEES ACCUSE NURSING HOME
description: A sign saying ''Shalom'' is one of the first things that a visitor to the Central New Jersey Jewish Home for the Aged sees.

title: MARY LYLE McCORISON ENGAGED TO WED
description: Mr. and Mrs. Marcus A. McCorison of Worcester, Mass., have announced the engagement of their daughter Mary Lyle McCorison, to Joshua L. Rosenbloom, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Richard S. Rosenbloom of Cambridge, Mass. A September wedding is planned.

description: Poland Eases Prices Upward

title: Porsche and Jaguar in Rivalry
description: When the starter waved a green flag and turned loose more than 90 sports cars in Daytona Beach, Fla., yesterday it signaled more than just the start of the annual 24-hour sports car race around the high-banked Daytona International Speedway. It also marked the competitive debut of the latest racing model from Porsche, and the initiation of a direct rivalry between two of the best- known manufacturers of high-performance European luxury cars.

title: IS THE FISHING INDUSTRY HEALTHY?
description: STAINLESS STEEL fish-processing equipment gleams in a vast room in a building on one of the wharves on the Manasquan Inlet here. But the equipment, used to skin, filet and clean fish, has been idle for six months now and is for sale.

title: JAPAN BUDGET: GIVE A LITTLE, TAKE A LITTLE
description: Fairly soon, a Japanese traveling from one city to another will have to spend as much as 15 cents on the dollar more for the train ticket than now. A bottle of beer will cost the equivalent of an extra dime. Many workers for big companies will begin paying 10 percent of their premiums for national health insurance that is now free.

description: LIKE a venerable actress preparing for a comeback, Rosemary Hall is getting a facelift. But what new role will be chosen for the large, pillared Old Westbury mansion remains undecided.

description: THE new Connecticut State Chess League, which will begin play next week, has attracted 12 teams from seven of the state's 30 chess clubs, so far. Officials hope the league will stimulate renewed interest in the game, which has lagged in recent years.

title: Two Germanys

title: NEW & NOTEWORTHY
description: THE LONESOME GODS, by Louis L'Amour. (Bantam, $3.50.) The hero of Louis L'Amour's 1983 best-selling historical novel, Johannes Verne, is a motherless 6-year-old traveling west with his dying father as the story begins. Before long, he finds himself on his own and eventually he must confront his murderous grandfather. ''The Lonesome Gods'' has all the ingredients found in Mr. L'Amour's western novels, including rousing action and interesting footnotes on history and lore, according to our reviewer, Mel Watkins. THE AMERICAN INQUISITION: Justice and Injustice in the Cold War, by Stanley I. Kutler. (Hill and Wang, $6.95.) A constitutional lawyer seeks ''to illustrate the whole process of legal repression'' in discussions of law, politics and power in public, private, covert and overt forms. Focusing on Tokyo Rose, Ezra Pound and others, his essays show how the Government came close to turning hundreds of apparently neutral laws into instruments of tyranny in the 1950's and how the legal system itself ultimately thwarted the effort.

title: THREE FIRES KILL 18 PEOPLE, INCLUDING 13 CHILDREN
description: Three fires killed 18 people, including 13 children, yesterday at a home in Tacoma, Wash., an unlicensed boarding house in Montgomery, Ala., and a house in Albany, Ga., where four of six children who had been left alone died. Their mother, who the authorities said was in a bar at the time, was jailed.

title: LEADING AGAINST SLAM
description: Computers have long been used by the American Contract Bridge League for dealing hands - a practice that has permitted many players to curse the computer unjustly for their failure to achieve good scores.

description: HARTFORD THE 1984 session of the General Assembly does not convene until Wednesday, but Governor O'Neill got a head start last week by proposing higher gasoline taxes and motor vehicle fees to rebuild Connecticut's roads and bridges over the next decade.

description: AT a time when most of his peers have left the classroom, 75-year-old Marten Tafel is still working there.

title: HARD-ROCK: IDOL AND BAND
description: ''You can't stop punk-rock,'' Billy Idol declared after his first song Thursday at the Beacon Theater. But Mr. Idol himself, who led the group Generation X during Britain's punk- rock years, stopped singing punk- rock as soon as it went out of fashion.

title:
MODERN NOVELS; 
THE 99 BEST
description: NINETEEN EIGHTY FOUR has arrived, but George Orwell's glum prophecy has not been fulfilled. Some of us half-feared that, on the morning of Jan. 1, we would wake with our seasonal hangovers to see Ingsoc posters on the walls, the helicopters of the Thought Police hovering and our television sets looking at us.

title: FUNK-ROCK: NINA HAGEN AND BAND
description: Nina Hagen did more than sing when she appeared Thursday at Irving Plaza. While her four-piece band knocked out rock, funk and reggae vamps, Miss Hagen - in a haircut that made her look like an owl with a pale-blue ponytail - performed like an opera singer gone haywire.

title: BARRING REPORTERS FROM THE BATTLEFIELD
description: Drew Middleton, The Times's military correspondent, has covered most major conflicts involving American troops since World War II. By Drew Middleton ILITARY TEXTBOOKS OF THE future will probably cite the United States invasion of Grenada as a swift and effective operation carried out with minimal casualties and the accomplishment of major objectives. But the textbooks, being military, will probably omit one unfortunate consequence of the operation - the worsening of relations between the news media and the military resulting from extraordinary restrictions placed on the former by the latter.

title:
CAMERA;
PHOTOGRAPHERS CAN LEARN FROM THEIR MISTAKES

description: Mr. and Mrs. Ruben Freedlander of Richmond have announced the engagement of their daughter Melissa Anne Freedlander to Douglas Keith Wagner Landau, a son of Mr. and Mrs Norman J. Landau of Teaneck, N.J., and Sharon, Conn. A late summer wedding is planned.

title: ABOUT LONG ISLAND
description: SEARINGTOWN EVER since Leon Hess called me a liar for a story I wrote several years ago (I said the New York Jets were considering leaving for New Jersey), I have been very wary of billionaires. In my few meetings with them, I found they always thought they knew the only truth. And no one who worked for them was about to contradict them.

description: A State Supreme Court justice has annulled a penalty against a real-estate company that New York City had charged with failing to complete and maintain a covered pedestrian mall in an apartment and office building near Lincoln Center.

description: On the first of his weekly radio broadcasts paid for by his campaign committee, President Reagan today criticized the Democrats in Congress for what he said was their ''pretty sharp rhetoric'' responding to his call for a bipartisan effort to reduce the budget deficit.

description: For the first time in more than a year, Walt Michaels stood on a football field today and coached one team against another. As his team, the New Jersey Generals, engaged the Oklahoma Outlaws in an assortment of drills and simulated game-condition plays at the University of South Florida, Michaels roamed among his players - watching them, instructing them, coaching them.

description: Mr. and Mrs. Donald J. Kraemer of Sparta, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter Donna Ann Kraemer, to William M. Read 4th, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Read of Clifton, N.J. An August wedding is planned.

description: Syvasky Lafayette Poynor, 24 years old, was arrested today and charged with murder in one of five deaths of women by shooting, Police Chief Patt Minetti of Hampton announced.

description: Two Brooklyn public high school runners turned in meet-record performances today at the West Point interscholastic track and field meet in the Army Fieldhouse.
