title: DANCER GIVING CLASS AT ALMA MATER
description: WHEN the Lar Lubovitch Dance Company concludes its weeklong City Center run today, Douglas Varone, a 27-year-old dancer, will be having a celebratory homecoming of sorts.

title: THE SILENT CHASE
CELEBRATING THE 'RHAPSHODY IN BLUE'
description: S ixty years ago next Sunday, the bandleader Paul Whiteman presented a program he called ''An Experiment in Modern Music'' at the now-defunct Aeolian Hall on West 43d Street between Fifth and Sixth Avenues. Whiteman's purpose in putting together the concert was to ''legitimize'' jazz, which was at that time considered an exotic and rather scandalous entertainment. An audience that included Jascha Heifetz, Serge Rachmaninoff, Igor Stravinsky and Virgil Thomson was in attendance. Although several popular composers, among them Victor Herbert and Zez Confrey, wrote material for the concert, the most memorable event of the day, which transformed Whiteman's experiment into an instant musical legend, was the world premiere of an original work for piano and jazz band by George Gershwin, the ''Rhapsody in Blue,'' with the composer at the keyboard.

title:
DINING OUT;
CELEBRATING THE YEAR OF THE RAT
description: TO RING in the Year of the Rat, a visit to a Chinese restaurant in is order. Although Sun Lee Garden in the Wayne Hills Mall seems, at first glance, an unlikely setting for festive Chinese dining, a handful of very good dishes served there are cause enough for celebration.

title: PIANO RECITAL: JORGE BOLET PLAYS LISZT
description: At the heart of Jorge Bolet's piano recital at the Metropolitan Museum Thursday night was a kind of Romantic thickness. Before intermission, Mr. Bolet played the long, often ponderous, F minor Sonata from Brahms's youth.

title: 300 ATTEND SERVICE FOR THE SINGER BRICKTOP
description: Bricktop, the ''peerless and witty'' singer and entertainer and the doyenne of cafe society in Paris during the 20's and 30's, was given an affectionate farewell yesterday at a funeral service in Manhattan.

title: DIANE T. LOWE TO MARRY JOHN N. DESROSIER IN JUNE
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Albert W. Lowe of Greenwich, Conn., of the engagement of their daughter Diane Therese Lowe to John Norman Desrosier, a son of Dr. Norman W. Desrosier of Wilton, Conn., and Naples, Fla., and Anne C. O'Brien of Atlanta and Wellesley, Mass. The wedding is planned for June 9.

title: VIOLINISTS ON VIEW IN COMING CONCERTS
description: COUNTY music lovers will find violinists featured at the upcoming concerts of all three professional orchestras in the county: Franco Gulli will appear with the White Plains Symphony; Eugene Fodor will be the soloist with Philharmonia Virtuosi; and Midori Goto will make her debut with the New Orchestra of Westchester.

title: A SMALL HIGH-TECH SUBGROUP SHINES
description: FOR the investor who grasped the significance

title: ECONOMIC CHAOS CAN BE AVERTED
description: LIKE many of its neighbors, New Jersey is haunted by the specter of abandoned factories and economically ravaged communities.

title: TEACHER-SALARY BILL IN HOPPER
description: LEGISLATION manadating a minimum starting salary of $18,500 for teachers, and requiring the state reimburse local school districts for the difference, has been introduced by Assemblyman Joseph V. Doria, Democrat of Bayonne.

title: AVANT GARDE RUSSIAN ARTS EVOLVE ON THE BRINK OF DISSIDENCE
description: Handwritten signs marked ''Exhibition'' showed the way to the basement of a nondescript apartment house. Many of the paintings were simply hung by string from steam pipes, their titles announced on typewritten scraps of paper glued to the wall. But as expected the intelligentsia turned up in force, filling the small cellar with tobacco smoke and gossip. It was, after all, the first one-man exhibition by Anatoly Zverev, and many in the basement remembered when his bold canvases, austere sketches and bright graphics were viewed only in private homes, and discussed quietly. They knew the basement, too. This was the space in the Graphic Artists Union that the authorities opened to avant-garde art in the wake of the furor over the bulldozing of an unofficial outdoor exhibition in 1974. In the intervening decade the gallery has become something of a home to art on the margins of the officially permissible.

title: CORRECTION
description: Because of a computer keypunch error, the Paperback Fiction Best Seller List in some copies of The Times Book Review today erroneously carries ''Someone Else's Money'' by Michael M. Thomas in eighth place. It should not appear on the list, and the books ranked 9th through 15th should each appear one position higher. ''Mistral's Daughter'' by Judith Krantz should be on the list, in 15th place.

title: CONSUMER RATES
FLAMENCO: ESCUDERO
description: In the solo guitar style that was spawned by flamenco music, melodies vie with the age-old rhythms established by poets and dancers. Mario Escudero, a major force in flamenco for 25 years, played a recital Friday at Town Hall that included both classical-style suites based on flamenco material and more improvisatory, dancelike pieces.

title: A STRETCHED-OUT DRAMA THAT STILL PACKS A PUNCH
description: To emerge from a Broadway theater carping and caviling at an American play which deals seriously, often interestingly, and sometimes very powerfully indeed with matters of social moment - well, that's a bit like emerging from the North Pole during the winter solstice carping and caviling at the sun for being a bit watery. One should be grateful for any spark, any glimmer in the engulfing murk. All the same, it is questionable whether Shirley Lauro has enriched her ''Open Admissions'' by multiplying its original 20 minutes some six or seven times, as the stopwatch I brought to the Music Box showed she had done. In the perverse algebra of the theater, more can frequently mean less. Dilute something enough, and it may end up as watery as any Arctic sun.

title: NIXON LIBRARY TO START WITH PRIVATE FINANCING
description: On the former President's own terms, and with or without financial help from Washington, plans are going forward to build the Richard Milhous Nixon Presidential Library on a high bluff here overlooking the Pacific.

title: OLYMPIC ORGANIZERS ALSO REACH FOR THE GOLD
description: When the Olympics were first televised in 1960, the broadcast rights fetched just $50,000. For the rights to the 1984 Winter Games beginning this week in Sarajevo, Yugoslavia, the American Broadcasting Companies paid $91.5 million, and will charge advertisers $225,000 for 30 seconds in prime time. ABC put up another $225 million for the Summer Games in Los Angeles and two weeks ago agreed to pay $309 million for the 1988 Winter Games in Calgary. For the 1988 Summer Games in Seoul, Korea, Olympic officials are talking of a fee between $750 million and $1 billion. And that's just for the American rights.

title:
NUMISMATICS;
MARKET GETS BIG BOOST FROM THE CARTER SALE
description: Just when the coin market seemed as cold as the weather a burst of hot bidding has given it a new sense of confidence. The bidding took place in New York on Jan. 18-21, when Stack's public auction of the Amon G. Carter Jr. family coin collection realized a total of nearly $8.7 million, making it one of the most successful sales in hobby history.

title: THE PERIPATO
description: To the Editor:

title: A COCKNEY GOES HOME
description: The accepted definition of a cockney is a man or woman born within the sound of Bow Bells. The first peal was hung in the belfry of St. Mary- le-Bow, on the street called Cheapside in the City section of London, in 1472, and could be heard everywhere inside the old Roman wall. A large bell was added in 1520 to sound the end of the working day, or retreat from work as it was known, and was probably heard by most Londoners, although by that time many lived outside the wall.

title: ABOUT MEN
description: THE ANDROGYNOUS MAN BY NOEL PERRIN Noel Perrin

title: Ethiopia Arrests 17 For Distributing Leaflets
description: The Ethiopian authorities have arrested 17 members of an anti- Government group, including three colonels and a major caught distributing leaflets, the Ethiopian press agency reported.

title: Danebo Wins on Coast
description: Danebo, ridden by Laffit Pincay Jr., rallied in the final turn for a 1 1/4- length victory over Water Bank in the San Pasqual Handicap at Santa Anita today.

title: FORMER EXECUTIVE PRODUCING SHOWS
description: AT Northwestern University (Class of '59), John Franklin's fellow students included the actors Warren Beatty (a dropout after two years), Richard Benjamin and Paula Prentiss. At the school near Chicago he also met his wife-to-be, Jeanne, who played Piglet in the campus production of ''Winnie the Pooh,'' while Mr. Franklin played Eeyore, the donkey.

title: COLORFUL CO-OP
description: A seven-story former commercial loft building next door from the Chelsea Hotel on 23d Street has been converted into a 21-unit cooperative apartment building called the Arcadia. David Glatman, architect for the project and a partner with John R. Souto in the venture, said the building at 240 West 23d Street was designed by Charles Pierpoint Gilbert and erected in 1898 and 1899.

title: IRWIN LEADING BY 2 IN CROSBY PRO-AM
description: Hale Irwin overcame the effects of a poor drive at the second hole, a bunker at the fourth, the deceptively strong wind at No. 17 and the threatening cliff and ocean along No. 18 on the Pebble Beach Links today. It was the vagaries of ''Dirty Harry's crowd'' that bothered him.

title: PSSST! WANT TO ACT IN A WOODY ALLEN FILM?
description: D uring an advance showing of Woody Allen's ''Broadway Danny Rose'' - the story of a second-rate talent agent for second-rate talents - there appeared on the screen a stout, balding man with glasses. He looked quite normal and said nothing, yet a dozen people in the theater began laughing. When the man spoke in a later scene, there was applause.

title: THE SECRET TO SUCCESS: STAY DISORGANIZED
description: MY well-organized friends often come to me, begging for the secrets of my success in life and, sadly, I tell them there are some things that cannot easily be imparted.

title: Swazi Storm Toll Rises to 39
description: The death toll from the cyclone that battered Swaziland last weekend has risen to 39, a police spokesman said today.

title: FOR SOME ISRAELIS, LEBANON WAR IS THE LIMIT
description: Among the statistics of the Lebanon war, one of the more significant provided by the Israeli Army stood last week at 110. That was the number of Israeli soldiers sent to prison so far for refusing to serve in Lebanon.

title: MAINTENANCE CHARGES RISING, BUT ONLY MODERATELY
description: MAINTENANCE charges for cooperatives and condominiums are increasing only slightly this year. Managers credit a decline in fuel prices and mortgage- interest rates combined with only moderate increases in other operating expenses. Some boards of directors were also able to hold the line by reducing building staff or raising rents for commercial space.

title: THE WORLD
description: Vatican Denies It Helped Nazis

title: Jurors in a Drug Trial Hear Tapes OF DEFENDANTS COUNTING UP CASH
description: A jury has heard two narcotics defendants counting large amounts of cash during taped conversations presented as key evidence in a Federal trial in Manhattan.

title: U.S. Oil Company Halts Operations in Sudan
description: A United States-owned oil company said today that it was suspending its operations in the Sudan to protect its workers after three foreign oilmen were killed Thursday.

title: Baker Wins Title
description: Mark Baker rolled past three opponents today, including top-seeded Bob Handley, to capture the $150,000 Miller High Life Classic and claim his first Professional Bowlers Association title. Baker beat Handley by 221-183 in the deciding match.

title:
DINING OUT;
INVENTIVE CONTINENTAL FARE
description: A WORLD away from the functional shops sharing the small shopping center, La Mer comes on suave. From the rounded blue and white canopy marking the entrance to the cozy, pinlighted bar to the deep French-blue dining room with glittering crystal chandelier and wall sconces, gilt moldings framing seascapes, ficus trees in illuminated corners and tables felicitously appointed, the decor suggests serious aspirations. And the food - presented beautifully, prepared carefully and unerringly fresh - most often rises to the occasion.

description: I sublet in a rent-stabilized building. The landlord agreed to the sublet in writing and charged an additional 5 percent of the rent. The prime tenant added 10 percent more for furniture, although I am not renting a stick of furniture. He also charged me a $270 fee. Is this legal? . . . C. McG., Manhattan

Brock of Grosse Pointe Shores, Mich. The Rev. Thomas D. Bowers performed the ceremony at St. Bartholomew's Episcopal Church in New York.

title: ONGOING PLIGHT OF WRITE-IN VOTER
description: BY law, voters can vote for ''any person for any office, whether or not nominated by any party.'' If a particular choice is not printed on the voting machine, the voter is allowed to write the name in the machine's write-in slot. But it is a myth that voters can do write-ins at will and that these votes will be recorded and published.

Grasso, was originally scheduled to be the day when a sculptor would be named to carve a statue of Mrs. Grasso for the State Capitol. However, a misunderstanding about the information to be submitted by prospective artists has resulted in a delay in the selection, according to the Rev. Joseph A. Devine , secretary-treasurer of the Ella T. Grasso Memorial Statue Committee.

title: MARY ELIZABETH PRITCHARD TO MARRY IN THE AUTUMN
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. John Franklin Pritchard Jr. of Liberty, Mo., of the engagement of their daughter Mary Elizabeth Pritchard, to Matthew Clarkson Dallett, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Francis James Dallett of Villanova, Pa. An autumn wedding is planned.

title: REAGAN PULLS OUT THE STOPS FOR HIS LAST CAMPAIGN...
description: WASHINGTON F OR all the well teased suspense leading up to his announcement for re-election, President Reagan finally did plunge eagerly into the last campaign of his career, marking its first days as akind of cavalcade of all that Americans have come to cherish or dispute about the nation's master politician. On the first day, Monday, Mr. Reagan invoked the Christian God in a speech and drew an ''Amen'' chorus from a handsomely tailored audience of broadcast preachers. They had to admire his old radio technique as much as his message as the President turned to one of his perennials, the abortion issue, and described the ''pain that is long and agonizing'' suffered by an aborted fetus. Physicians dispute this; but Mr. Reagan demonstrated in his heartfelt tones about ''helpless innocents'' an electric mastery of fundamentalist leadership.

title: DIANE ARONSON IS MARRIED TO
description: CHRISTOPHER CAVANAGH

title: A CITY OF LITTLE SHOPS
description: F ONE WALKS DOWN THE RUE DE Faubourg St. Honore in Paris or the Via Montenapoleon in Milan, what impresses a shopper is the wealth of boutiques catering to the famed French or Italian designers. These are polished architectural structures with expensive furnishings, all of which are intended to set off each designer's clothes and accessories on a luxury level. The same shopper stopping over in London can go to big department stores, such as Harrods, or prestigious men's shops, such as Turnbull & Asser. But what really sets London apart are the countless little shops that feature young English designers, many of whom are just starting out.

title: Virginia Defeated By Duke
description: Johnny Dawkins scored 19 points, including 5 from the free-throw line in the last 5 minutes, to help Duke preserve a 67-64 Atlantic Coast Conference victory over Virginia today.

title: ONCE UPON A SUMMERTIME IN BELLPORT
description: WITH Bellport catapulted into national prominence not long ago by way of the fireworks disaster, much has been reported of its wide- ranging housing developments, its predominantly working-class population. Nowhere, however, has its once glamorous past won mention.

title: SUNDAY SPORTS Basketball
description: Celtics vs. Detroit Pistons at Boston. (Television - ESPN, 1 P.M.). Spurs vs. Los Angeles Lakers at San Antonio. (Television - ESPN, 8 P.M.). College: Syracuse vs. Villanova at the Palestra, Philadelphia. (Television - Channel 4, 2 P.M. Radio - WNYE-FM 91.5, 7:30 P.M.). Oregon State at Michigan State (Television - Channel 2, 1 P.M.) Hockey

title: SHIFTS AT LILCO INTENSIFY DEBATE ON ITS PROBLEMS
description: DID the change in the top management of the Long Island Lighting Company come too late to improve the company's financial conditions?

title: JAPANESE AMBIENCE IN FAIRFIELD
description: JAPANESE restaurants are sparsely planted in Connecticut's culinary soil. But those few seem to bloom and thrive as hardy perennials.

title: NOAH WINS
description: Jimmy Connors, complaining about a pinched nerve in his neck, withdrew from a semifinal match against Ivan Lendl in the $250,000 Molson Light Challenge today.

title: Data Update
description: Conventional mortgages have fixed rates and terms, with payments that amortize the debt by the end of the term. Rollovers have short terms, do not completely amortize the debt and usually commit the lender to renew at the prevailing rate of interest.

title: MISS MARK PLANS TO MARRY IN MAY
description: Lisbeth-ann Mark, a daughter of Elizabeth A. Mark of Washington and Myersvile, Md., and Ross Folkard Mark of Washington and Fenwick Island, Del., plans to marry Charles Matthew Newman in May. Mr. Newman is a son of Alvin L. Newman of Palm Beach, Fla., and New York, and the late Patricia Rossoff Newman.

title: ROOTS OF BLACK POWER
description: THE MARCUS GARVEY AND UNIVERSAL NEGRO IMPROVEMENT ASSOCIATION PAPERS

title: MUSIC:NINA BEILINA, VIOLIN CLASSICIST
description: Nina Beilina, a Russian-born violinist who came to this country in 1977, offered an eloquent elegant recital Thursday night in the Abraham Goodman House, accompanied with deft understanding by May Cuckson, pianist. Miss Beilina teaches now at the Mannes College of Music, and perhaps that explained the heavy turnout of musicians in the audience. But one would like to think that they weren't all Mannes loyalists, and that most of them simply recognized quality and wanted to hear it displayed.

title: POP: WOODY HERMAN AT THE RAINBOW ROOM
description: Woody Herman, who organized his band two years after the Rainbow Room opened on the 65th floor of the RCA Building in 1934, is making his first appearance there as part of the room's 50th-anniversary celebration.

title: ZURICH
description: To the Editor:

title: CRITICS' CHOICE
description: The clarinet has all but disappeared from modern jazz. While a moonlighting saxophonist might pick up a clarinet once in a while, the instrument is rarely heard as a group's main voice.

title: Q AND A
description: Question:

title: I REMEMBER NANNY: NURSE, BOSS, FRIEND (AND BOOKIE)
description: WHEN I came home from school, my mother would usually be reading on her green-velvet chaise longue. After speaking with her, I would go out to the kitchen and have a cup of tea with Nellie.

title: CITY IS STARCHED AND READY FOR GAMES
description: SARAJEVO, Yugoslavia

title: Bonny Warner's $8 Investment Matures
description: B ONNY WARNER'S sports included running, so she was delighted when she was chosen to represent California in the Olympic torch relay for the 1980 Winter Olympics in Lake Placid.

title: The Problem Of Drugs
description: The article ''How Drugs Can Become a Problem in a Woman's Middle Age'' (Jan. 15) was horrifying. Drugs become a problem because people (men and women) are either self-medicating or are medicated by others (doctors, pharmacists, friends, spouses).

title: Cranston Jogs Indoors On Campaign Trail
description: Senator Alan Cranston told several hundred runners at an award ceremony here today that his campaign for the Democratic Presidential nomination had not stopped him from jogging daily.

title: RETRIAL TO BE ASKED IN UNION-FUND CASE
description: GEORGE E. WILSON, a lawyer with the Justice Department's Organized Crime Strike Force here, said last week that Frank Gerace, the hotel-casino labor leader whose embezzlement case ended in a mistrial, would be retried as son as Judge John F.Gerry's calendar pemitted.

title: Heiden Answers Critic
description: Eric Heiden , the speed-skating sensation of the 1980 Winter Olympics, said he had been ''surprised'' by a former teammate's charge that he had not done enough to promote the sport since winning five gold medals at Lake Placid. ''There are a number of things I've done for skaters,'' said Heiden after he was accused of turning his back on skating by Erik Henriksen , an alternate on the 1980 team and a member of this year's Olympic squad.

title: THE NATION
description: Big Steel Gets Urge to Merge

title: BETH ROBINOWITZ TO MARRY
description: Mr. and Mrs. Leonard J. Robinowitz of Succasunna, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Beth Ellen Robinowitz, to David Andrew Wanger, son of Dr. and Mrs. Jack Wanger of Dix Hills, L.I. Miss Robinowitz, a second-year student at the American University Law School, graduated from the University of Pennsylvania, as did her fiance, a member of the class of 1984 at the University of Michigan Law School. An August wedding is planned.

title: SOME REALITIES REMAIN HIDDEN IN THE SPOTLIGHT
description: As a spectator pastime, Presidential politics would hardly be worth watching if its inner realities always matched its surface appearances. But in 1984, as in every campaign year, the challenge lies in finding the hidden, deep pumpings of fear, ambition, anger, sheer chance and patriotism that drive the contest and the contestants.

title: GRENADA: A TRAVELER'S BRIEFING
description: The pilot of the Cessna 402, banking with casual grace, swoops toward the landing strip of the still unfinished Salines Airport on Grenada's southwest coast. We have flown over from Barbados, where I have been vacationing, to have a look at what today's tourist is likely to find on this recently embattled island.

title: Off the Wall
description: William Safire's point about ''off the wall'' is well taken, but I would like to add something (''The Walls Have Ears,'' On Language, Jan. 1). The expression is more exactly a child of the late 1960's and it was born in the political rap sessions of the black- power movement and the Students for a Democratic Society.

title: The Peripato
description: To the Editor: Joan Gage's article about the evening stroll in Greece, ''Peripato - Greek Life on Parade'' (Travel, Dec. 11) brought back fond memories. During our visit in 1980 my husband and I joined the stroll - only we called it the

title: SUNDAY OBSERVER
description: Being Nice

title: Six People Rescued After Six Days Adrift
description: Five men and a woman who spent six days adrift after their two boats ran out of gas survived by eating raw fish and sharing one beer a day until a Navy destroyer rescued them. ''Thank God for the Navy,'' one of the men, Jose Ramon Minsal of Hialeah, said Friday.

title: FOLK SONGS: PATRICK SKY
description: Patrick Sky, the popular 60's folk performer who ended a seven-year retirement last year, returned to Folk City on Friday with a pleasant, low- key program that interspersed Irish traditional music played on the Uillean pipes with original folk songs and gently humorous anecdotes.

title: AN 'AMADEUS STEPS OUT' FOR BROADWAY? NOT LIKELY
description: I t's really not fair, not fair at all.

title: LAWMAKERS HEAR PLEAS ON BUDGET
description: Witnesses at budget hearings here this week, some with impassioned pleas, others with angry statements, tried to persuade lawmakers that Governor Cuomo's proposed $35.4 billion budget was inadequate.

title: FOLLOW-UP ON THE NEWS
description: Vodka Ban Reacting angrily to the Soviet downing of a Korean airliner in September, a number of states barred the sale of Russian vodka in state-run liquor stores.

title: THE ENVIRONMENT
description: AN ADMINISTRATIVE law judge has given Robert E. Hughey, Commissioner of the state's Department of Environmental Protection, extra time in which to rule on the validity of a building permit in the controversial Smithville development in Atlantic County.

title: DANCE: NEW WORKS BY SIEGENFELD
description: Billy Siegenfeld has a dream. He'd like to be Fred Astaire, or maybe Gene Kelly or Jack Buchanan. Or so it seemed, given the new dances Mr. Siegenfeld presented on Thursday at the Theater of the Riverside Church.

title: BUSINESS TAXES
description: To the Editor:

title: LIBRARY
description: To the Editor:

title: IN BRIEF: RECENT FILMS ON CASSETTES
description: The following recent theatrical films are now available for home viewing. Excerpts are from reviews by Times critics. WARGAMES

title: 30 Food Outlets Cited by City ; 30 Food Places Listed For Health Violations
description: The New York City Department of Health cited 30 food establishments last week for violating the health code.

title: Data Bank; February 5, 1984
SCENARIOS OF ADVENTURISM
description: Richard H. Ullman is a professor of international affairs at Princeton University. THE GRAND STRATEGY OF THE SOVIET UNION

title:
STAMPS;
TAIWAN'S DISPLAY OF CHINA'S ART HERITAGE
description: No country in the world displays its arts and culture more profusely and attractively on stamps than does the Republic of China on Taiwan. But then no country has the host of treasures that China has, dating back to the early days of one of man's most ancient civilizations. The stamps of Taiwan are a philatelic cultural museum.

title: CURRY KEEPS TITLE ON DECISION
description: Donald Curry moved forward today to a unanimous 15-round decision over Marlon Starling and retained the World Boxing Association welterweight title.

title: MARY BETH MURPHY TO WED
description: Mary Beth Murphy and Thomas E. Lurcott, graduates of Cornell University, plan to be married in September. The future bride, the daughter of Rita Murphy of Pound Ridge, N.Y., and William A. Murphy of New York, is a landscape architect with Vollmer Associates in New York. Her fiance, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Horace V. Lurcott of Beach Haven, N.J., is an architect with Mitchell/ Giurgola Architects in New York.

title: Marchers in Jerusalem Seek Lebanon Pullout
description: An estimated 30,000 Israelis marched peacefully through the streets here tonight in a protest sponsored by Peace Now, a movement calling for immediate Israeli withdrawal from Lebanon and for the Government's resignation.

title: HOME STYLE AND GLATT KOSHER
description: A NUMBER of readers have written to recommend Jacob's Ladder in Cedarhurst for kosher food. The food is not only kosher but also glatt kosher, a term that is generally interpreted to mean extra kosher, but that in reality concerns the quality of the beef. Attention to certain details of kosher rules on the slaughtering of cattle is stricter if the meat is glatt kosher. Glatt kosher restaurants serve no dairy products.

title: Colts Delay on Tickets
description: Robert Irsay , the owner of the Baltimore Colts who has been seeking to relocate the club, has told his staff not to process season-ticket orders for the 1984 season, apparently as a prelude to a move, according to a published report. The Baltimore News American said that Irsay's instructions to delay ticket applications had been issued shortly before Irsay tried to negotiate a move of the team to Arizona over the Super Bowl weekend.

title: RANGERS DEFEAT CANUCKS, 5-4
description: Anders Hedberg scored two of the Rangers' five first-period goals tonight, and Ron Scott stopped 20 shots in his first National Hockey League start in goal for a 5-4 victory over the Vancouver Canucks at Pacific Coliseum.

title: HEADLINERS
description: Bonn's Solution West German Defense Minister Manfred W"orner probably doesn't believe everything he hears, but he confessed last week to believing too much of it. Mr. W"orner admitted having been ''too gullible'' in accepting reports that Gen. G"unter Kiessling, a deputy commander of NATO, frequented bars catering to homosexuals. The Defense Minister fired the general from his NATO job Dec. 31, saying he was a security risk.

title:
WHAT'S NEW IN FRENCH BUSINESS;
FRANCE'S REBELLIOUS DISCOUNTERS
description: Thanks to the Leclerc clan, price cutting is alive and well in France. The family, led by Edouard and his brother Michel, have challenged prices that are kept high through manufacturers' collusions, Government restrictions on discounts and French toleration of retail price maintenance.

title: TENANT MANAGEMENT ON RISE IN TROUBLED BUILDINGS
description: THE court appointment of tenants as administrators of troubled apartment

title: HOLLYWOOD SURVIVAL: 50 YEARS OF SUCCESS AND OBLIVION
description: LOS ANGELES

title: PISTOL LICENSE REQUESTS DROP SHARPLY IN THE CITY
description: Applications for handgun licenses in New York City decreased by almost 25 percent last year, bringing the number to its lowest level since the State Legislature passed a tougher handgun law in 1980.

title: ATHLETIC INCOMPETENCE OF OLYMPIC PROPORTION
description: IKNOW I shouldn't say it, but the Winter

title: ANOYNYMOUS ROLE OF A MET PROMPTER
description: LAST week the Metropolitan Opera staged seven performances. Joan Dornemann participated in four of them. Her name is not known to the public and she operates in complete anonymity. But without her, and her equally anonymous five colleagues, the stage business of the opera could develop into a snarled-up mess.

title: Volcano Is Watched For Eruption Signals
description: Scientists kept watch today on Mount St. Helens after numerous small earthquakes indicated the volcano could erupt again.

title: Car Race to South Africans
description: The South African team of Sarel Van der Merwe, Graham Duxbury and Tony Martin raced to a nine- lap victory today in the annual 24-hour sports car endurance race at Daytona International Speedway.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: MAYOR. By Edward I. Koch. With William Rauch. 364 pages. Illustrated. Simon & Schuster. $17.95.

title: MEDICARE: THE NEW 60-DAY PROPOSAL'S INEQUITY
description: To the Editor:

title: HARMON GETS 2D CHANCE WITH GENERALS ; Harmon Gets 2d Chance With Generals
description: Of all the former National Football League players on the roster of the New Jersey Generals, none has distinguished himself in quite the same way as the running back Clarence Harmon.

title: GUYANA'S PRESIDENT ACCUSES U.S. OF TRYING TO UNDERMINE REGIME
description: President Forbes Burnham of Guyana says his Government is determined to remain leftist and nonaligned despite what he says are efforts by the United States to undermine his country's socialist system.

title: MONDAY SPORTS
description: Basketball Knicks vs. Golden State Warriors at Madison Square Garden, 7:35 P.M. The Knicks return home following a three-game trip to Texas that produced three victories, giving them five straight, and 125 points by Bernard King. In the teams' only previous meeting, last Nov. 5, the Warriors posted a 102- 100 triumph despite a 20-point performance by Bill Cartwright and a 16-point, 9-rebound contribution by King. Ray Williams is back playing for the Knicks after missing six games with an ankle injury. (Television - MSG Cable, 7:30 P.M. and 1 A.M., tape. Radio - WNEW, 1130; 7:30 P.M.).

title: ADVERTISING
description: Wella Chooses Specialist Shop Advertising to Women, an agency that lost all its Gillette shampoo brands in December, announced Friday that it would handle advertising for the Wella Corporation on March 1.

title: NORDIC PROSPECTS BRIGHTER OR U.S.
description: Jim Page remembers 1964 and 1965, when he represented the United States internationally in Nordic combined skiing. Those were not exactly the good old days.

title: PURCHASERS CITE SLOWER ECONOMY
description: Growth in the economy slowed last month for the first time since August, the National Association of Purchasing Management said yesterday. But it said bad weather may have been the cause.

title: TRADERS AWAITING FED'S NEXT MOVE
description: Credit market participants seemed so inured to Federal budget developments last week that they shrugged off the announcements of a $180 billion deficit for fiscal year 1985 and of a record Treasury financing. But the complacent attitude of some dealers was shaken a bit Friday when the Federal Reserve published a summary of a December meeting of its monetary policymaking arm - the Federal Open Market Committee.

title: MODERATE WHO'S GONE
description: Shafik al-Wazzan, the 59-year-old Moslem Prime Minister whose resignation was accepted today by President Amin Gemayel, is fond of likening the Government to the parents of a Lebanese family. ''It hurts a parent to see his children fight among themselves,'' he once said, rejecting pressure that he should favor the Moslems over the Christian factions. ''If a parent favors one child over another he is not helping solve their differences.''

title: PONNELLE PRODUCTION OF 'LA CENERENTOLA'
description: Public television's Great Performances series is featuring tonight, on WNET/13 at 8, a Unitel production of Giocchino Rossini's opera ''Cenerentola,'' which is, of course, the Italian, very Italian, version of the Cinderella tale originally written by Charles Perrault. This version was directed and designed by Jean-Pierre Ponnelle, whose stage and television credits connected with opera are long, illustrious and controversial, often managing to infuriate music purists and other assorted fuddy- duddies. I must admit at the outset that I am an admirer of Mr. Ponnelle, at least as far as his TV efforts are concerned.

title: CAREER CLOTHES FOR PREGNANT WOMEN
description: More than half the pregnant women in this country are working outside the home, according to the latest Bureau of Labor statistics. For these women, looking good is more than a matter of a psychological lift. It is necessary if they want to compete in the marketplace, go to board meetings, make big sales or simply fit into the business world.

title: Albert S. Pinkus, 80; 40's Chess Champion
description: Albert S. Pinkus, a New York State and Manhattan Chess Club champion in the 1940's, died Saturday at Wyckoff Heights Hospital in Brooklyn. He was 80 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: IOWA CAUCESES: A POSSIBLE SURPRISE?
description: With the Iowa precinct caucuses two weeks away and no sign of excitement among the voters, there are some political stirrings across the winter landscape that have raised new hopes and concerns for the Democratic Presidential contenders.

title: Pennzoil Plans Getty Appeal
description: The Pennzoil Company will appeal a Federal judge's refusal to block Texaco Inc.'s proposed $10.1 billion takeover of the Getty Oil Company, a Pennzoil lawyer said. The lawyer, Perry Barber, predicted late Saturday that Pennzoil's antitrust claim would be upheld.

title: The Rush to Misjudgment on Crime
description: A Senate eager to make an election-year display of fighting crime passed a 387-page measure last week. The Senate should have been content with the bill's laudable attempts to make sentencing more fair and uniform, to ease the confiscation of criminals' assets and to make additional Federal properties available to state prisons. Instead, it rode pell-mell over the Constitution by sanctioning ''preventive detention'' of unconvicted felons and rolled back the insanity defense by about 140 years of human understanding.

title: OF LANDMARK CHURCHES AND THE DICTATES OF PUBLIC POLICY
description: To the Editor:

title: RELIEF, BUT STILL NO CURE, FOR 'MARRIAGE PENALTY'
description: The income tax filing season is when many working spouses rediscover a costly fact of American life: The state of matrimony is not a tax haven.

title: VILLANOVA BEATS SYRACUSE BY 77-75
description: Dwayne McClain hit a 15-foot jump shot with four seconds left to give Villanova a 77-75 victory over Syracuse in a Big East game today.

title:
The Calendar ;
 Monday
description: President Reagan celebrates his 73d birthday today with a visit to Dixon, Ill., the town where he spent much of his boyhood. He is the guest of honor at a Main Street parade, has lunch with his brother, Neil, and attends a party at the local high school before moving on to Eureka College, his alma mater, to deliver a ''Man of the Year'' lecture sponsored by Time magazine. The President then flies to Las Vegas for an overnight stay before two appearances there on Tuesday, followed by a trip to California.

title: LEBANESE CABINET QUITS AS PROTESTS BY MOSLEMS GROW
description: The Reagan Administration said today that it was urging President Amin Gemayel to move quickly to form a new Government that for the first time would include key representatives from Lebanese factions that have been opposed to his policies.

title: 3 QUICK GOALS LIFT CAPITALS OILERS
description: Gaetan Duchesne, Bob Carpenter and Mike Gartner scored during a 39-second span of the third period, the fastest three goals in Washington history, as the Capitals defeated the Edmonton Oilers, 9-2, today. The Capitals scored six goals in the third period.

title: ADVERTISING
description: Accord on Split Ads

title: O'CONNOR, IN A LETTER, IS RESOLUTE
description: Bishop John J. O'Connor of Scranton, Pa., who was chosen by Pope John Paul II last week as the next Archbishop of New York, has a reputation among fellow bishops as an expansive, articulate prelate who is persuasive and utterly loyal to the church's teachings.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''Some efforts should be made to end these bloody events where innocent people are killed and homes are destroyed while all hope is lost.'' - Shafik al-Wazzan, resigning as Prime Minister of Lebanon. (A1:6.)

title: JACK NUSBAUM IS WED TO MARGIE GOLDSMITH
description: The marriage of Margie Goldsmith, a filmmaker, novelist and songwriter, to Jack H. Nusbaum, a senior partner in the New York law firm of Willkie Farr & Gallagher took place in Manhattan yesterday. Rabbi Robert S. Widom performed the ceremony at the Sign of the Dove restaurant.

title: IRWIN TAKES PLAYOFF ATET REPRIEVE AT 18
description: It was Hale Irwin's turn to have a golf ball take a bounce his way today instead of against him as it has in the past. He got the reprieve on Pebble Beach Links' famous 18th hole when his hooked drive was heading for the Pacific Ocean but struck a rock down the seaside cliff and bounced back up onto the fairway.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: Because of an editing error, an article last Wednesday about the new Archbishop of New York misstated the number of archbishops who preceded him. There have been seven.

title: PISTOL PETE'S BRIEF SHOW;
description: I F Pete Maravich were going to feel the urge to

title: MORMONS VISIT BROOKLYN TO GRASP HASIDIC WAYS
description: In an unusual meeting of two worlds, a group of Mormon educators went calling on rabbis from the Lubavitch Hasidic sect in Brooklyn the other day.

title: BRITISH LABOR FIREBRAND: KING OF THE COAL MINERS
description: ''One of the goals stated in our constitution is the abolition of capitalism,'' said Arthur Scargill, the president of the National Union of Mineworkers, ''so nobody should be surprised if we take militant stands.''

title: POLLUTION HUNTERS STALK THE CITY BY NIGHT FOR NOISE AND SMOKE
description: Except for the buzz and click of neon lights, 42d Street was still. Shortly after midnight, a blue sedan with the New York City seal on its doors pulled onto the street from Second Avenue and headed west at a crawl. The three men inside rolled down their windows and began listening.

title: BLOW SOME MY WAY
description: When my daughter was about six years old, she came into my den, where I was happily inhaling the charcoal-activated fumes of a Lark cigarette, and looked at me, tears in her eyes.

title: TRIAL OF SIX STARTS TODAY IN POOL TABLE RAPE IN MASSACHUSETTS
description: Big Dan's tavern is closed now, converted into a Sunbeam bakery shop.

title: The U.N. Today; Feb. 6, 1984
description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY

title: MCENROE CAPTURES FINAL AT RICHMOND
description: John McEnroe won 3 consecutive points in the tiebreaker today to defeat Steve Denton, 6-3, 7-6, and capture the $100,000 Richmond Tennis Classic.

title: Thousands of Filipinos March in Manila Protest
description: Thousands of Filipinos turned out today for a march that combined a ceremony honoring the slain opposition leader, Benigno S. Aquino Jr., with a protest against the Government of President Ferdinand E. Marcos.

title: McDonald's New Effort To Enter Paris Market
description: McDonald's is making its second leap into the French fast-food business. Led by Thomas B. Allin, 34, managing director of McDonald's in France, the company opened its first Paris restaurant after a 13-month absence, and it plans to spend about $12 million to open six more restaurants, including four or five in Paris, by the end of this year.

title: BIGGER EAST SIDE HISTORIC AREA PONDERED
description: Curious to find out what it would take to extend landmark designation to more of the Upper East Side, about 100 residents of the area learned yesterday that it would take a great deal.

title: Morgan State Star Sets Hurdle Mark
description: Jack Pierce, a senior at Morgan State, set a meet record of 7.28 seconds in the 55-meter hurdles and anchored the winning shuttle hurdle relay today in the 13th Princeton relays at Jadwin Gym.

title: DR. HENRY KAPLAN, CANCER-FIGHTER, IS DEAD
description: Dr. Henry S. Kaplan, the radiologist whose work was the most responsible for transforming Hodgkin's disease from a hopeless form of cancer to one of the most curable, died at his home on the Stanford University campus in Palo Alto, Calif., Saturday night. His death, at the age of 65, came after a five-month battle against lung cancer.

title: MEXICO CARRIES WAR ON CORRUPTION TO UNIONS
description: The Mexican Government, stepping up its ''moral renovation'' campaign, has enacted new rules intended to end corrupt practices in letting Government contracts.

title: PENGUINS ARE BEATEN BY ISLANDERS AGAIN
description: The Islanders today completed a weekend sweep of the Pittsburgh Penguins.

title: Futures/Options; Mark Trading Proves Popular
description: F EW new options or futures markets have

title: Valentine Returns
description: The Portland Trail Blazers announced today they had reactivated Darnell Valentine and were asking waivers on Eddie Jordan. Valentine has been out of action since Jan. 1 when he broke a bone in his left hand during a game with Philadelphia. Jordan, the former Rutgers star who also played for the New Jersey Nets, signed two 10-day contracts with the Blazers after Valentine was injured and signed a one-year contract with the team on Jan. 23.

title: STUDY SAYS TEEN-AGERS ADOPT ADULT VALUES
description: A new national study of teen-agers challenges the popular assumption that adolescents are influenced primarily by their peers and a pervasive national youth culture. The findings show that adolescents' values and social roles are instead predominantly shaped by the communities where they live and the adults in their lives.

title: BRIEFING
description: Berlin Hopeful on Tour

title: 3 NEW RESTAURANTS TO OPEN IN ROCKEFELLER CENTER
description: Three restaurants are scheduled to open in Rockefeller Center in May in a move that center officials expect will bring new vitality at a time of increasing competition for office tenants in midtown.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Signing Off AGrumman Flxible bus was going

title: GIRARDELLI WINS IN SLALOM RACE
description: Marc Girardelli of Luxembourg won the season's final World Cup competition before the Olympics, finishing just 19-hundredths of a second ahead of Sweden's Ingemar Stenmark in a slalom race today.

title: RIGHTS PANEL'S STAND ON QUOTAS FLOUTS NO SUPREME COURT RULING
description: To the Editor:

title: ECONOMY IS LOOKING UP IN MONTREAL
description: After years of bad economic news, things may be improving in this largest French-speaking city outside Paris. The Banque Nationale and Bell Canada are building shining office towers, the stock market is gaining on Toronto's, and the lines at the unemployment office seem shorter.

title: CURRENT INTEREST RATES
description: Tax-Exempt Bonds*9.51

title: A VISIT TO DIXON, ILL., CRADLE OF REAGANISM
description: This is a small town on the banks of the Rock River that would not normally be worth a detour. But Ronald Reagan grew up here in the 1920's, a fact announced on a sign tacked onto the top of the town's most distinctive feature, a World War I memorial arch spanning Galena Avenue, which is Main Street, and confirmed by the presence of a couple of tawdry souvenir shops.

title: CRITICS OF REAGAN'S ACID RAIN PLAN HEAR DEFENSE FROM RUCKELSHAUS
description: Republicans and Democrats on the Senate Environment and Public Works Committee have accused President Reagan and his Administration of failing to propose a program to control acid rain.

title: U.S. SENATOR IS INVESTIGATING MILITARY BUILDUP IN HONDURAS
description: A United states Senator said today that the Reagan Administration appeared to be diverting funds from joint United States-Honduran military maneuvers to build permanent military bases in Honduras without approval from Congress.

title: TO REDUCE EUROPEANS' ANXIETY
description: The crisis provoked in Western Europe by the deployment of medium-range American missiles appears to have been overcome. The peace movement, particularly in West Germany, shows signs of demoralization and splintering. The governments of the major Western European countries have reaffirmed their solidarity with the United States. Nevertheless, the alliance remains in a paradoxical situation: Its European members are full of deep anxieties and wish to assert their common identity, and yet wisdom suggests a series of small steps rather than any grand design.

title: REBOUND CHEERS CAR DEALERS
description: After three years of slumping car sales that saw almost 4,000 auto dealers go out of business, the mood at the annual convention here of the National Automobile Dealers Association is decidedly upbeat.

title: Mozambique Refugees Flooding Into Zimbabwe
description: More than 30,000 hungry and destitute Mozambicans have flocked to northeastern Zimbabwe in search of food and work, officials said here today.

title: High School Wrestler Dies of a Head Injury
description: A 15-year-old high school wrestler in Pittsgrove, N.J., died of a cerebral hemorrhage after he and a teammate bumped heads during wrestling practice Friday, officials said yesterday.

title: Desert Wine First In Strub Stakes
description: Desert Wine, runner-up in both the 1983 Kentucky Derby and Preakness, held off Load The Cannons by a neck today and won the $356,400 Charles H. Strub Stakes for 4-year-olds at Santa Anita.

title: Levine Agency Lands Citizen Watch Account
description: Seven years ago Harold Levine, chairman of Levine, Huntley, Schmidt & Beaver, started trying to get the Citizen Watch Company of America account. Last week he landed it.

title: D.D.B. Leaves Porsche As Marketing Changes
description: Doyle Dane Bernbach has resigned the Porsche account because Porsche, the family-owned West German sports car manufacturer, has decided to do its own American marketing.

title: Advertising; Frito-Lay Introduces New Chip
description: PEPSICO'S Frito-Lay subsidiary, which can already claim a 42 percent share of the nation's $2.5 billion potato chip market with its Lay's and Ruffles brands, now antes up another chip: O'Grady.

title: 50-POINT GAMES STILL SPUR KING
description: It was not yet dawn in the booming Southwestern city of Houston as the last of the triumphant Knicks straggled through the lobby of their hotel yesterday to begin their journey home. On the night before, they had completed a difficult three-game Texas sweep by defeating the Houston Rockets, 103-95, to increase their winning string to five and their record to 27-18, fifth best in the league.

title: Nets Get Some Surprise Help
description: The Nets, floundering around .500 and below for much of the season, could grow in stature if Micheal Ray Richardson and Darryl Dawkins were able to contribute with more consistency.

title: A WAR ON HUNGER THE U.S. MUST NOT QUIT
description: To the Editor:

title: DOUBTFUL FUTURE EXPECTED FOR OTB
description: Thirteen years ago, when the first $2 bet was wagered, offtrack betting looked like a sure winner for New York City.

title: U.S. BID CAUSES STRAINS IN BLACK AFRICA
description: The latest United States diplomatic initiatives in southern Africa appear to have led to strains between South Africa's black nationalist exiles and the black-governed nations of the region.

title: DRUNKEN DRIVING TOLL IS DOWN, BUT FEARS REMAIN
description: Legislative and law-enforcement efforts to curb drunken driving have helped bring a sharp reduction in traffic deaths across the nation in the last three years, according to state officials and highway safety experts.

title: Washington Watch; A Quandary For the F.T.C.
description: T HE Federal Trade Commission spent 10

title: YANKEES TRADE FRAZIER FOR HARRAH
description: The Yankees, stung by the loss of Rich Gossage as a free agent, further decimated their bullpen yesterday by trading George Frazier to the Cleveland Indians. In return for Frazier and Otis Nixon, a speedy outfielder, the Yankees acquired Toby Harrah, a third baseman, whom they expect to help shore up their hitting efforts against left-handed pitchers.

title: Glenn Campaign Seeks $1 Million in Credit
description: Senator John Glenn's campaign is arranging a line of credit of at least $1 million, according to aides to the Democratic Presidential contender.

title: Market Place; The Unloading By Institutions
description: A WAVE of selling by nervous money managers engulfed the stock market last week and sent equity prices to their lowest level since late August. Moreover, Wall Street analysts say, prices may weaken further in the near future if pension funds and other institutional investors - worried about the course of interest rates - shift out of stocks and increase their cash reserves.

title: Voters Back Zoning For Resort on Kauai
description: Voters on the island of Kauai have restored resort zoning to a Japanese-financed tourist development, but a citizens' group has vowed to continue its struggle against the project.

title: Soviet Protests Radio Stations
description: Vitaly Smirnov, a senior member of the Soviet Olympic Committee, said today that the Soviet Union had protested the accreditation of reporters from Radio Free Europe and Radio Liberty to cover the Winter Olympics.

title: Duke of Beaufort Dies at 83; Renowned as a Fox Hunter
description: The Duke of Beaufort, known to Britons as the world's greatest fox hunter, died today at home at the age of 83, his family said.

title: CAPITAL NEIGHBORHOODS LIKE TO HATE EACH OTHER
description: A young woman moved to Washington from New York City not long ago and found the perfect apartment.

title: Debt Issues
description: * American Southwest Finance Co. is offering a $76.5 million issue of mortgage-collateralized bonds with a top yield of 12.95 percent, through underwriters led by Salomon Brothers Inc.

title: Question Box
description: QUESTION: Team A has two men in the penalty box in a National Hockey League game. Can Team B pull its goalie so as to have a three-man skating advantage? If so, can Team A retaliate by pulling one of its remaining skaters and putting a second goalie in the net?

title: BOEING'S MILITARY UNIT HAS A NEW PRESIDENT
description: Abraham M. S. Goo, 59, an electronics expert who once directed Boeing's avionics program for the B-1 bomber, assumed the title of president of the Boeing Military Airplane Company in Wichita, Kan., in recent days. But the former executive vice president says his work ''won't change much,'' in that he mostly will add administrative chores.

title: SPORTS WORLD SPECIALS
description: Tall Guy, Short Notice

title: BALLET: 'TANGO,' A MARTINS PREMIERE
description: STRAVINSKY'S short piano pieces have cropped up in the New York City Ballet's repertory over the decades. George Balanchine occasionally choreographed to some and also invited the company's house choreographers to try their hand at many of these brief pieces.

title: PATTY SHEEHAN WINS BY TWO
description: Patty Sheehan, the 1983 player of the year, shook off an erratic start and survived a double-bogey on the last hole today to post a par 72 for a two-shot victory in the Ladies Professional Golf Association's second tournament of the year.

title: NICARAGUA ELECTIONS LIKELY IN '85 DESPITE NEW SNAG, DIPLOMATS SAY
description: Western diplomats here say that Nicaragua's Marxist leadership is still on a path leading to multiparty elections in 1985 despite the Government's announcement Saturday that it had postponed indefinitely an important step toward elections.

title: BARBARA WALTERS SPECIAL
description: Barbara Walters interviews tonight Mr. T, Esther Williams and Howard Cosell, ''three marvelously uninhibited people,'' Miss Walters says, and all connected, in this week of the Winter Olympics, with sports. Mr. T once played football. The program, ''The Barbara Walters Special,'' will be seen on ABC at 10 P.M.

title: FERRY TO JERSEY FROM NEW YORK URGED BY KEAN
description: Governor Kean urged yesterday that ferry service be restored between New Jersey and Manhattan to help cope with dramatic increases in traffic that have put a strain on Hudson River bridge and tunnel facilities.

title: S B Leds Judith A. Kaplan
description: Judith A. Kaplan, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Samuel Kaplan of Neponsit, Queens, was married yesterday to Stanley A. Bass, the son of Alexander Bass of Bedford, N.Y., and Dorothy Cohen of River Vale, N.J. Rabbi Joan Friedman performed the ceremony at the Murray Hill Townhouse.

title: Safeway Stores
description: Safeway Stores Inc. said it would begin a pilot project with a subsidiary of the Lamar Savings Association to open a series of banking centers in six stores in the Houston area. Safeway, which is based in Oakland, Calif., said the centers would allow shoppers to cash a check, open new accounts, apply for home or personal loans, buy traveler's checks or transact most other types of banking business. Safeway said state regulators had approved the six pilot locations.

title: HOMELESS FAMILIES: OPTIONS RUN OUT
description: Betty Summerford and her children were on society's periphery.

title: LAS VEGAS REBELS OFF AND RUNNING
description: Moments after his team had defeated the University of Nevada-Las Vegas in overtime in December, John Thompson, the head basketball coach at Georgetown, predicted that Jerry Tarkanian's Rebels were becoming one of the nation's best teams.

title: A NEW APPROACH AT WCBS NEWS
description: Goodbye happy talk. Farewell blood and gore. Good journalism sells.

title: SHUTTLE HAS SECOND MAJOR MISHAP AS A BURST BALLOON CANCELS TESTS
description: A target balloon released from the space shuttle Challenger today burst into shreds, forcing the astronauts to curtail a critical rehearsal of rendezvous maneuvers for making repair calls on orbiting satellites.

title: SOUTH AFRICA SHIFT: REAL OR ILLUSORY?
description: NewsAnalysis

title: HOUSTON GAS RAISES COASTAL BID
description: The Houston Natural Gas Corporation said last night that it was prepared to offer $50 a share, or $1.1 billion in cash, for the Coastal Corporation if Coastal withdrew its offer to seek a controlling interest in Houston Natural Gas.

title: Hyatt Project Technician Reportedly Failed Test
description: A technician who played a key role in designing the skywalks that collapsed in the Hyatt Regency Hotel on July 1981 had failed a state engineering license test, The Kansas City Star reported today.

title: MONDAY, FEBRUARY 6, 1984 International
description: Lebanon's Prime Minister resigned and President Amin Gemayel immediately announced an eight-point program for national reconcilation. It included a promise to anti-Government forces that ''everything'' was negotiable. The program, addressed primarily to Mr. Gemayel's Syrian- backed opponents, appeared to fall far short of their conditions for particpation in any government of national unity, and it seemed unlikely to to halt the drift toward political and security disintegration in Lebanon. (Page A1, Column 6.) President Gemayel was urged by the Reagan Administration to move quickly to form a new government that would include, for the first time, key people from Lebanese factions opposed to his policies. (A1:5.)

title: PRESSURES ON STEEL IMPORTERS
description: At a time when steel imports are coming under heavy fire, Fernand Lamesch, who runs a 59-year-old steel importing house, is a middleman caught in the middle.

title: SHOWTIME CHALLENGES RIVALS
description: For most of cable's brief history, there was Home Box Office, and there was everyone else. But the recent merger of Showtime and The Movie Channel into one company with two pay services, and that company's exclusive arrangement with Paramount for films, has created a formidable rival, according to industry members.

title: A RESURGENT HEDBERGG SPARKS RANGERS
description: The knee is no longer a major problem. In fact, Anders Hedberg says, it's as good as it will ever be.

title: NEW YORK FINDS EDB TRACES IN SOME FOOD
description: Traces of the chemical EDB, a cancer causing agent in animals, have been found in half of a variety of food products sampled at random across New York State, the state agriculture agency said yesterday.

description: Times Staff Members To Give Lectures

title: FELDSTEIN: STILL STUBBORNLY RESISTING
description: Martin S. Feldstein, the President's chief economist, is not going to budge from his job, his office said today, nor from what he has been saying about the dangers of the spiraling Federal budget deficits.

title: STAR TASTES THE 'REAL WORLD'
description: The class was ''Personal Health,'' the morning's topic ''personality.'' As the physical education lecturer described how emotional tendencies influence behavior, a hand rose at the back of the room.

title: BEING NEAR AND LIVING FAR APART
description: INGER J. RILEY and Martha of tee Strout have been friends for 21 years. Several times a month, they discuss everything from classical music to current events. They reminisce about trips they took abroad, speculate about what they will do in the future and talk about their jobs. "Our friendship is one of the best things in my life," Mrs. Strout said. "I don't know what I would do without it." Mrs. Riley agrees. "We are incredibly close," she said. "I can tell Martha anything because she always understands and gives me the emotional support I need." What is significant about their friendship is that the women live more than 1,000 miles apart - Mrs. Riley in Milwaukee and Mrs. Strout in Melrose, Mass. They have not lived in the same community since 1966. Long-distance friendships are increasingly common, according to experts who observe how friendship develops. Some Americans, they say, look to friends who have moved away for the emotional support that previous generations got from families. "Long-distance friendships are important because they serve as markers in people's lives," said Dr. Dorothy C. Krugman, a child psychologist with the Children's Aid Society. "They remind people of who they are and where they came from." The experience of Mrs. Riley and Mrs. Strout bears that out. "Nobody knows us the way the other one does because we have gone through everything from high school to raising kids together," Mrs. Riley said. "We can communicate because we know what has shaped our thinking." They met in 1963 when Mrs. Riley came from Norway to stay with Mrs. Strout's family as an exchange student. They corresponded when Mrs. Riley returned home and became even closer when Mrs. Riley moved back to the United States and married a friend of Mr. Strout's. Long-distance friendships also enable some people like Margherita Hawkins, a nurse at Columbia Presbyterian Medical Center, to expand their interests. Her hobby is English and American country dancing, and she exchanges dance music tapes with her former teacher, who lives near Cleveland. "Talking with my teacher keeps me up on what is happening in dance in other parts of the country," she said. "I get a different perspective." Long-distance friendships can be invaluable in crises, as Barbara, a Manhattan banker, discovered. She used to telephone her best friend in another town several times a week when she was having problems at work. Her friend gave her advice that she couldn't seek from colleagues because she felt that would have jeopardized her position at the bank. Maintaining such friendships is not easy. Some people mistakenly assume that someone they have fond memories of but have not spoken to in years is a close friend. "To have a true friendship, you have to do more than exchange Christmas cards or call each other once a year," said Dr. Dolores Kreisman, a research scientist at the New York State Psychiatric Institute. "There has to be some continued support and attention; otherwise the relationship is a sentimental attachment rather than a true friendship." Long-distance friends often feel closer than do friends who live in the same city, Dr. Kreisman said. "The petty jealousies and other minor things that destroy ordinary friendships don't occur because such friends tend to concentrate on the positive aspects of their relationship," she said. "Sometimes distance adds to the intimacy because they know that their long-distance friends will not reveal anything to anyone in their present environment." Such friendships may not last forever. Dr. Krugman said: "Long-distance friends tend to let the relationship go when that part of themselves that they wanted to preserve is no longer important to them. A woman who was active in theater will keep up her friendship with a friend who was also active in the theater as long as that part of her life is still important to her. If she gets interested in something else in her new community, she may end the friendship." Face-to-face meetings may help break up a relationship if the friends find they have little in common, but may also make a friendship closer. "Spending some time last summer together brought Martha and me closer," Mrs. Riley said. "I discovered even more things I liked and shared with my friend." - RELATIONSHIPS

title: CUOMO, WHILE CUTTING STAFF, USES EMPLOYEES FROM OTHER AGENCIES
description: Last year, Governor Cuomo, faced with his projections of a state deficit, announced that he would cut the budget for his personal staff by 10 percent as a symbolic gesture to show state agencies how to do more with less.

title: Bridge: Trapezoidal Cards Are Fine When One Is Playing Alone
description: It is safe to suggest that you have never seen a trapezoidal playing card, and perhaps you do not even know what the word means. A card with slightly angled sides, and narrower at one end than the other, might seem most inconvenient, and indeed it would be for practical play. But it has a value in a special context.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Focus on the 60's

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Bracken Exploration Co., Oklahoma City, an independent oil and gas exploration company, has named Kendall C. Hays senior vice president-exploration.

title: CORRECTION
description: A dispatch from Eugene, Ore., on Jan. 23 about a meeting of journalism educators incorrectly identified an organization completing a study on journalism teaching. It is the Association for Education in Journalism and Mass Communication. Another group, the Accrediting Council on Education in Journalism and Mass Communications, evaluates and accredits journalism schools.

title: Religious Rulings Are Backed
description: The Reagan Administration welcomes recent Supreme Court decisions in church-state cases and encourages the Court to adopt a ''benevolent neutrality toward religion,'' Attorney General William French Smith said Saturday.

title: FIRE ALARMS FOR THE DEAF
description: To the Editor:

title: DANCE: JOAN EVANS
description: Joan Evans presented a solo concert Saturday night at the Cash Performance Space that was simultaneously thought-provoking and eerie, for her dances, though always vivid, kept raising questions. And there were no easy answers anywhere in sight.

title: GRAVESEND MAN AND TWO OTHERS ARE FOUND SLAIN
description: Three men were found shot to death yesterday in an execution-style killing at a home in the Gravesend section of Brooklyn, the police said yesterday.

title: Volmrich Takes First in Skiing
description: Jeff Volmrich, a member of the United States Ski Team, captured first place in the senior I class today in the United States Eastern Ski Jump Championships, earning 177.8 points on jumps of 167 and 190 feet.

title: Dividend Meetings
description: Following is a partial list of dividend meetings for the week of Feb. 6, 1984: MONDAY

title: Ex-Policeman Shot in Spain
description: A retired member of the civil guard was shot and gravely wounded today as he walked home from church, the police said. They said a gunman stepped up to Jose Herrero Quilez, 65 years old, in the town of Lasarte and shot him several times in the back. No group took immediate responsibility for the attack, but the method and the ammunition indicated that the Basque separatist group E.T.A. was responsible, the police said.

title: SPORT WORLD SPECIALS
description: The Right Touch

title: STARTING UP IN SILICON VALLEY: LONG HOURS, FORSAKEN LIVES
description: A little over two years ago, five young men with a vision and almost no money formed a new company in a tiny office above a camera shop in downtown Menlo Park, Calif.

title: COST OF SPACECRAFT INSURANCE MAY SOAR BECAUSE OF WESTAR
description: With major corporations preparing to make broad commercial use of space satellites for everything from high-speed data communications to cable television programming, the apparent failure of a $70 million Western Union satellite may drastically increase the cost of such ventures, insurance experts said yesterday.

title: FIVE GIVEN INJECTIONS QUIT BREATHING, DOCTOR SAYS IN NURSE'S TRIAL
description: The prosecution neared completion of its murder case against a nurse this week with testimony that every one of five infants given an intravenous injection she had prepared in a Kerrville clinic over a one-month period stopped breathing.

title: ISRAELIS DECLARE CURB ON VIOLENCE ON WEST BANK AND THE GAZA STRIP
description: The Cabinet said today that no resident of the West Bank and the Gaza Strip was exempt from the obligation to obey the law and to maintain public order.

title: BUSINESS PEOPLE
description: Midland Director Is Off to Crocker

title: The Editorial Notebook; A Nod to the Fading Boss
description: Meade Esposito was probably the last of the old-time New York political bosses. He may have been Brooklyn's Democratic leader longer than anyone, and managed to retain power long after bossism had been deemed dead and gone. His successor, Howard Golden, is Borough President first, Brooklyn leader second. But Mr. Esposito, who made his living brokering insurance while he brokered politics, was too busy as leader even to light the cigar that seemed permanently adhered to his face.

title: Barking At Ostriches
description: AGAINST a gray sky above the steep brown hill behind the Olympic Village, a Yugoslav soldier with a submachine gun walked his post. Down inside the electric wire fence that surrounds the high-rise buildings where the athletes of the XIV Winter Games live, Pat LaFontaine glanced up at the soldier who was only a speck on the horizon.

title: 'PRAIRIE' SET IS DYNAMITED FOR FINALE
description: Death comes to all things, including successful television series. When the inevitable occurs, most popular series like to go out with a bang, figuratively speaking. The bang, however, was literal when the cast and crew of NBC-TV's ''Little House on the Prairie'' filmed their last episode a few weeks ago.

title: JOANNE WALLENSTEIN IS WED TO DR. GLENN FISHMAN
description: Joanne Wallenstein, the daughter of Adele Satz of New York and the late Robert M. Wallenstein, was married yesterday to Dr. Glenn I. Fishman, a son of Ted Fishman and Joan Kohler, both of New York.

title: AMERICANS COUNTING ON MEDALS IN ALPINE EVENTS
description: Bill Johnson of Van Nuys, Calif., clocked the fastest time down mist- shrouded Bjelasnica in pre-Olympic trials today, lifting hopes for United States Alpine skiers in the XIV Olympic Winter Games, which begin this week.

title: SUMMER CITY MAYOR VISITS WINTER SITE
description: You don't often step onto a mountain peak in Yugoslavia and run into Mayor Tom Bradley of Los Angeles.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: MONDAY, FEBRUARY 6, 1984

title: Displaced Islanders Ask U.S. for Resettlement Aid
description: Residents displaced from Diego Garcia, an Indian Ocean island leased by Britain to the United States as a military base, have asked President Reagan for $6 million to finance their resettlement in Mauritius.

title: FRENCH AIDE MEETS WITH QADDAFI
description: J. DIONNE Jr.

title: Walton Signs
description: Johnnie Walton the New Orleans Breakers' quarterback who has been holding out because of his contract, has agreed to terms with the United States Football League club and will report for practice on Monday, team officials said. The terms of his arrangement were not revealed, but reports estimated the deal to be worth from $225,000 to $250,000 a year.

title: Moscow Says U.S. Is Trying To Turn Honduras Into a Base
description: The Soviet Communist Party newspaper Pravda accused the United States today of occupying Honduras as a base for actions against the leftist Government of neighboring Nicaragua.

title: MONDALE, IN PUERTO RICO, BYPASSES PARTY CHASM OVER ISLAND'S FUTURE
description: Walter F. Mondale moved into the thicket of Puerto Rican politics today, denouncing Reagan Administration policies at a tumultuous rally, seeking votes in the island's Presidential primary and carefully sidestepping the delicate issue of statehood.

title: I.O.C. CONSIDERS FINNISH PROTEST
description: The International Olympic Committee found itself in the middle of the bitter hockey dispute between the United States and Canada tonight after hearing a formal protest by Finland on the question of amateur eligibility.

title: New Needham Division Seeks Show Biz Clients
description: Anyone who was at the last annual meeting of the American Association of Advertising Agencies surely remembers the rousing final session with the chorus, the orchestra and the fantastic presentation of music from advertising.

title: RECORD WEEK FOR TREASURY ISSUES
description: Treasury note and bond financings will dominate the credit markets this week, as the Government plans to sell a record $16.25 billion of new issues to repay about $4.5 billion of maturing debt and raise $11.7 billion of cash.

title: DRUG MAKERS BALK AT RULES IN GREECE
description: Three major American pharmaceutical manufacturers, citing the impact on profits of new Government policies and uncertainly over the future, have ended operations in Greece.

title: SHULTZ CRITICIZES NICARAGUA DELAY
description: Secretary of State George P. Shultz said today that Nicaragua's postponement of the promulgation of electoral laws because of rebel air attacks last week was ''a transparent device to back away from elections.''

title: MUSIC: GEORGE CRUMB
description: At the retrospective concert devoted to the works of George Crumb presented by Continuum in Alice Tully Hall on Saturday night, seven masked players robed in black walked onto a stage bathed in red light. In the center of the stage a single candle was lit. And then began the first complete New York performance of a 1971 work, ''Lux Aeterna,'' done with choreography as the composer originally desired. Accompanied by a sitar, flute breathings and vocalizations of the Latin text in free- style Medieval solemnity, the choreographer Gail August danced, not ignoring the peculiar propensities of the work, even including Oriental gestures she associated with the sitar.

title: A Louis Rich Brand Moves to Ted Bates
description: Ted Bates Advertising/New York, a General Foods agency, has picked up the Louis Rich Brand Turkey Products business from Oscar Mayer Foods, which General Foods recently acquired.

title: GOOD THINGS COMING IN BUNCHES FOR WILMINGTON
description: For some time promoters have been calling Delaware ''the Small Wonder.'' People here are learning to like the label, especially now that some of what they see as wondrous is spreading to this old port city long marked by the unhealed scars of urban renewal bulldozers and by residential decay.

title: F.D.I.C. PAYOUTS AT RECORD LEVELS
description: The Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation spent a record $2.6 billion in 1983 reimbursing depositors and assisting troubled banks, bringing its payout for the last three years to $5.3 billion - more than the total amount paid out in the agency's previous 47 years.

title: LIVESTOCK ARE DYING FROM COLD
description: It is easy for people to shuck off the effects of the heavy snows and unusually bitter weather that has blasted across the Middle West in recent weeks: a few minutes shoveling snow, a rash of stories in the newspapers, film clips of skidding cars on television and brief travelers' advisories on the radio.

title: KLAMMER PICKED
description: Thirty-year-old Franz Klammer of Austria, who won the gold medal in the downhill at the 1976 Olympics at Innsbruck, Austria, has been chosen to carry his country's flag Wednesday at the opening ceremonies of the 1984 Winter Games.

title: Authorities to Drop Charges Against a Bombing Suspect
description: Billy Jeff Cornett, who had been charged with the murder of his brother-in-law, was freed Saturday after the police determined that he was not in the Dallas area when a bomb went off inside a newspaper vending box, the authorities said.

title: LEWIS SIGNS PACT
description: Walter Lewis, the former Alabama quarterback, signed a $1 million contract today with the Memphis Showboats of the United States Football League.

title: TAX INCREASE FOR SCHOOLS URGED IN KENTUCKY

description: Walter F. Mondale has replaced Senator John Glenn as the Democratic Presidential candidate that party leaders say is most likely to defeat President Reagan, according to a Newsweek survey.

title: Greece Seeks to Improve Its Image in U.S.
description: Greece has set out to improve what it termed its ''distorted'' image in the United States and has demanded revision of a United States-Greek civil aviation agreement that it says is unfair.

title: DORCHESTER OFFER SEEKS TO BLOCK DAMSON BID
description: The Dorchester Gas Corporation, trying to thwart a takeover attempt by the Damson Oil Company, will make a cash tender offer today to buy at least 5 million shares from its shareholders at $24 each, Dorchester said yesterday. But it added that the offer is subject to two conditions.

title: CELTICS SET BACK PISTONS FOR 9TH STRAIGHT
description: Robert Parish scored a season-high 36 points, Kevin McHale hit a career-high 33 and Larry Bird contributed 27 today as the Boston Celtics edged the Detroit Pistons, 137-134, in overtime for their ninth consecutive victory.

title: OFFICIALS TRY TO PROTECT U.S. TRACT AT MONTAUK
description: Fearing a seaborne invasion during World War II, the War Department built a military base camouflaged as a scenic fishing village on this isolated and vulnerable beachhead. No enemy ever tried to come ashore.

description: or fresh out of - college or high school, you have probably lost touch with ''The Rivals,'' the Richard Brinsley Sheridan comedy that is one of the constants of steeping us in the English literary tradition. The Manhattan Punch Line, the troupe that concentrates on making theatergoers smile, puts it on tonight at 6:45 in the Lions Theater, 422 West 42d Street.

title: Poll Says Mondale Lead Slips in New Hampshire
description: Former Vice President Walter F. Mondale has lost some of his lead for the New Hampshire Democratic Presidential primary, while the Rev. Jesse Jackson is threatening Senator John Glenn of Ohio for second place, according to a poll published today by The Boston Globe.

title: A Glimmer in the Asbestos Gloom
description: Some 18 million people have been exposed to the dangers of asbestos during the last 40 years, and 250,000 are likely to die early because of it. The courts are already clogged with 24,000 claims from victims. So far this massive disaster has evoked only paralysis, not a prompt and equitable system of compensation. But the first glimmer of a just response emerged recently from a New York bankruptcy court.

title: Lethargic Devils Lose to North Stars, 3-1
description: Only 24 hours after an inspired performance in a 5-3 victory in Quebec, the Devils played lethargically against the Minnesota North Stars tonight, falling 3 goals behind in the first two periods and losing 3-1.

MUSIC: JOHN BROWNING AND HAGUE ORCHESTRA
description: JOHN BROWNING broke onto the piano scene in the mid- 1950's after winning a Levintritt Award and has never looked back. From the beginning of what has developed into a major career, he played with tremendous fluency, taking on the stiffest tests that the repertory had to offer and handling them with the kind of technical brilliance that only a few pianists of his generation could command. There was a nervous tension in his style that caught the ear immediately, but his playing also could be tight and inflexible in phrasing, which often gave an impression of brilliant superficiality.

title: British Police Question Kashmiris on Killing
description: The British police said today that they were questioning Kashmiris throughout the country in their hunt for the killers of an Indian diplomat. The body of the diplomat, Ravindra Mhatre, who was abducted in Birmingham on Friday, was found late Sunday night in a farm lane.
