COMPUTER PROFITS DIVIDE ACADEMIA
description: AMERICAN college professors have always been free to retire to their studies, write textbooks and other scholarly works and pocket the revenues they generate. But when Sharon Dugdale writes course materials for math classes in elementary schools, she does so on the multimillion-dollar computer system of the University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign.

title: HOUSE DEMOCRATS DELAY MOVE ON MARINE PULLOUT
description: Democratic members of the House Foreign Affairs Committee decided tonight to delay consideration of a resolution calling for the ''prompt and orderly withdrawal'' of United States marines from Beirut.

title: Cuban Defects in Canada
description: A 29-year-old Cuban defected from an East German airliner at Gander during the weekend, Canadian immigration officials said today. He was the ninth person to defect from an airliner at Gander this year and the second Cuban factory worker to do so in three days.

title: PIEDMONT AVIATION INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Including tax credits of $1,773,000 for the quarter and $9,541,000 for the year. Results include gains of $12.8 million for the latest year and $12.6 million for the previous year from the sale of tax credits.

title: U.S. Backing G.M. Over Chrysler Suit
description: The Justice Department today lent support to the efforts by the General Motors Corporation to have a Federal court here dismiss the Chrysler Corporation's lawsuit aimed at blocking a proposed joint venture by G.M. and the Toyota Corporation.

title: GANNETT CO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Share earnings reflect a 3-for-2 stock split on Jan. 5, 1984.

title: Judge Reaffirms Decision In Coast Starvation Case
description: A Superior Court judge today made permanent his injunction blocking Elizabeth Bouvia from starving herself in a hospital, but lawyers said the order was unlkely to change the resolve of Mrs. Bouvia, who has crippling cerebral palsy, to die.

title: NEW VIEW OF MIND GIVES UNCONSCIOUS AN EXPANDED ROLE
description: SUDDENLY, psychology is excited again about the unconscious. For decades mainstream research psychologists suppressed the notion that crucial mental activity could take place unconsciously. Indeed, through the 1950's, these experimental psychologists largely ignored any such entity as ''the mind,'' focusing instead on observable behavior. Even in the 1960's when the resurgence of cognitive psychology legitimized the study of how the mind registers information, the unconscious was still slighted outside psychoanalytic circles.

title: ASSOCIATED HOSTS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 29
ANCHOR HOCKING CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31

title: U.S. GUNFIRE SUPPORTS REGIME; REAGAN; DENOUNCES SYRIAN AID
description: Shiite and Druse gunmen demanding the resignation of President Amin Gemayel took over virtually all of West Beirut today.

title: CARROLL J. SWAN
description: Carroll J. Swan, editor emeritus of Marketing and Media Decisions magazine, died Sunday at Norwalk (Conn.) Hospital.

title: IMPERIAL CORP OF AMERICA reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
OMNICARE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Revenue for all periods have been restated to exclude the hospitals' portion of revenue from hospital revenue- sharing contracts.

title: Chess: 2 Finish Tied for First Place In the Hastings Tournament
description: The British grandmaster Jonathan Speelman and the Swedish grandmaster Lars Karlsson tied for first place in the 59th Hastings International Tournament in England. Speelman, 27 years old, and Karlsson, 28, each scored 8 1/2-4 1/2.

title: 9 Countries to Confer In Ottawa on Acid Rain
description: Environment ministers from eight West European countries will come to Ottawa next month to discuss the growing menace of acid rain.

title: COSTA RICA IS GATEWAY FOR ILLEGAL U.S. IMMIGRANTS
description: Hundreds of Taiwanese and Cuban immigrants have been entering the United States using Costa Rican passports, either forged or obtained under false pretenses, according to Government officials and businessmen here.

description: The TalkofHiroshima

description: A LATE DIVORCE. By A. B. Yehoshua. Translated by Hillel Halkin. 354 pages. Doubleday & Co. $16.95.

title: U.S. Team Faces Canadians;  Crucial Game Opens Hockey Play
description: The United States and Canada, who have played 12 times over the last 4 months, will meet again Tuesday afternoon in the feature opening-round hockey game at the XIV Olympic Winter Games.

title: HAMBURGER HAMLETS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 25
CONSOLIDATED RAIL reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes gains from the sale of tax benefits of $11,100,000 for the quarter and $27,500,000 for the year, and a tax credit of $14,900,000 for the quarter and year. c-Includes gains from the sale of tax benefits of $19,400,000 for the quarter and $91,000,000 for the year, and a gain from the settlement of accounts due from passenger authorities of $44,100,000 for the quarter and year. Revenues for the year-ago periods include gains from discontinued passenger services of $154,000,000 for the quarter and $618,000 for the year.

title: WRITING AND THINKING
description: ''THERE was no way I was going to use writing in my math classes,'' said Jane Springfield. Like most mathematics teachers - or teachers of science, history, foreign languages and other subjects - she believed writing was not part of her responsibility. Let English teachers do it. The trouble is that even English teachers often run away from the task; they prefer teaching literature to correcting compositions. Consequently, nobody teaches writing - least of all math teachers like Jane Springfield.

title: Cuomo Rejects AIDS Fund Rise
description: Governor Cuomo has turned down a request by the State Health Commissioner to spend $5.2 million more on AIDS research, it was disclosed today.

title: ISRAELIS REPORTED UNLIKELY TO JOIN THE FRAY IN BEIRUT
description: Israeli officials and Western diplomats said today that Israel was unlikely to come to the aid of President Amin Gemayel with any major military operation.

title: Democrats Form Council On Ethnic Americans
description: A Democratic Council on Ethnic Americans was formed today by Charles T. Manatt, the party's national chairman.

title: NO NEW ARTS CENTER FOR OLD BUILDING
description: The building housing the School of Performing Arts is musty and old, with broken windows and wailing doors, and a parking lot for a neighbor. It would hardly seem likely to attract much attention.

title: HORNBECK OFFSHORE SERVICES reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Jailed Polish Unionist Reported Critically Ill
description: A jailed Solidarity activist, Janusz Palubicki, is in critical condition after almost eight weeks on a hunger strike, opposition sources said today.

title: SEARS UP BY 26.8% IN QUARTER
description: Sears, Roebuck & Company, reporting a particularly sharp gain for its merchandise group, said yesterday that its net income in the fourth quarter rose 26.8 percent, to $582.7 million, or $1.65 a share, from $459.4 million, or $1.31 a share, the year before. Fourth-quarter revenues rose 22 percent, to $10.82 billion, from $8.87 billion.

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL

title: AEROFLEX LABORATORIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Warsaw Pact Maneuvers
description: Warsaw Pact troops began winter maneuvers today in western Czechoslovakia along the border of West and East Germany, diplomatic sources said. Czechoslovak, Soviet and Hungarian troops were taking part in the maneuvers.

title: Senior Bonn Defense Official Resigns Over Kiessling Case
description: Joachim Hiehle, state secretary at the West German Defense Ministry, has resigned after adverse reports on Gen. G"unter Kiessling that he brought to official attention were discredited, ministry sources said today.

title: Suit Challenges Index Rules
description: The Chicago Board of Trade said today that it had filed suit seeking to block rules recently announced for trading futures on narrow-based stock indexes.

title: OLD REPUBLIC INTERNATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
DROP IN OIL PRICES HURT PETRO-LEWIS
description: Jerome A. Lewis started the Petro- Lewis Corporation in Denver in 1968 to introduce the idea of buying productive oil properties and selling equity in them through oil income funds.

title: Skier a Citizen
description: After a 6,000-mile journey from Europe, Audun Endestad, a member of the United States Olympic Nordic ski team, was sworn in today as a United States citizen. The 10-minute ceremony ended Endestad's 27-month quest for citizenship and a berth on the Olympic team.

title: WEBB, DEL E, CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a net loss of $101,000 for the quarter and a net gain of $315,000 for the year on the sale of assets. c-Including net gains on the sale of assets of $28,000 for the quarter and $2,578,000 for the year and a gain of $3,119,000 for the quarter and year from the cumulative effect of a change in accounting for investment tax credits.

title: U.S. BROKERS EXPAND IN JAPAN
description: In 1976, when Salomon Brothers Inc. set up shop in Asia, it decided for several reasons to locate in Hong Kong: The colony was centrally situated in the region, it was relatively free of regulations and it was bilingual. Clearly, the firm's executives concluded, Hong Kong was the financial heart of Asia.

title: TUESDAY, FEBRUARY 7, 1984 International
description: Beirut was in chaos as Shiite and Druse gunmen demanding the resignation of President Amin Gemayel took over most of West Beirut. As groups of Moslem youths attacked key Lebanese Army bases, some army officers and soldiers put up fierce resistance, while others broke and ran. As the fighting raged, the United States Marine contingent at Beirut airport came under fire, and American fighter-bombers and naval gunners responded by bombarding the bases of anti-Government militias in the hills overlooking the capital. (Page A1, Columns 3-6.) The use of U.S. air and naval forces against positions of anti-Government militiamen near Beirut was ordered by President Reagan as a show of support for President Amin Gemayel and as a warning to Syria and its Lebanese supporters, Administration officials said. (A1:3.)

title: Rainier President Quits
description: C. W. Strong Jr. has resigned as president of the Rainier Bancorporation of Seattle and as vice chairman of its subsidiary, the Rainier Bank. Mr. Strong, 54, said yesterday he had resigned to pursue other interests.

title: National Newspaper For Blacks Is Closing
description: The National Leader, a weekly formed less than two years ago to serve the black community nationwide, announced today that it would close because of heavy losses.

title: WAR ZONE ACCESS BY PRESS AFFIRMED
description: A Pentagon panel drafting guidelines on press access to combat zones agreed today that reporters and photographers should have such access ''to the maximum degree possible consistent with the security of the mission and the safety of troops.''

title: COLUMBIA PICKS NEW LAW DEAN
description: Benno C. Schmidt Jr., a constitutional scholar and authority on First Amendment press freedoms, has been named dean of the Columbia Law School.

title: JACKSON SCOURING NEW ENGLAND IN DRIVE TO SHOW APPEAL TO WHITE VOTERS
description: The Rev. Jesse Jackson, buoyed by gains in recent polls and hints that he may be able to attract a sizable number of white voters, is focusing more attention and time on New England.

title: AZTECH INTERNATIONAL LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income.

title: Amway of Canada Drops Tax Appeal
description: Amway of Canada Ltd. has withdrawn its appeal of a National Revenue Department civil claim for payment of about $105 million resulting from unpaid duty and taxes on goods entering Canada from May 6, 1977, to Jan. 28, 1980.

title: DANCE: CITY BALLET, VALENTINA KOZLOVA
description: VALENTINA KOZLOVA made an impressive debut as Odette, Queen of the Swans, in the New York City Ballet's performance of the second act of ''Swan Lake'' on Sunday afternoon at the New York State Theater.

title: HELMSLEY, TO QUIT RENTAL MARKET, TRIES TO SELL TUDOR CITY BUILDINGS
description: Harry B. Helmsley, contending rental housing is ''an impossible business to be in,'' has begun to sell some of his buildings in the 2,700-apartment Tudor City complex on the East Side.

title: Report on Addict Disturbs Mayor
description: Mayor Biagio DiLieto has said that a police report on the heroin-addicted director of this city's Commission on Equal Opportunities raises ''serious issues,'' and that he plans to replace two of the commission's board members.

title: SCOUTING
description: Dressed for Success

title: Bridge: An Unusual Bidding System Barely Gets the Official Nod
description: Outside North America, there has been an expert trend toward opening hands of subnormal strength. The more bizarre systems call for opening all weak hands, leaving a pass to show either strong hands or medium hands.

title: FREUDIANS' PROBLEMS IN VALIDATING THEORY
description: To the Editor:

title: CHUCK COOPER, N.B.A. PLAYER
description: Charles H. (Chuck) Cooper, who became the first black player in the National Basketball Association when he was drafted by the Boston Celtics in 1950, died of cancer of the liver today at Forbes Hospice. He was 57 years old.

title: WHAT KILLED A PROPOSAL TO BAN SECRET TAPING
description: To the Editor:

title: Team Explains LaFontaine Funds;  Money Was For School
description: The general manager of the junior team with which Pat LaFontaine played last season took issue yesterday with the report that the Montreal Canadiens had given the star center $15,000 in exchange for his giving up his American collegiate hockey eligibility.

title: BIJAN'S NEW STORE FOR MEN: BY APPOINTMENT ONLY
description: ''Ten million dollars!'' exclaimed Bijan Pakzad, the Beverly Hills tailor known simply as Bijan who has just opened his first New York shop. ''Yes! Ten million it cost Bijan to make this shop. Two years and 10 days to build the whole thing. Eight months just to remove a wall. Yes, two years of craziness! And the rent! We pay $100,000 a month! But it is done and beautiful! Byooteefoool!''

title: ASTRONAUTS POISED FOR BOLD WALK
description: Despite the accidents that have beset the mission so far, the Challenger astronauts were ready to go ahead with plans Tuesday morning for their most daring venture, jet-powered excursions outside in orbit and free of any link to the spaceship.

title: The U.N. Today; Feb. 7, 1984
description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY

title: LKey Rates
description: Kenny Index, Kenny Information Systems Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: Intecom Deal
description: Intecom Inc. said it had signed a $100 million agreement to supply integrated business exchange systems to United Telecommunications Inc.'s Isacomm subsidiary. The systems integrate voice communications, electronic mail, teleconferencing and voice store-and-forward message services, Intecom said. Isacomm, based in Atlanta, provides satellite communications services.

title: THE OTHER SORT OF SPOUSE
description: To the Editor:

title: JOHNSON 2D TO SWISS IN DOWNHILL DRILLS
description: Pirmin Zurbriggen, a giant- slalom specialist from Switzerland who has never won a World Cup downhill, turned in the fastest time today in the third training run for the Winter Olympic men's downhill event.

title: IN WESTERN SAHARA, DISTRUST AND DISLOCATION
description: This raw desert town of 100,000 people, with brown concrete houses, government offices and mosques newly built or still under construction, has an air of unsettled business, of intentions unfulfilled.

title: REPUBLICAN CHARGES SHIP MISSILE SYSTEM FAILS
description: A Republican Congressman said today that the Navy's tests of a cruiser designed to protect the fleet from missiles raised doubts that the ship could do that job.

title: PUT OUT TO PASTURE OUR IDEA OF AGE 65
description: Age 65 is obsolete. It has become an anachronism as a basis of policy, as a result of improved health and startling increases in longevity for many Americans. And yet the prevailing belief is that age 65 has some special significance. In this view, people are just late middle-aged until they reach their 65th birthday, at which time they suddenly are considered elderly.

title: GENE-SPLICING PANEL ENDORSES PLAN TO CREATE TOXIN-PRODUCING BACTERIA
description: The chief Federal advisory committee on gene-splicing policy today endorsed a proposal to grow in the laboratory genetic material that produces an important bacterial toxin.

title: FOREMOST CORP OF AMERICA reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
U.N. Commission Will Debate Controls on 33 Tranquilizers
description: The United Nations Commission on Narcotic Drugs opened a weeklong meeting here today that could lead to tight controls on manufacturing, trading and using commonly used tranquilizers.

title: 2D SATELLITE LOST AS FAILURES MAR SHUTTLE MISSION
description: The second satellite deployed by the space shuttle Challenger misfired this morning and strayed off course in an orbit too low for it to serve as a useful communications relay outpost. It thus apparently met the same mysterious and disquieting fate as the first one launched three days ago.

title: European Aide Startles Israelis With a Rebuke
description: The President of the European Parliament, Pieter Dankert of the Netherlands, surprised his hosts at a session of Parliament in Jerusalem today by criticizing Israeli policies on the Middle East.

description: Hume Smith Mickelberry, Miami, the oldest advertising agency in the state, is changing its name again.

LANE CO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31

title: MANES SPERBER, 78, NOVELIST
description: Man es Sperber, a novelist and essayist who wrote of the political and literary events of modern Europe, died of heart disease Sunday in a Paris hospital. He was 78 years old.

title: FEDERAL RESERVE PLANS STABLE RISE IN MONEY SUPPLY
description: Stock prices slumped for a second straight session in heavy trading. The Dow Jones industrial average fell 22.72 points, to 1,174.31. Page D1.

description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $15,000,000 for the quarter and $55,000,000 for the year, a charge of $336,000,000 for the quarter and year representing the estimated loss on the disposal of the company's money-losing Bendix Machine Tool business and its agricultural operations, and a credit of $39,000,000 for the year representing the cumulative effect of a change in accounting. c-Net income after a loss of $5,000,000 from discontinued operations. d-After a loss of $12,000,000 from discontinued operations.

title: REPORT SAYS U.S. HUNGER IS WIDESPREAD AND RISING
description: Hunger ''has returned to America'' because of unemployment and government policy, according to a study released today that differs sharply with the recent conclusions of a White House task force.

title: FOOTBALL DRAFTS CHALLENGED
description: Should the National Football League and the United States Football League be forced to draft players who have not fulfilled eligibility requirements in college?

title: DEFENSE FIGHTS SECURITY EFFORTS AT BRINK'S TRIAL
description: A defense lawyer in the Brink's trial demanded today that concrete barriers and other ''paraphernalia of a security circus'' be removed from the Westchester County Courthouse. He said they would negatively influence potential jurors.

title: JERSEY DEVELOPER PROPOSES TO RESTORE FERRY SERVICE
description: A New Jersey developer said yesterday that he was seeking to start regular ferry service between Manhattan and Weehawken, N.J., within 18 months.

GOING OUT GUIDE;
description: -speaking stage is nothing new - in fact, most of what appears is a few thousand years old. That is the problem addressed by the Greek Theater of New York, now in its fifth year and on the verge of starting, tonight, the presentation in English of plays by modern Greek writers who are virtually unknown here. Performances will be at the Westbeth Theater Center, 151 Bank Street, near the Hudson River.

title: BOOKWORM HOLDS COURT IN WORLD OF MOLES
description: Mata Hari? ''A damn fine dancer but probably a lousy spy.'' Maj. John Andre? ''A 'caseworker' in our language,'' not a proper spy at all. John le Carre? ''I resent his anti-intelligence attitude for a man who was in it. I wouldn't touch him with a 10-foot pole.'' George Washington? A man with supreme appreciation for the craft, ''really a bear'' on intelligence.

description: Following is the text of a statement today by President Reagan on the situation in Lebanon:

description: b-Includes a gain of $3,100,000 on the sale of assets.

SUMMER FORECAST FOR DRESSES
description: Dresses have a strong place in the summer collections of leading sportswear designers who, with remarkable unanimity, endorse them for ease, comfort and practicality.

title: STAGE: 'STREET DREAMS' AT LA MAMA
description: JOHN BRASWELL has taken songs from the Eve Merriam- Helen Miller musical ''Inner City,'' which played on Broadway in 1971, and has recycled them through his directorial imagination. The result, re-entitled ''Street Dreams,'' is a sidewalk clown show on stage at La Mama, a chamber musical dedicated to the jobless, the homeless and the hopeless.

title: Conrail Posts Record Net
description: Conrail, the federally operated freight railroad, said today that its earnings for the fourth quarter and for all of 1983 were the highest in its eight-year history.

title: CARLISLE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
ON THE FOREIGN POLICY TIGHTROPE
description: Lawrence S. Eagleburger was talking tough to the House Foreign Affairs Committee. If Congress passes a resolution calling for the ''prompt and orderly withdrawal'' of marines from Lebanon, he said last week, the lawmakers would embolden America's enemies, disrupt its diplomats and endanger its soldiers.

title: Payton Denies Report
description: Walter Payton , the Chicago Bears' all-pro running back, has denied reports that he was about to pass up an offer from the Chicago Blitz of the United States Football League and re- sign with the Bears. Payton, speaking to reporters yesterday in Chicago, said reports that quoted Bud Holmes , his agent, as having said he intended to remain with the N.F.L. team were taken from conversations that occurred ''four or five weeks ago.''

title: 20-Year Maturity On Barclays Note
description: The Barclays Overseas Investment Company is selling $250 million of 20- year floating-rate notes at a price of 99 1/4, through underwriters led by Barclays Merchant Bank Ltd.

title: Ayer Making Changes
description: The Los Angeles office of N. W. Ayer is going through a restructuring that starts right at the top. Bartine A. Stoner Jr., president of the western region, has become chairman and chief executive officer, and John E. Littlewood, a senior vice president and creative director in the Los Angeles office since 1981, has been named president. Also in Los Angeles, the departmental structure - which had creative, account, media and research people divided according to specialties - will be changed to two core groups made up of members of the various disciplines.

title: PRELUDE TO THE 'SPECIAL EDUCATION SPIRAL'
description: To the Editor:

title: RECORD ATTEMPT
description: Two British pilots will attempt to set a world hot-air balloon altitude record of about 80,000 feet Tuesday.

title: Bette Davis Bars Return to 'Hotel'
description: Bette Davis, who suffered a stroke following surgery last spring, announced today that she would not return to her role in the ABC television series ''Hotel.''

title: HARRY D. SUSSNA
description: Harry D. Sussna, former commissioner of the New Jersey Highway Authority, and founder and chairman of Level Line Inc., manufacturer of millwork products, died Wednesday at the Kimball Medical Center in Lakewood, N.J. He was 70 years old and lived in Lakewood.

title: FLORIDA ST. UPSETS LOUISVILLE BY 75-60
description: Al Gipson scored 19 points and the freshman Randy Allen had 16 tonight as Florida State upset Louisville, 75- 60, in a Metro Conference game.

title: Quakes Stop at Volcano But Eruption Is Forecast
description: Earthquake activity leveled off at Mount St. Helens early today after a steady increase, but scientists stood by their prediction that a potentially explosive eruption of the volcano was only hours away.

title: DONALD HUMBUG
description: Donald Trump is everywhere these days - putting together a pro football team with multimillion-dollar contracts, hinting at stepping into the huge Lincoln West housing development, telling the Governor and Mayor where they ought to build the projected sports complex, talking about erecting the world's tallest building. And, oh yes, he also spent some time trying to obstruct a group of his tenants from putting up a Christmas tree in their lobby.

title: INTERNATIONAL HARVESTER CANADA reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-Includes $3 million in net extraordinary charges. c-Includes $64 million in net special charges.

title: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES
description: Treasury Maintaining Quarter's Sales Pattern

title: REP. CONABLE, AFTER 20 YEARS IN CONGRESS, PLANS TO RETIRE
description: Representative Barber B. Conable Jr., a Republican from Rochester who is the ranking minority member on the House Ways and Means Committee, announced today that he would retire at the end of this Congressional session.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: TUESDAY, FEBRUARY 7, 1984

title: THEATER: 'GETTING ALONG FAMOUSLY'
description: WE all know that when New York theater people migrate to Hollywood, they lose their minds. But that didn't happen to Ted Flicker and Joan Darling, two onetime theatrical hands who left New York way back when. Mr. Flicker - then known as Theodore J. Flicker - and Miss Darling made an Off Broadway splash with the long-running improvisational cabaret ''The Premise'' in the early 1960's. Once they went west, they continued to do lively work. Among other achievements, Mr. Flicker wrote and directed a funny, paranoid film, ''The President's Analyst,'' starring James Coburn. Miss Darling's credits as a television director include the immortal ''Chuckles the Clown'' episode of ''The Mary Tyler Moore Show.''

title: AIRBORNE FREIGHT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
BRIEFING
description: Honoring Rusk

title: SPORTS PEOPLE ;  3 Islanders to Return
description: The Islanders, who play the Edmonton Oilers tonight at the Nassau Coliseum, learned yesterday that three of their ailing players would return for the Saturday night game against the Vancouver Canucks, also at the Coliseum. The cast was removed from Brent Sutter 's infected hand, and the center will be back with Dave Langevin , whose knee was injured, and Stefan Persson , whose tonsils were removed.

title: Irving William Hest; Dewey Staff Member
description: Irving William Hest, who was a confidential accountant on the staff of Gov. Thomas E. Dewey, died of a heart attack Thursday while on vacation in Hollywood, Fla. He was 78 years old and lived in the Bronx.

title: SCOUTING
description: Dean of Jersey Coaches

title: DOW DOWN BY 22.72, TO 1,174.31
description: Stock prices plummeted yesterday for the second consecutive session in heavy trading, with the Dow Jones industrial average closing at its lowest level in almost six months.

title: Gill Goes North
description: Turner Gill , quarterback of the record-setting offense on the Nebraska team that had a 12-1 last season, has signed a four-year deal with the Montreal Concordes of the Canadian Football League. He said he had never received an attractive offer from the Houston Gamblers, the United States Football League team that drafted him, and that he had no idea where he might go in the National Football League draft in May.

title: PLAN TO REDUCE MILK PRODUCTION IS FALLING SHORT
description: The Agriculture Department announced today that only 12 percent of the country's dairy farmers had agreed to take part in the new program paying them to reduce milk production.

title: REAGAN TURNS 73 AT HOME IN ILLINOIS, SAYING NATION'S 'SELF-DOUBT' IS OVER
description: President Reagan, sweeping through a birthday tour of his life and times, today proclaimed an end to an era of ''paralyzing self-doubt'' in the nation and a restoration of the ''just and legitimate uses of American power.''

title: A.T.& T. and Inmos in Talks
description: The American Telephone and Telegraph Company said today that it had begun talks on possibly acquiring a large stake in Inmos Ltd., Britain's state- owned semiconductor company.

title: SHARED MEDICAL SYSTEMS CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Rangers Await Morrison
description: General Manager Craig Patrick of the Rangers said yesterday that Mark Morrison, a forward who had to withdraw from the Canadian Olympic team over the eligibility issue, would be assigned to Tulsa in the Central Hockey League when he notified the Rangers that he was ready to resume playing. Patrick, who signed Morrison to a professional contract after he was drafted in June 1981, said that there was no room for him in the current lineup, and that he would have to ''earn his stripes'' in Tulsa before joining the parent club.

title: Market Place; Broker Stocks Downgraded
description: I N the first year of the bull market, from August

title: Spanish Official Warns U.S. on Arms Purchases
description: Spain's Under Secretary for Defense, Eduardo Serra, said today that his Government might have to cut back on future purchases of United States military equipment unless the United States buys Spanish equipment for American troops.

title: BRISTOL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Year-ago share earnings are adjusted to reflect a 25 percent stock dividend paid in June.

title: NETS HALT CELTICS' STREAK AT 9
description: After seeing their last two games decided by shots at the buzzer, the Nets built a 22-point first-half lead tonight against the Boston Celtics. But that only set the stage for another exciting ending.

title: MONITOR LABORATORIES INC reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
ADVERTISING
description: People

title: Career in Jeopardy
description: Michael Brooks , the forward with the San Diego Clippers who was seriously injured last Saturday night, underwent surgery yesterday for a knee injury that threatens to end his career. Dr. Bill Curran , the physician for the Clippers, said Brooks, who had not missed a game for three and a half seasons, was out for the rest of this season and possibly all of next season.

title: INCO LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The year-ago figures restated for an accounting change.

title: '88 GAMES MAY AID SKI RACE
description: The International Olympic Committee tentatively added super giant slalom skiing today as a medal sport for the 1988 Winter Olympics in Calgary, Alberta, pending expected approval by the International Ski Federation.

title: Beatty Asks Dela y Of Prison Term
description: The lawyer for former State Senator Vander Beatty said yesterday he would ask the Appellate Division of State Supreme Court to restore bail and delay the start of his client's four- year prison term for conspiracy and forgery.

title: PLAYSGordon S. White Jr.
description: PEBBLE BEACH, Calif.

title: Homeless by Choice?
description: Some Choice ''One problem we've had, even in the best of times . . . is the people who are sleeping on the grates, the homeless who are homeless, you might say, by choice.'' That's how President Reagan responded in a recent interview to a charge that his policies favor the rich. And superficially, he's got a point: Many of the homeless insist that they don't want help.

title: Eurobonds Slide In Light Trading
description: Fixed-interest dollar bonds were unchanged this afternoon after slipping 1/8 point this morning in quiet trading, dealers said.

title: 10 FROM PUERTO RICO POLICE INDICTED IN COVER-UP OF '78 KILLINGS
description: Ten current and former officers of Puerto Rico's police force were indicted today on Federal charges of conspiring to cover up the beating and shooting of two young activists in 1978.

title: SLAYING VICTIM FACED U.S. CHARGES
description: One of three Brooklyn men who were found shot to death Sunday night in a private house in the Gravesend section of Brooklyn was indicted last week by a Federal grand jury investigating a car- theft operation, the police said yesterday.

title: TUESDAY SPORTS Basketball
description: Nets vs. Hawks , at Atlanta. Otis Birdsong has proved especially tough for the Hawks this season, pacing New Jersey to a 3-1 record against them on an average of 23 points a game.

title: B.U., Northeastern Win in Beanpot
description: Boston University edged Boston College, 6-5, and Northeastern routed Harvard, 7-3, before 14,451 fans at Boston Garden tonight to gain the final round of the 32d Beanpot Tournament.

title: 2 SUBPOENAED IN AQUINO INQUIRY
description: A fact-finding board today subpoenaed the widow and son of Rolando Galman, the man the Government says killed the opposition leader Benigno S. Aquino Jr. The panel said it wanted them to testify about charges that Mr. Galman was linked to the military.

description: A crackdown on the ''drug supermarket'' of the Lower East Side has resulted in 1,362 arrests in 18 days, but the overall problem is beyond the powers of the police, Police Commissioner Benjamin Ward said yesterday.

FELDSTEIN WARNS ON DEFICIT SIZE BY END OF 1980'S
description: Martin S. Feldstein, chairman of the Council of Economic Advisers and a principal figure in the Administration's division over economic policy, said today that the Federal budget deficit could grow to ''a little over $300 billion'' by the end of this decade if the nation's economy did not grow as robustly as the Administration expects.

title: British Prices Rise
description: Producer prices in Britain rose a provisional six-tenths of 1 percent in January, after a revised increase of five- tenths of 1 percent in December, the Department of Trade and Industry said today.

title: Thrift Unit Case
description: The Beverly Hills Savings and Loan Association said the California savings and loan commissioner will hear on Friday the thrift unit's petition for reconsideration of the commissioner's approval of the application of Paul Amir, a dissident shareholder, to acquire control of the association. Beverly Hills Savings also said it had withdrawn its application for a permit to issue 833,333 common shares based upon conversion of $20 million of previously issued subordinated debentures.

description: b-Includes an extraordinary gain of $389,000, or 2 cents a share, and a one- time charge of $940,000 for employee paybacks.

description: The Lockheed Corporation said yesterday that it had record profits in the fourth quarter. The aerospace company, based in Burbank, Calif., said its earnings increased 32.9 percent, to $83.6 million, or $1.30 a share, from $62.9 million, or $1.07 a share, a year earlier.

title: Reagan Schedules Meetings With Hussein and Mubarak
description: President Reagan will confer with King Hussein of Jordan in Washington next Monday and with President Hosni Mubarak of Egypt on Tuesday, the White House announced today.

description: An international dispute over the eligibility of hockey players to compete in the XIV Olympic Winter Games was apparently resolved tonight. Five men who had competed in the National Hockey League were withdrawn by their countries less than 24 hours before the start of the hockey competition here.

Mondale, seeking the support of Georgia's farmers and state legislators, said today that the Reagan Administration's economic policies were ''in utter disarray'' and that the increased Federal budget deficit was ''a disaster to Georgia, a disaster to our country and a disaster to our children.''

description: Two southbound lanes of the P. T. Barnum Bridge on Interstate 95 were reopened early today after State Transportation Department crews repaired a two-foot crack in a steel beam.

description: A Nicaragan official said today that the Government had reversed its decision to postpone an important step toward general elections in 1985.

title: Getty Appeal
description: The Pennzoil Company, frustrated in its attempts to stop the merger between Texaco Inc. and the Getty Oil Company, today took its campaign to a Federal appeals court here. Meanwhile, Texaco pressed on with its plan to complete the record $10.1 billion merger, announcing that it had under tender or contract more than 75.5 million of Getty Oil's 79.1 million outstanding common shares.

From Sales at Mattel To Owning Intellivision
description: Terrence E. Valeski, senior vice president of marketing and sales at Mattel Inc., says that until two weeks ago, he was not aware that Mattel's troubled electronics division was for sale. Now he is about to become chairman and president of the spunoff unit.

description: Representatives of the International Monetary Fund and the World Bank today painted a picture of improving financial prospects for most developing countries this year and said the worst of the debt crisis seemed to be over.

description: New orders for West Germany's factories declined 1 percent in December from the month before but were up 3.4 percent from December 1982, the Economics Ministry said today.

According to officials at the agency, which is known as Sallie Mae, it is the first floating-rate note issued by a United States Government agency.

title: MUSIC: Y CHAMBER GROUP
description: ''ALEXANDER'S FEAST'' did much to warm the comparative bleakness of Handel's declining years. London audiences loved this wonderful ode to ''The Power of Music'' at its premiere in 1736 and celebrated its many revivals in the years that followed. There was another revival of ''Alexander's Feast'' at the 92d Street Y Saturday night; and as more and more general audiences have been discovering lately, the freshness and power of Handel's music are not diminished - and perhaps have even been enhanced - by the passage of two and a half centuries.

title: GLENN UNVEILS PLAN FOR YOUTH VOLUNTEER PROGRAMS
description: Senator John Glenn today proposed a ''national program of voluntary youth service'' consisting of revived versions of the G.I. Bill of Rights, which financed the education and housing of military veterans after World War II, and the Civilian Conservation Corps, which began in the 1930's.

title: PHILIP ROTH'S STRUGGLE TO MAKE TV FILM
description: Philip Roth has rarely ventured from the written word to the television screen. But when the novelist recently tried to develop a film for British television about a woman's 18- year imprisonment in Soviet penal camps, he was rebuffed in favor of a Hollywood screenwriter whose credits include such shows as ''The Untouchables,'' ''Dallas'' and ''General Hospital.''

title: CREDIT MARKETS Interest Rates Rise Modestly
description: Interest rates rose modestly yesterday, as securities dealers concluded from recent Federal Reserve publications that the central bank is less likely to encourage lower interest rates than was previously believed.

title: U.S. UNIT LISTS BARRIERS TO ADDED ATOM POWER
description: The nuclear power industry is unlikely to expand in this century beyond those reactors already under construction without major improvements in technology and management and greater levels of public acceptance, the Office of Technology Assessment said today.

title: THREE VIE FOR NOMINATIONS TO HEAD STEELWORKERS
description: A fierce contest is developing for the presidency of the United Steelworkers of America, pitting two officers of the union against each other with an outspoken dissident as a possible third candidate.

title: Taxes Are the Better Bet
description: In New York State, the independence of a separately elected Attorney General has helped to provide a kind of political balance for almost 150 years. So has the Attorney General's presumption that any law passed by the Legislature and signed by the Governor is constitutional.

title: Mr. Reagan's Vietnam Budget
description: Two decades ago, President Johnson ordered a military escalation in Vietnam but refused to ask Congress for tax increases or cuts in spending to pay for it. The eventual result was a $25 billion deficit - extraordinary in those days - and the start of a virulent inflation that still has not been fully subdued. The Johnson model finds an ominous parallel today.

description: J. Lynn Helms stepped down as head of the Federal Aviation Administration last week confident that his $10 billion to $20 billion plan to modernize the air traffic system would get the resources it needed.

title: REBELS CAPTURE WEST BEIRUT;U.S. GUNFIRE SUPPORTS REGIME; REAGAN DENOUNCES; SYRIAN AID
description: With the political and military situation deteriorating in Lebanon, the Reagan Administration is becoming ever more deeply committed to the Christian-led Government of President Amin Gemayel. At the same time, it is beginning to wonder whether Mr. Gemayal can continue in power. President Reagan has fallen back on the increased use of American military power as the only way to hold the situation together, having decided that Syria has ignored American warnings against stepping up the fighting.

title: PUBLISHER PROTESTS PULITZER FEE
description: THE publishing house of Farrar, Straus & Giroux has become embroiled in a dispute with the Pulitzer Prize Board over the $20 fee that the board initiated last year for each entry in the five book categories.

title: IN THE NATION, The Mess In Lebanon
description: The resignation of the Lebanese Cabinet is a new blow to President Reagan's claims of progress toward peace and stability in a country that for years has not known either; but Congressional Democrats had better step lightly in their efforts to extricate the Marines from the perilous position to which Mr. Reagan has sent them in Beirut.

title: Massachusetts Bans Sale Of EDB-Tainted Foods
description: The Massachusetts Public Health Council ordered a statewide ban today on the sale of 18 grain-based products due to the presence of the suspected cancer-causing pesticide EDB.

title: MUSIC: OLEGNA FUSCHI, PIANIST
description: THE pianist Olegna Fuschi's Sunday evening Carnegie Hall recital, in tandem with the Greenwich Symphony Orchestra under the direction of David Gilbert, afforded the listener an opportunity to get to know some rare and enjoyable music of the 19th century.

Gannett runs 85 daily and 37 nondaily newspapers, 6 television stations, 13 radio stations and an outdoor advertising company.

title: Charlotte Curtis A Feast, Texas-Sized
description: When Secretary of Energy Donald P. Hodel first saw the elaborately decorated 100-foot dinner table, it looked so long he thought he was seeing a shorter table reflected in a mirror. Secretary of Defense Caspar W. Weinberger said it reminded him of some Napoleonic banquet. James A. Baker 3d, the President's chief of staff, just smiled. He is as much a Texan as the hostess who ordered up the single narrow table for 110 guests. He knew he was in for the stuff of Texas legend.

title: MRS. LLOYD IS STILL SEEKING RIGHT SHOT
description: Outside the Ritz Carlton Hotel on Central Park South, a photographer from a British tabloid leaned against a lamppost, vigilantly watching the revolving door to catch his quarry coming or going. Other British journalists staked out a Manhattan television studio, a hotel in Memphis and a couple of airports in between. Their cameras and pencils were poised to record in soap-opera detail the latest agonies of Chris Evert Lloyd and her English husband, John, who last week announced a trial separation after almost five years of marriage.

Improvement At Pepsico
description: Pepsico Inc., the second-largest soft drink producer, reported yesterday that fourth-quarter profits totaled $77.2 million, or 82 cents a share, compared with a year-earlier loss of $40.7 million. Its latest results, the company said, were aided by strong performances at the Frito-Lay and food service units.

title: Trade Deficit Record in '83
description: The United States posted a record $60.6 billion foreign trade deficit for 1983, the Commerce Department said today.

title: CLEVELAND VOTERS BACK LOAN TO MILL
description: Voters today approved a bitterly disputed city plan to lend $7.5 million in Federal grant money to a private developer to build a steel mill.

title: ST. JOSEPH'S RALLIES TO TOPPLE DEPAUL
description: Tony Costner scored 18 points and Bob Lojewski had 13 as St. Joseph's, with the help of 13 consecutive points early in the second half, upset previously unbeaten DePaul, 58-45, tonight.

title: A LESSON IN THE HISTORY OF ARMS
description: OUR capacity for wickedness is a constant; only the ways in which we practice it change. ''The Arming of the Earth,'' the new chapter of ''A Walk Though the 20th Century With Bill Moyers,'' examines tonight the development of three weapons: the machine gun, submarine and airplane. Each enlarged the technology of destruction, facilitating the slaughter of innocents, while writing new rules for war. One rule gave way to another; each new rule obviated the one before. The final rule may be there is no rule at all.

title: Back to Springfield
description: He was frozen out in Sarajevo, but Don Dietrich will be in for a warm welcome when he returns to Spring- field, Mass., this week. One of five players disqualified from Olympic teams because they had played in the National Hockey League, Dietrich, a defenseman who was a member of the Canadian squad, is due to rejoin the Springfield Indians of the American Hockey League Friday.

Wayne Peace, the quarterback from the Univesrity of Florida, signed a three-year contract with the United States Football League's Tampa Bay Bandits.

title: ST. JOHN'S BEATEN BY PROVIDENCE, 65 TO 60
description: St. John's slumping basketball team suffered its seventh defeat in eight games and fourth in a row tonight as Providence College rallied for a 65-60 Big East Conference victory at the Civic Center.

title: HEADED BUREAU OF STANDARDS
description: Allen V. Astin, who for 17 years directed the National Bureau of Standards and became the central figure in a controversy over the effectiveness of a battery additive, died Saturday in Bethesda, Md., of a heart attack at the age of 79.

title: Honeywell-NCR
description: Honeywell Inc. and the NCR Corporation said they had signed a joint technology agreement that would permit Honeywell to use an NCR 32-bit microprocessor to develop small- and medium-size computers. The agreement is one of several among the manufacturers of large, mainframe computers that are attempting to enter the small office systems business. NCR is trying to make its 32-bit chip, which can process 32 pieces of information at one time, an industry standard.

title: Howe, Dodgers Agree
description: Steve Howe, one of four players suspended by Commissioner Bowie Kuhn for involvement with illegal drugs, decided yesterday to settle his contract differences with the Los Angeles Dodgers rather than go to salary arbitration. According to a source familiar with Howe's negotiations, the relief pitcher agreed to accept the $325,000 figure the Dodgers submitted for arbitration.

title: NEW BRONX INDUSTRIAL PARK WILL BE DEVELOPED BY CITY
description: Encouraged by the success of the four-year-old Bathgate Industrial Park in the South Bronx, the city said yesterday that it would develop a similar park less than a mile away.

title: WAR ACROSS THE BACK LOT MAY BE GROWN-UP GAME
description: In and around San Jose, Calif., electronics companies fire off declarations of war, challenging each other up and down Silicon Valley. But this time the stakes are not millions of dollars in computer business, but flags. The contest is the National Survival Game, a pastime that the manual describes as an adult version of capture-the-flag, but which has more than a passing resemblance to cowboys-and-Indians.

title: HOUSE VOTES CURB ON SALVADOR AID
description: The House of Representatives approved legislation today that would again make improvements in human rights in El Salvador a condition of United States military aid.tary aid.

title: PAGEANTRY TO MARK OPENING CEREMONY
description: The opening ceremonies of the XIV Olympic Winter Games will be held Wednesday afternoon, strange timing because the first six hockey games of these Olympics were played today.

description: A 56- year-old indigent ordered to undergo life-saving surgery was in stable condition today after doctors amputated his gangrene-infected feet.

Article 230530 -- No Title
description: The Bank of Boston, celebrating its bicentennial, announced today that it was creating a $1.5 million endowment for the Boston public school system.

title: NAVAL AIDE QUESTIONS PRESS
description: A senior Navy officer said today that the customary rules under which the press has covered combat failed to recognize change in the technologies of communication and in the attitudes of the war correspondents themselves.

title: Ex-Delaware Legislator To Seek Biden's Seat
description: John Burris, a former Republican State Representative, will challenge Senator Joseph R. Biden Jr., a Delaware Democrat who is expected to seek election to a third term in November, Mr. Burris's campaign manager said today.

title: YONKERS SETTLES PORTION OF 1980 SEGREGATION SUIT
description: Part of a four- year-old Federal lawsuit that accuses this city of segregation in its public housing and its schools was settled today, with an agreement to build 200 new units of public housing in a predominantly white area.

title: ALLEN ORGAN CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Star Stays in School
description: The Philadelphia Stars tried their best to sign him, but Kenny Jackson , Penn State's record-breaking wide receiver, said he had turned down the offer of an immediate contract in favor of completing his education. ''I'm not going to jump up and leave school,'' said Jackson, who said he was afraid that if he did leave school to join the United States Football League he might not go back for his degree. ''I've got my priorities straight,'' he said, citing the experience of his brother, Roger , a defensive back with the Stars, who had interrupted his education to play professional football, intending to return to school later. . . . The Michigan Panthers have broken off talks with their No. 1 draft pick, Carl Banks , a former Michigan State linebacker, after concluding that it would hurt team morale to sign a rookie to an expensive contract.

description: b-Includes increases from a change in accounting of $2,900,000, or 10 cents a share, for the quarter and $1,500,000 , or 5 cents a share, for the year. c-After losses from discontinued operations of $400,000 for the quarter and $14,600,000 for the year, losses from the disposal of operations of $16,500,000 for the quarter and $23,000,000 for the year, an increase of $1,700,000, or 6 cents a share, for the quarter from a change in accounting, and a decrease of $1,700,000 for the year from a change in accounting. title: AMERICANS IN BEIRUT: LIVING IN THE MIDDLE OF THE FIGHTING
description: The United States citizens who live in the Beirut area are a diverse group, numbering an estimated 3,000, not counting the United States Marine contingent deployed next to Beirut International Airport.

title: Fuji Photo Profit Rises
description: The Fuji Photo Film Company said today that its profits for the fiscal year ended last Oct. 20 rose to the equivalent of $250.4 million, from $240.3 million the year before. The maker of film and other photographic equipment said sales rose to $2.71 billion, from $2.51 billion.

title: Suspect in a Virginia Slaying Faces Charges in Four Others
description: A man charged with murder in the death of a Hampton woman will also be charged with murder in the slayings of four other women on the Virginia Peninsula, the authorities said today.

title: BRITAIN REPORTED ON VERGE OF A PULLOUT
description: Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher is on the verge of ordering Britain's 115-member military contingent out of Beirut, senior officials of her Government said tonight.

description: b-Net loss.

REGAN CAUTIONS ON ECONOMY
description: Treasury Secretary Donald T. Regan said today that the economic recovery could be aborted if the Government and the Federal Reserve Board were not careful in their actions over the next six months. Mr. Regan said that deficits had to be cut and that the Federal Reserve had to prevent its policy from being too tight.

title: Air Midwest
description: Air Midwest, a large regional airline, has dropped plans to buy Air Illinois because the idea has become ''less and less attractive,'' Air Midwest's president, Gary Adamson, said.

title: Hawaii Union Chief Gets 2 Years for Perjury
description: Walter H. Kupau, an $83,000-a-year business representative for the Hawaii Carpenters Union, was sentenced to two years in prison and fined $10,000 today after his conviction on Federal perjury charges.

title: First Boston Net Off 42.4%
description: First Boston Inc. said yesterday that net income in the fourth quarter fell 42.4 percent, to $20 million, or $1.57 a share, from $34.7 million, or $3.23 a share, in the quarter a year earlier.

title: A CHANNEL THAT FOCUSES ON GOVERNMENT
description: A growing number of Americans, apparently hungry for an unedited view of their government, have begun to watch the unusual and often live television programs offered by the Cable Satellite Public Affairs Network, widely known as C-SPAN.

title: G.M. EARNS $1.3 BILLION IN QUARTER
description: The General Motors Corporation reported today that it earned a record $1.3 billion in the fourth quarter of 1983, almost nine times as much as in the comparable 1982 period, and a turnaround from three years ago, when the company was reporting losses.

title: Greece Assails Accord On Aviation With U.S.
description: Greece today denounced the Civil Aviation Agreement that has existed since 1946 between Greece and the United States, asserting that the accord was financially detrimental to Greek commercial aviation and that the trend was getting worse.

title: Sikh Strike in Northern India
description: Indian authorities deployed nearly 50,000 troops across Punjab today to guard against possible violence during a strike by Sikhs demanding autonomy for the wealthy northwestern state. The Government of Prime Minister Indira Gandhi also ordered all bus and train services canceled and educational institutions closed Wednesday throughout Punjab.

title: FOR THE MARINES, FIRST FLOWERS AND NOW SANDBAGS
description: In its 16 months in Lebanon, the United States Marine force went from one that was welcomed by women throwing flowers and that patrolled with unloaded rifles to one that came under frequent and often heavy attack. In the end, the marines were virtually unable to move beyond their sandbagged bunkers at Beirut International Airport.

title: Exhibition on Trade
description: ''Silk Roads/China Ships,'' an exhibition on the trade between the Orient and the West from the first century to the early 20th century, will open on Feb. 17 at the American Museum of Natural History, Central Park West at 79th Street. The display contains textiles, porcelains, paintings, maps and other items and is drawn from collections at the Royal Ontario Museum in Toronto and other Canadian museums. It will be on view through May 12.

description: REMEMBER the Basic Bus? That goes back to 1970 when Metromedia ran the bus advertising in our town. The idea was to sell all inside advertising on a single bus to a single company and to inundate the passengers with its messages.

title: MISSING CHILDREN: U.S. FUNDS SOUGHT
description: A woman who said her daughter was abducted twice told a Senate subcommittee today that pending legislation would help in locating 150,000 children who are kidnapped each year. Two- thirds of the cases are said to be so- called custodial kidnappings, involving disputes between parents.

description: The principle owner of The National Leader said today that the weekly newspaper that serves the nation's blacks is not folding as its publisher announced but is reducing its number of issues.

description: He wrote the big ''10-5-3'' investment tax incentive bill for corporations in 1981 and, as ranking Republican on the Ways and Means Committee, skillfully guided it through the House. But that didn't mean he was a patsy for the wealthy.

title: FIGHTING MANAGEMENT
description: In the last year, the 205-day strike by 21,000 Caterpillar Tractor workers, the nine-week strike by 16,000 Con Edison workers, the three-week strike by 675,000 A.T.& T. workers and the long ongoing strike by Phelps Dodge copper miners in Arizona all probably could have been averted, or their duration greatly reduced, if labor leaders had understood and used sophisticated strategy and tactics in confronting management.

ISRAELIS ADMIT LAXITY ON OFFENSES BY SETTLERS
description: The Israeli Justice Ministry made public an internal report today that documented a pattern of official leniency toward Jewish settlers suspected of violent crimes against Arabs on the occupied West Bank. The report, written in 1982, was issued in response to public pressure in view of suspected Jewish terrorism.

description: To the Editor:

title: SHUTTLE PROBLEMS LEAD TO A 'RECALL'
description: Until engineers find and fix the problem that left two satellites unusable this week, the National Aeronautics and Space Administration's space transportation system will be unable to launch heavy payloads to high orbit, officials say. That threatens a major source of income for the shuttle program.

title: E G & G INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
2 EUROPES BRIDGE THE GAP
description: Soviet propagandists and Western peace movement leaders have long expected that the deployment of new intermediate-range nuclear missiles in Europe - American Pershing 2's and Soviet SS-22's - would destroy relationships between Eastern and Western European countries. This is not happening. Why not? Inspired by a vision of a Europe that transcends ideological, political and military dividing lines, the countries of Eastern and Western Europe are resolved that detente shall not die. The Europeans are using historical ties - between France and Poland, Austria and Hungary, West and East Germany - to bridge the gap created by superpower hostility. The United States cannot afford to ignore this trend.

title: NEW CHIEF, OLD WOES AT LILCO
description: The new chairman of the Long Island Lighting Company is taking command at a time when the operation of the Shoreham nuclear power plant is in some ways less certain than at any time in the last decade. The chairman, William J. Catacosinos, has not yet taken a public stand on what to do about the plant. The Shoreham plant is now the most expensive in the United States and could cause a rate increase of well over 50 percent.

title: SENATE APPROVES BILL ON EVIDENCE
description: The Senate voted today to allow the use of some illegally obtained evidence in Federal criminal cases.

title: SCOUTING
description: An Unveiling Of Champions

description: WEDNESDAY, FEBRUARY 8, 1984

title: 60-MINUTE GOURMET
description: RICE, which is used in most parts of the world, is not only nourishing but also remarkably versatile and is complementary to other dishes. It also has a long history as a dietary staple, being among the grains cultivated from the earliest times.

title: Baldwin-United Plan Challenged
description: A committee representing policyholders has asked an Arkansas court to reject a rehabilitation plan proposed by the Arkansas Insurance Commissioner for six insurance companies belonging to the Baldwin-United Corporation.

title: CHINA BIDS TO STORE RADIOACTIVE WASTE
description: The Chinese Government is offering to store dangerous radioactive waste from European nuclear reactors in remote areas of the country in return for badly needed Western currency. The deal could be worth as much as $5.45 billion, according to one European official.

title: METROPOLITAN DIARY
description: EVERY year at this time Lynn Goldberg of the Village Visiting Neighbors sits down to a heap of red hearts and lacy doilies and begins ''censoring the valentines,'' as she puts it. Not that the Visiting Neighbors are opposed to loving expressions of sentiment. On the contrary, the volunteer group was formed 12 years ago to brighten the lives of the elderly in Greenwich Village, and one of the many ways they do this is to encourage local schoolchildren to make valentine cards for the 200 old people served by the program.

title: A ROOKIE HELPS TOPPLE NETS
description: As the Knicks' assistant coach last season, Mike Fratello kept the statistics. Now, as the Atlanta Hawks' head coach, he tosses them around much the way his former boss, Hubie Brown of the Knicks, does.

title: Whalers 4 Red Wings 1
description: Greg Malone scored on a 30-foot wrist shot late in the second period to give Hartford the victory. Malone's goal, at 17:06, gave Hartford a 2-1 lead and the Whalers then skated to their their third consecutive victory - the first time the struggling Hartford team has won three in a row this season.

title: F.B.I. IS ORDERED TO PAY $35,000 TO 'FREEDOM RIDER' INJURED IN '61
description: The Federal Bureau of Investigation was ordered today to pay $35,000 to a wheelchair-bound civil rights activist for injuries he received in a Ku Klux Klan beating nearly 23 years ago on a Freedom Ride through Alabama.

title: MARINES AWAITING INSTRUCTIONS
description: A Marine spokesman, Maj. Dennis Brooks, said this morning that the marines were awaiting further instructions from the Defense Department and could be out of Beirut in three or four days if needed.

title: REAGAN STEPS UP PARTISAN ATTACK
description: President Reagan today accused his Democratic predecessors of having ''ravaged'' the nation with inflation and having induced a wave of ''national self-doubt as never before experienced in this country.''

title: CUOMO MAY PULL GRAIN PRODUCTS OFF SHELVES TILL STATE EDB RULES ARE MET
description: The Cuomo administration said today that it would order all grain products removed from grocery shelves in New York State in 10 days and bar their replacement until the products met strict state standards for the presence of the chemical EDB.

title: 2 ASTRONAUTS FLOAT FREE IN SPACE, 170 MILES UP
description: In a spectacle of bravery and beauty, two American astronauts flew out, up and away from the space shuttle Challenger today. Free of any lifeline and propelled into the dark void by tiny jets, they became, in effect, the first human satellites.

description: The violinist and conductor Yehudi Menuhin, the composer Thea Musgave and Sarah Caldwell, artistic director of the Opera Company of Boston, will participate in a three-part lecture series on music sponsored by the New York Institute for the Humanities at New York University.

title: Wayne State to Study Elderly's Role in Politics
description: Wayne State University has received a $39,110 grant from the Andrus Foundation of the American Association of Retired Persons to study what motivates the elderly to get involved in politics.

title: NEW DIVERSITY ADDS FLAVOR TO CHINATOWN'S CUISINE
description: GASTRONOMICALLY, the face of New York's Chinatown is changing, with more of its restaurants, markets and food reflecting a new influx of immigrants from Hong Kong. For almost a century this downtown Manhattan neighborhood was an enclave of Americanized Cantonese restaurants, teahouses and groceries - the legacy of the first immigrants from the Toisan suburb of Canton. In the past year, however, it has become an area of much greater culinary breadth.

title: LIFE IN WEST BEIRUT COMES FULL CIRCLE
description: Seventeen months after the Israeli Army forced the Palestine Liberation Organization out of West Beirut and suppressed the coalition of Lebanese Moslem leftist militiamen aligned with the P.L.O., events here have come full circle.

title: FLU SHOTS DEBATED FOR DOCTORS
description: A Federal health panel debated today whether to recommend that physicians be vaccinated against influenza to prevent them from spreading the disease to their patients.

title: CORRECTIONS

title: U.S. AND SOVIET ROLES IN LEBANON
description: What to do about Lebanon is a grave problem not only for the United States, but for France, Britain and Italy - the multinational force contributors - as well as Israel, Syria, Jordan and the Soviet Union. Participation by several of these parties, including both superpowers, may be necessary to stem the spiraling chaos.

title: HART CRITICIZES MONDALE AS LACKING IN LEADERSHIP
description: Senator Gary Hart today criticized Walter F. Mondale for what he said was a lack of strong leadership, contending that ''the pattern is always there - caution until consensus forms.''

title: PERSONAL HEALTH
description: ANGER. Envy. Hopelessness. Emptiness. Worthlessness. Depression. Despair. These are but a few of the terms couples use to describe their feelings when faced with the problem of infertility. Self-confidence and self-worth dissolve under the perception that they are somehow incomplete men and women. The romantic aura yields to mechanical sex on schedule as tests and treatments for infertility proceed.

Victor Files For Chapter 11
description: Victor Technolgies Inc., as expected, said it had filed a voluntary petition for protection from creditors under Chapter 11 of the Federal Bankruptcy Code. Victor also said it had agreed with Security Pacific National Bank, subject to court approval, for the bank to finance the company's near-term manufacturing and distribution needs.

title: Accorsi Leaves Colts
description: After two turbulent years, Ernie Accorsi resigned as general manager of the Baltimore Colts yesterday and said he would seek a post with another National Football League team. ''This is not a joyous occasion,'' said the 42-year-old Accorsi, who declined to discuss the reasons for his departure. The executive, who first joined the Colts as public-relations director in 1970, two years before Robert Irsay took over the club as owner, left Baltimore in 1975 to serve as an assistant to Commissioner Pete Rozelle but returned to the Colts in 1977 as assistant general manager. Expressing confidence that the Colts could field a contender next fall, Accorsi said,

title: Officials Likely to Get Big Bonus as Reward
description: The General Motors Corporation's record 1983 earnings are likely to produce some fat bonuses at the auto giant, including one that would push the annual income for the chairman, Roger B. Smith, to more than $1 million.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article in Metropolitan Report Thursday about the English Speaking Union misstated the national membership. It is 29,983.

title: TEXAS EXECUTIONS SEEN ADVANCED BY RULING
description: A ruling on the death penalty by the United States Supreme Court is likely to advance the execution date for a number of the 177 inmates on death row in Texas, according to the State Attorney General, who said the first might take place in four to six months.

description: Women who have cancer and believe they contracted it because their mothers took the antimiscarriage drug DES may sue the manufacturers even if they do not know which company made the pills, the Michigan Supreme Court has ruled.

description: Canada, inspired by a goal after only 27 seconds and a goalie who thought he would not be allowed to play, scored a stunning 4-2 victory over the United States today in the start of hockey competition at the XIV Olympic Winter Games.

title: FLYING WITH FOGGY BOTTOM AND THE KITCHEN SINK
description: When Secretary of State George P. Shultz goes on the road, it is like squeezing Washington into a bottle. The bottle is the Air Force jet, a modified Boeing 707, that carries Mr. Shultz and other senior foreign policy officials, support staff, security detail, reporters, a physician, an Air Force crew, an array of sophisticated communications equipment and, of course, a Xerox machine.

description: The Treasury's borrowing costs fell as it began its record $16.25 billion three-part midquarter refunding auctions yesterday. The first sale, $6.5 billion of 10 7/8 percent three-year notes, produced an average price of 99.788, equivalent to a yield of 10.96 percent.

title: SOUTH BOSTON SAVINGS BANK reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
Banker Out In Venezuela
description: President Jaime Lusinchi removed the president of the nation's central bank, Leopoldo Diaz Bruzual, on Monday night, saying that Mr. Diaz had been a ''disturbing'' factor in the development of the Government's economic policies. Benito Raul Losada, a former president of the central bank, was named to replace Mr. Diaz. Advisers to Mr. Lusinchi said it was necessary to remove Mr. Diaz to assure foreign bankers that the new Government was intent on serious talks concerning its foreign debt, which totals an estimated $34 billion.

title: CARTER BREY, CELLO, WINNER OF AWARD
description: AT first, there might have seemed something almost flamboyant about Carter Brey's cello playing at his recital as winner of the Michaels Award of the Young Concert Artists at Alice Tully Hall on Monday night. The young cellist's polished technique, after all, seemed to display its own easy achievements; and his entrances and exits were those of an experienced stagehand.

title: RECONSIDERING PASTA: THERE IS NOTHING WRONG WITH DRIED
description: THE history of dried pasta over the last 50 years is a lesson in the fickleness of American tastes. Our story begins in the Scotch-Irish Jackson Heights of the 1930's, where a small boy has been sent out in search of a pound of spaghetti. Since this strikes him as an exotic request (his mother having announced that she has just gotten the true recipe for Italian spaghetti sauce from a Mrs. O'Rourke next door), he passes the family's usual grocery on the corner of 92d Street and Roosevelt Avenue and proceeds eastward under the El toward the terra incognita of Corona.

title: 'A GOOD SPORT' ON CBS, JOUNALISM AND LOVE
description: TOMMY O'BANNON is a newspaper sports writer and a bit of a lush, given to spending the wee hours of the morning in a New York City gin mill with his statistics-crazed cronies. Michelle Tenney is a beautiful and tough editor of a fashion magazine. When a football linebacker gets involved with the introduction of a line of men's clothing, Tommy and Michelle meet, rather improbably. The initial signs are not especially good for the development of a serious affair but, this being a television movie, only the incurably naive could have any doubts about where ''A Good Sport'' is heading.

title: MUSING ON THE LESSONS OF ADVERSITY
description: Senator Paul E. Tsongas finds himself viewing his colleagues with more detachment these days. He has become less tolerant of what he calls ''political gamesmanship,'' ideological extremists, and the ''Mickey Mouse'' that he says is part of every job. He has begun to savor some things that he hardly noticed before, like sunrises and children's smiles.

description: After barely four years of service, New York City's entire fleet of Grumpermanently last night for being unsafe, the Transit Authority said.

title: CANADA INFORMS ALBANY IT PLANS PROTEST TO U.S. ABOUT ACID RAIN
description: Canadian officials said today that their Government would present a formal diplomatic note to the State Department this week protesting President Reagan's position on acid rain.

title: 2 NASSAU COUNTY JUDGES GET BOTH PENSIONS AND SALARIES
description: Through a loophole in the state's Civil Service law, two Nassau County Court judges who retired on New Year's Eve and were then sworn in on the following day to serve second 10-year terms, are receiving retirement benefits as well as their full salaries.

title: SOLOMON SCHONFELD
description: Dr. Solomon Schonfeld, presiding rabbi of the Union of the Orthodox Hebrew Congregations of Great Britain, died Monday in London after a long illness. He was 72 years old. Dr. Schonfeld continued the Jewish Secondary School Movement, started in the early 1900's by his father. During World War II, Dr. Schonfeld helped find homes in Britain for Jewish children from Austria and Hungary.

title: Field & Stream Insert With Focus on Cooking

title: British Gesture
description: Arnold Palmer , the winner of the 1961 British Open, needed a special exemption to compete in the 1983 event without qualifying, but from now on he and other previous winners will be welcome from the start. Under a new rule adopted by British golf officials, former winners may play in later Opens without qualifying until they reach the age of 65. In addition to Palmer, still a major draw at the age of 54, the rule will benefit such former champions as Ken Nagle , Tony Jacklin , Tom Weiskopf , Ro berto de Vicenzo , Peter Thompson and Bob Charles .

title: ; Franck Avril In Artists' Series
description: FRANCK AVRIL, a young oboist, offered the latest concert in the Affiliate Artists' Carnegie Recital Hall series on Sunday. He is a very attractive musician - one who can add dry humor to the proceedings and still approach musical problems in very serious ways.

title: HAIR AT EAR LENGTH: SHORT CUTS A LA LULU
description: EVERY few years the scene changes noticeably in the pace-setting beauty salons around town. What was a vista of long, frizzy hair seems overnight to have given way to shorter, straighter hair and a younger look even for middle-age patrons.

title: Lakers 106, Pacers 105
description: Kareem Abdul-Jabbar scored 33 points, including the winning shot with 30 seconds remaining. The center was unstoppable with his hook shot, getting 17 of his points after the Pacers took a 15-point lead midway through the third period. A 19-7 spurt helped the Lakers pull to 84-77 going into the fourth quarter. Two free throws by James Worthy gave them a 90-89 lead with 7:47 remaining, then they pulled away to 104-99 on a shot by Abdul-Jabbar. But Indiana got the next 6 points on baskets by Herb Williams, Jerry Sichting and Clark Kellogg before Abdul Jabbar's go-ahead basket. The Pacers had one more chance to win, but a short jump shot by Williams was no good, and Abdul-Jabbar grabbed the rebound.

title: NATO Holds Naval Exercise
description: Warships from the United States and seven other NATO navies began a two-week exercise today off northern Scotland. About 2,500 men and 30 warships are taking part in the exercise. Other countries involved are Britain, the Netherlands, West Germany, France, Portugal, Norway and Denmark.

title: Radioactive Material Lost in Maryland
description: A search is under way today for three missing vials of radioactive material that were part of a shipment apparently misrouted on the way from Chicago to Frederick, Md., the authorities said.

title: SHULTZ MAKES QUICK VISIT TO GRENADA
description: Secretary of State George P. Shultz said during a visit to Grenada today that the 280 United States troops who are still on the Caribbean island would be removed as soon as internal security could be assured. He set no dates.

description: The police arrested three men at gunpoint in an Upper West Side apartment yesterday on charges involving drugs, a cache of weapons - and littering.

title: THE POP LIFE
description: GEORGE RUSSELL, who is leading a big band at Sweet Basil in Greenwich Village tonight through Sunday, was first attracted to jazz more than half a century ago when a riverboat carrying the band led by the legendery Fate Marable stopped in his hometown, Cincinnati. Today, the 60-year- old composer and theorist of modern jazz introduces his latest compositions, influenced rhythmically by funk and rock, with a quote from the rap artist Grand Master Flash: ''I always try to stay in touch with the roots.''

He will take office on March 12, replacing Glenn W. Ferguson, who announced his resignation on Dec. 1.

After all, there already was a cabernet sauvignon, and people had enough trouble with that. So he changed the name of his sauvignon blanc to fume blanc.

title: FOR A VALENTINE, A SWEET HERAT (EDIBLE0
description: ASEEMINGLY endless assortment of edible Valentine's Day gifts are in shops all over town. At Bloomingdale's Bakery on 59th Street between Lexington and Third Avenues you can get a Valentine message of 10 to 15 letters for $10, with each letter a sugar cookie 3 inches high. The message is assembled while you wait and boxed in popcorn (to prevent breaking). It's called Eat Your Words and is the creation of a company called the Alpha Bakery, which specializes in alphabet cookies. If your message contains 5 to 10 letters the price is $5.

description: THE purchase and care of quality kitchen knives have often been discussed in this column, and one point repeatedly stressed is the importance of having a good sharpening steel to maintain a knife's fine edge. Sharpening steels come in several shapes and materials. Most are made of finely grooved high-carbon stainless steels; others are made of various rock-hard ceramic materials.

Among those who will take part are Colleen Dewhurst, Frances Sternhagen, Tom Aldredge, Lewis J. Stadlen and Norman Kean. The service is open to the public.

title: WEDNESDAY, FEBRUARY 8, 1984 Crisis in Lebanon
description: A redeployment of the marines in Beirut to United States Navy ships offshore has been ordered, President Reagan announced. At the same time, he said that American naval and air forces would now attack any units behind Syrian lines that were firing into the Beirut area, breaking with the practice of firing only when American citizens were threatened. (Page A1, Column 6.) It may take up to a month for the American marines to turn over the task of guarding the Beirut airport to the Lebanese Army before redeploying to ships offshore, White House and Pentagon officials said. They said that work on a phased redeployment was beginning last night. (A8:1.)
