title: WHEELING TO SELL 10% TO NISSHIN
description: In the first such partnership involing a major United States steel company, the Wheeling-Pittsburgh Corporation, the nation's eighth-largest steel company, announced yesterday that the Nisshin Steel Company, Japan's sixth-largest steelmaker, had agreed to buy 10 percent of its common stock.

title: NewTrialOrdered For Jersey Officer
description: A Weehawken police officer whose service revolver killed a fraternity brother during a game of Russian roulette at a party in 1981 is entitled to a new trial on a weapons charge, a state appeals court ruled today.

title: ORCHESTRA TO TOUR ASIA
description: The New York Philharmonic will perform 22 concerts during a 13-city tour of Asia in August and September. The tour will mark the first visit by a major American orchestra to Kuala Lumpur, Malaysia; Jakarta, Indonesia; Singapore, and Delhi and Calcutta, India.

title: Arco Spending
description: The Atlantic Richfield Company said its board had approved a capital spending program of $227 million for its share of enhanced oil recovery and natural gas liquids at the Prudhoe Bay oilfield on Alaska's North Slope. Arco said the project would remove natural gas liquids and some ligher components from recycled Prudhoe Bay gas. It said the heavier liquids production, expected to be about 40,000 barrels a day when the project starts up in 1987, will be combined with crude oil and transported through the Trans-Alaska Pipeline.

THEATER: DOWN AND OUT IN MIAMI
description: THE two leading characters in Arthur Whitney's ''Mademoiselle'' meet cute. She is a faded old French teacher, living with her books and illusions in a Miami fleabag. He is a young hustler, with bulging biceps and muscles between his ears. The game between them begins in the semi-darkness of her single-occupancy, no-cooking room when he tries to steal her valuables - she has none except those taunting books filled with ideas - and she catches him.

SAN DIEGO AGREES TO DIM ITS LIGHTS FOR SAKE OF ASTRONOMERS

title: G.E. TO BUILD NAVY JET ENGINE
description: Secretary of the Navy John F. Lehman Jr. said today that the Navy plans to use General Electric engines in future models of its F-14 fighter, rather than the Pratt & Whitney engine now used.

title: The Worth of a Judge
description: New York's judges have dared to ask the Legislature for more money, as recommended by a distinguished commission on judicial salaries. Governor Cuomo, though firm in his reverence for the robe, opposes the $20 million request. He agrees that judges' salaries have been eroded by inflation but says he can still find lawyers of quality for every vacancy. And he challenges the judges to say what they would cut from his $35.4 billion budget.

title: CBS PROFITS DOUBLED IN 4TH QUARTER
description: CBS Inc. said yesterday that its net income for the fourth quarter more than doubled, to $77.3 million, or $2.61 a share, from $37.4 million, or $1.33 a share, a year ago. The company said its results were helped by gains in its record, publishing and broadcast groups.

title: MEXICAN CAUTIONS U.S. ON LATIN MOVES
description: President Miguel de la Madrid of Mexico called on the United States today to lessen its emphasis on military means to deal with the problems of Central America.

description: The Soviet Union announced today that a member of the Politburo, Geidar A. Aliyev, would visit Syria soon. Western diplomats linked the trip to the abrupt realignment of forces in Beirut.

description: This resort, a haven for the very rich, awoke this morning to a political upheaval caused by Town Council elections Tuesday.

description: An airport employee testified today that he saw Benigno S. Aquino, the opposition leader, falling from an airline staircase after he heard a shot. That sequence directly contradicts the official version of the assassination of Mr. Aquino.

title: Citicorp Units
description: The Federal Reserve Board has approved a request by Citicorp, the nation's largest bank holding company, to establish Citicorp Financial Services Corporation subsidiaries in Kentucky and Tennessee. The Fed said the subsidiaries, in Lexington and Louisville in Kentucky and in Madison, Memphis, Knoxville and Nashville in Tennessee, would be allowed to engage in industrial banking, including offering consumer and commercial loans and accepting time and saving deposits.

title: Promoter Set Back
description: The New Jersey Casino Control Commission voted, 3-2, yesterday to prohibit temporarily the boxing promoter Ronald (Butch) Lewis from staging any fights in the state until he is granted a casino service industry license. But the ruling will not affect the world light heavyweight title bout between Michael Spinks , the unbeaten champion, and Eddie Davis that is being promoted by Lewis and is scheduled Feb. 25 at Resorts International, an Atlantic City casino. The state says that Lewis failed to pay $62,000 in luxury taxes for a fight he promoted in Atlantic City last year, but Lewis says he was unaware of the tax and has since met all obligations.

title: THEATER: SHERIDAN'S 'RIVALS'
description: ZOUNDS! sirrah, how durst the Manhattan Punch Line attempt Sheridan's ''Rivals''? With its gallery of sharply defined characters, this is a classic that would tax the resources of America's large institutional theaters. In its favor, the affable Off Off Broadway troupe has proved itself a deft reviver of contemporary comedies, and many of the actors in the present cast have demonstrated their skills in a variety of comic circumstances. The set, designed by Toby Corbett and Michael P. Moran - a miniaturized, toy theater view of the Royal Crescent at Bath - offers additional encouragement.

title: Bengals Interested
description: Steve Young , the Brigham Young quarterback, may not become the first choice in the National Football League's draft this year. But the Cincinnati Bengals, who have the first pick, are looking him over, and Young, who is also being courted by the Los Angeles Express of the United States Football League, is looking back. He has met with two Bengal officials and will see the team's coach, Sam Wyche , next week.

title: New Priorities

description: Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir and his Cabinet met today to discuss the situation in Lebanon, but no decisions were made, officials said.

description: The Speaker of the House, Thomas P. O'Neill Jr., said today that President Reagan's new policy of shelling Syrian and Druse artillery positions that were firing into the Beirut area was ''absolutely not'' within the authorization granted by the Lebanon war powers resolution that Congress adopted last fall.

description: Fire swept through a home in a working-class neighborhood tonight killing at least eight people, including four children, fire officials said.

description: ''City people have an idyllic view of life in the country,'' said Arlene Shako. ''It is a beautiful life - and that's why most farmers stay with it. They love it. But it's also tremendously exhausting and stressful.''

description: The nine prizes just awarded and the nine more to be given out include yearly payments of at least $61,425 until the age of 75, office staffs, free postage, free haircuts, free massages, travel allowances, subsidized lunches and tax exemptions, and there is no limit on earning money elsewhere.

description: ROBERT SMALL was most impressive when he pretended to be sleeping on Tuesday night at the Bessie Sch"onberg Theater. He was a restless sleeper. He curled up, stretched out, thrashed, flailed and rolled around, all the while huffing and puffing his way through a one-man oratorio of snoring sounds.

title: Hart and McGovern Exchange Bouquets
description: Senator Gary Hart of Colorado and George McGovern, campaign manager and candidate in the 1972 Presidential campaign, who are competitors for the Democratic Presidential nomination in 1984, heaped bouquets on each other today at a meeting of the Iowa City Foreign Relations Council at the University of Iowa. But they did not forget they were opponents this year.

title: 2 FROM UPSTATE KILLED ON CLIMB AS SNOW SLIDES
description: Two climbers from New York State were killed and two others were seriously injured today in the first known fatal avalanche on mile-high Mount Katahdin in northern Maine, authorities said.

title: EXECUTIVES
description: Bank of America, San Francisco, has announced the retirement of Thomas A. Deane, vice chairman.

title: Office of the Chairman Is Created by Pan Am
description: Pan American World Airways said yesterday that it had established an office of the chairman, with two newly promoted vice chairmen joining C. Edward Acker in the office.

title: CRIMINAL LAW REVISION INTRODUCED IN CANADA
description: The Government of Prime Minister Pierre Elliott Trudeau has introduced legislation that would sweepingly alter Canadian criminal law. It would permit, among other things, life sentences for violent criminals while allowing victims of crimes to seek restitution and punitive damages from offenders.

title: Presidential Debates Said to Be Parties' Job
description: Representatives of the Twentieth Century Fund proposed Tuesday that the Republican and Democratic parties sponsor televised debates between Presidential candidates, with a bipartisan commission monitoring the process.

title: BOARD ON UPPER WEST SIDE QUALIFIES A VOTE ON ZONING
description: With the fate of their own neighborhood in mind, members of the Upper West Side community board gave a qualified blessing Tuesday night to zoning changes proposed in the area, but they also demanded a temporary halt to some kinds of development.

title: Defense of Texas Nurse In Death Starts Today
description: The prosecution rested its case Tuesday in the murder trial of Genene Jones, a nurse accused of killing 15-month-old Chelsea Ann McClellan of Kerrville, Tex., with a drug injection.

title: AS TABOOS FALL, PRESS IN YUGOSLAVIA TURNS BOLD
description: For years it was an axiom of Western foreign correspondents that their Yugoslav colleagues were likely to be among the best informed reporters, especially in other Communist capitals.

title: Cable and Wireless
description: Cable and Wireless P.L.C. said it now owns 52.36 percent of the Hong Kong Telephone Company. Cable and Wireless began a bid for the issued shares and warrants of Hong Kong Telephone on Monday, following an announcement that it already owned 38.4 percent of the company. A Cable and Wireless spokesman said the company's general offer would continue, noting that the Hong Kong code on takeovers and mergers requires the offer to be effective for at least 21 days.

title: NEC China Sales
description: The NEC Corporation, a big Japanese computer and telecommunications company, said it had signed a contract with the Chinese Government to export its personal computers for educational and agricultural use. Under the agreement, NEC will deliver 155 of its PC-8000 computers and 150 of the more sophisticated PC- 8800's at a total cost of $854,000, a company spokesman said. The PC- 8800 can display about 3,000 Chinese characters that are used in Japanese writing.

title: West Berlin Panda Dies
description: The West Berlin Zoo's female panda, Tian-Tian, died today, a zoo spokesman said. Tian-Tian - the name means Little Heaven - was being treated for a viral intestinal infection at the city's University Animal Clinic by six veterinarians.

title: C.D. Rates Mostly Up
description: Interest rates on six-month certificates of deposit increased nationally in the week ended yesterday, but New York rates declined slightly, The Bank Rate Monitor reported.

description: NOB and Non Utsumi say that they leave the function of their new area rugs to ''the user's choice.'' That is sound practice, considering that some of their wool rugs have high-relief surfaces that one could possibly trip over.

description: Julius Erving scored a season-high 42 points as Philadelphia won despite 41 points by Ralph Sampson.

description: Charging an ''orgy of criminal activity,'' a Federal judge today ordered the removal of the executive board of a teamsters local and placed control of the union under a trustee until supervised elections were held.

description: The Casino Control Commission voted unanimously today to prohibit Nicodemo Scarfo from casinos in Atlantic City, based on his background as a ''career and professional criminal.''

title: U.S. AIDES SAY NEW AIM IN BEIRUT IS DETERRENCE OF ATTACKS BY SYRIA
description: Senior Administration officials said today that President Reagan's decision to authorize unlimited naval and air strikes against any shelling of Beirut from Syrian lines was made in part to deter Syria from attacking the marines now that they are to be moved to ships off shore.

Mrs. Dillon, whose late father, Donald Lillis, was one of five investors who bought the team for $1 million in 1963, would not disclose the amount she had received from Hess.

description: The 4-year-old boy who survived 20 minutes submerged in icy Lake Michigan is now walking but remains ''agitated and confused'' and has not yet spoken, doctors said Monday.

description: Two of the most popular and pervasive myths concerning Latin American politics are that revolutions are caused by poverty and social injustice and that foreign economic assistance will prevent those revolutions.

description: When governors come to Washington they have to have some place to hang their hats and do their business. This is provided in a big modern building in the shadow of the Capitol, the Hall of the States, which has all the distinction of a series of dentists' offices.

description: Following are the major developments in New York City's experience with Grumman Flxible buses since the Transit Authority signed a $89 million contract in July 1979 for 837 buses from the Grumman Flxible Corporation of Delaware, Ohio:

title: Marine Major Is Shot Dead In Beirut Airport Compound
description: A United States Marine major was found shot dead in his quarters at the American compound at Beirut International Airport today, the Pentagon said.

title: One-Day Dock Strike in Peru
description: Peruvian port operations returned to normal today after a one-day wildcat strike by dockworkers at the country's main port of Callao. Luis Negreiros, the dockworkers' union leader, threatened Tuesday to start an indefinite strike on Saturday if the National Ports Company failed to grant union members a 30 percent increase in their average monthly salary, now $180.

title: INFORMATICS GENERAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
BEIRUT TURMOIL COMPLICATES PULLBACK PLAN, OFFICIALS SAY
description: Military planning for pulling back the 1,470 marines at the Beirut International Airport to ships off Lebanon began two weeks ago to anticipate a Presidential decision, Administration officials said today. But the plan has been complicated, they said, by events of the past 48 hours.

title: Lord Byers Dies at 68: A Liberal Party Leader
description: Lord Byers, the Liberal Party leader in Britain's House of Lords since 1967, died late Monday at a London hospital after collapsing in his office. Lord Byers, who had a history of heart trouble, was 68 years old and lived in Lingfield, Sussex.

title: BOY, 12, OUT OF 'BUBBLE' FOR TREATMENT
description: David, a 12-year-old boy who was born without immunity to disease, hugged and kissed his mother for the first time after he was removed from his germ- free ''bubble'' so a recent fever and digestive problems could be evaluated, his doctors said today.

title: Volcanic Lava Rises In Mount St. Helens
description: Molten rock appeared to be close to breaking through the surface of the lava dome inside the crater of Mount St. Helens today as small earthquakes rattled beneath the volcano, scientists said.

title: New York City Area; Is Warned on Water
description: The densely populated New York- New Jersey-Connecticut area is using more water than it can safely expect to be on hand and is avoiding major shortages only through large and timely rainfalls, the Army Corps of Engineers reported today.

title: Dockers in New York Vote in Favor of Pact By The Associated Press
description: Longshoremen in New York, the nation's busiest seaport, voted more than 2 to 1 to ratify a new contract as 50,000 dock workers in more than 30 East Coast cities voted yesterday.

title: TWITCH CANCELS A TRANSPLANT
description: Organ transplant surgeons, who were ready Tuesday to remove the liver of a man who had been declared dead nine hours earlier, called off the operation when his feet twitched as they were tickled.

title: Q&A
description: Q.

title: RETALIATION THREATENED BY LEADER OF THE DRUSE
description: A Lebanese Druse leader said here today that his forces would retaliate against American diplomats and civilians in Lebanon if United States warships continued their ''indiscriminate'' shelling of Druse villages.

title: Philadelphia's Mayor Is Set To Back Mondale Candidacy
description: Mayor W. Wilson Goode of Philadelphia plans to announce his endorsement of Walter F. Mondale on Thursday for the Democratic Presidential nomination.

title: Pursuer of Nazis Again Arrested in Chile
description: A Nazi-hunter, Beate Klarsfeld, was arrested today for the second time in nine days as she led a demonstration outside the home of Walter Rauff, the inventor of mobile gas chambers used by the Nazis in World War II.

title: GIVING IVY PLANTS A HAPPY MILIEU
description: WHEN ivy is grown indoors, remember two key words: Think forest. In nature ivy grows in the shaded glades of the understory, where the sun touches gently and the earth is cool and moist.

title: LIMITS ARE ADVISED ON VIEWING FETUSES THROUGH ULTRASOUND
description: A panel of experts convened by the National Institutes of Health recommended today that the use of ultrasound devices for visualizing the unborn fetus in pregnant women be limited. They said neither the safety nor the benefits of routine ultrasound screening had been proved.

title: PAYMENT BY VATICAN BANK SEEN
description: Pope John Paul II is expected to authorize soon a ''goodwill payment'' of $230 million by the Vatican to help compensate banks for losses suffered when Banco Ambrosiano failed, according to bankers familiar with the negotiations under way with the Vatican.

title: Aide Ousted In Venezuela
description: President Jaime Lusinchi today dismissed the top official of Petroleos de Venezuela, the state oil monopoly and one of the biggest companies in Latin America.

title: Report Says Pretoria Relocated 3.5 Million
description: The South African Government forcibly relocated almost 3.5 million people between 1960 and 1982 in ''one of the most cruel and devastating effects of apartheid,'' a church official said today.

title: FatalBlazeLinked ToFaultyCooking
description: A fire that raced through a three- story rooming house here, killing two young women and three children, was accidentally caused by ''careless cooking,'' Union County officials said.

title: RANGERS TRIUMPH
description: Herb Brooks, the Ranger coach, says no one has been demoted. He has Mark Pavelich playing on a different line, which happens to be New York's fourth line.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE;
description: SEASONING The word ''season'' embraces several definitions. Calendar seasons are three months, but the well-seasoned Murray Louis Dance Company (it's been in and out of season since 1953) starts one tonight at 7 P.M. that is only six days long, but perhaps comparable, in a terpsichorean way, to an astronomically longer one.

And that, together with an affable disposition, should make Bobby Bonds an ideal batting instructor, according to the Cleveland Indians, who just signed Bonds to become just that.

Bomb Victim's Stepson Held
description: The authorities filed a murder charge Monday against the 21-year-old stepson of a man killed when a bomb exploded inside a newspaper vending box last month. The stepson, Marshall Dewayne Williams, was accused in the death of Ward S. Keeton, 60, who was killed Jan. 27 as he tried to buy a newspaper near his North Dallas apartment. Mr. Williams, a Mesquite security guard, was held on $100,000 bond.

title: Father Sentenced in Slaying After Sons Testify for State
description: A Yonkers man whose young sons had testified against him was sentenced today to 6 to 18 years in prison for beating his nephew to death.

title: Who Needs Federal Death?
description: When the Supreme Court struck down virtually all capital punishment laws in 1972, nearly 600 prisoners were spared. None were Federal prisoners, for the United States had no need for the death penalty. Only one Federal prisoner had been executed during the 1960's and only a few in the 1950's. Yet suddenly, on no new showing of need, the Senate is seriously considering a measure that would bring back death as punishment for numerous Federal crimes.

title: 2 in Football Hall
description: Duffy Daugherty , the former Michigan State coach, and the late James Tatum , who coached at Oklahoma, Maryland and North Carolina, have been named to the National Football Foundation's College Football Hall of Fame. Daugherty, who compiled a record of 109-69-5 in his 19 years at Michigan State, beginning in 1954, will be honored at the foundation's annual dinner here in December. Tatum, who died at the age of 45 in 1958, had a 100-35-7 record in 14 seasons, including a 10-0 mark with a Maryland team that upset Tennessee in the 1952 Sugar Bowl.

title: FOR U.S. CIVILIANS, BITTERSWEET FAREWELL
description: American diplomats and family members who arrived here today from Beirut had few qualms about getting out, many words of worry for those left behind and some frightening stories about their final days in a capital where law and order had fallen apart.

title: IS THE SOVIET MILITARY RISING IN POWER?
description: The Soviet military's unprecedented public prominence in recent months is generating heightened speculation that the military's influence is rising. The increased visibility of defense officials has coincided with the prolonged public absence of Yuri V. Andropov from all official functions. But whether the military is merely helping fill a temporary power vacuum or carving a larger policy-making role for itself remains an open question.

title: An Abusive Amendment
description: Just when it seemed that the specter of Big Brother had faded forever from the hospital nursery, the House of Representatives has raised his shade again. Last week it voted to deny funds for child abuse prevention to states that fail to set up procedures to investigate and report the withholding of nutrition and ''medically indicated treatment'' from handicapped infants.

title: HERS
description: THE first call came around 9 o'clock one night 10 years ago. I was living alone in the country, unmarried, 20 years old. Watching whatever happened to be on TV, finishing my second bowl of ice cream, when the phone rang. The man talked like a cowboy, said he lived in Oklahoma and his name was Jim. He'd read a book I wrote. He wanted, he said, to be my friend.

Catacosinos, the new chairman and chief executive officer of the Long Island Lighting Company, stepped up to the lectern. He announced that first he would speak and afterward take questions for 30 minutes. Then, speaking in measured tones, he outlined the company's history, ticked off its problems, said he would welcome the opportunity to meet with his opponents and opened the floor to questions.

WHY SOME AMERICANS AID THE I.R.A.
description: THE sound of Ireland has been the sound of keening, and the impulse that drives the Irish Republican Army is rooted in the history of 500 years. The impulse that drives its American supporters is different. ''Frontline,'' the public television series, examines tonight the I.R.A. support, particularly as expressed by Americans. It finds in it elements of a secular, sentimental and pop religion. The program will be seen on Channel 13 at 10 P.M.

Two are scheduled for delivery in the spring of 1985 and the other two in 1986, it said.

title: OPERA: 'ROBERTO DEVEREUX' PERFORMED IN NEWARK

title: TEACHING AT HOME WITH HELP OF COMPUTERS
description: HE butler's pantry may seem a strange place for mathematics lessons, but in a big Victorian house in New Haven, Michael De l'Aune, 11 years old, is mastering long division while his 6-year-old brother, Christian, is learning to read. For two years now, the boys have been taught at home, helped by an Apple II computer nestled on a counter near the china and silverware. The computer is an important tool in the home-education program that Frances, a former piano teacher, and William De l'Aune, a research supervisor at Veterans Administration Medical Center in West Haven, have created for the two youngest of their five children.

title: Technology; Raising Status Of Engineers

title: ROOFTOP LIVING: THE NEW FRONTIER

Recently, living up high has taken a different turn. The cost and scarcity of existing residential space have encouraged some pioneers to cross a new residential frontier: using roof rights and building directly on roofs.

title: UNITED TELEVISION reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
IOSIF KOVACS
description: Iosif Kovacs, one of Rumania's six Vice Presidents and a member of the Communist Party Central Committee, died in Bucharest Tuesday at the age of 72, the party newspaper Scinteia reported today. Mr. Kovacs, a member of Rumania's Hungarian minority, was also an author and rector of Cluj University. He was elected in 1965 to the post of Vice President of the State Council, and had been a member of the Central Committee since 1955.

title: THURSDAY, FEBRUARY 9, 1984 International
description: American warships bombarded Syrian and Druse gun batteries in Lebanon for more than nine hours in the heaviest and most sustained United States military action since the marines arrived in Beirut 16 months ago. Western military informants said the battleship New Jersey fired more than 200 16-inch shells. The Pentagon said the destroyer Caron also joined in the bombardment. The Christian Phalangist radio said the barrage knocked out 30 gun batteries along with a Druse command post. (Page A1, Columns 4-6.) Britain withdrew its troops from Beirut. The 115 Britons went to the port city of Junieh, where helicopters met them and flew them to the aircraft carrier Reliant. (A15:4-6.)

title: Police Partner Testifies In Miami Arcade Killing
description: The partner of Police Officer Luis Alvarez testified today that Officer Alvarez shot a young black man in a video game arcade after the victim turned quickly toward him, but he said he never saw the victim reach for a concealed handgun.

title: ART AND CRAFTS FROM BLOOMSBURY DAYS
description: ''I am intending to start a workshop for decorative and applied art,'' wrote Roger Fry, the English art critic, to George Bernard Shaw in 1912. Fry, the first great champion of the artists he dubbed Post-Impressionists, wanted to apply the vivid gaiety of Post-Impressionism to the decorative arts and provide paid employment for struggling artists. Shaw thought the idea good enough to donate $:250, a goodly sum at the time and a quarter of the capital with which the Omega Workshops started business in July 1913.

The assets for sale are in two subsidiaries, Tricentrol U.S. Inc. and Tricentrol Resources Inc. Tricentrol said it wanted to retain its interests in 32 tracts in the Gulf of Mexico and its interests in the Montana gas fields. The spokesman declined to put a figure on the value of the assets.

If found guilty, he could face from two to five years in prison and up to $2,000 in fines.

title: DEXTER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes a nonrecurring charge of $3,400,000.

title: CHESAPEAKE INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes extraordinary gains of $172,000 for the quarter and $331,000 for the 6 months, and income from discontinued operations of $13,322 for the quarter. c-Net loss after losses from discontinued operations of $13,799 for the quarter and $24,143 for the 6 months.

title: Sharon Is a Candidate For Israeli Leadership
description: Former Defense Minister Ariel Sharon announced today that he would run for the leadership of the Herut Party and seek the nomination for Prime Minister.

title: RALLY BY RUTGERS DOWNS IRISH
description: Chris Remley, a junior forward, hit a 22-footer from the left of the key with 2 seconds left to give Rutgers a 61-59 victory over Notre Dame tonight at Byrne Meadowlands Arena in the first meeting ever between the teams.

title: MONOGRAM OIL & GAS reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss.

title: CANCER GENE LINKED TO FLAWS IN GROWTH OF AN ORDINARY CELL
description: An important link between a cancer gene and a natural substance that promotes cell growth within the body has been discovered by a team of scientists in Israel, Britain and the United States.

title: U.S.I.A. to 'Destroy' Blacklist ;
description: U.S.I.A. Aide Regrets Blacklist as an 'Error'

title: TESORO PETROLEUM CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Year-ago results have been restated.

title: TAMPAX INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
West Berlin Elects Mayor
description: The West Berlin House of Deputies elected Eberhard Diepgen today as the city's new Mayor. Mr. Diepgen, who ran unopposed, replaces Richard von Weizs"acker, who resigned to take the post of President of West Germany.

title: U.S. NOT YIELDING, WEINBERGER SAYS
description: Secretary of Defense Caspar W. Weinberger said today that President Reagan ''was not giving up'' in Lebanon, despite plans for a Marine pullback, and would soon ask Congress for funds to finance military aid to the Lebanese Army.

title: Debt Issues
description: * Guaranteed Mortgage Corp., a wholly owned financing subsidiary of Pulte Financial Cos., filed to offer $900 million in G.N.M.A.-collateralized mortgage bonds.

title: SPARE THE PIGS AND GOATS
description: To the Editor:

title: Citicorp in Maine
description: The United States Comptroller of the Currency's office said it had approved a national bank charter for Citicorp in Maine, the first national bank chartered under Maine's interstate banking statute. The new bank, to be known as Citibank National Association of South Portland, will be a Maine bank-holding company owned by Citicorp. As now envisioned, the new Citicorp unit will have $2 million in capital and surplus and will concentrate on offering primary and secondary residential loans as part of a full line of consumer services.

title: FIRST VERMONT FINANCIAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
STATESIDE ENERGY reports earnings for Year to July 31
description: b-Net income.

title: Market Place; Selling Theory Out of Date?
description: -fashioned ''selling climax,'' some brokers have been saying. The hope is that a large, concentrated burst of selling will sweep away clouds of gloom and let the sunshine of a bull market break through again.

title: Inmates Riot at Nigerian Jail, Seeking Improved Treatment
description: Prisoners rioted at a maximum-security prison in Lagos today to protest what they call poor treatment, complaining that 55 politicians who have been detained by the new military Government are treated better.

title: REALITY IN LEBANON
description: American policy in the current Middle East crisis could be much more clearly focused on its proper objectives if all parties would stop using loaded language - ''cut and run,'' ''bug out,'' ''throw in the towel,'' ''stand tall,'' ''pushed around,'' ''credibility'' and ''determination.''

title: Reagan to Join Dinner Held by G.O.P. Women
description: President Reagan will attend a Republican women's fund-raising dinner in honor of the birthday of the suffragist Susan B. Anthony next week, a spokesman said Wednesday.

title: NEWS SUMMARY FRIDAY, FEBRUARY 10, 1984 International
description: American naval gunners fired on Druse and Syrian artillery positions in Lebanon for a second day in retaliation for the shelling of mostly Christian East Beirut. An American Marine spokesman said a destroyer fired about 150 rounds from its five-inch guns. (Page A1, Column 6.) Americans will not be evacuated from Lebanon at this time because of concern that such a move would send the wrong political signal, according to authorities close to the United States Embassy in Beirut. They said an evacuation would upset negotiations aimed at keeping President Amin Gemayel in power. (A10:1-4.)

title: COMPANY NEWS ; A.T.&T. Will Sell Stake in Company
description: The American Telephone and Telegraph Company will sell its 24 percent share in the Southern New England Telephone Company later this year, the two companies announced today.

title: LILCO'S FINANCIAL ILLS OVER SHOREHAM
description: When the new chairman of the board of the Long Island Lighting Company made his first public appearance, at a news conference this week, he cited two familiar impediments to the opening of the Shoreham reactor: malfunctioning diesel generators and a dispute with Suffolk County over an emergency evacuation plan.

title: DEMOCRATS' BILL TO SAVE MEDICARE HAS CEILING ON HOSPITAL REVENUE
description: Congressional Democrats said today that they had drafted a comprehensive legislative proposal to avert the bankruptcy of the Medicare trust fund without raising taxes or cutting benefits.

title: Hong Kong Goose, Peking Duck
description: In an obviously calculated remark during his American tour, China's Prime Minister Zhao Ziyang sang the praises of capitalism - in Hong Kong. Though some capital is fleeing the colony, he said, more is flowing in because ''conditions for investment in Hong Kong are better than any area in the Asia-Pacific region.'' No booster of that bustling, British-ruled entrep^ot would claim more.

title: NAVY'S GUNS RAKE HILLS OVER BEIRUT WITH 150 ROUNDS
description: United States naval gunners bombarded anti- Government artillery batteries in Lebanon today for the second day in retaliation for the shelling of Christian- dominated East Beirut.

title: Canadiens Seek Tretiak
description: Vladislav Tretiak, the star goaltender for the Soviet hockey team, has received a contract from the Montreal Canadiens, an official of the Canadian Government said today, but whether he has signed it is not known. The official, Jacques Olivier, Minister of Fitness in Amateur Sports, said that Jerry Grundman, a representative of the Canadiens, had delivered the contract to a Soviet sports official.

title: ISRAELIS SAY GEMAYEL MEN ASKED AID
description: Israeli officials say the Government has received repeated, indirect requests from the Government of President Amin Gemayel to attack Syrian, Shiite and Palestinian forces in Lebanon.

title: REAGAN STANDING SHORT
description: When one side tries in good faith to reach a peaceful compromise, while the other side is trying to gain a military victory, chances are the side that is playing to win will win.

title: Phil Mahre Says He'll Retire
description: Phil Mahre, one of America's hopes for an Olympic medal in men's skiing, says he'll quit the sport soon after the Games in Sarajevo and pursue ''a more balanced life.''

title: REAGAN'S RIGHT TO VOICE HIS RELIGIOUS VIEWS
description: To the Editor I, too, was offended by President Reagan's speech, but not because he distorted a political doctrine. I object to the President's perversion of reli

title: VOLCKER DISCERNS HOPE ON DEFICITS
description: Paul A. Volcker, chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, said today that he thought the financial markets had overreacted to statements by him and Administration officials that Federal budget deficits could sow another recession.

title: INSTRUMENT SYSTEMS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a tax credit of $750,000. c-After an extraordinary gain of $225,000 from an exchange for subordinated debentures and a tax credit of $375,000.

title: I.B.M. Computers
description: The International Business Machines Corporation's installations of mainframe computer systems reached record levels last year and shipments of its 3380 large-scale disk storage system also increased significantly, according to the company's annual report. The chairman, John R. Opel, said in his statement to shareholders, ''Although much attention is focused on the growth in small computers, large systems still account for a substantial portion of I.B.M. revenue.'' He added that ''in 1983, we matched, and in some areas exceeded, industry growth.'' I.B.M.. did not release specific numbers on shipments of individual products.

title: CROSS, A.T., CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
GREYHOUND COMPUTER OF CANADA LTD reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
NATIONAL PATENT DEVELOPENT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $665,000 for the quarter and $1,669,000 for the year and tax credits of $260,000 for the quarter and $1,121,000 for the year. c-Including income from discontinued operations of $215,000 for the quarter and a loss from discontinued operations of $258,000 for the year and tax credits of $1,208,000 for the quarter and $6,261,000 for the year.

title: Takeoff Mishap at Seattle
description: An Alaska Airlines Boeing 727 carrying 22 passengers and a crew of six returned to Jackson International Airport Thursday shortly after one of its three engines failed on takeoff. The plane, bound for Oakland, Calif., landed without difficulty after the engine failed about 500 feet off the runway, Jim Johnson, an airline spokesman, said. He said passengers were placed on other flights and that the plane's engine would be repaired or replaced.

title: BFI COMMUNICATIONS SYSTEMS reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Comings and Goings
description: Carlos (Sugar) DeLeon , the World Boxing Council's cruiserweight champion, will defend his title against Anthony Davis , the second- ranked contender, in a 12-round bout March 9 as part of the undercard of the Greg Page-Tim Witherspoon heavyweight bout, according to the promoter, Don King . The site will be named. . . . Bill Madlock , the Pittsburgh Pirate third baseman, underwent an emergency appendectomy in Pittsburgh and will be hospitalized at least three days.

title: NAVY'S DEFENSES FOR ATTACKS BY SUICIDE PILOTS QUESTIONED
description: A Navy admiral's remark this week that an Army infantry antiaircraft weapon had been deployed on American vessels off Lebanon has raised questions in Congress about how well the Navy can defend itself against suicide attacks.

title: Person and Etta Jones
description: The saxophonist Houston Person and the singer Etta Jones will perform tonight and tomorrow at the Universal Jazz Coalition's Jazz Center of New York (924-5026 or 505-5660), 380 Lafayette Street. Sets begin at 8:30 and 10 P.M., and tickets are $8.

title: 11 Injured in Fire At 666 Fifth Ave.
description: A two-alarm fire broke out yesterday afternoon on the third floor of the 39-story building at 666 Fifth Avenue, causing it to be evacuated by the Fire Department. Eleven people, seven of them firefighters, were taken to hospitals or treated at the scene for burns or smoke inhalation.

title: CROWN LIFE INSURANCE CO reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-Includes a gain of $9,601,000 on foreign currency translation and other unusual items. c-Includes a gain of $29,101,000 on foreign currency translation and other unusual items.

title: GAMBLE PAYS OFF FOR FINN
description: Marja-Liisa Haemaelainen of Finland gambled at the start of the 10-kilometer women's cross-country ski race today and came away with the first gold medal of the XIV Olympic Winter Games.

title: REAGAN IS ACCUSED OF LAX PRESIDENCY
description: Walter F. Mondale, in his most direct personal attack on President Reagan, said today that Mr. Reagan ''has not applied himself'' to the job of President and ''should get on the plane and come back to Washington'' from his vacation in California to deal with the crisis in Beirut.

title: REAGAN'S RIGHT TO VOICE HIS RELIGIOUS VIEWS
description: To the Editor:

title: Bates Goes National For Sterling Cigarettes
description: R.J. Reynolds Tobacco, which went into test market with its Sterling cigarettes just last month, announced yesterday that it planned to take the brand national in April.

title: Legislator Faces New Charges
description: Additional charges were filed in Manhattan yesterday against State Senator Joseph R. Pisani of New Rochelle, N.Y., who was indicted in December on Federal fraud and tax- evasion charges.

title: RESCUE FROM ANONYMITY
description: They always called him Jack. But today, on a hillside across the river from the towering memorial to his grandfather, his real name was carved on his tombstone: Abraham Lincoln 2d.

title: CREDIT MARKETS ; Bond Prices Decline Slightly
description: The credit markets stumbled through this week's $16.25 billion Treasury note and bond financing with only modest investor demand for the 29 1/2-year bonds sold yesterday and the 9 3/4-year notes sold Wednesday. During yesterday's trading, prices fell and yields rose slightly for Treasury, tax-exempt and corporate bond issues, as dealers sought to attract more investors.

title: National Medical
description: National Medical Enterprises Inc. said it had bought the 220-bed Doctors Hospital and an adjacent medical building in Dallas for an undisclosed amount of stock. The company also said it had signed a 25-year lease to operate the 151-bed Central Plains Regional Medical Center in Plainview, Tex., and had agreed to lease the 206-bed Cherokee County Memorial Hospital in Gaffney, S.C. The company said it would build a $21 million, 150-bed hospital in Gaffney to replace the existing building.

title: Slate Elected In Jersey Vote
description: The New Jersey Resources Corporation said preliminary figures showed that its slate of directors had won election to the board over candidates backed by the NUI Corporation. The company said that, according to a preliminary count by Arthur Young & Company, the management slate received Tabout 1.9 million votes, or 62 percent of the shares voted, while the NUI-backed slate received about 1.15 million.

title: FuelChargeDown ForManyTenants
description: Many tenants in rent-controlled apartments will pay slightly lower rents this year because of lower prices for oil and electricity, according to the city's Commissioner of Housing Preservation and Development, Anthony B. Gliedman.

title: LUMPP GRAPPLING WITH TRACK TRUST
description: Amateur sports used to be simple

title: GOOD REAGAN RHETORIC
description: A President's words - the Government's declaratory policy - can have an enormous effect. President Reagan's much maligned ''tough talk'' to the Russians, however much it may have alienated European intellectuals and American critics, has created the possibility of real cuts in both countries' nuclear arsenals.

title: Required Reading 'What Recovery?'
description: The recession officially ended a year ago. We're having one hell of a recovery. That's the prevailing view among mainstream economists, who think things will keep coming up roses through 1984. This is nice for President Reagan, because the media will stop hammering him on unemployment (you can see the change on the nightly news shows already) and his opponents will be skittish about attacking Reaganomics. But it's bad news to at least 30 million people for whom the recession still happens to be the central fact of life. For them, an American tragedy is in the making. They are about to become the invisible Americans of 1984.

title: JOINT CHIEFS PLAN NEW PRESS POLICY
description: The Joint Chiefs of Staff have adopted new procedures to plan for press coverage during military operations, a Pentagon panel was told today.

title: SAGEGUARD BUSINESS SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Swiss Prices Climb 0.4%
description: The cost of living in Switzerland rose four-tenths of 1 percent in January from the month before and was up 2.7 percent from a year earlier, the Government reported today.

title: SPIRITS ARE HIGH IN 2D SPACE WALK
description: Two free-flying astronauts joked and turned somersaults in space today and then practiced docking to a satellite berthed in the shuttle Challenger's cargo bay.

title: DEMOCRATS INSIST ON MILITARY CUTS IN DEFICIT TALKS
description: Representative Jim Wright, the House majority leader, said today that the Reagan Administration would have to agree to reductions in military spending before the Democrats would discuss other spending reductions and tax increases.

title: $98.4 Million Issue For Ohio Hospital
description: A $98.4 million issue of Hamilton County, Ohio, hospital revenue and refunding bonds for the Jewish Hospital are offered through underwriters led by Seasongood & Mayer, Cincinnati.

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL

title: ANACOMP OUSTS OPERATING CHIEF
description: Anacomp Inc., a software company in Indianapolis that has been suffering losses, said yesterday that it had dismissed its chief operating officer, John Flanigan, and had eliminated the position.

title: DECOM SYSTEMS reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 30
PATRICK NAGEL
description: Patrick Nagel, whose Art Deco renditions of female figures appeared in Playboy magazine for nearly a decade, died of a heart attack Saturday after exercising at a fund-raiser for the American Heart Association. He was 38 years old.

title: FILM: 'UNFAITHFULLY YOURS'
description: DUDLEY MOORE may not want to play Hamlet but his ambition to play more or less straight roles has resulted in a series of unfortunate performances in even more unfortunate films - ''Six Weeks,'' ''Lovesick'' and ''Romantic Comedy.'' Actually, ''Lovesick'' wasn't all that bad but, let's face it, Mr. Moore is never going to be Cary Grant.

title: Greene Street Comedy
description: The High Heeled Women, a comedy quartet, will appear Fridays through March 30 at Upstairs at Greene Street, 101 Greene Street. Performances are at 8 P.M. There is a $10 cover charge. Reservations: 925-2415.

title: GOLAR TO RUN AGAINST ADDABBO
description: Simeon Golar, who got 42 percent of the vote when he opposed Representative Joseph P. Addabbo for the Democratic nomination for the House in southeast Queens two years ago, said yesterday that he would try again.

title: Atom Panel Charged With Neglecting Safety
description: A member of the Nuclear Regulatory Commission charged today that the panel had been so busy approving nuclear power plants that it had failed to assure the reactors were safe.

title: SABINE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Including a tax credit of $840,000. Results for the latest year include a net gain of $17.9 million from the sale of Canadian operations and a net gain of $4.5 million the he sale of non-oil and gas assets.

title: DANCE: THE CITY BALLET
description: JEROME ROBBINS'S ''Dances at a Gathering'' closed the New York City Ballet's program on Wednesday night at the State Theater. But all the works on that program could be termed choreographic gatherings of some sort.

title: HIS FOES GATHERED IN SYRIA, DEBATE GEMAYEL'S SURVIVAL
description: Lebanese opposition leaders met through the day here with Syrian officials and among themselves today and reportedly remained deeply divided over whether President Amin Gemayel of Lebanon should resign.

title: STRIKING MEAT WORKERS REACH AN ACCORD WITH SUPERMARKETS
description: A tentative agreement was reached early this morning in the 26-day-old strike by meat cutters and delicatessen clerks against four major supermarket chains in northern New Jersey and parts of New York State.

title: LINCOLN NATIONAL DIRECT PLACEENT FUND INC reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
No Headline
description: A long, low building rising on the Stanford University campus is a symbol of the tightening of links between academic and industrial research to bolster American technological prowess. It has also become a focus of debate over the proper relationship between the two.

title: Greyhound's Net Up 2.5%
description: The Greyhound Corporation, operator of the nation's largest bus system, said fourth-quarter earnings edged up 2.5 percent, to $24.2 million, or 49 cents a share, from $23.6 million, or 54 cents, a year earlier.

title: HOME FEDERAL SAVINGS & LOAN (SAN DIEGO, CALIF) (O) reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After an extraordinary charge of $2,755,000. c-Net loss after an extraordinary charge of $5,042,000. Results for the latest year include a gain of 8 cents a share earned in the first quarter prior to the association's conversion from a mutual to a stock association.

title: The U.N. Today; Feb. 10, 1984
description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY

title: The Artful Manager
description: No one who ever heard New York Deputy Mayor Nathan Leventhal growl at a commissioner would guess that his City Hall day generally started with a rousing tape of ''Lucia di Lammermoor'' - that his passion is not hounding bureaucrats but hearing baritones. Now the culture buff has come out from behind the payroll charts as Mr. Leventhal leaves to become president of Lincoln Center.

title: Baldwin-United Recovery Outlook
description: It would take ''a major miracle'' for creditors and shareholders of the Baldwin-United Corporation to recover all their investment, the company's chairman said.

title: A CHOICE OF 9 PLAYS ON THE BOARDS
description: ''CHECK IT OUT!'' the local entrepreneurs used to shout when the attractions on the 400 block of West 42d Street included massage parlors and burlesque shows. There is still plenty of reason to check out the block between Ninth and 10th Avenues, but the lures today are of a very different sort.

title: RESTAURANTS
description: THEY may have the meatiest ribs in town and the freshest, fattest fried onion rings, but without doubt Tennessee Mountain has the worst muffins. The aroma of the artificial flavors in these blueberry and corn muffins made from a mix is so powerful you can smell it even before you bite into them.

title: U.S. LOSES AGAIN IN HOCKEY;CHANCES FOR MEDAL ARE SLIM
description: At 12 minutes 23 seconds of the opening period tonight, after Czechoslovakia had scored a goal against the United States Olympic hockey team despite being a man short, the lights went out at the Zetra ice arena. It was a dour omen for the Americans, who were defeated, 4-1, and practically eliminated from medal contention in the XIV Olympic Winter Games.

title: PREWAY INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Year-ago share earnings have been adjusted for a 5 percent stock dividend paid in December 1983.

title: Jackson Gets U.S. Funds To Match His $100,000
description: The Rev. Jesse Jackson on Thursday became the seventh Democratic Presidential candidate to receive matching funds. He was awarded an initial payment of $100,000.

title: PLANE WAS SAVED BY ALARM SYSTEM
description: A wide-body airliner still five to ten miles from a night landing at La Guardia Airport about a year ago was flown to just 400 feet above Brooklyn, according to industry sources.

title: ART: FRANCISCO OLLER, PUERTO RICO GLIMPSED
description: RETRIEVING artists from oblivion, like taking in stray animals, is an activity fraught with emotion. The scholars who do it commonly grow so close to their charges as to become one with them and, when politics enters the picture, objectivity becomes virtually impossible for all concerned.

title: IN IOWA CAUCUSES, THE VOTE ISN'T SECRET AND THAT PUTS A SPIN ON THE BALL
description: It is time once again to reflect on the screwball quality of the Iowa caucuses.

title: STRONG DOLLAR ERODES RAYCHEM'S EARNINGS
description: The Raychem Corporation, whose insulation materials and radiation- treated plastics have applications ranging from oilfields and utilities to aircraft, computers, electronic devices, missiles and telecommunications equipment, is running into troubles at home and abroad.

title: 3 MAJOR PORTS ARE STRUCK OVER LOCAL ISSUES
description: Sixty-five hundred longshoremen went on strike yesterday in Boston, Baltimore, Philadelphia, and Wilmington, Del., but the East Coast's largest port, New York, remained open as did others.

title: Coleco Phones
description: Coleco Industries said it plans to introduce a line of telephones in June aimed at the teen-age market.

title: Must Play in '84, Sting Is Told
description: The North American Soccer League turned down today a request by Lee Stern, owner of the Chicago Sting, to suspend the Sting's 1984 outdoor season.

title: EDB Test Causes A Recall of Rice
description: A Houston-based producer was ordered today to pull more than 100,000 pounds of rice with possibly hazardous levels of ethylene dibromide off store shelves in the New York City area.

title: Friday BEN JONSON ON BOWERY
description: T. S. Eliot called it ''a titanic show,'' but Edmund Wilson found it ''revolting.'' The work is ''Epicoene, or the Silent Woman,'' Ben Jonson's 1609 comedy about the tormenting of a man who hates noise, and it begins a rare run tonight at 8 at the Cocteau Repertory, 330 Bowery. The director, Gerald Chapman, formerly resident director of London's Royal Court Theater, has set the play in New York, with farcical scenes inspired by the Marx Brothers. It runs two and a half hours. Tickets: $8.50. Reservations: 677-0060. SECOND AVENUE POWWOW

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''We are deeply concerned about the amount of shelling. We are wondering whether or not our policy is dramatically changing.

title: SPEEDY ASTRONAUTS HARDLY FEEL IT Traveling 17,500 miles an hour may seem fast, and on earth it surely is. But the astronauts of the space shuttle Challenger, which is going that fast around the world, hardly feel any movement at all.
description: There is no resistance from atmosphere out there, and so no feeling of air rushing by. There are no reference points, like telephone poles or signposts, to go flashing by.

title: CLASSICAL DANCER FROM INDIA
description: Balasaraswati, who was considered one of the greatest classical dancers India has produced and who performed and taught in the United States over a period of 20 years, died yesterday in Madras, India. She was 64 years old and had been ill for some time.

title: CUMMINS ENGINE CO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a charge of $19,500,000 for the closing of two plants. Share earnings for the 1982 year are after the payment of preferred stock dividends.

title: MCDERMOTT INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss

title: OFFICIAL VERSION OF AQUINO KILLING IS CONTRADICTED
description: The Philippine Government's statement that the opposition leader Benigno S. Aquino Jr. was slain last summer on the airport tarmac was challenged by an airport worker at a hearing today.

title: I.O.C. Is Assailed In Reporters' Ban
description: The president of Radio Free Europe protested today the exclusion of his reporters from the Sarajevo Olympics and suggested that the United States bar Soviet-bloc journalists from the Summer Games in Los Angeles.

title: THE DISPUTE AT HOME: WAR POWERS ACT
description: The dispute between President Reagan and Congress on the War Powers Act focuses on a resolution that became law last fall. It provides that the Marines could remain in Lebanon for 18 months and that United States air and sea forces could be used to take ''protective measures'' that might be necessary ''to insure the safety'' of the American troops.

title: TV DINNERS SEEK GOURMET MARKET
description: The continuing success of low-calorie and so-called gourmet frozen foods has revived a market whose palate was dulled by traditional TV dinners. And this year promises an even broader range of entries as the nation's leading frozen food marketers fight for a bigger chunk of what is now the industry's fastest-growing and most profitable sector.

title: WETLANDS ACCORD SETS PROTECTION
description: Millions of acres of ecologically sensitive wetlands will be protected under an out-of-court settlement announced today between the Army Corps of Engineers and a coalition of 16 environmental groups.

title: 2 EX-DRYSDALE OFFICERS PLEAD GUILTY
description: The two top officers of the Drysdale Government Securities Corporation, which collapsed in 1982, pleaded guilty yesterday to defrauding the Chase Manhattan Bank of $270 million.

title: PENTAIR INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Floating-Rate Eurobond Notes
description: New floating-rate note issues dominated the Eurobond market with banks in particular attracted by the high-quality liquid appeal of these bonds, dealers said.

title: KULICKE & SOFFA INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
ART: DIETER HACKER, WEST BERLINER, IN DEBUT
description: ONE of the weightier debuts of the season is that of Dieter Hacker, the 41-year-old painter from West Berlin, whose work can be seen at the Marlborough Gallery, 40 West 57th Street, through March 3.

title: Chicago Utility Sued on Plant
description: A class action suit has been filed against the Commonwealth Edison Company on behalf of shareholders who said they had lost money because the utility did not disclose potential problems at its Byron nuclear plant. The suit, filed Wednesday in Federal District Court, contends that the utility made false and misleading statements in a registration statement on last December's sale of three million shares of stock.

BRITONS BATTLING OVER PROPERTY TAX
description: -UPON-TYNE, England - From the perspective of London, the battle over ''rate-capping,'' which has prompted the most serious ruckus within the Conservative Party in the last five years, often seems tedious and esoteric. But not to Michael Campbell.

KARIN ENKE WINS GOLD, SETS SPEED-SKATE MARK
description: The Eric Heiden of the XIV Olympic Winter Games may be a former figure skater, Karin Enke of East Germany.

title: U.S. SKATERS FEEL IN MEDALIST FORM
description: Figure skating starts Friday in the XIV Olympic Winter Games, with the United States in a strong position to win medals in all four events. Consider these prospects:

title: FILM: 'ANDROID,' A HIJACKING IN SPACE
description: ''ANDROID,'' which opens today at the Waverly Theater but was made two years ago, is an essentially cheerful, knowing little science-fiction film that positively celebrates the shoestring on which it was made. The basic sets - all interiors - are those roomy space ships and space stations left over from such Roger Corman cheapie classics as ''Battle Beyond the Stars'' and ''Galaxy of Terror,'' refurbished and repainted as needed.

description: Diet of Doughnuts
