description: b-Includes a gain of $22,800,000 from the previously announced sale of the company's Special Metals Corp. unit. c-There were no share earnings for the year-ago quarter and the latest year because preferred dividend requirements exceeded net income applicable to common shares.

title: Bridge: A Bit of Clever Dummy Play Occurs at Beverly East Club
description: The busiest bridge club in Manhattan, and one of the busiest in the country, is the Beverly East Club, at Lexington Avenue and 50th Street.

title: C.A.B. TO WRITE RULES ON RESERVATIONS SYSTEMS
description: The Civil Aeronautics Board moved today to curb possible abuses in the computerized reservations systems used by travel agents to book airline flights for their customers.

title: RAFFLE TONIGHT DETERMINES A CHICAGO LOBSTER'S FATE
description: The fate of Sandy Claws, a 28-pound lobster that may be over 100 years old, rests in the hands of more than 2,000 raffle-ticket holders who are sharply divided over whether it should be swimming in a Newburg sauce or in the cool waters of Chicago's Shedd Aquarium.

title: KEY IMAGE SYSTEMS reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After tax credits of $4,961 for the quarter and $14,900 for the 9 months. c-Net income after tax credit of $10,050. d-After tax credit of $12,000.

title: U.S. PLANS OVERFLIGHT RULES FOR NUCLEAR PLANTS
description: The Federal Government, concerned about potential terrorist attacks, proposed Wednesday that aircraft flights over nuclear weapon facilities in the United States be banned or sharply curtailed.

title: CURTISS-WRIGHT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
PAKISTANI CITIES NUCLEAR ADVANCE
description: A Pakistani nuclear scientist said in an interview published today that his country could now enrich uranium and could produce its own atomic bomb if necessary.

title: BROADWAY
description: WHILE Linda Ronstadt and Wilford Leach were working on ''The Pirates of Penzance'' three years ago, they were already tossing around ideas for their next project. ''We were talking about pieces we thought were beautiful,'' Mr. Leach, the director of ''Pirates,'' says. First on their list was ''La Boh eme,'' Puccini's opera. ''Linda said, 'I think I can do this if I work real hard,' '' Mr. Leach recalls. Miss Ronstadt went to work almost immediately with Marge Rivingston, the vocal coach, but the really hard part was finding time in the singer's busy schedule. The first opening wasn't until the fall of 1984. Miss Ronstadt and Mr. Leach have just decided to go into rehearsal with ''La Boh eme'' on Oct. 2 and to begin performances Oct. 30 for a limited run at the Public Theater.

title: BRISK TRADE IN GULF PUTS FOCUS ON MESA
description: Heavy trading yesterday in the stock of the Gulf Corporation pushed the price up $2.125, to $56.75 a share, and heightened speculation that T. Boone Pickens, chairman of the Mesa Petroleum Corporation, may be on the verge of making a takeover bid for Gulf.

title: GRUBB & ELLIS COMMERCIAL BROKERAGE CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Year-ago results are restated for tax benefits realized in 1983 and applied as bases of adjustments to assets disposed of in 1982.

title: TWYLA THARP WEDS DANCE TO VIDEO
description: Twyla Tharp's ''Bad Smells,'' which will be performed tonight and tomorrow night at the Brooklyn Academy of Music, is a simultaneous live and video performance. While a group of ashen and tattered dancers gesticulates, grimaces and gyrates to a pounding original score by Glenn Branca, a cameraman records their frenzied movements in one unbroken take with a black-and-white video camera. What he shoots is projected on a screen suspended over a stage, whose wings and rear brick wall are totally unmasked.

title: ICE FISHING: SURFACE DETAILS ARE VITAL
description: Driving through the Brewster, N.Y., area last weekend, I could not resist stopping in at Bob's Sport and Tackle Shop at Whitehall Corners - the junction of State Highways 100 and 35 - in Katonah.

title: UNION LOCAL WORRIED ABOUT MOVING OF JOBS
description: It is a tale of survival, for a manufacturer unable to compete because of labor costs, as well as for workers faced with family obligations and the prospect of losing their jobs.

title: Bomb Blasts Rock Corsica
description: Two bombs exploded here overnight, wounding one person. The bombings followed similar blasts Wednesday on this Mediterranean island where separatists have been fighting against French rule.

title: FUTURE IS UNCERTAIN IN SPEED SKATING
description: Dianne Holum of Hanover Park, Ill., the coach of the American speed- skating team for the Olympic Winter Games, fears for the future of her sport in the United States.

title: B.F. SAUL REAL ESTATE INVESTMENT TRUST reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a loss of $10,000 on the sale of properties and a tax credit of $9,000. c-Net income including a gain of $3,871,000 on the sale of properties and a tax credit of $1,237,000.

title: Immune-Deficient Boy Is Reported Better
description: David, the 12-year-old immune-deficient boy removed this week from a germ-free environment for the first time in his life, showed signs today of overcoming a flu-like illness. But doctors were unsure of his long-term prognosis.

title: CHEMICAL FABRICS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 1
description: b-Net loss. The company went public in November 1983.

title: U.S. Sees Namibia Talks At 'a Very Fragile Point'
description: A senior State Department official said today that negotiations to win independence for South-West Africa and bring about a truce between South African and Angolan military forces had reached ''a very fragile point.''

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * American Cyanamid Co., Wayne, N.J., a chemical manufacturer, has elected to its board Allan R. Dragone, vice chairman of Burlington Industries.

title: REGISTER PLAYS A SPECIAL ROLE IN IOWA
description: Year in and year out, through the natural rhythms of farm life that shaped John Stravers's boyhood on the rich plains around Prairie City east of here, there was one manmade constant: The Des Moines Register.

title: AT THE MOVIES
description: ON March 10, the Directors Guild of America will announce its choice for best director of 1983. And Philip Kaufman, who directed - and wrote the screenplay for ''The Right Stuff'' is one of the nominees, an honor he shares with Bruce Beresford (''Tender Mercies''), Ingmar Bergman (''Fanny and Alexander''), Lawrence Kasdan (''The Big Chill'') and James Brooks (''Terms of Endearment'').

title: DIVERSIFIED ENERGIES INC reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
South Korea Offers To Deliver a Message
description: South Korea offered today to meet with North Korean representatives on Friday for the first time in four years and give them Seoul's response to Pyongyang's offer of peace talks.

title: Diner's Journal
description: SOME of the best dinner bargains in New York can be found along Brooklyn's Atlantic Avenue, home of about a dozen Middle Eastern and North African restaurants. One of these is Moroccan Star, 205 Atlantic Avenue, a simple, tidy restaurant that serves a melange of Arabic and European dishes for prices so low you can't help suspecting they are a mirage.

title: ALGAE IN CITY WATER HARMFUL TO NO ONE
description: To the Editor:

title: LAWRENCE TETZLAFF
description: -Lawrence (Jungle Larry) Tetzlaff, an animal trainer who wrestled alligators as a stand-in for Johnny Weismuller in three Tarzan movies, died at his home Monday. Mr Tetzlaff, in his mid-60's, according to his wife, Nancy, had been ill for some time.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Convention Center Change

title: THE EVENING HOURS
description: ''JUST look at those men,'' Oleg

title: CALIFORNIA BIOTECHNOLOGY reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-Net loss.

title: JACKSON TELLS ALABAMA IT 'WILL NEVER BE THE SAME'
description: ''I am,'' the Rev. Jesse Jackson thunders from the stage, tall and erect and commanding, a red velvet chair waiting behind him like a throne.

title: Prime Computer In Refinancing
description: Prime Computer Inc. said it had renegotiated its $100 million revolving credit and term loan agreement, reducing its borrowing costs and extending the term of the agreement through Sept. 30, 1991.

title: NOT INDUSTRIAL POLICY BUT BACK TO BASICS
description: To the Editor:

title: Big Red Mistake
description: The Cincinnati Reds had just won their second consecutive world championship when their fans were stunned by the news that the club's sparkplug first baseman, Tony Perez , had been traded to Montreal. That was in December 1976, and, to many Cincinnati fans, it marked the beginning of the dismantling of their beloved Big Red Machine.

title: Pennzoil Request Rejected by Court
description: A Federal appeals court denied the Pennzoil Company's request for an order blocking Texaco Inc.'s proposed $10.1 billion acquisition of the Getty Oil Company. The United States Court of Appeals for the 10th Circuit also upheld the decision of a Tulsa, Okla., Federal judge, who last Saturday refused Pennzoil's request to block the merger on antitrust grounds.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: MYSTERIES OF WINTERTHURN. By Joyce Carol Oates. 482 pages. Dutton. $16.95.

title: Howell Petroleum
description: The Howell Petroleum Corporation said its independent directors had recommended that minority shareholders accept the offer from the Howell Corporation to buy all Howell Petroleum shares it does not now own for $30 a share. The company is 52 percent owed by the Howell Corporation, an energy industry holding concern.

title: QUANTRONIX CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: c-Including tax credits of $54,000 for the quarter and $159,000 for the 9 months. c-Net loss

title: PHILHARMONIC: DICTEROW, VIOLINIST
description: ONE of the perquisites enjoyed by the principal players in a symphony orchestra is being allowed to step out now and then to perform as featured soloists. Often they do not make the most of the opportunity, either because they lack the necessary soloistic temperament in the first place or because they have lost some of their desire and flair as a result of sitting too long in the ranks. Fortunately, that has not happened as yet to Glenn Dicterow, the New York Philharmonic's concertmaster, who gave a performance of the Brahms Concerto last night that would have done many a big-name violinist proud.

title: ARCHDIOCESE ON COAST AND 7 PRIESTS ARE SUED
description: A woman who asserts she was seduced by seven priests as a teen-ager and had a baby by one of them has filed a $21 million lawsuit against the priests and the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of Los Angeles.

title: ART: RACKSTRAW DOWNES AND THE UNSPECTACULAR
description: A CANVAS titled ''IRT Elevated Station at Broadway and 125th'' cannot be the most romantic of landscapes, particularly when done by the matter-of-fact brush of Rackstraw Downes. As it turns out, the elevated is merely a detail in this wide-screen panorama, which tilts to one side as if seen from a zooming helicopter. Taking the eye almost to midtown, the painting records in minute particulars everything from a close-up yellow water tank to cars crawling miles away like cockroaches on rain-wet streets, all bathed in the sullen, overcast light of a drizzly day.

title: CONROCK CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes a gain of $3,156,000 from the sale of properties. c-Includes a gain of $4,066,000 from the sale of property.

title: ART: FROM LEON GOLUB, POLITICAL THUGS GALLERY
description: SINCE 1976, Leon Golub has been making paintings of mercenaries, assassins and political interrogators that do not so much stick in the mind as take it over. His large-than-life-size political thugs, sometimes stripped to the waist, sometimes dressed in dungarees or battle fatigues, chat, fondle their guns or women, pose while torturing or look at us with annoyance just after they have put their gun to a victim's head. Like violent news images that fill our living rooms from continents away, these figures keep coming back, sometimes in the middle of the night, often without being invited.

title: FARED ROBOT SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income. The company said the year-ago first quarter results, which include the operations of Robotic Systems Inc. for the month of January, reflect a gain of $1,135,740 related to the sale of stock by the company's Fared Drilling Technologies Inc. subsidiary.

title: SLATER STEEL INDUSTRIES LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss. c-After a special charge of $612,000 reflecting the company's equity in the writeoff of an afffiliate. The company is listed on the Toronto Stock Exchange.

title: FILTERTEK COS. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
DIALECT OF LOST JEWS LINGERS IN A BAVARIAN TOWN
description: Shortly after he became Mayor of this little Bavarian town in 1978, Hans- Rainer Hofmann was sitting in a tavern, where he overheard some elderly people whispering something unintelligible: ''Der Schoufett hockt im Juschbess und kippt sein Ranze voll.''

title: Woman Convicted in Death
description: Ethel Yarbrough was convicted today in Allegan County Circuit Court of involuntary manslaughter in the death of her 12-year-old son, John, July 4, one day after enduring a beating at the House of Judah camp. Sentencing for Mrs. Yarbough, the last of six cult members to be tried in the boy's death, was set for March 16. The charge carries a maximum sentence of 15 years in prison and a $7,500 fine.

title: CANADA AND SOVIET RAISE MARKS TO 2-0
description: The hockey teams that won their opening games Tuesday at the Olympic Winter Games won again today. The teams, Canada, Sweden, the Soviet Union, West Germany and Finland, have 2-0 records in their group standings, along with Czechoslovakia, which today defeated the United States, 4-1.

title: Craft for Jupiter Is Unveiled
description: A tiny spacecraft named Galileo, built to make the first venture into Jupiter's hostile atmosphere, was unveiled here today. Space agency officials said the craft's mission, to begin in 1986, could yield clues to the solar system's birth.

title: A TALE OF THE TWO KANSAS CITIES: THEY FEAR A FEDERAL DIVORCE
description: If cities could talk, both the Kansas City in Missouri and the one in Kansas might now be saying, ''Oops!''

title: New Pact for Switzer
description: Barry Switzer , the Oklahoma football coach since 1973, has been given a new four-year contract in a qualified vote of confidence by the school's Board of Regents. Switzer had been working since 1976 under what amounted to a rolling five-year arrangement in which the Regents routinely added another year following each season. Their decision not to do so this year, according to the Regents, has less to do with Oklahoma's sagging football fortunes, including three consecutive seasons with four losses, than with concerns about the distractions of Switzer's complicated business problems, which he has agreed to address.''

title: EMBASSY RULES OUT EVACUATION OF U.S. CIVILIANS
description: The United States Embassy said in a statement today that it did not regard a full- scale evacuation of American civilians from Lebanon ''as justified at this time.'' It added that it would continue to monitor the situation.

title: Braniff Refund Campaign Set
description: BraniffInc. today announced a promotional campaign in cooperation with the March of Dimes Birth Defects Foundation aimed at getting travelers to try the new airline that plans to begin flying March 1. William D. Slattery, Braniff's president, said the airline would distribute three million coupons that, when applied to a Braniff ticket, enable the user to collect a 5 percent refund on the price of the ticket.

title: C.I.T. FACTORING OFFICIAL GOES TO BANKERS TRUST
description: Marvin Nadler, president and chief executive officer of the Meinhard- Commercial Corporation, has joined the Bankers Trust Company as chief executive of its factoring division. At Meinhard-Commercial, a subsidiary of the C.I.T. Financial Corporation, Albert Camhi was named to succeed Mr. Nadler.

title: BALLY MANUFACTURING CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income.

title: 3 HUMAN-RIGHTS GROUPS SAY ABUSES INCREASE IN HONDURAS
description: Three human-rights monitoring groups asserted yesterday that political killings, disappearances, and torture had increased in Honduras in the last year.

title: REBEL CHIEFS VOW HANDS OFF IN SALVADOR ELECTION
description: The leaders of the political arm of El Salvador's guerrilla opposition said today that next month's elections in that country ''will not be the object of direct military attacks.''

title: THEATER: 'THE RINK'
description: WHEN Chita Rivera steps down front to put over her first John Kander-Fred Ebb song in ''The Rink,'' you feel a surge of relief. Liberated from the draconic attire of ''Merlin'' and looking in every way terrific, Miss Rivera is in command of a Broadway stage for the first time since her 1975 appearance in the Kander-Ebb ''Chicago.'' And if her song is more likable than inspired, Miss Rivera raises it higher: Her voice is firm and sparky; her crinkly smile, often forced in recent years, is spontaneous; her taut dancer's body is in perfect concord with the music's beat.

title: Indian Judge Orders Hanging Of Kashmir Separatist Leader
description: An Indian judge today ordered the execution Saturday of a Kashmir secessionist leader, Maqbool Butt, whose release was demanded by the kidnappers of an Indian diplomat who was slain in England last weekend.

title: DESERTION UNSETTLES GREEN PARTY IN BONN
description: West Germany's Green Party was jolted today when one of its most respected legislators resigned from the party in protest over ''intrigues and power struggles'' and what he said was the growing influence of the party's Marxist-Leninist faction.

title: SCOUTING
description: A Bright Side For Southern Cal

title: NORTHWESTERN NATIONAL LIFE INSURANCE CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Year-ago results reflect a charge of $8 million for prior years' deferred taxes.

title: WHITE HOUSE REBUFFS O'NEILL ON BEIRUT
description: The White House said today that President Reagan had ''many options'' for taking action in Lebanon beyond the Congressional resolution that has become a focus for criticism of his policy.

title: FRIDAY SPORTS Basketball
description: Knicks vs. Utah Jazz, at Salt Lake City. For the first time this season, the Knicks face Utah's Darrell Griffith, who has scored 56 3-point shots, more than the number by any other entire team. (Television - Channel 9, 9:30 P.M.)

title: DANCE: TWO PREMIERES BY MURRAY LOUIS TROUPE
description: MURRAY LOUIS is a choreographer who can be uneven, but certainly this time around, as demonstrated by his opening last night at the City Center, he has come up with two winners as premieres.

title: Imperial Group Net Up
description: Imperial Group P.L.C., the tobacco and foods giant, said today that pre-tax profits rose 25.3 percent in 1983, to $274.5 million, from $219.1 million in 1982.

title: Reagan and Andropov To Hear From Trudeau
description: Prime Minister Pierre Elliott Trudeau told Parliament today that he would write letters to President Reagan and Yuri V. Andropov, the Soviet leader, urging them to build on 10 mutually acceptable principles that he said formed a common ground between East and West.

title: SCOUTING
description: A Deserved Rest

title: DOUGLAS AIRCRAFT STRIKE ENDS
description: A bitter, 16-week strike against the Douglas Aircraft Company ended today when more than 2,000 striking members of the United Automobile Workers ratified an agreement.

title: ADVERTISING
description: People

title: CLUETT PEABODY & CO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a loss of $795,000 from discontinued operations. c-Includes gains from discontinued operations of $644,000 for the quarter and $119,000 for the year.

title: ARBOUR IS BEARING DOWN WITH 500TH VICTORY NEAR
description: There is always a week in the Islander season when Coach Al Arbour narrows his eyes just a bit more than usual, tightens his lips that extra millimeter and looks just a shade unhappier.

title: Greenland Plan
description: The European Economic Community today proposed a 10-year financial agreement that would let Greenland withdraw from the trade bloc. Greenland is a self-ruling territory of Denmark, one of the 10 member nations.

title: AUCTIONS
description: -century master designers as Louis Comfort Tiffany, Rene Lalique, Emil Galle, Edward Hald, Tapio Wirkkala and Erik Hoglund will be auctioned in an Art Nouveau and Art Deco sale next Friday at 2 P.M. and Saturday, Feb. 18, at 10:15 A.M. and 2 P.M. at Sotheby's, York Avenue at 72d Street.

title: MOLECULAR GENETICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Including extraordinary credits of $70,740 for the quarter and $96,000 for the year. c-Net loss

title: Don't Beat Up on Debtors
description: The bankruptcy system is in chaos, the number of business and personal failures is at a record high - and yet a Congressional rescue effort seems stymied. Good.

title: STATE POWER AGENCY WILLING BUY SHOREHAM
description: The problems of costly nuclear plants are depressing the stock prices of some utilities. Page D1.

title: Economic Scene; Placing Blame In Stock Slump
description: WHO is killing the stock market? In Washington, the accusations are flying thick and fast, and the tumbrels may soon start to roll.

title: ARNOLD INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
THE WAR WELCOMED BY ONE AND ALL
description: To the Editor:

title: Homicide Charge
description: Craig MacTavish is the Boston Bruin forward who was charged with drunken driving last month after his car had smashed into the rear of another in Peabody, Mass., fatally injuring a young woman.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Fear and Friendship

title: IRAN, 5 YEARS LATER, DIVIDED AND IN CONFLICT
description: Tomorrow, Iran will mark the fifth anniversary of its Islamic revolution. Five years after the overthrow of the monarchy, Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini and his clerical colleagues are firmly in control. But they rule over a country riven by division and conflict.

title: SABRES BEAT DEVILS AS PERREAULT STARS
description: Mike Foligno, a Buffalo right wing, scored two goals, one during a four-goal second period outburst, as the Sabres routed the New Jersey Devils, 8-5, tonight.

title: The Curbside Hustle
description: Jack and Marie Mansfield, visitors to the New York area from Washington state, took a train from a New Jersey suburb to Penn Station recently and then needed to take a cab uptown about 25 blocks. A young man clutching a fistful of dollar bills accosted them, asked where they were going and hailed them a cab. As he swept open the door, Mr. Mansfield offered a $1 tip.

title: RYDER SYSTEM INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Dodgers Waive Baker
description: The Los Angeles Dodgers waived the outfielder Dusty Bakertoday.

title: BRIEFING
description: Coalition on Deficit

title: MORLAN INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
ENFORCER MOVES UP
description: Robert Esnard was spoiling for a fight. On a bright October morning last year, the Buildings Commissioner walked briskly down Whitehall Street - surrounded by a dozen policemen - to stop the illegal gutting of the old Army Building and, he hoped, to arrest those responsible. By the time he got there, the workers were already gone. But Mr. point. ''In the Buildings Department, you've got to be tough-minded,'' Mr. Esnard said yesterday, shortly after being named Deputy Mayor for Policy and Physical Development.

title: Caldwell, Peete Lead by 1 on 65's
description: Rex Caldwell and Calvin Peete, both using new drivers, shot seven-under-par 65's today and shared the lead by one stroke after the first round of the $500,000 Hawaiian Open.

title: MEN DEFY COLD IN BULKY FURS
description: Men about town these cold days are wearing long-haired furs such as silver fox and almost-white fox and nutria. These skins are used for enormous overcoats that make a man look like a well-tailored bear prowling in frigid climates.

title: CONQUEST EXPLORATION CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes a tax credit of $340,000.

title: GALA IN WASHINGTON HONORS DEAN RUSK
description: A former First Lady, three former Secretaries of State and scores of elder statesmen from the foreign-policy and diplomatic establishment were invited to the State Department's diplomatic reception rooms tonight to honor former Secretary of State Dean Rusk.

title: Browns Get Hairston
description: Carl Hairston , a 31-year-old defensive end who started 106 consecutive games for the Philadelphia Eagles until he was replaced late last season, was traded to the Cleveland Browns for an undisclosed 1985 draft choice. Hairston, a seventh-round draft choice in 1976, had been the Eagles' defensive captain for the last five seasons. He was replaced in the starting lineup by Greg Brown as part of a move by the Eagles to develop younger players.

title: Arts and Letters Group Adds Members
description: Ten new members - five authors, four artists and a composer - have been elected to the American Academy and Institute of Arts and Letters, it was announced yesterday by John Kenneth Galbraith, the organization's president.

title: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES;
description: New York City to Sell $250 Million in Bonds

title: BRIEFS
description: ADAC Laboratories , a Sunnyvale, Calif., producer of medical imaging products, said it had canceled plans to acquire Interad Systems Inc. of Chicago.

title: 3 CANDIDATES CRITICIZE SHELLING
description: Three of the eight candidates for the Democratic Presidential nomination yesterday applauded President Reagan's decision to order a pullback of the marines in Lebanon. But they voiced concern about the future American naval and air role in the region.

title: HEALTH-CHEM CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss.

title: GREYHOUND CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes gains from discontinued operations of $21,126,000 for the quarter and $20,537,000 for the year, and extraordinary gains of $12,063,000 for the quarter and $14,677,000 for the year. c-Includes gains from discontinued operations of $3,701,000 for the quarter and $4,569,000 for the year, and an extraordinary loss of $3,099,000 for the quarter and year. Year-ago results have been restated for discontinued operations.

title: Peru and Banks Agree on Financing
description: Peru has reached agreement with its 12-bank advisory group on a $2.6 billion program designed to cover the country's financing needs through July of next year.

title: TAX BURDENS INCREASE IN THE NEW YORK AREA
description: The savings many Americans will realize on their Federal income tax returns this year will be partly offset by higher state and local taxes.

title: SOUTHLAND ROYALTY CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
FIRE STARTED BY A HEATER KILLS L.I. FAMILY OF 7
description: A postal worker, his wife and their five children were killed today in an early morning fire that swept through their two-story frame home here while they slept, the Nassau County police said.

title: Hernandez-Mets Accord
description: The Mets reached agreement yesterday with Keith Hernandez, their first baseman, and will announce today that they have signed him to a five-year contract worth approximately $8 million. That figure will make him the second-highest-paid player in the team's history.

title: THE SECRET OF MRS. HECKLER'S 'RAINBOW BOOK'
description: When Margaret M. Heckler, the Secretary of Health and Human Services, defended her department's budget request at a Congressional hearing this week, she seemed to have a ready answer to every question.

title: Aid Pact Jeopardized by World Bank Ranking
description: India's refusal to accept a lower ranking in the hierarchy of stockholders of the World Bank - from seventh to ninth place - has jeopardized a finely wrought compromise affecting billions of dollars of aid to the poorest countries, international financial officials said today.

title: SAFEWAY STORES INC reports earnings for 16 wks to Dec 31
QUIT THE U.N.
description: Pre sident Reagan's decision to withdraw the United States from Unesco raises a question in the public's mind: Is our national interest served by our remaining in the United Nations? Such an issue, publicly debated, would serve as a timely warning about how the United Nations has alienated its friends.

title: Egypt and Morocco Reported Ready to Restore Relations
description: King Hassan II of Morocco and President Hosni Mubarak of Egypt have agreed to restore diplomatic relations that were severed when Egypt signed a peace treaty with Israel in 1979, authoritative sources said today.

title: UTILITIES FACE NUCLEAR WOES
description: Electric power utilities enjoy an unusual status: the quasi-public enterprises have a monopoly in their service areas but are closely regulated by government boards.

title: A LIVELY HOME FOR SPANISH THEATER
description: The room is without windows and small, just large enough for a few chairs and a table at which a middle- aged woman in a yellow oxford cloth shirt sits sewing, as ''La Valija'' (''The Suitcase'') opens at the Repertorio Espanol. The author, Julio Mauricio, and the setting are Argentine in the original, but here the sounds of an elevated train and the Cuban accents hint at New York.

title: SHULTZ IS GLOOMY ON LEBANON CRISIS
description: Secretary of State George P. Shultz said today that he was unable to report any progress in President Amin Gemayel's efforts so far to end the political crisis in Lebanon.

title: THE FERRY STILL STIRS HEARTS ALONG HUDSON
description: During the rush hour, the crowd on the Staten Island Ferry is generally quiet. The riders are business people who have staked more or less permanent claims to seats and who bury their heads in newspapers and paper work as New York Harbor slips by.

title: TELLABS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Year-ago share earnings reflect a 2-for-1 stock split paid in August 1983.

title: Home Sales Up 37.2%
description: Sales of existing homes jumped 37.2 percent last year, a trade association said today. For all of 1983, sales of previously owned homes, condominiums and cooperative apartments hit 2.91 million units, up from 2.12 million in 1982, according to the National Association of Realtors. It was the best showing since 3.16 million units were sold in 1980.

title: Millicom in China
description: Millicom Inc. said Government authorities in Canton, China, had granted preliminary approval to install and operate a mobile telephone system to China Telecom Systems Ltd. Millicom owns 30 percent of the venture, and China Resources Ltd. of China holds 25 percent. Other partners include Onwell Holding Ltd. of Hong Kong and Comvik A.B. of Sweden.

title: Convicted Killer Chosen As King of Malaysia
description: Malaysia's hereditary rulers, ignoring the wishes of Prime Minister Mahathir Mohamad, today elected the Sultan of Johore to be King for the next five years.

title: MUDD SIGNS NBC PACT
description: After a self-imposed absence of nearly six months from news broadcasts following his removal as Washington anchor of the ''NBC Nightly News,'' Roger Mudd yesterday agreed to become the network's chief political correspondent.

title: AMERICAN FILTRONA CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes a gain of $1,214,000 on the sale of investment in an affiliated company.

title: ENTERRA CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income.

title: Hong Kong Sales Grow
description: Soaring exports to the United States helped lift Hong Kong's merchandise trade 24 percent last year, to $43 billion, the Government said today.

title: Citizen Endestad
description: SARAJEVO, Yugoslavia

title: The Rozier Effect
description: According to Tom Osborne , the coach, Nebraska's recruiting in football went ''exceptionally well'' until the last 10 days, coinciding with publicity surrounding comments made by Mike Rozier . Two weeks ago, Rozier, the former Nebraska running back and Heisman Trophy winner, was quoted in published reports as saying he had received money and other help from Nebraska alumni while he was a student there.

title: Jan DeGaetani Recital
description: The mezzo-soprano Jan DeGaetani will present a recital Sunday at 8 P.M. in Alice Tully Hall.

title: FRASER INC. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31

title: Cranston, in Iowa, Asks $38 Billion Arms Cut

title: JAZZ CONCERT BY WHITEMAN 60 YEARS AGO TO LIVE AGAIN
description: A 1924 concert called ''An Experiment in Modern Music,'' that seems, in retrospect, embarrassingly wrongheaded in its intent, will be repeated at Town Hall on Sunday afternoon at 3. This 60th-anniversary performance would seem an odd kind of celebration were it not for the fact that the concert included the premiere of a work by the 25-year-old George Gershwin, for which George's brother, Ira, provided the title, ''A Rhapsody in Blue.'' The composer was the piano soloist.

Sets begin at 9:30 and 11:30 P.M. tonight and tomorrow and 9 and 11 P.M. on Sunday; there is a $7 music charge and a $7 minimum at tables. The engagement continues through March 4.

The officer, Russell Lynn Boyd, was one of six people prosecutors said Mr. Moreno killed in a five-hour, 130-mile rampage touched off by estrangement from his wife, Blanca. Two of his in- laws in College Station and three elderly Hempstead residents were killed.

title: Fire Damages Liddy's Home
description: A fire broke out tonight in an attic portion of the home of G. Gordon Liddy, causing $20,000 damage but no injuries, the Prince George's County authorities reported. A fire department spokesman, Tony DeStefano, said a smoke detector alerted Mr. Liddy and his wife to the fire about 8 P.M. The fire was put out in about 15 minutes, he said. Mr. Liddy served 52 and a half months in prison in the 1972 Watergate break-in at Democratic National Committee headquarters. Mr. DeStefano said the origin of the fire ''is not believed to be suspicious.''

DEAR HEART
description: Three- quarters of a century before Esther Holland, a stationer's daughter from Worcester, Mass., introduced valentines to the United States, another young Worcester woman sent her suitor ''a Heart . . . wrought in paper with a Lock and Key.'' When the young man surveyed his ''curious Present,'' he ''found the Emblems clear.'' The medium may have been unusual, the imagery was not.

title: MUSIC: FLAVIO VARANI, PIANIST
description: The pianist Flavio Varani's Thursday evening concert at the Abraham Goodman House was a hit-or-miss affair. Mr. Varani was at his best in some flashy music of the early 20th century, which allowed him to display a reasonably polished technique, and an ability to create attractive, glittering sonorities. The highlight was clearly a traversal of Poulenc's Nocturnes, which were marked by graceful clarity.

title: POOR ADVICE ON U.S. POLICY TOWARD YUGOSLAVIA Having spent two years in Bel
description: grade as a Fulbright Fellow studying Yugoslav courts (1981-83), I find that Felice Gaer's article does not reflect the realities of life in Yugoslavia. Her charges are at best overstated, at worst simply false. Specifically: Gaer's assertion that the Yugoslav press is fettered indicates that she does not read it. I was astonished, on arriving in Belgrade, at how free the political discussion in the press is. Recent articles have been blunt about the sources of Yugoslavia's economic troubles and have raised serious questions about the political system. If some of these points have been expressed indirectly, the Yugolavs certainly have been able to understand what was being said. Nor are ''political cases'' hushed up. Rather - and ironically - Amnesty International's main source of information on Yugoslavia seems to be the Yugoslav press. This hardly bespeaks censorship. Gaer asserts that Yugoslavia has ''one of the highest rates of political prisoners in Eastern Europe.'' This assertion is simply not credible. No one who has lived there would put Yugoslavia in the same league as the Warsaw Pact countries, to say nothing of at the head of that league. She calls for repealing the law on ''hostile propaganda'' and releasing the ''500 or more'' people interned under that law. To judge from the Amnesty International report on Yugoslavia for 1982, most of these people are there because of their efforts (Serbian, Croatian, Albanian, Islamic) to balkanize the Yugoslav state. Freedom of opinion is, of course, a lovely ideal.

title: Trial Shift Sought
description: Pascual Perez , the Atlanta Brave pitcher who is facing a serious drug charge in the Dominican Republic, has asked the Dominican Supreme Court to move his trial from Santiago to another city on the ground that judges in Santiago had been subjected to ''psychological pressures'' that could jeopardize his right to a fair trial. The petition was filed just two days after an appeals court upheld a decision to charge him as a cocaine trafficker, a charge that carries a penalty of from two to five years in prison. Perez, who was arrested Jan. 9 and accused by the police of having half an ounce of cocaine in his wallet, maintains he had a much smaller amount of the drug and should have been charged with no more than simple possession, a charge that could be resolved with a $1,000 fine.

description: All kidding aside, Clifford Freeman is just astounded. He started out to write a few clever lines that would sell some hamburgers, and now his jottings are grist for humor mills from the playground to the pulpit.

description: The verdict, issued by Judge Robert DeMascio of Federal District Court, in effect killed the five-year, $3.5 million contract that Sims signed last July with the Gamblers, an expansion club in the United States Football League. Regan, and Japan's Finance Minister, Noburu Takeshita, excused themselves on the grounds of a heavy workload on their respective budgets.

title: 400 AMERICANS ARE EVACUATED FROM LEBANON
description: With only a few hours' notice, more than 400 American citizens, protected by United States marines and Druse militiamen, were evacuated from Beirut today. Britain also evacuated hundreds of its citizens, and Italy prepared to do so.

title: $900,000 Pact for Hoyt
description: LaMarr Hoyt , the Chicago White Sox pitcher who won the American League Cy Young Award last year after leading his team to a division championship, has signed a one-year, $900,000 contract with the club, but only as a stopgap measure. ''Basically this is just to get things settled for now before starting negotiations for a long-term contract,'' said Hoyt after he and the White Sox avoided arbitration by compromising on salary.

title: RULING BARS CLOSING OF SESSION ON NUCLEAR REACTOR
description: A Federal appeals panel ruled today that the Nuclear Regulatory Commission had acted illegally in deciding to exclude the public and press from a planned meeting about whether to allow the undamaged nuclear reactor at Three Mile Island to reopen.

title: Flu Outbreaks Reported In 14 States and Capital By The Associated Press
description: Widespread outbreaks of flu or flu- like diseases have been reported in 14 states and the District of Columbia, according to the Centers for Disease Control in Atlanta.

title: DREYER'S GRAND ICE CREAM reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Year-ago share earnings and shares outstanding are restated for a 3-for-2 stock split effective June 20, 1983.

title: Jorge Guillen Is Dead at 91; A Spanish Poet and Teacher
description: Jorge Guillen, the Spanish poet and teacher who lived in self-imposed exile in the United States after the Spanish Civil War, died at his home in Malaga, Spain, on Feb. 6. He was 91 years old.

title: Power Is Winner In Home Finale
description: In a game that may have signaled the end of one of New York City's richest traditions in high school basketball, Power Memorial defeated All Hallows High School last night, 76-58, before 1,400 fans at the Power gymnasium.

title: Letter: On Landmark Preservation Church, State and St. Bart's To the Editor:
description: Your Feb. 2 editorial on the impact of the Landmark Preservation Law clearly described the disparate treatment of nonprofit owners and commercial owners, and the bizarre situation in which a panel with architectural expertise must pass on the ''need'' of nonprofit owners. As you concede, your suggestion of a special economic review panel seems to raise constitutional questions when it involves religious organizations protected by the First Amendment.

title: Injured Islanders Ready to Return
description: Three regulars - the defensive partners Dave Langevin and Stefan Persson, and the center Brent Sutter - will return from injuries tonight when the Islanders play the Vancouver Canucks at Nasssau Coliseum.

title: DRILLERS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income.

A PLACE THAT'S A LOT MORE THAN BEER AND 'BRATS'
description: The TalkofMilwaukee

title: CORRECTIONS
description: A Washington dispatch in some copies yesterday, on the Lebanon situation, misattributed a statement about sending ''a signal'' to Syria. The speaker was Representative William S. Broomfield, Republican of Michigan.

title: JENNIFER TIPTON, THE THEATER'S MAGICIAN OF LIGHT
description: A cone of light slices through the darkness, making a puddle on the floor and transfixing two figures standing in black tank suits. They spring to life. Suddenly, four racks of 144 gigantic floodlights snap on, high at the back of the stage. The glare outlines the dancers and assaults the audience's optic nerves. Twyla Tharp's new ballet, ''Fait Accompli,'' neurosis incarnate, has begun.

title: PROPERTY TRUST OF AMERICA reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-Including a gain of $1,286,558 from the sale of real estate and mortgage notes. c-Including a gain of $3,086,788 from the sale of real estate and mortgage notes.

title: SOME STRIKERS BITTER OVER PACT AT PLANE PLANT
description: ''I blame Reagan for this!'' Manuel Ahumada, a California aerospace worker for 30 years, said as he angrily pounded a fist into his palm. ''He started it with the air traffic controllers. He let people know unions don't mean a thing. Now he and his buddies in big business are trying to put the unions out of business.''

title: U.S. Steel Files Trade Suits
description: The United States Steel Corporation filed unfair trade charges today against steelmakers in Spain, South Africa, Argentina, Finland and Australia, contending that they are selling steel in the United States at prices well below the cost of production.

title: McKesson Chief's Leave
description: The McKesson Corporation said today that its president and chief executive, Thomas E. Drohan, 56 years old, had been granted a leave of absence to receive medical treatment. Neil E. Harlan, 62, chairman, was named to the added posts of president and chief executive in his absence, the company said. McKesson is a diversified concern with interests primarily in drugs, liquors, housewares and dairy products.

title: Professor Missing in Beirut
description: An electrical engineering professor at the American University of Beirut, Frank Regier, disappeared today, and university officials said he may have been kidnapped. ''I believe he has been abducted,'' Samir Thabet, the university's acting president said. The professor, who is 50 years old, is married to a Lebanese, Mary Hananina, a mathematics professor at the university.

title: Libyan Ambassador Dies of Wounds in Rome
description: The Libyan Ambassador to Italy, who was shot outside his Rome apartment Jan. 21, died in a hospital today, officials said.

title: HOME BENEFICIAL CORP reports earnings for Year to Dec 31

Justice O'Connor Hailed As Administration Aide
description: The Republican National Committee is distributing a brochure calling Justice Sandra Day O'Connor of the Supreme Court ''one of eight outstanding women in the Reagan Administration.''

title: BALLET: 'DAVIDSB"UNDLERT"ANZE'
description: George Balanchine used to talk teasingly of the conversations he had with his composers. To judge from ''Robert Schumann's 'Davids- b"undlert"anze,' '' performed by the New York City Ballet on Thursday at the New York State Theater, Schumann must have given Balanchine an earful on the loneliness and alienation of the artist. And that Romantic view of the creator was not foreign to the practical-minded Balanchine, as several of his ballets suggest.

title: Profits Plunge At Metromedia
description: Metromedia Inc., citing the absence of the extraordinary gains from discontinued operations that it registered in the preceding year, said yesterday that earnings in the fourth quarter plunged 83.2 percent, while sales rose 22.4 percent. Metromedia, a broadcasting concern based in Secaucus, N.J., said net income in the latest three months dropped to $37.2 million, or $1.27 a share, from $221.5 million, or $6.51 a share, a year earlier.

description: Islander Business At the Olympics

title: Jersey to Conduct Study of Dioxin
description: The first comprehensive medical study in the country on the effect on Vietnam veterans of dioxin in Agent Orange is scheduled to begin within a month at a hospital here, officials said today.

title: Posthumous Election
description: Jackie Jensen , who starred in baseball for the Boston Red Sox, is among four deceased football players who have been elected to the National Football Foundation's College Football Hall of Fame. Besides Jensen, who played fullback for the University of California from 1946 to 1948, those elected were Johnny Bright , Drake halfback, 1949-51; George V. Kerr , Boston College guard, 1938-40, who later became a priest in Weymouth, Mass., and Emil Sitko , Notre Dame fullback, 1946-49. All four will be honored at the foundation's annual dinner next December as will Duffy Daugherty and Jim Tatum , whose election in the coach's category was announced earlier this week.

title: SYRIA ORDERS 7 DAYS OF MOURNING
description: Syria declared seven days of official mourning today to commemorate the death of Yuri V. Andropov, the Soviet leader. Offices will be open but flags will fly at half-staff, according to the official Syrian press agency.

title: EXAMINED ATTITUDES OF SOCIETY ONDEATH

title: LILCO WITHDRAWS FROM PARTNERSHIP IN UPSTATE PLANT
description: The Long Island Lighting Company defaulted yesterday on its partnership agreement with four other New York State utilities that are building the Nine Mile Point 2 nuclear power plant on the shore of Lake Ontario.

title: Most Wanted Criminal Is Seized in Argentina
description: The Argentine police today arrested Anibal Gordon, one of the most wanted criminals and suspected leader of a rightist group accused of carrying out hundreds of abductions and murders.

title: Aladdin Hotel Chapter 11 Filing
description: The Aladdin hotel and casino filed under Chapter 11 of the Federal Bankruptcy Act after trustees for a teamsters' pension fund loan refused to grant further extensions on delinquent payments. Mike Sloan, an attorney, said the filing had been made in Federal Bankruptcy Court shortly before the deadline set by the Victor Palmieri Company of Los Angeles to bring delinquent payments current.

title: I.B.M. Leasing
description: The International Business Machines Corporation said it was raising convenience lease and rental charges by about 7 percent for systems and equipment ranging from its I.B.M. 3084 processor and System/34 to the I.B.M. 3420 magnetic tape unit. License fees for a number of products, including the multiple virtual storage/system product, will be raised 7 to 10 percent.

description: b-Net loss.

title: LESLIE FAY'S PARTNERS NEGOTIATING A BUYOUT
description: The partners in the Leslie Fay Company, who bought the apparel manufacturer less than two years ago for $54 million, are negotiating a new leveraged buyout of the company for $169 million.

GOING OUT GUIDE;
description: DANCE For 40 years, the Dance Collection of the New York Public Library has been gathering the landmarks of the art. The collection, now housed in the dance section on the third floor of the library branch in Lincoln Center, 111 Amsterdam Avenue, at 65th Street (870-1655), has amassed 37,000 books and pamphlets, hundreds of thousands of letters, manuscripts and photographs, 1,500 oral-interview tapes, 2,500 motion-picture reels, many original drawings and stage designs, along with posters, clippings, scrapbooks and microfilm.

title: SATURDAY, FEBRUARY 11, 1984 Death of Andropov
description: Yuri P. Andropov died on Thursday of a chronic kidney ailment less than 15 months after he succeeded Leonid I. Brezhnev as General Secretary of the Soviet Communist Party. The official announcement was read on radio and television at 2:30 P.M. (6:30 A.M. New York time) and repeated throughout the day. (Page 1, Column 6.) The U.S. said it wanted to reaffirm its desire ''for a constructive and realistic'' dialogue with the Soviet Union during this period of transition in Moscow. A statement read by Secretary of State George P. Shultz was meant as a prompt signal, State Department officials said, that Washington was more ready than ever for a significant improvement in relations, in keeping with President Reagan's exhortations last month. (1:3.)

title: O'Rourke Selects Executive Officer
description: The vice chairman of the Westchester County Legislature was named today by County Executive Andrew P. O'Rourke to be his executive officer.

title: SWEETS FOR VALENTINE'S DAY: RIPE RED PEPPERS
description: They are red, they are sweet and they are available. That makes them an appropriate, if unusual, subject for a column devoted to Valentine's Day. Unlike chocolate candy hearts, red velvet cake and cookies dyed red and cut in the shape of cupids, red peppers are very low in calories, sodium, fat and cholesterol, high in Vitamin C, loaded with Vitamin A and in addition offer some B vitamins, a little iron and fiber.

title: VOTE SETS BACK NUCLEAR PLANT
description: The Neshaminy Water Resources Authority has ordered a halt to work on the Point Pleasant Pumping Station, clouding the future of both the project and an uncompleted nuclear power plant that needs water from the station.

title: Rights Survey Stops Using Word 'Killing'
description: The word ''killing'' has been stricken from State Department reports on human rights. Officials said today that the Government considered it more precise to say ''unlawful or arbitrary deprivation of life.''

title: Old and New French Music
description: The Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center will celebrate both the 75th anniversary of Olivier Messiaen and the 300th anniversary of Jean Philippe Rameau with performances tomorrow afternoon at 5 in Alice Tully Hall.

title: No Steps Are Taken On Replacing Buses
description: No steps were taken to replace the city's 851 flawed Grumman Flxible buses at the monthly meeting of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority board yesterday.

title: Lecturing Nicaragua Solves Nothing
description: Woodrow Wilson once remarked that he aimed ''to teach the South American republics to elect good men.'' Almost as loftily, Secretary of State Shultz the other day expounded the rudiments of democracy to Nicaragua's Marxist regime. Plainly, there is much to be said about the on-again, off- again election maneuverings in Managua. But the Secretary spoke carelessly, less than candidly and not, therefore, helpfully.

title: Soviet Star Vaults 19-1 1/2 for Indoor Mark INGLEWOOD, Calif., Feb. 10 (AP) - Sergei Bubka, the world champion pole-vaulter from the Soviet Union, soared 19 feet 1 1/2 inches tonight to break his world indoor best at The Los Angeles Times-United Airlines Indoor Games.
description: The record vault, which matched the outdoor record held by Thierry Vigneron of France, came moments after Billy Olson, the former record holder, had cleared 19- 1/4.

title: SOUGHT JOBS, NOT A PAYOFF, OLMEDO SAYS
description: City Councilman Luis A. Olmedo of Brooklyn, charged with criminal conspiracy and attempted extortion, declared at his trial yesterday that he had been seeking jobs for his constituents and not graft for himself in his dealings with a Brooklyn company.

title: Cleveland Electric
description: The Cleveland Electric Illuminating Company said it planned to file with the Public Utilities Commission of Ohio for a rate increase of $180 million, or 15 percent. The company said that it expects to make its filing after March 10 and that it would take 10 months for regulatory reviews to be completed.

title: Iran Again Threatens To Shut Off Oil Flow
description: The President of Iran, Hojatolislam Ali Khamenei, said Thursday that his country would stop the oil flow from the Persian Gulf to the West if the United States became actively involved in the Iran-Iraq war, the Iranian press agency reported.

description: Geologists saw what appeared to be a new lobe of molten rock on top of the Mount St. Helens lava dome today, but clouds and fog prevented more than a brief glimpse, scientists said.

For the first time, he sat in a chair, picked up a cake of soap and considered wearing shoes.

description: The captain was too short to see over the wheel without standing on a chair. The first mate was three inches shorter.

title: TV: ABC'S COVERAGE OF THE WINTER OLYMPICS
description: On television, the 1984 Winter Olympics vamped for time this past week. ABC gave us hours and hours from Sarajevo, Yugoslavia, but it only proved that less is more, and that ''if you've got it, flaunt it,'' really doesn't work. ABC used more air time than it knew what to do with. Digressions were everywhere; sports events were not. Viewers, the ratings showed, turned away in great numbers.

description: At the end of the second act of ''Tannh"auser'' last night at the Metropolitan Opera, the principals trooped onstage in a body, as is the company's custom, to accept applause communally for what had been a particularly rousing contest of wills in the Hall of Song. The ovation, however, exploded into a roar every time Leonie Rysanek appeared from behind the curtain and exploded again every time she made her move to leave the stage.

title: U.S. DOCTORS BELIEVE ANDROPOV HAD FAILING KIDNEY WHEN HE TOOK OFFICE
description: Yuri V. Andropov probably had a failing kidney when he took office 15 months ago, and his health was apparently also harmed by long-term complications of diabetes, American physicians said yesterday.

title: POPE SAYS SUFFERING CAN MEAN SPIRITUAL GAIN
description: Pope John Paul II has issued an apostolic letter on suffering in which he says physical, mental and moral pain pose a mystery that can lead to spiritual growth and salvation.

title: THE CHIEF MOURNER IN MOSCOW
description: The appointment of Konstantin U. Chernenko today to head Yuri V. Andropov's funeral commission marked at least a partial triumph for a veteran Communist who only 15 months earlier seemed to have reached the end of his political career. Whether the appointment suggested that Mr. Chernenko had been tapped to succeed Mr. Andropov, or whether it was given him on the strength of his position as the second-ranking secretary, was likely to become clear only when the Central Committee named a new General Secretary.

title: Harvester Sets Executive Pacts
description: The International Harvester Company has entered into contracts with its key executives that provide for the continuation of salary and benefits for up to two years in case of termination as a result of restructuring activities, according to proxy statements. The agreements also permit the executives to resign and receive specific severance benefits if, as a result of a change in the company, the executives' salary or benefits are reduced.

description: b-Net income. Year-ago share earnings are not available because the company's initial public offering was made Sept. 7, 1983.

title: A GALA PARTY FOR NEW MISSONI SHOP
description: The Missoni shop on Madison Avenue actually opened quietly on Dec. 28, three months behind schedule. But Rosita and Ottavio Missoni didn't get to see it until Tuesday, when they arrived from Milan for a week's stay. And it wasn't until Thursday night that the shop was given a gala send- off.

title: Ranger Farm in Trouble
description: The future of the Rangers' top farm club, the Tulsa Oilers of the Central Hockey League, was in doubt yesterday after the new owners of the financially ailing team canceled their purchase. Ranger officials had no immediate comment, but General Manager Craig Patrick was on his way to Denver, where the Oilers were playing last night.

title: STATE DEPARTMENT ACCORDING TO RUSK
description: In mid-December there began to come into being what might be called a ''trade union'' of former Secretaries of State. They did not send me here, George, to recruit you to join our ranks any time soon, but nonetheless, I think we would agree that there are certain things about the job that perhaps the public does not fully understand. Some of them you cannot do very much about.

title: SUDDENLY, NEW RESOLVE TO CONFRONT THE DEFICIT
description: The Federal Reserve said it would keep doing what it has been doing - keeping a lid on inflation while trying to slow the economy's growth to a speed it might maintain for the balance of the 1980's. But the Fed chairman, Paul A. Volcker, said he was not going to modify his plans if a force he cannot control - the biggest Government budget deficits in history - set off a paralyzing rise in interest rates or even another recession. With that, hundreds of thousands of investors canceled their bets on a healthy economy and the stock market plunged.

title: P.S.C. STAFF FAULTS LILCO
description: The staff of the State Public Service Commission recommended today that the Long Island Lighting Company absorb at least $1.5 billion of the cost of the Shoreham nuclear power plant because of ''serious mismanagement'' by the utility.

description: When and if United States troops involved in the Big Pine II military maneuvers in Honduras are withdrawn, they will leave behind a lonely ghost.

title: TEXAS COURT BARS COASTAL BID
description: A state district court in Austin, Tex., issued a temporary restraining order yesterday barring the Coastal Corporation from going ahead with its unwelcome takeover bid for the Houston Natural Gas Corporation.

title: SCHWAB SAFE CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
SOURCE CAPITAL INC reports earnings for As of Dec 31
Texaco-Getty Link Advances
description: A Federal Trade Commission source said tonight that the agency's staff had recommended that Texaco Inc. be allowed to acquire the Getty Oil Company, subject to the divestiture of two Getty refineries, in New Jersey and Kansas, and a pipeline that runs between Colorado and Kansas. Texaco must also agree to supply crude oil to certain refineries now served by Getty, according to the source, who declined to be identified.

title: Meeting With Dupree
description: Marcus Dupree , the former running back from the University of Oklahoma who had transferred to the University of Southern Mississippi and then dropped out, met yesterday in the New York area with Joseph Canizaro , the owner of the New Orleans Breakers, to discuss possible future employment for Dupree in the United States Footall League. Also at the meeting were Randy Vataha , the Breakers' president, and Kenneth Fairley , Dupree's adviser.

title: GLENN'S STAFF PLANS TO SEEK INQUIRY ON MONDALE FUNDS
description: Senator John Glenn's Presidential campaign said today that it would ask the Federal Election Commission to investigate what it said was the ''improper use of labor money'' by former Vice President Walter F. Mondale's campaign in Iowa and New Hampshire.

title: PATRICK J. BOHEN Sr.
description: Patrick J. Bohen Sr., president of Caravatt Home Entertainment, a division of Caravatt Communications, died Wednesday at Huntington (L.I.) Hospital. He was 54 years old and lived in Melville, L.I.

title: JOHN BREEN
description: John Breen, the general manager of the Houston Oilers from 1971 to 1973, has died of cancer at the age of 76. Mr. Breen started in professional football in 1957 as director of player personnel for the Chicago Cardinals and most recently worked as a sports broadcaster for radio station KTRH here. The station announced his death Thursday. He is survived by his wife, Betty, and three children.

title: TOWN EXPERIMENT CUTS TV VIEWING
description: More than a quarter of this town's residents either sharply reduced the time they watched television last month or did not watch it at all, according to surveys taken by backers of a monthlong experiment.

title: Humility Is for Wackos
description: Mayor Koch has just published a book titled ''Mayor,'' which is notable - possibly revolutionary - for its absence of humility.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''The Central Committee of the Communist Party of the Soviet Union, the Presidium of the U.S.S.R. Supreme Soviet and the U.S.S.R. Council of Ministers with deep sorrow inform the party and the entire Soviet people that Yuri Vladimirovich Andropov, General Secretary of the C.P.S.U. Central Committee, President of the Presidium of the U.S.S.R. Supreme Soviet, died after a long illness at 16 hours 50 minutes on Feb. 9, 1984.'' - Announcement from Central Committee of Soviet Communist Party. (6:1.)

title: CORRECTION
description: A table in Business Day yesterday listing utilities with majority interests in nuclear plants included one incorrectly. The Public Service Company of New Mexico has a 10.2 percent interest in three reactors under construction.

title: RENTERS IN THE COMMODITY PITS
description: Getting onto the trading floor of the Board of Trade would seem to require not only an ample reservoir of courage, but a fat wallet as well. Full membership, which allows one to trade any contract in any pit, sells for $320,000 or so. Even the most limited membership fetches about $20,000.

title: TOUR OF 3 LEBANESE VILLAGES U.S. SHIPS SHELLED SHOWS LESS DAMAGE THAN REPORTED
description: Three villages in this Syrian-controlled part of Lebanon were said to have been among areas subjected to American naval bombardment this week, but a brief, limited tour today showed less destruction than had been reported.

title: POLICY AFTER ANDROPOV: WASHINGTON FORESEES CONTINUING CONFLICTS
description: The passing of a major political leader sometimes creates a sense of opportunity. But as seen by a range of Reagan Administration officials, Yuri V. Andropov's death offers not so much a chance for breakthroughs as a time for gestures that might lead to breakthroughs later on. There is little evidence that anything fundamental has changed in either Moscow or Washington with Mr. Andropov's passing. Essentially, the same people have been running Soviet foreign policy for five or six years. Mr. Andropov was ill for almost one year of his 15-month tenure. His predecessor, Leonid I. Brezhnev, seemed inactive for his last three years. Soviet policy has been much the same throughout.

title: PACIFIC NORTHERN GAS LTD Year to Dec 31 reports earnings for 1983
ANSWERS TO QUIZ
description: Questions appear on page 16.

title: V.A. CRITICAL OF OFFICIALSAT WESTCHESTER HOSPITAL
description: A report by investigators from the Veterans Administration has recommended a major leadership reorganization at the Franklin D. Roosevelt Hospital in Montrose, N.Y., the largest psychiatric facility in the V.A. system.

title: ISRAELI JETS ATTACK PALESTINIAN POSITIONS
description: Israeli jets attacked Palestinian guerrilla positions in the hills east of here today in their first raids in Lebanon since Shiite and Druse militiamen took over West Beirut on Monday.

title: Soviet Skier Wins Cross-Country Race
description: The Soviet Union won its first gold medal of the XIV Olympic Winter Games today, as Nikolai Zimiatov lunged through driving snow and wind to beat a teammate, Aleksandr Zavialov, in the 30-kilometer cross- country ski race.

title: INTERNATIONAL CONTROLS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After loss from discontinued operations of $75,000. c-Includes income from discontinued operations of $306,000 and a gain on disposal of discontinued operations of $491,000. d-Includes income from discontinued operations of $619,000 and income from an extraordinary item of $3.4 million.

title: DOROTHY ARMOUR, 91, IS DEAD
description: Dorothy Armour, who for decades was a prominent social figure and fund- raiser for charitable causes in New York, died Thursday of pneumonia at her home in Manhattan. She was 91 years old.

title: Pact in Jersey On Jail Crowding
description: Essex County and New Jersey officials have reached agreement on inmate levels at the overcrowded county jail and will seek a Federal judge's approval next week, officials said today.

title: HERNANDEZ SIGNS 5-YEAR PACT
description: The Mets signed Keith Hernandez yesterday to one of baseball's richest contracts: $8.4 million for five years, with $1 million of it in a signing bonus and $3.4 million in a deferred annuity for the rest of his life.

title: Fate and the Reagan Slate
description: It's impossible, even while expressing all due sympathy on the death of Yuri Andropov, not to notice that it reflects something about the life of Ronald Reagan. There are times when fate seems to be on his side, and this is another one.

title: SHULTZ EMPHASIZES U.S. IS READY FOR EFFORT TO IMPROVE RELATIONS
description: President Reagan and Secretary of State George P. Shultz told Soviet leaders today that during this period of transition in Moscow the United States wanted to reaffirm its desire ''for a constructive and realistic dialogue'' with the Soviet Union.

title: PRODUCER PRICES UP 0.6% IN MONTH, LED BY FOOD
description: Producer prices for finished goods, driven up by a sharp rise in food prices, climbed six- tenths of 1 percent in January, the Labor Department reported today. It was the largest monthly rise in more than a year.

title: POOR ADVICE ON U.S. POLICY TOWARD YUGOSLAVIA
description: To the Editor:

title: Touring Romantic Sites
description: The love lives of some famous New York politicians, actors, writers and artists are the subjects of a bus tour tomorrow sponsored by the 92d Street Y in celebration of Valentine's Day.

title: GOV. MATHESON BARS AN ATTEMPT TO GAIN THIRD TERM IN UTAH
description: Gov. Scott M. Matheson, a Democrat who has served two four-year terms, said today that he would not seek re-election. The decision opened the door for Republicans, who have not held the Utah governorship in 20 years.

title: CLARK POSTPONES COAL RIGHTS SALE
description: Interior Secretary William P. Clark announced today that he would put off a major sale of coal leases on Federal land in the San Juan Basin of New Mexico at least until next year, pending a decision on what lands to protect as wilderness areas.

title: STATE GRANTS MADE FOR HIGH TECH
description: T HE Kean administration's program to develop an economy based on high technology moved out of the talking stages last week, when monetary awards were announced for expanding the industrial uses of ceramics and finding new ways to dispose of hazardous and toxic wastes.

title: Cadets Barred at Dartmouth
description: The faculty of arts and sciences at Dartmouth College voted this week against reinstatement of United States Naval Reserve Officer Training Corps program.

description: Anthony Austin , an editor of The New York Times Magazine, reported from Moscow for The Times from 1979 to 1981. MEMOIRS

title: HAYES ENJOYING FAREWELL SEASON
description: The mere mention of Elvin Hayes brings to mind the turnaround jumper, the shot responsible for the majority of the 27,136 points he has scored during his career. Much like Kareem Abdul- Jabbar's skyhook, Hayes's shot is recognized as one of the most devastating ever developed.

title: PRO-GEMAYEL FIGHTERS WELCOME U.S. ACTIONS
description: Lebanese Christian militia leaders here said today that they welcomed the United States naval bombardment of anti-Gemayel militia targets, saying they believed it may have encouraged Syria to ease its demands against President Amin Gemayel, a Maronite Christian.

title: OWNERS OF VINEYARDS REMAIN OPTIMISTIC
description: C ONNECTICUT vineyard owners have to be an optimistic group. They struggle to get the vines through the state's harsh winters, then spray and pray to get the grapes through the disease- prone growing seasons, all the while fending off birds and other pests that try to eat the crop early.

title: Tass Says Mission Failed
description: The official Soviet press agency Tass reported the landing of the United States space shuttle Challenger today and called it one of the ''most unsuccessful'' missions in the shuttle program. ''Setbacks plagued nearly each day of the flight,'' the agency said.

title: FREE SPIRITS Stick With Macaroni In 1972 Connecticut's governor picked its first state song: ''The Green Hills of My Connecticut.'' Though unsingable, it lasted until 1978, when the General Assembly substituted ''Yankee Doodle.''
description: Some considered that an insult: The song portrays Yankees as rubes who stick feathers in hats and call them macaroni.

title:
BUSINESS FORUM;
BUT IT'S HIGH TIME TO CONTROL THE FLOW
description: GOVERNMENT regulators get concerned when they see financial risks that have traditionally been borne by large, sophisticated investors transferred to the Federal Government.

title: ARBOUR WINS NO. 500
description: With the help of a little mixing, a little psychology and perhaps one of his familiar long, cold stares, Al Arbour recorded his 500th regular-season coaching victory tonight as his Islanders beat the Vancouver Canucks, 6-4.

title: LESSONS IN REALITY
description: NEWARK O N THE first morning of the practice-of-medicine course at the New Jersey Medical School here, Dr. Eugene Lewit, an economist, not a physician, told fourth-year medical students how to set up a practice to make the most money.

title: Mike Woods Back in Shape, And Back in Olympic Games
description: It was September 1982, and Dr. Michael Woods, assistant professor of anesthesiology at the Medical College of Wisconsin in Milwaukee and staff anesthesiologist at the Veterans Administration Hospital there, had a problem. He was growing soft.

title: EAST GERMANS 1, 2 IN BOBSLED
description: Wolfgang Hoppe, a 26-year- old army engineer, won the gold medal in the two-man bobsled competition at the Winter Olympics today as the East Germans captured the top two spots.

title: SCHOOL WRESTLER, 16, COLLAPSES AND DIES AT START OF A MATCH
description: A 16-year-old high school wrestler in Westchester County collapsed and died less than 20 seconds into a match, the county's Superintendent of Schools said yesterday.

title: ELECTRONIC MONITOR TURNS HOME INTO JAIL
description: Cesario Romero was not pleased at having an electronic transmitter strapped to his ankle 24 hours a day. It was irritating and got in his way at work sometimes

title: IOWA AN AVERAGE STATE THAT REAPS CORN AND ABOVE-AVERAGE INFLUENCE
description: Once again Iowa is center stage as its voters prepare to pass the first judgment by the public on the eight major Democratic Presidential candidates competing in the state's precinct caucuses Feb. 20.

title: SUNDAY SPORTS Basketball
description: Nets vs. Houston Rockets, at Byrne Meadowlands Arena, 1 P.M. Ralph Sampson pays his first visit as a professional to the Meadowlands, and Elvin Hayes pays his last one for the Rockets. The Nets won by their largest margin this season in the first meeting, 104-86 in Houston on Nov. 15. Otis Birdsong, who has been out with a sprained right foot, returns for the Nets. He scored a game-high 34 points in the previous game with Houston. (Television - SportsChannel 1 P.M. and 8 P.M. tape. Radio - WNBC 660, 1 P.M.)

title: TOILING IN THE VINEYARD
description: IN THE BEGINNING, there was the donnish school of wine writing: prose redolent of old leather bindings and reminiscent of warm spring afternoons when motes of dust float silently in sunlight shafting through leaded library windows. Lots of references to rites Dionysian and Bacchanalian, Greek and Latin quotations, and carefully modulated fervor, lavished almost exlusively on claret and port. The dons, so far as I can tell, are all gone.

title: NEW CHARGES IN IGERIA CITE WIDE CORRUPTION
description: Nigeria's military Government has made sweeping new allegations of corruption against politicians ousted in the New Year's Eve coup. It accused one of depositing millions of dollars in a bank account in the name of a United States corporation.

title: Uncritical 'Scientists' Are Taken to Task
description: The article ''Searchers Seek Indian Crypt'' (Jan. 1) dealt with a particularly naive archeological dispute; it is of a genre easily found in the feature section of any newspaper, but I was surprised to find it in The New York Times.

title: WEST GERMAN WINS BIATHLON
description: Peter Angerer of West Germany charged past Jan Matousch of Czechoslovakia on the final leg of the 20-kilometer biathlon today and won the Olympic gold medal in 1 hour 11 minutes 52.7 seconds.

title: RESTARTS HURT AHERN OF U.S.
description: Pat Ahern of Breckenridge, Colo., lost an opportunity to win an Olympic medal in Nordic combined skiing today when controversial rulings by the jury canceled two rounds of jumping and wiped out his jumps, two of the longest of the competition.

title: Cold Weather Is Suspected In a Surge of Winter Deaths
description: Two weeks of bitter cold in late December appear to have been a factor in a spurt of deaths around the United States, Government weather experts say.

description: T HE player was lethargic in practice and erratic in games. He seemed to be in financial

title: TIME AND AGAIN, IT'S A MATTER OF THE HEART
description: WE were a crazy group then, back in the early 60's. There were Mike, Emily, Richy, John, Craig, Marlene and I, and we spent our leisure moments at college drinking gobs of coffee in a booth at the Pancake House near the campus or lounging in the Student Union, sharing everything from trivial gossip to profound philosophical debates.

title: MUSIC: PREMIERE BY COREA
description: The term ''classical crossover'' applied to jazz musicians usually suggests light concert fare that glosses the crowd-pleasing style of late-Romantic music while avoiding complex thematic development. The pianist Chick Corea, however, is one of a handful of jazz musicians whose finest compositions, while thought eclectic, really do have the weight and richness of serious concert music.

title: CARNIVAL IN ALASKA LIGHTS UP DARK DAYS OF NORTH'S WINTER
description: It began in 1936 when this city was a small cluster of people huddled a snowball's throw from Cook Inlet. The purpose was to combat the cabin fever that visits the north country in the dark days of the long winter.

title: NURSE ACCUSED OF KILLING CHILD WEIGHS TESTIFYING
description: Defense attorneys have not yet decided if Genene Jones, a nurse, will take the stand to defend herself against charges that she killed a young girl with an injection of a muscle relaxant, purportedly in a scheme to justify a children's intensive care unit.

title: KNICKS TROUNCE NUGGETS, 138-112
description: In facing the Denver Nuggets tonight, a slumping team that was debilitated by the flu, the Knicks were hoping to tire their opponents in the opening three periods and finish them off in the fourth. They didn't have to wait that long..

title: Dockworkers Accept Pact in New Orleans By The Associated Press
description: New Orleans dockworkers accepted a tentative pact yesterday to end a two- day-old strike by members of the International Longshoremen's Association.

title: TWO PROGRAMS AID GIFTED HANDICAPPED STUDENTS
description: T WO programs in the county are helping gifted students with handicaps to experience greater success in school and increase their self-esteem.

title: SAIL SKATEBOARDS TAKE TO ICE
description: LONG BRANCH P AUL MINDNICH glanced up apprehensively at the gray skies, then down at the puddles that lay on the plastic bag over his parka. The rain had stopped and a fresh breeze was sweeping across the mirror-like ice of the Shrewsbury River.

title:
STAMPS;
NEW CATALOGUES REFLECT CHANGING TRENDS
description: The spotlight this year is on the first-day cover catalogues. They may never be the same again - an idea that requires a few words of explanation.

description: After more than 20 years as a star of the New York City Opera, after countless nights of glittering arias, roaring audiences and thrilling curtain calls at Lincoln Center, the mezzo-soprano Muriel Costa-Greenspon has finally hit it big with a number.

description: One Man's Compensation The Federal Bureau of Investigation will have to dig into its pocket because of its negligence in the case of Walter Bergman .

title: REPAIRING HIGHWAYS ALSO REQUIRES LOTS OF POLITICAL CAPITAL
description: HARTFORD S INCE the collapse of the Mianus River Bridge in Greenwich last June, Connecticut officials have been adding up what it would cost to rebuild the state's bridges and roads. Gov. William A. O'Neill, in his annual budget message delivered last week at the opening session of the General Assembly, finally presented the bill: $5.5 billion over the next 10 years, with about $2 billion to be paid by the state and most of the rest to come from Federal funds.

title: Matter of Hanging Or Shooting Clay
description: In George L. Mahoney's letter to the editor, published on Jan. 1, he did a slight disservice to Henry Clay by saying that Andrew Jackson's last regrets were that he had not shot or hanged Clay and John C. Calhoun.

title: THE TROUBLE WITH LAWYERS
description: Charles Fried is Carter Professor of General Jurisprudence at Harvard Law School. By Charles Fried HEY SAY THERE'S A problem about lawyers: that only the very rich can afford proper legal services. My law students have a problem, too, but not that one. The day they graduate from Harvard Law School they can earn up to $50,000 a year in Wall Street law firms or their equivalents in other large cities. They can't explain these princely salaries the way doctors do - as the reward for years of privation - since these same firms may have paid them $1,000 a week during their summer vacations (sometimes throwing in a clothing allowance) just to get a hook into them. Ten years down the road, if they are made partners, these privileged young can expect to earn $200,000 a year, while the superstars of the profession pull down more than half a million.

title: May Wedding Set By Miss Claggett
description: Announcement has been made by Capt. Bladen Dulany Claggett, U.S.N., retired, and Mrs. Claggett of Chevy Chase, Md., of the engagement of their daughter, Mariamne Morris Claggett, to Hugh Blanchard Vickery 3d, a son of Comdr. Hugh B. Vickery, U.S.N., retired, and Mrs. Vickery of Washington.
