description: The Rangers, after losing command of a three-goal lead and once trailing by a score of 6-4, came back to finish with a 6-6 tie against the Los Angeles Kings tonight.

title: Su Yu of China Dead; Communist Army Aide
description: Su Yu, a Chinese military commander who served as Chief of Staff from 1954 to 1958, has died, Peking said Friday. He was 77 years old.

title: 50 YEARS AGO: THE BIRTH OF TAPE
description: T here were proper celebrations last month in the Rhineland city of Ludwigshafen, where the first workable recording tape was produced just 50 years ago by BASF, Germany's largest chemical concern. Among the guests at these festivities was Heinz Thiele, a sprightly gentleman and eminent engineer, whose memory and researches reach back to the beginnings of tape recording.

title: St. John's Defeats UConn By 84-65
description: Coach Lou Carnesecca sipped champagne from a paper cup today as if his St. John's team had just won the Big East Conference basketball championship. He was merely relieved that the Redmen had broken their four-game losing streak and that he had become the most sucessful coach in the school's history.

description: While the snow fell, steadily, muffled, for nearly 48 hours, clogging mountain roads and wiping out manicured ski runs, a sense of nervousness crept through the United States Alpine ski team.

title:
ANTIQUES;
GETTING TO THE HEART OF THE MATTER
description: A NTIQUES and other objects whose central focus is a heart design enjoy considerable collectible interest throughout the year, but are especially prominent, of course, as Valentine's Day approaches. Advertisements featuring hearts of all types capture popular interest, and this is reflected somewhat in the antiques marketplace.

title: WILD TURKEYS FIND A HOME IN L.I. SUBURB
description: The wild turkey, considered extinct in the state by 1844, is now flourishing in only the most rural upstate areas. But in a suburban neighborhood in Wantagh, a small flock has been a common sight for almost eight years, to the delight of some and the annoyance of others.

title: Horseman Aids
description: Smith Fund Alan Leavitt, the president of Lana Lobell Farms, said yesterday that he would donate a $15,000 stud fee earned by his trotting stallion, Speedy Somolli, to the Red Smith Writing Scholarship at Notre Dame. Speedy Somolli, who was named 3-year-old trotter of the year in 1978, stands at Bedminster, N.J., one of Lana Lobell's three farms. Leavitt said that the scholarship fund, a memorial to the sports columnist and Notre Dame alumnus who died in 1982, would receive one of several fees Speedy Somolli was expected to earn tomorrow, the first day of the farms' breeding season.

title: UNDERSTANDINGS, OLD AND NEW, CRUMBLE TO CHAOS IN LEBANON
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon T HE most frightening thing about being in Beirut last week was not the widespread shelling of civilian apartment houses or the window-rattling bombardments of the battleship New Jersey. Rather, it was watching a society come apart, with people running through the streets in panic not knowing where the fighting was coming from, where it would lead or when it would stop. The status quo that had developed as a result of the Israeli invasion had collapsed.

title: VOLUNTARY DESEGREGATION OF SCHOOLS DIVIDES BAKERSFIELD, CALIF.
description: In the 1950's, while Everett Beed was a black child attending a predominantly white elementary school here, the Board of Education was repeatedly changing attendance zones, segregating and resegregating the schools.

title: WHEN POLITICS BECOMES PART OF THE SERMON
description: G od moves in a mysterious way, especially on television. Religious programming proliferates, and evangelists are everywhere. We need not watch them, although it is a mistake if we dismiss them. The magazine Good Housekeeping polled its readers and found that, while Ronald Reagan was first among men the readers admired, the Rev. Jerry Falwell was second, with the Rev. Billy Graham third. Mr. Falwell, besides being the leader of the Moral Majority, is the host of the ''Old Time Gospel Hour.'' Meanwhile, for the second year in a row, Mr. Reagan has spoken at the annual convention of the National Religious Broadcasters, pressing his position on school prayer and abortion. The assembled ministers loved the President; it is reasonable to assume some of them will talk about him on their broadcasts. Church and state will not necessarily be joined, but religion and politics will find a way to march hand in hand.

title: FOR HIGH TECHNOLOGY, ONE SPIRIT
description: T HERE is a saying that ''he who limits his aims limits his accomplishments.'' In the field of high technology, we must set our goals high and then work diligently to achieve them.

title: DANCE VIEW ; JEROME ROBBINS IN A LANGOROUS MOOD
description: ''A ntique Epigraphs,'' Jerome Robbins's latest premiere for the New York City Ballet, might or might not be Jerome Robbins's new companion piece to his own ''Afternoon of a Faun.'' It has the same virtue of richness in simplicity. It has, like the earlier ballet of 1953, a score by Debussy. Now, too, the ballet poetically implies a subtext that stems directly from Debussy's own inspirations - which were the poems of French writers he admired. Moreover, the poetry in each case found its theme in the mythology of Ancient Greece.

title: CLEAR CHOICES IN SALVADOR, MURKY PLANS IN NICARAGUA
description: For an hour, the middle-class crowd in the suburban Guadelupe Gardens shopping center chanted, ''Fatherland, yes! Communism, no!'' and sang a political pep song about ''Communist criminals with animal instincts.'' Finally, Roberto d'Aubuisson, the Presidential candidate of the right-wing Republican National Alliance (Arena), made his entrance, a boyish, handsome, trim figure in a sporty red-white-and-blue T-shirt, smiling, waving and throwing kisses.

title: NO NEED TO SHUN THE FRUMIOUS PRUNES OF YOUTH
description: food stores, dried fruits regained their popularity - somewhat. But they still remain much overlooked, eaten once in a while with breakfast cereal or munched on as a snack. Perhaps too many people never recovered from the stewed prunes of their childhood.

title: FOLLOW-UP ON THE NEWS
description: Contending that rents for National Park Service employees living in Government housing were ''artificially low,'' the Interior Department moved in May 1983 to raise them. Rangers at Yosemite National Park formed a tenants' association and sued in Federal Court in Fresno, Calif., to block the action, which they said would increase rents 100 percent.

title: Miss Wirth, TV Aide, Marries Daniel Pope

description: Nearly 80 years ago the great naturalist John Muir and his Sierra Club undertook a fight to save California's Tuolumne River from being impounded to supply water for San Francisco.

title: Arafat Returns to Tunis
description: The Palestine Liberation Organization leader, Yasir Arafat, returned to his Tunis headquarters today after visits to Iraq, Kuwait and Yemen. The Palestinian press afency Wafa said Mr. Arafat met with P.L.O. officials in Yemen on Friday night to discuss events in Lebanon. There was no immediate word on the P.L.O. chief's next moves.

title: IRAN: FIVE YEARS OF FANATICISM
description: Terence Smith, a former foreign correspondent and chief White House correspondent for The New York Times, is editor of the Washington Talk page. By Terence Smith HEIR TICKET TO PARADISE IS the blood-red headband and the small metal key that they wear into battle. ''Sar Allah,'' (''Warriors of God''), some of the headbands read in Farsi script, identifying the wearers as divinely designated martyrs who will use their keys to go directly to heaven if killed in the holy war against Iraq declared by their leader, the Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomei ni. The headbands and the keys are worn by young boys, aged 12 to 17, who are recruited by local clergy or simply rounded up in the villages of Iran, given an intensive indoctrination in the Shiite tradition of martyrdom, and then sent weaponless into battle against Iraqi armor. Often bound together in groups of 20 by ropes to prevent the fainthearted from deserting, they hurl themselves on barbed wire or march into Iraqi mine fields in the face of withering machine-gun fire to clear the way for Iranian tanks. Across the back of their khaki-colored shirts is stenciled the slogan: ''I have the special permission of the Imam to enter heaven.''

title:

VERY Jan. 25 for nearly 200 years, Robert Burns's birthday has been celebrated as a holiday almost anywhere a pair of Scotsman can get together to hoist a glass of whisky. A dearth of Scots notwithstanding, the celebrating of Burns has also become a gala event in the People's Republic of China, where the poet has been taken on as a patron saint of proletarianism.

title: FOR LANDFORD WILSON, DRAMA BEGINS AT THE CROSSROADS
description: L anford Wilson has long specialized in what, at the risk of making his work sound more commonplace than it is, one might call the Crossroads Play. When we meet his characters, they usually seem to be grinding to a halt beneath a signpost pointing backward at terrain they have found pleasant enough at first but pretty depressing in its later stages. It is clearly time to take some new turning. So they stop and ruminate, unpacking the life-luggage they've accumulated during the journey and holding it up for our inspection. How much, if any, should they take forward with them? And which way, if any, is forward?

There is also the possibility of running into them in the lobby of a hotel. Following is a sampling of some favorite haunts abroad. Prices are approximate and subject to currency fluctuations. title: VARIOUS SOUNDS OF BLACK HISTORY

Later that name changed to Black History, and the celebratory period was extended to include the entire month of February, encompassing as it does the birth dates of our country's first President and our 16th, the Great Emancipator.

Art Resnick, coach of the Scarsdale High School girls' soccer team is the mastermind behind a soccer dynasty that he has built from scratch.

Names can be added to the list by card at either shop, or by telephone, for notice of seasonal sales. Men's, women's and children's clothing and equipment are carried at both shops, for both winter and summer wear.

title: Deer Can Be Dangerous, Too
description: Mr. Blumenthal's commentary about deer (Jan. 22) brings mixed feelings. As a trained biologist, I do appreciate their grace and beauty. I also know of their stupidity and danger to themselves and to others. In deep winter they will ''yard up'' to eat everything within reach. Rather than move on, they will starve or fall prey to household dogs in their weakened condition.

The employees also get a paid six-week sabbatical every four years, yearly stock options and other inducements to feel part of the venture.

title: NOTE WORTHY TRICKS FOR DISCARDING

The rationale is that such discards tend to make life easy for the declarer, but this is not always true. Suppose that in the end-game the declarer has to guess a vital queen in this type of position: NORTH D K 10 4 3 SOUTH D A J 5 2

title: Censorship And Selection
description: In his article ''Yes, That's Censorship'' (Opinion Page, Jan. 15), Richard Lettis distinguishes between removing books from school libraries and selecting them, claiming that ''when a teacher or librarian picks a book from among the countless texts available, he or she is not engaged in the act of censorship, but simply of selection.'' Not so simply.

title: BEATING THE DRUMSTIC
description: T IS UNDENIABLY true that, if you work professionally in the food field, you almost inevitably wind up with a trend or two. One ''trend'' that we have followed recently is stuffed boneless chicken - in one form or another. It all began when we invited four well-known chefs from France into the kitchen, and they prepared stuffed boneless chicken legs and thighs, both of which may seem basic and boring to the home cook. As prepared by those chefs, however, they become sublime. After pursuing this, we progressed to stuffed boneless chicken breasts and, more recently, to the stuffing and deep frying of drumsticks. We can assure you that the end result is a far-from-pedestrian exercise in eating. And we have discovered that the kinds of fillings to be used in stuffing those drumsticks or chicken legs are endless. The ones that we used most successfully were with sausage, with chopped chicken livers and with chopped chicken and mushrooms. The preparation of the chicken legs, which is to say the boning, is simplicity itself. You simply scrape around the bone, top to bottom, and the meat loosens easily. When the bone is chopped away (you leave a small portion of the base), you are left with a cavity to be filled according to whim.

title: Gamblers Lose $2.8 Billion

description: Montreal often seems a city made for spring. The mind easily wanders ahead to the flowers that blossom on Mont Royal, to the sidewalk cafes on Rue St. Denis, to the smiles of some of most stylish men and women on this continent. The winters - featuring perhaps more snow than any other major metropolis in the world as well as subzero temperatures and treacherously slippery streets - thus tend to be viewed as simply a necessary passage to May.

title: MICHAEL ALFORD ENGAGED TO WED SARAH KATE BOTT
description: Announcement has been made by Harry F. Bott of New Providence, N.J., of the engagement of his daughter, Sarah Kate Bott, to Michael Andrew Alford, a son of Mrs. Ronald Putnam of Round Lake, N.Y. A June wedding is planned. The future bride, the daughter also of the late Mary Campbell Bott, is a senior at the Rochester Institute of Technology, of which her fiance is a graduate. Her father, who is retired, was a vice president of the United States Fire Insurance Company in Morristown, N.J. Her mother was a chemist at Bell Laboratories in Murray Hill, N.J.

title: TENOR, CELLIST, VIOLINIST AND PIANIST AMONG PERFORMERS IN RECITALS
description: Having spent more than two years singing the role of Don Jose in Peter Brook's ''Tragedie de Carmen,'' now playing at the Vivian Beaumont, the tenor Howard Hensel, who made his recital debut at Merkin Hall last Sunday night, had all the poise and dramatic acumen one might want from a singer of lieder and art songs. For each selection, Mr. Hensel seemed to take on a role, to change his pose and character, so that even songs within the same cycle had their own distinct voices.

title: Pitcher Gets Pact
description: One of LaRussa's relief pitchers, Salome Barojas , became the seventh and last Chicago player to reach terms with the club on a new contract and thereby head off an arbitration hearing. Barojas, who had a 3-3 record with 12 saves and a 2.47 earned-run average in 87 innings last season, signed a one-year contract. . . . Wade Boggs , whose .361 average led the American League in batting last year, has agreed to a one-year contract with the Boston Red Sox and will sign it Wednesday.

title: 100 LEBANESE RETURN HOME, TO DESPAIR
description: As foreigners were evacuated from Lebanon today because of fighting, a handful of Lebanese returned to their blighted land on boats that provide the only link with the outside world.

title: 2,652 Dogs to Seek Best in Westminster
description: For the next few days dog fanciers will not be looking toward Sarajevo and the Olympic Winter Games but will rather direct their attention to America's biggest dog showcase - Madison Square Garden.

title: CONSUMER RATES
WHEN A PLANE'S BUT A STEP AWAY
description: MANY of today's corporate executives spend so much of their time on the job traveling that when it comes time for their corporations to expand or relocate, easy access to an airport becomes a prime consideration.

title: SCIENTIST'S HOLIDAY LEADS TO NEW DRUG
description: EAST HANOVER ASCIENTIST'S work is never done. Even on vacation, many dig up soil, hoping that routine screening back in the laboratory will find something extraordinary.

title: India Hangs Kashmiri For Slaying Banker
description: A terrorist leader from Kashmir who preached secession from India was executed today. Kashmiri terrorists who seized and killed an Indian diplomat in Britain last Sunday had demanded his release.

title: BRITISH LABOR PARTY CHIEF VISITS BRONX
description: Pausing in the faint drizzle on the steps of the Fort Apache Youth Center in the South Bronx yesterday, Neil Kinnock, the leader of Britain's opposition Labor Party, looked up and down the street.

description: T HE black pine trees that rise over the Greenwich Country Day School campus were hung with low fog last weekend. Dun playing fields were dotted with icy puddles and melting snow banks.

title: Linda Harris to Wed Mark D. Lewis in September
description: Mr. and Mrs. Harvey H. Harris of Manhasset, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter Linda Hope Harris to Mark David Lewis, the son of Mary Jane Lewis of Randolph, N.J., and Richard Lewis of Lake Worth, Fla.

title: 'FREEZE' MOVEMENT SEEKS POLITICAL VOICE
description: PISCATAWAY N EW JERSEY'S nuclear- freeze movement has established a political action committee that will try to translate statewide support for such a freeze into clout in this year's Presidential and Congressional elections.

title: Balance Needed In Mental Care
description: Recent letters and articles have done an excellent job of calling attention to the problems of Connecticut's mental health system. The Connecticut Hospital Association has filed suit against the Department of Mental Health to force the department to accept all referred mentally ill patients. Food bank and emergency shelter proponents cite statistics showing that 30 to 40 percent of street people using these facilities have a prior history of institutionalization for mental illness.

title: CANADA (3-0) HANDS FINLAND FIRST LOSS
description: Craig Redmond scored on a 40-foot slap shot to break a 2-2 tie in the third period today as the Canadian Olympic hockey team beat Finland, 4-2. Canada improved its record to 3-0. Finland fell to 2-1.

title: JACKSON'S 'RAINBOW' MAY LACK SOME OF SPECTRUM
description: In many ways the organization of the Rev. Jesse Jackson is still racing to catch up with his campaign promise to build a ''rainbow coalition'' to support his candidacy for the Democratic Presidential nomination.

title: TRANSCRIPTIONS GET THEIR DUE ON DISK
description: Paul Turok writes frequently about recorded music.

title: IN THE SHADOW OF THE PYRENEES
description: In the Shadow of the Pyrenees Close to the Mediterranean, between Narbonne and Perpignan in France, there runs a range of limestone mountains called the Corbi eres. For many centuries, these outcroppings, paralleling the Pyrenees, formed a border between Toulouse and the Kingdom of Aragon - a landscape studded with castles perched on pinnacles and of rich, verdant valleys where vineyards flourish.

title: DEATH DOGGED HER FOOTSTEPS

title: M MWed In the Spring
description: Mr. and Mrs. William Sanford Miller of Bedford, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter Charlotte Baker Miller to Michael Jordon McCarthy of New York, a son of Mr. and Mrs. William Jordon McCarthy of Baltimore. The wedding is to be May 12.

title: INTERIOR SECRETARY FAVORS SAVING L.I. BASE AS PARK
description: The Secretary of the Interior, William P. Clark, has entered a dispute over a tract of Federal land at Montauk Point, L.I., saying he believes the site should not be sold for commercial development.

title: A DEPARTMENT STORE FOR EYEGLASSES
description: Manhattan Eyeland, promoted by its owners as New York's only eyewear department store, has opened in 20,000 square feet of commercial space at 240 East 59th Street, just off Second Avenue. The boutique-styled store is easily six times the size of the average storefront eyewear shop.

title: No Headline

title: THEY'RE CLOSING POWER MEMORIAL BASKETBALL BOOK
description: By 8 o'clock Friday evening, more than 1,000 fans, many of them teen- age boys and their girlfriends, had settled into the Power Memorial gymnasium at West 61st Street to watch the undefeated Panthers host All Hallows in the regular-season finale.

title: Judith Anne Donahue Plans to Marry B. E. Lafranchi, an Account Executive
description: Mr. and Mrs. Donald Jordan Donahue of Greenwich, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter Judith Anne Donahue to Bruce Edward Lafranchi, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Edward A. Lafranchi of Livermore, Calif.

title: Headliners; Goodbye to City Hall
description: In part because a deputy mayor's job is a holding action at best, Nathan Leventhal announced last week he was letting go. Mr. Leventhal said he would resign as Mayor Koch's chief aide to become president of the Lincoln Center for the Performing Arts next month. After 11 years in New York City government - he also worked in the administration of John V. Lindsay - Mr. Leventhal said his job was frustrating for a person who liked to complete one task and move on to the next one.

title: LESSENING THE EFECT
description: A MONG the preventive measures mentioned by experts for minimizing exposure to airborne pollutants and maximizing the body's defenses against them are the following: Ventilation - Some scientists warn of the ''synergistic effect'' of exposure to many pollutants at once, including carbon dioxide, carbon monoxide and dust particles. They recommend simply opening a window slightly to assure an exchange of air. Most desirable is cross-ventilation to create an airflow through a room or working space, or the use of fans.

title: A HYBRID CONVERSION
description: An 82-year-old commercial building on Fifth Avenue at 14th Street is being converted into what might be called a hybrid office condominium. Space will be offered on both a sale and a lease basis.

title:
THE LIVELY ARTS;
'DISCOVERING' AN ARTIST AT 96
description: ''INEVER understood why I lived so long. Now I know why.'' Peter Bela Mayer is 96 years old and has been painting for 75 of those years. But although his landscapes figured prominently in major exhibitions before World War I and in the 1920's and 30's at the National Academy of Design, the Pennsylvania Academy of Fine Arts, the Art Institute of Chicago, the Corcoran Gallery of Art in Washington and even the 1924 International Exhibition of Contemporary Art in Venice over his long (and seemingly secret) career, the Port Washington artist had never been the subject of a monographic one-man exhibition.

title: SCHOOL SYSTEM IN JERSEY IS ADOPTING A DRESS CODE
description: A pair of short pants, of all things, has led the school district here to adopt a dress code for the entire system.

title: Vatican and Polish Officials Meet on Exchanging Envoys
description: Archbishop Luigi Poggi, the Vatican diplomat who handles contacts with the Polish Government, met Friday with Foreign Minister Stefan Olszowski to dicuss the possible exchange of ambassadors. The Vatican's last ambassador to Poland left during the German invasion in 1939.

title: ART ; MALCOLM MORELY, A STUDY IN EXTREMES
description: T O make no bones about it, Malcolm Morely is an exceedingly difficult artist to discuss. It doesn't help, either, that his exhibition in the county, at Galasso Fine Arts Leasing in Ossining (191 Main Street), is small, slight and confined to works of the 1970's.

title: Haggling in Peru
description: To The Editor: My daughter and I recently had the opportunity to tour Peru with a charter group. Peru is a developing country and is having obvious difficulties changing from an agricultural to an urban society.

description: T HE Oceanic Society causes little debate in Stamford since many people mostly know the nonprofit organization for its public cruises on Long Island Sound to study crabs and oysters or for its educational films and lectures in local schools or at the Rotary Club.

description: Norway, which had yielded 26 goals in its first 2 hockey games, played a 3-3 tie with the United States today that eliminated the defending gold medalists from the medal round of the XIV Olympic Winter Games.

description: To the Editor:

title: SUIT SEEKS TO END REVISIONS OF THE CONGRESSIONAL RECORD
description: Three Republican members of the House have filed a suit to halt the practice of making long additions to the Congressional Record.

description: Whoever takes the place of Yuri V. Andropov as leader of the Soviet Union will face a host of problems that he might be called upon to address immediately.

title: 'TALLEY'S FOLLY,' A STAGE VALENTINE
description: -winning romance, ''Talley's Folly,'' is the February presentation of the Theater in the Park's 10th anniversary season. It is a ''valentine,'' its protagonist declares, not only for his intended, but for the audience as well.

title: ECONOMIC WOES TIED TO ABUSE OF RESOURCES
description: The global economic stagnation of the early 1980's is in large part a consequence of the extensive depletion and misallocation of natural resources, according to a study released here today.

title: SABELE FOSTER PLANS TO WED
description: Mr. and Mrs. Esty Foster of New York and St. Huberts, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter Sabele Foster to Richard E. Gray of New York and Litchfield, Conn., a son of Robert Gray of Philadelphia and the late Mrs. Gray. A June wedding is planned.

title: CAN EVEN MODEST HOPES BE FULFILLED
description: Not too long ago, Transit Authority officials were saying that at least the city's bus fleet was in working order. Since more than half of the vehicles were less than five years old, it seemed likely things would stay that way. So David L. Gunn, who took office as president of the Transit Authority Feb. 1, must have felt bedeviled when on Feb. 2 his fleet of 851 Grumman Flxible's was found to have yet another set of serious flaws. It hardly got better on Feb. 3 when a Grumman caught fire on 57th Street near Fifth Avenue just after its passengers were evacuated.

title: HOUSE'S FATE STIRS HUNTINGTON
description: B USINESS and residential interests will square off in Huntington this week; the battlefield is a 110-year-old residence in the village area of the town.

description: To the Editor: In reference to the Q&A inquiry (Travel, Jan. 15.) about apartment rentals in Israel, I would like to share our experience with your readers.

description: Barry Laine writes frequently about the performing arts.

description: Helen Dudar is a freelance writer and critic. ANY FOUR WOMEN COULD ROB THE BANK OF ITALY.

title: A CONSERVATORY TURNS TO PRODUCING
description: T wo innovative organizations - the Peabody Institute of The Johns Hopkins University and Sine Qua Non Records - have joined forces to produce recordings emanating from the conservatory's new state-of-the-art recording studio. The Peabody, which last year inaugurated a five-year course leading to the degree of bachelor of music in recording arts and sciences, has now turned its attention to producing commercial recordings - initially by faculty members - that will be manufactured and distributed by Sine Qua Non, which has successfully marketed high-quality audiophile cassettes on a mass-market basis, in addition to its other recording activities.

title: Devils Lose, 3-2, In Basement Battle
description: Doug Shedden's goal late in the second period carried the Pittsburgh Penguins to a 3-2 victory over the New Jersey Devils tonight in a game between the teams with the worst records in the National Hockey League.

title: CITY BALLET: STRAVINSKY 'CONCERTO FOR SOLO PIANOS'
description: There was a wonderfully tart astringency to Peter Martins's ''Calcium Light Night'' that has been absent from his later ballets. But it shines through the pas de deux in ''Concerto for Two Solo Pianos'' and made that recent Stravinsky ballet a highlight of the New York City Ballet's program on Friday at the New York State Theater.

title: ARIZONA TOADS FOCUS OF STUDY
description: Arizona Toads Focus of Study In the Chiricahua Mountains of Arizona, renowned for the diversity of their birds and wildlife, there lives a creature called the spadefoot toad. Capable of spending most of its life burrowed in desert soil from which it emerges only at the first summer's rain each year to breed, it is a natural object of scientific curiosity.

title: DEAN WITTER: CASHING IN ON THE RETAIL CONNECTION
description: THE Dean Witter Reynolds desk,

title: TIME AND AGAIN, IT'S A MATTER OF THE HEART
description: T HERE is something particularly hopeful about a ''love'' day, at any time of year. What makes Valentine's Day so perfect is its timing. Falling as it does between the excitement of New Year's and the thrill of the first crocus blossom, it brightens the winter doldrums of the long stretch between the two. For one brief moment in February, the spirit soars.

title: BOLSHOI: RUSSIAN CLASSIC
description: The Bolshoi Theater is the Soviet Union's premier opera and ballet house, home to the finest singers and dancers of the Soviet Union and to some of its most lavish productions. It dates back to a troupe founded on March 28, 1776, that performed in the home of Count R. I. Vorontsov. Its first home, acquired in 1780, burned down in 1805. A new one built in 1825 burned down in 1853, and the current grand theater, then known as the Petrovsky Theater, was built in 1855-56 in the neo-classical style popular at the time, with one of the deepest stages in Europe and a glittering interior of gilt and red velvet. The interior, with six levels of seats, 2,150 in all, and a grand chandelier, was impeccably restored for the bicentennial in 1976 and forms a strikingly elegant backdrop to the lavish productions.

title: TAKING THE PLUNGE
description: In Finland, a land of 4 million people and

title: TSONGAS DECISION SPURS 'WILD RACE'
description: A scramble for the Senate seat being vacated by Paul E. Tsongas has turned into the most widely contested election here in recent years, pitting several liberal Democrats against one another and enticing Elliot L. Richardson, a Republican, back to his home state.

title: THE REGION
description: The Governor's Budget Magic

title: SINGAPORE IS URGING THE EDUCATED TO MULTIPLY
description: Singapore is working on a new family planning program that is based on the theory that children born to scholars have a better chance of growing up to be productive citizens.

title: THE BLACK WOMAN'S STORY
description: I was disappointed, even annoyed at times, by the article on Alice Walker. I found that I was reading a great deal about David Bradley.

description: Legislation that would permit the conviction of a child molester solely on the testimony of the victim received the support of two key legislators this week.

title: Heartwarming Return
description: Normand Leveille, the Boston Bruin forward who suffered a paralyzing cerebral hemorrhage during a game in Vancouver, British Columbia, 16 months ago, made his first visit to the Boston Garden yesterday since having been stricken. Walking with a cane and wearing his old jersey, No. 19, Leveille, who has made remarkable progress in his recovery, appeared in the runway before the Bruin game against the Edmonton Oilers.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''The machine is back, and it's in great shape. That was a dream of a touchdown, really a fine landing.'' - Lieut. Gen. James A. Abrahamson, the space agency's shuttle chief. (1:4.)

title: Miss Feinerman Engaged to Wed
description: Mr. and Mrs. Judah Feinerman of Far Rockaway, Queens, have announced the engagement of their daughter Sharon Riba Feinerman to Rabbi Raphael Z. Schwartz, a son of Rabbi and Mrs. Maurice Schwartz of Salisbury, Md. The wedding is planned for August.

title: Hearns Retains His Title
description: Thomas Hearns successfully defended his World Boxing Council super welterweight title tonight, pounding out a unanimous 12-round decision over Luigi Minchillo of Italy. Minchillo, 28 years old, was able to get inside and effectively counter the champion's 5 1/2-inch reach advantage in the early going, but from the sixth round on Hearns - who was cut over the right eye in the second round - was able to keep his ever-pressing opponent from doing any damage.

title: politics ; COMPLAINTS ON JUDGES DETAILED BY PANEL
description: TRENTON ASPECIAL committee, created by law in 1974 to handle the ticklish job of maintaining public confidence in the state's judiciary by investigating complaints against judges, has released its annual report, which also includes a review of the last decade. For the first time, it has recommended in a presentment the removal of a Superior Court judge.

title: FIRST SHUTTLE LANDING AT LAUNCHING BASE IS PERFECT
description: The space shuttle Challenger, ending an eight-day mission marked by disappointing failures and dazzling achievements, glided to a perfect landing here today. It was the first time a shuttle had landed at its launching base.

title: CRITICS' CHOICES
description: David Bowie's popularity finally caught up with his influence last year. In a succession of public images through the 1970's, the British singer showed a generation of rock performers how to be self-consciously theatrical and soulful at the same time.

title: CRITICS' CHOICES
description: Together again! Twyla Tharp and Mikhail Baryshnikov danced together in 1976 and although the vehicle wasn't one of Miss Tharp's hits, the memory remains of a pair of witty dancers with a special affinity for each other. Miss Tharp and Mr. Baryshnikov will dance again together Sunday afternoon, ending the Tharp company's immensely popular season at the Brooklyn Academy of Music in a benefit gala in which the two will perform ''Sinatra Suite'' and a reprise of ''Sinatra Songs.''

title: BILL FORSYTH TAKES A LOOK BACK IN LAUGHTER
description: A fter his agent saw a screening of Bill Forsyth's latest film, the man stood up and said, ''Thank God. It's not a comedy.'' Mr. Forsyth agreed. ''It's a very sad film,'' he said, laughing heartily.

title: CHINA IS LOOKING TO BETTER RELATIONs
description: China sent ''deep condolences'' today on the ''unfortunate death'' of Yuri V. Andropov and voiced hope that relations with Moscow would continue to improve.

title: BE READY TO SWITCH WHEN A GAMBIT IIS DECLINED
description: Anyone who prepares to offer a gambit and eagerly anticipates taking the reins in an exciting tactical attack should also be prepared for the quite different type of game that arises if the sacrifice is sidestepped or declined.

title: THE TRUTH ISN'T STRANGER THAN SCIENCE FICTION, JUST SLOWER
description: Two astronauts floated free in space last week before their shuttle touched down in Florida yesterday. They were not tethered. They left the spacecraft and returned to it on their own.

title: STAKES TOO HIGH FOR OLYMPIANS TO REMAIN AMATEURS
description: O RGANIZING high priests of the modern Olympic Games and prominent theorists of amateurism were Baron Pierre de Coubertin (1863-1937) and Avery Brundage (1887-1975). Both men were inspired by a jumble of 19th-century ideas and both held conveniently false ideas about the amateur ideal in classical Greece.

description: The question is not meant as a challenge, only an inquiry into what seems to be a genuine generation gap.

description: SALISBURY

title: SOVIET WINNER AT 18-8 1/4
description: Billy Olson, America's best pole vaulter, called him ''Superman's little kid.''

title: CAN THOSE SKIRTING NATURE BE KEPT IN LINE?
description: When gene-splicing techniques were introduced a decade ago, they sent chills through sections of the scientific community and much of the public. The techniques allow researchers to snip bits of genetic material from one organism and transfer them to another organism to obtain valuable biological products and insights into biological processes.

title: F.T.C. EXPECTED TO APPROVE MERGER OF TEXACO AND GETTY
description: The Government is expected to give approval Monday to Texaco Inc.'s $10.1 billion takeover of the Getty Oil Company, a merger that would be the biggest on record.

title: GLENN DOESN'T BELIEVE IN LEAVING THEM LAUGHING
description: As the Iowa precinct caucuses draw near and Senator John Glenn faces his first real test of 1984, his top campaign officials are recalling one of his first outings in the arena of Presidential politics. It happened last spring, at the Massachusetts State Convention. Many of the other Presidential contenders had applied makeup for the television cameras. Mr. Glenn's staff, telling him he needed a little tone in his face, urged him to use some as well. ''I'm not going to go out and talk to people with makeup on my face,'' he said.

title: Marriage Planned By Laura L. Ellis
description: Dr. F. Henry Ellis Jr. of Brookline, Mass., and Elizabeth Watson Blanchard of Needham, Mass., have announced the engagement of their daughter Laura Lawson Ellis to David Gayley Milliken, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Roger Milliken of Spartanburg, S.C. A September wedding is planned.

title: VOLCKER UNSETTLES THE STOCK MARKET
description: The Federal Reserve and its chairman, Paul A. Volcker, caused quite a stir last week as the board submitted its annual report to Congress and the chairman made his semi-annual appearance on the Hill. Mr. Volcker's message was, in essence, ''cut the deficit before it's too late.'' While the Fed plans to orchestrate continued steady growth for the economy, he warned that it could not be expected to loosen its monetary policy to block a deficit-induced rise in interest rates, which could easily bring on another recession. The chairman added that Congress and the Administration would have to cut up to $125 billion in the next two years to make any substantive progress. As a result of his warnings, the stock market plunged and it appeared that Wall Street suddenly became concerned about the $200 billion annual deficits. So adverse was the reaction that Mr. Volcker took pains on Thursday to note that his comments had been ''a little blown up'' and that markets had overreacted.

title: Christine Flynn To Wed in May
description: Mr. and Mrs. Joseph P. Flynn of Pelham Manor, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter Christine Patrice Flynn to Stephen Merle Dirks, a son of Lee E. Dirks of Bloomfield Hills, Mich., and Barbara N. Dirks of Bethesda, Md. A May wedding is planned.

description: The New York Arrows of the Major Indoor Soccer League have named James McGeough to take over as head coach, replacing Dr. Joe Machnik , who will become vice president of soccer administration. . . . Robert Pickett , resigned as head football coach at the University of Massachusetts, citing personal reasons. . . . Jim Kaat , the 45-year-old pitcher with more than 23 seasons in the major leagues, has been invited to attend the Pittsburgh Pirate training camp as a nonroster player.

description: Dr. Angela Maria Macchiarulo and Dr. Steven Roy Bader plan to be married March 11. The future bride, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Anthony Macchiarulo of Long Island City, Queens, is a third-year pediatric resident at Children's Hospital in Boston. Her fiance, son of Mr. and Mrs. Edwin H. Bader of New York, is a dentist practicing in Burlington, Mass.

title: New Spot for Walton
description: Bill Walton, the San Diego Clipper center, hadn't started a game as a forward since he was a junior in high school and his older brother was the school's starting center. After his brother had been graduated, Walton moved to center and stayed there through his all-America college years at U.C.L.A. and his professional career.

title: LONG ISLAND JOURNAL
description: E DUCATION has become one of the many fields touched by the East End's numerous zoning and development disputes. The Southampton Montessori School, a for- profit institution for 3- to 6-year-olds, has been advised to become nonprofit or risk going out of business.

title: OPERA: LEONIE RYSANEK IN 'TANNHAUSER' AT MET
description: At the end of the second act of ''Tannh"auser'' Friday night at the Metropolitan Opera, the principals trooped onstage in a body, as is the company's custom, to accept applause communally for what had been a particularly rousing contest of wills in the Hall of Song. The ovation, however, exploded into a roar every time Leonie Rysanek appeared from behind the curtain and exploded again every time she made her move to leave the stage.

title: Bronx Subway Repairs Set
description: Track repairs will disrupt subway service in the Bronx starting today and running through Feb. 29, the Transit Authority said. Uptown service on the No. 2 and No. 5 lines will not stop at the 174th Street or East Tremont Avenue stations on weekends between 8 A.M. and 5 P.M., and weekdays between 9 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: MYSTERY OF QUAKES STUDIED IN MOODUS
RECAPTURING THE PAST IN FICTION
description: WHAT is it that provokes us into attempting to write fiction set deep in the past? Fine historians write as well and as episodically as any novelist - Fernand Braudel, Cecil Woodham-Smith, Barbara Tuchman, Shelby Foote. The late critic Nicola Chiaromonte answered for us: ''It is only through fiction and the dimension of the imaginary that we can learn something real about individual experience. Any other approach is bound to be general and abstract.''

title: SECRETS IN THE NASSAU BUDGET?
description: A PPROVED in December 1983, Nassau County's budget for 1984 broke the $1 billion barrier for the first time. The county budget has ballooned from $446.5 million in 1971 to $1.2 billion in 1984, an increase of more than 150 percent in 13 years. With Nassau taxpayers already paying the highest rates in the nation, is this increase justified? County residents will never know the answer as long as budget procedures remain closed to public scrutiny.

title: PROPOSALS ON RENT-STABILIZATION CODE IGNITE A DEBATE

title:
NUMISMATICS;
LINCOLN CENT IS RECORDED-SETTER OR LONGEVITY
description: Of all the tributes paid to Abraham Lincoln, none has been seen more often by his countrymen than the Lincoln cent. On this, the 175th anniversary of President Lincoln's birth, this coin is also marking some important milestones. It has been 75 years since the Lincoln cent made its debut and 25 years since the Lincoln Memorial design was placed on its reverse.

title: Earthquake Rocks Delphi
description: An earthquake struck central Greece today, damaging homes near the ancient shrine of Delphi but causing no injuries, police here said.

title: Mary Jule Steele To Marry in May
description: Announcement has been made of the engagement of Mary Jule Steele, a daughter of William C. Steele of Westfield, N.J., and Mary Schnopp Steele of Colorado Springs, to Michael Guilfoile, the son of Mr. and Mrs. William F. Guilfoile of North Miami, Fla.

description: Lilco Seems At Wit's End On Shoreham

title: COLUMBIA GIVES AN INCENTIVE FOR WORKING IN PUBLIC SECTOR
description: Columbia Law School, concerned that a high percentage of its graduates take lucrative positions with law firms and corporations instead of working in the public sector, has begun a program to encourage careers in government and public-interest law offices.

title: ISRAELI BUILDING NEW SUBURBIA ON WEST BANK
description: -Occupied West Bank - Maaleh Adumim appears suddenly after a bend in the Jerusalem-Jericho road, a giant futuristic beehive of white apartment houses set in close-packed tiers against the tawny hills of the Judean Desert.

title: A CASE STUDY IN BRILLIANT RESTORATION
description: T o restore or not to restore, that is the question with which museums and collectors of period art works frequently wrestle. The answers are most often based on a variety of considerations, involving the rarity and worth of the object in question, the nature of the damages and whether the piece will deteriorate further, with or without repairs.

title:
ART ;
CELEBRATING AN EXPANSION
description: T O supplement its regular gallery space at 16 Village Square in Glen Cove, the Hempstead Harbor Artists Association is now operating a satellite gallery around the corner in the Town Development Office's Community Room. To celebrate its expansion and inaugurate its second full season of exhibitions, the group has mounted a pair of invitational shows featuring a total of five painters and one sculptor.

title: STRICTER CONTROLS ON WATER PURITY IN PINE BARRENS MEET OPPOSITION
description: A T least two towns, Riverhead and Brookhaven, business groups, developers and others are arrayed against the Suffolk County Department of Health Services and the Board of Health, which is seeking broad powers to limit new or expanded industry on 260,000 acres of pine barrens and other water recharge areas.

title: Brooke Alwyn Is Betrothed
description: Mr. and Mrs. Macrae Sykes of Delray Beach, Fla., and East Hampton, L.I., have announced the engagement of Mrs. Sykes's daughter Martha Brooke Alwyn to David Walker Laughlin, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Alexander Mellon Laughlin of New York and East Hampton. The wedding is planned for June.

title: A MERGER TO SAVE MONEY IS OPPOSED
description: A PLAN by the State Department of Motor Vehicles to close six offices in northeast, southeast and southwest Connecticut, and to open three centrally situated offices that would serve these areas, is meeting some stiff opposition.

DINING OUT;
WHERE GOULASH REIGNS SUPREME

description: MAYOR

title: About Men: Dad
description: Andrew Malcolm's essay, ''Dad'' (About Men, Jan. 8) was the most honest and moving tribute I have ever read.

title: DANCE: LOUIS TROUPE PERFORMS FOUR WORKS
description: The Murray Louis Dance Company is so known for its darting mercurial style that its second bill of the season, seen Friday night at the City Center, seemed uncharacteristically even- keeled.

title: CARRUTHERS DUO OFF TO FINE START
description: Kitty Carruthers was operating on youthful energy.

title: PORTUGAL'S SAVORY CATAPLANA
description: Along Portugal's Algarve coast is found a dish that may have been inspired by Arab alchemists centuries ago striving to turn base metals into gold. The dish, like the special cooking vessel used to prepare it, is called cataplana. It is a stew of clams, pork, vegetables and spices steamed in a handmade, airtight copper pot that resembles a football cut in half but hinged on one side. The cataplana thus appears to be the ancestor of the pressure cooker.

title: WITHOUT ANDROPOV
description: MOSCOW W HENEVER a Politburo member dies and the Grand Hall of Columns is draped in mourning for the lying in state, older Russians are invariably reminded of the traumatic, violent and awesome days after the death of Stalin 31 years ago.

title: Miss Brown Is Affianced
description: Mr. and Mrs. Thomas B. Hynson Brown of New York have announced the engagement of their daughter, Amanda Tilghman Brown, to Burton Jonathan Megargel, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Welles F. Megargel of Bronxville, N.Y., and Lake Ariel, Pa. The wedding is to be in May.

title: CREATING THE BEER TO EDUCATE TASTE
description: S OME men live to improve the breed. Steven Rosenthal hopes to improve the brew. Mr. Rosenthal, who lives in East Hills, is the president of Beer Boys Industries of Garden City - a corporation involved in wholesale and retail distribution of beer and soda, in wholesale distribution of cigarettes and candy and in tax-stamping cigarettes as an agent for the State of New York.

title: Official Hairdresser
description: The list of ''official'' things at the Winter Olympics has been joined by an official hairdresser. Ruffles, a Beverly Hills (Calif.) company, has received the designation from the local Olympic organizing committee.

BUSINESS FORUM;
A VITAL PIPELINE FOR SMALL BANKS...

title: GREAT VOICES OF THE PAST STAKE THEIR CLAIM TO FRESH ATTENTION
description: ''L et us hear no more of a golden age of bel canto,'' George Bernard Shaw wrote in 1950. ''We sing much better than our grandparents.'' Many, finding no reason to investigate recordings by the great singers of the past, would echo Shaw's words today. In the past year, it has been possible to attend New York performances by such splendid artists as Joan Sutherland, Alfredo Kraus, Marilyn Horne, Montserrat Caballe, Placido Domingo and Kathleen Battle, among others. Any era that can produce such a roster can hardly be considered vocally deficient. In addition, many music lovers simply don't want to put up with the antiquated sound of early recordings. After all, why bother with a sizzling, scratchy Caruso 78 when you can hear Pavarotti in state-of-the-art digital stereo sound?

title: No Headline
description: Conference to Address Black Families in May

title: THE INTRICATE MANEUVERING TO CASH IN ON THE DEFICIT
description: Asked last week about President Reagan's proposal that Congress work with the White House to make a $100 billion ''down payment'' on the Federal deficit, Speaker Thomas P. O'Neill Jr. answered: ''Do I think it's political? Yeah, I believe it's political.'' Capitol Hill's leading Democrat was commenting on Republican attitudes toward deficit reduction. But his statement was an apt summary of the approach of both parties. Almost everybody is worrying about politics first and policy second.

title: CUBAN ALIENS, BUT NOT HAITIANS, WILL BE OFFERED RESIDENCY STATUS
description: The Reagan Administration is planning to offer legal status and citizenship opportunities to more than 100,000 Cubans who came to the United States by sea in 1980 from the Cuban port of Mariel.

title: STATE TO STUDY NOISE LEVELS IN I-95 COMMUNITIES
description: PORT CHESTER T HE trucks and cars passing Anthony Zaccagnino's Cape Cod-style home alongside the New England Thruway make such a din that it is difficult to carry on a conversation outside.

title: ROAD TO AN ISLAND STIRS DEBATE
description: T HE conflict between claimed property rights and ecological imperatives has been fought in many theaters on the East End. This time the battlefield is a tombolo.

title: JUDGE CONSIDERS IN FATAL FILM CRASH
description: A preliminary hearing to determine if the director of the movie ''Twilight Zone'' and four members of his crew should stand trial on charges of involuntary manslaughter has ended in Los Angeles Municipal Court.

title: GIFTS TO THE NEEDIEST SURPASS $2.5 MILLION FOR THE FIRST TIME
description: Contributions to The 1983-84 New York Times Neediest Cases Fund have reached a total of more than $2.5 million, a level considered a milestone for the fund.

title: BANK CONVERTS TO A STOCK PLAN
description: T HE account holders of the Westchester Federal Savings Bank of New Rochelle have voted to convert the institution from a mutual to a stock-holding form. In so doing, they have created a new bank holding company: the Westchester Financial Services Corporation.

title: Sewer Study: Water District's Views
description: As one of the three Water Commissioners of the South Huntington Water District, I feel it necessary to state the water district's position on the Melville sewer district study (''Sewer Plan Studied for Melville Industrial Strip,'' Jan. 8).

title: SHAMIR DECLARES ARMY MAY ACT ON ITS OWN TO POLICE BORDER AREA
description: While the evacuation of foreigners in Beirut continued, efforts to end the effective siege of West Beirut made no apparent progress. Page 12.

title: 7 Foreigners Seized By Sudanese Rebels
description: Rebels raided a French-operated construction camp in the south and apparently took seven foreign workers with them when they were driven off by soldiers, the official Sudanese press agency said today.

title: A WEDDING OF ART AND INDUSTRY
description: MILLVILLE C ULLETS, shards of broken glass left by industrial glass- making, normally are swept up and tossed in the dumpster.

title: ACCOUNTANTS UPDATING IMAGE
description: PATERSON R EVOLUTIONARY changes in businesses ranging from telecommunications to banking are plunging the accounting firms that serve them into a headlong competition for accounts.

title: REAGAN'S 'BLACKBOARD JUNGLE' BROADSIDE
description: President Reagan returned last week to his contention that American schools are plagued with crime and violence and unruly behavior. In a speech to the National Association of Secondary School Principals, meeting in Las Vegas, he called for the restoration of ''good old-fashioned discipline.''

title: PARIS: THE IRANIAN EXILES
description: Richard Z. Chesnoff, who reported from Teheran while an editor of Newsweek, writes from Paris and New York. By Richard Z. Chesnoff

title: SPECIAL VALENTINE TO AN AILING MOTHER
description: T HIS Valentine's Day, my mother will undergo breast surgery. She just called to let me know. From her voice, carefully poised, from her words, slowly uttered, I guessed she was scared. With my inner eyes, I see her now, sitting at her desk in the home of my childhood, on the other side of the ocean, in faraway Paris. She has put down the receiver. She is staring into space, feeling her right breast with nervous fingers. Her shoulders are hunched.

title: Sudden Blizzard Traps Colorado Motorists
description: A blizzard swept into the eastern plains of Colorado so quickly today that dozens of motorists were stranded on highways blocked by snowdrifts and the National Guard was alerted.

title: Dr. Hunter Is Married To Dr. R. A. Henseler
description: Dr. Nancy Joy Hunter, a pathologist, and Dr. R. Alan Henseler, a surgeon, both at Morristown (N.J.) Memorial Hospital, were married yesterday. The Rev. W. James White performed the ceremony at the United Methodist Church in Morristown.

title: CHANGE U.N. CHARTER, SAYS ROMULO, A SIGNER
description: Carlos P. Romulo, the last living signer of the 1945 United Nations Charter, says weaknesses in the document have made it impossible for the organization ''to carry out the purposes for which we intended it.''

title: Alternative Solutions In Mental Health
description: Dr. Audrey M. Worrell, State Commissioner of Mental Health, described the difficulties her department has in admitting patients to state institutions (Letter to the Connecticut Editor, Jan. 8). She expresses her inability to reconcile her avowed goal of emptying the state hospitals with the traditional and moral obligation of the state to care for the mentally ill.

title: Lincoln's Way
description: To the Editor:

title: Kissinger Anticipates Soviet Peace Offensive
description: Henry A. Kissinger said today that he expected ''a peace offensive'' by the Soviet Union as a result of the death of Yuri V. Andropov.

title: PHILOSOPHICAL TALE OF GORE
description: Patricia Craig is co-author of ''The Lady Investigates: Women Detectives in Fiction.'' MYSTERIES OF WINTERTHURN

title: SHAPING A SEARS FINANCIAL EMPIRE
description: AT his desk recently in Chicago's Sears Tower, Edward R. Telling, architect and overseer of Sears, Roebuck's $800 million venture into financial services, pondered the progress of the two-year-old gamble. ''Well, on a scale of 10, not to be flip about it, I've got us at about 10 1/2,'' he said with a smile. ''We are only two years into it but we are ahead of where I thought we would be in five years.''

title: 75,000 GATHER TO SEE LANDING
description: An estimated 75,000 spectators lining highways and riverbanks cheered and blew automobile horns today as the Challenger space shuttle came into view and coasted to earth.

title: ON A WING AND A COMPUTER
description: Andrew H. Malcolm is the chief of the Chicago bureau of The New York Times. By Andrew H. Malcolm T WAS 1:00 A.M. AND BLACK IN THE OTHER world outside. The two men sat in their safety harnesses softly speaking in codes by the eerie green light of computer- controlled dials. At times, a voice from outside read numbers and directions and speeds into their ears, but nothing happened until the final approval came. Allen Amsbaugh answered, ''American 98 Heavy, rolling.'' He looked at Tom Seiger on his right and nodded. Each put one hand on the beige metal knuckles of the throttles between them. They pushed ahead.

title: DISSIDENT PUTS POLAND ON STAGE
description: ''E verything here is in the open,'' a Polish Government official assures a filmmaker in Janusz Glowacki's play ''Cinders.'' ''We have nothing to hide.'' In the absurd and upside- down world of Mr. Glowacki's plays - and of Poland itself, the playwright says - the official means quite the opposite. Nothing is apparent, everything is obscure. The surface of ''Cinders'' concerns a performance of ''Cinderella'' by the girls in a reform school; the subtext is a tale of doubletalk, informers and how a regime breaks the will of its critics.

title: Votes in Congress; Last Week's Tally in Key Eastern States
description: Senate

title: Indian Point 2 Shuts Down
description: Seepage from a radioactive portion of the Indian Point 2 nuclear power plant caused it to shut down yesterday afternoon, less than a day after a 28-hour shutdown attributed to malfunctioning instruments. The latest halt could last as long as several weeks, according to officials of the Consolidated Edison Company, which operates the plant.

title: GENEVA PARLEY AGREES ON A RADIO PLAN
description: Representatives of 120 nations meeting here agreed today to set up a new system for allocating the world's overcrowded high-frequency radio waves among broadcasting stations.

title: Phyllis Fletcher Betrothed
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Irving Fletcher of New York of the engagement of their daughter Phyllis Gail Fletcher to Harvey Roberts, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Samuel Roberts of Forest Hills, Queens. A fall wedding is planned. Miss Fletcher is the vice president of Medical Projects Inc. Her fiance is vice president of Roberts Consultants Company, a New York construction- engineering concern headed by his father.

title: HELL MOUNTAIN FOR PEOPLE IS HEAVEN FOR VULTURES
description: A LL'S WELL with the vultures of Hell Mountain, very well indeed. Its flock of turkey vultures, one of the largest in New Jersey, continues to grow, and as the new year began no fewer than nine black vultures also could be seen circling over Mountainville, a picturesque village in northern Hunterdon County.

title: HOW TO ADJUST OR REPLACE TROUBLESOME WINDOW SHADES
description: M OST window shade problems are caused by improper tension in the spring inside the shade roller. If the spring is wound too tight, it sends the shade flying up out of control; if it is wound too loosely, the shade tends to lower by itself, or it refuses to rewind when you try to raise it. As a rule, either of these problems is easy to correct.

title: THE YOUNG PHYSICISTS WHO WOULD BE 'PAWNS'
description: To the Editor:

title: FASHION
description: SOFT SHOULDERS ne of the most appealing styles to surface in evening wear this past season is the ball gown or cocktail dress that bares the shoulders. As these photographs taken at recent galas show, when done properly it is both a becoming fashion for younger women and an attractive look for women 'of a certain age,' forming a dramatic frame for the face.

title: CABARET: FRED BARTON
description: Fred Barton, whose animated, wide-eyed face has been peering over the piano at audiences in Palsson's for the last two years while he provides piano accompaniment to ''Forbidden Broadway,'' is now staying after the show on Thursday nights to do his own solo nightclub act, ''Miss Gulch Lives!''

title: 2 INMATES KILLED AND 5 HURT IN FIGHTS AT L.I. PRISON
description: Two inmates were stabbed to death and five others were injured early yesterday in two separate brawls at the state prison in Brentwood, L.I., state correction officials said.

title: Simple Pleasure Of the President
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: 46-STORY TOWER
description: Foundation work has begun on a blockthrough site between West 52d and 53d Streets for a slender 46-story residential condominium that will feature such hotel-like amenities as concierge, maid and room services.

title: JOAN COE, A RESTAURATEUR, TO BECOME BRIDE IN JUNE
description: Joan Michael Coe, an owner of the Cantina Restaurant in Ketchum, Idaho, and Baird St. Clair Gourlay, an owner of the Paul Kenny Ski Shop in Sun Valley, Idaho, plan to be married in June.

title: RURAL CO-OPS ARE HURT BY NUCLEAR PLANT COSTS
description: Marcus Rust's family had to choose last summer where to buy electricity for its new egg farm.

title: V.A. TO STUDY 30,000 VETERANS WHO ARE TWINS
description: The Government is about to undertake a nationwide search for 30,000 veterans who are twins so it can compare the health of men who served in the Vietnam War with their brothers who did not.

title: STUDY FINDS SEX STEREOTYPES AFFECT VOTERS AT POLLS
description: Sex stereotypes are alive and at work when voters go to the polls, and women as well as men tend to vote for a woman only if she is by far the more qualified candidate, according to a study released today by a polling organization.

title: ENZYME BATTLING HEART ATTACKS
description: A FTER losing a game of racquetball, Alvin Schwartz thought only of immersing his body in the steamy hot water of a sauna. His relaxation was coldly interrupted, however, by a sharp pain coming from the back and moving into the center of his chest, leaving him breathless.

title: DEMOCRATIC RIVALS JAB AT MONDALE IN DEBATE
description: The eight major Democratic Presidential candidates met here today in a debate marked by polite but persistent criticism of Walter F. Mondale, who has a strong lead in the polls in his bid for party's nomination.

title: Higher Education
description: Samuel Johnson could have had Arnold Beichman's article ''Is Higher Education in the Dark Ages?'' (Nov. 6) in mind when he said, ''He who tries to recommend him by select quotations will succeed like the pedant in Hierocles, who, when he offered his house for sale, carried a brick in his pocket as a specimen.''

title: New & Noteworthy
description: THE ARAB-ISRAELI WARS: War and Peace in the Middle East, by Chaim Herzog. (Vintage, $8.95.) Chaim Herzog, now President of Israel, aims to tell the country's ''whole bloody postindependence story'' in ''a volume that anyone who wants to understand what Israel has endured will have to read or refer to,'' J. Robert Moskin noted in his 1982 review. ''The Arab-Israeli Wars'' conveys strong impressions of the dramatic strengthening of Israeli defense forces since 1947 and role of the Soviet Union in the Arab-Israeli conflict. THE LONELY GUY, by Bruce Jay Friedman. (McGraw-Hill, $4.95.) Bruce Jay Friedman tells the lonely they are not alone in ''a funny tract'' couched as a self- help manual that has now spawned a movie. First published in 1978 as ''The Lonely Guy's Book of Life,'' the book struck our reviewer, Herbert Gold, as winsome, true and ''more universal than the title suggests. Some former wives might find, with small translations and a few adjustments for child custody and slipcover skills, that they are really lonely guys too.''

title: IDEAS & TRENDS
description: Use of Drugs On the Decline

title: HEADLINERS
description: Out of the Bubble After 12 years, the days of look-but-don't-touch are over for David and his family. David, who was born with a severe immune deficiency and spent his childhood hospitalized in a germ-free ''bubble,'' stepped into the nonsterile world for the first time last week.

title: Skeleton Found in Chimney
description: A skeleton found in the chimney of a furniture warehouse was apparently that of a would-be-burgler who got stuck, the police said Thursday. A fuel company employee was trying to determine why a 70-foot chimney was clogged at Littlepage's Furniture Warehouse when the police said he found a nearly intact skeleton.

title: WITHDRAW DECENTLY FROM LEBANON
description: We should not be covering up our withdrawal from Lebanon with a new demonstration of our might: The artillery fire of American battleships will not enhance what prospects, if any, remain for the regime of President Amin Gemayel. It will only deplete the political and moral capital that we will need if we are to play an effective role in the next phase of the Lebanese crisis.

title: Margaret Johnson Plans May Wedding
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Robert N. Johnson of New Canaan, Conn., of the engagement of their daughter Margaret Elizabeth Johnson to Daniel Renaldo Bernstein, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Morris Bernstein of New York. A May wedding is planned.

title: CONCERT: ZUCKERMAN AND ST. PAUL ORCHESTRA
description: The St. Paul Chamber Orchestra led by Pinchas Zuckerman began its busy stay in New York Friday night with a Carnegie Hall concert heaped with troubles.

title: OLD CRAFTS ARE BEING REVIVED
description: EVER since the Federal Government began offering generous tax benefits three years ago to developers willing to restore historic buildings authentically, there has been a burst of interest in finding craftsmen who can do the intricate work in accordance with the strict regulations that govern these projects.

title: LEBANON: THE IRANIAN PRESENCE
description: Thomas L. Friedman is The Times's bureau chief in Beirut, Lebanon. By Thomas L. Friedman HE REGIME OF AYATOLlah Khomeini clearly sees in Lebanon a unique mixture of political and human elements that make it an ideal place to begin proving its thesis that the Islamic Revolution can and will be spread to other countries in the Middle East. The Iranians also seem to view Lebanon, with its large contingents of American and Israeli troops, as the natural sequel to their own revolution - the next place where the United States and its allies can be driven out of town.

title: BOOKSTORE SALE STIRS LIBRARY
description: F OR six years, a bookstore with no overhead or paid employees had been turning its profits over to a small public library. Now the library's trustees have sold the bookstore building and book sales have ended, and the action has patrons in Bridgehampton and Sagaponack choosing sides rather than books.

title: A WELCOME NEW STEAKHOUSE
description: T HE massive, windowless gray concrete block structure on Glen Cove Road in Greenvale looks like the keep of a medieval castle, but it is Dar Tiffany, a new steakhouse. Instead of a moat, it is surrounded by a parking lot guarded by valets. It is named for one of the owners.

description: SARAJEVO,Yugoslavia

title: The Pope and Agca
description: To the Editor:

title: To Whom It May Concern
description: Congratulations on your selection as Secretary General of the Soviet Communist Party. Despite our inevitable pretenses in the coming days, we don't know anything about you, and the chances are you don't know much about us. Yet here we are, each other's most formidable problem. May you be calm and wise in handling it.

title: RULES ON ARCADES, 'ADULT' SHOPS ARGUED
description: P ORNOGRAPHY and video games, two seemingly unrelated subjects, have become the center of legal debates in three Connecticut municipalities.

title: SIGNIFICANT PROGRESS ON WATER POLLUTION REPORTED
description: Significant progress has been made in controlling pollution of the nation's waters, but municipal and industrial discharges still violate pollution standards in many areas, the Environmental Protection Agency has reported.

title: Using Leverage
description: To the Editor:

title: WINTER STRAINS BUDGETS FOR SNOTW REMOVAL AND HEATNG OIL
description: T HIS winter's erratic, occasionally bitterly cold weather is exhausting snow removal budgets, increasing the cost of home heating oil and threatening garden plants and shrubs, but so far it has created no discernible health problems for Long Islanders.

title: POOR RECORD ON ARMS
description: McLEAN, Va. - President Reagan has started his re-election campaign with a public-relations attempt to demonstrate that he and his Administration have been serious about controlling nuclear weapons and reducing the risk of nuclear war. But this public-relations blitz does nothing to change President Reagan's dismal record on the nuclear war issue, which is critical to our survival.

title: The American Muse
description: To the Editor:

title: Thailand Burns Poppy Fields
description: The authorities burned off about 80 acres of poppy fields tended by opium- producing hill tribes in northern Thailand near the Laotian border, a military officer said today.

title: ABOUT MEN
description: is a New York-based writer.

title: ASSEMBLY-LINE ARTICLE ELICITS COMMENTS
description: Miss Dubnoff has discovered a dirty little secret of industrial life: For many people, work is not clean and quiet and performed in carpeted offices by obviously well-educated, sophisticated men and women like Miss Dubnoff.

title: CENTRAL AMERICAN REFUGEES' PLIGHT DESCRIBED
description: Civil war and political persecution have created a refugee crisis in Central America, a leading refugee worker told a conference on ''The World's Uprooted'' here today.

title: PARISIAN SPLENDOR
description: Home Design By Patricia McColl

title: Policeman Gets Life Term
description: A police officer was sentenced Friday to life in prison in the deatrh by shooting of a black teen-ager in a high-speed chase. The officer, Stephen Rosiere, was sentenced Friday by Judge John Covington of Baton Rouge, but was released on a $500,000 bond paid by a New Orleans businessman, pending an appeal hearing April 10.

title: On Being Admitted But Unregistered
description: Westchester Community College is really responding to the needs of the coummunity in its programs. Dr. (Joseph N.) Hankin's accomplishments are commendable (''A Community College Measures Its Role,'' Jan. 22) However, there is a change that should be made in the procedure for midyear entrance and registration at the college.

title: Jane Rabin Wed To Russell Stern On Long Island
description: Jane Rabin, the daughter of retired Associate Judge Samuel Rabin of the New York Court of Appeals and Mrs. Rabin of Floral Park, L.I., was married yesterday to Russell N. Stern, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Harry J. Stern of Sands Point, L.I., and Stuart, Fla. Rabbi Israel Mowshowitz performed the ceremony at the Rabin home.

title: BUSH'S MISSION HAS SLIM HOPES FOR BREAKTHROUGH
description: For President Reagan, the death of Yuri V. Andropov has provided an opportunity for a possible thaw in Soviet-American relations just when Lebanon was providing the Administration's gravest foreign policy crisis to date. Congressmen who had been sharply attacking the Administration over the situation in Lebanon, were by Friday putting Lebanon aside to debate whether the President should go to Moscow.

title: PROSPECTS
description: Table Talk

title: Reagan Found Leading All Democrats in South
description: Former Vice President Walter F. Mondale has a 2-to-1 lead over Senator John Glenn in the South but President Reagan would sweep the region against either contender for the Democratic Presidential nomination, a new poll indicates.

title: SUNDAY, FEBRUARY 12, 1984;  Death of Andropov
description: Limousine traffic at the Kremlin and the headquarters of the Communist Party's Central Committee indicated that Soviet officials were attending high-level meetings that could determine who will succeed Yuri V. Andrpov, whose bier was visited by thousands of mourners. (Page 1, Col. 6.) The complex maneuvering to fill the vacancy created by Mr. Andropov's death may never come to light, since all that the world is likely to see is a ''unanimous'' decision by the Communist Party Central Committee sometime soon on a successor. (1:5.)

title: Drug Tests Backed
description: Manager Tony LaRussa of the Chicago White Sox has joined his crosstown counterpart, Dallas Green of the Chicago Cubs, in urging that major leaguers be required to submit to drug tests. Green has contended that a provision in the standard contract requiring players to submit to physical examinations gives clubs the right to include a test for drugs as part of routine urinalysis.

title: A BLOOM IN THE HEART OF TEXAS
description: Tell an urbane, exotically traveled Easterner there's a purely scenic reason to visit the harsh outback of the Texas Hill Country west of Austin, and there is that delicious moment, fleeting to be sure, when what flickers across his face is the instant certainty that you have mislaid your mind. Not so, since there is delight in the outlying and seemingly barren prairies not far from the city limits.

title: AT 50, WNEW IS STILL SWEET ON MELODY
description: W hen radio station WNEW celebrates its 50th anniversary on the air tomorrow, it will also be completing a cycle from discovery to identity crisis to rediscovery. After a dazzling success as a pioneer promoter of pop songs, pop singers and swing bands in the 1930's and 40's, it was overwhelmed by rock-and-roll, which claimed its young audience in the 50's and 60's. But now, as it reaches its half-century mark, the station has found fresh vitality in the face of still prevalent rock by renewing its faith in the melodic, rhythmic, romantic music with which it was originally identified.

title: DISKS VS. CASSETTES--THE PROS AND CONS
description: T he rampant vogue of video cassettes should not entirely obscure the alternative. Consider the merit of videodisks, which maintain a loyal following among viewers impatient with the somewhat fuzzy and grainy image obtained from even the best video-cassette recorders at their present stage of technical maturation. Of course, the obvious drawback of the disk - that you cannot record off the air - limits its appeal. Still, all other considerations aside, the best videodisks (i.e., those played through a laser beam) remain the best available medium in terms of picture quality.

title: Swedes Seek Intruder Sub

The Navy first noticed what it believed to be a foreign submarine Friday, a military spokesman said, declining to identify the supposed intruder. Sweden protested to the Soviet Union when a Soviet submarine ran aground off the Karlskrona base in 1981 and has said Soviet submarines have violated its waters on other occasions.

description: The Prix de Lausanne, one of four major international ballet competitions, will be held at the Brooklyn Academy of Music in 1985. The competition, created by Philippe Braunschweig, normally takes place in Switzerland and differs from other ballet competitions in that it grants scholarships for ballet study to advanced students, rather than cash awards or medals.

description: The old saw that ''lightning never strikes twice'' doesn't always work out that way. For example, prolonged delays impaired two recent consecutive charter flights operated from New York to Rio de Janeiro by International Weekends of Boston on a DC-8 of Arista International Airways. Both flights were plagued by mechanical difficulties, causing acute discomfort, anxiety, substantial loss of vacation time and widespread anger among the several hundred passengers involved.

title: LOVEABLE CHERUBINO GREW UP TO BE A RASCAL
description: W ould it shock you to learn that after the curtain falls on ''The Marriage of Figaro'' the lovable young page Cherubino runs away with the Countess Almaviva and that they have a baby? If so, you probably are one of the many operagoers who do not know that Beaumarchais wrote three, not two, Figaro plays. ''La Mere Coupable,'' or ''The Guilty Mother,'' follows the further fortunes of several characters that the French dramatist sketched so indelibly in his ''Barber of Seville'' and ''Marriage of Figaro.'' Milhaud, late in his career, made an opera out of ''La M ere Coupable'' and Gretry is known to have considered an opera on the subject. However, the play has attracted few other important composers during the nearly two centuries of its existence. The earlier adventures of Figaro and his friends, on the other hand, have inspired at least 40 opera composers, according to the reference books.

title: AFTER 175 YEARS, THEY STILL PURSUE LINCOLN
description: Herbert Mitgang , cultural correspondent for The New York Times, is the author of the biographies ''Lincoln as They Saw Him'' and ''The Fiery Trial'' and a play, ''Mister Lincoln.'' HERE are about 5,000 books on Lincoln, most out of print by now; but, rest assured, new ones are coming. At the moment, I am riffling through the pages of Ida M. Tarbell's forgotten ''Life of Abraham Lincoln.'' It first appeared as articles in 1895 in McClure's Magazine. What the muckraking Tarbell was able to do then was impossible for mid- 20th-century biographers - interview people who knew Lincoln. Yet even before the turn of the century Tarbell believed that there wasn't much left to say about Lincoln. ''Never has a man's life in so short a period been so many times written and rewritten,'' she wrote, ''unless possibly it is that of Napoleon Bonaparte.''

title: GENETICIST IS APPOINTED DEAN OF YALE'S SCHOOL OF MEDICINE

title: WESTCHESTER JOURNAL
description: -panel stained-glass window isn't Louis Comfort Tiffany, it is Hutchinson School sixth-grade class of '83. The window, which incorporates about 300 pieces of glass averaging 5 by 7 inches each in 50 different colors, while not the master's, is no less masterful in the eyes of those who saw to its design and its placement in a spot where ''dappled sunlight streams right into the main hallway of the school.''

title: POP DISKS CONTRAST ROMANTIC STYLES
description: L aura Nyro and Christine McVie represent nearly opposite styles of pop romanticism. Miss Nyro, who became a star in the late 60's while still in her teens, is now 36 but still exudes the mystique of a pop music prodigy. The music on ''Mother's Spiritual'' (Columbia FC 39215), Miss Nyro's first album in five years, is essentially the same keyboard- based, homemade mixture of pop- soul, jazz, folk, and theater music that she introduced more than a decade and a half ago.

title: THE BLACK WOMAN'S STORY
description: By waging her ''womanish'' quest, however genuine, Alice Walker deepens the wounds of equally oppressed black men. It is ironic that Alice Walker's holisms failed to take her counterparts - the men who are much the source of her suffering - into consideration.

title: Data Update
description: Conventional mortgages have fixed rates and terms, with payments that amortize the debt by the end of the term. Rollovers have short terms, do not completely amortize the debt and usually commit the lender to renew at the prevailing rate of interest.

title: THE ITALIAN TRADITION
description: Traveling means knowing how to read signs, but also how to find signs. Some of my art-loving friends, when they are in a new city without guidebook or map or compass, look up at the skyline, pick out the tallest spire, and head in its direction, confident that, at the end of their way, they will find the Cathedral and, in it, the works of art they have come to see. As a music lover, I have a different method: I wait till I see a few men and women with instrument cases hurrying in the same direction; following them I will almost certainly arrive at the opera house.

Whiting of Clinton. The nondenominational ceremony was performed at the Hamilton College Chapel by the chaplain, the Rev. Jeffrey C. Eaton, a Lutheran pastor.

Before accepting the conventional wisdom that Mr. Reagan is unbeatable, political prophets should consider strong evidence that the President is worse off with the electorate - and women particularly - than he was four years ago.
