description: -foot freshman point guard at the University of Florida, thought for a moment about the major differences between high school and college basketball.

title: RESORT VILLAGE IN PUERTO RICO
description: On the site of what once was a 2,700-acre sugar cane plantation in Puerto Rico, a self-contained resort community was developed 15 years ago and has been growing in stages ever since. Construction of Palmas del Mar, 46 miles southeast of San Juan near the town of Humacao, began in 1972 after three years of ecological and architectural planning. By 1982, Palmas had more than 1,000 guests at peak season in its two hotels, two-story condominiums, villas and townhouses - designed by the architect Esteban Padilla in Italian or Spanish style and clustered together in village-like developments.

title: ABOUT BOOKS
description: ''W HEN I hear about all the fuss made over the woman who had a book published at the age of 80,'' William M. Ashby commented the other day, ''I feel like calling her to talk about the pleasures of writing.''

description: Four of the six Democrats vying in a Feb. 21 primary to replace the late United States Representative Clement J. Zablocki are running neck and neck in the eyes of politicians.

title: DEAL STRUCK TO SELL SPORTS CAR TRACK
description: W HEN Henry Tredwell Jr., president of the Bridgehampton Road Races Corporation, announced early this month that an agreement had been reached with a group of investors interested in buying the 521-acre Bridgehampton Race Circuit property, he delivered the news without fanfare.

title: More Old War Shells Found
description: Ten more pieces of old military ammunition, two 81-millimeter shells and eight 75-millimeter shells, were found this week in Tierrasanta Canyon, bringing the total to 61 since a search of the area began four weeks ago, the Navy said.

title: Lake Factor May Thwart Bid
description: The Chicago Yacht Club's challenge for the America's Cup may be cut short by the Royal Perth Yacht Club of Western Australia, the holder of the cup since Australia II won it last summer. The decision hinges on whether the Australians consider the Great Lakes an arm of the sea.

title: THE NAMES BEHIND THE O-T-C SYMBOLS
description: Chubb is Chubb, Apple is Apple and MCI is MCI. But not all over-the- counter stocks are as easily recognized by their published O-T-C listings. A holder of, say, Comprehensive Care stock might find it hard to tell at a glance whether he should look under CompC, Compcp, CmpA or a host of other alphabetical flourishes.

title: Wyoming Governor Won't Seek Re-election
description: Gov. Ed Herschler of Wyoming announced Friday he would not seek a fourth term as Governor in 1986.

title: RECITAL: ANNE HAENEN
description: Those who attended the Wednesday night recital of the mezzo-soprano Anne Haenen at the 92d Street Y were rewarded by one of the most challenging and unusual musical events of the season. As if to prove her classical credentials, Miss Haenen opened her program with a selection of songs by Rachmaninoff and Tchaikovsky, acompanied by the sensitive pianist Mikael Eliasen.

title: COAST PUBLIC WORKERS SEEK TO BOLSTER UNION

title: The Editorial Notebook; Mr. Koch, Meet the 'Mayor'
description: The indiscretions in Edward Koch's newly published reminiscences, ''Mayor,'' have obscured the fact that he is, after all, a politician with big ears and thin skin. He counts his friends in public as often as a dieter counts calories. He knows when to remember a grievance, and when to forget.

title: ADVERTISING

title: MAINE HOPING AGAIN TO SEE PEREGRINE FALCON ON THE WING

title: GOING OUT GUIDE;
description: PUTTING ON THE DOG There has always been a breath of aristocracy about dog shows, either on the part of the dogs or their owners, even in these egalitarian days. The Westminster Kennel Club Dog Show parades its classic canines today and tomorrow at Madison Square Garden for the 108th year. This pure-bred event has inspired the Dog Museum of America, across town at 51 Madison Avenue, at 26th Street (696-8350), to offer an exhibition that puts the dog show into focus as an institution and hallmark of Western civilization.

title: POOLING DAY-CARE INFORMATION
description: Five companies with offices in Hartford have organized a day-care referral service for their employees. The service provides workers with up-to-date information for the Hartford metropolitan area.

description: Tom Nnakwe captured the 55-meter hurdles in the meet-record time of 7.29 seconds today in leading Seton Hall to the Metropolitan Intercollegiate Track and Field Association indoor title today at Yale.

description: Ron Francis scored four goals and Greg Malone three as the Hartford Whalers got six power-play goals today in an 11-0 rout of Edmonton. It was the Oilers' fifth straight defeat.

title: STOPPING DEADLY EDB
description: It may be better to be pregnant in Massachusetts than in Vermont. It may be safest to feed your baby a jar of baby food sold in California. That's because the infamous pesticide EDB and the cancer it can produce is being taken dead seriously in certain states - and not seriously enough by the Government.

title: NEWS SUMMARY MONDAY, FEBRUARY 13, 1984 International
description: Designation of a new Soviet leader is likely today, according to growing indications in Moscow. The delay in announcing a successor to Yuri V. Andropov suggested that the 12 members of the Politburo had been unable to reach a prompt consensus on the new leader. A stalemate in the Politburo would give the Communist Party's Central Committee an opportunity to review the issue. The Committee is expected to meet today. (Page A1, Column 6.) State Department sources believe that the new Soviet leader will be Konstantin U. Chernenko, 72 years old, who was a close associate of Leonid I. Brezhnev. Mr. Chernenko was named Friday to head the funeral commission for Mr. Brezhnev's successor, Yuri V. Andropov. (A7:1.)

title: Egyptian Court Rehabilitates 2 Opposition Party Leaders
description: An administrative court ruled today that two leaders of the New Wafd opposition party could resume political activity that was halted when Anwar el-Sadat, the late President, issued a decree in 1978 banning them from politics.

title: No Headline
description: IN about three hours, Kitty and Peter Carruthers would be on the ice at the XIV Olympic Winter Games in the pairs' free-skating program. But last night, at a little restaurant in a snow-drifted neighborhood near the Zetra arena, their parents were having dinner and talking about the adopted brother and sister who would win the first medal here, a silver, for the United States team.

title: MORGAN LIBRARY SHOWS ITS LINCOLN COLLECTION
description: In a handwritten letter from the Executive Mansion, signed ''Yours truly A. Lincoln'' and dated Nov. 13, 1861, the President addressed a short note to Simon Cameron, the ''Hon. Sec. of War.'' In a few brief lines, Lincoln's letter tells much about his humor and compassion and the close watch he kept as Commander in Chief of the minutest details of the Union Army. It went:

title: 76ERS ROUT CELTICS
description: Julius Erving scored 30 points and Andrew Toney 21 as the Philadelphia 76ers rolled to a 109-91 victory over the Boston Celtics today in a showdown of National Basketball Association powers.

title: BUSINESS PEOPLE
description: Newcomer Steers United Merchants

title: DEATH HELPS RAISE THE KREMLIN VEIL
description: As has happened before, the world is learning more about a Soviet leader in death than during his lifeftime.

title: SALVADOR, DIVIDED BY ELECTION, UNITED BY WEARINESS OF WAR
description: After five years of guerrilla warfare, El Salvador is now hovering in precarious uncertainty, its people worried about a divisive election campaign, unsure about future United States aid and weary of the destruction wrought by the civil war.

title: JACKSON ASKS UNIVERSITY STUDENTS TO HELP VOTER REGISTRATION DRIVE
description: The Rev. Jesse Jackson stressed peace and education today in a speech to 900 students whom he challenged to help make it easier for others to vote.

title: ASKEW AND GLENN TRY TO MAKE MONDALE'S FINANCES A POLITCAL ISSUE
description: With Walter F. Mondale the heavy favorite to win the Iowa precinct caucuses a week from Monday, some of his opponents are attempting to make a political issue of the former Vice President's personal and campaign finances.

title: ADVERTISING
description: People

title: SAMPSON INJURED
description: A crowd of 16,524, the Nets' second largest of the season, came to Byrne Meadowlands Arena today to see Ralph Sampson, the Houston Rockets' 7-foot-4-inch rookie center.

title: BRIEFING
description: Carter on Mondale's Stance

title: The Lesson of the Great Engine War
description: As fear of the Federal deficit sends the stockmarket into a tailspin, Congress must be asking if there isn't some magic way to cut the defense budget without impairing defense.

title: GULF PLANS TAKEOVER DEFENSE
description: The Gulf Oil Corporation, bracing for a takeover bid by T. Boone Pickens, warned yesterday that if the Mesa Petroleum Company chairman ever got 51 percent of Gulf's shares the company might use $6 billion in bank credits to buy the rest, turning itself into a financial cripple.

title: BERNARD NEWMAN, RETIRED VICAR
description: Canon Bernard C. Newman, the former vicar of the landmark Trinity Episcopal Church in the financial district of Manhattan, died Saturday at Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center. He was 83 years old and lived in Wyckoff, N.J.

title: Can't Afford Balloting, Nigerian General Says
description: Maj. Gen. Mohammed Buhari, who seized control of Nigeria in a coup New Year's Eve, said in an interview published today that the country could not afford to hold elections for a new civilian government.

title: Carolina Unions Back Gilmore for Governor
description: The North Carolina branch of the American Federation of Labor and Congress of Industrial Organizations has endorsed Tom Gilmore, a Democrat, for the governorship, saying he stood ''head and shoulders'' above the rest of the crowded field.

title: Washington WatchRobert D. Hershey Jr. Reviving Plan To Export Oil WASHINGTON
description: S ENATOR Frank H. Murkowski, a Republican from Alaska who sits on the Energy Committee, has dusted off and modified a long-dormant plan to authorize the export of Alaskan oil to Japan. He plans to offer it as an amendment to the Export Administration Act when it comes up for renewal later this month.

title: PROPOSED GRANT FOR JERSEY CITY DRAWS A PROTEST
description: Charging that the Federal Government is helping draw jobs out of New York City, the state's two United States Senators and most of the city's Representatives have demanded that the Government reconsider a $40 million development grant planned for Jersey City.

title: FROM ONE LIVING ROOM IN IOWA, OPINIONS ON THE 8
description: Five couples from this farming community north of Des Moines had just finished watching the debate among eight Democratic Presidential contenders. What they had to say was not good news for Walter F. Mondale, the former Vice President, who leads in the polls.

title: U.S. TO KEEP BACKING ISRAEL-LEBANON ACCORD
description: The Reagan Administration has decided to reaffirm its strong support for the agreement between Israel and Lebanon even though it recognizes that this will hinder the efforts of President Amin Gemayel to resolve Lebanon's political crisis, senior State Department officials said today.

title: CABARET: 2 LANDMARKS OF HARLEM CELEBRATED
description: the Cotton Club and the Savoy Ballroom - were celebrated in cabaret shows over the weekend. ''An Evening at the Cotton Club,'' which is being presented Wednesdays through Saturdays at the Silver Lining, 349 West 46th Street, tries to raise memories or fantasies of the club by invoking the names of bands and singers who performed there - Cab Calloway, Jimmie Lunceford, Ethel Waters, Lena Horne and others.

title: The Calendar ;  Monday
description: President Reagan is scheduled to meet this week with two Middle Eastern leaders to discuss the crisis in Lebanon. He meets today with King Hussein of Jordan and on Tuesday with President Hosni Mubarak of Egypt. On Tuesday, all three will have a working luncheon.

title: THE LURE OF FOREIGN MUTUALS
description: In Australia, there are the media stocks. Sweden has high-growth drug companies. Japan offers the electrical supply companies.

title: DANCE: CITY BALLET'S 'KAMMERMUSIK'
description: IT would be easy to see George

title: NO ELEPHANT CIRCUS: STEP RIGHT UP
description: An elephant will eat about $150 worth of feed every day, whereas a human performer will not, according to Bob Daraio. Reason enough, perhaps, to look kindly upon the No Elephant Circus.

title: ROCK: LOS LOBOS BAND
description: BANDS from the East and West Coasts brought revved- up, back-to-basics rock and roll to Irving Plaza on Saturday.

title: KEY SECTIONS FROM TRANSCRIPTS OF DEMOCRATS' DEBATE IN IOWA
description: Following are excerpts from a transcript of a debate Saturday at the Civic Center in Des Moines, Iowa, among the eight major candidates for the Democratic Presidential nomination, as recorded by The New York Times through the facilities of Cable News Network. James P. Gannon, editor of The Des Moines Register, served as moderator.

title: OF POULTRY, DRINK LAW AND PUPILS
description: The numbers were small, for the poultry business, but the shock was great as new cases of avian influenza erupted in small areas of Virginia and Maryland. The disease had already caused the destruction of about 10 million chickens in Pennsylvania and driven egg prices up.

title: OUTDOORS: NIGHT SKIING AN INVIGORATING EXPERIENCE
description: THOUGHTS of night skiing usually conjure up visions of hidden hazards, difficult snow conditions and unsure footing. While it is true that skiing under lights can be an out-of-the ordinary, even mysterious experience, unusual danger is not one of its characteristics.

title: Buffeting by Storms Blamed For Death of 30,000 Seagulls
description: Hunger and stress from constant buffeting by storms killed about 30,000 seagulls that have been washed up along the French Atlantic coast in the last two weeks, French television said today.

title: HBO STARTS PRODUCING MOVIES FOR THEATERS
description: ''We want to prove we can make commercially successful movies,'' Michael Fuchs, president of the Entertainment Group at Home Box Office, said. ''The rarefied prestige movies are a luxury we cannot afford.''

title: SOVIET PREPARING TO NAME A LEADER AT PARTY MEETING
description: The Soviet Union passed a third day today since the death of Yuri V. Andropov without announcing a successor, but there were growing indications that the Central Committee would name a new leader on Monday.

title: Season's First Tornadoes Strike in 5 States By The Associated Press
description: The first tornadoes of the season hit in parts of Texas, Arkansas, Louisiana, Kansas and Missouri over the weekend as waves of strong thunderstorms poured up to six inches of rain on the lower Mississippi Valley.

title: BOOK OF THE TIMES
description: FRAGMENTS. By Jack Fuller. 211 pages. William Morrow and Company. $12.95. GARDENS OF STONE. By Nicholas Proffitt. 373 pages. Carroll & Graf. $14.95. FREE FIRE ZONE. By Rob Riggan. 426 pages. W. W. Norton & Company. $15.95.

title: Pursuer of Nazis Is on Mengele's Trail
description: Beate Klarsfeld, the pursuer of Nazis, who is in Paraguay in an attempt to persuade Gen. Alfredo Stroessner's Government to expel Dr. Josef Mengele, the world's most notorious war criminal, says she has found support for her efforts.

title: UNWELCOME GREETERS AT RAIL TERMINALS
description: To the Editor:

title: 65 LONDONERS HURT AS FLOOR FALLS
description: The floor of a London apartment collapsed under the weight of at least 200 partygoers early today, plunging many of them into a store 10 feet below, the police said. At least 65 people were injured and taken to a hospital.

title: TV BRINGS WESTERN CULTURE TO EAST GERMANY
description: In the East Berlin subway, two elderly women were overheard gossiping about the wild goings-on of a clan that hardly seemed to fit into the proletarian milieu of East Germany. In breathless whispers, the two spoke of sleek women, flashy cars, seamy adulteries and high-rolling business deals.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''I'm sure that President Reagan is fully committed to help Lebanon recover its sovereignty and independence.

title: Ward Loses Bid
description: The Texas Rangers announced today they had won their arbitration dispute with the outfielder Gary Ward.

title: . . . And a Lovely One, Too
description: Manhattan can be just one long love story, if you look at it that way, and yesterday 32 people did when they visited some historic romantic spots. It was the 92d Street Y's Valentine's Day tour, led by Marvin Gelfand, writer, self-taught historian and impassioned New Yorker.

title: New President Picked At Daniel Industries Daniel Industries of Houston, a nuts and bolts company in the oil industry, has a new president, Louis F. Crane.
description: Mr. Crane, 43, succeeds W. A. Griffin, 68, who continues as chairman. Mr. Griffin, a principal shareholder with some 15 percent of the stock, has been president since 1956 and chairman since 1957.

title: Carol Blumencranz Is Wed
description: Carol Blumencranz, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Richard Blumencranz of New York, was married in Manhattan yesterday to Glenn Shaye, the son of Mrs. Henry Bochner of Albany and the late Morton Shaye.

title: Question of Pressure
description: To the Editor:

title: Squirrel Stops Power For 13,000 in Jersey
description: A squirrel climbed into a transformer at the Atlantic Electric Company's Grenloch station this morning and was electrocuted, causing service to be cut off for several hours to 13,000 customers in six Gloucester County communities, a company spokesman said.

title: CLUB SHOWS MARK WESTMINSTER EVE
description: While 20 specialty clubs at nine sites in the metropolitan area caused the principal excitement in the dog world yesterday, they were only a prelude to the main event, the 108th consecutive Westminster Kennel Club show, which gets under way in Madison Square Garden this morning and ends tomorrow night.

title: WEST BANK-BOLSTER MODERATES
description: While the Lebanon crisis necessarily occupies much of Washington's attention these days, United States policy makers are also closely watching moves by the Arab moderates to test the waters for a new start in Arab-Israeli negotiations.

title: ISLANDERS STICKING WITH SMITH IN GOAL
description: Al Arbour rested his chin on a hockey stick today, observing and thinking, while in front of him Billy Smith was lashing out at flying pucks, scooting from side to side in the net to deflect them.

title: POST MANSION BUYERS LISTED
description: Two developers who say they plan to live in it will pay more than $14.5 million for the pink, 118-room mansion once owned by Marjorie Meriwether Post, according to a real estate broker.

title: JEWISH TERROR GROUP TAKES RESPONSIBILITY IN GRENADE INCIDENT
description: Another anti- Arab bombing was attributed this weekend to Terror Against Terror, an organization that has claimed credit for planting Israeli Army-issue grenades at Moslem and Christian buildings in the Jerusalem area.

title: Michigan Judge to Rule On Caucus Challenge
description: A judge says she will rule this week on whether Michigan state officials should be required to supervise Democratic Party caucuses at which delegates to the party's national convention are selected.

title: SUSPECT GIFTS FROM A FOREIGN AGENT
description: To the Editor:

title: Bridge: Strong Reply May Backfire After a Strong Opening Bid
description: Conventional wisdom calls for aggressive bidding when the opponents have opened with a strong artificial club bid, such as Precision.

title: Norman Is Victor
description: Greg Norman of Australia birdied the final hole today and won the $60,000 Victorian Open golf tournament by two shots. He had a closing par 72 for 281.

title: Wisconsin Governor Set To Stump for Mondale
description: Gov. Anthony S. Earl says he will campaign in Iowa this weekend in behalf of Walter F. Mondale's candidacy for the Democratic Presidential nomination.

title: THE NEXT BIG TEST FOR LOTUS
description: In scarcely a year, the Lotus Development Corporation has done for the world of personal computer software what International Business Machines has done for personal computers: It has created a product so wildly successful that scores of other companies are scrambling to imitate it or improve on it.

title: 2 HOLIDAY MOVIES TURN INTO SURPRISE SUCCESSES
description: This year's biggest movie surprise so far is Paramount's ''Uncommon Valor,'' an adventure film about a father who trains guerillas to rescue his son, a prisoner of war in Laos, that had been lightly regarded by the film industry before it was released over the big Christmas season.

title: PANIC CITED BY TRADERS IN STOCKS' 3-WEEK FALL
description: Many of Wall Street's top analysts, trying to explain the stock market's steep decline, have pointed to fears of an economic downturn. But some of those on the front line, who make or arrange transactions involving millions of shares, say that fears of climbing interest rates and growing Federal deficits have only been the spark that ignited the selling streak.

description: They build windmills. They tap natural steam from below the earth's surface. They even burn walnut shells.

title: NEW STUDIES ON 'GIRL TOYS'AND 'BOY TOYS'
description: In an earlier day, parents voiced concerns about their children's gender development with questions like: ''Is it all right for my little boy to play with dolls?'' Or, ''Is it all right for my little girl to be such a tomboy?'' Such questions seem less relevant in a time when so many small boys are playing with ''Star Wars'' dolls and when it is unexceptional for girls to play baseball, basketball and soccer. But some parents' concerns may be just as intense.

title: 700 Evacuees Arrive In Cyprus From Beirut
description: A last group of 700 evacuees from Lebanon, mainly Americans and Italians, landed today in Cyprus after an overnight journey across the eastern Mediterranean.

title: Faulty Car Hoods Sought
description: The Chrysler Corporation announced Friday that it was recalling 2,500 Chrysler Laser and Dodge Daytona sports cars in a search for 600 automobiles that might have faulty latches that could allow the hood to fly open.

title: INABILITY TO PROTECT LEADS IRKS RANGERS
description: The trip covered some 13,000 miles, included enough airline food to make a homemade peanut-butter-and-jelly sandwich taste like a gourmet offering and had more than its share of cribbage games, practical jokes and Grade B movies piped into hotel rooms.

title: ARGENTINE WRITER OF FICTION
description: Julio Cortazar, the Argentine writer whose novels and short stories bore the Latin American literary stamp of richness in language and imagery and who was a supporter of the Cuban and Nicaraguan revolutions, died yesterday in Saint Lazare Hospital in Paris. He was 69 years old and had suffered from leukemia for several months.

description: * Anderson, Greenwood & Co., Houston, manufacturer of valves, has elected M. E. Jones vice president, sales.

title: LAYMEN DISPENSE LOCAL JUSTICE IN NEW YORK
description: Every Thursday night, Edward N. Starr leaves his job as an assistant manager at a local Agway farm and garden store and drives to the firehouse, where, in the back room, he becomes justice of the village of Cambridge and of the town of White Creek.

title: Guatemalan Unionist Is Kidnapped
description: A group of men armed with automatic weapons kidnapped a newspaper union leader Saturday as he was walking with friends, according to a report today from the newspaper Prensa Libre, where the kidnapped union leader worked.

title: 25 DEMOCRATS OPPOSE MEESE
description: Twenty-five Democrats in the House of Representatives have signed a letter opposing the nomination of Edwin Meese 3d as Attorney General on the ground that he is no friend of those who seek justice.

title: FOR BURTT, GAME ISN'T ALL
description: IN a sense, they both were freshmen then, unproven and insecure, faced with the task of perpetuating the sudden success that a firebrand coach, Jim Valvano, and a burly center, Jeff Ruland, had brought to Iona College in the late 1970's. A framed photograph of Pat Kennedy and Steve Burtt hangs on the wall behind Kennedy's desk and is a reminder of the challenge they faced and of the progress they have since made.

title: HARLEM LINE TO TEST POWER
description: The Metro-North Commuter Railroad will begin testing Wednesday on the new third-rail system for its Upper Harlem Line, which is scheduled to be converted to electric power by the end of March, officials said today.

title: ARKANSAS HANDS N. CAROLINA FIRST LOSS
description: Charles Balentine sank a five-foot baseline jumper with four seconds remaining as Arkansas upset top- ranked and previously undefeated North Carolina today, 65-64.

description: For Miriam Haddad, the game became real almost at the start, when she was stripped and searched by a scowling female guard. ''They took my identity when they took my clothes,'' she said. ''I guess that was the point.''

title: Coast Bank Closed, Sold LOS ANGELES, Feb. 12 (AP) - The Wilshire State Bank will take over the assets and some liabilities of the primarily Korean-owned West Olympia Bank, which was shut Friday by California's Superintendent of Banks, officials said today.
description: ''Substantial loan and operating losses reduced the bank's capital to an inadequate and unsafe level and made it necessary to close the bank,'' said Louis Carter, the Banking Superintendent.

title: Dr. Andrew G. Grossman Marries Amy Schechter
description: Amy Schechter, a daughter of June Schechter and the late Dr. Lester Schechter of Kew Gardens Hills, Queens, was married yesterday to Dr. Andrew George Grossman, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Earle H. Grossman of Hewlett Harbor, L.I. Rabbi Sidney Solomon performed the ceremony at the Jewish Center of Kew Gardens Hills.

title: Market PlaceVartanig G. Vartan A Down Trend Seen for Prices
description: U NLIKE many technical analysts, Edward P. Nicoski of Piper, Jaffray & Hopwood Inc. does not like to predict targets for the stock market's various indicators. ''But my basic feeling is that the market peaked last May and June,'' he said in Minneapolis last week, ''and I think the trend is still downward.''

title: Agreement on Arrows' Sale
description: An agreement has been reached to sell the New York Arrows to a group of seven investors, according to David Schoenstadt, the owner of the Major Indoor Soccer League team.

description: SHE is slim, smart, funny, spontaneous, spiritual, into films,

title: THEATER: 'LEVITATION,' AT THE CIRCLE REPERTORY
description: DOWNTOWN at the Circle Repertory Company, there is an undying affection for plays in which all-American families resolve their all-American conflicts on an all-American front porch. This kind of play can still sizzle - especially if written by Lanford Wilson, the Circle Rep's outstanding dramatist - but second-best examples of the genre are so predictable that they might as well have rolled off an assembly line. So it is with Timothy Mason's ''Levitation'' - a play equipped with a lovely porch (designed by David Potts), some heavenly moonlight (designed by Dennis Parichy) and a lot of long-winded talk about the wages of familial love and death.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: Because of an editing error, a dispatch from Belgrade Thursday on the press in Yugoslavia misidentified a Communist Party member. Dimce Belovski is a member of the presidium of the Central Committee of the League of Communists of Yugoslavia.

title: CONNORS RETAINS CROWN
description: Jimmy Connors won the United States Indoor tennis title for a record seventh time today with a 6-3, 4-6, 7-5 victory over Henri Leconte. The match between the left-handers at the Racquet Club ended with a double fault by the Frenchman.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article in Weekend on Friday about Theater Row on West 42d Street gave the origins of Playwrights Horizons incorrectly. The company started at the West Side Y.W.C.A.

title: China Reports a Panda Death
description: Three giant pandas were saved from starvation by a rescue operation in the mountains of Sichuan Province but a fourth died because of a severe shortage of bamboo, wildlife conservation officials said here today. The death brought to four the number of pandas that have died of starvation in the last four months in China because of the withering of their staple food, the arrow bamboo.

title: IVORY COAST STABILITY IS SHAKEN
description: On the last day of 1983, a senior Government official was reflecting on news of the military takeover in Nigeria. ''Here in the Ivory Coast,'' he said, ''one needn't worry about such things. Here we have calm and stability always.''

title: WNEW Plans Benefit For 50th Anniversary
description: A concert celebrating the 50th anniversary of radio station WNEW will be held at the Felt Forum at 7 P.M. on Monday.

title: Indian Pt. 2 to Stay Closed for Repairs
description: The Indian Point 2 nuclear power plant is expected to be inactive for several weeks because of repairs needed to fix a leak that let several gallons of radioactive water seep from one closed system to another.

title: FLORIDIANS SEEK RESIDENCY STATUS FOR HAITIANS, ALONG WITH CUBANS
description: Quick passage of a bill introduced by Representative Peter W. Rodino Jr. to legalize the immigration status of some 7,200 Haitian refugees is being urged by some Miami leaders as a way to lessen tension between Cubans and Haitians here.

title: St. Louis Boys Get 10 Years For Raping Girl, 14, in Park
description: Two teen-age cousins, arrested after an 11- year-old boy alerted the police, have been sentenced to 10 years in prison for raping a 14-year-old girl at a city park fountain.

title: ALWORTH, GRIESE NAMED TO HALL
description: Lance Alworth, a member of the pro football Hall of Fame, Bob Griese and Mean Joe Greene were among 11 players named yesterday to the National Football Foundation's College Football Hall of Fame.

title: Court Ruling Is Awaited On Redistricting in Ohio
description: Litigants in Ohio's Congressional redistricting struggle apparently will not know until this week whether a three- judge Federal panel will delay its threat to redraw the existing districts.

title: OF ARABS, MARONITES AND TWISTED HISTORY
description: To the Editor:

title: BURGER SAYS LAWYERS MAKE LEGAL HELP TOO COSTLY
description: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger asserted today that the nation's lawyers were making the pursuit of justice more expensive and time-consuming and diminishing public confidence in the legal profession.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Women in Jazz

title: Vietnam Said to Shell China
description: China accused Vietnam today of shelling and firing at Chinese border villages during their Lunar New Year celebrations, killing a farm worker.

title: Haitians Select Rubber-Stamp Assembly
description: -AU-PRINCE, Haiti, Feb. 12 (AP) - Haitians voted today for members of a 59-seat National Assembly that was dissolved a year early as part of a Government overhaul by President-for-Life Jean-Claude Duvalier.

title: Radioactive Table Base Discovered in Chicago
description: After the discovery of a highly radioactive table base in a Chicago hotel, Illinois nuclear officials said Sunday they were ''pretty confident'' no more of the contaminated pedestals would be found in areas open to the public.

title: PARKS DEPT. HARD PRESSED TO REPLACE ITS CRAFTSMEN
description: The carpenters are making seesaws. The auto mechanics are taking apart a front-end loader that looks like a prehistoric animal. The tinsmiths, blacksmiths, painters, plumbers, electricians, machinists and upholsterers are welding, hammering, wiring and generally overhauling everything in sight in the cavernous building on Randalls Island.

title: OUTLOOK IS SHINY AND GOALS ARE SET FOR TIFFANY CHIN
description: Tiffany Chin is not a figure-skating china doll, contrary to what some people have tried to suggest. Sweet-looking, yes. Artistic, definitely.

title: A TOP PEKING AIDE TO GO TO MOSCOW
description: The Government said today that Deputy Prime Minister Wan Li would travel to Moscow for the funeral of Yuri V. Andropov. He would be the highest-ranking Chinese official to visit the Soviet Union in two decades.

title: Advertising; Ethical Drugs and Television
description: LAST week the CBS-TV network started a series of meetings to present the results of its research into the desire of consumers to know more about prescription drugs. In doing so, it probably got jump on the competition in what could become an important advertising category.

title: BIGGER BORDER PATROL CAN'T HALT INLUX, AGENTS SAY
description: The Reagan Administration has drafted plans to deploy hundreds more law-enforcement officers along the Mexican border in a new effort to halt the influx of illegal aliens. But Border Patrol agents say it will take more than additional manpower to end illegal immigration.

description: How high is up? Sergei Bubka was asked.

description: The Canadien Way

title: Schedule Is Light for Debt Securities
description: The supply of new debt securities scheduled for sale this week is relatively light in all sectors.

title: Part of WNYC Show Is Lost by Technicians
description: Part of the Saturday evening broadcast of one of radio station WNYC's most popular programs, ''A Prairie Home Companion,'' with Garrison Keillor, was interrupted when WNYC technicians tried to delay the program for an announcement, said Ray Gallon, the station's producer of membership drives.

title: U.S. SAID TO EXPECT CHERNENKO VICTORY
description: A high- ranking State Department official said today that, from the available evidence, the United States expects Konstantin U. Chernenko to replace Yuri V. Andropov as the next leader of the Soviet Union.

title: Morphine Seized in Turkey
description: Turkish narcotics police have seized 33 pounds of base morphine, worth several million dollars on Western drug markets, near the eastern Turkish town of Tatvan.

title: WITH CELEBRITIES' HELP, FUGAZY FINDING A NICHE
description: A golf bet with the entertainer Bob Hope and some advice from Terence Cardinal Cooke helped transform the Fugazy International Corporation from a simple but successful travel agency into a complex and still successful transportation company.

title: MUSIC: MARCUS THOMPSON
description: MARCUS THOMPSON is such an elegant violist, with such an easy command of his chosen instrument, that one only wishes his Friday evening concert at Carnegie Recital Hall had been more inspiring. Mr. Thompson has an impeccable technique and seems incapable of playing a sour note. But his interpretations, for all their refinement, struck this listener as overly fastidious, characterized by a dessicated clarity rather than by empathy.

title: Yarborough Gains Daytona 500 Pole
description: Cale Yarborough drove a Chevrolet Monte Carlo SS to the pole position for next week's Daytona 500, barely outrunning Terry Labonte today as both broke the 200-miles-per-hour barrier at Daytona International Speedway.

title: Peru General Says Activity By Maoist Rebels Is Declining
description: The commander of Peru's antiguerrilla campaign says Maoist rebel activity has declined in recent months in southeastern Peru, but he added that the group might be extending its zone of operations closer to Lima.

title: Bridge Is Closed After Railing Falls
description: A 30-foot-long section of the concrete railing on a bridge here toppled into the Passaic River today and an inspection revealed that columns supporting the bridge had become dislodged, Mayor Frank X. Graves said.

title: American Financial
description: Ronald F. Walker has been promoted to president and chief operating officer of the American Financial Corporation. Carl H. Lindner, who had been president, continues as chairman and chief executive officer. Mr. Walker had been an executive vice president of American Financial, and president of the Great American Insurance Company, American Financial's property-casualty subsidiary.

title: Required Reading Nuclear Power Watch
description: The financial collapse of nuclear power in the United States may be particularly severe, but it is not unique. Countries around the world have encountered problems that have slowed the pace of development, and many have trimmed their plans for the future. Although most governments with major nuclear programs remain strongly committed to nuclear power, the gap is widening between the money and talk spent on nuclear power and actual achievements. Behind the lagging pace lies a varied list of technical, economic and political problems and a diminished rate of growth of electricity demand.

title: ALL JOKES ASIDE, BERRA IS BACK ON TOP
description: HAVE you heard the one about Dr. Zhivago, where when Yogi gets home, Carmen tells him, ''I saw 'Dr. Zhivago' this afternoon'' and Yogi asks her, ''What's wrong with you now?''

title: Photo of pairs skating medalists; CARRUTHERS DUO WINS SILVER MEDAL IN PAIRS SKATING
description: The United States won its first medal of the XIV Olympic Winter Games tonight when Caitlin (Kitty) and Peter Carruthers of Wilmington, Del., took the silver medal in pairs figure skating.

title: C.I.A. SEEKS TO READ MOSCOW AUGURIES
description: When the Soviet leader Leonid I. Brezhnev died 15 months ago, the Reagan Administration was ready. In a memo to President Reagan, William J. Casey, the Director of Central Intelligence, picked Yuri V. Andropov as a dark horse closing fast at the finish to succeed Mr. Brezhnev.

title: Threat of Rate Rise Depressing Prices;  U.S. Deficits Cause Worry
description: Sentiment that 1984 will bring higher interest rates seems to have gained ground recently, as seen in the steady decline of note and bond prices over the last six trading sessions.

title: DRIVERS BECOME FINAL UNION TO APPROVE TIMES CONTRACT
description: Truck drivers who deliver The New York Times ratified a three-year extension of their contract with the newspaper yesterday, becoming the 10th and final union at the paper to approve such an agreement.

title: WAIT GOES ON FOR URUGUAYAN WHO FELL OUT OF STEP
description: One of Latin America's most illustrious political prisoners is a retired general and former presidential candidate who has spent more than nine years in this capital's central jail.

title: Airbus Derides Offer
description: A vice president of Airbus Industrie said today that a proposal from the Boeing Company to join forces on an unspecified project was ''a joke.'' Pierre Pailleret, Airbus senior vice president for marketing, told reporters: ''You can't cooperate when you are at war with the adversary, an adversary you fight every day.'' The proposal for cooperation was made last week by Boeing's vice president for civil aviation, who said the two companies could be equal partners.

title: THIRD WORLD DEFAULT
description: When the Democratic candidates were asked, at the Presidential debate in New Hampshire, what they would do about the third world debt, the silence was immense and awkward. Yet the question has been prominent in the news for a year and a half.

title: PETER MARTINS PRESENTS 4 DANCES TO STRAVINSKY
description: AT a WNET/Channel 13 luncheon for a few journalists several months ago, Peter Martins conceded that he was still a bit uneasy about bringing the New York City Ballet to television. He would be happier if the screen were more flexible, being able to expand like an accordion from the standard 19-inch diagonal to something perhaps as large as 90 inches. Fortunately, though, Mr. Martins, who with Jerome Robbins is co-ballet master of the company, is continuing to work in television, and tonight's ''Dance in America'' presentation on WNET/13 at 8 demonstrates that his concern for scale can have its rewards.

title: Islamic Exhibition
description: Islamic paintings and manuscripts from the 12th to the 17th centuries, will go on view Friday at the Metropolitan Museum of Art, Fifth Avenue at 82d Street. The display, which runs through Oct. 14, is drawn from the collection of Prince Sadruddin Aga Khan.

title: STATE PANEL REPORT DUE ON BANKS
description: A special commission appointed by Governor Cuomo is expected to recommend tomorrow that individuals with low-balance bank accounts be provided with basic banking services at low or no cost.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST MONDAY, FEBRUARY 13, 1984
description: Companies

title: BEIRUT MAY SHIFT STANCE ON TREATY
description: President Amin Gemayel has told his opponents that if they agree to take part in another Geneva conference, he will be ready to consider the abrogation or renegotiation of the May 17 Israel- Lebanon withdrawal accord, officials close to the negotiations said today.

title: MEXICO ASKS U.S. TO CHANGE POLICIES
description: President Miguel de la Madrid, expressing deep concern about the economic chaos and military violence in Latin America, has called on the United States to reappraise its policies for the region in 1984.

title: GEMAYEL EXPRESSES ASSURANCE THE U.S. SUPPORTS HIM FULLY
description: Amin Gemayel, the embattled Lebanese President, paused for a long time today before answering a reporter's question on the strength of the American commitment to his efforts to stay in power.

title: Walker Filling Knick Role
description: As he slumped against the locker-room wall with a look of exhausted relief, it was easy to perceive what Darrell Walker was feeling moments after being a prime force in the team's 138-112 rout of the Denver Nuggets Saturday night.

title: SYSTEM REDESIGN IS CONSIDERED
description: Two brakes failed as the Challenger landed here and a possible collision with a bird damaged some heat-shielding tiles, but space agency officials said today that the space shuttle should be ready to fly again, as scheduled, early in April.

title: Pay-As-You-Build Power
description: ''CWIP'' could be the unintentional witticism of a bad speller. Actually, it's an acronym for ''Construction Work In Progress'' fees, an idea at the core of a debate between consumer groups and electric utilities. Last week the House joined the battle, approving a bill that would make it difficult for Federal regulators to order consumers to pay any portion of building power plants before they begin operation.

title: POP: TABU LEY ROCHEREAU AT SAVOY
description: TWO of the most popular musicians in Zaire, and in all of French-speaking Africa, have passed through New York recently. The singer Tabu Ley Rochereau performed with his Orchestre Afrisa International at the Savoy on Friday; in December, the singer-guitarist Franco and T.P.O.K. Jazz appeared at the Manhattan Center.

title: Cake Mix Recalled For EDB in Jersey
description: Governor Kean today ordered the recall of some Duncan Hines Deluxe Devil's Food Cake Mix in New Jersey after tests found high levels of EDB.

title: SOUTHERN PRACTICE OF EATING DIRT SHOWS SIGNS OF WANING
description: It's after a rainfall, when the earth smells so rich and damp and flavorful, that Fannie Glass says she most misses having some dirt to eat.

title: ISRAEL RENEWS SEARCH FOR OIL
description: The Israelis, having relinquished to Egypt the oil and gas fields they discovered in the Sinai Desert, are stepping up their search for oil at home.

title: SYRIA WARNS U.S. NOT TO CONTINUE NAVAL SHELLING
description: A senior Syrian official said today that Syria would not continue to exercise ''self-restraint'' if American shelling of its positions in Lebanon persisted.

title: Bank Merger Set in Jersey
description: The New Jersey National Corporation plans to buy Citizens Bancorp of Vineland, N.J., for $30.4 million in cash.

title: CHERNENKO ARTICLE CITED NEED FOR IMPROVED U.S. RELATIONS
description: Konstantin U. Chernenko, a member of the Soviet Politburo who could succeed the late Yuri V. Andropov, said in an article published here today that improving relations with the United States was ''more important than ever before.''

title: MISS HAMALAINEN OF FINLAND WINS 2D GOLD MEDAL
description: Marja-Liisa Hamalainen of Finland became the first athlete to win two gold medals at the XIV Olympic Winter Games today with a 10.1- second victory over Norway's Berit Aunli in the 5-kilometer cross-country ski race on Veliko Polje.

title: Panels to Discuss The Broadway Musical
description: The future of the Broadway musical will be discussed by theater professionals and critics in a six-part series beginning March 1 at the 92d Street Y. Moderating will be the author Martin Gottfried.

title: Explosion Kills Prospector
description: A dynamite explosion in an ''old, hole-in- the-rock gold mine'' in foothills near the California-Nevada border killed one prospector and seriously injured another man, the authorities said Saturday.

title: Debt Issues
description: * National Health Corp., of Murfreesboro, Tenn., offered $21 million of 8 3/4 percent convertible subordinated debentures due 1999 priced at 100 through Prudential-Bache Securities Inc.

title: LINGERING BUS CRISIS
description: News Analysis

title: PRINCETON LEADS IVY LEAGUE
description: Although Princeton leads the nation defensively and is in first place in the Ivy League, Coach Pete Carril insists the league title will be contested by several teams.

title: QUESTION BOX
description: QUESTION: Team A punts from its 5-yard line in a National Football League game. The punt is blocked by Team B, and the ball goes out of the end zone. What is the ruling? Also, what happens if Team A last touches the blocked punt before it goes out of the end zone?

title: JAPAN'S RULING PARTY LOOKS FOR PARTNERS
description: After nearly three decades of governing alone, Japan's Liberal Democratic Party has begun to look for partners in the opposition to strengthen its hold on government.

title: German Industry Busy
description: The use of West German industrial capacity rose to 80.7 percent in December from 75.4 a year earlier, the Economic Research Institute reported today.

description: Revenue figures represent commissions and fees. Corrected from Saturday's editions.

STEWART INFORMATION SERVICES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31

title: U.S. SAYS THE CHERNENKO SPEECH HINTS DOOR MAY BE OPEN TO TALKS
description: The United States said today that it welcomed some apparently conciliatory comments in the speech by the new Soviet leader, Konstantin U. Chernenko. American officials said the comments suggested that the door might be open to reviving a dialogue.

title: TUESDAY SPORTS Basketball
description: Nets vs. Cleveland Cavaliers , at Richfield, Ohio. The Nets, 2-0 against the Cavaliers this season, have not lost to them in more than three years, a streak of 16 games.

title: NEPAL: A TREK THROUGH A FOREST IN CRISIS
description: FOLIAGE is shaking in a tree to the left. It may be a monkey. No. A man with an ax is cutting branches, getting food for his buffalo. Another cut into Nepal's depleted forests.

title: FUN AND GAMES AT TOY FAIR
description: Nick Pannone turned to his opponent, Donna Miller. ''Don't knock out my communications,'' he said Pow! She gleefully scored a bull's-eye on Rampage Rock, his headquarters in the Flash Force 2000 game.

title: BR COMMUNICATIONS BARRY RESEARCH CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
ACTION GROUP AROUSED BY NICKELODEON AD PLAN
description: For 13 hours a day, Nickelodeon entices, instructs, entertains and terrifies children with tasteless jokes, deft biographies (Golda Meir and Mahatma Gandhi and their resistance to British authority in Israel and India in the same half hour), scientific experiments (How to make a homemade volcano), a five-hour electronic sandbox (gentle programming for pre- school children) and scary adventure fiction (a 13-year-old girl conjures up the angry ghost of a man who has been dead for more than 200 years).

title: WHEREHOUSE ENTERTAINMENT INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Open Hatches Blamed in Sinking
description: The fishing boat Joan La Rie III, which sank off North Jersey in 1982 with the loss of eight lives, went down because water rushed through open hatches that should have been secured, according to a Government report released today.

title: Bridge: A Her Well in New York
description: In the 1973 world team championship, the United States team included a father-and-son combination from New York: B. Jay Becker, who had won his third world title 20 years earlier, and Michael Becker, who was to win his first 10 years later.

title: Judge Orders Suspect To Confess From Pulpit
description: Under orders from a Federal judge, a man stood up in his boyhood church Sunday and confessed he helped sell a stolen truck, then asked the congregation to ''forgive me and pray for me.''

title: SAVING INJURED HORSES
description: FOR years thoroughbred horses that suffer severe leg injuries while racing have had to be destroyed.

title: Griffith Gets Raise
description: Calvin Griffith , the owner of the Minnesota Twins, who is not known for extravagant spending, confirmed yesterday that he is receiving a raise this year even though his American League club lost almost $1.8 million last season.

title: CONCERT: CALLIOPE
description: CALLIOPE, the early music group, joined Frederic Hand, the lutanist, at the Abraham Goodman House Saturday night in a trip through the heart of the Renaissance. There were Italian instrumental pieces from both the beginning and the end of the 16th century, and finally, music from England's rich Tudor period.

title: A Valentine Call: To Arms!
description: A Nashville store is urging men to give their valentines a pistol this year.

title: HOUSTON, COASTAL END MERGER BATTLE
description: The Coastal Corporation and the Houston Natural Gas Corporation ended their takeover struggle yesterday with a joint announcement that they had withdrawn their offers to acquire each other and had dropped all pending litigation.

title: DEBBIE ARMSTRONG JUST SKIING FOR FUN
description: SARAJEVO, Yugoslavia

title: Fruit Destroyed After EDB Tests
description: One hundred cases of imported Sicilian blood oranges have been destroyed after laboratory tests found they contained high levels of the pesticide EDB, New Jersey health officials said today.

title: U.S. CAPTURES GIANT SLALOM AND TAKES FIRST GOLD MEDAL
description: The United States, which had won only one medal in the first four days of full-scale competition at the XIV Olympic Winter Games, picked up two more today when Debbie Armstrong won the gold and Christin Cooper the silver in the women's giant slalom.

title: NEW YORK ; SCHOOLYARD RECREATION
description: A state agency known as the Division of Substance Abuse Services has done another study on the availability of drugs in the vicinity of New York City schools.

title: SALVADOR IS FAULTED ON DIVERSION OF AID IN AUDITORS' REPORT
description: The Salvadoran Government lacks an effective mechanism for preventing the diversion of United States aid money, according to a confidential report prepared for the Agency for International Development.

description: The presidents of more than 100 Irish-American organizations that participate in the St. Patrick's Day Parade nominated three men last night to be the grand marshal.

title: MARITIME CONFEREES NEAR VOTE
description: A House-Senate conference committee is expected to approve a compromise bill next week to grant American shipping companies broader immunity from antitrust laws.

description: The three Lebanese, two women and a man, are Christians who live in East Beirut. They have suffered some inconvenience in the last week, since they live about 50 yards from the so-called green line, across which Moslem militiamen in West Beirut and Lebanese Army soldiers in the east shoot at each other day and night.

description: Graduates of private and public colleges and universities in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut are sending donations to their alma maters in record amounts, college fund-raisers report.

title: Weeks Working
description: When they demoted Steve Weeks to their minor league farm club in Tulsa earlier this month, the Rangers said they expected the goalie to return to New York in two weeks. Based on his performance so far, he is ready to come back.

description: A 71-year-old man who was assaulted and robbed of $200 in a Lower East Side subway station drew his licensed .38-caliber revolver and shot his teen-age attacker in the stomach Sunday night, the police said.

title: European Energy Use
description: Energy consumption in Common Market countries fell 1 percent in 1983, the fourth year in a row, but is expected to rise slightly this year, the trade bloc's headquarters said today.

title: INDIANA UTILITY URGES RATE INCREASE
description: The Public Service Company of Indiana, which has canceled completion of its Marble Hill nuclear plant, will be forced into bankruptcy proceedings unless it is allowed a 14 percent emergency rate increase totaling $105 million a year, the company said.

title: Stable Oil Price Seen by Briton
description: The chief executive officer of the British National Oil Corporation, Ian Goskirk, said today that he thought oil prices had bottomed and that the next several years would see a period of worldwide price stability. He said at an investment seminar that there was also evidence of demand bottoming out, as was apparent in the increases reported for the last two quarters of 1983.

description: President Mohammad Zia ul-Haq, speaking amid growing speculation about Pakistan's nuclear research, said today that his Government had no plans to make a nuclear bomb.

title: SYRIAN FEAR: SOVIET SHIFT
description: Yuri V. Andropov's death has revived an undercurrent of Syrian anxiety about its relationship to the Soviet Union, according to Syrian officials and Western diplomats here. A high-level delegation that included Syria's Defense Minister, Lieut. Gen. Mustafa Tlas, left Damascus today to attend Mr. Andropov's funeral.

No contract figures were released, but The Boston Globe reported that Boggs would be paid $475,000 plus incentive bonuses, an increase from the $125,000 he earned last season in his second year with Boston. . . . Ricky Rudd , hospitalized overnight for injuries sustained in a crash Sunday at the Daytona International Raceway, was released yesterday and made a brief appearance at the raceway's garage area. He had two black eyes and multiple bruises, but no serious injuries.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE;
description: CITYSCAPE Raymond Hood is not a name that sparks instant recognition, but it is a signature etched on some of the most graceful stones of midtown Manhattan. Hood was an architect, one of the most celebrated designers of skyscrapers during the period when skyscrapers were the exclamation points of modern civilization. His handiwork is evident in the RCA Building in Rockefeller Center, the beguilingly green McGraw-Hill Building on West 42d Street, the American Radiator Building on the south side of Bryant Park and The Daily News Building on East 42d Street.

Starring two very talented performers, Mimi Kennedy and Jeff Goldblum, Aubrey Wertheim's ''Popular Neurotics'' is a sometimes clever but always insubstantial romantic comedy.

title: Waste Management

Revenues of the waste disposal company rose 4.6 percent, to $274 million, from $262 million. For the year as a whole, Waste Management earned $120 million, a 13.2 percent gain over 1982's profit of $106 million.

description: Diebold Inc. said yesterday that Robert W. Mahoney had been elected president.

title: Tupperware at Y.& R.
description: Young & Rubicam's Chicago office and Stone & Adler, a direct marketing subsidiary, are going to be working for Tupperware Home Parties, a division of Dart & Kraft. The advertiser was served by Batten, Barton, Durstine & Osborne for 25 years and did not have a specific direct marketing agency. According to B.B.D.O., the general advertising account billed less than $5 million last year and was going to be less in 1984. Y.& R. estimates billings at more than $6 million.

title: CAPITAL GOODS UPTURN SEEN
description: Thomas A. Holmes heads the Ingersoll-Rand Company, which has operations in 40 countries, selling compressors, pneumatic tools, turbines and other construction and industrial machinery.

description: Canada's Olympic hockey team is beginning to think, sound and play like the United States' 1980 miracle workers in Lake Placid.

title: EINSTEIN REVEALED AS BRILLIANT IN YOUTH
description: CONTRARY to a popular legend that has given comfort to countless slow starters, young Albert Einstein was remarkably gifted in mathematics, algebra and physics, academic records recently acquired from Swiss archives show.

title: Advertising; Crayola's Image: Just Toys
description: VISITORS to Toy Fair in Manhattan this week will be the first to judge whether Binney & Smith of Easton, Pa., made a wise move when it shifted its advertising account for the Crayola line last year to Needham, Harper & Steers.

title: Nicaraguan Arts Program
description: The Manhattan Theater Club will present an examination of Nicaraguan arts on March 12 at 7:30 P.M. at 321 East 73d Street. The program, arranged by Victoria Rue, will feature poetry, dance, theater, music, painting and film by Nicaraguan artists.

title: WHEN FEAR PAYS A VISIT TO A CARIBBEAN PARADISE
description: -A-PITRE, Guadeloupe, Feb. 11 - The month of February appeared to be off to a happy start in this busy island in the French West Indies. Carnival season was getting into swing, cruise ships were arriving almost daily and the resorts were full of tourists. Then the bombers struck.

title: HEART ATTACKS AND BEHAVIOR: EARLY SIGNS ARE FOUND
description: THE mother spoke encouragingly as her blindfolded young son tried to stack a pile of blocks. When time was up, she said, ''Next time try for six blocks.'' Another mother whose son was also taking part in the experiment said, ''Next time go a little faster.''

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: For Doctors, The Play's the Thing

title: SOVIET SAID TO SET CONDITIONS FOR U.N. FORCE IN LEBANON
description: The Soviet Union has indicated its willingness to support the formation of a United Nations force to monitor a cease-fire in Lebanon, a United Nations official said last night.

description: Tourists paid 26.4 million visits to this city last year, making it the most popular resort in the United States for the third year in a row, city and gaming officials said today.

title: 51% IN POLL CALL REAGAN VISIT TO THE FUNERAL UNNECESSARY
description: Despite solid majority support for greater efforts to reach accommodations with the Soviet Union, the American public apparently does not feel that President Reagan should have gone to the funeral of Yuri V. Andropov.

title: CONCERT: MESSIAEN
description: OLIVIER MESSIAEN is 75 years old this year, and the Chamber Music Society helped celebrate the event Sunday afternoon in Alice Tully Hall by playing his ''Quartet for the End of Time.''

title: Texas Prosecutor Links Black to Murder Pistol
description: Lenell Geter, a black engineer who says his armed robbery conviction resulted from racism, owned a gun that was used in a South Carolina murder, a prosecutor said today in a hearing.

title: A POSITIVE OUTLOOK HELPS HIGH JUMPER
description: Jim Howard stopped worrying about keeping up with the Stoneses, started accentuating the positive and this year the gangly high jumper from Alvin, Tex., expects to make the United States Olympic team ''not as a fluke, but because I deserve it.''

title: Contract Revision
description: The quarterback Bobby Hebert , who two weeks ago walked out of the Michigan Panthers' training camp in Tempe, Ariz., has signed a new contract with the United States Football League club and will return to training today. The club announced the signing last night after a bargaining session in Phoenix attended by Hebert, his agent, Greg Campbell , the Panthers' general manager and president, Vince Lombardi Jr. , and the Panthers' coach, Jim Stanley .

title: ST. JOHN'S DEFEATS BOSTON COLLEGE BY 3
description: After losing four close games in recent weeks, St. John's managed to win a tight game last night, defeating Boston College, 68-65, at Alumni Hall.

title: DIEN BIEN PHU: A FOOTNOTE TO ITS FALL
description: The United States Army drew up plans for a nuclear attack on the Vietnamese forces besieging the French at Dien Bien Phu in 1954, according to an official Army history.

title: SWEDE WINS IN CROSS-COUNTRY
description: On Friday morning, before the men's 30-kilometer cross-country ski race, Gunde Svan of Sweden woke up, leaned out of his window at the Hotel Igman and playfully shouted ''stop snowing'' to anyone willing to listen. Later that day, plodding on a soft, snowy course, Svan won a bronze medal.

title: The Empty Craters of Lebanon
description: How little we really know about what's happening in the Kremlin ought be clear from the fact that it was not until his funeral that we learned Yuri Andropov had a wife, named Tatyana. Instead of struggling to find meaning in the still-raw news from Moscow, therefore, Americans would do well this week to sort out the lessons of the failure of the Marine deployment in Lebanon.

title: GULFSTREAM LAND & DEVELOPENT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
THE BEACH IS FOR ALL
description: Nearly hidden between two palm trees along the celebrated coastal highway known as ''old A1A,'' right on the border of Duval County and St. Johns County, is a narrow beach path to the Atlantic Ocean. Even if you knew where to find it - and most people do not - you would be discouraged from stopping by red ''No Parking Any Time'' signs every 50 yards. You might, understandably, assume that the beaches of this wealthy community near Jacksonville were private. You would be wrong, though, because in Florida, as elsewhere along the South Atlantic coast, the land between the water and mean high tide belongs to the state and all of its people.

title: SHUTTLE TESTS CONTINUE
description: The cradles used to ferry two ill-fated communications satellites into space aboard the shuttle Challenger have been given a clean bill of health, space agency officials said today.

title: TEACHERS TELL OF POWERLESSNESS AND FRUSTRATION
description: AMERICANS tend to think of teachers as saints or servants, with low pay in either case. The saintly teacher, who persists in the memories of aging adults, inspires the young and solves problems that confound parents and politicians. Teachers as servants are pushed around by their superiors and insulted by the public. Their advice about education is generally ignored.

description: The Rev. Jesse Jackson said today that he might fly to Nicaragua next week to take part in celebrations by the leftist Sandinista Government commemorating the 50th anniversary of the death of Gen. Augusto Cesar Sandino.

title: TUESDAY, FEBRUARY 14, 1984 International
description: Konstantin U. Chernenko was chosen by the Soviet Communist Party's Central Committee to succeed Yuri V. Andropov as its General Secretary. His assumption of the post automatically made the 72-year-old Mr. Chernenko the Soviet Union's preeminent leader. The appointment marked what appeared to be a remarkable political comeback for Mr. Chernenko. (Page A1, Column 6.) Konstantin U. Chernenko is a Bolshevik of the old mold. He is widely regarded in Moscow as an ideologue low on formal education or managerial experience, but high on propaganda and party loyalty. (A1:5.)

title: Addenda
description: American Health magazine increasing by 23 percent its advertising rates and circulation rate base, to 800,000, from 650,000, with the July/ August issue.

title: PACE QUICKENS IN CELLULAR RADIO MARKET
description: Cellular radio, the computerized system that promises to make mobile telephone service available to many more people, is operating on a limited basis so far. It has started in just three cities - Chicago, Washington and Baltimore. But New York City will be added in a few months, and analysts are predicting a $3 billion market by 1990.

title: JULY SHUTTLE FLIGHT IN DOUBT
description: A secret military payload set for launching on the space shuttle in July has been cancelled, and the shuttle mission will be scrubbed without it, officials of the Air Force and National Aeronautics and Space Administration said tonight.

title: Dismissed Transsexual Pilot Wins $158,590 in Back Pay
description: A veteran pilot dismissed by Eastern Airlines after having a sex-change operation to become a woman was awarded $158,590 in back pay and expenses today by a Federal judge.

description: The Generals reduced their roster to 58 players yesterday by trading 2 players and releasing 10, including Dana Noel, who started 17 games last season at strong safety.

title: Japanese Gas Deal
description: A Japanese consortium has agreed in principle with the Government of Sharja to set up a $200 million liquefied petroleum gas plant in the emirate, Japanese officials said today. They said a consortium of the C. Itoh Company and the Japan Gas Corporation was preparing a draft agreement. Industry sources said the project would have a daily capacity of 300 million cubic feet of gas.

title: Peruvian Guerrillas Kill Soldier in Ambush
description: Leftist guerrillas ambushed an army patrol on Sunday and killed one soldier a block from police headquarters in this city, which is the base for antisubversion troops, police sources said today.

title: EX-U.S. ENVOY CALLS CHERNENKO DULLARD
description: Americans who have met Konstantin U. Chernenko, the new Soviet leader, say they were not particularly impressed with the caliber of his mind or his command of information.

title: CAT SCRATCH DISEASE
description: THERE was a time when doctors scoffed at the idea that certain enigmatic diseases might be caused by bacteria. After all, they reasoned, the laboratory methods of detecting bacteria had been so standard for so long that it seemed unlikely any organisms could have been missed.

description: b-Net loss.

title: NEW HEAD TRAVELS FAR FOR PACIFIC TELESIS UNIT

But in preparing for his role as president and chief executive of Pacific Telesis International, a newly formed subsidiary of California's Pacific Telesis Group, Mr. Sledge, now 43, has journeyed to China three times in recent months, as well as to other countries.

title: Miss Oceana Takes Hibiscus
description: Miss Oceana, generally considered the early favorite for this year's 3-year- old filly classics, won the Hibiscus Stakes at Hialeah Park today after Birdie Belle, who finished first, was disqualified.

title: DOW POSTS SHARP DROP OF 10.57, TO 1,150.13

title: CBS Joins Fight to Bar Compromise on Reruns
description: CBS has joined the two other major networks and broken off efforts to negotiate a compromise in its dispute with Hollywood producers over the right to own and sell reruns of prime- time television shows, Mary Boies, a CBS spokesman said yesterday.

title: COCA-COLA GAINED 2.7% IN 4TH QUARTER
description: The Coca-Cola Company said today that strong sales of soft drinks everywhere but in Latin America helped push its profit to $124.6 million, or 91 cents a share, in the fourth quarter of 1983, up 2.7 percent, from $121.3 million, or 89 cents a share, a year earlier.

title: HOW BILLIE WHITELAW INTERPRETS BECKETT
description: WERE Billie Whitelaw to teach a class or to give a demonstration in acting Beckett, it would be in stark contrast to Ian McKellen's evening of ''Acting Shakespeare.'' She would deal with such consequential minutiae as the quarter-pause, acting while blindfolded and acting only with one's eyes, synchronizing the rhythm of a rocking chair with one's own voice on tape; and she would discuss the dramatic power of stasis in performance.

title: PEI LOUVRE DESIGN APPROVED
description: President Francois Mitterrand announced today that he had given final approval to a rebuilding program for the Louvre Museum that includes a spectacular but controversial glass pyramid in its central gardens.

title: THE VERSATILE RAINCOAT FOR SPRING
description: Many women collect raincoats with the same enthusiasm that others buy shoes or sweaters. ''You wear them all summer and through November, then you start up again in March,'' said one of these collectors, who owns eight raincoats of different weights and is always in the market for more. ''I keep them for years,'' she said. ''They never go out of style.''

title: POPE'S 2 APPOINTMENTS: SOME CLUES FOR CATHOLICS
description: With the appointment of new Archbishops for New York and Boston, many Roman Catholics, while hesitant to draw firm conclusions, see some patterns they think might point the way toward the larger intentions of Pope John Paul II for the church in America. Both Bishop Bernard F. Law of Springfield-Cape Girardeau, Mo., who was named to head the Boston archdiocese on Jan. 24, and Bishop John J. O'Connor of Scranton, Pa., appointed to the New York see a week later, were plucked from small dioceses for two of the nation's most important church posts. Among their fellow bishops, both are highly regarded.

title: CONCERT: YEHUDI MENUHIN AND CINCINNATI ORCHESTRA
description: THE program for Michael Gielen's concert last night with the Cincinnati Symphony Orchestra at Carnegie Hall tried to make a case for the proposition that Franz Schubert and Alban Berg had a great deal in common as composers. Beginning with Schubert's Symphony No. 4 in C minor, the so-called ''Tragic,'' the orchestra's music director went on to Berg's Three Pieces for Orchestra (Op. 6), Schubert's Symphony No. 5 in B-flat and, finally, Berg's Violin Concerto, with Yehudi Menuhin as soloist. Obviously, parallels can be drawn in the careers of the two composers: Both worked in Vienna, for instance, Schubert at the bridge between the Classic and the Romantic periods, Berg at a time when Romantic movement was in its final throes and entering the modern era. However, the case for juxtaposing them can be made more persuasively in literary than in musical terms.

title: AMERICA, APPROACH SYRIA
description: The heat of United States diplomatic and military clashes with Syria should not be allowed to obscure the inevitable convergence of interests between Washington and Damascus. Controversial as it seems in today's atmosphere of confrontation, conversations in Damascus with top Government and Baath Party officials leave a visitor with the strong impression that Syria genuinely seeks to make a deal with the United States.

title: John R. Newell Is Dead at 71; President of Bath Iron Works
description: John R. Newell, former president of the Bath Iron Works Company, died of cancer Saturday in Boca Raton, Fla., after a four- year illness. He was 71 years old.

title: NEW ENTRANT REVIEWED
description: The current battle in the personal computer revolution seems to be for the consumer's hands - and feet. It centers on the obvious fact that, to be of any use, a computer must be controllable by the operator. The traditional way of accomplishing this is through a typewriter-like keyboard.

There were brief cycles by Frank Martin, Ravel and Faure and then two New York premieres - Pia Gilbert's ''Vociano'' and ''Strand Settings: 'Darker' '' by Mel Powell. United Bankers, with subsidiary banks in Waco, Bryan, Port Arthur, Marlin, Madisonville and Commerce, has assets of about $535 million. Texas Southwest, a holding company, is the parent of Southwest Bank of Mesquite and Southwest Bank in Garland, which is being organized.

description: President Ricardo de la Espriella of Panama resigned today without explanation, the Panamanian Government announced. He was immediately replaced by Vice President Jorge Illueca.

title: BIRTH CURB IN CHINA
description: ''NOVA'' looks tonight at China's ambitious attempt to control its overpopulation, although the larger topic of the program may be the fabric, weave and collective psyche of China itself. In 1980, Peking declared that each Chinese family would be allowed to have but a single child. Policy, in effect, countermanded tradition, culture and, one assumes, the deepest desires of many Chinese. A fascinating report, ''China's Only Child,'' will be seen on Channel 13 at 8 P.M.

title: Symon Adds Hoffritz
description: Symon & Hilliard has become agency for the Hoffritz for Cutlery chain, which had been served by Warren Pfaff Inc. The chain has 52 stores in 15 states, according to James Symon, chairman. He said the billings would be $2 million. Add that to the recently won General Electric assignment for business-to-business advertising for major appliances, and the new, unnamed automotive product from a longtime client, Fram, and you have a pleasant outlook for 1984.

title: 2D 'SMITHSONIAN WORLD'
description: ''CROSSING THE DISTANCE,'' the second in the ''Smithsonian World'' series, is more or less about how we get from one place to another. The program itself stops off here and there, admiring this and that, a serendipitous journey. Most of the trip is pleasant, and one stopover, a visit to Anne Morrow Lindbergh, is memorable. ''Crossing the Distance'' will be seen on Channel 13 at 8 o'clock tonight.

The news director of KASI, Rich Fellingham, and a morning announcer, Johhny Gray, were taken to a nearby hospital, treated and released after the microphone short-circuited.

title: SOLO CLIMBER REACHES TOP OF MCKINLEY
description: Naomi Uemura has become the first person to climb Mount McKinley alone in the winter, but has he met stormy weather descending from the highest peak in North America and may be temporarily stranded on the mountain, officials said today.

title: Olympic Notebook; CZECHS, CANADIANS KEY GAME
description: For the United States hockey team, which plays Finland Wednesday night, the goal now is fifth place. But for Canada and Czechoslovakia, the stakes are considerably higher when they also meet that night.

title: Ex-Bell Units' New Shares
description: The American Telephone and Telegraph Company said that 3.3 million stock certificates will be mailed out Wednesday to the new shareholders of the seven regional companies taking over local phone systems. A.T.& T. said the shares, which will be mailed by its American Transtech unit, were the first of 16 million to be issued. Wednesday will also be the last day that the stock of the seven regional companies, traded on the New York Stock Exchange, will be traded on a when-issued basis, and the last day shares of the pre-divestiture A.T.& T. will trade. On Thursday, regular trading of the ''new'' A.T.& T. and the regional holding companies will begin on the New York Stock Exchange.

These players from East Berlin, who are members of the Berlin Radio Symphony Orchestra, also have a string style similar to their colleagues from Leipzig.

title: SIS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
FOR REAGAN, A CROSSFIRE
description: With the Lebanese Government under severe strain and United States Middle East policy in considerable disarray, President Reagan found himself caught today in a crossfire of competing pressures from Israel and moderate Arab leaders. Although the Administration is trying to persuade all sides that the President's decision last week to pull back American marines from Beirut does not signal any shift in policy, both Arab and Israeli officials said they sensed that American policy was in flux after setbacks in Lebanon.

title: Radioactive Tables Continue to Turn Up United Press International
description: Metal institutional tables, contaminated with radiation emitting hourly levels equal to several chest or dental X-rays, are being discovered by the thousands in hotels and restaurants around the nation.

title: Gourdine Leaving Consumer Post
description: Simon P. Gourdine, the City Consumer Affairs Commissioner for two years, announced his resignation yesterday to become secretary of the Rockefeller Foundation.

title: Grenada Asks $150 Million
description: The leader of Grenada's interim government, Nicholas Brathwaite, said today that he would seek $150 million in aid to complete the island's airport and carry out other projects. He spoke at a meeting of the Caribbean Group for Cooperation and Economic Development sponsored by the World Bank. The group was established in 1977 to coordinate aid to 14 Caribbean nations from 18 donor countries and 29 international organizations.

title: Coach Suspended
description: Marvin Adams, the basketball coach at Arkansas State, has been dealt a one-game suspension by the Southland Conference for his public criticism of the officiating at a game against Lamar last month. Adams had accused the referees of being intimidated by the crowd during the opening minutes of the game, played in Beaumont, Tex.

title: START REHABILITATING RELATIONS WITH SOVIET
description: The change of leadership in Moscow provides both dilemmas and opportunities for the United States.

title: GUARDS WITH DOGS SET FOR LAGUARDIA IN A TWO-YEAR PACT
description: After a successful one-year experiment, security guards with dogs will begin patrolling the parking garage at La Guardia Airport on a regular basis next month to reduce auto-related thefts.

description: While the nation's attention has been drawn to the stage of Presidential politics, the development of small, affordable computers of great capacity has begun to change the character of American election campaigns at the Congressional, state and local levels.

title: BENIHANA NATIONAL reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 1

title: City and Area Sales Show Smaller Gain
description: New York's big retailers showed an average 4.1 percent sales gain in the city and a 5.9 percent increase in the metropolitan area in January compared with last year, a monthly spot- check found yesterday. But the January performance was a weak conclusion to a strong retailing fiscal year, which ran from Feb. 1, 1983, to Jan. 28.

title: PERSONAL HEALTH
description: ARE you tired of trying to exercise on icy streets or returning home from your run soaked by rain, covered with mud or with your scarf frozen to your face? Are you thinking of joining a health club so you can forget about the weather during your workout? Fine, if you can afford it. But the first thing you should do is to investigate.

title: DISPUTE MARKS JURY SCREENING IN BRINK'S TRIAL
description: Jury screening began today for the final Brink's robbery and murder trial, with defense lawyers saying that pretrial publicity had prejudiced nearly half of those who had indicated that they were prepared to be jurors. The trial is expected to last six months.

title: IRAQ ATTACKS IRANIAN TOWNS, THEN PROPOSES TRUCE
description: Iraq staged air and missile attacks today against six Iranian towns and said they were in retaliation for Iranian shelling of Iraqi towns on Monday. The Iraqi Government then announced that it would halt such attacks for a week if the Iranians did the same.
