title: Canada Cup Tourney Set
description: Alan Eagleson announced today that final agreement has been reached for a six-team Canada Cup hockey tournament for 1984 that will end with a two-of-three-game final series. After meeting with officials of the countries involved, Eagleson, international negotiator for Hockey Canada, said the tournament would begin ''on or about'' Sept. 1 in eastern Canada and end Sept. 18 in the western part of the country.

description: Vice President Bush met with Konstantin U. Chernenko today and said afterward that the new Soviet leader agreed on the need ''to place our relationship upon a more constructive path.''

description: The Dorchester Gas Company said yesterday that the financing for its proposed leveraged buyout had not been obtained and that the status of the loan described in the company's proposal was ''problematical.''

title: METROPOLITAN DIARY
description: VALENTINE'S DAY was yesterday, dear hearts. Expect no romantic treacle in this space. Stand by instead for a real-life tale of boy-meets-girl in the fast-track in the 80's. The scene is the IRT Seventh Avenue Express in rush hour. Victoria Smith is clinging to a pole. A young man, fairly well-dressed, with briefcase, squeezes through the closing doors at 72d Street. He joins her at the pole. His eyes travel from her boots to her coat to her face.

title: 9 Are Reported Killed During Strike in India

In any event, it can be seen tonight at 8 on cable systems carrying the pay-television channel.

title: The Police Blotter
description: Martin Boulay, 15 years old, of Brooklyn, was stabbed to death outside Tilden High School at about 2:30 P.M. yesterday by a man who had argued with him and then fled, according to the police. . . . In a dispute between two owners of a bar in Brooklyn Heights shortly before midnight Monday, the police said, Richard Maroon, 50, was shot and critically wounded by Anthony Amato, 57. Mr. Amato drove him to the emergency room of Long Island College Hospital and was then charged with second-degree assault and illegal possession of a weapon. . . . Larry Caiell, 32, was fatally shot on 145th Street near St. Nicholas Avenue in Harlem at 8 A.M. in what was apparently an argument over drugs, the police said.

Rose Kennedy's Car Stolen
description: Rose Kennedy's automobile was stolen while she attended church with her daughter Eunice Shriver Sunday but it was recovered within hours, the police reported today.

title: APPEALS COURT ACTS ON ALCOHOL LABELS
description: An appeals court has backed the Treasury Department in its decision to drop a requirement that labels on alcoholic beverages list all ingredients. However, the court left the way open for new lawsuits on the issue.

description: A Better Bike

title: SEIBERT DUO OF U.S. IS FOURTH
description: - The scoreboard lighted up with the marks of the nine judges, and the numbers made history. Jayne Torvill and Christopher Dean of Britain won the ice-dancing gold medal in the XIV Olympic Winter Games tonight, and every judge had given them a perfect score of 6.0 for artistic impression.

title: Rouge Contract
description: The Rouge Steel Corporation, a unit of the Ford Motor Company, said it had awarded a contract for a continuous- slab casting plant outside Detroit to a consortium headed by the Mitsubishi International Corporation of Japan. The continuous caster will be built by Mannessmann Demag of West Germany and Hitachi-Zosen of Japan, the Ford unit said. It said the computer- controlled, two-strand, variable- width casters will produce steel slabs about 8 inches thick and 38 to 75 inches wide and will have an annual capacity of 1.8 million tons, half of Rouge's capacity.

title: Warning on Snuff Is Sought
description: A consumer group asked the Government today to require health warnings similar to those for cigarettes in advertisements and labels for chewing tobacco and tobacco snuff. In a letter to James Miller, the Federal Trade Commission chairman, Public Citizen, a group founded by Ralph Nader, said consumers must be alerted to the ''now well-established link between the use of such products and oral cancer.'' The Smokeless Tobacco Council, a trade group based in Peekskill, N.Y., said in a statement that ''any effort to curtail advertisements is unwarranted.''

title: Ex-Jersey Mayor Given 3 1/2 Years
description: A Federal judge sentenced former Mayor Wally P. Lindsley of Weehawken today to three and a half years in prison for conspiracy, but allowed him to remain free pending an appeal.

title: ARCO APPROACHED GULF, BUT DID NOT MAKE BID
description: The Atlantic Richfield Company acknowledged yesterday that its chairman, Robert O. Anderson, had met with top executives of the Gulf Corporation and the Mesa Petroleum Company. Mr. Anderson said in a brief statement that he had not made a formal offer to buy Gulf.

title: Notes of an Underground Art Critic
description: The F train was disappointing today. Kendo, Boop! and Super Stud are still smearing the same old stuff, and whoever took a chisel to the tiles at 53d and Fifth obviously doesn't understand bas-relief.

title: AIR QUALITY RULE MIGHT BE CHANGED
description: The Environmental Protection Agency indicated today that it intended to go ahead with a change in a key air pollution standard that critics say could significantly loosen current requirements.

title: PAN AM NARROWS DEFICIT
description: Pan American World Airways announced yesterday that it had narrowed its losses for the fourth quarter and for the year and had posted an operating profit for the year, its first since 1979.

title: Israeli Official Assails U.S. for Not Consulting
description: Israel's Deputy Prime Minister complained today to American Jewish spokesmen that the Reagan Administration had not consulted Israel before deciding to move the marines to ships off Beirut or before inviting President Hosni Mubarak of Egypt and King Hussein of Jordan to Washington for talks.

title: GIRL, 6, UNDERGOES DUAL TRANSPLANT
description: A young Texas girl was recovering today from what doctors described as the first operation in which both the heart and the liver were transplanted.

title: LOWER FIFTH AVE. GREETS REFUGEES FROM MIDTOWN
description: When Geer, DuBois Inc., a well-established advertising agency, left 1 Dag Hammarskjold Plaza in 1981 for 61,000 square feet of commercial loft space on lower Fifth Avenue at 16th Street, its executives were considered daring pioneers by others in the advertising field. But since then they have been joined by many other companies fleeing the high rents and tight space of midtown Manhattan.

title: OPERA: CAST CHANGES IN THE MET'S 'RINALDO'
description: BEING asked to take the place of an opera star of Marilyn Horne's magnitude in a part she has claimed as her own is not an enviable assignment for any singer, let alone a comparatively unknown one. But that intimidating task fell last night to Ewa Podles, a Polish mezzo-soprano who made her Metropolitan Opera debut in the title role of Handel's ''Rinaldo.'' Although she fell considerably short of scoring a total triumph, Miss Podles proved herself a singer of real vocal quality whose smallish but flexible voice should suit her for many other roles in the coloratura mezzo repertory.

title: Train's Engineer Convicted
description: Edward Peyton Robertson, a former railroad engineer, was found guilty today of being reckless in his handling of a mile-long train that derailed Sept. 28, 1982, bursting into flames and forcing 2,700 residents to leave their homes for two weeks to avoid toxic fumes. Mr. Robertson, who was accused of being drunk on the job, was the first person to be tried under Louisiana's new law making it a crime to handle hazardous cargo recklessly. He faces a maximum penalty of 10 years in prison and a fine of $10,000.

title: Defense Rests in Texas In Death of Infant Girl
description: Defense attorneys today unexpectedly rested their case without calling the defendant, Genene Jones, to testify about the death of a 15-month- old girl in her care.

title: Comings and Goings
description: Pelle Lindbergh , the Philadelphia goalie who has gone from a National Hockey League all-star to a backup in a little more than a year, was demoted yesterday to the Flyers' farm club in Springfield, Mass., for more work. . . . Sylvain Turgeon , Hartford's leading goal-scorer, suffered a mild concussion in the Whalers' 11-0 victory over the Edmonton Oilers Sunday and may be out of the lineup 10 days. . . . Ron Chismar , offensive coordinator at Arizona State, has been chosen to succeed Willie Jeffries as head football coach at Wichita State. Jeffries resigned last month to become coach at Howard University. . . . Stanley Floyd , the former world-class sprinter who has been trying for a pro football career, was cut by the Los Angeles Express of the United States Football League.

title: Study of Blacks
description: Black major league baseball players have lost ground in key leadership positions over the last two decades, according to a study by a sports sociologist. In an article in The Journal of Sport and Social Issues, John Phillips, a professor at the University of the Pacific in Stockton, Calif., said that, of all the players in the traditional leadership positions of catcher, second baseman and shortstop, the number of blacks had declined from 25 percent to 14 percent from 1960 to 1982. At the same time, he said, the percentage of blacks in the outfield rose from 54 to 64 percent. Prof. Phillips said the widening disparity reflected a substantial increase in discrimination.

Free and Cavaliers Defeat Nets, 103-93 RICHFIELD, Ohio, Feb. 14 (AP) - World B. Free, returning from a back injury that kept him out of three games, scored 18 points in the second quarter tonight as the Cleveland Cavaliers built a 27-point half-time lead on the way to a 103-93 victory over the New Jersey Nets.
description: Free, who finished with 30 points, entered the game in the second quarter as Cleveland moved from a lead of 30-18 in the first quarter to a 61-34 lead at the half - the Cavaliers' biggest intermission lead of the National Basketball Association season.

title: ANDROPOV 'HARDLY MADE A START' TOWARD 'SOME SORT OF ORDER'
description: Barely 15 months have passed since the day Yuri V. Andropov stood atop Lenin's tomb and delivered a eulogy at Leonid I. Brezhnev's funeral. Moscow is in mourning once more, but this time the city has said farewell to Mr. Andropov himself. When Mr. Brezhnev died, most people in this country reacted with an indifference that surprised Western correspondents - in fact, most people greeted the news with carefully disguised relief. But Mr. Andropov's demise evoked in many ordinary people sorrow, grief - even anxiety. ''He hardly made a start on putting things in some sort of order and already - death,'' many could be heard saying.

title: WEDNESDAY, FEBRUARY 15, 1984 International
description: Druse militiamen won a major victory over Lebanese Army units in the mountains southeast of Beirut. After 18 hours of ground fighting, artillery duels and air strikes, the army's Fourth Brigade said it had been forced to abandon strategic positions along a ridge overlooking the capital. title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: THE PLACE OF DEAD ROADS. By William Burroughs. 306 pages. Holt, Rinehart & Winston. $15.95. IN 1983, William Burroughs was named a member of the American Academy and Institute of Arts and Letters. After finishing his new novel, I thought about that election and it inspired a fantasy. I pictured Mr. Burroughs getting up in an auditorium and reading ''The Place of Dead Roads'' to that august body. What would they do, I wondered, while he detailed the book's accounts of casual and indistinguishable acts of sodomy, its gloating over sadistic killings, its repeated evocations of putrescence and excrement? Would they applaud? Burst into tears? Or just sit there and nod?

HOW G.E. WON 'ENGINE WAR'
description: On the eve of the Air Force's recent announcement of the winner of its ''great engine war,'' Brian H. Rowe, the head of General Electric's engine group, was too nervous to sleep. After tossing about for hours in his bed in his hotel room in New York, he got up and watched a series of reruns on early morning TV. It was to be a long day.

title: POLAROID CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
TELECI INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income.

title: ANDROPOV BURIED AMID SOMBER MARTIAL GRANDEUR
description: Yuri V. Andropov was buried today in Red Square amid the somber military grandeur that also marked the funeral of Leonid I. Brezhnev, his predecessor, 15 months ago.

title: NATIONS SEEK KEY TO GROWTH
description: A broad agreement that public spending must be curbed and business executives must be freed from governmental red tape before industrial economies can reduce unemployment has emerged from an informal two-day meeting here of finance ministers.

title: Court Relief, but Not Roulette
description: In his concern for the overcrowding of court calendars, Chief Justice Warren Burger urges a rule change that could work severe hardship and injustice. Speaking to the American Bar Association, he has called for study of a rule that would stiffly penalize anyone who rejects an opponent's offer to settle if he then loses at trial or wins less than the offered amount. The cost of guessing wrong would be to have to pay the fees of the opposing lawyers from the time they offered a deal.

title: DANCE: NINA MARTIN OFFERS HER 'ON THE OTHER HAND'
description: NINA MARTIN kept trying to present a dance called ''On the Other Hand'' Sunday night at Performance Space 122. It appeared to be a brisk, rigorous dance. And between its episodes came solemn films of agitated facial expressions and jolly films of dancers in the streets.

title: Article 249838 -- No Title
description: A restaurant has been closed by a local magistrate for charging the actor Kirk Douglas and

title: CHILI'S INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Porsche Picks Nevada
description: Porsche International, the West German sports car manufacturer, said today that it would establish its United States headquarters in Reno. Porsche's distribution agreement with Volkswagen of America Inc. ends Sept. 1.

title: Original USA Today Begins Accepting Ads
description: The original USA Today, in no way related to Gannett's national newspaper, is the 112-year-old, 160,000 circulation publication of the Society for the Advancement of Education. Its format alternates from month to month between a magazine and a newsletter.

title: PUPILS BOYCOTT QUEENS SCHOOL OVER PRINCIPAL
description: A number of students at Public School 45 in South Ozone Park, Queens, did not attend school yesterday and Tuesday in a protest over a new principal.

title: WHEN HIRING A PRO TO RUN A TAG SALE
description: WHEN Janet Holmes made plans to move from her large house to an apartment in Westchester, she did what many people do these days. Even before calling the moving company, she telephoned the tag-sale professionals. ''I had a houseful to sell, and I knew I couldn't tackle the job without help,'' she recalled. ''I didn't know enough about pricing or how to set up a sale or attract customers. Besides, I didn't want to watch while people commented and pulled apart the things I've lived with and loved for years.''

title: JACKSON SAYS HE FAVORS TAKING NICARAGUAN TRIP
description: The Rev. Jesse Jackson is making preparations to go to Nicaragua next week just as the 1984 American political season enters the first round of voting.

title: MIDLAND CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a loss of $56,000 for the quarter and a gain of $706,000 for the year from discontinued operations.

title: INDEPENDENT INSURANCE GROUP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After capital losses of $4,135,000 for the quarter and $1,354,000 for the year. c-After a capital loss of $445,000. d-After a capital gain of $357,000.

title: THEATER: 'BABALOONEY'
description: EVER since the advent of the Second City troupe, Chicago has been a fertile spawning ground for improvisational comedy revues. Let us hope that ''Babalooney,'' the new revue imported from Chicago to the Provincetown Playhouse, is not indicative of the current state of the art. Though this attempt at a low-budget ''Hellzapoppin''' aspires to be silly, it settles for much less. The evening is mostly innocuous.

title: ON SCALING DOWN DEFENSE AMBITIONS
description: Defense is not obscenely expensive, just prohibitively expensive. The defense budget is the price of our foreign policy, but the connection is not always clear. The cost would matter little if the nation could easily afford its defense program, but this is far from the case. We are faced with a crisis of national solvency, and defense must take its share of large cuts in spending. This means scaling down our ambitious defense program. The central question is: What can America do without?

title: Statistical Formula Used
description: The Justice Department's decision to deny the proposed merger of the LTV Corporation and the Republic Steel Corporation leans heavily on a statistical tool called the Herfindahl-Hirschman Index that has been embraced by Government antitrust enforcers within the last two years.

title: Finland's Jobless Rate
description: Unemployment in Finland rose to 6.8 percent in January, with 158,700 people unemployed, the Labor Ministry said today. The jobless rate was 6.2 percent in December, with 155,500 people out of work.

title: SOUTH AMERICAN DEMOCRACY
description: A democratic tide is sweeping over South America. In country after country, military juntas have returned to the barracks, and the establishment and consolidation of democracy are at the top of the political agenda.

title: 3 FURNITURE CRAFTSMEN AT HOME
description: THE woodworkers Jon Brooks, Edward Zucca and Hank Gilpin contour their furniture in forms that range from organic to Art Deco to spare. The back- to-the-earth look that issues from Mr. Brooks's New Hampshire studio differs from the space-age cut-ups made by Mr. Zucca in Connecticut and the trim simplicity of Mr. Gilpin's Rhode Island pieces.

title: Mitterrand's E.E.C. Plea
description: President Francois Mitterrand of France urged the 10 nations of the European Economic Community today to make compromises to facilitate reforming the nearly bankrupt community.

title: GJON MILI, LIFE MAGAZINE PHOTOGRAPHER, DIES
description: Gjon Mili, one of the first photographers to use the electronic flash to capture people and things that move too fast for the naked eye, died of pneumonia Tuesday at the Courtland Gardens Convalescent Home in Stamford, Conn. He was 79 years old and had lived in Manhattan.

title: Utility's Offering Increased in Size
description: The Philadelphia Electric Company's issue of 14 1/2 percent sinking fund debentures due in 2009 was increased to $150 million from $125 million and was all sold at a price of 100, according to underwriters led by Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc.

description: b-Includes investment gains of $31,100,000 for the quarter and $134,500,000 for the year. c-After an investment loss of $14,800,000 for the quarter and an investment gain of $26,800,000 for the year.

title: Olympic Notebook; Chinese Compete to Learn
description: Zhang Tingquan, sports editor of Xinhua, the New China News Agency, heads a group of four reporters, one photographer and one technician that arrived last week to cover the 37 Chinese ski racers, ice skaters and sledders in the Winter Games.

title: Arizona Judge Calls Off Trial of 20 Blacks
description: A judge today dismissed a jury and called off a criminal trial involving 20 members of an all-black church because Cochise County would not pay defense costs for indigent defendants.

title: SALES SOAR
description: Businesses increased their inventories by four-tenths of 1 percent in December, but sales rose six times as fast to a record level, the Commerce Department said today.

title: AMERICAN ISRAELI PAPER MILLS LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Year-ago results include gains of 98 cents a share for the quarter and $1.22 a share for the 9 months from the sale of Mollet shares.

title: HOME IMPROVEMENT
description: NO tool is more frequently used, and more frequently abused, than the screwdriver. Designed for one job - driving and removing screws and bolts that have screw heads - the screwdriver is all too often put to work prying, poking, scraping and pounding. This can often result in sufficient damage to the blade so that the tool becomes useless.

Italian Output Declines
description: Industrial production in Italy fell 4.5 percent in December after a 1.4 percent rise in November, the Government reported today.

title: LOS ANGELES MAYOR IRKS GREEK TOWN

title: CRANSTON OFFERS JOB PLAN AND ALTERS STRATEGY
description: Senator Alan Cranston today proposed a detailed $23 billion program that he said would create up to two million jobs and would be financed by large cuts in the military budget.

description: President Reagan said today that Federal budget deficits were not a serious threat to the economic recovery and were not the cause of high interest rates.

title: Dr. Sabin, Polio Healer, Walks After Paralysis
description: Albert B. Sabin, who developed an oral vaccine to prevent polio, is walking again, seven months after he was paralyzed by a mysterious nerve disorder.

title: ; DON'T TAKE BELLEAYRE FROM THE SKIERS
description: To the Editor:

title: GOING OUT GUIDE;
description: HOMECOMING The Grolier Club was founded 100 years ago, its members dedicated to improving the breed of the book and, through exhibition, showing off the best in book arts and literature. To celebrate its birthday, this literate club yesterday opened a very special exhibition, a grand reprise by 100 items that were displayed during the Grolier century. They are on view in the club's high-ceilinged, librarylike hall in its headquarters, at 47 East 60th Street (838-6690).

description: Tenant leaders say the rent stabilization code drafted by the landlords makes drastic changes in tenants' rights. Landlord spokesmen say the draft merely codifies the years of changes in the law by the Legislature, decisions made by courts, and rulings by the body that now administers rent stabilization, the Conciliation and Appeals Board.

description: The board of directors of Getty Oil Company was reshuffled today by the company's new owner, Texaco Inc., and the losers included Gordon P. Getty, the sole trustee of the Sarah C. Getty Trust.

Policeman Is Killed By Sikhs in Punjab

title: AVOIDING 'FISHEYES' DURING REFINISHING
description: Silicones are present in a majority of furniture-care products today, and for good reason: They make the polishes easy to use, require but one applicator cloth and provide a lasting shine - all with minimum effort.

CAVE-IN FOLLOWS U.S. NUCLEAR TEST
description: An underground nuclear test blast caused the earth more than one-fifth of a mile above to collapse today, injuring 13 atomic scientists whose trailers plunged into the hole. One of the workers was critically injured, but no radiation escaped as a result of the accident, officials said.

title:
PRESS NOTES;
ALBANY PAPER IRKS OFFICIAL, GIVES UP ADS
description: The Albany County Executive, angered by an account of the county's Democratic patronage system in The Albany Times-Union, has canceled $60,000 a year in advertising the county used to place in the newspaper.

title: NURSE CONVICTED IN INFANT'S DEATH
description: A licensed vocational nurse was convicted today of killinga 15-month- old girl with an injection of a powerful and hard-to-trace drug. The nurse, 33- year-old Genene Jones, could be sentenced to life in prison for the slaying in September 1982 of Chelsea Ann McClellan.

title: TEACHER SUPPORT OF REAGAN WANES
description: In 1980, Jill Shaeffer voted for Ronald Reagan because she was disenchanted with Jimmy Carter. This year she will vote Democratic because she is disenchanted with Mr. Reagan.

title: CAMPAIGNING IN STYLE FOR MONDALE
description: --In a city not particularly known for its neighborhoods or neighborliness, Cleveland Park, an area of expensive Victorian homes in the Northwest, with a scattering of redwood moderns, has always been more like Smalltown, U.S.A. It has an exceptionally active Parent-Teacher Association and several thriving food cooperatives.

title: PAROLEE IS ARRESTED INSLAYING OF OFFICER AND WOUNDING OF 2
description: A man free on parole after a manslaughter conviction was arrested in a Bronx hospital early yesterday and charged with murdering a New York City police officer and wounding two others.

title: Needham Is Watching Hamburger Campaign
description: For Needham, Harper & Steers, with its main bastions in New York, Chicago and Los Angeles, the place to watch these days is Washington. The reason is hamburger consumption, especially those at McDonald's.

title: ANDOVER CONTROLS reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 8
description: The company said the first, third, and fourth quarters of its fiscal year are 12 weeks while the second quarter is 16 weeks.

title: Market Place; 'Old' A.T.&T. Leaves in Style
description: IT was a fitting tribute for one of the nation's most enduring stocks: Yesterday, American Telephone and Telegraph was the most actively traded issue on the New York Stock Exchange. Today, it is only history.

title: N.A.D. Resolves 9 Ad Complaints
description: During January, six advertisers whose claims were being investigated by industry self-regulators either changed the claims or dropped the advertising, according to the National Advertising Division of the Council of Better Business Bureaus.

title: EX-BANKER NAMED IN FALSE-LOAN PLOT
description: -- A Federal grand jury indicted a former vice president of a Middlesex County bank today in a scheme to approve $600,000 in spurious loans to businessmen in return for at least $50,000 in cash.

title: CHESEBROUGH-POND'S INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Delay on Dupree
description: The executive committee of the United States Football League has deferred action on a proposal by the New Orleans Breakers that would have allowed the club to sign the running back Marcus Dupree despite league rules prohibiting the signing of players with remaining college eligibility. The proposal would allow the rule to be waived in cases satisfying certain established criteria, including financial hardship. Dupree, who dropped out of the University of Oklahoma, may go to court to challenge the rule against signing underclassmen, according to his friend and adviser, Ken Fairley.

title: COUSINS HOME FURNISHINGS reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Long Island Franchiser Pursuing the Right Mix
description: To some, it might seem an odd combination to find under one corporate roof: hair-care salons, computer software stores and fast-food outlets. But to Richard F. Stanley, president of Cutco Industries in Jericho, L.I., it makes perfect sense.

description: Year-ago results are restated for the acquisition of Instacom Inc. in October 1983.

title: Mobil Accord in Japan
description: Mobil Sekiyu, a unit of the Mobil Corporation, and Kygnus Sekiyu said today that they had agreed to form a joint distribution network for selling their refined petroleum products in Japan.

title: Two Pilots Fail to Find Climber on Mt. McKinley
description: Pilots searching for the stranded Japanese adventurer Naomi Uemura, the first person to climb Mount McKinley alone in the winter, failed to find him today on the slopes of North America's tallest mountain.

title: PORTABLE I.B.M. COMPUTER EXPECTED
description: The International Business Machines Corporation will market its first portable computer within a month, according to dealers who said they were notified Monday to expect the machine.

title: APARTHEID FOE ASSAILS KOCH ON CAMPAIGN GIFT
description: An official of a New York group that opposes apartheid in South Africa called on Mayor Koch yesterday to return a $2,000 campaign contribution from a law firm that represents the Pretoria Government.

title: Fan Club Dispute
description: The 19-year-old head of the Jimmy Connors fan club has accused the tennis star's lawyer of harassing her in an effort to get her to drop a lawsuit against Connors and his managers. The suit was filed in Federal court in St. Paul last month by Terri Flasch , who contended that Connors and his associates had tried to take the fan club away from her.

title: 3 COUNTRIES PLAN PARLEY ON TRUCE
description: The United States, South Africa and Angola have agreed to open talks on Thursday to preserve the current cease-fire between the two southern African countries, the State Department said.

title: Eve Merriam to Read Poetry
description: Eve Merriam will read from her poetry on Monday at 7:30 P.M. as part of the ''Writers in Performance'' series at the Manhattan Theater Club, 321 East 73d Street.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: Because of an editing error, a front- page article in some editions yesterday incorrectly described Federal regulations concerning the pesticide EDB. The Government still requires the use of EDB on certain imported fruit.

description: Q.

title: Floating Notes For Texas Bank
description: A $100 million issue of floating rate notes of Texas Commerce Bankshares due in 1996 is offered at a price of 99.8 through underwriters led by Salomon Brothers.

title: 718 AREA CODE FOR BROOKLYN, QUEENS AND STATEN ISLAND GAINS APPROVAL
description: The State Public Service Commission today voted to divide New York City into two area codes to ''prevent an impending exhaustion of telephone numbers.''

title: 4th Quarter Profit Seen By Warner
description: Warner Communications, citing improved results at its Atari consumer electronics unit, said yesterday that it expects to report fourth- quarter earnings of about $5 million after losses in the previous three quarters. The company earned $33 million in the fourth quarter of 1982.

title: WORLD ATTENTION TURNS TO CHERNENKO'S HEALTH
description: As the normal rhythms of life returned to the Soviet capital after Tuesday's burial of Yuri V. Andropov, whose death came after months of medical problems, Western diplomats began to raise questions about the health of the new Soviet leader, Konstantin U. Chernenko.

Minnesota Bonds Are Sold Quickly A $125 million issue of Minnesota general-obligation bonds was offered yesterday with yields ranging from 5.5 percent for bonds due in 1985 to 8.25 percent in 1994 and 9.35 percent in 2004 through underwriters led by the Bankers Trust Company. The issue was well received, with all but $39.8 million of the issue sold the first day.
description: The economic recovery has improved the state's financial condition, which suffered during the 1981-82 recession. After recording a budget deficit of $32.3 million under generally accepted accounting principles in 1983, the state now projects a surplus of $401 million by mid-1985, as well as a $250 million budget reserve account. The Governor has recommended that the surplus be reduced by eliminating the 10 percent income tax surcharge.

description: Results for the year-ago quarter have been restated to reflect changes in the method of translating the financial statements of its foreign subsidiaries to conform to F.A.S.B. Statement No. 52.

title: HEADED SPORTING-GOODS CHAIN
description: Henry Modell, chairman of Henry Modell & Company, a sporting-goods retail chain, died Tuesday at the Hollywood (Fla.) Memorial Hospital. He was 91 years old and lived in Hollywood.

title: CHANCELLOR OPPOSES BID TO RAISE TUITION FOR CITY UNIVERSITY
description: The City University Chancellor said today that Governor Cuomo's proposed state budget threatened the university's mission by raising tuition and reducing its staff.

title: Poll Finds Mondale Still Holds Wide Lead
description: Walter F. Mondale continues to hold a big lead over his rivals for the Democratic Presidential nomination, according to the latest Gallup Poll. It found the Rev. Jesse Jackson and Senator John Glenn running even but far behind the former Vice President.

description: The producer-director Hal Roach has been voted an hononary Academy Award for lifetime achievement, and the producer M. J. (Mike) Frankovich the Jean Hersholt Humanitarian Award, the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences announced Tuesday.

title: ETHEL MERMAN, QUEEN OF MUSICALS, DIES AT 76
description: Ethel Merman, the musical-comedy star whose belting voice and brassy style entertained Broadway and movie audiences for 50 years, was found dead in her Manhattan apartment yesterday.

title: UNDER LAS VEGAS'S NEON BEATS A HEART OF DENIM
description: This place expends a good portion of the power generated at Hoover Dam upon neon palm trees and cowboys. One can wander from Rome to the Barbary Coast to the 21st century in a few steps along the Strip, or make a fortune in small change if the watermelons, bars or red sevens line up.

title: WOMETCO CABLE TV INC reports earnings for 16 wks to Jan 8
Mission to Tulsa
description: Craig Patrick , the Rangers' general manager, was in Oklahoma yesterday trying to line up new ownership for the Tulsa Oilers, the club's top farm team, which collapsed on Tuesday under a mountain of debt. ''I'm optimistic, but I don't have a deal yet,'' Patrick said last night after a day of discussions with two groups of Tulsa businessmen who have expressed tentative interest in taking over the Central Hockey League team. Should the negotiations fall through, the Oiler players, including such occasional Rangers as Dave Barr, Gary Burns, Robbie Ftorek and Steve Weeks, could be added to the Rangers' National Hockey League roster as a taxi squad or disbursed among other minor league teams under special loan arrangements with their major league affiliates.

title: URUGUAY IS FERTILE SOIL FOR MOON CHURCH MONEY
description: The Unification Church of the Rev. Sun Myung Moon, who like Uruguay's military rulers is strongly opposed to Communism, has become one of the largest foreign investors here.

title: HOME BEAT
description: HE had been collecting 20th-century Moderne and Art Deco objects for a number of years and found that he was running out of room at home. So Steven Korff, left, a bookkeeper who was once a drummer in a rock band, decided to open a shop and sell some of his favorite things. Yesterday's Tomorrow is now situated in a 300-square-foot space in SoHo and crammed with decorative glass (from $100 to $350 apiece), Italian pottery from the 1950's ($35 to $150), bakelite cologne bottles ($200 each) and small wrought-iron furniture (a telephone stand is $60), as well as some refinished pieces such as the red lacquer boomerang table, above, which costs $700. Yesterday's Tomorrow, at 68 Thompson Street, is open Tuesday through Sunday from noon to 7 P.M.; the telephone number is 219-3160.

UPSTATE A-PLANT CALLED DEFICIENT IN N.R.C. STUDY
description: The construction of the Nine Mile Point 2 nuclear power plant at Scriba, N.Y., is hampered by poor management and inadequate quality control, a Federal Nuclear Regulatory Commission audit released today said.

REAGAN'S POOR DEFENSE OF A GOOD TAX PROGRAM
description: To the Editor:

title: SPURS CURTAIL RALLY, BEAT NETS, 114-108
description: The New Jersey Nets came close to surviving the one-game suspension of their power forward, Buck Williams, tonight. But they missed his muscle down the stretch and were beaten by the San Antonio Spurs, 114- 108, before 10,678 fans at the Byrne Meadowlands Arena.

title: U.S. FIGHTS BID BY LTV TO BUY REPUBLIC STEEL

description: The National Conservative Political Action Committee said today it would spend $2 million in New Hampshire ''to expose the liberal record'' of Walter F. Mondale in the Democratic Presidential nomination race.

title: HERS
description: THERE have been a half dozen women, in my six years as a parent, with whom I've entrusted my son and daughter at the going rate of $1 an hour. (One of them tried raising her rates to $1.50, but all her customers left.) I know, from the tops of my children's heads, the different ways those women's houses smell - cigarette smoke, spaghetti sauce, room deodorizer. Most of them have never been to my house, know only vaguely what it is I do during those hours I leave my children in their care. The words we exchange when I drop off my child are nearly always the same: ''Cold enough for you?'' ''Nice bathrobe.'' But we're connected, and what I feel for these women is close to love.

title: New Pact for Robinson
description: There has been speculation all winter that Frank Robinson 's tenure with the San Francisco Giants would end with the 1984 season. ''I hope this puts this matter to rest for good,'' Bob Lurie , the team's president, said yesterday when he announced the extension of Robinson's contract as manager.

title: Retreat From a Secrecy Madness
description: Still protesting that Congress doesn't appreciate the peril to national security, the Reagan Administration is nevertheless retreating from its reckless hunt for leaks and leakers. At least for now, it has shelved the sweeping order imposing an unconscionable lifetime censorship on Federal employees and terrorizing normally trusted public servants with random lie-detector examinations.

title: OPERA: SHOSTAKOVICH LEADS 'LADY MACBETH'
description: SHOSTAKOVICH'S ''Lady Macbeth of Mtsensk,'' as every collector of operatic anecdotes knows, is the work that so horrified Stalin by its explicit sexuality and dissonant musical idiom that he went home and launched a violent attack on modern art of all kinds. Imagine how he would have reacted if he had witnessed Liviu Ciulei's English-language production of the work's original 1934 version, which the Juilliard American Opera Center presented last night at the Juilliard Theater. In one scene, a bored police chief made up to resemble Stalin kills flies while an assistant keeps count of his victims at a blackboard. The Stalin look-alike heads up a police force of bumblers that flounders about like a Russian version of the Keystone Kops.

title: A BLACKSMITH'S SHOP FORGES MEMORIES
description: RALPH CAUSARANO raised his hammer over the anvil and pounded an iron construction pick into shape. Sparks flew. A poker cooled in an old aluminum beer keg. His cat, Little Guy, a fifth-generation blacksmith calico, slept by the forge.

title: AMERICA, ACT TO END CAMBODIA OCCUPATION
description: A military and diplomatic deadlock has existed in Indochina since 1979 following the Vietnamese invasion of Cambodia and the ouster of the internally murderous and externally aggressive Pol Pot regime. Vietnam continues to occupy Cambodia with some 160,000 troops, while its principal opponents in the standoff, China and Thailand, demand a withdrawal and internationally supervised elections. It is unlikely that the deadlock will be broken soon, given Vietnam's formidable military grip on the country and the intransigence that it represents.

title: AEG-Telefunken Head
description: AEG-Telefunken A.G., the struggling electrical concern, said today that its board had voted to retain Heinz Duerr as managing chairman for another five years after his first term expires in December 1985. Mr. Duerr, who is 50 years old, has guided AEG through insolvency proceedings since 1982. AEG's 1983 results are yet to be published, but sources have said the company probably reached its targets of $4.2 billion in revenues and a sharply narrowed loss.

title: FILM: PHIL OCHS, A SHORT BIOGRAPHY
description: FOR those with a lingering interest in the folk singers of the 1960's and the political and cultural climate in which they flourished, Michael Korolenko's ''Chords of Fame'' is worth recommending for some of the raw material that it contains. But Mr. Korolenko, in assembling this portrait of the late singer-songwriter Phil Ochs, has taken an exasperating approach to his subject. Reasonable as it would be to expect the music and photographs of the real Mr. Ochs to figure prominently in this documentary, Mr. Korolenko has replaced him with a double. All the other key characters in this story appear as themselves.

title: THURSDAY, FEBRUARY 16, 1984 International
description: Druse militiamen forced troops of the Lebanese Army out of their remaining positions south of Beirut and linked up with Shiites, leaving the United States Marines nearly surrounded at their airport compound. The Druse leader, Walid Jumblat, said President Amin Gemayel must resign and be tried for ''crimes.'' (Page A1, Column 6.) Abrogation of an accord with Israel is included in an eight-point plan for a political settlement in Lebanon that has been signed by President Amin Gemayel, according to a knowledgeable Reagan Administration official. He said the information had come through Saudi diplomatic channels. Later, he said, the White House learned independently that Mr. Gemayel's signature on the settlement plan, which was proposed by a Saudi mediator, was ''imminent.'' (A1:3.)

title: POLICY ON BEIRUT: CONTRADICTIONS ABOUND
description: In the last several days, the volatile situation in Lebanon has led the Reagan Administration to give new and sometimes differing definitions of its policies, its relationship with the Government of President Amin Gemayel and the role of the United States marines in Beirut. In addition, there have been contradictory reports from Administration officials about the seriousness of the military and political crisis in Lebanon. There have also been contradictory statements about the timetable for the withdrawal of American marines from the Beirut airport, and about the purpose of the shelling of Syrian positions by American warships.

title: Financial Problem
description: Willie Horton , the former major league outfielder, and his wife, Gloria , have filed reorganization papers in Seattle, seeking to consolidate their $133,282 in debts and arrange a repayment schedule. ''I think this is the best way to go so everybody can get something,'' said the 40-year- old Horton, who recently signed as a minor league hitting instructor for the Oakland A's. Horton, who played 18 years with the Detroit Tigers and the Seattle Mariners and then in the minors in 1981 and 1982, said his income had dropped from $88,894 in 1982 to $10,000 last year.

description: The Penn Central Corporation increased its stake in the American District Telegraph Company to 1,115,400 common shares, or 8.8 percent, of the shares outstanding, according to documents filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission.

title: A COOLER WATT STATES CASE OUT WEST
description: A small school looking for attention got just that Tuesday night, with the help of a speaker who has been something of a specialist in the field, former Interior Secretary James G. Watt.

title: 9 in Democratic Primary In Georgia March 13
description: Democratic voters in Georgia's Presidential primary on March 13 will choose among nine candidates, including Gerald Willis, a former Alabama legislator.

title: St. Peter's Tops Fordham by 3
description: Two free throws by Darren Rowe, his only points of the game, broke a 42-42 tie with 44 seconds to play as St. Peter's scored a 45-42 Metro Atlantic Conference victory over Fordham last night at the Rams' Rose Hill Gymnasium.

title: VISHAY INTERTECHNOLOGY INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Share earnings for the latest periods reflect the effect of conversion of 11 percent convertible debentures in June. Year-ago share earnings have been adjusted for a 5 percent stock dividend in June.

title: WEINBERGER BACKS $20.5 BILLION BOMBER ESTIMATE
description: Defense Secretary Caspar W. Weinberger still believes 100 long-range B1-B strategic bombers can be built for $20.5 billion, he says in a letter to Congress dated Jan. 31.

title: THURSDAY SPORTS Basketball
description: Knicks vs. Indiana Pacers, at Madison Square Garden, 7:35 P.M. The Knicks are surging, having won 3 games in a row and 9 of their last 10; their recent road record is 8-1. (Television - MSG Cable, 7:30 P.M., live, and 1 A.M., tape. Radio - WNEW, 1130; 7:30 P.M.)

title: REAGAN AND MONDALE EVOKE IMAGE OF SUSAN B. ANTHONY
description: Susan B. Anthony, the pioneer of women's rights who was treated as a pariah by the major politicians of her time, was recalled with fervor on her birthday today by some of the men running for President.

title: ULTRASOUND IN PREGNANCY: THE REMOTE RISK
description: To the Editor:

title: FRANKLIN RESOURCES reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
HE IS SAID TO SCRAP ISRAEL PACT; REAGAN GIVES PLAN ON MARINES
description: Druse and Shiite militiamen consolidated their takeover of several strategic lebanese Army positions around Beirut Wednesday and launched a new offensive against army and Christian Phalangist troops still trying to hold out south of the capital.

title: AT POLICE STATION, MOURNING MINGLED WITH PRIDE
description: They were hanging the purple and black bunting above the door of the 41st Precinct station house in the South Bronx yesterday in the way that the police mark an officer's death in the line of duty. It is as much of a ritual as the black mourning bands that the entire force placed over their shields yesterday or the long lines of blue that will stand at attention at the funeral of Officer Thomas P. Ruotolo on Saturday.

title: MISS SUMNERS LEADS SKATING
description: Women's figure skating began today at the XIV Olympic Winter Games, and United States medal hopes rose and fell at the same time.

title: OLMEDO CALLS REMARKS AN ATTEMPT TO MISLEAD
description: City Councilman Luis A. Olmedo of Brooklyn said at his trial yesterday that he had been ''fooling them'' when he told detectives posing as kickback-paying construction executives that he could help them get public contracts. He carried out the ruse, he said, because he thought the undercover men were mobsters or drug dealers and he was ''very scared'' of them, causing him to ''say anything'' to avoid angering them at a 1982 meeting. Mr. Olmedo, a 49-year-old Democrat who has been a Councilman for 10 years, and two community leaders are charged with conspiring to extort kickbacks from the bogus construction executives.

title: STAFF CUTS RESHAPING STATE ARTS COUNCIL
description: THE State Council on the Arts, which has fewer employees and less money than it did a decade ago, now is further cutting its staff and undergoing a shake-up that will affect its services to 2,000 arts groups in New York.

title: JOHNSON & JOHNSON INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After an extraordinary charge of $50 million. The company recognized a nonrecurring charge against net earnings of $38 million due to the divestiture of the dialysis portion of its business during the latest fourth quarter. The latest year net includes one- time costs associated with the first quarter 1983 temporary withdrawal of the company's Zomax brand Zomepirac sodium.

description: b-Net income. Results for the latest periods reflect a charge of $340,000 for the restructuring and closing of facilities.

title: North Korea Rejects Seoul's Call for Talks
description: North Korea today rejected South Korea's call for direct talks on easing tension on the Korean peninsula, the North Korean Central News Agency reported.

description: b-Includes an extraordinary credit of $397,000.

MAXIMUM SENTENCES ARE IMPOSED ON 4 BRINK'S DEFENDENTS
description: Maximum prison sentences were imposed yesterday on the four defendants convicted in the Federal Brink's trial in Manhattan.

WARSAW CARDINAL TRANSFERS A MILITANT PRIEST
description: Roman Catholic Church sources said today that Jozef Cardinal Glemp, under pressure from the authorities, had begun to transfer activist pro-Solidarity priests from their parishes.

description: Following is the text of a statement by J. Paul McGrath, the Assistant Attorney General in charge of the Justice Department's antitrust division, explaining why the department opposes the proposed merger of the LTV Corporation and the Republic Steel Corporation:

title: CORRECTIONS
description: An article in Business Day Tuesday about the insurance industry misstated the Mission Insurance Company's plans for its reinsurance line. It will be continued.

title: EAST GERMANS SWEEP IN SPEED SKATING
description: Andrea Sch"one beat her teammate, Karin Enke, and led East Germany to a sweep of the women's 3,000-meter race today, the final speed-skating event for women in the Winter Olympics.

description: Subtract Figure Skating SARAJEVO, Yugoslavia

title: STANG HYDRONICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income.

title: PRINCES OF THE CHOREOGRAPHIC REALM AT CITY BALLET
description: GEORGE BALANCHINE may have declared that ''ballet is woman.'' Yet the New York City Ballet has never been without fine male dancers. At one time or another, quite a few noted male dancers have been on its roster and many of them, including Andre Prokovsky, Jean-Pierre Bonnefous and Peter Martins, visibly improved while they were with the company. Moreover, the company developed such male stars of its own as Jacques d'Amboise, Edward Villella and Arthur Mitchell.

title: SWITCHCO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income.

title: ARMY FINDS DRUG TEST ERRORS
description: Thousands of soldiers and airmen disciplined for drug abuse may be exonerated because of improper urinalysis testing, the Army said today.

title: Letter: On Shelters Havens for the Homeless
description: To the Editor:

title: WYMAN-GORDON CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
MONDALE AND LABOR'S BACKING: HIS AIDES SEE A TACTICAL ERROR
description: In the last few days Walter F. Mondale has found there is another side to organized labor's endorsement of his Presidential candidacy. Although the former Vice President derives major financial and organizational benefits from the support of the A.F.L.-C.I.O., he has been dogged lately by questions about organized labor's influence over his campaign.

title: IMATRON INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
SEEDS AND PLANTS FOR SMALL SPACES
description: GARDENERS tend to enjoy sharing. But most also find that the other side of this generous spirit is an irrepressible impulse to acquire. Yielding to the temptation of ordering too many plants may be dandy for those with acres to spare, but city gardeners with space limitations must temper their longings - or at least find clever alternatives.

title: MET OPERA: CAST CHANGES IN 'RINALDO'
description: BEING asked to take the place of an opera star of Marilyn Horne's magnitude in a part she has claimed as her own is not an enviable assignment for any singer, let alone a comparatively unknown one. But that intimidating task fell Tuesday night to Ewa Podles, a Polish mezzo-soprano who made her Metropolitan Opera debut in the title role of Handel's ''Rinaldo.'' Although she fell considerably short of scoring a total triumph, Miss Podles proved herself a singer of real vocal quality whose smallish but flexible voice should suit her for many other roles in the coloratura mezzo repertory.

title: South Africa Village Cleared
description: Government crews removed the last 80 families today from this village west of Johannesburg, which has become a symbol of forced resettlement of blacks.

title: CRIME CONTROL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The company said the latest quarter and year results reflect a previously announced nonrecurring charge from Radio Shack's decision not to renew its options under leases with Crime Control.

title: Mobil Barge Price
description: The Mobil Corporation said its Mobil Oil unit had reduced its New York harbor barge price for distillates, including heating oil, diesel fuel and kerosene, by 9 cents a gallon, to 89 cents. It also cut wholesale heating oil prices at most points east of the Rocky Mountains: by less than a cent a gallon in San Antonio, to 6 cents a gallon at its Philadelphia terminal. Its Philadelphia barge price was reduced 8 cents a gallon. Mobil's cuts follow by one day price reductions by the Sun Company, the Exxon Corporation and Tenneco Inc.

title: AFFILIATED HOSPITAL PRODUCTS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Bank Board Proposes Rule
description: The Federal Home Loan Bank Board voted today to ask for comment on a proposed rule that would stiffen the minimum net worth requirements for thrift institutions.

title: Dow Declines 5.13, to 1,158.71
description: Changes in stock prices were mostly minor yesterday but trading picked up. Favorable economic news seemed to have little effect in counteracting the growing concern over interest rates.

title: 7 ARRESTS AND NOW ANOTHER
description: The arrest of George Acosta yesterday on charges of shooting three police officers, killing one, was his eighth, according to police and court records. Following is a summary of his criminal record, beginning in 1976 when he was 16 years old: April 13, 1976.

title: C.D. Rates Edge Up
description: Interest rates on six-month certificates of deposit edged upward across the country in the week ended yesterday, The Bank Rate Monitor reported.

title: COVER-UP CHARGED IN DEATH OF NUNS
description: A classified investigative report prepared for the State Department concluded that there was a cover-up by Salvadoran authorities in the killing of four American churchwomen in December 1980 and that it was ''quite possible'' that the present Salvadoran Minister of Defense was aware of it.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Brooklyn Drug Crackdown

title: NBC LEADS AS OLYMPICS CUT ABC RATINGS
description: The unexpectedly low viewership last week of ABC's telecasts of the Winter Olympics gave NBC its first victory in the prime-time ratings this television season, officials of the two networks said yesterday. ABC, which has invested nearly $200 million to provide exclusive coverage of the international competition in Sarajevo, Yugoslavia, came in third.

title: ROBOTIC VISION SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31

description: Governor Cuomo today offered legislative leaders an agenda to deal with a broad spectrum of energy issues facing New York State.

title: AMERICAN EFFORT SAID TO HAVE OVERLOOKED DOUBTS OF OFFICERS
description: In the 14 months that the United States Army trained the Lebanese armed forces, American officers continually sent optimistic reports on the program's progress back to Washington, according to senior Pentagon and Administration officials.

title: E.E.C. Steel Price Up
description: The Commission of the European Economic Community has authorized an increase of about 2 percent in minimum prices for certain steel products, a spokesman said today. The action followed the Common Market's adoption in December of a plan to halt a slide in steel prices.

title: Article 253950 -- No Title
description: Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato has already raised $1.3 million for his 1986 campaign, according to records filed with the Federal Election Commission.

title: Nurse Gets 99 Years In Texas Injection Death
description: Genene Jones, found guilty of murdering a baby girl by fatal injection, was sentenced today to 99 years in prison by the jury that convicted her.

title: MICKELBERRY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Year-ago results include operations of Cunningham & Walsh Inc., which was acquired as of March 22, 1982, and accounted for as a purchase, starting in the second quarter.

description: b-After a net writedown of $37.8 million by the company's Cotton Petroleum Corp. unit relating to oil and gas properties. c-After an extraordinary charge of $60,480,000 for the quarter and year related to the settlement of curtailment litigation.

title: Phone Links to Beirut Cut Off for 12 Hours
description: All telephone and telex communications out of Lebanon were cut off from roughly 9 P.M. Wednesday until 8:35 A.M. today (2 P.M. Wednesday until 1:35 A.M. Thursday, New York time) because of a mechanical failure in the Lebanese post, telephone and telegraph center in Beirut.

title: LAWTER INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The year-ago results were restated for an accounting change.

title: BINNEY & SMITH reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After an extraordinary charge of $4,165,000. c-Net income.

title: Biegenwald Guilty Of Second Murder
description: Richard F. Biegenwald, already sentenced to die for murder, was found guilty of another slaying today.

title: CAESARS WORLD INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a loss of $640,000 from discontinued operations.

title: Interpublic and F.C.& B. Report Higher Earnings
description: The Interpublic Group of Companies and Foote, Cone & Belding Communications yesterday reported results for the fourth quarter and year.

title: FILM: PREWAR INTRIGUE
description: THERE'S not much variety to what Tom Selleck does on the screen. It goes without saying that he seems friendly and looks preternaturally handsome, that he wears clothes well and changes them with amazing frequency. But he doesn't appear to have more than a passing interest in anything that goes on around him, so why should you? Though ''Lassiter'' flings Mr. Selleck into a plot involving Nazis, diamonds and beautiful but depraved German aristocrats, you may soon lose track of the fine points. Even by the standards of escapist entertainment, little of ''Lassiter'' seems to matter.

title: Bridge: An Opening Lead May Look A Little More Safe Than It Is
description: Finding a safe opening lead is often difficult. It may seem easy to a player looking at a six-card suit headed by Q-J-10, and he is not likely to look further.

title: HAYES-ALBION CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-After tax credits of $449,000 for the quarter and $1,235,000 for the 6 months. c-Net loss

title: AN 0-24 SEASON WITH GUSTO
description: The palm-slapping and the hooting and hollering at the end of the game Wednesday night were worthy of champions - only these weren't champions. The Raiders from Rutgers-Newark had just lost their 24th game in 24 tries, ending their basketball season with a 99-73 loss to Ramapo College, yet the seven players and two coaches were swarming over the floor in Mahwah, N.J., as if they had won a title.

title: Diner's Journal
description: FOR those with adventurous tastes in Chinese food, Auntie Yuan, a dramatic, modern restaurant at First Avenue, between 64th and 65th Streets, is offering a gastronomic tour of the Chinese provinces. David Keh, the restaurant's owner, and Simon Teng, his executive chef, have assembled a 10-course banquet based on the best meals they sampled during a trip through China last year.

title: MICHIGAN UPSETS ILLINOIS, 62-60
description: Eric Turner's baseline jumper with two seconds left in the game lifted Michigan to a 62-60 upset over Illinois in the Big Ten Conference tonight. Turner, who scored 11 of his game-high 22 points in each half, had pulled the Wolverines into a 60-60 tie with a jumper from the left corner with 1 minute 20 seconds remaining.

title: P.S.C. CALLS AREA PHONE SERVICE POORER
description: The quality and reliability of telephone service in the New York City area has worsened in the last year, according to the State Public Service Commission. The deterioration, which has become of increasing concern to the commission, is only partly related to the breakup of the Bell System, according to commission reports.

title: Cambodian Insurgents Report Raid on City
description: Guerrillas supporting the ousted Pol Pot regime said today that they had driven Vietnamese occupation troops out of western Cambodia's most important city.

title: REYNOLDS NET RISES 29%
description: The International Harvester Company, helped by a 42 percent increase in truck sales, reported yesterday that it had narrowed its loss in the first fiscal quarter of 1984 ended Jan. 31 to $55 million, from $111 million a year earlier.

title: Hollings Drops Out Of New York Primary
description: Senator Ernest F. Hollings of South Carolina dropped out of the New York Presidential primary today, and his state manager contended that the rules for getting on the April 3 ballot were stacked in favor of Walter F. Mondale.

title: Holder Backs Bid On Beverly Hills
description: Paul Amir, a Los Angeles developer, agreed to vote his 17 percent stake in the Beverly Hills Savings and Loan Association in favor of a sweetened offer for the thrift unit by Triangle Industries.

title: CONCERT: PHILHARMONIC IN 'PLANETS'
description: THE first and last pieces on last night's New York Philharmonic program at Avery Fisher Hall peered uneasily at one another from opposite ends of the musical spectrum. The two were Webern's cantata ''Das Augenlicht'' and ''The Planets'' by Holst; and though written scarcely 20 years apart, each stood pointed in its own radically different stylistic direction.

title: THE NEW YORK TIMES CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Including equity in earnings of associated companies of $2,396,000 for the quarter and $4,704,000 for the year. c-Including equity in earnings of associated companies of $2,158,000 for the quarter and $9,178,000 for the year. The shares outstanding and the share earnings were adjusted retroactively for a 3-for-1 common stock split which became effective in December 1983.

title: PERSONAL INCOME UP
description: Personal income rose a healthy 1.1 percent in January, the sharpest gain since a comparable increase in October, while personal spending rose 1.2 percent, up from a revised 1 percent gain in December, the Commerce Department said today. The gain in income in December had been eight- tenths of 1 percent.

title: FLIP SIDE OF A GOLD MEDAL
description: SARAJEVO, Yugoslavia

title: OPERA: 'LADY MACBETH OF MTSENK'
description: SHOSTAKOVICH'S ''Lady Macbeth of Mtsensk,'' as every collector of operatic anecdotes knows, is the work that so horrified Stalin by its explicit sexuality and dissonant musical idiom that he went home and launched a violent attack on modern art of all kinds. Imagine how he would have reacted if he had witnessed Liviu Ciulei's English-language production of the work's original 1934 version, which the Juilliard American Opera Center presented Wednesday night at the Juilliard Theater. In one scene, a bored police chief made up to resemble Stalin kills flies while an assistant keeps count of his victims at a blackboard. The Stalin look-alike heads up a police force of bumblers that flounders about like a Russian version of the Keystone Kops.

title: FILM: 'LE CRABE TAMBOUR,' ADVENTURE
description: TO come to the point immediately, ''Le Crabe Tambour,'' Pierre Schoendoerffer's 1977 French film based on his own French novel, is one of the grandest, most beautiful adventure movies in years. It may be somewhat old-fashioned in its emphasis on courage, honor and the glory of war, no matter what the cause. However, it's also wonderfully old-fashioned in its convoluted, romantic narrative, which moves from Vietnam, during the collapse of France's control of Indochina in the 1950's, to East Africa, Algeria, Brittany, Newfoundland and the stormy fishing grounds on the Grand Banks.

title: STOCK PRICES FALL IN LIGHTER TRADING
description: Stock prices fell moderately yesterday in less active trading.

title: Economic Scene; Andropov and His Legacy
description: K ONSTANTIN U. CHERNENKO takes over the leadership of the Soviet Communist Party at a time when its hopes are rising that the late Yuri V. Andropov found ways to break the stagnation into which the Soviet economy had lapsed in the last years of the Brezhnev regime.

title: CHIEFS GIVE UNCERTAIN SIGNALS ON WARRANTY LAW
description: A struggle over a 1983 law requiring the Pentagon to ask for written guarantees against defects in weapons has become as complex as some of those exotic weapons themselves. Asked on five occasions this month if the Department of Defense was seeking to repeal the guarantee law, various spokesmen for the Department have answered absolutely no, yes, no, not really and yes.

title: JERSEY TO BATTLE NEW YORK STATE TO KEEP PROJECT
description: The New Jersey Congressional delegation vowed today to fight the New York delegation's attempt to block a development plan for the Hudson River waterfront here.

title: First Chicago
description: The First Chicago Corporation, holding company for the First National Bank of Chicago, is offering 750,000 shares of $100 preferred stock at a price of $100 with an initial dividend rate of 10.2 percent, through underwriters led by Salomon Brothers. Interest on the preferred stock will be adjusted quarterly at 1.8 percentage points below the higher of the yield on 3-month Treasury bills, 10-year Treasury notes or 20-year Treasury bonds. The stock is subject to a minimum rate of 6 1/2 percent and a maximum of 17 1/2 percent.

title: CHARGES FLY OVER PAROLEE HELD IN OFFICER'S FATAL SHOOTING
description: A retired judge, the Bronx District Attorney and state officials traded accusations yesterday over their handling of a 24-year- old man charged with murdering a police officer and wounding two other officers while free on parole.

title: SOME MINOR DRUG SELLERS TO FACE FEDERAL CHARGES
description: Some of the low-level drug dealers arrested each week in New York City will be tried on Federal instead of state charges, Police Commissioner Benjamin Ward said yesterday.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: E. B. WHITE: A BIOGRAPHY. By Scott Elledge. Illustrated. 400 pages. W. W. Norton. $22.50. IN 1942, reviewing E. B. White's ''One Man's Meat,'' Irwin Edman called him ''our finest essayist, perhaps our only one.'' Diana Trilling wondered whether ''his felicity has not sometimes been achieved by going around rather than over intellectual hurdles.'' Ralph Ingersoll accused him of ''gentle complacency,'' and another of Mr. White's friends described his essays as ''little adventures in contentment.''

title: What's a Woman's Work Worth?
description: A Federal court ruling in Seattle last December continues to reverberate around the country. Judge Jack Tanner ordered the state of Washington to spend nearly $1 billion to correct pay inequities between its female and male employees. His ruling is causing heartburn for public and private employers everywhere.

title: HOOVER CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After extraordinary gains of $298,000 for the quarter and $2,534,000 for the year.

title: DEMOCRATS TO PRESS BILLS AGAINST SECRECY MEASURES
description: Despite a White House effort to ease the dispute, Congressional Democrats said today that they would press their challenge to President Reagan's policy of using censorship and polygraph, or lie-detector, tests to guard national security secrets.

title: ARIZONAN THIRST FOR GROWTH THAT BELIES SEVERE WATER PROBLEMS
description: To the Editor:

title: SCOUTING
description: Salazar Returns

title: GOVERNOR'S 8-PART PLAN ON ELECTRICITY IS OUTLINED
description: In the agenda of energy issues that he released Wednesday, Governor Cuomo outlined an eight-part plan to change utility regulation, shift energy production from large generating plants to smaller ones and use state action to preserve low energy rates.

title: PERINI CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Including a gain of $1.6 million form an insurance claim settlement.

title: CANDIDATES SEEK OUT HOGS IN IOWA
description: In Iowa hogs are big business and good politics. At today's prices, the state's 13 million hogs are worth about 46 cents a pound on the hoof, but to the Presidential candidates trouping through the state hogs are worth their weight in television time.

title: SIPPICAN OCEAN SYSTEMS reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Fed Changes Report Dates
description: The Federal Reserve returned yesterday to publishing money supply data on Thursdays rather than on Fridays, and has also altered release dates for many other financial reports.

description: b-Net loss c-After losses from discontinued operations of $79,598 for the quarter and $354,598 for the year.

title: MARINES WILL BEGIN LEAVING IN 2 OR 3 DAYS, OFFICIAL SAYS
description: United States marines, surrounded on three sides by Moslem militiamen, will begin moving from the Beirut airport to ships offshore in two or three days, a senior White House official said today.

title: PKS-COMMUNICATIONS reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Debt Issues
description: * Mor-Flow Industries, a manufacturer of water heaters in Cleveland, said it will redeem 14 percent convertible subordinated debentures due Feb. 1, 2001, on March 19. The redemption price is $1,091 on each $1,000 principal amount of debenture plus accrued interest to March 19.

title: Bank of America
description: The Bank of America said it had reached an agreement under which the Capital Holding Corporation will provide automobile, homeowners and life insurance to consumers at Bank of America branches.

title: FRIDAY, FEBRUARY 17, 1984 International
description: Amin Gemayel informed his enemies that he will cancel the 1983 accord with Israel in exchange for their agreeing to begin reconciliation talks with his Government. Senior Government officials said the Lebanese President realized that the United States could not save his deteriorating Government and army with military support. (Page A1, Column 6.) American marines will begin moving from the Beirut airport to ships offshore in two or three days, a senior White House official said. (A14:1-2.)

title: GTE Will Invest $1 Billion in Sprint
description: The GTE Corporation said it planned to invest $1 billion in its Sprint long-distance phone and satellite operations this year.

title: Dow Chemical Sale Combines Oil Units
description: The Dow Chemical Company said yesterday that it had agreed to sell 50 percent of its Dowell subsidiary to a company it jointly owns with Schlumberger Ltd. for $440 million.

title: BIG BATTLE ERUPTS IN IRAN-IRAQ WAR
description: Iran said today that its forces had begun an offensive against Iraqi border fortifications on the central front and that Iranian soldiers were advancing. Iraq said it had contained the drive.

title: BOUCHER WINS 2D GOLD IN SPEED SKATING
description: Gaetan Boucher, a 25-year- old student from Quebec, scored an easy victory in the men's 1,500-meter speed skating today to become the first Canadian ever to win two gold medals in the same Olympic Winter Games.

title: RUSSIANS HOPE ANDROPOV AIMS HOLD
description: As Russians picked up the rhythms of their lives again this week, there were some who had fresh worries to add to the daily concerns about food lines, adequate winter clothing and the fortunes of Soviet athletes in the Winter Olympics.

title: Questions About a Cop Killing
description: How could George Acosta, charged with killing a police officer in Tuesday's shootout in the Bronx, be on the street when he was supposedly serving 15 years for manslaughter?

title: KYOZO MORI
description: PLS USE

title: Progressive Rock
description: Birdsongs of the Mesozoic, a progressive-rock instrumental band from Boston, will perform tonight at midnight at the Pyramid Club (420- 1590), 101 Avenue A, near Seventh Street. Tickets are $7.

title: Orlov Reported Freed From Prison in Soviet
description: Yuri F. Orlov, the Soviet human rights activist, has been released from prison after completing a seven-year term and now begins five years of internal exile, a Western diplomat said today.

title: SHARE POWER IN BEIRUT
description: The Administration should swallow its pride and propose a new domestic compact in Lebanon. The Saudi plan, accepted Tuesday by President Amin Gemayel, calling for a pullout of all foreign troops and cancellation of the May 17 Israeli-Lebanese withdrawal accord, creates the conditions for such a national reconcilation. The United States should grab this opportunity to establish real credibility - based less on strength and resolve, and more on wisdom and political acumen.

title: COOPERATE ON AID
description: In its never-ending quest to shape the world in its own image, the Reagan Administration is moving dangerously away from the postwar principle of working through multilateral development banks to effect policy changes in the third world. Washington has chosen to sacrifice international cooperation for a narrow-minded pursuit of national glory.

title: SCOUTING
description: Changing Game

description: b-Includes income from discontinued operations of $372,000 for the quarter and $1,553,000 for the year. c-Includes income from discontinued operations of $442,000 for the quarter and $2,036,000 for the year.

title: New Poll in Illinois Shows Reagan in Lead
description: President Reagan, who trailed in an Illinois poll last fall, would probably win the state if the general election were held today, a new voter sampling shows.

title: Baryshnikov Indicates He May Stay at A.B.T.
description: Mikhail Baryshnikov has indicated that he is willing to remain as artistic director of the American Ballet Theater past a previously announced deadline of June 16, the company said yesterday.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Far Apart in Taste

title: MUSIC: THE CINCINNATI POPS
description: THE Cincinnati Pops Orchestra, which came to Carnegie Hall on Wednesday, is the model of what a traditional ''pops'' orchestra ought to be. Conducted by Erich Kunzel, the ensemble blended the bustling energy of a big band and the spacious sound of a Hollywood studio orchestra in a program whose first half offered selections from Offenbach's ''Gaiete Parisienne'' and a Gershwin tribute.

title: A SONG FOR CONNECTICUT: MACARONI OR OAK TREE?
description: Never mind state budgets or legislation to repair roads and bridges. The biggest draw at the State Capitol today was a legislative hearing on another issue. The issue: Should ''Yankee Doodle,'' Connecticut's state song, be replaced?

Comings and Goings
description: Tony Dungy , a 28-year-old assistant coach with the Pittsburgh Steelers, has been named the club's defensive coordinator, making him the league's youngest unit coordinator. He succeeds Woody Widenhofer , who left to take over as head coach of the Oklahoma Outlaws of the United States Football League. . . . Ken Landreaux , a Los Angeles Dodger outfielder, was charged with the illegal possession of a concealed weapon, a misdemeanor, after sheriff's deputies said they found Landreaux carrying a handgun in a leather purse when they stopped a car driven by his wife to give her a speeding citation. A court appearance is set for March 23. . . . Rafael Ramirez , the Atlanta Braves' shortstop who had been seeking a $625,000 salary, lost his arbitration case and was ordered to accept the club's offer of $500,000. . . . Tim Raines, the Montreal Expo outfielder, signed a one- year contract four days before a scheduled arbitration hearing on the $820,000 he was seeking and the $600,000 the Expos were offering. . . . Franz Beckenbauer, the former Cosmos star, has agreed to play in an exhibition game May 5, when the Cosmos play a team of former players.

title: Surgery for Beardsley
description: Dick Beardsley , the nation's second-fastest marathon runner, withdrew from the Los Angeles Marathon on Sunday and said he faced a further round of leg surgery that could cost him a place in the Olympics. Beardsley, who had surgery last August to repair an injured Achilles' tendon in his left leg, needs to run a marathon in 2 hours 19 minutes 4 seconds or better to qualify for the Olympic trial May 26.

description: The Soviet Union is prepared to lie whenever lying suits its national purpose. The United States has an obligation to tell Americans as much of the truth as can safely be told about its operations. That difference in the approach to truth was tested recently.

description: M ONEY pouring into Individual Retirement Accounts, or I.R.A.'s, provided fuel for the stock market's strong performance in the opening months of last year. But if equities continue to decline in 1984 and thereby stir disenchantment with growth-oriented investments, the I.R.A. prop to stock prices - for the time being, at least - could be substantially weakened.

description: The Hewlett-Packard Company said today that its profit rose 11.8 percent in its fiscal first quarter from a year earlier, on a 20.8 percent sales gain. title: BACK FOR NIGHT AT TOWN HALL, CAROLE KING OF IDAHO
description: EVEN though she lives on a remote Idaho ranch, Carole King, who will make her first appearance in the city in six years tonight at Town Hall, will always be a New York pop-music institution. One of the most gifted and successful young songwriters of the early-1960's Brill Building school of teen-age pop, Miss King had established herself as a major songwriter by the age of 21 with hits like ''Will You Love Me Tomorrow?'' and ''Up on the Roof,'' both written with Gerry Goffin, who was then her husband and lyricist.

The concert is a benefit for the the Bowery Mission and the Catholic Worker, two Lower East Side Missions, and tickets are $8.

title: Lewis to Compete
description: Carl Lewis , who achieved the world-indoor best of 28 feet 10 1/4 inches in the long jump at the Millrose Games last month, has decided to enter the USA/Mobil Indoor Track and Field Championships at Madison Square Garden next Friday, partly, he said, to contest reports that he had used illicit hormones. Lewis had planned to skip the event, but said he had changed his mind, both because he was in ideal condition and that he wanted to submit to a drug-testing program being conducted at the meet.

title: IOWA RACE MAY ANSWER NEW HAMPSHIRE RIDDLE
description: It is unfashionable to suggest that any outside force can sway the independent- minded voters of New Hampshire. Nonetheless, a lot of political strategists are depending on Iowa to clarify the muddled political situation that prevails here in advance of the first primary of the Presidential campaign on Feb. 28.

title: ABUSING TAXPAYERS
description: The United States often holds foreign countries to high standards in matters of civil and human rights. Should it be too much, then, to expect certain agencies of the Federal Government, specifically the Internal Revenue Service, to respect the rights of its own citizens? I'll tell you about someone who is beginning to wonder.
