title: 117 BODIES FOUND IN LEBANESE VILLAGE RECAPTURED FROM CHRISTIANS
description: The bodies of at least 117 civilians were counted today in a mountain village captured two days ago by Druse militiamen. Druse spokesmen said the civilians had been massacred there five months ago when the village was under Lebanese Christian control.

title: REAGAN'S LATIN ENVOY SAID TO QUIT AFTER CLASH WITH STATE DEPT. AIDE
description: Richard B. Stone, President Reagan's special envoy to Central America, has resigned, effective March 1, Administration sources said today.

title: FILM: 'FOOTLOOSE,' STORY OF DANCING ON THE FARM
description: ENJOY the terrific title sequence of ''Footloose'' while it lasts, not just for its montage of interesting-looking dancers' feet and red-hot musical accompaniment, but also for its promise of the jumpy, colorful, exciting movie that, unfortunately, is not to follow. Instead, ''Footloose'' is a ''Flashdance'' set in farm country, with tractors supplying the blue-collar chic and the flash mostly missing. The single burning idea behind the movie can be summed up as follows: Don't Knock the Rock.

title: ROSALYNN SUMNERS DROPS TO 2D PLACE
description: Rosalynn Sumners of Edmonds, Wash., the world champion, suffered two setbacks today in women's figure skating in the XIV Olympic Winter Games. As a result, Katarina Witt of East Germany won the short program and took the overall lead going into the final day of the women's competition.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Coleco Industries, West Hartford, Conn., a manufacturer of toys and games, has promoted Ralph Lancellotti to vice president-sales.

description: The union leader of Guatemala's largest newspaper has been freed unharmed by kidnappers.

title: CONCERT: SYLVIA KAHAN PLAYS PIANO
description: SYLVIA KAHAN, who teaches at the Hebrew Arts School, undoubtedly cared about the music she played at her piano recital in Merkin Hall on Tuesday night. That much could be heard in the pretty moments in Debussy's ''Children's Corner'' or the lyrical episodes of Mendelssohn's Fantasy in F sharp minor (Op. 28).

title: SPORTS PEOPLE ;  Tryout for Kingman
description: Dave Kingman , the 35-year-old slugger who was released by the Mets after a 14-year career in the major leagues, may have another season ahead of him. The Oakland A's said Kingman had accepted an invitation to join the team for spring training and would sign a contract, ''if he makes the team.'' The club spokesman, Jay Alves , said Kingman would report to camp today. . . . Dusty Baker , the outfielder who was waived by the Los Angeles Dodgers last week, was claimed by the San Francisco Giants yesterday, but still has five days to accept bids from other teams.

title: French Truckers Halt Traffic to Italy
description: Major Alpine highways from France to Italy were blocked by truck drivers today, leaving thousands of vehicles stranded on both sides of the border.

title: U.S. HOCKEY GOAL IS 7TH PLACE
description: The United States hockey team will close its books on the XIV Olympic Winter Games Friday by facing Italy for seventh place in the 12-team competition.

title: Strip-Mining Official Quits
description: James R. Harris, the director of the Office of Surface Mining, which enforces strip-mining regulations, announced today that he was resigning for ''strictly personal'' reasons. Mr. Harris said reports that he had been asked to leave by William P. Clark, the Secretary of the Interior, were ''not correct.'' Mr. Harris will be replaced by Dr. Lisle Reed, effective March 15.

title: ABC BARS NBC AFFILIATES FROM OLYMPIC BROADCASTS
description: ABC has barred NBC and its 215 affiliated stations from showing pictures on network or local newscasts of any events of the 1984 Olympic Winter Games for two days after ABC televises the events.

description: The New York State Health Commissioner, for the first time, recommended yesterday that a large teaching hospital be prevented from acquiring a major piece of medical equipment on the ground that it would further inflate soaring health costs.

description: Lord Pentland, a British businessman who served as president of the Gurdjieff Foundation in New York for 31 years, died Tuesday in New York Hospital. Lord Pentland lived in Manhattan and was 76 years old.

title: HERITAGE COMMUNICATIONS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The latest year net includes a net gain of $197,000 from nonoperating fees from cable TV limited partnership and a net gain of $310,000 from the sale of a minority investment in a cable TV system. The 1982 net includes a net gain of $576,000 from nonoperationg fees from a cable TV limited partnership and a net gain of $715,000 from the sale of a minority investment.

title: MEXICO RELAXES RULES ON FOREIGN OWNERSHIP
description: In a qualified invitation to businesses based abroad, Mexico said today that it would allow majority foreign ownership for certain companies. The law generally requires 51 percent Mexican capital in foreign-held subsidiaries.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: The Most Outstanding . . .

title: STUDY TIES SMOKING IN PREGNANCY TO SIZE OF NEWBORN INFANTS
description: A study of pregnant women has provided ''very strong'' new evidence that cigarette smoking retards the growth of fetuses, researchers said today.

title: JOHNSON IS REALISTIC
description: Dave Johnson spent his first full day in uniform today as manager of the Mets. And, although his pet computer was being programmed at the University of Central Florida, 100 miles away, he did not need a computer to measure the perils of the job.

title: ATLANTIC AMERICAN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Share earnings reflect a 10 percent stock dividend paid in November 1983.

title: FILM: 'BLAME IT ON RIO'
description: OF all the remakes, credited and uncredited, now coming into New York theaters, two of the most joyless must be ''Crackers'' (reviewed on page C19) and ''Blame It on Rio,'' which, though there is no acknowledgment of the fact, is based on a 1977 French comedy by Claude Berri, ''One Wild Moment,'' released in this country in 1981.

title: Pope to Visit Low Countries
description: Pope John Paul II will visit Belgium, the Netherlands and Luxembourg in May 1985, a spokesman for Belgium's Roman Catholic episcopate said today.

title: MANUEL CABRANES, PUERTO RICAN AIDE IN CITY FOR 20 YEARS
description: Manuel Cabranes, a former government official in New York and in Puerto Rico, died in San Juan Sunday. He was 79 years old.

title: Bryan Foods Joins Ally
description: The well-spread fame of Ally & Gargano has brought it a new client from the deepest South - Bryan Foods of West Point, Miss., a meat processor that serves only that region of the country.

title: INTEREST RATES RISE; MONEY SUPPLY UP
description: Interest rates rose modestly yesterday, with most of the increase coming late in the day after the Federal Reserve announced that the nation's basic money supply had risen $2.5 billion in the week ended Feb. 6, to $532.9 billion.

title: RESTAURANTS
description: Cantonese fare that's unusual.

title: Mr. Mondale's Backbone
description: Reporters and the other Democratic Presidential candidates have been hounding Walter Mondale across Iowa with the question Gary Hart sprang on him in last week's debate: Could he name ''one major domestic issue in the last three or four years'' on which he had disagreed with the A.F.L.-C.I.O.?

title: PHONE USERS' COMPLAINTS RISING AFTER THE BELL SYSTEM BREAKUP
description: When Steve Latham, a distributor of Halloween costumes, moved his office in Manhattan recently, New York Telephone disconnected the phone in the old office before the new one was installed. So his business was without a phone.

title: SFE TECHNOLOGIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 27
TRUDEAU HAILS SESSION WITH CHERNENKO
description: Prime Minister Pierre Elliott Trudeau says his talks with Konstantin U. Chernenko, the new Soviet leader, suggested that Moscow might be prepared to accept the Canadian leader's proposal that the five major nuclear powers meet to discuss arms reductions.

title: KING'S 17 IN FOURTH HELP KNICKS WIN
description: The Knicks have learned how to win even when they play poorly. Bernard King has taught them.

title: STARTS IN HOUSING JUMP 15%
description: Construction of new homes jumped 15 percent in January from December, to the highest level in five years, the Government reported today.

title: WNYC 'AMERICATHON,' FREE CONCERT AT PUBLIC
description: Americans are changing the ways they celebrate their musical achievements. While once our ''serious'' music made claims to the European tradition of high art, we have recently taken to honoring instead our music's variety and energy. We celebrate not our art's depth, but its breadth; not its coherence, but its eclecticism; not any weighty past, but the promise of future experimentation.

title: No Headline
description: Phibro Gains 24.5% in Period Phibro-Salomon Inc., the international minerals trader

title: INTEGRATED ENERGY INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Trottier Back Tomorrow
description: Already strengthened by the limited return of Mike Bossy, the Islanders were cheered yesterday by the news that Bryan Trottier, their other scoring star, would be back in the lineup for the game tomorrow against the Rangers at Nassau Coliseum. Bossy was used in four power-play situations but not on a regular shift Wednesday night when the Islanders lost to the Rangers at Madison Square Garden, 3-2, on a goal by Nick Fotiu with 6 minutes 52 seconds to play.

title: CHANGES FOR COOPERATIVES THAT SELL TO PROFESSIONALS
description: Last August, the New York State Attorney General's office, which reviews offering plans for cooperatives and condominiums, issued proposed regulations governing the sale of professional office space in cooperative apartment buildings.

title: Target Store Chairman To Head Grand Union
description: Floyd Hall, chairman and chief executive of the Dayton-Hudson Corporation's Target discount store chain, has been named chairman and chief executive of the Grand Union supermarket chain.

title: NEW YORK TIMES CO. REPORTS NET UP SHARPLY
description: Earnings at The New York Times Company more than doubled in the fourth quarter of 1983 from earnings of a year earlier, the company announced yesterday.

title: VIKING FREIGHT SYSTEM INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income.

title: AUCTIONS
description: Napoleonic to Victorian.

title: CINCINNATI SCHOOL PACT IS EMBRACED AS A MODEL
description: A settlement described as an alternative to the type of school desegregation plan hailed last month by the Reagan Administration was reached today in a 10- year-old case here.

title: MEI CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
ALEXANDER ENERGY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Results for 1983 are restated for an accounting change.

title: Mt. McKinley Climber Signals to a Pilot
description: A pilot saw the Japanese adventurer Naomi Uemura on the windswept slopes of Mount McKinley today and reported he appeared to be in good condition after surviving a blizzard.

title: Tapping Telephone Good Will
description: When Ma Bell ran the phone system all by herself, the sure cure for an ailing dial tone was to call 611, the repair number. But when the system was divided last month, one-stop service ended. The local Bell operating companies, like New York Telephone, got the wires and most of the switching equipment, while A.T. & T. got the phones. Now if there's a problem on the line, it's New York Telephone's job to repair it. If your Trimline or Princess goes on the fritz, it's up to A.T. & T.

title: AVON LONG, ACTOR AND SINGER IN THEATER AND FILM 50 YEARS
description: Avon Long, who danced at the Cotton Club, sang in ''Porgy and Bess'' and acted in ''Roots: The Next Generations,'' died of cancer Wednesday at Columbia Presbyterian Medical Center. He was 73 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Britain Sets Spending Cut
description: Britain plans to cut public spending in real terms in the fiscal year beginning April 1, to hold the line the next year and then to cut spending again the following year, according to the annual white paper released today by the Treasury Department.

title: LOYALIST STRENGTH DROPS-6,100 ESTIMATED TO BE FIGHTING DAILY
description: Lebanese and Western military officials estimated today that only 12,000 of the 22,000 combat troops in the Lebanese Army were still loyal to the Government of President Amin Gemayel after two major defeats in the last 10 days.

title: HAMILTON WINS GOLD MEDAL IN FIGURE SKATING
description: His performance was uncharacteristically subdued, tentative and flawed. The usual animation was missing, and the crowd seldom had opportunities to get involved.

description: b-Includes tax credits of $202,000 for the quarter and $1,002,000 for the year. c-Net loss after a gain of $100,000 for the year from discontinued operations, pre-tax provisions for plant closings and litigation of $9,105,000 for the quarter and $13,470,000 for the year. The latest quarter had 12 weeks as compared to 13 weeks a year ago, and the 1983 year had 52 weeks as compared to 53 weeks a year ago.

description: b-Comparative year-ago results are not available because the company began operations in January 1983.

title: Nine Britons to Live In Tents in Antarctic
description: Nine British soldiers leave tomorrow to spend nine months in the Antarctic with no base hut to protect them from the savage winter.

title: HEALTH GROUPS ASSAIL CIGARETTE ADS
description: Three leading health organizations today accused the R. J. Reynolds Tobacco Company and other tobacco companies of ''misleading'' and ''irresponsible'' advertising that presented a false picture of the health consequences of smoking.

title: Heart-Liver Recipient Gains
description: Stormie Jones was ''awake, alert and responsive'' today at Children's Hospital, Dr. Basil Zitelli, her pediatrician, her doctor said. Early Tuesday, the 6-year-old Texan became the first recipient of a heart and liver transplant.

title: Profit Posted By Goodrich
description: The B.F. Goodrich Company said today that rising demand for its tires, chemicals, plastics and other products helped it post a profit of $6 million, or 24 cents a share, in the fourth quarter, compared with a $33.7 million loss a year earlier. Sales rose 17 percent, to $806.4 million, from $687.8 million.

description: The results from all prior periods have been restated to reflect the pooling-of-interests with Bailey International Group in 1983 and the 2-for-1 stock split in the form of a 100 percent stock dividend earlier this year.

title: Pennsylvania Mine Blast Leaves 3 Men Missing
description: An explosion apparently caused by methane gas in a Pennsylvania coal mine early today injured 10 miners and left three men missing. Officials said they feared the three men were dead.

title: 'ENDEARMENT' TOPS OSCAR NOMINATIONS
description: ''Terms of Endearment,'' a tragicomic movie about the relationship between a mother and daughter, today led the Academy Award nominations as expected, receiving 11 in nine separate categories.

title: DETROIT SCOUTS ALTER PROJECT ON SEXUALITY AFTER COOKIE THREAT
description: Fearing a boycott of their annual cookie sale by an anti-abortion group, Girl Scout leaders in the Detroit metroplitan area have revised a proposed program on teen-age sexuality so that it no longer mentions birth control or abortion.

title: Playboy to Sell Its Share in Casino
description: Playboy Enterprises Inc. announced today that it would pull out of the gaming business here and sell its 45.7 percent interest in its casino to its partner, the Elsinore Corporation.

title: M D C CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Grey and BBDO Also Did Nicely in 1983
description: Two ad agency companies that reported earlier - Grey Advertising and BBDO International - also had good years.

title: MADISON AVENUE: UPTOWN, IT'S COUPLES
description: THERE was a time when female artists married to male artists invariably took second place on the exhibition scene - if, indeed, they showed their work at all. ''His wife's an artist, too,'' was the usual comment made about a male artist afflicted with a ''creative'' spouse. But times have changed. Today, nearly a decade and a half after the first stirrings of feminism in the art world, such is the climate of acceptance for women artists that even their husbands feel free to acknowledge them as peers.

title: HAWKINS CHEMICAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
CAMPBELL SOUP COMPANY LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 29
LAURENCE MARCHINI, FOUNDER OF TWO BANKS IN MANHATTAN
description: Laurence Marchini, president and founder of the Gotham Bank of New York and for many years a leading financial figure in New York City's garment industry, died of pneumonia Monday at the Florida Medical Center in Fort Lauderdale, where he was vacationing. Mr. Marchini was 69 years old and lived in Manhasset, L.I.

title: REMARQUE'S DIARIES GIVEN TO N.Y.U.
description: THE diaries of Erich Maria Remarque, 22 composition books totaling more than 1,000 pages, have been donated to New York University by Paulette Goddard Remarque, the author's widow. One of the diaries covered 1918, a decade before Remarque wrote ''All Quiet on the Western Front,'' the best-known novel of World War I and one of the most powerful of all antiwar novels.

title: OUTLOOK IS BRIGHTER FOR MEDICARE TRUST FUND, AGENCY SAYS
description: New estimates by the Congressional Budget Office indicate that the Medicare trust fund is in somewhat better financial condition than some people thought, at least through 1989.

title: SOUTH AFRICANS AND ANGOLANS SET UP DISENGAGEMENT PANEL
description: South Africa and Angola have agreed to set up a joint commission, which might include the United States, to monitor South Africa's disengagement of troops from southern Angola, Foreign Minister Roelof F. Botha said today.

description: b-After a tax credit of $340,000. c-Net loss.

title: U.S. Play Angers Czechs
description: Czechoslovakia accused the United States Olympic hockey team today of dirty play in the game between the two countries last week and said that the motive was to help American television ratings. ''The Czechoslovak ice hockey match against the American team in Sarajevo, Yugoslavia, will not be forgotten soon, not for the quality of the game but for the foul play brought into it by the Americans,'' the official Communist Party daily Rude Pravo said.

title: A.T.&T.-Olivetti Deal
description: The American Telephone and Telegraph Company and Ing. C. Olivetti & Company said A.T.&T. had agreed to distribute $250 million worth of Olivetti products in the United States. The products will be made in Italy.

title: GLORY TOPS VALUE IN OLYMPIC MEDALS
description: Olympic athletes may strive for years to win the coveted prizes, but the value of the gold, silver and bronze medals that finally hang around their necks is more symbolic than real.

title: Continental Cuts Air Fares
description: Continental Air Lines Inc. said yesterday that it would reduce fares for flights between 73 markets in the Middle West, Northeast and on the West Coast. Continental said the reductions, which become effective Tuesday, were made to match cuts made by other airlines on selected western routes.

title: 5 NATIONS SUPPORT U.N. FORCE
description: Five nations today endorsed the idea of a greater United Nations peacekeeping effort in Lebanon but left unanswered the conditions under which the world body might replace the American, French and Italian troops in Beirut.

title: The U.N. Today; Feb. 17, 1984
description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY

title: LUDVIG'S OVERTIME GOAL WINS FOR DEVILS
description: The Devils relinquished two- goal leads twice in the third period tonight but defeated the Hartford Whalers, 6-5, on Jan Ludvig's goal with only six seconds left in the five- minute overtime period.

title: 2 MAJOR DEFENDANTS IN DRUG CASE GO FREE IN APPARENT MISTAKE
description: Two major narcotics defendants, who were being held in Manhattan in $1 million bail, have been released in what the United States Attorney described yesterday as apparently ''an unfortunate mistake.''

title: Tulsa Club's Future Dim
description: The Rangers said yesterday that they had abandoned their efforts to find new owners for the Tulsa Oilers, their top farm club, and would reassign 19 of the 20 Oiler players to other minor league teams while recalling the goaltender Steve Weeks. The decision appeared to mean the end of the Tulsa franchise, but at the request of the four other teams in the Central Hockey League the Rangers were reportedly considering a 24-hour moratorium on the reassignments in order to give the league a chance to work out a plan to keep the squad intact as a road team for the rest of the season.

title: MADE IN JAPAN: U.S. COOKIE
description: A best-selling New York cookie arrived in town today, and the question was whether Japanese would be interested more in the cookie or in New York. Or in either, for that matter.

title: FIGURE-SKATING JUDGES HAVE ROUTINE ALL THEIR OWN
description: They are the world's best amateur figure skaters. They have trained six hours or so a day, year after year, to reach the XIV Olympic Winter Games here.

title: SUPPORTERS OF REAGAN SEEK TO SETTLE CHARGES FROM '80
description: A political action committee and President Reagan's 1980 campaign committee agreed this week to pay civil penalties in an effort to resolve charges that both violated Federal election laws, according to officials of both groups.

title: CORRECTION
description: A brief news article yesterday about a poetry reading by Eve Merriam at the Manhattan Theater Club gave an incorrect date. It has already taken place.

title: LEGAL BARRIER LIFTED FOR PHOTO LICENSES FOR DRIVERS IN STATE
description: State officials said today that they had cleared away the legal obstacles that had blocked the use of pictures on drivers' licenses in New York, and that the first such licenses would be distributed by July 1.

title: Money Fund Assets Rise
description: Assets of the nation's money funds remained at their highest level since June 1983 in the week ended Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute reported yesterday.

title: Castro Stops in Spain; First West Europe Visit
description: Fidel Castro set foot in Western Europe for the first time today when he stoped here on his way home from Yuri V. Andropov's funeral in Moscow.

title: GOODRICH, B F, CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss and includes a provision of $19,900,000 for the quarter for restructuring.

title: Supply System Bonds
description: Holders of $2.25 billion worth of bonds on which the Washington Public Power Supply System defaulted have asked a Federal judge to put on hold millions of dollars of judgments against the power system.

title: WIRING M.I.T. FOR COMPUTERS
description: On the edge of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology campus here, in a red-brick warehouse marked only as Building E-40, the world's two largest computer companies are collaborating on a project that the university hopes will form a blueprint for the desktop computer systems of the next two decades.

title: Advertising; Studying Profits at 9 Agencies
description: R EVENUES of the nine public ad agencies have experienced decent growth over the last five years, but not so profits, according to a study by Veronis, Suhler & Associates, an investment banking firm that started in consulting for the magazine industry. According to the study, the agencies' collective earnings dropped 34.1 percent in the period although revenues were up 16 percent.

title: REPUBLIC'S QUEST FOR SURVIVAL
description: The Justice Department's rejection of the proposed merger of the LTV Corporation and the Republic Steel Corporation leaves Republic, the nation's fourth-largest steelmaker, still searching for the help it so badly needs. The weakened Cleveland- based company, many analysts said, will have a very tough time surviving on its own.

title: WINTER OLYMPICS FINALE
description: ONE viewing marathon, in sports, comes to a close Sunday on Channel 7. Another, in entertainment, gets started the same day on Channel 2..

title: Air Jamaica Account To Altschiller Reitzfeld
description: Air Jamaica, formerly served by Ketchum Advertising/New York, has chosen Altschiller Reitzfeld Solin as its agency.

title: South Africa Economy
description: Drought and falling gold prices have seriously affected South Africa's economy, which needs ''urgent attention,'' the country's Finance Minister, Owen Horwood, said today as he presented a preliminary budget to Parliament. Mr. Horwood said the general sales tax would be increased to help the Government reduce borrowing. He is expected to announce further tax increases when he presents his official budget March 28.

title: AT THE MOVIES
description: Isak Dinesen tale of Africa to be filmed.

Drug Testing Is Negative
description: Prince Alexandre de Merode of Belgium, the president of the International Olympic Committee's medical commission, says that of more than 500 athletes tested so far at the Olympic Winter Games here, none has been found to have taken banned drugs.

title: Police Are Cleared InPatient'sSuicide
description: An investigation of the arrest and suicide in a jail cell of a patient at a Veterans Administration hospital has found no violation of penal law, the Westchester County District Attorney's office said today.

title: Man Accused of Mail Theft
description: A postal worker was charged in Federal court Thursday with stealing 121,000 pieces of donation-laden mail intended for Oral Roberts, the television evangelist. The postal worker, Terry Lee Osborne, was released on $5,000 bond after a preliminary hearing was scheduled for March 2. The mail was believed to have been stolen from December 1981 to last Tuesday.

title: First Peoples Bank
description: First Peoples Bank of New Jersey said the Comptroller of the Currency had approved the application by First National Bank of Toms River to acquire certain assets and assume certain liabilities of seven branches of First Peoples Bank.

title: NICHOLAS A. YANNI JR.
description: Nicholas A. Yanni Jr., the host of a cable-television talk show in New York City and the author of magazine articles and books on television and film, died Wednesday in the Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center.

title: BEIRUT'S CHRISTIANS ASK IF THE U.S. HAS A POLICY
description: Christians in East Beirut have expressed anger and uncertainty over United States policy toward Lebanon.

description: A defense lawyer yesterday rejected a deaf man as a juror in a Manhattan drug trial, arguing the man was ''not qualified'' because he could not hear or speak.

title: JUDGE REBUKES GOVERNMENT ON FARM WORKER SANITATION
description: A Federal district judge rebuked the Government today for delays in enforcing a court order that the Labor Department require drinking water and basic sanitation facilities for millions of farm workers.

title: PLAYING HOCKEY AT 52: A KID AT HEART
description: On a gray January Sunday morning, which happened to be the eve of my 52d birthday, I drove past the frozen town pond, on my way to the general store to pick up the newspaper and a carton of milk. Two boys were on the pond ice, slapping a hockey puck around - not an uncommon winter scene in this neck of the Connecticut woods - but the sight of them that particular morning bumping over the rough ice brought back a wistful memory or two: a similar New England pond 40 years ago . . . myself, bundled up and perspiring, rushing a puck down the ice toward my best friend, an insouciant goaltender guarding a rickety, homemade wooden cage . . . the satisfying exhaustion that comes with hard exercise in the cold.

title: BRIEFING

title: STAGE: REVUE BY THURBER
description: Up at the Equity Library Theater on 103d and Riverside Drive - with a suggested admission of $6, the plays are one of the best bargains in town - someone had the bright idea of bringing back James Thurber's ''Thurber Carnival,'' the comedy revue with music by Don Elliott that scored on Broadway 24 years ago.

Results are in Australian dollars.

title: POP: CUCUMBERS OF HOBOKEN
description: The Cucumbers, a four-piece band from Hoboken, N.J., have a new twist on the winsome pop of the 1960's. At Irving Plaza Thursday, the Cucumbers played snappy propulsive songs - many of them about desire and its discontents - that were smart but not cynical, and earnest without a hint of na"ivete.

title: MISS SUMNERS VOWS HER BEST
description: Talking like a prizefighter before a title bout, Rosalynn Sumners of Edmonds, Wash., pledged today to make an all-out effort in the free- skating program Saturday and win the Olympic gold medal in women's figure skating.

description: To the Editor:

title: Ambrosiano Pact Called Near
description: Pope John Paul II will authorize a payment of about $250 million from Vatican funds to the creditors of the defunct Banco Ambrosiano under a plan being considered by bankers, banking sources said today.

title: MERRILL FIGHTS DEPOSIT RULE
description: Merrill Lynch & Company has begun a grass- roots lobbying effort to overturn a regulation proposed by Federal banking regulators that would limit the availability of insurance on deposits placed by brokers.

LISBON OFICERS CLUB: COUP MAKERS OR BREAKERS
description: Inside the Fortress of Good Success, an aging concrete structure on the banks of the Tagus River here where the guns have not sounded in years, the walls are decorated with posters from the Portuguese revolution of almost a decade ago.

title: FLOATING POINT SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
Tuition Assistance Needs
description: Assistance For low- and moderate-income college students in New York, TAP, the Tuition Assistance Program, has been a blessing. It provides them with tuition grants of up to $2,200, based on need, to attend public or private universities in the state. But the blessing has been shrinking ever since the program began in 1974.

title: WIFE REPORTS DISSIDENT TRANSFERRED TO SIBERIA
description: The wife of a leading Soviet human rights activist said today that the authorities had indicated that her husband was en route to Siberia to serve the second part of his 12-year sentence, a 5-year term of ''internal exile.''

title: K Mart Is Allowed Savings Collection
description: A state court judge said the K Mart Corporation is free to collect savings deposits from customers in its Florida stores, rejecting requests for an injunction sought by state banking regulators. It was unclear whether K Mart would be able to immediately resume the program, suspended on Jan. 31 after two weeks in operation.

title: Ranger Farm to Denver
description: The Rangers and the Central Hockey League reached agreement in principle yesterday to revive the Tulsa Oilers, the Rangers' farm club, as a road team for the rest of the season. The move came a day after Craig Patrick, the Rangers' general manager, said the team had abandoned its efforts to find new owners in Tulsa for the Oilers, whose previous owners had said they could no longer continue the debt-ridden team's operations.

title: Moroccan to Visit U.S.
description: Prime Minister Mohammed Karim Lamrani will visit Washington for two days starting Feb. 27 for talks with Secretary of State George P. Shultz and Secretary of Agriculture John R. Block, diplomatic sources said today.

title: LED STATE LIQUOR AUTHORITY
description: Thomas E. Rohan, a former chairman of the New York State Liquor Authority who also served as a judge in New York City, died of cancer yesterday at St. Vincent's Medical Center. He was 78 years old and lived in Pelham Manor, N.Y.

title: DIGITECH INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Year to Oct 31
description: b-After a charge of $2,367,000 against electro-mechanical inventories located in the company's Sace operations.

title: JETS WILL LOSE RUDOLPH IN 1985
description: Among the reasons the Jets traded the defensive linemen Kenny Neil and Abdul Salaam to the San Diego Chargers earlier this week was that three younger players - Ben Rudolph, Barry Bennett and John Walker - had impressed Coach Joe Walton and his staff enough to be ''in our future.''

title: PURITAN-BENNETT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss.

title: ONE-MAN SHOW'S CAST OF 50
description: Ever since he opened five weeks ago in ''Acting Shakespeare,'' his one-man tour de force at the Ritz Theater, Ian McKellen has been taking a final bow to thunderous applause. But the acclaimed British actor, who must end his run tomorrow night to report to the National Theater in London, has not been taking his bow in solitary splendor.

title: MAN IS ARRESTED IN FOUR SLAYINGS SINCE DECEMBER
description: A man described by the police as a ''contract killer'' was arrested yesterday on charges of shooting four people to death in upper Manhattan since last December. All the slayings, the police said, were related to drugs or gambling.

title: SATURDAY NEWS QUIZ
description: Questions are based on news reports in The Times this week. Answers appear on page 39.

title: FIRST CARS FOR IRT MADE BY JAPANESE FAIL 30-DAY TESTS
description: The New York City Transit Authority said yesterday that its new Japanese subway cars had failed their first two performance tests because of minor problems with brakes and door switches.

title: UNITED FINANCIAL GROUP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income.

title: Xonics Chapter 11
description: Xonics Inc., a maker and distributor of medical equipment, said its domestic subsidaries had filed under Chapter 11 of the Federal Bankruptcy Act. The company said the filing resulted from unsuccessful negotiations with its lenders and a major customer to restructure its financial obligations. The company reported a loss of $17.9 million for its third quarter.

title: RAX RESTAURANTS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 28
TV: VIEW OF NBC COVERAGE OF LEBANON INVASION
description: ''NBC in Lebanon,'' subtitled ''A Study in Media Misrepresentation,'' is a polemic; it stacks the deck, and sometimes it nearly collapses under its own sarcasm. At the same time, it raises significant questions about television journalism. It attempts to prove, and to a large extent does prove, that coverage by the ''NBC Nightly News'' of the Israeli invasion of Lebanon in the summer of 1982 was faulty. The one-hour documentary will be seen on National Jewish Television, carried by several cable systems, at 1 P.M. tomorrow.

title: SCOUTING
description: Taylor's Worry

title: Red Brigades Claim Killing of American
description: Italy's Red Brigades guerrilla group claimed responsibility today for the slaying of a United States diplomat in Rome.

title: GUARD GIVES DETAILS OF BRITISH GOLD ROBBERY
description: A detailed picture of the $38 million gold robbery near Heathrow Airport in November emerged today in testimony involving a security guard.

title: CULTURAL EXCHANGE: ONE WAY TO LEARN
description: Up until the end of 1979, cultural ties between the Soviet Union and the United States were strong and developing successfully under an official agreement. In December 1979, the agreement expired. A month later, President Jimmy Carter announced sanctions against the Soviet Union, which included cancellation of negotiations on renewing the treaty and planned visits and expositions by Soviet artists, musicians, actors and dancers - in particular, the exhibition ''Treasures from the Hermitage.'' The idea of renewing cultural contacts was raised by certain people in America last year. But there were new sanctions in September, before negotiations could start.

title: WHITE HOUSE WRONG TO BAR GROUPS FROM FUND DRIVE, COURT RULES
description: A sharply divided Federal appeals panel ruled today that President Reagan violated the Constitution in excluding legal defense funds from the annual charitable fund- raising drive among Federal employees.

title: WNYC Will Repeat Interrupted Radio Show
description: Radio station WNYC is going to rebroadcast the ''News From Lake Wobegone'' segment of the popular ''Prairie Home Companion'' series that was cut short last week because of difficulty in receiving a satellite transmission.

title: SYRIA DENOUNCES SAUDI PEACE PLAN
description: Syria today denounced an eight-point Saudi- backed plan intended to bring about a negotiated settlement of the Lebanese crisis.

title: REAGAN DEFENDS RECORD ON WOMEN
description: President Reagan today told a group of Republican women who are officeholders, ''By turning the economy around, we've helped every American, and particularly women.''

title: Bridge: Use of the Negative Double Presents Variety of Choices
description: Most users of the negative double consider that a double of one diamond, as shown in the diagram, promises both major suits. Whether this must be 4-4, or could be 4-5, 5-4 or 5-5 is a matter of partnership agreement.

title: Donald Richardson Sr. Dies; Bred Prize-Winning Orchids
description: Donald Richardson Sr., a horticulturist who specialized in breeding, judging, lecturing and writing about orchids, died Thursday at his home in Manhasset, L.I., a month after undergoing hip surgery. He was 77 years old.

title: BOBBIE BROOKS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 28
description: b-After income from discontinued operations of $1,200,000 for the quarter and $2,992,000 for the 9 months, and a tax loss of $240,000 for the quarter.

title: LET THEM VISIT THEIR GRANDCHILDREN
description: To the Editor:

title: 'ANTI-TARGETING' AS BAD FOR TRADE AS SMOOT-HAWLEY TARIFFS IN 1930'S
description: Foreign governments' selection of particular industries for support, a practice known as targeting, has incubated the latest trade disease germinating in Congress: anti-targeting. The political prospect of attacking the practice is so seductive, and proposed legislation so well-sponsored, that unfortunately it has an excellent chance of becoming law. If anti-targeting takes hold, it could be equally as disastrous as the Smoot-Hawley tariff and quota legislation of the early 1930's, which promised to solve trade problems.

title: BRT REALTY TRUST reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes an extraordinary gain of $1,276,654 attributable to the forgiveness of the remaining obligations to leading banks less related expenses resulting from the financial restructuring plan. The company changed its fiscal year from one ended Nov. 30 to one ended Sept. 30 to conform with that of Gould Investors which owns a majority of BRT's outstanding shares. Year-ago results are for the quarter which ended Feb. 28, 1983.

title: Work Group Files Complaint On Labor's Aid for Mondale
description: The National Right to Work Committee filed a complaint with the Federal Election Commission today charging that elements of organized labor were illegally ''subsidizing'' the campaign of Walter F. Mondale for the Democratic Presidential nomination.

title: NEW YORK NOTABLES DINE TO MEET, NOT TO EAT
description: Power brokers and high society luminaries attired in black tie and designer gowns dined on Bill Blass's meat loaf in the Grand Ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria. On another night, Wall Street brokers, bankers and lawyers wore waterfowl neckties, made duck calls and occasionally hurled a French roll during the annual dinner staged by Ducks Unlimited, a national group of conservation-minded waterfowl hunters.

title: Brown Defeats Lewis in 2 Sprints
description: Ron Brown scored a pair of upset victories over Carl Lewis in tonight's Michelob Invitational indoor meet.

title: Key Rates
description: * Kenny Index, Kenny Information Systems Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: STATES' ACTIONS ON EDB IN FOOD RESULTING IN PATTERN OF CONFUSION
description: State governments have reacted quite differently to the threat of the pesticide EDB in food, confusing consumers and causing health officials to look for a way to standardize their testing and enforcement programs.

title: Glenn Defends Tactics After Party Warning
description: A spokesman for Senator John Glenn of Ohio defended his campaign tactics today, but Senator Alan Cranston said the strident debate between Mr. Glenn and Walter F. Mondale in their quests for the Democratic Presidential nomination helped no one but President Reagan.

title: PANEL FORMED TO STUDY GOALS FOR CITY'
description: S GROWTH

title: GEOFFREY MILLER
description: Geoffrey Miller, the European sports editor for The Associated Press, died today, apparently of a heart attack. He was 62 years old.

title: DOW OFF 6.7, TO 1,148.87, ON INTEREST-RATE FEARS
description: The stock market, still beset by interest-rate worries, continued to confront selling pressure yesterday, and prices finished moderately lower in the slowest trading since early January.

title: County Is Upheld On Rent Freeze
description: A two- year rent freeze enacted last Oct. 20 and involving 64,000 Westchester County apartments has been upheld by Justice Morrie Slifkin in State Supreme Court here.

title: Carrie Munn, Dress Designer In the 40's and 50's, Is Dead
description: Carrie Munn, a designer who created custom clothes for women in the 1940's and 50's, died of a stroke Wednesday at Presbyterian Hospital. She was in her 80's and lived in Manhattan.

title: CORROON & BLACK CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
OLIVER HAUPT
description: Oliver Haupt, who won the national junior figure-skating championship in 1938 and was a member of the 1940 United States Olympic team, died Thursday in New York, apparently of a heart attack.

title: Sean Connery Awarded $4.1 Million in Lawsuit
description: Sean Connery, better known to millions of movie fans as secret agent 007 James Bond, was awarded damages of $4.1 million against his former accountant, his lawyer said today.

title: MAXWELL LABORATORIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: Results for the latest periods include merger expenses of $148,000. Year-ago results have been restated to reflect an acquisition in January 1984.

title: IRAN-IRAQ CONFLICT IS SEEN AT NEW CRITICAL JUNCTURE
description: Military Analysis

title: William Polisi Is Dead at 76; Ex-Philharmonic Bassoonist
description: William Polisi, a prominent bassoonist for more than 50 years, died on Thursday at his home in Queens. He was 76 years old.

title: Soviet Defeats Canada, 4-0
description: Canada built a wall to contain the Soviet Union's hockey scoring machine tonight, but the unbeaten Soviet squad still managed a 4-0 victory that assured a gold-medal showdown with Czechoslovakia Sunday at the XIV Olympic Winter Games.

title: SWANK INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Two Editors Named by U.P.I.
description: Lucien Carr has been named to the new position of assistant managing editor- news for United Press International, Maxwell McCrohon, executive vice president and editor in chief of the news agency, announced today. Mr. Carr, who is 58 years old, served most recently as senior general news editor. Mr. McCrohon also announced the appointment of Daniel Chiszar, 35, as night news editor.

title: FIRST PEOPLES BANK OF N.J. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
KOHL SEEKING U.S.-SOVIET SUMMIT TALKS
description: Chancellor Helmut Kohl has decided to press President Reagan and the new Soviet leader, Konstantin U. Chernenko, to hold a summit meeting that he hopes would lead to a resumption of talks on limiting nuclear arms, a high aide to the West German leader says.

title: KOZLOVS FIND A HOME AT NEW YORK CITY BALLET
description: ''How's the show going?'' a genial headwaiter asked as Leonid Kozlov and Valentina Kozlova, recently seen on Broadway in the revival of the musical ''On Your Toes,'' slid into a restaurant booth the other day. ''The show is over there now,'' Mr. Kozlov replied, pointing across the street to the New York State Theater, where the New York City Ballet will complete its winter season tomorrow.

title: REALEX CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-Net loss.

title: U.S. WOMEN ARE SHUT OUT
description: Paoletta Magoni of Italy mastered a steep, fog-shrouded slalom course today to win the gold medal at the XIV Olympic Winter Games, beating Perrine Pelen of France and Ursula Konzett of Liechtenstein.

title: Special Trade Duties Support
description: The Commerce Department, in a potentially significant foreign trade ruling, said today that the Government can impose special duties to protect United States companies against subsidized imports from ''non-free market'' nations, such as China and Eastern European countries.

title: CENTRAL MAINE POWER reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: The Horse in the Lobby

title: BKW INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income.

title: LONGVIEW FIBRE CO reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-Net loss

title: PETRO-LEWIS PLANS TO LAY OFF 400
description: The Petro-Lewis Corporation, which earlier this month suspended its main sales operations, said today that it would lay off about 400 workers within the next two weeks.

title: RIGHETTI GETS RELIEF ROLE
description: When Dave Righetti arrived at Fort Lauderdale Stadium today for the start of spring training, he noticed that his name was not posted above his locker. ''I guess they're trying to tell me something,'' he said jokingly.

title: 3 Exchanges Are Moving
description: Reflecting the growth in the commodity and options markets, the Chicago Board Options Exchange, the MidAmerica Commodity Exchange and the New Orleans Commodity Exchange will move to larger quarters over the weekend.

title: Get Serious About Simulcast Racing
description: Pinched between stagnant betting totals and rising racing costs, New York State's race tracks and its six Off-Track Betting corporations are a rising source of worry in Albany. The state and its local governments take about $150 million a year from the betting public, an amount that's likely to decline in coming years.

title: DURHAM CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Two Irelands
description: There are two Irelands, and they meet uneasily each March on St. Patrick's Day. One is the dream country in the minds of many Irish-Americans like Thomas Gleason, just elected grand marshal of next month's parade. Put simply, theirs is a country cruelly wronged by centuries of British oppression, which continues to throttle Northern Ireland using police-state methods.

title: Youth Is Suspect In30FalseAlarms
description: A Manhattan teen-ager suspected of calling in as many as 30 false fire alarms was arrested yesterday at a phone booth across the street from his high school, authorities said.

title: Biegenwald Gets A Life Sentence
description: The jury in the trial of Richard F. Biegenwald failed today to decide on a penalty for the murder of a reputed drug dealer, so a judge sentenced him to life in prison. Mr. Biegenwald has already been sentenced to die for the murder of a young Camden woman.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Have Seat, May Build

title: TRECO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a charge of $120,000 for the quarter from the reversal of a tax credit and a tax credit of $1,250,000 for the 9 months. c-Net loss after a charge of $115,000 from the reversal of a tax credit. d-Including a tax credit of $2,061,000 and a gain of $2,420,689 from the early repayment of debt.

title: 7 Turkish Leftists Doomed
description: A military court sentenced seven leftists to death today for trying to establish a Communist dictatorship and sentenced 41 other leftists to jail for terms ranging from 3 to 20 years, the semiofficial Anatolia press agency reported.

title: Payton Offer Dropped
description: The Chicago Blitz of the U.S.F.L. say they have withdrawn their multimillion-dollar offer to Walter Payton because the Chicago Bears' running back failed to meet a second deadline either to accept or reject the offer. ''I'm a little bit aggravated,'' said Ron Potocnik , the Blitz general manager, after a deadline of midnight Wednesday passed without a response from Payton, who has been negotiating with the Bears.

title: Freddie Waits Trio
description: The drummer Freddie Waits will lead an unusual trio, with Bob Stewart on tuba and Jay Hoggard on vibraphone, tonight at the Manhattan Healing Arts Center (685-4785), on the sixth floor at 386 Broadway, below Canal Street. Sets begin at 9 and 11 P.M., and tickets are $7.

title: INTERCONTINENTAL ENERGY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Youth Is Suspect In 30 False Alarms
description: A Manhattan teen-ager suspected of calling in as many as 30 false fire alarms was arrested yesterday at a phone booth across the street from his high school, authorities said.

title: CARHART PHOTO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
No Headline

description: b-Net loss

title: BellSouth Rates
description: Southern Bell asked the Florida Public Service Commission for a $92.5 million rate increase. A spokesman said this was to enable the company, now a unit of BellSouth, to recover revenues from leased telephone sets handed over to the American Telephone and Telegraph Company.

title: PATENTS
description: ORTHRODONTIST DEVELOPS 'FACEBOW' FOR PATIENTS

title: 2 More Killed in Punjab As Sikhs Fight Police
description: Sikh gunmen, some firing from the rooftops of their holiest shrine, fought the police for nearly seven hours today in a battle that left two dead and three injured.

title: NEW CONGRESSIONAL DISTRICTS FOR JERSEY APPROVED
description: A Federal Court panel approved a Congressional redistricting plan today that fixes the boundaries of the state's 14 districts for this year's elections.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: SATURDAY, FEBRUARY 18, 1984

title: CANADA,U.S. ACT ON TRADE
description: The United States and Canada acted today to strengthen their trading relationship by starting exploratory talks on more duty-free trade. The two countries also adopted procedures to eliminate frictions when they take temporary measures to protect domestic industries.

title: TEXAS UTILITIES CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
KIDDE INC reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-After loss from discontinued operations of $196,400,000. c-Net income after income from discontinued operations of $19,820,000.

description: b-Including income from discontinued operations of $386,000 for the quarter and $5,601,000 for the year amd an extraordinary gain of $7,625,000 for the year. c-Including income from discontinued operations of $827,000 for the quarter and $3,954,000 for the year. Results have been restated for a change in accounting mandated by the Interstate Commerce Commission.

NORTEK INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
CALIFORNIA PETITIONS SEEK U.S. BUDGET BALANCE
description: Petitions signed by more than 550,000 California voters who support an amendment to the Constitution that would require a balanced Federal budget were filed with county voter registrars today.

title: 39 FOR ERVING
description: There is no better cure for a struggling team than another struggling team. Tonight, the Nets and the Philadelphia 76ers, both trying to work out of slumps, were ideal opponents.

title: Garbage Gas Is Turned Into Energy on Coast
description: The nation's largest landfill began today producing electrical energy from methane gas emitted by 10,000 tons of garbage dumped each day.

title: CASABLANCA INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes an extraordinary credit of $1,804,000. c-Includes an extraordinary credit of $204,000.

title: ARE BANK RECORDS PRIVATE?
description: HOW much information should a bank divulge over the telephone about a customer's accounts? That question came up recently when a Manhattan real estate broker called a major bank's customer service number and, in less than two minutes, was told exactly how much a client had on deposit at a branch on the Upper West Side.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE;
description: IN THE BACK ROOM You would never expect to find the Boomerstown Women's Club and its poetry forum in the back room of Eric's, a bar and restaurant at Second Avenue and 88th Street (534- 8500), but there they will be tomorrow night and next Sunday at 8 P.M. (and maybe more after that), elevating the tone of this flashy and lively thoroughfare.

title: CANFOR reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes a special charge for reversal of a tax credit of $700,000 for the quarter and a tax credit of $300,000 for the year.

title: A GROUP OF DOCTORS OWNS DEVICE DENIED TO HOSPITAL
description: Eight physicians in private practice on Fifth Avenue have installed the same type of expensive diagnostic machine that New York State is denying to the Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center.

title: REAGAN DEFENDS LEBANON POLICY, CITING SYRIA AS 'STUMBLING BLOCK'
description: President Reagan asserted today that it was ''unfair'' to say his policies had failed in Lebanon, despite the military and political disarray of the Government there.

title: NUI TO CONTINUE MERGER BID
description: In an unusual takeover battle between two New Jersey utility companies, the NUI Corporation says it will continue its attempt to merge with the larger New Jersey Resources Corporation despite a lopsided defeat in a proxy battle.

title: REPUBLIC AUTOMOTIVE PARTS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Results for the latest periods include operations of Distribution Center and Ten Jobber Stores, acquired effective Sept. 1.

title: E.C. ERNST INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Year-ago results are restated. Revenue figures represent contract income.

title: SCOUTING
description: On the Road Back

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Helping the Mother Tongue

title: MINNESOTA U. SETTLES STUDENT NEWSPAPER SUIT
description: In a case that raised issues of press and academic freedom, the student newspaper at the University of Minnesota has won $182,000 and reinstatement of a guaranteed subsidy under an out-of-court settlement with the university.

title: PRIMA ENERGY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Tall in the Saddle
description: Donald Miller Jr. , a 20-year-old jockey in his third year as a professional, brought home his 1,000th career winner yesterday when he rode Perfect Light to victory in the first race at Bowie Race Course in Maryland. Then, to celebrate the milestone, Miller rode five more winners, equaling the best one-day performance in the track's 70-year history.

title: PIONEER SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Year to Dec 3
description: b-After a loss of $318,000 from discontinued operations. c-Net loss after a loss of $962,000 from discontinued operations.

title: CUOMO BLOCKS STATE FUNDS FOR CAREY PAPERS
description: Governor Cuomo has blocked state funds for the publication of the official papers of his predecessor, Hugh L. Carey, saying printing the papers costs too much and should be discontinued.

title: Charges in Tanker Suit
description: The Justice Department today sued three former executives for more than $1.8 million on charges of defrauding the Government during the construction of natural gas tankers and nuclear submarines by the General Dynamics Corporation.

title: REGAL BELOIT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Share earnings reflect a 3-for-2 stock split in November.

title: LOGIMETRICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes tax credits of $5,999 for the quarter and $39,527 for the 6 months. c-After a tax credit of $12,203.

title: KANE-MILLER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $365,000 for the quarter and $8,069,000 for the year. c-After gains from discontinued operations of $266,000 for the quarter and $440,000 for the year. d-Net income The latest year loss from discontinued operations includes estimated loss of disposal of $6,545,000 in the third quarter of 1983.

title: Letter: On Nuclear Power Time to Abandon Shoreham To the Editor:
description: While The Times editorial board seems determined to be the last to go down with the Shoreham ship, and more than willing to captain the situation until then, it has gone too far in asserting that there would be a cost savings associated with operating the nuclear power plant.

title: ECONOMY GREW 4.9% IN QUATER
description: The United States economy grew at an annual rate of 4.9 percent in the final quarter of 1983, the Commerce Department said today.

title: ISRAELI ARMY TO QUIT URBAN AREAS FOR NEW POSITION CLOSER TO BORDER
description: Officials said today that Israel was planning for a long-term occupation of a zone in southern Lebanon, in view of the Lebanese Government's decision to cancel a security accord with Israel.

title: SOVIET TAKES BIATHLON RELAY
description: Sergei Buligin overtook Frank Ullrich of East Germany in the final lap, then held off challenges from fast-closing Norwegian and West German competitors today to give the Soviet Union its fifth consecutive Olympic victory in the 4-x-7.5- kilometer biathlon relay.

title: BUYING A BOND ON FIDUCIARIES
description: T he use of fiduciary bonds, which are meant

title: UNITED CUTS SOME FARES TO MATCH CONTINENTAL'S
description: United Airlines yesterday matched Continental's lower fares in markets mainly west of the Mississippi, and analysts said the price reductions by Continental could set off a wider fare war this year.

title: POLICE IN JERSEY TOLD TO RETURN SEIZED STUDENT FILES
description: A State Superior Court judge today ordered the police in Summit to return to school officials a carton of student disciplinary records they seized last week.

title: Color Them Red
description: The Buffalo Bills have decided to switch from white to red helmets for the coming football season, and the reason, they say, is strategic and not cosmetic. White helmets are thought to provide an advantage in the passing game because the highly visible headgear makes it easier for a quarterback to pick up receivers down field.

title: U.S. News Invites Purchase Offers
description: The board of directors of U.S. News & World Report informed employees that it had decided to invite potential buyers to submit offers for the company. A memo distributed to the staff of the 2.2-million circulation weekly said Morgan Stanley & Company, which was retained to evaluate an offer for the company, had proposed that it be authorized to solicit any ''indication of interest'' by other potential buyers.

title: Rights Panel Chief Leaving His Post
description: The chairman of the city's Commission on Human Rights has submitted his resignation, Mayor Koch's office announced yesterday.

title: TOYS FOR '84: TRIVIA AND HIGH TECHNOLOGY
description: It's nostalgia time in toyland. There, dependable old heroes - Superman, Batman, Wonder Woman, Spider-Man and the rest of their Marvel Comics and DC Comics companions - are returning to join the newer good guys like Mr. T and the rest of the A-Team and Maxx Steele, a 34- pound programmable robot with an electronic computer brain. And many of the newer board or card games are set in past eras.

title: Times Square Report Is Available to Public
description: An 880-page draft environmental- impact statement for the proposed $1.6 billion Times Square redevelopment project was released yesterday and is available to the public.

title: GENESEE BREWING CO reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
KING 91-83 WINNER IN P.S.A.L. PLAYOFFS
description: In a game in which quick changes in tempo made it seem as much a relay race as basketball, Martin Luther King High School defeated John F. Kennedy, 91-83, yesterday at Brandeis High in the opening round of the Public Schools Athletic League playoffs.

title: SCOUTING
description: New Hitting Life Begins at 40

title: THE MARXIST WHO LEFT HIS MARK ON THE CAPITAL
description: He remains one of the most mysterious figures ever to cast his shadow on Washington, a German-born genius who was at the heart of the political struggles of the 19th century and whose ideas took root the American capital, where they flourish still.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: A picture caption in some copies of Sports Pages yesterday with an article about the Rutgers-Newark basketball team listed one name too many. Those seated were Paul Reid and Derrick Moses.

title: Accidents Upset Daytona Drivers
description: The third accident this week took place on the fourth turn at Daytona International Speedway today, leading Darrell Waltrip and other drivers to call for urgent repairs on the turn.

title: ROUSE CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Dorchester Accepts New Damson Bid
description: The Dorchester Gas Corporation has accepted a revised takeover offer for $24 a share, or about $312 million in cash, from the Damson Oil Company, the two companies announced yesterday.

title: Axia to Be Bought For $173 Million
description: Axia Inc. said that it had entered into a merger agreement with a group of private investors under which the company will be acquired for $26 a share, or a total of about $173 million.

title: U.S. Denies Hearing On Sweetener Safety
description: The Food and Drug Administration today rejected a request by a consumer group and a food scientist to hold a public hearing on the safety of the low-calorie sweetener aspartame.

title: ATTEMPT TO REPLACE PAROLE BOARD CHIEF RENEWED BY CUOMO
description: The Cuomo administration said yesterday that the arrest of a parolee on charges of killing a police officer had ''reinforced and accelerated'' its efforts to replace the head of the State Parole Board.

title: AMERICAN DISTRICT TELERAPH CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Layoffs at Excel
description: The Excel Corporation said today that it would close its plant at Rockport, Mo., for at least two weeks, laying off 475 hourly employees, because of economic problems in the processed beef industry.

title: ON RESTAURANTS AND RESERVATIONS
description: After a recent column described the problems caused by people who book tables at restaurants but fail to show up, readers who honor their reservations wrote to present their side. Their unpleasant experiences cover everything from a restaurant's refusing to honor a reservation or keeping patrons waiting for ages to treating early diners as second-class citizens.

title: SHOWY JEWELRY FOR SPRING
description: Most of the American spring collections for women were made of simple, plainly tailored clothes in crisp cottons and linens, so it makes perfect sense that much of the new costume jewelry being designed now is the exact opposite in feeling.

title: STAGE: 'FREEDOM DAYS,' CIVIL RIGHTS MOVEMENT
description: The Modern Times Theater, which specializes in plays with political and moral content, is in residence at the Washington Square Church with ''Freedom Days,'' a quartet of tales about heroes and heroines of the civil- rights movement. The fact that the subject is a familiar one does not diminish the evening's effectiveness or the value of the retelling.

title: Dual-Transplant Girl Greets Her Mother
description: Stormie Jones, the 6-year-old girl who had the world's first simultaneous heart and liver transplants, greeted her mother today with ''I love you'' and sat in a chair for the first time since the operation, the hospital reported.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: SATURDAY, FEBRUARY 18, 1984 International Amin Gemayel's reconciliation offer was rejected by the Lebanese opposition, and Syria denounced the plan. Syria's official press agency described it as a ''trick that has been unmasked.'' Opposition officials in Lebanon indicated that they felt it was too late to repair relations between them and Mr. Gemayel. (Page 1, Column 6.) Long-term occupation of a zone in southern Lebanon is being planned by Israel in view of the announcement by President Gemayel that he will cancel a 1983 security accord with Israel. The zone's boundaries were not defined, but Israeli officials said the army would pull back from positions at the Awali River to a line closer to the Israeli-Lebanese border and leave such major population centers as the coastal city of Sidon. (1:4.)

title: INTEREST RATES MOVE HIGHER
description: Interest rates rose yesterday when investors sold government securities because of growing fears that the Federal Reserve may tighten credit availability in response to the continuing strength in the economy.

description: Supreme Court Justice Sandra Day O'Connor cleared the way today for the jailing of Jake Butcher, the bankrupt Tennessee financier, if he refuses to turn over business records to a Federal grand jury.

PATENTS;

description: A system for transmitting computer or other data among a number of stations while avoiding message interference has been patented for the Department of Energy.

The card is headed by a superheavyweight rematch between Tyrell Biggs of the United States and Teofilo Stevenson , the gold-medal winner in the last three Olympics who scored a second-round knockout over Biggs in November 1982.

description: A three-member panel named by the Department of Energy went to the Nevada Test Site today to investigate a ground collapse that injured 14 workers after a nuclear explosion.

description: A taxi driver on the island of Crete was charged today with the murder Thursday of an 18- year-old United States Navy specialist. The victim, James J. Antkowiak, of Peru, Ill., joined the Navy four months ago and was about to join the aircraft carrier Independence at Crete. His badly beaten body was found outside a Canea nightclub.

title: MARCOS FOE ARRESTED DEPARTING FOR U.S. THEN ORDERED FREED
description: Salvador H. Laurel, a political opponent of President Ferdinand E. Marcos, was arrested at the airport Friday as he was about to board a plane for the United States. He was charged with illegally carrying a handgun.

title: Financier Gets St. Regis Stake

The group said Sir James held discussions with William Haselton, chairman of St. Regis, on Tuesday and Wednesday.

title: CONFERENCE TAKES LOOK AT LOS ANGELES'S FUTURE
description: Leaders here took stock of their city's future this week and concluded that it was largely being shaped by powerful forces beyond its borders.

description: The Government today ordered the police to break up highway blockades set up by truckers that have stranded thousands of vacationers and villagers in freezing weather across a 20,000- square-mile area of the French Alps.

title: Devil's Bag May Face 5
description: Devil's Bag, the undefeated early favorite for the Kentucky Derby, will make his seasonal debut Monday in the Flamingo Prep at Hialeah Park against five apparently outclassed 3-year-olds. Devil's Bag, who won all five of his starts as a 2-year-old and set two stakes records in the process, will be ridden by Eddie Maple and carry top weight of 121 pounds over seven furlongs.

title: OPPONENTS BALK NAVY SIGNALS FROM DEEP IN MICHIGAN FOREST
description: Just off Crooked Lake Road, deep in the snow-dusted isolation of the Escanaba River State Forest, a three-mile-long corridor has been cut through the pines and birches. Lined precisely down the center of this trail and standing taller than the trees are new utility poles, the first stages of a sophisticated military communications system that would run for 56 miles in these northern Michigan woods.

title: A YOUTH'S SUICIDE UPSTATE BRINGS 200 PEOPLE TOGETHER TO ASK WHY
description: The 200 parents and teachers who filled the junior high school auditorium here Thursday night seemed at a loss as they tried to understand why a 14-year-old student had hanged himself Tuesday evening.

Shift at Wilson Foods
description: The Wilson Foods Corporation said today that its president, Richard T. Berg, would retire on March 1. It also announced the dismissal of 100 salaried workers as part of its reorganization under Federal bankruptcy laws. Wilson said Mr. Berg's responsibilities would be handled by other officers of the company.

title: Abortion Clinic Is Bombed
description: Several pipe bombs exploded early today outside a building housing an abortion clinic, smashing windows but causing no injuries. Seven pipe bombs and a sign that said ''Hillcrest murder'' were found outside the clinic, the authorities said.

title: CORRECTIONS

Chaffetz of Chicago. The ceremony was performed at the Episcopal Church of the Heavenly Rest by the Rev. C. Hugh Hildesley.

title: FRENCH ACT TO END TRUCK BLOCKADES

Without disputing Mr. DelBello's version of his original purpose for the council, I would like to offer information absent from his letter.

A small museum built especially to display one of the most dazzling collections ever gathered by an eccentric millionaire is, by definition, the rarest of treats. But when it comes to sheer diversity enhanced by the highest of standards, then the Gulbenkian Museum in Lisbon is in a category of its own.

title: DOCUMENT BY G.M. SHOWS LABOR PLAN

title: THE DEBUTANTE RITUALS --

Fun for all, not an orgy or a circus spectacle. Those kinds of shows of pompous pretension are what helped to kill the idea in the first place. Whitbread Gilligan, was married in Weston yesterday to Peter Michael Dusseau, the son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Lambert Dusseau of New York. Isaac Patch, a justice of the peace, performed the ceremony at the Old Parish Church. The couple are vice presidents of Drexel Burnham Lambert in New York. Mr. Dusseau's previous marriage ended in divorce.

title: Paris Gives Tunis Food Aid
description: France signed agreements today to give $67.5 million worth of wheat and credit to Tunisia, a former French colony where an estimated 200 people were killed in bread riots last month. France agreed to provide 40,000 tons of wheat, valued at nearly $5 million, $48 million worth of credit to buy French farm products and $14.5 million in loans at 3 percent interest, payable over 25 years.

description: There is much that is admirable about Colloquium, a new dance group directed by Robin Staff: for instance, its obvious dedication, its willingness to commission new music and its policy of offering both ballet and modern-dance works. Nevertheless, Colloquium's performance Thursday night at Marymount Manhattan Theater was disappointing because all the participating choreographers ran into compositional problems.

title: WEEKEND VISITS: A CLASH OF HOPE AND REALITIES
description: M ANY children view the weekend as the time designated to put the pressures of school aside and be kids again. It is as if permission has been granted to be irresponsible and adventurous on Saturday and Sunday.

title: R.O.T.C.,15 YEARS SFTER IT LEFT, IS ONCE MORE AN ISSUE AT HARVARD
description: Fifteen years ago students were occupying the administration building at Harvard University, boycotting classes and rallying against American involvement in the Vietnam War. One demand was that Harvard abolish its Reserve Officers Training Corps program, through which students could receive academic credit and scholarships.

title: MAINTAINING THE BODY
Futurist Photos, Rich in Ideas
description: IT was exactly 75 years ago this month when an essay by the Italian poet F. T. Marinetti, ''The Founding and Manifesto of Futurism,'' sparked a vigorous avant-garde movement - one that called for a repudiation of traditional subjects and methods and for an effort to make art reflect the physical dynamics of modern life.

description: A former high school majorette who was suspended from her squad for being four pounds overweight says a public apology by the school board was a ''good enough'' victory.

title: CRAFTING A HIGH-TECH RENAISSANCE AT OLIVETTI
description: ROME WHEN times are bad or uncertainty looms large in Italy, Carlo de Benedetti, the outspoken chairman of Olivetti, looks abroad for refuge. Since 1975, his wife and three sons have been living in Switzerland as a precaution against the urban guerrillas who have been kidnapping and murdering prominent Italian businessmen and their families.

title: Villanova Defeats Seton Hall By 73-66
description: Villanova took advantage of some lapses by Seton Hall in the second half to gain a 73-66 Big East victory in the second game of a double- header today at Byrne Meadowlands Arena.

title: DR. PANGLOSS SPEAKS
description: On Wednesday last President Reagan told reporters that the Lebanese Army was ''well- trained and a better fighting force than the recent engagements . . . indicate.'' When he spoke, the Lebanese Army had been humiliatingly defeated by rebel forces and was disintegrating. Nearly half its soldiers, including most of those trained by American advisers, deserted.

title: Marshal Pavel Batitsky, 73; Former Soviet Commander
description: Marshal Pavel F. Batitsky, who commanded the Antiaircraft Defense Corps of the Soviet Union for 12 years until his retirement in 1978, died Friday, according to the official Soviet news agency Tass. He was 73 years old.

title: SROM SOUTH AFRICA, A TALE TOLD IN BLACK AND WHITE
description: ''T he revolution I am involved in as a writer,'' the South African novelist Andre Brink has said, ''is a revolution in the conscience of my people.'' To American ears, such sentiments sound like the dated echoes of the Group Theater of the 1930's or the street theater of the 1960's. But in South Africa, they are the words by which a generation of writers live.

title: ROME: ON FOOT IN THE PAST
description: Like everybody else, I learned about Rome in school, and for me the ancient city lived in the old Alinari photographs, standard in every Latin classroom at the time - Colosseum, Forum, Pantheon - suggesting that the once-great capital's buildings all resembled the Lincoln Memorial or, closer at hand, the Bank of Warren on Main Street in Front Royal, Virginia.

title:
CABLE TV NOTES;
CANDIDATES WEIGH THE USES OF CABLE
description: W ith Election Year already well underway, the political advertising blitz that punctuates the candidate selection process is about to begin. Yet, this time, a new ingredient will be added: cable television. One result could be that the 30-second hard-sell political commercial will be complemented by longer, more issue-oriented appeals aimed at target groups of voters.

title: CINCINNATI BACKS INTEGRATION PLAN
description: The Cincinnati Board of Education has unanimously approved a voluntary plan for racial balance in city schools. The board's action was the first hurdle toward resolving a decade-old school desegregation suit.

title: OPERA IS THRIVING IN THE U.S.
description: T he Central Opera Service, a national information and research group associated with the Metropolitan Opera, has released its detailed statistics about American opera production during the 1982-83 season. The organization, founded in 1954, compiles data on company budgets, works performed and numbers of premieres, and acts as a clearing house for information on the opera scene.

title: Data Update

description: The New York City Ballet brought an extra freshness to Jerome Robbins's ''Dances at a Gathering'' on Friday at the New York State Theater. Dancers new to their roles often have that effect on a ballet, and Maria Calegari as the woman in pink, and David Moore and Jock Soto as the men in brown and brick, respectively, were no exception to that rule.

title: Steelers Seek DeBerg
description: With Terry Bradshaw's future in doubt because of a lingering elbow injury and with last year's starter, Cliff Stoudt, gone to the Birmingham Stallions of the United States Football League, the Pittsburgh Steelers are in the market for a quarterback. One possibility is Steve DeBerg, a free agent who was the sometime starter for the Denver Broncos and ended the season playing behind the rookie John Elway. The Steeler general manager, Dan Rooney, said he had been talking with Denver officials about a possible trade.

title: Reward Set in Cat Killings
description: Cat lovers here are offering a $700 reward in an effort to stop a series of cat killings. Velda R. Boenitz, president of the Spay-Neuter Services Inc., said her organization posted a $100 reward Monday and it had grown to $700 within hours in response to news articles about an estimated 100 cat killings since shortly after Christmas on the city's East Side. The killings have baffled the police and local residents.

title: BABYLON HONORS MARCONI
description: O N Dec. 12, 1901, a signal was sent forth from a tiny shack in the Village of Babylon that was to change the way the world communicated. The sender of the signal was Guglielmo Marconi, and his achievement, the first trans- Atlantic wireless signal, provided the basis for the radio and telecommunications age that followed.

description: W E Americans are often criticized by others in this world for what is seen as our tendency to adopt quick, simplistic approaches to what are frequently involved, complex issues.

description: This western Massachusetts town, which declared its independence from Britain two years before the rest of America, is now considering seceding from the state over an unwanted site for treating hazardous wastes.

title: Comings and Goings
description: Robert Reid, a Houston Rocket forward, underwent arthroscopic surgery to repair sprained ligaments in his left knee, and will be out for three weeks. . . . Zhu Jianhua , the Chinese athlete who set the world record at 7 feet 9 3/4 inches in September, withdrew from Friday night's Toronto Star Indoor Games and canceled a scheduled appearance at the USA/ Mobil Indoor Championships in New York next Friday because of illness, according to Chinese athletic officials. . . . Rickey Henderson , who submitted to arbitration in an effort to gain a $1.2 million contract, lost his case and will have to settle for $950,000 from the Oakland A's, the American League club announced. Henderson, an outfielder, set a major league single-season record by stealing 130 bases in 1982. Last year, he reached 100 stolen bases for the third time in his career, with 108, and hit .292. . . . The Montreal third baseman Tim Wallach lost his arbitration bid to increase his salary to $500,000 and must accept the Expos' offer of $360,000, the club announced. Wallach batted .269 last season, with 19 home runs and 70 R.B.I.'s.

title: Award for Mrs. Reagan

President Reagan's wife will be given the Rotary International Presidential Citation at a dinner at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel for arranging the surgery for Lee Kil Woo, 4 years old, and Ahn Ji Sook, 7, whom she met on the President's trip to the Far East in November.

title: AN AISLE OF TEARS
description: LAST YEAR MY DAUGHter was married, and I was thrust into a role that I had long expected and for which I was totally unprepared: that of being father of the bride. I had always imagined that, as I escorted Rebecca down the aisle - she, beautiful in her white, flowing gown and veil; I, cool, poised and proud to give her away in marriage - I would dwell on certain album moments of her childhood, our good and bad and learning times together, or that I would consider with a bittersweet pang how it all, the luck and the raising, the trying and the helplessness, had come down to this, this one lovely woman, my daughter, bedecked as a bride, and this moment, this one shining now.
