title: ROADS THAT LEAD AWAY FROM THE ETERNAL CITY
description: Where all roads lead to, everyone knows. That these same roads also lead away from Rome is self-evident, but worth recalling to the visitor, nonetheless. Because along them, within easy distance, excuses can be found to justify short jaunts away from St. Peter's and the Forum while still living up to the tourist's duty of seeing and doing. They will allow you to get out of the great city's sometimes all- too-throbbing life during the heat of the day and return refreshed for the following morning's assault on the Sistine Chapel or the shops around the Spanish Steps.

title: FOOD OF THE 80'S IN 40'S ATMOSPHERE

But if you can stand pink, green and black decor in a spartan luncheonette setting, with a 1940's musical background, you'll find value - not quite 1940's, but good - and some interesting dishes at the Pink Flamingo.

title: LOST ILLUSIONS
description: During the last two weeks of fighting in Lebanon the Reagan Administration has witnessed the almost complete collapse of all of its policy objectives for this country. Since the marines arrived in Beirut in September 1982, President Reagan has articulated three basic American goals - the removal of all foreign forces from Lebanon, the extension of the Government's authority throughout the country and the rebuilding of the Lebanese Army. Army Has Collapsed Instead, it is the American peacekeepers who are retiring to their ships in frustration; the American-sponsored troop withdrawal agreement of last May has been torn up; the territory under the control of the central Government has now shrunk to the fence around the Presidential palace and even that is no longer secure; and the army has collapsed along religious lines after two days of serious fighting with ragtag militiamen. ''The United States is lucky that Lebanon is not that strategically important,'' Ghassan Salameh, a top Lebanese international affairs expert, said. ''If it had made the same miscalculations in dealing with a strategically important ally like Saudi Arabia or Pakistan that it did here, the destruction to American interests would have been enormous.'' If the Lebanese had serious questions about the purposes and effectiveness of United States policy, so did other friendly nations in the Middle East as well as critics at home. Even Administration officials seemed to throw up their hands in frustration, leaving the initiative, for the moment, to others.

title: MAJOLICA ENJOYS RENEWED INTEREST
description: -CENTURY majolica, an exuberantly colored, lead-glazed pottery, was one of the most popular decorative wares in American and English homes during the Victorian era. Since then, however, it has been largely relegated to the attic because it was considered overdecorated and gaudy by succeeding generations attracted to the simple lines of art pottery.

When motorists drove by on the highway, they saw, and sometimes smelled, a huge dump. And when people spoke of Norwalk they seldom mentioned outlying sections such as Rowayton, which has large homes on the waterfront, but pointed instead to South Norwalk, an economically depressed area of rundown and abandoned buildings and high crime.

To that point, the dozen or so front-runners in the field of 42 cars will simply be gathering information on each other's strengths and weaknesses, and trying to stay out of trouble.

title: THE IDEOLOGICAL ELECTION
description: Richard Reeves, author and syndicated columnist, wrote ''American Journey: Traveling With Tocqueville in Search of Democracy in America.'' By Richard Reeves OVERNMENT IS NOT THE SOLUTION TO our problem. Government is the problem.'' So says the President of the United States. What Americans think of that statement will, I believe, determine whether Ronald Reagan or a Democrat wins the 1984 election. After almost four years of strong Reagan leadership, it is clear that the two parties are looking at the country from opposite ideological directions. There is a big difference between seeing a big, clumsy government as protector or as oppressor, as friend or as foe. The difference has not changed the governing of the United States - yet. In the next four years, though, it could be a different place, as it was after Franklin D. Roosevelt.

title: FASHIONING A RENAISSANCE FOR DOWNTRODDEN DOWNTOWNS
description: All roads on Long Island once led here. Residents from across the Island traveled miles in the 1940's and 50's to shop in Hempstead, transforming the village into a retailing power that rivaled cities many times as large. The 1960's, however, brought the shopping mall and a steady eastward migration of people and businesses. In a pattern more reminiscent of an inner city than a suburban village, many shops in Hempstead were shuttered and closed, making downtown a place to avoid and a symbol of suburban decay.

title: ON THE CORPORATE BOOKSHELF
description: Ever wonder ow licrative computer book publishing has become? Take a stroll into the McGraw-Hill Book Store in midtown Manhat- tan. It's as if an avalanche had struck What started as a modest computer book section a few years ago has grown to fill one-quarter of the store's shelves and has sprawled out onto the carpeted floor in intimidating, though neat, piles.

title: THE NEW OLYMPIC SKI TRAIL
description: SARAJEVO, Yugoslavia

title: Stevenson Leads Cuba To Victory Over U.S.
description: The three- time Olympic champion Teofilo Stevenson won a three-round superheavyweight decision from Tyrell Biggs of Philadelphia today as a Cuban amateur team took an 8-4 victory from a United States team.

title: MONEY IS RAISED IN BERKELEY TO AID TOWN IN EL SALVADOR
description: While the Reagan Administration is proposing to send more than $200 million in military aid to El Salvador this year, citizens of this city are raising thousands of dollars for a small rebel-held agricultural town in that country.

title: CHINA
description: To the Editor:

title: THE REGION
description: Transit Management

title: DEADLINE ON FARM PRICE SUPPORTS IS EXTENDED
description: Agriculture Secretary John R. Block, reversing a previous stand, today gave farmers three more weeks to sign up for 1984 commodity price supports. At the same time, he added sweeteners to entice participation in the wheat programs.

title: Pennsylvania Gets a Payment On Its Three Mile Island Claim
description: A $250,000 payment has been made to Pennsylvania for costs incurred from the 1979 accident at the Three Mile Island nuclear power plant, Attorney General LeRoy Zimmerman says.

title: CHINA
description: To the Editor: As A. E. Hotchner sug

title: SOUTHERNER WITH HER OWN ACCENT
description: ONE WRITER'S BEGINNINGS

title: WASTE INQUIRY BACKS CONNECTICUT COMPANY
description: Connecticut's Department of Environmental Protection says tests have turned up little evidence to support charges by employees of a waste treatment company in Waterbury that the company improperly buried, discharged or stored hazardous chemicals on its property.

title: HOMES, COMMUTING CITED BY O'ROURKE IN ANNUAL ADDRESS
description: A N optimistic County Executive Andrew P. O'Rourke declared the State of the County sound this week, but coupled what he felt were the accomplishments of his first year in office with expressions of caution.

title: ASSAD'S CHANCE TO CONSOLIDATE HIS WINNINGS
description: President Hafez el-Assad of Syria is on the verge of achieving most of his goals for Lebanon. In less than two weeks, he has watched Lebanese President Amin Gemayel lose half his Cabinet, half his army and half his capital to Syria's Lebanese allies.

title: ST. JOHN'S BEATS PITT BY 65-62
description: Despite uneven performances at both ends of the floor, St. John's played one of its most physical games of the season and defeated Pittsburgh, 65-62, before today at Alumni Hall.

title: The Dunk That Died
description: Georgeann Wells, a 6-foot-7-inch sophomore center on West Virginia's women's basketball team, dunked the ball during a 77-64 victory yesterday over Massachusetts, making her the first woman ever to make such a shot in a college game. However, the two- handed stuff with 43 seconds to play was disallowed because a Massachusetts player was called for a foul on another West Virginia player before the shot.

title: No Headline
description: Karen Dieter Is a Bride

title: IRAN AGREES TO U.N. MISSION BUT NOT FOR MEDIATION
description: Iran said today that it would accept a new United Nations mission to assess damage to civilian areas in the Persian Gulf war but would not hold political discussions with the group.

title: WHEN EVE NEEDED AN ALIAS
description: Susan Gubar , the co-author with Sandra M. Gilbert of ''The Madwoman in the Attic,'' a study of 19th-century women writers, teaches at Indiana University. AN AMERICAN TRIPTYCH

title: Miss Moore Is Betrothed
description: The engagement of Denise Elizabeth Moore to Francois Pierre Brosens has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. Peter B. Moore of Sergeantsville, N.J., parents of the future bride. Her fiance is the son of Dr. and Mrs. Pierre J. Brosens of Belmont, Mass.

title: Tax Help for Condominiums in Norwalk
description: In the next few weeks, about 350 Norwalk residents who have formed a special tax district will become the first condominium owners in a Connecticut city permitted to deduct part of their monthly common charges on their income-tax returns.

title: SUSAN CLISHAM IS ENGAGED
description: The engagement of Susan Clisham to Steven B. Nesbitt has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. Roger R. Clisham of Southbury, Conn., parents of the future bride. Her fiance is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Carl G. Nesbitt Jr. of Buffalo. An August wedding is planned.

title:
GARDENING;
THE DULL BUT DELIGHTFUL KIWI
description: M OST fruits that find their way to our tables are brightly colored and shiny. We are so conditioned by their appearance that our mouths begin to water when we see them. Then there's the kiwi.

title: Couple Awarded $850,000
description: A Federal jury has awarded a suburban couple $850,000 for property damage when a Pan American jetliner struck their neighborhood in 1982. Dorris and Elrose Vidrine of Kenner had sought $12 million for property damage and trauma.

title: PAPERBACK BEST SELLERS
description: February 19, 1984Fiction

title: CASINOS FAULTED ON TOP-LEVEL MINORITY HIRING
description: While Atlantic City's casino industry has met state quotas on hiring women and members of minority groups, it has fallen short in placing them in high- level positions, according to an official of the state's Casino Control Commission.

title: Sikh-Hindu Clashes Spread in North India
description: The police battled rioting Hindus and Sikhs in northwest Haryana state today, leaving one dead and 15 injured in ethnic clashes that spread from Punjab state, officials said.

title: FOR VACATIONING CHILDREN, FUN ABOUNDS
description: W ITH many schools in the county closed for vacation this week, parents may be seeking activities to occupy both their children's intellect and their energy. Although a wide selection of programs is geared to interest young children, there are also activities that teenagers - or the whole family - may enjoy. It is a good week for the family to become better acquainted with seldom-visited parts of the county, while the children participate in activities that are often inexpensive or free.

title: Steinbeck's Nobel Award
description: To the Editor:

title: SUN POWERS SIX NEW LIBRARIES
description: LAWRENCE TOWNSHIP B RONZE sundials and a plaque with the sun embossed on it are more than sidewalk decorations at six new libraries in Mercer County. They are symbolic of how the buildings are heated and lighted.

title: Change Needed
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: BEHIND THE SCENES IN MUSIC (AND MOVIES) WITH 'THE BASILEUS QUARTET'
description: ROME

title: NEW ROCHELLE DEBATES PLAN FOR FOUR 33-STORY BUILDINGS
description: I F the apartment and office

title: COMPUTERS TO HELP PINPOINT ARSON TARGETS
description: With the help of a grant from the Ford Foundation, fire departments in five cities around the nation will soon be using computers to pinpoint buildings that could be targets of arson.

title: A GREAT CAMERAMAN WEAVES AN EPIC SPELL
description: A fter one has watched movies for a living over a period of years, the surprises become increasingly rare. It's not that one's senses have been dulled, though that can happen after a stretch of films that are neither very good nor very bad. Those are the ones that anesthetize the senses.

title: HAS PAROLE RUN OUT OF TIME IN NEW YORK?
description: When George Acosta, a 24-year-old parolee, was arrested in the fatal shooting of a police officer and the wounding of two others last week, grief became mixed with anger. And when it was discovered that Mr. Acosta's parole had not been revoked despite two recent arrests and one conviction, the anger gave way to outrage.

title: IN SOVIET NORTH, A PARTY GREETS THE SUN
description: Here, on the northern fringes of the inhabited world, sunrise is an occasion for a party. It is not that the people of Murmansk are particularly given to superstition or paganism. But living north of the Arctic Circle teaches them not to take the sun for granted.

title: Why Stars Fall
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: ARLEDGE WEATHERS THE STORM
description: It had not been an especially good day for Roone Arledge. The women's downhill race in the XIV Olympic Winter Games was again postponed, the United States hockey team was tied by Finland in the closing minute, and ABC Sports was being criticized in some quarters for not informing television viewers in the United States about results, even when some of the results were being shown as long as nine hours after an event.

title: U.S. and Turkey Agree On Military Cooperation
description: The United States and Turkey have agreed on further cooperation in military matters after a high-level defense group meeting that ended here today, the Turkish Foreign Ministry said.

title: A Deadly Encounter on Bruckner Boulevard
description: 6:45 P.M. Tuesday: A stolen moped pulls into the driveway of a Power Test gas station at 149th Street and Bruckner Boulevard in the Bronx. Two police officers spot the vehicle and pull in behind it. Officer Thomas P. Ruotolo, winner of eight distinguished service citations in just three years on the force, walks toward the driver and asks for his license and registration. The man pulls out a gun and fires, killing the patrolman with a single shot to the head. Oficer Rutolo's partner, Tanya L. Brathwaite, gets off a shot before she is felled by a bullet in her lower back. An off-duty patrolman using a nearby pay phone, Hipolito Padila, aims his revolver at the gunman and squeezes the trigger five times before he is wounded in the abdomen. The gunman flees down 149th Street. Hundreds of officers begin a search, aided by helicopters and dogs. They find a blood-soaked fatigue jacket a half mile away, but the trail goes cold.

title: Whose Recovery?
description: To the Editor:

title: IF THERE WERE JUST ONE MUSTARD, THAT WOULD BE DIJON
description: A DECADE or so ago, it was possible to buy up every variety of mustard, imported and domestic, that you might find for sale in supermarkets and gourmet shops. You would wind up with perhaps two dozen jars to sample. Today there are hundreds of mustards ranging from mild to astonishingly forceful, flavored with countless herbs and spices and ranging in color from pale gold to dark brown with green, reddish and orange not uncommon.

title: Claire Dennison, Executive, Wed To L. T. Griffith
description: Claire Dennison, a daughter of Mrs. John Paul Dennison and the late Mr. Dennison of Pecos, Tex., was married in New York yesterday to Luther T. Griffith, the son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Francis Willard Griffith of Short Hills, N.J., and Tortola, British Virgin Islands. The Rev. C. Hugh Hildesley performed the ceremony at the Episcopal Church of the Heavenly Rest.

title: MARINE MAMMALS FOUND OFF SHORE
description: BRIGANTINE Some of the most graceful marine mammals in the world are regularly sighted by commercial and recreational fishermen 20 miles off the New Jersey coast.

title: REAGAN ADMINISTRATION HELD 9-MONTH TALKS WITH P.L.O.
description: For a period of nine months, the Reagan Administration conducted secret discussions through an intermediary with Yasir Arafat, the head of the Palestine Liberation Organization, according to American participants in the effort.

title: Q AND A
description: Question:

title: IRISH NATIONALISTS SEARCH FOR A FORMULA FOR UNITY
description: Irish nationalists, after eight months of deliberation and few signs of encouragement from the British, are preparing to make painful and politically sensitive decisions to produce a formula they hope will lead to Irish unity.

title:
SPEAKING PERSONALLY;
THE MAKING OF AN AMERICAN MYTH
description: G REAT men often grow after they are dead, for the force of legend swells them to superhuman proportions. The Homeric heroes probably were human beings at one time, but myth has magnified them into godlike creatures.

title: The Balfour Declaration
description: To the Editor:

title: HEADLINERS
description: Johnson's Gold As Bill Johnson evidently sees it, modesty, like losing, is for the other guy.

title: Judith C. Connelly Engaged to Marry In June Ceremony
description: Mr. and Mrs. John F. Connelly of Jenkintown, Pa., have announced the engagement of their daughter Judith Celeste Connelly to Philippe Delouvrier, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Paul Delouvrier of Paris.

title: Immigration Official Quits
description: Gerald Riso, deputy commissioner of the Immigration and Naturalization Service, has resigned effective Feb. 24 to return to private business. Alan Nelson, in announcing the resignation Friday, said Mr. Riso was instrumental in preparing pending immigration reform legislation.

title: Bailing Out?
description: To the Editor:

title: WHAT'S DOING IN DALLAS
description: PETER APPLEBOME contributes to The Times from Dallas.

title: EARTH BELIEVED TO FACE COMET BOMBARDMENT
description: Periodic passages of the solar system through the dust-laden plane of the Milky Way Galaxy roughly once every 30 million years result in bombardment of the Earth by comets and other objects, causing mass extinctions, according to a hypothesis of two scientists of the National Aeronautics and Space Administration.

title: NATION
description: A Less Wild Blue Yonder

title: HUGHES CRITICIZES MATTHEWS INQUIRIES
description: ATLANTIC CITY R EPRESENTATIVE William J. Hughes last week decried the pace of Federal and state investigations into the administration of Mayor Michael J. Matthews, saying they were ''adding more frustration to a resort already stagnated by confrontation politics and racial overtones.''

title: 4 PERIODICALS AIM AT WOMEN
description: -publishers and editors of The Woman's Newspaper of Princeton shake their heads when they recall the humble beginnings of the monthly publication two years ago.

title: ADDING UP THE COST OF CHARTER FLIGHTS
description: The prices seem alluring: Seven nights in Peru for only $379, two weeks in Scandinavia for $699, seven nights in Cura,cao for $349 - all including hotels and round-trip jet transportation from New York. Seem too good to believe? Read on.

title: ENVOYS AND LABORERS
description: William E. Schaufele Jr. is a retired Foreign Service officer who has served as Assistant Secretary of State and ambassador, most recently to Poland. THE DIPLOMATS

title: ISLANDERS WIN IN LAST :006
description: There is the chance, however slight, that the Rangers and Islanders may not meet again for another eight months. Their regular-season encounters are over now, ending in tonight's 4-3 Islander victory that came with six seconds to play when Brent Sutter tipped in a long wrist shot by Denis Potvin.

title: EUROPE,TOO, FEELS THE SOCIAL PROGRAM PINCH
description: Hard times in Western Europe have obliged both poor and relatively prosperous countries to make fresh cuts in welfare systems that are widely perceived as the bedrock of Western Europe's postwar political and social stability. But although regularly described as in a state of crisis, the welfare state has not been dismantled, only pruned.

title: Katherine Walker Wed to D. A. Fisher in Kansas
description: Katherine Wales Walker, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Granville Walker of New Canaan, Conn., was married in Stillwell, Kan., yesterday to Douglas Andrew Fisher, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Clark Henderson Fisher of Mission, Kan. The Rev. Dr. Robert F. Cavitt performed the ceremony at St. Francis of Assisi Episcopal Church.

title: Nuptials Planned By Miss Schirmer
description: Katherine Schirmer, a senior staff adviser at the Exxon Company U.S.A. in Houston, and James Louis Cochrane, a vice president of Texas Commerce Bancshares, also in Houston, plan to be married March 24.

title: LONG ISLAND JOURNAL
description: M UCH to the relief of some Port Jefferson residents, the latest development proposal for a key waterfront property in the village includes neither high-rise condominiums nor an exclusive yacht club, and may even lead to the creation of a small public park on the waterfront.

title: JACKSON TACKLES FOREIGN AND NUCLEAR ISSUES
description: Campaigning in New Hampshire this week, the Rev. Jesse Jackson supplemented his evangelistic oratory with new stands on foreign policy, nuclear energy and the use of nuclear weapons.

title: NEW CASSETTES:FROM A FELLINI CLASSIC TO A BILLY JOEL CONCERT
description: La Strada Starring Anthony Quinn, Giulietta Masina and Richard Basehart. Directed by Federico Fellini; 1956. JEF Films 115 minutes. $59.95

title: Spanish Farmers Protest
description: Thousands of farmers and cattlemen demonstrated in central Madrid today to protest Government farm policies. The police estimated that the protesters numbered 30,000, but the organizers, including Spain's Agrarian Federations Union, said 50,000 people participated. The protesters said they wanted the Government to consult them about its policies, including setting prices.

title: Skier's Problem Reported
description: A brush with the law six years ago nearly cost Bill Johnson a spot in a tough training program that helped him on his way to a skiing career, according to a published report. Johnson, of Van Nuys, Calif., became the first American man to win the downhill skiing gold medal when he triumphed at the Winter Olympics in Sarajevo, Yugoslavia, last week.

title: RIDING THE GLACIER EXPRESS
description: BANNON McHENRY is a writer who lives in New York City.

title: MILL TOWN HAS STAKE IN 2 WORLDS
description: R EVOLUTION in Iran and the Soviet move into Afghanistan seem remote from the life of Stafford Springs, a town of 9,200 residents on the northeastern border of Connecticut.

title: FASHIONING A RENAISSANCE FOR DOWNTRODDEN DOWNTOWNS
description: In many ways, it is a textbook case. A relatively prosperous city, a regional center for goods and services, falls victim to the urban flight of the 1960's. By the mid-1970's, downtown New Brunswick has the tired and shabby look of a town forgotten. Now, however, it is held up as a model of urban revitalization. Since 1977, more than $200 million worth of projects have given the city not only a new facade but a promising economic base as well, development officials say.

title: BURGER'S ADMIRERS
description: To the Editor:

title: Miss Peters, P. G. Schwed Are Married
description: The marriage of Margaret Allen Peters, who is on the staff of The New Yorker magazine, to Peter Gregory Schwed, a partner in the New York law firm of Bernstein, Obstfeld & Schwed, took place in Manhattan yesterday. The Rev. Emily B. Preston, assisted by the Rev. Judith Baumer, performed the ceremony in the chapel of St. Bartholomew's Episcopal Church.

title: THE REGION
description: Doctor's Orders: Save $4 Million

title: Catalan Politics
description: To the Editor:

title: COMPOSER IS TAKING NEW PATH
description: C OMPOSING for saxophone quartet and brass quintet is a radical departure from Leopold Godowsky 3d's heritage. His grandfather was the pianist Leopold Godowsky, and his father, co-inventor of color film, was a fine violinist. His mother's brothers were George and Ira Gershwin, the songwriting team. Mr. Godowsky, who lives in Clinton, is a pianist.

title: TWYLA THARP TAPS THE WELL OF POPULAR CULTURE
description: T wyla Tharp is the only choreographer to date who has plugged into the popular youth culture with spectacular effect. That indisputable success, obvious in her Brooklyn Academy of Music season, has a great deal to do with her identification with that culture and all its ambiguities.

title: PANELS TO STUDY EDUCATION PLAN FOR THE VERY YOUNG
description: A LTHOUGH research has indicated that early learning experiences can help normal and handicapped children develop more fully, there is a growing debate in the state over what experiences should be provided, who should receive them and how they should be paid for.

title: Major Solar Flare Reported
description: A Federal scientist has reported a major solar flare that would have little X-ray impact on the earth, but he said more flares were possible over the next two weeks from the same region of the sun. Joe Sutorik, a forecaster with the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration's Space Environment Center, said the flare occurred in an area of the sun just rotating into the earth's view, and the region would be facing the earth for another two weeks.

title: Data Bank; February 19, 1984
; A SEPTUAGENARIAN JOB HUNTER'S SECRET
description: To the Editor:

title: BILL WOULD SPEED JOBLESS-PAY DEBT
description: TRENTON R OGER A. BODMAN, Commissioner of the state's Department of Labor, is drafting legislation that would reduce from four years to two the time New Jersey would need to pay off the remaining $442 million of the $735 million it borrowed from the Federal Government to provide unemployment-insurance benefits dating as far back as 1975.

title: NEW CASSETTES: FROM A FELLINI CLASSIC TOA BILLY JOEL CONCERT
description: Two Streisand Comedies: ''Up the Sandbox,'' starring Barbra Streisand and David Selby; directed by Irvin Kershner, 1972. ''What's Up, Doc?,'' starring Barbra Streisand and Ryan O'Neal; directed by Peter Bogdanovich, 1972 Warner Home Video Approx. 96 minutes each.

title: PRESSURE IS ON SOVIET IN HOCKEY FINAL
description: Czechoslovakia has never won an Olympic gold medal in hockey. The Soviet Union has lost the gold medal only twice in seven competitions, each time to the United States.

BUSINESS FORUM;
AND AN ARCHAIC APPROACH TO TRADE
description: FOREIGN trade plays a smaller

title: Hurdle Given New Task
description: The Mets, who are short of catchers, began another experiment today in converting an infielder into a catcher. They asked Clint Hurdle to learn the job, one day after they had opened spring training with Tucker Ashford trying to convert.

title: COALITION OF SCHOOLS, BUSINESSES FORMING
description: A N unusual alliance is being forged between corporations, colleges and school districts in the county in an effort to improve primary and secondary public education. Supporters say that if the project is successful, it will also help meet the occupational needs of business and provide a well- prepared pool of students for higher education.

title: MEDIOCRE SKYSCRAPERS DOMINATE THE SKYLINE

title: DEBATERS DIFFER ON HOW TO AVOID ATOMIC WAR
description: In a debate this week about nuclear war, two strategic thinkers of opposing points of view cut through other issues to concur that a political agreement between the United States and the Soviet Union might be the only way to prevent a holocaust.

title: SMALL BUSINESS MYTHS
description: The typical newspaper or magazine article on urban small business catalogues the fear and failures generated by dope addicts, shoplifters and other little fry who abound in poorer neighborhoods. But hardly a complaint is heard about the big banks, big landlords, big producers, big distributors and occasionally big customers - in short the big fish - whose collective behavior toward small-business people is the cause of most of what ails them.

title: Murdoch on Move
description: Don Murdoch, the onetime Ranger rookie sensation who has been playing with the Detroit Red Wings' Adirondack farm club in the American Hockey League, has been transferred to the Montana Magic of the Central League. The 27-year-old Murdoch set a Ranger rookie scoring record with 32 goals in the 1976-77 season.

title: PEREZ DE CUELLAR ARRIVES IN POLAND FOR TALKS
description: Secretary General Javier Perez de Cuellar arrived here today for talks with Polish leaders that are expected to include a discussion of a United Nations employee who was convicted by the Government of spying for ''a NATO power.''

title: FINDING THE RIGHT ARTISANS
description: OWNERS of historic structures who are restoring them as commercial ventures with the benefits of Federal tax credits or who are reviving the beauty of old houses for their own use often have difficulty in finding the special craftsmen they need to do the work.

title: CHINA

description: The following article was excerpted from a report sent to the Nuclear Regulatory Commission this month by Parents Concerned About Indian Point. It was prepared by Phyllis Rodriguez, a member of Parents, and Joan Holt of the New York Public Interest Research Group.

title: SUSAN J. THOMAS TO MARRY IN MAY
description: The engagement of Susan Jane Thomas to Robert Spalding Winborne has been announced by her mother, Helen Thomas of Decatur, Neb.A May wedding is planned.

title: JAZZ: BERNE AT ROULETTE
description: The Tim Berne Quintet takes marvelous liberties with its tunes. At Roulette on Friday, Mr. Berne, an alto saxophonist and composer, defied the conventional theme-solos-theme format of most jazz sets.

title: REPORTER IS ARRESTED WITH FIVE IN TEXAS IN AIDING OF ALIENS
description: A reporter for The Dallas Times Herald was arrested Friday with three Salvadorans, a nun and a social worker and charged with transporting illegal aliens. An editor for the newspaper said said he was working on an assignment at the time,

title: TEXANS COURT SETS TRIAL FOR BLACK ROBBERY SUSPECT
description: A judge declined today to dismiss armed robbery charges against a black engineer and said the case would go to trial April 9.

title: Susan W. Hendel Engaged
description: Mr. and Mrs. Philip F. Hendel of New York have announced the engagement of Mr. Hendel's daughter, Susan Wells Hendel, to David E. Fleming, the son of Gertrude Hahn Fleming of the Mount Airy section of Philadelphia, and the late Ernest E. Fleming.

title: Richard Todd's Career With the Jets
description: Selected on first round of draft, another Alabama quarterback for the team made famous by Joe Namath. April 1, 1977 - Ending of doubts on his being starting quarterback as Namath is waived. Oct. 23, 1977 - Has best day of any N.F.L. quarterback that season, throwing for 397 yards and 4 touchdowns, as Jets lose to Oakland Raiders, , 28-27.

title: 'BABY DOE' ADVOCATES ARE AN UNLIKELY TEAM
description: In an uneasy alliance, the antiabortion movement and groups advocating rights for the disabled have one powerful point of agreement: Government must protect the rights of handicapped infants whose parents and physicians might let them die.

title: 'CANTORIAL' IS HARD TO COMPREHEND
description: W ITHIN a year, the Hartman Theater in Stamford has put on new plays by three multimedia luminaries: Neil Simon's ''Actors and Actresses,'' Elia Kazan's ''Chain'' and, currently, Ira Levin's ''Cantorial.'' All were losers, and that gives a new dimension to the question, ''What's in a name?''

title: 'VOUCHERS'--KEY TO HOUSING THE POOR?
description: If the Federal Government encouraged poor people to shop around for rental housing on the open market, would they do so, and in the process sharply reduce Washington's stake in the construction and maintenance of public housing?

title: Pressler to Seek Re-election
description: Senator Larry Pressler, Republican of South Dakota, announced today that he would seek a second term and said he would not take re-election for granted. No Democratic has announced yet that he will seek the seat.

title: JETS SEND TODD TO SAINTS FOR NO. 1 DRAFT CHOICE
description: Richard Todd, who never quite lived up to people's expectations that he was another Joe Namath, had his expectations realized yesterday when the Jets traded him to the New Orleans Saints for a first-round choice in the college draft May 1.

title: Alerting Buyers
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S. Postal Service Reports Surplus for 2d Straight Year
description: The Postal Service made money for the second straight year in 1983, the first year it did not get its usual subsidy from Congress, Postmaster General William F. Bolger said in the agency's annual report.

title: WHEN A 'ZERO' FITS A RETIREMENT PLAN
description: AT first, the sales pitch sounded too good to be

title: FOOD
description: T IS ASTONISHING TO ME how many Americans seem unfamiliar with what I consider to be one of the finest of all cereal grains: barley. It is easy to cook, enormously versatile and its taste and texture, whether used in a soup or hearty casserole, are wholly admirable. The majority of packaged barley to be found on the supermarket shelf is marked ''pearl'' and ''medium.'' Pearl barley is that which has been husked and then polished. The grains are a grayish pale- brown color. Medium has nothing to do with size, but refers to the cooking time, as opposed to the quick-cooking grains that have been presteamed at the processing plant before drying and packaging.

title: Longshoremen Back at Work At Docks in Philadelphia Area
description: Eight area longshoremen's locals have returned to work after approving a contract that will increase average wages from $14 an hour to $17 over three years.

title: THE WORLD
description: Is Arrested

title: TOKYO'S VENERABLE GINZA: IS IT TIME FOR A FACELIFT?
description: The lights of the Ginza glitter, as ever, and the black limousines line the narrow side streets, waiting for the well-heeled and well- oiled to find their way back from another sake-hazed evening. By day, the shoppers hold sway, streaming in and out of the department stores and jewelry shops in a finely groomed parade.

title: ARGENTINA'S GOAL NOW IS TO PUNISH THE UNDERLINGS
description: A soul-searching legal issue that troubled the Allies after World War II, the French after the Algerian War, and the Americans after the My Lai massacre in Vietnam is now deeply dividing Argentines. To what extent are military men responsible for atrocities committed while following orders?

title: Article 257016 -- No Title
description: With more than $67 million already pledged, the fund-raising campaign to restore the Statue of Liberty and Ellis Island is preparing for its formal start in July, the 100th anniversary of the presentation in Paris of the statue to the United States by France.

title: McEnroe Is Winner
description: John McEnroe scored a 6-3, 6-3, 6-3 victory over Guillermo Vilas in the final of the $400,000, four-player Akai Gold Challenge tennis tournament tonight.

title: An Agenda, Comrades
description: Like the skiers at Sarajevo, Soviet and American leaders are suddenly bathing their Olympian rivalry in a great show of camaraderie. Over the bier of Yuri Andropov they rediscovered a taste for better relations, with Mr. Chernenko, according to an approving President Reagan, proposing talks to keep regional conflicts under ''control'' and to prevent ''inadvertent'' use of nuclear weapons.

title: STATE TRYING TO SAVE RING-NECKED PHEASANT
description: State wildlife biologists will begin a five-year study this spring of how to save New York's ring-necked pheasant population, which has been nearly decimated by modern farming practices.

description: T HERE was one other time,

description: IT SEEMED surprising at first to Gary L.

title: 5 Tennessee Prisoners Flee in 3 Vehicles
description: Five convicts drew guns on their guards in a field today, commandeered three vehicles, riddled another with shotgun fire and escaped in different directions, the authorities said.

title: A MARRIAGE DIES LITTLE BY LITTLE
description: A S I SAT reading the newspaper and listening to music from the 50's and 60's, the urgency of the printed page pushed the music further and further into the background, as if to prove my children's contention that their father cannot do two things at the same time.

title: HOW TO COPE CONFIDENTLY WITH A CLOGGED SINK DRAIN
description: A LTHOUGH the commercials we see on television make it seem that every clogged sink drain can be effortlessly - and almost instantly - cleared by simply pouring a bottle of chemical drain cleaner down into the drain, this is unfortunately not always the answer to the problem. There are many cases when more than chemical treatment is needed - when the clog consists of something solid that was accidentally dropped down the drain and is stuck in the trap under the sink, or when the clog is just so heavy and so solidly packed into the drain pipe that it will not respond to simple chemical treatment.

title: Human Embryo Transplants
description: I'm sure the arrival of embryo transplants is the answer to many prayers (''Human Embryo Transplants,'' by Harris Brotman, Jan. 8).

title: FUNERAL IS HELD FOR SLAIN OFFICER
description: In this small Westchester County village where he grew up and lived, Thomas P. Ruotolo, the New York City police officer shot to death in the Bronx on Tuesday, was memorialized today with words of sorrow and bitterness.

title: IN WEST BANK, EVEN A CROP JOINS CONFLICT
description: -Occupied West Bank, Feb. 12 - Against the brown earth of the Judean Desert, long sheets of plastic glitter in the winter sun like strips of silver, sheltering this season's crop of vegetables.

title: REAGAN AIDE OPPOSES HIGHER STUDENT LOANS
description: A Reagan Administration official has cautioned educators against seeking higher student loan limits and long repayment periods, saying they might make it difficult for today's students to send their own children to college.

title: TV PROGRAM ABOUT MAINE A BIG SUCCESS
description: Did you know that the coast of Maine is 3,478 miles long? That Maine's oldest sardine cannery was built in 1876? That lobsters swim backwards?

description: FOCUS ON GEORGE

BUSINESS FORUM;
A LOW-TECH ECONOMY AT HOME...

title: THE CONFERENCE CENTER AS GATEWAY
description: The managers of the year-old Arrowwood Conference Center in Rye, N.Y., have come up with a plan to maximize the use of the compound's 114 acres, 276 rooms, 9-hole golf course, pools and other recreational facilities during the summer months, generally the low season for business conferences.

title: A WOMAN'S PLACE IS UNDER THE HOOD
description: A RICH Brazilian friend who often clucks over how hard North American women work (she doesn't have Saran Wrap or Oreos or Skippy, but that is another story) once asked me what I minded most about running a typical suburban household. I instantly cried, ''I hate being the Car Person!''

title: DOES A COMPOSER'S LIFE AFFECT HIS MUSIC?
description: L et us suppose, just for the sake of supposing, that tomorrow a large cache of previously unknown letters of J. S. Bach were to come to light, discovered by workmen excavating for a new apartment building in Leipzig. Suppose, however improbably, that most of the letters were of a highly personal, confessional nature and only marginally concerned with music. Might musical scholars, nevertheless, be expected to show some interest in examining these papers? Silly question. They would, of course, trample one another in the rush to be first, and justifiably so.

title: Patricia S. Allen To Be the Bride Of Paul H. Ross
description: Dr. Peter Allen of Vancouver, British Columbia, has announced the engagement of his sister, Patricia Stuart Allen, to Paul Humphrey Ross, the son of Mrs. Richard Ross of Stamford, Conn., and the late Mr. Ross.

title: HISTORIAN'S ROLE IN WHITE PLAINS
description: I T seems fitting that Renoda

title: ADJUSTMENTS Hearing in Court
description: Should Alec Naiman have been allowed to serve as a juror in the drug- selling trial of Hector Guzman? Mr. Naiman met all the traditional qualifications, but there was a problem: He can neither hear nor speak. For that reason, the defense attorney exercised his peremptory right to bar Mr. Naiman from the jury.

title: FISHERS FERRY GETS DONATIONS
description: M ANY of the residents of Fishers Island own planes and expensive cars. But their ''lifeline,'' as several people described it, is the ferry that shuttles between the island and Connecticut. The operators of that lifeline now say they need money for expansion, and the residents are responding by donating about half a million dollars in cash and stock.

title:
CAMERA;
GREETING CARD INDUSTRY CN BE A MARKETPLACE
description: Over the past seven years the greeting card industry has developed into a strong and, in some cases, well-paying market for freelance photographers. The giants of the traditional greeting card industry (Hallmark, American Greetings and Gibson) have tripled their use of photography. In addition many new companies, whose cards are exclusively photographic, have sprung up across the country.

title: CANDIDATES FACING FIRST MAJOR TEST IN IOWA CAUCUSES
description: When they assemble in precinct caucuses across Iowa Monday night, a comparative handful of this state's citizens will start the process in which the nation's 106 million registered voters will be called upon to choose the next President.

title: DETAINEES IN WAR WIN COMPENSATION
description: About 36 Japanese-Americans who lost jobs with the city when they were forced into camps in World War II will receive $5,000 each in compensation, the City Council has decided.

title: Bush Compares Reagan With 8 'Woeful' Foes
description: Vice President Bush says the choice is clear between the incumbent Republican Administration and the ''woeful eight'' leading Democratic challengers: fear and despair versus a Republican message of hope and peace.

title: OLD MILL IN NEW ROLE: ARCHITECTS' OFFICE
description: BASKING RIDGE H ARDLY a day goes by without someone visiting a 19th-century gristmill here that serves as a branch office for Haines Lundberg Waehler , an architectural firm with headquarters in Manhattan and business all over the world.

title: THE DEATH PENALTY: QUESTION OF FAIRNESS
description: Three weeks ago, in Pulley v. Harris, the United States Supreme Court decided that appeals courts do not have to compare a death penalty imposed in one case with penalties imposed in other cases involving similar crimes. The Court said that ''any capital sentencing scheme may occasionally produce aberrational outcomes,'' and found nothing in the Constitution's prohibition of cruel and unusual punishment to bar such aberrational outcomes. As a result, California is one step closer to executing Robert Harris for murder and bank robbery.

title: TWIN SISTERS
description: Caroline Seebohm , a freelance writer, is working on a novel. THE TWO OF US

title: DOMESTIC DERANGEMENTS
description: A LATE DIVORCE

title: Anne Denebeim Is Wed to Michael Bjon Farber
description: Anne Kelny Denebeim, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Bruce K. Denebeim of San Francisco, was married yesterday to Michael Bjon Farber, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Ajon F. Farber of Omaha. Rabbi Joseph Asher performed the ceremony at Temple Emanu-El in San Francisco.

title: HEROIC AIRMAN REMEMBERED
description: FAIRVIEW O N DEC. 12, 1967, two days before Vito Muti was to board a Navy reconnaissance plane as a radio operator, he telephoned his father, Luigi, in Fairview.

title: WHOSE RECOVERY?
description: To the Editor:

title: Children Are Different; Education Should Be
description: Mr. Peter Gibbon's article, ''Education Commission Overlooks Need for Clerks, Truckers,'' (Opinion Page, Jan. 22) stating: ''Reformers, unlike classroom teachers, have no visceral sense of ineradicable differences in temperament, intelligence, maturity and family background,'' is right on target and a view long overdue in recognition, although the headline is not the issue.

title: SUNDAY OBSERVER
description: Grouch

title: The State of Dance On the Island
description: The Jan. 15 article on the precarious state of the Eglevsky Ballet (''Eglevsky Without Villella'') offers in my opinion some misleading comments concerning the overall state of dance on Long Island. Although the disappearance of the Eglevsky Ballet Company would indeed be a severe and unfortunate loss to the region, we do have another professional ballet company on Long Island, and it is at this time quite alive and well.

title: PROTESTANTS STEPPING UP PUERTO RICO CONVERSION
description: On the public square of nearly every town in Puerto Rico is a Roman Catholic church built when the square was. It is as standard a fixture as the town hall.

title: SUPER THRILLERS AND SUPER POWERS
description: Robert Lekachman is the author of ''Greed Is Not Enough: Reaganomics.'' When he is not consuming thrillers, he teaches economics and sociology at the Lehman College and Graduate Center campuses of the City University of New York.

title: BROOKLYN WINS IN THE END
description: Dan Wakefield is the author of the novel ''Under the Apple Tree'' and other books. TIN WIFE

title: NEW CASSETTES: FROM A FELLINI CLASSIC TO A BILLY JOEL CONCERT
description: J. R. R. Tolkien's 'The Hobbit' Produced by Rankin/Bass ABC Video/Sony 76 minutes. $39.95

title: Double Dactyls
description: To the Editor:

title: CHINA
description: To the Editor:

title: BLACK THEMES IN SUREAL GUISE
description: AIME CESAIRE

title: MARTINELLI URGES FLYNN-PLAN ACTION
description: YONKERS T HE 10 proposals offered by State Senator John E. Flynn to alleviate the city's threatening budget gap have encountered a slow-moving City Council and criticism from the state.

title: NEW YORKERS AT HEART GIVE TO NEEDIEST
description: They are former New Yorkers, new New Yorkers or just sometime New Yorkers, but they seem to share a feeling for the city that inspires support of The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund.

title: PUTTING 'DAYDREAMS' INTO NOVELS
description: W HEN her children get off to school and her husband is on the train to Manhattan, Susan Isaacs, author of the recently published novel ''Almost Paradise,'' goes downstairs to the basement of what she calls her ''grandiose split-level'' in Manhasset to work in her office.

title: MUSIC: JEWISH THEMES
description: Israeli classical music, like Jewish art music itself, is in a peculiar situation. On the one hand, it draws upon one of the longest and richest of traditions, going back to the cantillation of Scripture, including the religious and folk songs of European Jewry along with the melodic universe of Middle Eastern Jews who now make up the majority of Israel's Jewish population. But these ancient riches are also mixed with the secular tradition of concert music from Western Europe; and this mixture comes to maturity in a secular society that is itself extraordinarily young.

title: LIFE'S URGENT ISSUES IN CLASS FOR YOUTHS
description: R ONA B. LIEBERMAN sat outside her father's hospital room last month, correcting the final exams from the Rite of Becoming course she teaches to seniors at Bethel High School. The course deals with the passage through life, from the wonder of childhood to the isolation of adolescence to the decline of old age.

title: MONDALE HAS FAMILIARITY IN HIS FAVOR
description: NEWTON, IOWA W HEN the Democrats in this farming and industrial town of 16,000 people hold their precinct caucuses tomorrow night, Don Salisbury will almost certainly be there to vote for former Vice President Walter F. Mondale. Tyra White, who likes Senator Gary Hart, might have to stay home with her daughter. Mr. Mondale sparks little popular enthusiasm. But his backers tend to be activists like Mr. Salisbury, a lawyer and former county chairman, who will bother to trek down to the ornate Jasper County Court House and stand up for their candidate. Senator Hart and some other long-shots have stirred interest. But many of their supporters are neophytes, such as Mrs. White, a 29-year-old housewife, who has never attended a caucus and does not know where hers is being held.

title: HUMAN EMBRYO TRANSPLANTS --
description: From my perspective as a research scientist, the patenting and licensing of technical knowledge for the embryo- transplant procedure, described in Harris Brotman's article, is highly unethical and detrimental to the society that medicine supposedly serves. The profit motive injected into the practice of medicine by Fertility and Genetic Research Inc. perverts the basic intent of our health-care system, regardless of legal precedents.

title: WITH CHERNENKO'S ASCENSION, OLD GUARD REASSERTS ITSELF
description: At moments last week there were watchers who thought they saw a flicker of satisfaction cross the dour features of Konstantin U. Chernenko as he moved through the rituals of death and succession. At the rites for Leonid I. Brezhnev 15 months ago, Mr. Chernenko was a crushed figure, elbowed into the second rank of Politburo leaders beside the grave. As the loser in the contest that annointed Yuri V. Andropov, he was widely regarded as a has-been, with little to hope for in a new Kremlin hierarchy committed to ending the slackness and corruption that flourished under Mr. Brezhnev.

title: HANDLING STRESS IS PART OF THE JOB
description: R OGER J. PEARSON never really demanded a great deal of attention. Yet now that he is the new First Selectman of Greenwich, the spotlight never seems to dim.

title: ADVOCATE AGENCY ACCUSED OF LAXITY
description: TRENTON S OME current and former employees of the state's Division of Advocacy for the Developmentally Disabled say that work has slowed to a crawl; others insist that, although the agency may seem slow at times, important activity is nontheless going on.

title: CHINA
description: To the Editor:

title: 'ZIPS' AND BORDERS: NEWMAN PRINTS AT THE PRINCETON MUSEUM
description: PRINCETON T HE influence of Barnett Newman as leader of the sublime, as opposed to the gestural, camp of Abstract Expressionism is still being felt 14 years after his death.

title: ; THE INFLUENCE OF JIMMY ERNST
description: I read with great interest of the autobiography of Jimmy Ernst, a man who has been not only an important artist of our times, but also a fine teacher (''Shedding Light on the 'Not So Still' Life of Jimmy Ernst,'' Feb. 5). I had the great fortune of studying with Jimmy at Brooklyn College, and he was a great influence in my life.

title: Sudan Troops Said to Kill 30 Rebels in a Clash
description: A military commander says Sudanese troops killed 30 rebels who had attacked a Nile River passenger steamer earlier this week, the official press agency reported today.

title: The Right To a Drink Of Water
description: THE land and water resources of Suffolk county are the birth right of all its citizens, local government, both town and county, to secure this right. government does not have a more important public health responsibility than protecting the drinking water supply.

title: INSIDER'S GUIDE TO PACIFIC PALISADES
description: The City Fathers of Beverly Hills, in their sometime wisdom, recently banned sightseeing buses from their residential streets. Not a decree of great moment, you may say, but to the residents of the right side of the tracks - yes, even in Beverly Hills there is a wrong side - it promises relief from the ever- present menace of having some relentless sightseer gawk into your bedroom or brashly join you in the shower. However, to us in Pacific Palisades, that ordinance looms as a threat: What if the thwarted sightseer is diverted to our blissfully obscure community? Heaven forfend!

title: SUNDAY, FEBRUARY 19, 1984;  International
description: Syria remained firm in its refusal to participate in any kind of reconciliation with President Amin Gemayel until he unconditionally abrogates the 1983 accord for the withdrawal of Israel troops. Lebanese opposition officials said Rafik Hariri, a Saudi mediator, was expected in Beirut with a ''clearcut and unambiguous'' message from President Hafez el- Assad of Syria that, until the accord is broken, he has no intention of discussing reconciliation. (Page 1, Col. 6.) Secret discussions with Yasir Arafat conducted by the Reagan Administration for nine months were broken off by the Palestine Liberation Organization after Israel's invasion of Lebanon in June 1982. The purpose of the talks, which were held through an intermediary, was to persuade the P.L.O. to accept the American offer to recognize it in return for the P.L.O.'s acceptance of Israel's right to exist. The United States offer contradicted its policy toward the P.L.O. since 1975, which is based on nonrecognition of the P.L.O. until it recognizes Israel as a nation. (1:5.)

title: NEW JERSEY JOURNAL
description: ''B RENDAN BYRNE ARENA,'' the name on the facade of the indoor sports facility in the Hackensack Meadowlands, is there for all to behold. By day, the letters stand out starkly; at night, lights give them a soft glow.

title: ARE SWISS ACCOUNTS WORTH THE CACHET?
description: FOR people interested in keeping their financial affairs private - say, from a suspicious

title: DAVID LETTERMAN'S OFF-CENTER HUMOR FINDS A HOME
description: I f an infrequent television viewer

title: Q.& A. WITH THE STATE'S NEW ADMINISTRATOR OF RENTS
description: MANUEL MIRABEL, an assistant commissioner for Community Development and Neighborhood Preservation at the city's Department of Housing Preservation and Development, is the newly appointed State Rent Administrator. In this position, which carries the title of Deputy Housing Commissioner for Rent Administration in the State Division of Housing and Community Renewal, Mr. Mirabel will supervise the state's takeover of jurisdiction over New York City's 1.2 million rent-stabilized and rent-controlled apartments.

title: POLITICAL THEMES IN COMIC-STRIP STYLE
description: THERE are many who argue that art and politics are mutually exclusive pursuits, that artists whose primary aim is to expound a political message are little more than propagandists whose individual creativity must be subordinated to getting that message across. Others hold that all art is political by nature, reflecting and either supporting or rejecting the values of the society that gives it birth.

title: Margaret Waters Engaged to Rodney A. Pearson
description: Dr. and Mrs. Richard J. Waters of Hanover, N.H., have announced the engagement of their daughter Margaret Mary Waters to Rodney Andrews Pearson, a son of Thomas H. Pearson of Clarksdale, Miss., and Diane T. Pearson of Oxford, Miss. A June wedding is planned.

title: U.M.W. TO REOPEN A REWARD DISPUTE
description: The United Mine Workers has quietly begun to decide who, if anyone, should receive a $50,000 reward for the arrest and conviction of the killers of Joseph A. Yablonski, who was a reformist candidate for the union presidency in 1969.

title: FISHERMEN SEEK TO STOP DAM IN NEW HAMPSHIRE
description: The powerhouse at Sewall's Falls on the Merrimack River is quiet now, abandoned since 1966.

title: IN THE ORCHID WORLD, MINIATURES ARE SOMETHING SPECIAL
description: Orchids are habit forming. Few people can grow just one. A dozen is more like it. But 10,000? That's a commitment and one that three orchid professionals have developed into a thriving business.

title: HOMAGE TO AUDUBON, HORSE COUNTRY TOURS
description: A Pilgrimage In Louisiana Fetes Naturalist About 110 miles to the northwest of New Orleans, in the heart of what once was plantation country, stands the community of St. Francisville, La. It was there, in West Feliciana Parish, that John James Audubon - inspired by the beauty of the wooded ridges and the clear streams of the countryside - painted more than 80 of his ''Birds of America'' while living in the parish in the 1820's. And it is there, in his memory, that the 13th annual Audubon Pilgrimage takes place from 9:30 A.M. to 5 P.M. March 16, 17 and 18.

title: Motherhood Cancels Ape's Duty as a Stud
description: Eric, the Lincoln Park Zoo's orangutan, was nearly on his way to China for stud duty when he gave birth. Eric was renamed Erica.

title: Juror Is Accused of Bribery After a Mistrial Is Declared
description: A mistrial has been declared in a civil case as a result of what court observers called a rare case of a juror purportedly seeking a bribe from a plaintiff.

title: 8,000 U.S. Marines Set Sail For 3-Week NATO War Games
description: About 8,000 United States marines sailed today for a three-week NATO exercise in the North Atlantic.

title: LOOKING FOR A MESSAGE FROM MOSCOW
description: For President Reagan, who faces criticism that his moralistic attacks on the Soviet Union have been too harsh and his diplomacy too inflexible to curb the arms race, the change of leadership in the Kremlin is a political windfall. Any big change in Moscow kindles American optimism about the opportunities for improving relations. However, history and circumstance suggest that concrete gains will be hard to come by.

title: KNICKS BEAT NETS AS KING SCORES 32
description: On a night when Knicks honored Bill Bradley, their small forward of past glory years, Bernard King, their small forward of the present, paved the way for New York's fifth straight victory.

title: IT TAKES MORE THAN TALENT TO BUILD A MUSICAL CAREER
description: A fter a concert in Alice Tully Hall not long ago, two impressions lingered - how imaginative the music had been and what an interesting, serious player. The next thought came just as naturally - that professionally, this musician was going nowhere.

title: MALL TAKING BOW
description: The stage and movie screen are gone and workmen are now busy dislodging some 600 seats from the Central Theater in downtown West Hartford, Conn., to make way for a mixed-use retail and office mall being developed in the building where vaudeville players once performed.

title: NEW CONDOMINIUMS AT HARLEMS'S EDGE
description: NOT long ago, the notion that the neighborhoods bordering the northwestern and northern edges of Central Park were attractive areas for condominium developments would have been considered fanciful.

title: A CHRONOLOGY OF THE SHOREHAM PLANT
description: B Y the time major construction ended last November at the Shoreham nuclear power plant, the project had become the costliest undertaking of its kind ever. At an estimated $4 billion, the plant was more than 15 times over budget, and it was 10 years behind schedule.

title: CONQUERING BOLIVIA'S FRONTIER
description: Jonathan Kandell is a former Latin American correspondent of The Times. This article is adapted from his book, ''Passage Through El Dorado,'' to be published next month. By Jonathan Kandell T WAS THE CLIMAX of the rainy season in the Beni, Bolivia's tropical northern province. The river-veined savanna below our aircraft was now a vast archipelago. Ranches and entire towns appeared under siege by the black, rising waters, which had wiped out any trace of roads. Speedboats and canoes navigated the same plains that jeeps and oxcarts had crossed during the dry season only a few months before.

title: IN IOWA, THEY REALLY DO STAND UP TO BE COUNTED
description: COON RAPIDS, IOWA T HE first votes in the 1984 Democratic Presidential race will be cast tomorrow night in Iowa, a state that has produced something of a hybrid political system that combines the preference voting of a primary with the town-meeting process known as a caucus.

title: PRESSURE EXERTED ON HIGH SCHOOLS
description: The University of Colorado, by raising its requirements for undergraduate admission, has joined a growing number of state universities in a move to put pressure on high schools to upgrade education in their classrooms.

title: 5 ARE CHARGED WITH ROBBING STUDENTS ON A SUBWAY TRAIN
description: Five youths have been charged with robbery, riot and criminal possession of a weapon after an attack on a group of high school students on a subway train on the West Side of Manhattan, the police said yesterday.

title: STATE SAYS L.I. INMATE TRANSFER WILL START IN SPRING
description: New York State officials say they plan to begin transferring inmates from the Long Island Correctional Facility in Brentwood by late spring.

title: TENANTS PRESS BILL TO CONTROL RENT COSTS
description: STAMFORD T REVOR KING lives in a two-bedroom apartment on the west side of Stamford. His apartment complex sits on the corner of West Main Street, the street that runs through the middle of one of Stamford's poorest areas.

title: CAUGHT IN A CRISSCROSS SQUEEZE
description: The declarer had several reasons to be pleased with his playing effort on the diagramed deal from the recent European Championships in Wiesbaden, Germany. In both rooms in a match between Finland and Italy the contract was four spades and the opening lead was the heart queen.

title:
NUMISMATICS;
THE PROS AND CONS OF ISSUING OLYMPIC COINS
description: Olympic coins, like the Olympic Games themselves, have become a quadrennial tradition. Since 1964, each host country for the Olympic Summer Games has issued special coins in their honor. This year, Yugoslavia, the host of the Winter Games is doing likewise.

title: NEW CASSETTES: FROM A FELLINI CLASSIC TO A BILLY JOEL CONCERT
description: Billy Joel Live From Long Island CBS/Fox 80 minutes. $29.98

description: I N outlying suburbs in the New

title: MANY DEMANDING CURB ON PHONE PORNOGRAPHY
description: A man in New Jersey describes all telephone sex services as ''cesspools for our children to get trapped in.'' A New York couple argues the First Amendment could never have been meant to protect ''Dial-a-Porn.'' A Georgia woman uses adjectives such as ''despicable'' and ''disgusting.''

title: NYKAENEN WINS 90-METER JUMP
description: Matti Nykaenen of Finland outdueled East Germany's Jens Weissflog today and won the 90-meter ski jumping competition at the XIV Olympic Winter Games.

title: CHINA
description: To the Editor:

title: PROTESTERS AT DIABLO CANYON CARRY OUT ROUTINE SMOOTHLY
description: Changing times are evident in the open-ended protest at the Diablo Canyon nuclear power plant here, where organizers plan for arrests, run a travel service and operate a legal bureau.

title: NATURE WATCH
description: Size: Up to 6 inches; averages 3 1/2 inches.

title: Marijuana Mailed Often From Hawaii, U.S. Says
description: About 80 percent of all packages mailed from the island of Hawaii contain marijuana, according to Federal officials.

title: U.S. STILL BLACKLISTS 3,000 CANADIANS FOR POLITICS
description: More than 3,000 Canadian citizens are still barred from entering this country because they have been identified as Communist Party members or sympathizers, according to the Immigration and Naturalization Service.

title: WIDENER TO ARGENTINE HORSE
description: Mat Boy, an Argentine throughbred hero who had never raced in this country, was an easy 3 1/2-length winner of the Widener Handicap today at Hialeah.

title: Canada
description: To the Editor: Reading the ''Dollars in the Sun'' article by Richard Meis

title: MONACAN ROYAL FAMILY STARS IN CHARITY FESTIVITIES
description: A black-tie gala tonight opened the final act of an extravagant charity benefit, a round of social activities that was expected to raise $1 million for the recently organized Princess Grace Foundation.

title: Polish Union Activist Is Found Dead on Farm
description: A 33- year-old Solidarity activist was found dead under mysterious circumstances a week ago, and a Roman Catholic Bishop is reported to have called the death a murder.

title: Passenger Jet Reported In a Near Collision
description: A World Airways DC-10 carrying 183 passengers came within five miles of colliding with two Air Force KC-135 tanker planes in flight before the pilot changed course, officials have said.

title: COLORFUL BOUNTY OF THE CHINA TRADE
description: T rade between the United States and China began 200 years ago on Washington's birthday, when the Empress of China sailed from New York for Canton. Over the next century, an untold number of tall ships, involved primarily in the tea trade, brought back to New York a bounty of embroidered silks, lacquer trays, camphorwood chests, ivory chess sets, chased silver tureens, paintings on glass and tons of porcelain.

title: BUFFALO MALL DESIGN PROVOKES DISPUTE
description: The disagreement began when local preservationists first looked at design sketches for a downtown pedestrian mall, the $42 million centerpiece of a rapid transit line scheduled to open next year.

title: HOW TO WIN FRIENDS AND INFLUENCE FOREIGN POLICY
description: At a meeting a few weeks ago, House Speaker Thomas P. O'Neill Jr. asked Representative Lee H. Hamilton for his views on the continued stationing of marines in Lebanon. Mr. Hamilton had supported the deployment of the marines, and indeed had played a key role in fashioning the compromise that provided that the troops would perform a peacekeeping role for a period not exceeding 18 months.

title: DANCE: NIKOLAIS TROUPE IN 1953 'KALEIDOSCOPE'
description: The purity, simplicity and just plain fun of Alwin Nikolais's early dance-theater pieces came to the fore again Friday night at the City Center when the Nikolais Dance Theater revived a remarkable work called ''Kaleidoscope.''

title: BALTHUS MESMERIZES WITH HIS CHILLING IMAGERY
description: B althus (born Balthazar Klossowski in 1908, and now often known by his own wish as the Comte de Rola) is distinctly the man of the hour. In Paris this winter his retrospective exhibition at the Pompidou Center was for many thousands of visitors the event of the season. It was crowded from morning till night. The catalogue weighed four-and-a-half pounds in paperback. But more important than either of those things was the fact that people identified with his paintings to a degree that was way beyond the normal. They had to see them. Having seen them, they couldn't stop thinking about them. It was as if Balthus had been painting for each one of them, individually, and had released something within them that would otherwise have remained inert.

title:
STAMPS;
AN INDUSTRIAL PIONEER
description: Dr. Lillian Gilbreth has been called ''one of the unique greats of her time.'' Her portrait appears on a new 40-cent stamp coming out Friday in the Great Americans Series. She was, with her husband, and later by herself, a pioneer of industrial engineering. She also became known to millions as the mother of 12 children through the book, ''Cheaper by the Dozen'' which was also made into a movie.

title: GAGS AND GHOSTS HAUNT 'CANTORIAL'
description: STAMFORD I N less than a year, the Hartman

title: Reagan Likens Quest Of Peace to Olympics
description: President Reagan urged today that world leaders pursue peace as hard as athletes strive for excellence in the Olympic Games.

title: HENRY JAMES AND RED EMMA
description: Alan Trachtenberg's most recent book is ''The Incorporation of America: Culture and Society in the Gilded Age.'' THE DIVIDED MIND

title: Another Bird on Way
description: He's a 17-year-old sophomore and only a part-time starter on his high school basketball team, and he would hardly warrant a second look if it wasn't for one thing, his name. He is Eddie Bird, the younger brother of Larry Bird, the Boston Celtic star who started his road to greatness at the same Springs Valley High School in French Lick, Ind.

title: ISLAND IN HUDSON IS A SANCTUARY FOR THE BALD EAGLE
description: IONA ISLAND D URING the summer the Boy Scouts camp here, but from December through March, eagles soar. In recent years, bald eagles in increasing numbers have returned each winter to this 219-acre island in the Hudson River just south of the Bear Mountain Bridge. This season, two adults and four immature birds have been sighted on and around Iona Island.

title: Tiernan M. Shea Becomes Bride of Douglas Boyle
description: The marriage of Tiernan Mary Shea and Douglas Scott Boyle took place in New York yesterday at the home of Beverly Bates Boyle, mother of the bridegroom. Jean S. Kotkin, executive director and a leader in the American Ethical Union, performed the ceremony.

title: THE NATION
description: New Questions On Meese's Campaign Roles

title: SMALL MISSILE SET FOR 90'S DELIVERY
description: The Department of Defense says it can produce a single-warhead strategic nuclear missile by the early 1990's but admits fundamental problems remain to be solved.

title: INTEREST GROWS IN CAR INSPECTION OPTIONS
description: TRENTON D ESPITE a slow start, New Jersey's dual system of motor-vehicle inspections not only is functioning at last, but also bringing small but increasing numbers of motorists to private garages and service stations for the annual checkups.

title: GO-BETWEEN WAS MIDEAST CONSULTANT
description: In a biography of John Edwin Mroz distributed by the Institute for East-West Security Studies, it is stated that he served as ''a consultant to several Middle East Governments and has represented the Reagan Administration in private negotiations in the Middle East.''

description: W HEN auditors and consultants started months ago to analyze the construction of the Shoreham nuclear power plant and to determine whether the Long Island Lighting Company had acted prudently, they were dealing with a plant that ranked poorly in an industry known for its delays and cost overruns.

title: No Headline
description: Paul Morrill took his gun off the shelf on Tuesday night, filled each chamber with a bullet, placed the gun in its holster and strapped the holster to his waist.

title: U.D.C. AIDS FACTORY PLAN FOR RHEINGOLD SITE
description: The state's Urban Development Corporation has approved a grant of up to $175,000 to assist a knitwear manufacturer that intends to build a 350,000-square-foot factory on the old Rheingold Brewery site in the Bushwick section of Brooklyn.

title: WHEN IS IT TIME FOR CHANGE?
description: T he infirmities of age also catch up with sound equipment, and after their allotted span of anywhere from five to 10 years, those cherished components may be ripe for retirement. Though many hours of pleasure may have spun sentimental attachments between the listener and his sound gear, there comes a time for parting. The question is when.

description: Melanie Fleischmann, a freelance writer on interior design in New York, was married yesterday to Bradford Garnett, an actor. The Rev. John-Michael van Dyke performed the ceremony at the Emmanuel Episcopal Church in Delaplane, Va., assisted by the Rev. Norman C. Catir Jr., rector of the Episcopal Church of the Transfiguration in New York.

title: Rehabilitated Oriole
description: Fresh from an eight-week treatment program for alcoholism, Dennis Martinez has joined 18 other pitchers at the Baltimore Orioles' training camp in Miami, saying he is ready to fight for the spot in the starting rotation he lost last season. He entered the program after he was arrested for drunken driving following a minor traffic accident in December.

title: LIVING WITH BLINDNESS AND CONQUERING ITS MYTHS
description: -page headlines. When retirement gives way to a comeback, it's back to the headlines as it was when Sugar Ray Leonard announced his plans to return to boxing after a 13-month retirement due to an eye injury. As an avid sports fan, former high school athlete and a professional person who is blind, I have followed Leonard's plans with special interest and concern.

title: MONDALE HAS 'SCENT OF VICTORY' IN IOWA CAUCUSES
description: Walter F. Mondale said today that he had ''a scent of victory'' in the Iowa caucuses on Monday but voiced concern that the attacks on him by his rivals for the Democratic Presidential nomination would leave ''cracks in the party.''

title: GUIDELINES FOR SALAD BARS PLANNED
description: L AST fall Mary M. Heslin, the State Consumer Protection Commissioner, stood in a supermarket in West Hartford and watched a little girl take a chickpea from a salad bar, bite it and put it back.

title: PAPAL PEOPLE
description: Peter Hebblethwaite is the Vatican affairs writer of the National Catholic Reporter. He is completing a biography of Pope John XXIII. O VATICAN!

title: TO MAKE SERIOUS THEATER, 'SERIOUS' ISSUES AREN'T ENOUGH
description: O f all the ills that plague the American theater right now, none is more disturbing than the widespread perception that American plays simply do not matter anymore. There was a time when writers like O'Neill and Williams and Miller were at the center of this country's intellectual life - when a major play on Broadway was as fit a subject for universal comment and debate, pro or con, as the latest major novel or museum show or ballet. These days, theater is a special interest, occupying a ghetto on the cultural landscape. While the fluffiest Broadway entertainments are consumed by the masses (or at least the wealthiest masses), serious American theater is followed by a far smaller coterie - and is often either ignored or viewed with contempt by the general public and the arts-minded elite alike.

title: Youth Board's Role In Mediation Project
description: On behalf of the Education Assistance Center of Long Island and the Mediation Alternative Project, thank you for the article on M.A.P. (''Trying Mediation Instead of Court,'' Jan. 29). I would like to add, however, that the article failed to mention the significant role played by the Nassau County Youth Board in the project's operation.

title: '64 RULING'S WAKE UPSETTING CRITICS
description: The Supreme Court ruling two decades ago that Congressional districts should have equal populations has led to major political changes, but some experts say lower courts may be trying to carry the principle too far.

title: OFF-SITE MODELS
description: Model apartments are a common sales tool, but the models opening today for Manhattan Place, a 35-story condominium rising at 560 First Avenue near 37th Street, are unusual. They are full-sized replicas set up in another building, at 664 First Avenue, a block from the construction site.

title: TORAH REGISTRY CREATED TO FIGHT THEFTS
description: A coalition of Jewish organizations has set up a Torah registration program designed to deter what they said has been a rash of thefts of the valuable sacred scrolls in recent years.

title: FLYERS BEAT DEVILS ON 2D-PERIOD GOALS
description: Brian Propp and Tim Kerr each had a goal and an assist today as the Philadelphia Flyers defeated the New Jersey Devils, 4-3.

title: 'THE RINK' SUCCUMBS TO CHARMLESS PREDICTABILITY
description: F irst catch your whale. Strip it down to the ribcage. Blend with bits of gothic cathedral, Japanese pagoda and steel fretwork borrowed from the side of some neo-brutalist bridge. Add a corrugated iron side-entrance, clusters of overgrown electric candles, brass railings, a ramshackle staircase meandering up to a plainly painted door, an Art Deco bar, and a theater organ. Knead until the odd pipe or trellis spills out of the stage into the auditorium; and, no, you still haven't got a recipe complete enough for you adequately to replicate the architectural blow-out Peter Larkin has served up at the Martin Beck. His set for ''The Rink'' is a gorgeous folly, at once dowdy and ornate, promising all kinds of quirks and oddities in the men and women inhabiting its spidery corners.

title: Chicagoan Is Called Unqualified as Judge
description: The Chicago Council on Lawyers has rated former Mayor Michael A. Bilandic unqualified for a state appellate court judgeship because of his ties to the political machine of Mayor Richard J. Daley.

title: FURNITURE IS THE THEME OF EXHIBITION-SALE
description: T HE annual furniture exhibition and sale at The Elements Gallery in Greenwich through March 7 is devoted exclusively to tables and chairs, basic pieces that many people consider of paramount importance.

title: CRITICS' CHOICES
description: Just one year ago the Modern Jazz Quartet played a week's engagement at the Blue Note, 131 West Third Street, signaling its return to an official touring schedule that brought the celebrated group back together on a regular basis for the first time since it broke up in 1974. These performances were some of the most fully realized communications between the quartet and its audience since the group started playing in public 30 years ago (it existed only on records for a couple of years before it came out of the studio).

title: FIRST LIST OF STATE MAMMALS SHOWS UNEXPECTED DIVERSITY
description: T HE first comprehensive list of mammals in New Jersey reveals a diversity and abundance that belie the state's size and high population density.

title: U.S. TEACHING DEFENSE IN THE CARIBBEAN
description: United States Army Special Forces teams are on this island more than three months after the American-led invasion not so much to defend Grenada as to teach others how to do it.

title: JUDGE DISMISSES CHARGE AGAINST MARCOS FOE
description: A judge today dismissed a weapons charge against Salvador H. Laurel, a leading political opponent of President Ferdinand E. Marcos. The judge acted shortly after Mr. Laurel rejected a conditional reprieve ordered by Mr. Marcos and insisted on immediate arraignment in the case.

title: WRENCH IS TOSSED IN BIG STEEL'S PLAN
description: The Justice Department sent shock waves through the steel industry and upset some key members of the Reagan Administration when the Antitrust Division said it would oppose the proposed merger between LTV and Republic Steel. J. Paul McGrath, the new antitrust chief, said the combined company would created too much concentration in flat-rolled steel and stainless steel products - a situatiion that could too easily lead to price collusion. The announcement was also a blow to United States Steel and National Steel, which have also announced intentions to merge. Criticism of the Justice Department's action came quickly from Commerce Secretary Malcolm Baldridge and Trade Representative Bill Brock. ''It seems we intend to impose greater trade barriers on ourselves than other governments impose on us,'' Mr. Brock commented. Mr. McGrath did leave a door open to the steel industry, saying that it would consider the LTV-Republic combination if the plan were revised.

title:
GARDENING;
THE DULL BUT DELIGHTFUL KIWI
description: M OST fruits that find their way to our tables are brightly colored and shiny. We are so conditioned by their appearance that our mouths begin to water when we see them. Then there's the kiwi.

title: East Germans Sweep in Sleds
description: Wolfgang Hoppe and his No. 1 East German crew of Roland Wetzig, Dietmar Schauerhammer and Andreas Kirchner rode their way to the gold medal today in the four- man bobsled competition at the XIV Olympic Winter Games.

title: MISS SUMNERS EDGED OUT FOR GOLD
description: In a free-skating event so close that if either of two judges had given the second-place finisher a tenth of a point more, the outcome would have been reversed, Katarina Witt of East Germany won the gold medal tonight in women's figure skating at the XIV Olympic Winter Games. Rosalynn Sumners of Edmonds, Wash., earned second place and the silver medal.

title: Mary Calvert Jopling Weds Kenneth Gould
