Gould 3d of Suffern, N.Y. The Rev. Robert Shaw performed the ceremony at All Souls' Episcopal Church in Oklahoma City.

title:
BUSINESS FORUM;
KEYNES RETURNS AFTER THE OTHERS FAIL
description: DURING the past decade, the word Keynesian became a pejorative term - as in the phrase, ''outmoded Keynesian idea.'' Advocates of monetarism, new classical economics (also called rational expectations), and supply-side economics claimed that Keynesianism had failed and deserved to be discarded like an old shoe.

title: BACKLOG OF 200,000 HOPE FOR ASYLUM IN U.S.
description: Kamzati Chombo, a young African in a brown polyester suit, sat among a half- dozen Salvadorans recently, waiting somberly in a judge's wood-paneled chamber for his asylum petition to be filed.

title: SYRIA'S ASSAD: HIS POWER AND HIS PLAN
description: Stanley Reed is a writer who specializes on the Middle East. By Stanley Reed ORE THAN EVER, President Hafez al- Assad is a key figure in the Middle East. Taking advantage of the events set in motion by the 1982 Israeli invasion of Lebanon, the Syrian leader has clipped the wings of his old enemy Yasir Arafat, chairman of the Palestine Liberation Organization, and has brought most of the P.L.O.'s military forces under his control. He has lodged 40,000 of his troops firmly in Lebanon, in defiance of Israeli and American pressure for their withdrawal. It is Israel, as of this writing, that has withdrawn its troops in Lebanon to a southern security belt, and it is President Reagan who decided to redeploy the American Marines in Beirut onto naval vessels offshore.

title: JERSEY OFFERS NEW MEDICAID PROGRAM
description: A new attempt to dissuade Medicaid patients from using expensive hospital emergency rooms for routine illnesses such as a common cold is being made here by New Jersey health officials.

This was in his plush upstairs office in the Board of Trade building at the foot of La Salle Street. The markets had taken some bizarre twists just hours ago. He grumbled a bit about some nasty trades. Then it was time to reminisce.

title: GOING COLD TURKEY IN ALPHABETVILLE
description: For the last decade, in scores of abandoned tenements on Manhattan's Lower East Side, drug dealers have flourished openly, serving buyers from throughout the region. The marketing system in what police described as the retail drug capital of America was so well organized that dealers employed local children as lookouts for $100 a day and used pregnant women to move drugs from one location to another. Drugs were so much a part of the community that addicts injected themselves openly in vacant lots and dealers used buckets to transfer drugs from their window to a buyer on the street below.

title: The U.N. Versus The U.S.
description: In the article ''The U.N. Versus the U.S.'' (Jan. 22), Richard Bernstein seemed indignant that the United States could no longer get whatever it wanted in the United Nations, as it used to when there were only a third as many members and the United States could easily control the majority by means of its foreign aid.

title: CITIES SPURNING WASHINGTON IN BID TO REASSERT AUTHORITY
description: Most mayors seem to be giving up their long, arduous effort to get more money from the Federal Government and are instead seeking greater authority to increase their own revenue or carry out their own initiatives as they see fit.

title: MY PURPOSE IS TO WRITE FOR THE SPACE AGE
description: BEGAN writing 35 years ago, at the age of 35, in Mexico City after the war. Encouraged by Allen Ginsberg, I set down my experiences from five years of addiction to opiates, sticking close to the facts and using, as Wordsworth put it, ''the language actually used by men.'' ''Junky'' was published in 1953 as an original paperback, and there were no reviews at the time. After all, the book was presented as an ''inside look'' at the world of a drug addict, with no literary pretensions.

title: Peggy McDonnell and Cyrus Vance Jr. Are Engaged to Be Married in Spring
description: Mr. and Mrs. T. Murray McDonnell of Peapack, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter Peggy McDonnell to Cyrus R. Vance Jr., the son of Mr. Vance, Secretary of State in the Carter Administration, and Mrs. Vance of New York. The wedding is to be in May.

title: LET U.N. FORCE KEEP PEACE IN BEIRUT
description: The amber lights flashed this week by both the White House and the Kremlin will, if they turn green, make it feasible for a neutral peacekeeping presence to take the place of the multinational ''peacekeeping'' force now ending its mission impossible in Beirut. It will take an ecumenical miracle to make a unified nation out of Lebanon's fragments. But only a genuinely international effort can free the United States to focus on the underlying issues that have triggered a major Arab-Israeli war every eight years, on the average, since 1949.

title: A FEW WORDS IN DEFENSE OF THE AMATEUR READER
description: John Updike delivered this speech last month in New York on the occasion of his accepting a National Book Critics Circle Award for his ''Hugging the Shore: Essays and Criticism.'' INNING a prize for criticism from a circle of critics is a wonderful thing, and I thank you. I do not presume to call myself a critic, while paradoxically harboring the hope that some of what I write might be dignified with the name of criticism. I am a freelance writer who writes on occasion about books, bringing to the task a rusty liberal arts education, an average citizen's spotty knowledge of contemporary issues and a fiction writer's childish willingness to immerse himself in make-believe. My embarkation, 25 years ago, on my first book reviews was prompted, perhaps, by a dim sense that the humanities and arts need repeated injections of amateurism.

title: HOME DESIGN
description: A HOUSE TO MATCH THE MOUNTAIN takes its shape from the old woolen mills and factories that have been part of the northern New England landscape since before the turn of the century. 'I didn't want the house to look decorated,' says its owner, an interior designer. 'Furniture was kept to a minimum.' Much of what was used comes from local craftsmen.

title: 'Village' Hotel
description: To the Editor:

title: Bradley Honored At Garden
description: Last night was special in Madison Square Garden. Much of the sellout crowd of 19,591 paid their money to cheer and pay tribute to the best basketball player in the United States Senate.

title: THEATER: 'THREE SISTERS' IN TRANSLATION BY JARRELL
description: In her production of ''The Three Sisters'' at the Arena Stage, Zelda Fichandler has achieved a Chekhovian balance between lingering hope and fearful despair. It is an evening filled with regret, from the youngest sister, whose ideals have no future in her stifling provincial community, to the elderly doctor, for whom time has obliterated all distinction between decency and deceit.

title: GUESS WHO READS SPY NOVELS?
description: Peter Maas's latest book, ''Marie: A True Story,'' won a Christopher Award for l983.

title: Olympic Notebook; FOR THE DURABLE, MARATHON ON SKIS
description: The final cross-country skiing event of the XIV Winter Games is 50-kilometer (31-mile) race for men Sunday. This race is much like a running marathon.

title: SUNDAY SPORTS Basketball
description: Knicks vs. 76ers, at Philadelphia, 1 P.M. The Knicks took advantage of the absence of Julius Erving to hold the 76ers to the lowest point total in the National Basketball Association this season in beating them, 111-73, Jan. 9. But Dr. J is back today. (Television - Channel 9, 1 P.M., and ESPN, 12:30 A.M. Monday morning, tape.)

title: THE JOHNNY APPLESEED OF PLAYGROUNDS IS COMING TO COUNTY
description: -raising techniques familiar to earlier generations of Americans, several hundred residents of Dobbs Ferry are planning to spend four days in May building a playground for village children.

title: FASHION
description: t is a twice-told tale. On the European side of the Atlantic, most designers favor sleek, high- heeled sandals, many of them bicolored or decorated.

title: CONCERT: MENUDO
description: Menudomania is hardly the frenzied pop phenomenon it's been cracked up to be. The Puerto Rican teen-age vocal quintet that will conclude its 10-show engagement at the Radio City Music Hall Thursday, is more a children's group than a teen sensation. Friday's concert found far fewer love-crazed teeny-boppers than youngsters tugging on their parents.

title: ON MAIN STREET IN BRONXVILLE
description: LE BRISTRO, for the last eight years a popular neighborhood restaurant on Bronxville's busy shopping street, has resisted the trend toward pubbiness. The pastel mural of balloons hovering over Paris rooftops remembered from our first visit five years ago remarks, as do the gay striped awnings. Relegated to the entry and first dining rooms, that look is now somewhat dated and unimaginative, but cozy nevertheless. Bar expenses of wall give a temporary feel to the back dining room, and a dead sweep of wood paneling bags for strip of mirror or some pictures for relief.

title: MARTHA GRAHAM
description: Anna Kisselgoff is the chief dance critic of The New York Times. By Anna Kisselgoff ARTHA GRAHAM, A VIRTUAL synonym for the still young art form known as modern dance, turns 90 this spring. Now preparing her dance company for the Feb. 28 opening of its three-week season at Lincoln Center's State Theater, she is found each day in her studio - an unmistakably charismatic figure goading her young dancers into maximum expressiveness. Seated opposite the dancers in rehearsal and moving angularly in her chair, she may demonstrate, for example, the alignment of the shoulder in relationship to the pelvis in a turn. ''Work on it,'' she urged in a recent rehearsal. ''Now it means nothing. Don't do that turn because you're told to do it. You should have the feeling of sunlight coming in - that's the why, the why you make that turn.''

title: Headliners; Powell's Washington
description: Jody Powell says he has long felt ''journalism should be covered like government, labor and the environment.'' Some in the Washington press corps might agree with that proposition, but perhaps not with the way Mr. Powell went about it in ''The Other Side of the Story,'' a recollection of his days as Jimmy Carter's press secretary. As advance copies of the book made the rounds last week, journalists learned he criticized them as prima donnas (Joseph Kraft, for one) and overly brash (Sam Donaldson of ABC) and accused one of having drug abusers among his subordinates (Bill Kovach, Washington editor of The New York Times). Mr. Powell's targets said that when he wasn't unfair, he was just plain wrong.

title: FRAGILE TRUCE OVER NAMIBIA COULD GROW TO WIDER PEACE
description: One of the longest-running American diplomatic efforts, and one of the most tantalizing, has been the attempt to end South African control of the vast territory of South-West Africa, or Namibia. Nearly six years ago a formula to bring Namibia to independence seemed about to work, but success slipped away. Now diplomacy is in an active new phase and hopes are rising. Last week, ranking South African, Angolan and United States officials met in Lusaka, Zambia, and agreed to set up a commission to monitor a trial cease- fire. South Africa said Americans might be asked to help, but Angola's official press agency said they would be unacceptable because Washington was not neutral.

title: UTILITY SAYS NINE MILE PT. PLANT MAY BE SCRAPPED
description: One of the partners in the Nine Mile Point 2 nuclear plant has told the Securities and Exchange Commission that the reactor, 80 percent complete, might have to be abandoned for financial reasons.

title: 'MASTER OF THE GAME' IS SOAP OPERA ON A GRAND SCALE
description: W ant an epic? Sidney Sheldon will cut it for you by the yard. The best-selling author has a knack, if not a peculiar genius, for writing popular novels that lend themselves easily to screen adaptations (''The Other Side of Midnight,'' ''Bloodline,'' ''Rage of Angels''). The films are usually as forgettable as the books, but there is no denying they sell and, in today's publishing and film-producing markets, that is the one criterion that gets executives to humming. Obviously aware that mini- series were were going to enjoy more popularity on television, Mr. Sheldon has designed his latest entertainment package around ''Master of the Game,'' a sprawling story that begins in 1883 and ends, after an interminable string of tragedies and crises, in 1982. The novel has been on both the hard-cover and paperback best-seller lists. Now, although published just two years ago, it has been adapted into a nine-hour, three-episode series that begins tonight on CBS from 8 to 11. The remaining installments will follow tomorrow and Tuesday evenings, also beginning at 8.

title: No Headline
description: LILLIAN WALD OF HENRY STREET, By Beatrice Siegel. Illustrated. 192 pp. New York: Macmillan. $12.95. (Ages 12 and Up)

title: No Headline
description: Ann Weeks Is Betrothed

title: 'PROTEST ART' AT THE THORPE INTERMEDIA
description: T HE first major example of protest art is considered to have been Gericault's ''Raft of the Medusa.'' The picture, which was exhibited at the Paris Salon of 1819, depicted the results of a shipwreck in which the officers preempted the lifeboats, leaving the crew to survive on a hastily constructed raft. The huge canvas disturbed the salon audience greatly, because though on a scale normally reserved for historical epics, it was, in the words of the historian Lorenz Eitner ''a tragedy without a hero, a scene of physical suffering without redemption.''

title: AROUND THE GARDEN;
description: JOAN LEE FAUST This Week:

title: Ann S. Breakey Engaged to Wed
description: Mr. and Mrs. Paul Hoffman of Mamaroneck, N.Y., have announced the engagement of Mrs. Hoffman's daughter Ann Stewart Breakey to John Mahlon Billik of New York and Little Compton, R.I., the son of Mr. and Mrs. Gene S. Billik of Livingston, N.J.

title: CONCERT: BLACK COMPOSERS
description: Music is more interesting for its intrinsic quality than for its racial origins; but if events like Friday's program of black composers at Carnegie Recital Hall do serve a purpose, perhaps it is as an informal survey, a way of looking back at a generation of black cultural assertiveness and trying to sort out who has been influencing whom.

title: DEF LEPPARD BECKONS TO THE POP MAINSTREAM
description: T here are a lot of these English, second-generation bands, the substance of which, and the sources from which they draw their influences, are no longer Howlin' Wolf and Robert Johnson. . .They just listen to what's comercially successful, ape it, come over here, sell four million records. . .and bludgeon everybody's ears with something that has no representation of subtlety at all.'' That is how Robert Plant, the one-time lead singer of Led Zeppelin and currently the maker of excellent and subtle rock and roll under his own name, described the new wave of heavy metal bands in an interview with Musician magazine. The outfit he had in mind, Def Leppard, took its name, look, and sound from Led Zeppelin, the preeminent hard rock group until its break-up in 1979.

title: MANY CLUBS GOING WITH 'NEW' FACES
description: T he American League defeated

title: Maoist Storefront
description: To the Editor:

title: WESCHESTER JOURNAL
description: ''A CHILD of the 60's'' is how Joseph R. Bravo refers to the Independent Living Center movement. Designed ''to provide disabled people with information on a peer-to-peer level,'' he said, ''the movement started in Berkeley, where everything else started, during the late 1960's, when a group of disabled people became fed up with the way services were being provided and took matters into their own hands.''

title: CRITICS' CHOICES
description: Among living European painters, Pierre Alechinsky has a place all his own. As a painter he can cover very large spaces in a resourceful and easy-going style that never cloys or clogs.

title: KILLER'S FREEDOM STIRS COAST FEAR
description: On a summer day in 1978 a Stanford University graduate student, Theodore Streleski, crept silently into the office of his faculty adviser and bludgeoned him to death with a hammer. After taping the victim's head inside a plastic bag, he calmly placed a sign on the door saying ''No office hours today'' and left.

title: CONSUMER RATES
Jury Awards Surgeon's Kin Over $8 Million From Insurer
description: A jury has awarded more than $8 million in actual and punitive damages against Mutual Life Insurance Company of New York (MONY) in the death of a Mississippi surgeon who was killed in a 1980 airplane crash in Warsaw.

title: SEAVER ACCEPTS WHITE SOX TERMS
description: Tom Seaver settled his contract dispute with the Chicago White Sox yesterday and immediately headed for their spring training camp in Sarasota, Fla.

title: 1853 RESTORATION
description: The 130-year-old Gelston House Restaurant, long familiar to patrons of the Goodspeed Opera House in East Haddam, Conn., which is next door, has been sold to David L. Joslow, an industrialist, hotelier and restoration specialist from the nearby town of Chester.

title: CHRONICLER OF KENTUCKY HILLS
description: Jesse Stuart, the poet laureate of Kentucky and chronicler of its mountain country, died Friday at a nursing home in Ironton, Ohio, after a long illness. He was 76 years old and a lifelong resident of W-Hollow, Ky.

title: Collecting X-Ray Items
description: ''I ALWAYS feel I have to do something for the community, for other people,'' said Seymour R. Hollander of Rockville Centre.

title: HOW WOOD ALLEN'S OLD WORLD INSPIRED HIS NEW FILM
description: M ax Gordon of the Village Vanguard remembers Woody Allen as ''a shy young kid, kind of scared, who came to the Blue Angel in the 50's never having appeared before an audience before.'' He adds: ''How he used to worry between shows. His manager Jack Rollins would ask me to go up and talk to him between shows. He'd say, 'Max, tell Woody how well he's doing,' and I would tell him. 'Max, tell him not to worry,' and I would tell Woody, 'Don't worry.' ''

title: REFLECTIONS AND OUTBURSTS
description: Richard L. Strout , of the Washington bureau of The Christian Science Monitor, wrote the TRB column for The New Republic for 40 years. FINAL REPORTS

title: LARGER GOVERNMENTS ASSUMING SERVICES FROM CITIES
description: Runaway Point is an unincorporated subdivision of $60,000 homes outside the Savannah city limits, and at first glance it seems it would, like so many other middle- class enclaves, embrace President Reagan's concept of ''privatization'' of public services.

title: SECRECY PROPOSAL: RISKS WEIGHED AGAINST GAINS
description: Congress has forced President Reagan to back off, at least temporarily, from using more censorship and polygraph testing to protect national security, not because it thought the goal unimportant, but out of doubt that such measures would accomplish much. In the view of Congressional critics, Mr. Reagan's plan would limit debate on vital issues and compromise the civil liberties of Government officials while doing little to prevent leakage of validly classified information and less to protect national security.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: Because of an editing error, a Beirut dispatch in some copies Saturday incorrectly characterized an accusation by the Shiite Moslem leader Nabih Berri. Mr. Berri's statement that the Gemayel Government had to accept responsibility for ''the massacre of the southern suburbs'' was apparently a reference to the shelling of Shiite neighborhoods by the Lebanese Army early this month.

title: Shahanga Wins Marathon Race
description: Gidamis Shahanga of Tanzania pulled away in the late going and Jacqueline Gareau of Canada was strong all the way as they won the men's and women's titles in the 1984 Los Angeles International Marathon run today on the Summer Olympics course.

title: DAVID EDWARDS WNS HIS FIRST TITLE ON A 64
description: David Edwards shot a spectacular seven-under-par 64 on the tough Riviera Country Club course today and won the Los Angeles Open by three strokes for his first individual triumph on the PGA Tour.

title: MUSIC: NOTED IN BRIEF;
description: GailWyntersSingsSolo In Program at Jasmine

title: Underground Nuclear Blast Detected in Western Siberia
description: The Soviet Union set off an underground nuclear explosion today at a test site in western Siberia, a Swedish seismological institute reported.

title: Steve Belloise Is Dead at 66
description: Steve Belloise, a one-time middleweight contender who twice came within a split decision of winning the world championship and was known as the fighter who knocked a man down three times with a single punch, died on Saturday at the Bronx Veterans Hospital. He was 66 years old and had been hospitalized with Alzheimer's disease for four years.

title: JAPAN'S WINTER IS NOT JUST A CONVERSATION PIECE
description: People here were grumbling this weekend about the taxis.

title: OVERTURE TO A $1 FARE
description: To the Editor:

title: JACK PAAR REMINISCES
description: It was vintage Jack Paar all the way. Jack Paar in person, aged 65. Jack Paar up on the screen, much bigger than life, with clips of his old television programs from the 1950's and 60's. A bit pudgy, a bit edgy, but still with that mischievous glint in his eye, the slow take he learned from Jack Benny, the impish grin.

title: U.N. Chief, in Poland, Deplores Rights Abuses
description: Secretary General Javier Perez de Cuellar, in Poland for an official visit, today condemned human rights abuses, including violations of labor union freedoms.

title: Patricia Kern Ribner Wed
description: The marriage of Patricia Kern Ribner, who teaches English at the Bronxville (N.Y.) School, to Daniel Zendel, a partner in the Manhattan law firm of Ladas & Parry, took place yesterday at the Woman's Club of White Plains. Rabbi Burt Siegal performed the ceremony. The parents of the couple, whose previous marriages ended in divorce, are Mr. and Mrs. Louis M. Kern of North Miami Beach, Fla., and Dr. and Mrs. Joshua Zendel of Eastchester, N.Y.

title: FEAR NOT THE NEW PATHMARK
description: From Brooklyn, the most resilient of New York's boroughs, I bring comforting advice to my Manhattan neighbors who are currently enduring the supermarket crisis: Having a suburban-type grocery store built in your midst, replete with giant parking lot and infinite aisles of stuff to buy, may not be the end of the world.

title: MUSIC: NOTED IN BRIEF;
description: Carole King Performs At Town Hall

title: ABUSES DISCLOSED IN AID PROGRAMS IN LATIN NATIONS
description: United States economic assistance programs in Central America suffer from extensive mismanagement and corruption, according to State Department audits and a Congressional study.

title: Tremor Jars North Greece
description: A strong earth tremor shook Salonika and other towns in northern Greece today, causing panic but no casualties or damage. The Salonika and Athens observatories said the tremor registered 5 on the Richter scale. Its epicenter was 21 miles east of Salonika.

title: LINKING MEDICARE AND ABILITY TO PAY
description: Federal officials, searching for ways to control the cost of the Medicare program, are once again asking whether benefits, premiums and other charges should somehow be tied to an elderly person's income.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: A Pose in the Fog

title: Harold Koontz Is Dead at 75; Gave Advice on Management
description: Harold Koontz, an adviser to many of the country's largest industries and author of the best-selling book ''Principles of Management,'' is dead at the age of 75.

title: SPORTS WORLD SPECIALS
description: Riding the Boards

title: CAR PARTS SHORTAGES A PROBLEM
description: The sudden return of customers to new-car showrooms has brought joy to the automobile companies, the dealers and the thousands of suppliers for the industry, which is climbing out of a long recession.

title: A CHILD'S CHOICE OF FRIENDS
description: ONE young mother in the group was unsure how to respond when her reserved and well- mannered 6-year-old son was overjoyed to be invited to the home of the class bully. Another mother, burdened with bitter memories of her own parents' constant criticism of her choice of friends while she was growing up, was at a loss how to intervene when faced with a similar dilemma.

title: ASKEW STRESSES MAVERICK POSITIONS
description: In this state of flat, lonely stretches of farmland, Reubin Askew should feel at home. Frequently called the candidate with a ''difference,'' he often finds himself alone among eight major Democratic Presidential contenders on such issues as arms control and trade protectionism.

title: BRINK'S TRIAL: BACK TO A CLIMATE OF FEAR
description: To the Editor:

title: Italian Industrialist Is Freed By Kidnappers After a Year
description: Kidnappers freed an industrialist in exchange for ransom today, the police said.

title: FORGOTTEN ARIZONA TOWN GIRDS TO RESIST TOURISM
description: Along the road from Tombstone that sweeps into the high desert country of southeast Arizona and the mile-high town of Bisbee, it is easy to see why local folk call the cut through the Mule Mountains ''the time tunnel.'' Bisbee still looks much as it did when Teddy Roosevelt staged raids into the surrounding hills in a futile search for Pancho Villa and when Lily Langtry stayed in the Copper Queen Hotel while she played at the theater down the street.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST MONDAY, FEBRUARY 20, 1984
description: The Economy

title: FOR HOSPITAL TRAUMA CENTER TEAMS, THE FIGHT IS AGAINST TIME AND DEATH
description: It had seemed like a quiet Friday night. No patients had arrived for more than an hour, and the trauma team at the Kings County Hospital Center was sitting around a cluttered desk, talking about patients.

title: PARIS AND TRUCK DRIVERS AGREE TO TALK
description: The Government and truck drivers agreed tonight to hold talks on ending the drivers' protests, which have taken the form of road blockades that have hindered traffic on dozens of main highways.

title: 8 in Nuclear Protest Win Round in Court
description: Eight antinuclear activists convicted of burglary and conspiracy after entering a General Electric plant and hammering the nose cones of two nuclear missiles have won their appeal.

title: OYEZ! A TOWN CRIER ON TOUR
description: That Richard John Fox of England finally managed to get to New York after 27 trips to the United States in the last five years was reason enough for him to be enthusiastic while walking down Fifth Avenue.

title: Maritime Unions' Chief Holds Off on Mondale
description: Frank Drozak, the head of the A.F.L.-C.I.O.'s maritime unions, said today he would continue to withhold endorsement of Walter F. Mondale for President until Mr. Mondale addressed the rebuilding of America's shipping industry.

title: Taking Children at Their Word
description: Imagine a child who has been sexually abused by an uncle, or family friend, or the man who runs the corner store. Imagine that child - confused, taught to obey his elders, deeply ashamed - finally finding the courage to tell his parents.

title: The Haitians and the Lucky Law
description: Those poor 7,200 Haitians: Is there no end to the torment and inequity they must suffer for wanting a better life in the Land of the Free? They've already proved fitness for the Home of the Brave.

title: U.S. NEARS STATUS OF DEBTOR NATION
description: Late this year, or perhaps next year, the United States could find itself in the company of many developing countries in a curious respect: The United States may become a debtor nation for the first time since it was a developing country itself, before World War I. Foreigners have been lending and investing more money in the United States than Americans have been lending and investing abroad. As a result, for the first time foreign holdings in this country may soon outweigh Americans' holdings abroad.

title: BISHOP HOPES TO BRING NEW SPIRITUALITY TO COUNCIL OF CHURCHES
description: Bishop Philip R. Cousin, the first member of a predominantly black denomination to become president of the National Council of Churches of Christ, said he hopes to infuse the council with the vitality he has experienced in the black church, emphasizing spirituality with social activism.

title: MONDAY, FEBRUARY 20, 1984 International
description: Israeli planes bombed what were described as Palestinian guerrilla bases in the Syrian- and Druse-controlled hills around Beirut. The air attacks coincided with the eruption of major battles around the mountaintop village of Suk al Gharb, just east of Beirut, where units of the Lebanese Army loyal to President Amin Gemayel are defending the approaches to the presidential palace in Baabda. Syrian-backed Druse and Shiite militiamen appeared to be poised to try to push Mr. Gemayel out of his official residence. (Page A1, Column 6.) Lebanon's army is preparing for what many in Lebanon say they think will be the decisive battle between the Lebanese Government and Moslem militias opposing it. Many Lebanese leaders say critical battles will be fought for two towns, Suk al Gharb, a mountain settlement in a commanding military position above Beirut, and Baabda, where the presidential palace is situated. (A1:5.)

title: Fresno State Routs Nevada-Las Vegas
description: Fresno State routed Nevada-Las Vegas, 68-43, today behind Ron Anderson's 27 points.

title: ISLANDERS DEFEAT DEVILS IN OVERTIME
description: The Devils played the Islanders on equal terms today, rallying from a three-goal deficit in the third period before losing, 5-4, in overtime.

title: THE SOUPY SELLOUT
description: This is one of those now-it-can-be-told columns about sources and methods of nailing down an anecdote.

title: AT U.S. INDOORS, COMPUTER IS KEY
description: In the locker room at the Four Seaons Racquet Club, a half-dozen women huddled with their calculators - adding, subtracting and hoping. They were studying the current standing of the 14-month Virginia Slims circuit, guessing what round they would reach in this week's United States Indoor tennis championships, figuring what their new point total would be and then computing whether it would be enough to qualify for the series finale next week at Madison Square Garden.

title: ARMS PUSH STIMULATES JOBS BOOM
description: From the hectic days of World War II, when its factories mass-produced ships and bombers, through the postwar era, when long-range nuclear missiles came out of many of the same factories, the West Coast has been a rich beneficiary of Pentagon budgets.

title: UNION CARBIDE'S NEW CORPORATE HOME: A METALLIC CASTLE TUCKED IN WOODS
description: The new headquarters of the Union Carbide Corporation here is in 674 acres of woods, and it sits amid the trees looking less like a building than a sprawling metallic beast.

title: REAGAN REPORTED IN DARK ON TALKS
description: Robert C. McFarlane, the White House national security adviser, said today that neither he nor President Reagan had been aware of contacts between the United States and the Palestine Liberation Organization carried out through an intermediary from August 1981 to May 1982.

title: A SPECIAL ON ROCK
description: well, almost - shows up on ''Super Night of Rock 'n' Roll,'' scheduled tonight at 9 on NBC-TV.

title: Libby McGarry Is Wed to Craig Albert
description: Mary Elizabeth McGarry, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas F. McGarry of Stamford, Conn., was married yesterday to Craig Justin Albert, a son of Murray Albert of Beverly Hills, Calif., and Gerda Albert of New York. Msgr. Thomas P. Guinan performed the ceremony at St. Michael Roman Catholic Church in Greenwich, Conn., assisted by Cantor Raymond Smolover of the Jewish Community Center in White Plains.

title: TRACY AUSTIN EVALUATES HERSELF
description: -aged man waiting for an elevator in the Manhattan tennis club jumped at the chance to make small talk with a champion. ''How's your back?'' he jdd Tracy Austin, who has sat out 18 months in the last three years with a series of related injuries.

title: Olson Will Miss USA-Mobil Meet
description: Billy Olson, the American record- holder in the pole vault and the first man to clear 19 feet indoors, will miss the USA-Mobil Indoor Track and Field Championships at Madison Square Garden because of a sprained ankle.

title: Nine Inmates At Large After Five Escapes By The Associated Press
description: Nine inmates, some of them armed, remained at large yesterday after separate escapes in three states. Two medium-security prisoners who walked away from a work detail Friday afternoon outside the walls of the Tennessee State Prison remained free last night.

title: FIFIELD WORKUM
description: Fifield Workum, a retired partner in the Manhattan law firm of Simpson, Thacher & Bartlett, died Friday at his home in Bedford, N.Y. He was 84 years old.

title: ANTINUCLEAR PROTESTS AGAINST RIVERSIDE RESEARCH INSTITUTE ARE ON THE RISE
description: One day last August, James Munves, a New York freelance writer, rode the elevator to the ninth-floor offices of the Riverside Research Institute, a military and medical research laboratory on 42d Street between Eighth and Ninth Avenues in Manhattan. In the hallway, Mr. Munves pulled a sheet of paper from a manila envelope and loudly read these words before a security guard ordered him to leave:

title: MONDAY SPORTS Basketball
description: Staten Island vs. City, 1 P.M.; Hunter vs. John Jay, 3 P.M.; Baruch vs. Lehman, 6 P.M., and Medgar Evers vs.

title: LEBANESE ARMY EXPECTS BATTLES FOR KEY TOWNS
description: The Lebanese Army is girding for what many here think will be its decisive test of strength against Druse and Moslem militias opposed to President Amin Gemayel.

title: IT'S TIME FOR A CHANGE
description: T HE howls began when the Jets drafted Ken O'Brien last spring. Verbal New York fans, observing the National Football League draft in a midtown hotel, wanted to know if the Jet management had lost its mind drafting a Division II quarterback ahead of Dan Marino.

title: POPE BEATIFIES 99 MARTYRS OF REIGN OF TERROR
description: Pope John Paul II beatified 100 people today, all but one of them victims of that phase of the French Revolution known as the Reign of Terror.

title: St. Peter's Cancels Game in Delaware
description: St. Peter's has canceled its basketball game at Delaware State Monday night. A St. Peter's spokesman said today that the contract for the game had specified that Eastern College Athletic Conference Metro officials would work it, but that Delaware State informed St. Peter's last week that the school wanted to use officials from its own league, the Mid-Eastern Athletic Conference.

title: Henderson of A's Loses Arbitration
description: The arbitrator who gave Fernando Valenzuela a $1 million player last year did not help Rickey Henderson break Valenzuela's arbitration record this year.

title: No Headline
description: Fifi W. Bergman, 59; Avedon's First Model

title: YARBOROUGH TAKES DAYTONA 500 RACE
description: Cale Yarborough, using the same slingshot maneuver that won for him last year, swept his Chevrolet Monte Carlo SS into the lead just two turns from the finish today to become only the second driver to capture two straight Daytona 500 stock-car races.

title: FEDERAL INMATE DIES AND 2D IS HURT IN ESCAPE BID
description: An inmate trying to escape was killed and another was critically injured yesterday night when a handmade rope of bedsheets snapped and the men fell from the ninth floor of the Metropolitan Correctional Center in lower Manhattan, a spokesman for the center said.

title: CENTER MARKS 20 YEARS OF KIDNEY TRANSPLANTS
description: It never occurred to Alroyd Henry that he might refuse a request to donate his kidney to his sister, Norma Jones, seven years ago.

title: NEW F.B.I. THREAT
description: The Federal Bureau of Investigation has often had difficulty striking a balance between effectively enforcing Federal law and preserving individual rights. During the 1950's and 1960's, it relied on what a Senate Committee later called ''abusive techniques'' and ''vicious tactics'' in the conduct of investigations. From 1971 to 1974, it tracked the activities of thousands of citizens whose only offense was lawful dissent from Government policies.

title: Bridge: Coup Doesn't Need a Name To Be an Effective Weapon
description: Half a century ago the Culbertson theorists found themselves unable to think of an appropriate name for a particular maneuver for the declarer. They settled, rather feebly, for the ''coup without a name.''

title: Stassen Prods Iowans Not to Back Reagan
description: Former Gov. Harold E. Stassen of Minnesota is urging Iowa Republicans to send an uncommitted delegation to the Republican National Convention in Texas next summer.

title: Jets 4, Capitals 3
description: Doug Smail scored 55 seconds into overtime to snap Washington's 14- game unbeaten streak and 10-game winning streak.

title: Iowa Caucuses HISTORY
description: Every four years since 1972 the Iowa caucuses have served as the nation's first test of voter preference in Presidential politics. Democratic caucuses of today grew out of changes in state party rules in 1972 designed to make the process more open. Both George McGovern in 1972 and Jimmy Carter in 1976 used strong showings in the caucuses to propel their dark-horse candidacies to the Democratic nomination. In 1980, those attending the Iowa caucus rejected an effort by Senator Edward M. Kennedy of massachusetts to challenge President Carter for the nomination. THE STATE

title: EXPORT ALASKA OIL TO JAPAN
description: This week, Congress will consider whether to rescind the Export Administration Act's ban on the export of Alaska oil, allowing the crude to flow to markets in the Far East. It is in the national security and economic interest of the United States that the ban be lifted.

title: Question Box
description: QUESTION: Is it goaltending in a National Basketball Association game if a player attempting to score touches the ball after it enters the cylinder, or if he touches the basket?

title: SHAKEOUT FOR PETROCHEMICALS
description: It happened in steel, it happened in copper and now it is starting to happen in basic petrochemicals.

title: DEMOCRATS' IOWA CAMPAIGN ENDS WITH SHARP ATTACKS ON MONDALE
description: On the eve of Iowa's precinct caucuses, the Democratic Presidential candidates wrapped up their campaigning in the state today to await the first judgment of voters in 1984.

title: Moves Confuse Jets
description: The extraordinary upheaval of the Jets, for many years a team that was predictable in the front office and on the field, has been building for some time.

title: Men Lost in Vietnam Subject of New Mission
description: The highest-level United States Government delegation to visit Vietnam since the end of the war in that country left Bangkok for Hanoi today to discuss the issue of 2,500 Americans missing in action, a United States Embassy spokesman said.

title: HOLOGRAMS FIND MARKET ON MAGAZINES AND CARDS
description: In the right light, an eagle seems ready to fly off the cover of National Geographic's March issue, now being mailed to 10.5 million subscribers. And this spring, birthday salutations and images of ships and goldfish, among other things, will appear to float from a new line of Hallmark greeting cards.

title: Pellet-Gun Shot Hits Boy in Heart
description: A 13-year-old boy was seriously injured early today by a pellet- gun shot that pierced his heart, traveled through a kidney and lodged in his liver, the authorities said.

title: ISRAEL BOMBS SITES IT SAYS ARE BASES FOR PALESTINIANS
description: Israeli warplanes bombed targets in the hills near the Lebanese capital today.

title: DISPUTE OVER GRANT TO JERSEY CITY TURNS INTO A BATTLE OF WASHINGTON CLOUT
description: The dispute over a proposed $40 million Federal grant for a Jersey City waterfront project that New York City officials charge threatens to draw business from Manhattan has escalated into a high-stakes game of Washington politics.

title: Warn Industries Puts 3d Generation at Helm
description: Michael T. Warn, 31, has assumed control as chairman and chief executive of Warn Industries, a family- owned company founded in 1948 by his grandfather, Arthur, who helped revolutionize the four-wheel-drive jeep industry.

title: JACKSON DENIES USING TERM OFFENSIVE TO JEWS
description: The Rev. Jesse Jackson, who preaches the politics of reconciliation, is being persistently questioned about whether he has used derogatory terms in referring to Jews.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE;
description: WITH FANFARE What better way to celebrate a holiday, such as today's in celebration of our founding father's birthday, than with a fanfare? Without fanfare, the New York Brass Ensemble has announced that it is devoting itself to a program of American fanfares tonight at 8 o'clock in the Good Shepherd-Faith Presbyterian Church, 152 West 66th Street, a modest blast away from Lincoln Center.

title: Banking Role For Australia
description: A Government-commissioned study has urged the development of an offshore banking center here, claiming that Sydney could become the world's third-largest financial center, after New York and London. The report, issued late last week by a panel appointed by the premier of the state of New South Wales, said the recent relaxation of Australian foreign exchange regulations offers ''a unique opportunity to develop a regional financial center in Australia.''

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Dinosaurs and Domesticity

title: HIGH HOPES FOR METS' GOODEN
description: Who struck out the most batters in professional baseball last year?

title: More Express Buses Are Due in Midtown
description: New limited-stop bus service will begin tomorrow on Lexington and Third Avenues to speed travel in midtown Manhattan, the Transit Authority said.

title: LATEST WORD: NEW YORKESE OF '84 IS HERE
description: The oilitics gloomster fedexed user- friendly signage to his binuclear family before goin' Hollywood.

title: SWEDES GO 1-2 IN NORDIC
description: The sun was struggling over the crest of the fir trees, and four Hungarians worked to set a hot-air balloon aloft advertising polypropylene. Such was the atmosphere as 54 skiers set out this morning on long narrow skis, with upturned tips like Viking ships, to begin the 50-kilometer cross-country race.

title: 'THE COMEDY OF ERRORS,' STARRING ROGER DALTREY
description: PUBLIC television's ''Shakespeare Plays'' project finally gets around tonight, on WNET-TV, Channel 13, at 8, to ''The Comedy of Errors,'' one of the earliest - some scholars would say the first - of his works for the stage. It is a short play. It is occasionally an exasperating play. In fact, it is something of a piffle.

title: 28 SOLDIERS DIE IN CRASH OF 2 SALVADOR COPTERS
description: Two Government helicopters collided and crashed today after being fired on by guerrillas, killing all 28 military men aboard, an army spokesman announced.

title: FRENCH SETTLE IN CHAD FOR LONG STAY
description: To many visitors, it has been a long time since this war-weary capital has appeared so relaxed.

title: 1-2 AND BABY MAKES 3
description: SARAJEVO, Yugoslavia

title: Debate: Who's the Bully?
description: Common Cause, which calls itself the citizens' lobby, has portrayed itself for years as a diminutive David, challenging the overpowering Goliath of the corporate political action committees that give millions of campaign dollars to favored candidates. Now the corporations are trying to switch roles, maintaining that Common Cause is really the bully and they are its helpless targets.

title: SHIITE AND DRUSE MEET WITH SYRIANS
description: Lebanon's Shiite Moslem and Druse leaders met here today with Syrian officials to plan political and military strategy after President Hafez al-Assad's rejection of a Saudi-backed peace plan.

title: Washington Watch; Conrail Bidders Are Lining Up
description: WASHINGTON

title: MUSIC: 'INSURRECT'
description: FOR the past 20 years, the Bread and Puppet Theater has taken singing, dancing, playing and acting, infused them all with social and political concerns, and brought this mixture of art and polemic to the streets, to city lofts and to churches everywhere. The group is spending a few weeks away from its permanent home in northern Vermont and is giving New Yorkers a chance to see its ''Insurrection Opera and Oratorio.'' It plays at the Judson Church on Washington Square until March 11.

title: PHONE NEVER RANG FOR PHIL MAHRE
description: In recent days, President Reagan has telephoned congratulations to Bill Johnson, Debbie Armstrong and Scott Hamilton, the previous American gold-medal winners in the XIV Olympic Winter Games.

title: Colombia-Venezuela Accord Aimed at Drugs and Rebels
description: The Colombian and Venezuelan Governments agreed Friday to join forces against drug trafficking and guerrilla activity in the jungle along their border.

title: DEMOCRATS PREPARE BACKGROUND STUDIES FOR MEESE HEARINGS
description: Senate Democrats plan to question Edwin Meese 3d, the White House counselor, about allegations of political cronyism, his personal finances and his stand on civil liberties when he testifies on his nomination as Attorney General.

title: CHIEF SHOREHAM CONCERN
description: To the Editor:

title: 2 STATES IN BATTLE OVER TAX INCREASE
description: A tax war has the states of Washington and Oregon at each other's throats, with name-calling and political threats.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: A dispatch from Manila last Sunday on the views of Carlos P. Romulo misstated his standing with respect to the signing of the United Nations Charter. V. K. Wellington Koo, a former Chinese Nationalist diplomat, is also a surviving signer.

title: WORKPLACE DEATH PROMPTS A DISPUTE
description: A year ago this month, a 45-year-old Polish immigrant died of cyanide poisoning at a job he had briefly held at a factory that the Cook County prosecutor has described as ''a huge gas chamber.''

title: DEVIL'S BAG STARTS HIS QUEST FOR 3-YEAR-OLD GLORY
description: BY 4 o'clock this afternoon, the brown colt in the center stall of Barn M will be hungry, so hungry that he may have figured out that this is a special day.

title: EUROPEANS GAIN LITTLE IN TALKS
description: -ST. CLOUD, France, Feb. 19 - Foreign ministers from the 10 Common Market countries reported little progress here today after two days of informal talks aimed at resolving the community's financial crisis, which has brought it to the brink of bankruptcy.

title: CARIBBEAN INITIATIVE ATTRACTS INVESTMENT
description: A number of companies are beginning to rise to the Administration's Caribbean-investment lure.

title: HIDDEN HAZARDS/HIDDEN TREASURES; Hometown Treasure Harry Truman, a fellow Missourian, once called Thomas Hart Benton ''the best damned painter in America.'' But for many years one of the best damned painter's best known works was more or less hidden. ''America Today'' was installed in a fifth-floor classroom of the New School for Social Research in Greenwich Village. The school had commissioned the work in 1930.
description: Two years ago the 10 panels of the mural, depicting straphangers, stockbrokers, boxers and laborers, passed out of sight completely.

title: Pilots Accept Eastern Plan
description: Eastern Airlines pilots ignored union leaders and approved a salary-for-stock swap that is the key to a $367 million bailout plan for the troubled carrier, a union vote count showed today.

title: No Headline
description: '79 Plot to Kill Mayor Of Chicago Is Reported

title: Spaniards March on Base
description: Tens of thousands of people marched from the center of Madrid to a nearby United States air base today, calling for Spain's withdrawal from the North Atlantic Treaty Organization and the removal of American bases, the police said. The march organizers, the Anti- NATO Commission, said 55,000 people joined the protest, which took four hours to cover the seven miles to the base at Torrejon.

title: PORTER EASILY WINS CROSS-COUNTRY TRIAL
description: The fact that Pat Porter won the men's United States trial today for the world cross-country championships next month was not as surprising as the margin he won it by.

title: Rewards for the Arrest Of Cat-Killer at $2,000
description: Publicity over the deaths by beating of nearly 100 cats here has brought donations ranging from $1 to $500 to a reward fund. The fund is now over $2,000.

title: THE OPERA: 'CHERUBIN'
description: CURIOUS are the ways of the Zeitgeist, or perhaps we should say ''l'esprit du temps.'' For decades, the operas of Jules Massenet have languished on the outskirts of the international repertory and have been slighted even in France, condemned by a modernist spirit as somehow too sinfully pleasurable, too aromatically melodious, for truly

title: IONA PREP TAKES TRACK TITLE
description: Iona Prep scored 44 points to win its first team title yesterday in the 57th Catholic High Schools Athletic Association intersectional track and field championship at the 102d Engineers Armory in Manhattan.

title: U.S.I.A.'s Little List
description: Credit Charles Wick with an honest abhorrence of evenhandedness. He believes that the United States Information Agency, which he heads, is ''supposed to be partisan to a certain extent.'' That's fine if he means one of its tasks is to explain Administration policies abroad. But Mr. Wick inspires a more literal loyalty, like that of the eager beavers who, in the spirit of the Mikado's Lord High Executioner, prepared a little list of speakers who never would be missed.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Blair Strip Steel Co., New Castle, Pa., has named J. Austin Murphy president and chief executive officer, and appointed James R. Stillwagon vice president, finance and administration.

title: A SANDANISTA HEALTH 'ADVANCE' THAT WASN'T
description: To the Editor:

title: MODEST OPTIMISM IN CANADA
description: In what has become a tradition in this capital city, Canada's Finance Minister holds a luncheon for the press on the day after his budget is introduced to Parliament. Over the years, the menu for the affair has evolved into an economic indicator of sorts.

title: ARAB ANGER AT U.S.
description: Anti-Americanism is gathering force in the Arab world, particularly the Gulf region. This resentment is not always rational and has not been entirely caused by the United States, but it has taken considerable new momentum in the last 18 months - largely in response to what is perceived as Washington's increasingly pro-Israeli bias, its tendency to ignore the Arabs and write off their concerns. Washington should act to reverse these perceptions before it is too late.

title: HIDDEN HAZARD/HIDDEN TREASURE ; Heel Trap
description: ''Step on a crack and break your mother's back'' is what children on the sidewalk tell each other. Until recently, to step on a crack in the new red granite sidewalk of the Bank of America Plaza (the old Biltmore Hotel 43d) was to jeopardize your own back.

title: Preliminary Ruling on Steel
description: The International Trade Commission has determined in a preliminary finding that United States producers of stainless steel are being harmed by imports of stainless steel sheet and strip from Spain.

title: Welcome Planned For Miss Sumners
description: Their favorite didn't get the Olympic gold medal, but the proud residents of Rosalynn Sumners's hometown are planning a big homecoming for the top American woman figure skater just the same.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: UPSET: Australia Wins the America's Cup. By Michael Levitt and Barbara Lloyd. Color Photography by Dan Nerney. 212 pages. Nautical Quarterly/Workman. Paper. $7.95.

title: Bill to Bar Felons From Office Draws Fire
description: A bill that would bar felons on probation from running for office has drawn charges of racism because its first effect would be to stop an influential black leader now behind bars from trying to regain his seat in the Maryland Legislature in 1986.

title: DANCE: THE NATIONAL BALLET OF CANADA
description: The National Ballet of Canada's annual winter gala took an unusual turn Saturday night here at the O'Keefe Center. In place of the standard classical pas de deux or large chunks of the company's own choreography, the emphasis was on modern dance or ballet that borrows heavily from outside the classical idiom.

title: PRESS CORPS AND GOVERNMENT, AT LATER PERSPECTIVE
description: ''The Government always wants the reporters on the team,'' says James Deakin. ''But if the journalists are on the team, who will report the game?''

title: STOPPARD DEBATES THE ROLE OF THE WRITER
description: WHEN the curtain falls on ''The Real Thing,'' the talk has only begun. Tom Stoppard's play has not only stimulated critical discourse, but also after-theater debate, much of it continuing the argument waged by Mr. Stoppard's characters on stage - whether, in a troubled world, art can exist for art's sake or whether it should serve a political cause.

title: McEnroe Beaten
description: Ivan Lendl defeated John McEnroe, 2-6, 6-4, 6-2, 7-6, today in an exhibition tennis match. On Saturday McEnroe finished a four-man event in Sydney, Australia, with a victory over Guillermo Vilas.

title: EDUCATION'S NEEDIEST
description: To the Editor:

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Celebrating Brotherhood

title: THE MIDEAST PEACE PROCESS NEEDS 'AUTHENTIC' PALESTINIANS
description: To the Editor:

title: Hussein Returns to Jordan
description: King Hussein returned home today from an 18-day trip, which included a series of medical tests in Cleveland. Following his stay in Cleveland, King Hussein met with President Reagan and President Hosni Mubarak of Egypt in Washington. On his way back to Amman, the King, accompanied by his wife, Queen Noor, stopped in London for talks with Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher.

title: WORK WAS PRESENTED IN 1905
description: ''Cherubin'' was the 19th of Jules Massenet's 29 surviving operas, and counts as one of the most obscure of the lot; last night's Carnegie Hall performance apparently marked its American premiere. The opera was inspired by a play by the Belgian Francis de Croisset that in comedic form traced the amorous adventures of Beaumarchais's (and Mozart's) Cherubino after the end of ''Le Mariage de Figaro''; de Croisset and Henri Cain, a frequent Massenet librettist, wrote the ''Cherubin'' libretto.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''She was doing all the work while I was out playing.'' - Phil Mahre, who learned shortly after he won the gold medal in the slalom in the Winter Olympics that his wife had given birth to a boy earlier in the day. (C6:6.)

title: GREAT SOYBEAN UPROAR AND ITS FINAL OUTCOME
description: Somewhere in the United States there may be a more peculiar marriage. If so, news of it has not emerged lately.

title: MUSIC: TAPLIN PLAYS MOZART
description: AS the administrative and business aspects of musical life expand, it is encouraging to find an administrator whose dedication to the art extends not just to fund-raising and organizing, but to the making of music itself. That was the case on Saturday afternoon in the Cathedral of St. John the Divine, when Frank E. Taplin, the president of the Metropolitan Opera, played the piano part in Mozart's Quartet in G minor, accompanied by members of the Herrick Quartet.

title: ADVICE FOR SMALL BUSINESSES
description: In the three years since Phyllis Gerrans founded Fancy Frocks in Santa Maria, Calif., she has seen her dress-manufacturing company grow from a three-person operation with a fragile hope of survival into a thriving enterprise with a staff of 48 plus 5 sales representatives around the country.

title: SPORTS WORLD SPECIALS
description: A Terrapin Insider

title: RANGERS LOSE TO FLYERS IN OVERTIME, 3-2
description: The Rangers have a different look this morning, a second-place look, after being knocked out of the top spot in the Patrick Division last night in a 3-2 overtime loss to the Philadelphia Flyers at Madison Square Garden.

title: JAPAN SHAREHOLDERS TALK BACK
description: Japanese stockholders traditionally have enjoyed few privileges, and the airing of complaints at company annual meetings has not been among them. But slowly, as the importance of revisions in the Japanese commercial code has come to be appreciated, things are starting to change: Japanese shareholders are talking back.

title: E.E.C. Cartel Inquiry
description: The European Economic Community has begun an investigation of ferro-manganese producers, a Common Market spokesman said. He said five to six companies in Britain, France, West Germany and Italy were being investigated on charges concerning price fixing and quotas.

title: Heavy Fighting Erupts In Persian Gulf War
description: Heavy fighting flared again on the central sector of the Persian Gulf war front today as Iran accused Iraq of breaking its pledge to suspend air and artillery attacks on Iranian cities.

title: 4 Killed in Indian Protest
description: Four people were killed and about 25 were wounded today when police officers opened fire to disperse demonstrators in the troubled northern Indian town of Panipat, the Press Trust of India news agency reported.

title: Britain and Argentina Reported Near Accord
description: Britain and Argentina are near an agreement to open talks on declaring an end to hostilities over the Falkland Islands and the normalization of relations, according to unofficial reports circulating here.

title: Jersey State Police Suspend 2 Officers
description: Two state police sergeants have been suspended without pay pending the outcome of an internal investigation into allegations that troopers have sold confiscated weapons to gun dealers, a state police spokesman said today.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article in The Home Section Feb. 2 about reproductions of antique wallpaper and fabrics misidentified the Longfellow poem that inspired the name of Priscilla curtains. It was ''The Courtship of Miles Standish.''

title: Flatley Is Ejected In Canada's Loss
description: Pat Flatley, Canada's second-leading scorer in the Olympic hockey tournament, was ejected from the bronze-medal game against Sweden today when a linesman said he had struck him in the chest with his stick.

title: Futures/Options; Profiting With Index Trading
description: W HEN the Kansas City Board of Trade opened the first stock index futures market two years ago this week, conventional Wall Street wisdom held that if the market survived at all, it would merely serve as another gambling vehicle for a few traders.

title: VISITING HOTELIERS SAVOR NEW YORK
description: Smiling proudly for the camera, Dermot Fitzpatrick of Scotland hugged a New York City transit police officer.

title: MUSIC: MCCORMACK PROGRAM
description: THE Irish tenor John McCormack was born 100 years ago this June; on Sunday afternoon at Carnegie Hall the tenor Frank Patterson presented a McCormack centennial concert, in celebration of the anniversary. The program was built along the same lines as a typical McCormack recital: Irish ballads were mingled with Schubert and Handel, Marshall's ''I Hear You Calling Me'' with Mozart's ''Il mio tesoro.''

title: Pay in Urban Areas Up in '82
description: The average annual pay of Americans working in metropolitan areas totaled $17,327 in 1982, a rise of 6.8 percent over the previous year, the Bureau of Labor Statistics has reported.

title: DOCTORS DISAGREED INLEONARD'S EYE
description: The two examining ophthalmologists who agreed last week that Sugar Ray Leonard could resume his boxing comeback - pending an examination in a week - apparently disagreed about the severity of the fighter's problems with his right eye.

title: WHAT BABY'S PREMIER TEACHER SHOULD KNOW
description: To the Editor:

title: BUSINESS PEOPLE ;
description: A New Chairman At Sonat Offshore

title: MUSIC: NOTED IN BRIEF;
description: Alice Giles Presents A Solo Harp Concert

title: THEATER: 'FABLES FOR FRIENDS,' A COMEDY BY MARK O'DONNELL
description: IN his first comedy at Playwrights Horizons, last summer's ''That's It, Folks!''

title: REAGAN VISIT: NOSTALGIA FOR IOWA, WITH MILEAGE
description: As Iowa's voters prepare for caucuses Monday night here in the first test of strength among Democratic Presidential candidates, President Reagan will be returning to the scene of his first success as a radio personality.

title: Dr. T. H. Gertel Wed To Joan Marie DiBona
description: Joan Marie DiBona, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Anthony DiBona of Far Rockaway, Queens, was married yesterday to Dr. Theodore Hilliard Gertel, a son of Mr. and Mrs. William Gertel of Springfield, Mass. Rabbi Elliot Gertel, the bridegroom's brother, performed the ceremony at Leonard's of Great Neck, L.I.

title: SPORTS WORLD SPECIALS
description: 'Wanna Bet?'

title: MICHENER'S 'SPACE' TO BE MINI-SERIES
description: Exactly one year from now, if all goes according to a lot of well-laid plans, some 100 million American televison sets will be tuned to one main event: the adaptation of James Michener's novel, ''Space.'' At this point not a single foot of film has been shot, but a small army is being assembled, ready to spring into action on April 15 to consummate one of the most ambitious and expensive undertakings in the history of television.

title: DEALING WITH A PERIOD OF FOREIGN POLICY REVERSES
description: The crisis in Lebanon unfolded at the White House last week in an atmosphere that seemed epitomized by President Reagan's enjoying an arm- wrestling contest with a visitor in the Oval Office at the moment a top aide was giving details of the disarray in Beirut.

title: MEDAL STANDING
description: Gold Silver Bronze Total

title: Nassau Prisoner Is Found Hanged
description: A Long Island man arrested late Saturday night and held on a charge of driving while intoxicated was found hanged in his cell in the Nassau County police headquarters three hours later, the police said today.

title: GOAL TAKES NIEKRO ON A LONGER DRIVE
description: As he drove his red and white van south on the Florida Turnpike early this morning, Phil Niekro turned up the volume on the cassette player, filling his ears with polka music.

title: TRUSTEE FOR CURRENCY TRADER
description: A Federal judge has appointed a former San Diego municipal judge to investigate whether an investment concern specializing in currency trading had improperly managed millions of dollars in customer accounts.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: 'Striking It Rich'

title: MISSOURI COMPANY PLEADS GUILTY TO VIOLATIONS OF CLEAN WATER ACT
description: A big eastern Missouri company has pleaded guilty to criminal violation of the Federal Clean Water Act for concealing the amount of pollution the company treatment plan was discharging into the Meramec River.

title: Professor of Finance Joins Lehman Brothers
description: After trying his hand as a floor trader, William L. Silber is giving up an academic career to join Lehman Brothers Kuhn Loeb as senior vice president, trading strategy.

title: No Headline
description: MusicNoted in Brief

title: Foe of Marcos Flies to the U.S.
description: A Philippine opposition leader, Salvador H. Laurel, flew to the United States today, saying he would ask the American leadership to stop aiding the ''oppressive'' rule of President Ferdinand E. Marcos unless Mr. Marcos pledged honest elections.

title: DEMOTION OF POLICE CHIEF BY MANAGER STIRS MIAMI
description: The demotion of Miami's Police Chief by the City Manager two weeks ago has set off a bitter political controversy with racial undertones.

title: 76ERS DEFEAT KNICKS
description: After all of his masterful recent performances, Bernard King became human at an inopportune time here this afternoon.

title: MAHRES AND SOVIET GOLD MARK END OF GAMES
description: At the finish, they converged on the goal, hugging and kissing each other, and happily heaving their hockey sticks into the crowded stands of the Zetra ice arena. And in the middle of their red-shirted band, taller than the others and easily visible because he had shed his helmet, was Vladislav Tretiak.

title: MAHRE TWINS WIN SLALOM MEDALS AS THE OLYMPICS END IN SARAJEVO
description: Phil and Steve Mahre, the twins from Yakima, Wash., ended a seasonlong slump in a burst of skiing grace today by finishing first and second in the men's slalom on the final day of the XIV Olympic Winter Games.

title: PLAN WOULD PUT JAIL DETAINEES IN WORK PROJECT
description: New York City's Department of Correction is planning to start a work program for several hundred of the inmates held in city jails awaiting trial, the Correction Commissioner said yesterday.

title: No Financial Loss Seen for Games
description: The XIV Olympic Winter Games will at least break even financially, the president of the Organizing Committee said today, the last day of the Games.

title: 'Across Pond' Is Staged At 18th Street Theater
description: To observe Black History Month, the four-year-old O'LAC Repertory Ensemble is producing ''Across the Pond,'' a drama by George Joshua that focuses on several black soldiers stationed in the Philippines during the Vietnam War. Mr. Joshua is himself a United States Air Force veteran.

title: THIEVES TAKE SUBSCRIBER LIST OF RUSSIAN-LANGUAGE PAPER
description: The Manhattan office of a Russian- language daily newspaper was entered early yesterday by intruders who stole subscription lists and left a threatening note, according to the police and to executives of the paper.

title: Ecuador Sets Oil Plan
description: Ecuador plans to spend $2.24 billion over five years to develop its oil industry, Patricio Ribadeneira, the manager of the state oil corporation, said last week.

title: NAHUM TSCHACBASOV
description: Nahum Tschacbasov, a Russian- born painter, teacher and poet, died last week at New York University Hospital.

title: MANNED U.S. SPACE STATION: NOT NOW
description: To the Editor:

title: New Hampshire Hours For Drinking Extended
description: State officials have agreed to extend drinking hours at some bars and restaurants in the last week of New Hampshire's Presidential primary campaign.

title: Japan VTR Exports Up
description: Japan's exports of videotape recorders climbed to a monthly record of 1.66 million units in December, the Electronics Industries Association of Japan said. This was a rise in VTR exports of 72.3 percent from a year earlier and 5.6 percent from November.

title: Angelo G. Rocco Dies at 100; Leader in Mill Strike of 1912
description: Angelo G. Rocco, a key figure in the Lawrence mill workers' strike of 1912, one of the earliest walkouts in the American labor movement, died Friday in Fort Lauderdale, Fla., after a heart attack and a fall. He was 100 years old.

title: TIMES SQ. PLAN: EXPERTS DEBATE IMPACT ON CRIME
description: Where will all the street people go?

title: Britain Considers Fate of Crown Agents
description: One of the few remaining legacies of the British Empire may not survive the 1980's.

title: 103 Introductions
description: Even though January is a slow month for product introductions, Martin Friedman, editor of the Dancer Fitzgerald Sample New Product News, reports that last month saw 103 introductions, a slight improvement over January 1982 and well above the 66 that was the monthly average from 1964 to 1980. Mr. Friedman's count is only for food and nonprescription drugs.

title: POLAND FREES A U.N. WORKERCONVICTED OF SPYING
description: A Polish United Nations employee convicted of spying was released today after serving more than four years of a seven-year prison term.

title: SECURITY PACT BEING WORKED OUT BY MOZAMBIQUE AND SOUTH AFRICA
description: Mozambique and South Africa announced today that they intended to enter into a formal security agreement.

title: NOTES ON FASHION
description: ''P-P-M-N-M-M,'' Karl Lagerfeld said to his rapt audience at lunch last week at Le Cirque while Richard Nixon sat nearby discussing the coming Presidential election with an equally rapt group. ''That's my new direction for fall. Post-post-modern-new-mobile-minimalism. The post-modern movement brought in detail, color and a touch of romance. Now we are going to something that compresses all that into a clean edge.''

title: Reynolds Metals
description: The Reynolds Metals Company, Richmond, said it would permanently close its San Patricio aluminum reduction plant, which is near Corpus Christi, Tex.

title: RATING MIXED FOR OLYMPICS
description: During the final weekend of the 1984 Winter Olympic Games, ABC's prime-time telecasts of the events in Sarajevo, Yugoslavia, lost in the audience ratings twice to CBS, a CBS executive said yesterday.

title: Heating Bills Found to Rise
description: Heating bills for the average resident using natural gas jumped 27 percent for December and January from the period a year earlier, largely because of frigid weather, according to a study released by the Citizens-Labor Energy Coalition, a consumer group.

title: Hospital Corp. Raises Profit
description: The Hospital Corporation of America said yesterday that earnings rose 33.7 percent in the fourth quarter, to $55.9 million, or 64 cents a share, from $41.8 million, or 52 cents a share, a year earlier. Revenues rose 6.5 percent, to $964.3 billion, from $905.79 billion.

title: Youth Movement
description: After all of their talk about starting from scratch this season, the Cincinnati Reds began their youth movement by hiring 80-year-old Walter (Doc) Eberhardt to lead the players in conditioning exercises at training camp.

title: LAS VEGAS CASINO'S OWNER THRIVING IN A HIGH-RISK, HIGH-STAKES SETTING
description: No matter that his Dunes Hotel and Casino lost $30 million last year, or that he is 77 years old and had a heart attack three years ago, or that he filed for protection under the bankruptcy laws last month, listing $184 million in obligations, Morris A. Shenker demurs at the suggestion his back may be to the wall.

title: WAITERS AND I.R.S. GIRD TO DO BATTLE OVER TIPS
description: The Internal Revenue Service is unpopular at the best of times, but lately it has sunk to some sort of new low among waiters, waitresses and managers at restaurants and bars throughout the country. The reason: a new regulation aimed at squeezing greater tax revenue out of tips.

title: POLES PACK A MASS TO DEMONSTRATE AGAINST CARDINAL
description: More than 2,000 Poles packed into a Roman Catholic Church in this industrial suburb of Warsaw tonight for a protest mass that represented a challenge to the authority of the Polish Primate, Jozef Cardinal Glemp.

title: MARY BOYLAN
description: Mary Boylan, a character actress and playwright for 45 years, died Saturday in Roosevelt Hospital. She was 70 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: 2 Bahamians Convicted In Drug Conspiracy
description: A Federal court jury convicted two Bahamians today of drug conspiracy for accepting a $100,000 bribe to arrange a cocaine shipment to Florida.

title: Inmos Rejects A.T.& T.'s Bid
description: The American Telephone and Telegraph Company's $65.3 million takeover offer for Inmos Ltd., Britain' state-owned semiconductor producer, has been rejected. The British Government is wrestling with how to introduce more private capital into Inmos's structure, but both Inmos and Government officials here agreed that the company was worth far more than A.T.& T.'s bid, which was made about two weeks ago. Don McLaughlin, an A.T.& T. spokesman in the United States, said today that the company had not been formally advised of the decision and would have no comment on Tit.

title: Guerrero Settles
description: Hours before his case was scheduled to go to arbitration, Pedro Guerrero, the Los Angeles Dodgers third baseman, signed what is believed to be the largest contract in the club's history. Details were not revealed, but according to management sources, Guerrero received a five- year contract worth about $7 million.

title: 300 PUT OFFSHORE
description: The Italian contingent of the multinational force completed its withdrawal from the Lebanese capital today.

title: THE DEAN OF LOBBYISTS
description: For more than half a century, he has trudged through the halls of Congress, his short legs pumping vigorously, a cigar in one corner of his mouth.

title: TUESDAY SPORTS Basketball
description: Knicks vs. Portland Trail Blazers , at Madison Square Garden, 7:35 P.M. The Knicks lost to the Trail Blazers, 106-97, in the fourth game of the season.

title: CITY BALLET: MARIA CALEGARI IN 'FAUN'
description: THE New York City Ballet closed its winter season at the New York State Theater Sunday night. But Sunday afternoon, it offered a major debut by casting Maria Calegari in Jerome Robbins's ''Afternoon of a Faun.''

title: Connecticut Executive Slain in New Orleans
description: A Connecticut businessman who left his hotel in the French Quarter and went jogging was shot and killed when he refused to stop for a robber in a downtown neighborhood, the police said. A 17-year-old youth was later booked on a charge of first-degree murder.

title: Advertising; Carrier's Trade-In Campaign
description: T HE Carrier Corporation, the nation's leading producer of central air conditioning systems, will make a new marketing thrust in a $5 million ad campaign starting Feb. 29 in print and television.

title: HOW A WRITER BECAME A MURDER EXPERT
description: When Ann Rule was divorced in 1972, she wondered how she would feed her four children. She did not expect that as a result of the decision she made she would be regarded 12 years later as an expert on multiple murders and be lecturing detectives on how to solve such crimes.

title: Study on Seabrook Unit
description: The Central Maine Power Company, 6 percent owner of the financially troubled nuclear project at Seabrook, N.H., said Friday that it would ask the Maine Public Utilities Commission to allow the company's $48 million investment in the second reactor to be recovered from ratepayers. A consultant's study prepared for Central Maine Power estimates the cost of Seabrook 1 at $4.8 billion and Seabrook 2 at $5.5 billion - a total of $10.3 billion. But in Manchester, N.H., a Public Service spokesman, Myra Rivera, reiterated the company's support for both reactors.

title: Shamir Bids Europeans Give Israelis a Better Trade Deal
description: Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir appealed to the European Community tonight to provide a better trade deal for Israel's troubled economy, but gained only vague assurances, diplomats said.

title: The U.N. Today February 21, 1984
description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY

title: RISE OF A NEW GENERATION IN CHINA AND TAIWAN DIMS HOPES OF REUNIFICATION
description: Hopes for reunifying the Chinese mainland and Taiwan, a vision sacred to the leadership in both Peking and Taipei, seem more remote than ever as new generations, born apart, grow up without the emotional ties of their forefathers.

title: THE AGING MIND PROVES CAPABLE OF LIFELONG GROWTH
description: RESEARCHERS can now demonstrate that certain crucial areas of human intelligence do not decline in old age among people who are generally healthy.

title: LETTER: ON THE HANDICAPPED
description: THE TROUBLE WITH SPECIAL EDUCATION

title: DRAMA ON SCOPES TRIAL IS BARRED FROM CLASS
description: To some, it seems like the Scopes monkey trial all over again. James Dickerson, a teacher in a nearby suburb, has been trying for a year and a half to show his students a fictionalized movie account of the 1925 case in which another teacher, John T. Scopes, was arrested when he agreed to challenge an old Tennessee law prohibiting the teaching of Darwin's theory of evolution.

title: ; BANKRUPTCY REFORM CAN'T WAIT TILL AFTER NOV. 6
description: To the Editor:

title: OFFICER SHOT AS 2 GUNMEN ATTACK NARCOTICS STAKEOUT
description: A plainclothes police officer was shot and seriously wounded yesterday by two men who burst into a vacant Harlem apartment that he and another officer were using to observe suspected drug sales, the police said.

title: TINY TURTLES' BIG SECRET, A MYSTERIOUS AND PERILOUS JOURNEY, IS DISCOVERED
description: THE mystery of where baby sea turtles spend their first months of life has been partly solved, a Florida biologist who has been studying the puzzle for more than 30 years reports.

title: AMHERST STUDENTS HOLD SIT-IN
description: Amherst College students staged a sit-in at the administration building today to protest an administration plan to end the campus fraternity system.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''The future has been postponed, not canceled.'' - James J. Whalen, president of Ithaca College, on an unexpected surge in student applications. (C10:3.)

title: AN ANGELA CUMMINGS SHOP
description: Bergdorf Goodman's continuing renovation is quickly changing the face of that high-fashion store. There are new escalators. The famous Delman shoe shop has moved upstairs.

title: ADMIRAL IN ARGENTINA HELD IN MURDER INQUIRY
description: A retired admiral widely accused of heading Argentina's most notorious torture center in the 1970's has been arrested in connection with the activities of rightist death squads, the federal police said today.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE;
description: THE GODS There are 40 gods that peer back at visitors to the gallery of the Asian Arts Institute, up two flights at 26 Bowery, near Pell Street, in Chinatown (233-2154). They are paper gods, the sort burned on important occasions by Chinese who believe that the spirit of the gods may be released.

title: CLOSE RACE FOR 2D AS GLENN TRAILS
description: Walter F. Mondale won a commanding victory in the Iowa Democratic caucuses today, and John Glenn, running far back in the eight-candidate field, took a beating that threatened to cripple his Presidential candidacy.

title: Dollar Is HigherIn Europe
description: The dollar was slightly stronger in European trading today, but dealers said it was difficult to identify a trend in view of the holiday closure of trading in the United States.

title: SPRING CLOTHES: PARED DOWN
description: Spare, uncluttered, easy to wear: These are the dominant characteristics of the warm- weather clothes now coming into the stores.

title: Gloom Greets Hockey Team
description: Coaches and players of the United States Olympic hockey team were greeted by fewer than 50 people at International Airport on their return from Sarajevo, Yugoslavia.

title: ARMS CONTROLLERS' STAKE IN PURSUING VIOLATIONS
description: To the Editor:

title: BRICKS AND LOCAL POWER
description: Raise the issue of low- or moderate- income housing with developers in this city and they will tell you, in chorus, that it can't be done - land is too expensive, Federal subsidies have dried up, there is no profit in anything but luxury apartments.

title: 2D CHANCE ENDS SLIDE FOR FLYERS
description: Brian Propp, standing in the right face-off circle, had the first chance. But his shot deflected off Tom Laidlaw, one of the Ranger defenseman, and came right back to him.

title: JAPANESE EDUCATORS SEE MERITS IN U.S. SYSTEM
description: JUST when critics of American education are looking with envy to Japan's tough education standards, Japanese educators appear worried that their schools may be too tough. They are even turning to American school reformers for suggestions.

title: TALKS ADVANCE ON MERGER OF PRINTERS INTO TEAMSTERS' UNION
