description: Discussions between the International Typographical Union and the International Brotherhood of Teamsters have produced a merger document that would make the printers' union a separate division within the teamsters.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: A column by Dave Anderson in SportsMonday incorrectly characterized the accomplishment of Phil and Steve Mahre Sunday in the Winter Olympics at Sarajevo, Yugoslavia. The first set of brothers to finish first and second in an Olympic event were Platt and Ben Adams of the United States, in the standing high jump at the 1912 Summer Games at Stockholm.

title: THEATER: 'CINDERS,' A LOOK AT POLAND
description: IN ''Cinders,'' the new play at the

title: SUSPECT ARRESTED AND ONE SOUGHT IN MURDER OF AN OFF-DUTY OFFICER
description: One man has been arrested and another is being sought in the murder of an off-duty police officer who was shot and killed, possibly with his own gun, during a robbery on Jan. 31, the police said yesterday.

title: Hollings Courts Voters Of Dixville Notch, N.H.
description: Senator Ernest F. Hollings abandoning the Iowa caucuses, spent Sunday mingling with the 27 voters of this precinct, which votes first in the nation, in an effort to spring a surprise in the New Hampshire primary Feb. 28.

title: Shipbuilding Fraud Suit
description: The Justice Department has filed a civil suit to recover more than $1.8 million from a former General Dynamics manager and two former Frigitemp Corporation executives.

title: Fund Company Can Set Up Bank
description: The Comptroller of the Currency said it had approved the application of the FMR Corporation of Boston, parent of the Fidelity Group of mutual funds, to set up a bank, the Fidelity National Bank and Trust Company in New York. In approving the application last week, the Comptroller's office said Fidelity would do business with employee benefit and personal retirement plans.

title: Border Officers Hold 18 Who Landed in Florida
description: At least 18 people from Cuba and Bangladesh, including two children, were turned over to the United States Border Patrol after their boat was found washed ashore here today in a possible smuggling operation, the police said.

title: BELL AND REGIONAL SCOREBOARD
description: The beer and whisky flowed freely, followed by shrimp cocktail and heaping plates of steak and lobster. Last Thursday's party was for traders from the floor of the New York Stock Exchange to celebrate the end of ''when-issued'' trading in the stripped-down American Telephone and Telegraph Company and the seven regional holding companies it had spun off.

title: Sealaska President Begins Rebuilding
description: A recent realignment of management at the Sealaska Corporation of Juneau, Alaska, will provide the opportunity ''to build a foundation upon bedrock'' to carry the native corporation through the decade, says Byron I. Mallott.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: TUESDAY, FEBRUARY 21, 1984

title: A SINGER SHORT STORY DRAMATIZED
description: ISAAC BASHEVIS SINGER

title: Red Wing Suspended
description: The National Hockey League announced that the Detroit Red Wings left wing Joe Paterson had been suspended for two games after he incurred his fourth game misconduct penalty of the season for fighting during a victory over Toronto Sunday night. The league also fined Paterson $100 and the Red Wings $1,000. Under N.H.L. rules, a player is given a one- game suspension after his third game misconduct with the penalty increased by one game for each subsequent game misconduct penalty.

title: A Bottling Executive Joins Binney & Smith
description: Binney & Smith Inc., the company that makes Crayola brand crayons, has named Richard Gurin president and chief operating officer.

title: Q&A
description: Q.

title: SCOUTING
description: Cutting Back

title: CURRENT INTEREST RATES
description: Tax-Exempt Bonds*9.68

title: India Orders the Police To Shoot Rioters on Sight
description: The Government ordered the police and paramilitary troops to shoot rioters on sight today after a week of fighting between Sikhs and Hindus that has left at least 32 people dead in northern India.

title: Tonka Dismisses Aide
description: The Tonka Corporation announced yesterday that it had dismissed L. Martin LeBus, its senior vice president and chief financial officer, because he ''made an apparently unauthorized and improper investment of $2 million of company funds.''

title: INVESTORS SHUN U.S. DEBT ISSUES
description: After more than a week of gradually falling prices in the credit markets, investors have still not bought up the $16.25 billion in Treasury securities auctioned earlier this month.

title: SEAVER BERATES METS' OFFICIALS
description: Tom Seaver, solemn and ''mentally spent,'' joined the Chicago White Sox today and, in his sharpest criticism of the Mets, asked: ''How could they be so blind?''

title: Fur Workers Picket at Saks
description: Unionized furriers picketed Saks Fifth Avenue in Manhattan yesterday in an attempt to discourage women from buying fur coats, union officials said.

title: THE BOOKS THAT TRY FOR PULITZER HONORS
description: To the Editor:

title: AT A SAC BASE, LIVING CENTERS ON STATE OF ALERT
description: If the world as we know it ends next week, Tech. Sgt. David Demmon figures ''there's a pretty good chance I'll have a front-row seat.''

title: 2 Boats Seized for Drugs
description: Twelve people were arrested and nearly 32 tons of marijuana was seized aboard two boats that were escorted into Key West today. A Coast Guard cutter fired on one of the vessels, a 70-foot shrimper, and arrested nine Colombian nationals last Wednesday, then while towing it to port seized the 42-foot sport fishing boat Night Hawk II and arrested three Florida residents.

title: PLAYERS ; VAULTER SEES CITY FROM GROUND LEVEL
description: Up until now, nearly all of Sergei Bubka's view of America had been from the top, looking down from various heights between 19 feet and 35,000 feet. His schedule had become a routine of an all-night flight followed by a world pole-vault record, followed by another flight. In the months around his 20th birthday early last December, as Bubka had risen from being an unknown to become the leading vaulter in the world, he had not seen much along the way.

title: LABOR CHIEF CRITICIZES REAGAN ECONOMIC POLICIES
description: The Reagan Administration has not addressed any of the basic economic problems confronting the nation, and these problems are ''time bombs ticking away that are going to exact a price sooner or later,'' Lane Kirkland, president of the American Federation of Labor and Congress of Industrial Organizations, said today.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Consul Corp., Minneapolis, which owns the Chi-Chi's chain of Mexican restaurants, has named James H. Crivits, president and chief operating officer, to the additional post of chairman and chief executive.

title: VERMONT STUDENTS FIGHT SCHOOL BAN ON PRESENTING 'RUNAWAYS' PLAY
description: The embittered, abused children of Elizabeth Swados's play ''Runaways'' may yet find their way on stage in the central Vermont town of East Montpelier.

title: Business and the Law; Boom Times, Yet Criticism
description: T HE classic joke about the legal profession has

title: CALMER SEAS WITH CLARK AT HELM
description: Representative John F. Seiberling, an Ohio Democrat, was surprised last Thursday to receive a telephone call from the new Interior Secretary, William P. Clark. This turned to amazed gratification when he asked his opinion about the pending resignation of the director of the department's Office of Surface Mining.

title: People
description: Peter C. Vetowich elected an executive vice president of Ross Roy, Detroit.

title: Greeks Warn on Flame
description: In a veiled warning of possible tougher action, the Ancient Olympia municipal council pledged today to continue opposition to any plan that would involve commercialization of the Olympic flame. At issue is a proposed 82-day torch relay throughout the United States to raise funds for youth and sports charities before the Summer Games in Los Angeles.

title: 4 'Dangerous' Convicts Hunted in Tennessee
description: Prison guards with shotguns searched houses and barns near a landfill today for four ''extremely dangerous'' convicts who fled a prison work detail.

title: HOSPITAL DISPUTE SIDE STEPPED
description: The executive council of the American Federation of Labor-Congress of Industrial Organizations refused today to grant a charter to the National Union of Hospital and Health Care Employees, the old New York-based union.

title: TUESDAY, FEBRUARY 21, 1984 International
description: The Italian force completed its pullout from Beirut. The departure of nearly all the 1,385 Italians left only about 1,300 United States marines and 1,250 French troops to protect areas of the Lebanese capital. Marine officers said the Americans would probably start withdrawing to ships offshore today and complete the pullout in about a week. (Page A1, Col. 6.) The possibility that U.N. troops who have been stationed in southern Lebanon since 1978 will be sent to Beirut to replace the departing Western troops seems unlikely now, according to United Nations officials. (A1:4-5.)

title: BRIEFING
description: Homey Tradition

title: LEONARDO'S REFUSAL TO SERVE 'MURDEROUS ENDS'
description: To the Editor:

title: Satellite Service Bid
description: The TRT Telecommunications Corporation said it had asked the Federal Communications Commission for permission to offer a trans- Atlantic satellite service.

title: Response to Levi Offer
description: Levi Strauss & Company said 11.2 million shares had been tendered under its offer to buy at least four million shares at $39 each. The apparel maker said it would buy four million shares and, following the waiting period, it might buy two million more in the open market. Levi Strauss closed Friday at $36, up 25 cents.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article Saturday incorrectly identified the Federal district judge who ruled that legal defense funds had been unconstitutionally excluded from a fund-raising drive. The judge was Joyce Hens Green.

title: OPERA: PREMIERE OF 'CHERUBIN' AT CARNEGIE HALL
description: CURIOUS are the ways of the Zeitgeist, or perhaps we should say ''l'esprit du temps.'' For decades, the operas of Jules Massenet have languished on the outskirts of the international repertory and have been slighted even in France, condemned by a modernist spirit as somehow too sinfully pleasurable, too aromatically melodious, for truly

title: The Secret Pregnancy
description: Denise Jackson led her Indiana University basketball team to a Big Ten co-championship and a strong showing in the 1983 National Collegiate Athletic Association tournament. But few knew that she had accomplished all that while she was pregnant.

title: ANDREA LEAND WINS
description: Andrea Leand, who dropped out of Princeton two years ago to play professional tennis, posted the first upset in the United States Women's Indoor tennis championships today when she eliminated Barbara Potter, 6-3, 6-3, in 38 minutes.

title: PUNCHING WALL WON'T COST ALEXANDER
description: Doyle Alexander, who didn't have much pitching luck in his recent term with the Yankees, continues to have good financial fortune against them.

title: Senator, in Soviet, Finds 'New Tone' on Arms
description: A United States Senator held talks with Soviet officials today on President Reagan's arms-reduction proposal and said afterward that he sensed a ''new tone'' on the Soviet side and a willingness to deal with arms-control questions.

title: PUERTO RICO FINDS WATER IS VICTIM OF DEVELOPMENT
description: When light manufacturing began to come to farm towns like this one, 25 years ago, the impoverished residents thought better times were ahead.

title: I.M.F. Funds Going to Brazil
description: Brazil will get a $390 million portion of an International Monetary Fund loan ''automatically'' on March 15 and will suspend currency controls two weeks later, the president of the central bank said.

title: CLOUDS GATHERING OVER UNTROUBLED WEST SALVADOR
description: A motorist driving through eastern El Salvador has the eerie feeling that it has been evacuated.

title: Imperial's Chief Pursues A Long-Term Strategy
description: Geoffrey Kent has made giant strides in breathing life into Imperial Group P.L.C. since becoming chairman and chief executive of the tobacco and foods giant in July 1981. The fiscal year 1983 saw an 84 percent profit increase over two years. Even the Howard Johnson restaurant and hotel chain, an embarrassingly poor investment at its 1980 price of $630 million, finally shows signs of becoming a positive contributor.

title: FLAG-WAVING AT OLYMPICS
description: The opening and closing days of the Winter

title: Kaufman Appointment
description: Michael G. Carberry, 42-year-old former employee of Wells, Rich, Greene in New York, has been named president and chief operating officer of Henry J. Kaufman & Associates in Washington.

title: CONGRESSMEN SAYS PROBLEM AT NUCLEAR PLANT WAS KNOWN
description: Nineteen months before a critical cooling system failed at the Browns Ferry Nuclear Power Station in Decatur, Ala., a safety study had identified that system as a ''weak link,'' a Massachusetts Congressman asserted yesterday.

title: Debt Issues
description: * Commonwealth Oil Refining Co., San Antonio, is extending its offer for three classes of outstanding debentures until March 16.

title: The New South America
description: While the United States remains fixated on the problems of bringing democracy to the tiny nations of Central America, the vast continent of South America is, mostly on its own, taking giant strides in that direction. In doing so, it defies the conventional wisdom that economic hardship inspires authoritarianism.

title: Addenda
description: Peter Hahn & Associates is a new advertising agency in Armonk, N.Y.

title: 'MAYOR' IS TOP SELLER, AND KOCH IS ECSTATIC
description: The question has changed. The man who made the phrase ''How'm I doing?'' famous has a new passion.

title: THE OLD ORDER HANGS ON-BUT WATCH GORBACHEV
description: At Yuri V. Andropov's funeral, those who were closely watching his successor, Konstantin U. Chernenko, could not miss his obvious satisfaction at having achieved his life's ambition and dream. Leonid I. Brezhnev's protege already had lost out once in the contest for the General Secretaryship of the Communist Party.

title: DR. EMANUEL MESSINGER
description: Dr. Emanuel Messinger, former director of the psychiatric clinic of the New York State Supreme Court, died Sunday of complications from a stroke at the Veterans Administration Hospital in Northport, L.I. He was 77 years old and lived on Barbados.

title: Service for Arthur Elwood
description: A memorial mass for Arthur H. Elwood, a makeup editor at The New York Times and a former associate news editor at The New York Herald Tribune, will be offered at 11 A.M. March 6 at St. Vincent Ferrer Roman Catholic Church, 66th Street and Lexington Avenue. Mr. Elwood died on Feb. 10 while on vacation in Florida.

title: DAY BY DAY: MORE SHOPPERS THAN PARADERS
description: The February gray was broken briefly yesterday by a parade up Fifth Avenue.

title: No Headline
description: Network Reports Hurt, Iowa Democrat Says

title: THE EMPLOYEE BID TO ACQUIRE CONRAIL
description: The Federal Government in recent months has stepped up its efforts to sell its 85 percent stake in the Consolidated Rail Corporation, the nation's sixth-biggest railroad in terms of trackage and the most important freight carrier in the Northeast.

title: PROBLEMS HALT LAYING OF PIPE AT L.I.R.R. PROJECT
description: Mechanical problems have halted the laying of plastic pipe at the $162 million Long Island Rail Road yard being built on the West Side of Manhattan, south of the new Convention Center.

title: SCOUTING
description: Globetrotters Are Nominated

title: Continental In Sydney
description: The Transport Workers Union has defied a court injunction and banned the servicing of Continental Air Lines planes at Sydney Airport. A union spokesman said the action, which took effect Sunday, would stop Continental's Sydney flights.

title: Domenici to Seek 3d Term
description: Senator Pete V. Domenici, chairman of the Budget Committee, announced today that he would seek a third term.

title: FREE TRADE IMPETUS IN CANADA
description: More than 20 years ago, Robert Thompson, a member of Parliament from Red Deer, Alberta, summed up the love-hate feelings Canadians have for their southern neighbors: ''The Americans are our best friends, whether we like it or not.''

title: THOSE COMPUTER MATCHMAKERS
description: ADVERTISEMENTS extolling compatibility are making computer magazines look more like sponsors of dating services than technical journals. Everybody's electronic marvel is compatible with someone else's, or so they claim.

title: COMPANY NEWS
description: * Harris Corp. of Melbourne, Fla., said it signed an agreement with Execucom Systems Inc., Austin, Tex., to market Execucom software products for computers.

title: AND NOW, DOVIDJENJA, SARAJEVO
description: SARAJEVO, Yugoslavia

title: Mahres Get Phone Call
description: Each of the United States' three previous gold-medal winners at the Winter Olympics in Sarajevo had received a congratulatory phone call from President Reagan. But when Phil and Steve Mahre placed first and second in the slalom race Sunday, no phone call followed.

title: STUDENTS' COMPUTER TAMPERING 'SNOWBALLED'
description: ''It started out as a gag and then it snowballed,'' said the head of security for Gompers Secondary School in San Diego, where several students tapped into the school's computer system.

title: Macmillan Chooses Title
description: Former Prime Minister Harold Macmillan, who accepted a peerage on his 90th birthday, is to take the title of Earl of Stockton, after the town in northeast England he first represented in Parliament. The first Earl of Stockton will be introduced into the House of Lords, Parliament's upper chamber, on Feb. 29.

title: REAGAN ATTACKS RIVALS, DRAWING CHEERS IN IOWA
description: In an acknowledged attempt to upstage Democratic Presidential caucuses in Iowa tonight, President Reagan toured the site of his early radio announcing career today and drew rousing cheers as he assailed the Democrats as catering to special interests and lacking the ''values, judgment and courage'' to govern.

title: Rolm Bid for Shares
description: The Rolm Corporation, a supplier of digital business communications systems, is offering to purchase three million of its shares at $41 each, starting today.

title: Playboy Chief Of Operations
description: Christie Hefner, the 31-year-old president of Playboy Enterprises Inc., was named chief operating officer of the company on Friday by her father, Hugh M. Hefner, Playboy's chairman and chief executive. The announcement of Miss Hefner's promotion was part of a restructuring of top-level management at the publishing and entertainment company. The company said two top officials, Marvin Huston, 51, executive vice president, and Stephen Silverstein, 35, senior vice president and chief financial officer, would be leaving the company to pursue separate business interests.

title: STAR MAY CAUSE EXTINCTIONS ON EARTH
description: Two groups of scientists say the sun has a companion star that, at regular intervals of about 28 million years, invades the cloud of comets surrounding the solar system and sends a billion of them flying in all directions, destroying much of the life on earth.

title: Market Place; Some Brokers Turning Dour
description: M ANY brokerage firms are keeping a stiff upper lip these days in issuing advice on the stock market. Their hope is that equity prices, after tumbling since early January, will somehow recover to bring back the bull market that has all but vanished.

title: Deere Official at Cornell
description: Curtis W. Tarr, vice president for management development at Deere & Company, the farm equipment manufacturer, has been named dean of the Cornell University School of Management. Mr. Tarr, who is 59 years old, succeeds David A. Thomas, who is retiring after 31 years at Cornell. From 1963 to 1969, Mr. Tarr was president of Lawrence University in Appleton, Wis. He received his bachelor's and Ph.D. degrees at Stanford, and an M.B.A. at Harvard.

title: ROLE IN BEIRUT IS CALLED UNLIKELY FOR U.N. FORCE IN SOUTH LEBANON
description: The possibility that United Nations troops stationed in southern Lebanon will be sent to Beirut seems unlikely at this time, according to United Nations officials here.

title: Nixdorf Plans To Go Public
description: Nixdorf Computer, one of West Germany's few high-technology companies, announced today that it plans to go public. The new listing for the 32-year-old company, due in May, would be the largest in West German history, with a 20 percent stake in the company offered initially and up to 50 percent registered for trading later.

title: A DIRECTOR WITH AUTHENTICITY
description: For the first play he ever directed, back in 1970, Gerald Gutierrez of Brooklyn's Marine Park community was already working with talent. Kevin Kline and Patty LuPone were the leads, playing Adam and Eve.

title: STATES JOIN CITIES TO SUE FOR MORE POWER
description: This city, as much as any, could qualify as one of what some urban observers call the emerging city-states of the Southwest: sprawling, growing metropolitan areas of diverse population with an entrepreneurial spirit that breeds self-assurance.

title: Arthur Hiltebrant, 91, Dead; Ex-Bethlehem Steel Official
description: Arthur Hiltebrant, former head of the Eastern ship repair district of Bethlehem Steel, died Thursday at Nyack (N.Y.) Hospital.

title: TALKS CONTINUING IN HAWAIIIN PUBLIC EMPLOYEES DISPUTE
description: Union leaders said today they were pessimistic about the chances of avoiding a statewide walkout Wednesday by 40,000 public employees ranging from college professors to garbage collectors.

title: Dear Deprived Hoteliers
description: We read in the paper that a bunch of you toured the Apple last weekend and thought everything was swell. A man from England bragged about the hash browns served him for breakfast, and a Scot thought it was cute when a waitress called his wife ''honey.''

title: Pilots Search McKinley For Japanese Climber
description: Pilots took advantage of clear skies today to look for the overdue Japanese adventurer Naomi Uemura, the first person to climb to the top of Mount McKinley alone in winter.

title: Venezuela Austerity Program
description: Venezuela plans to realign its currency exchange rate system, raise domestic fuel prices by 20 percent and cut the earnings of highly paid public sector executives under an austerity program to be announced this week, President Jaime Lusinchi said.

title: Yankee Pitchers at Bat
description: Yankee pitchers won't hit in games during the season, but they spent nearly an hour hitting today and it was the highlight of their spring training. Bob Shirley, John Montefusco and Shane Rawley were especially happy because they hit home runs.

title: CONCERT: ASHKENAZY
description: WE have been watching the young conducting career of Vladimir Ashkenazy through his recordings with the Philharmonia Orchestra for London Records. Sunday night, Mr. Ashkenazy and the orchestra gave us a first-hand progress report with the first of two New York concerts, this one at Avery Fisher Hall.

title: Chess: Two Americans Hold Lead In Tournament in Reykjavik
description: Lev Alburt, a 38-year-old New York grandmaster, and Nick DeFirmian, a 26-year-old Oakland, Calif., international master, held the lead with perfect scores after three rounds of the 11th Reykjavik International Tournament.

title: CHILDREN OF THE DISAPPEARED: ARGENTINE DOCTORS FIND A SYNDROME OF PAIN
description: Seven-year old Facundo Guerra has a persistent nightmare. A huge bird is attacking and killing everyone in sight except children. The screeching bird then tries to claw through Facundo's bedroom window for him. His mother slams the window shut just in time, chopping off one of the bird's fingers.

title: The Calendar
description: Tuesday

title: O.A.U. Chief Tackles Western Sahara Issue
description: The chairman of the Organization of African Unity, Lieut. Col. Mengistu Haile Mariam of Ethiopia, has undertaken a new effort to break a deadlock in the conflict over Western Sahara, diplomats said today.

title: 2 FOREIGN PRIESTS FACE TRIAL WITH 7 FILIPINOS IN KILLING OF 5
description: Two foreign priests, a Filipino priest and six Roman Catholic lay workers are scheduled to go on trial this week for the murders of a Mayor and four of his aides in the central Philippines.

title: Old Photos of Shaw Are Found in Minsk
description: Workers repairing an old building in Minsk have discovered 73 photographs of George Bernard Shaw, Tass, the official Soviet press agency, reported today.

title: GATT Meeting Set on Steel
description: The Reagan Administration has made an unusual request for a special meeting of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade in a final attempt to prevent European retaliation in a trans- Atlantic dispute over steel imports, a GATT spokesman said today.

title: DOCTORS ON COAST WARN THAT BITE OF 'HARMLESS' PET SNAKE CAN BE DEADLY
description: AMAN who had difficulty dislodging a pet snake after it bit him nearly died of the bite, causing doctors to warn that snakes should not be considered harmless until proved so.

title: 4 FACING FRAUD TRIAL IN PLAN FOR MERGING UNIONS ON THE COAST
description: More than a year ago Allen M. Dorfman, a longtime associate of organized crime figures, was indicted here along with two business associates and two local culinary union officials for attempting to defraud the union.

title: SANDINO'S LEGACY
description: Today, the Nicaraguan revolution commemorates the 50th anniversary of the assassination of its founding father, Augusto Cesar Sandino. International attention will be focused on the Sandinistas' expected announcement of an electoral schedule for 1985 and on whether or not this satisfies domestic critics and the Reagan Administration, which for the past three years has been escalating United States pressure against Nicaragua. But North Americans should also take the time to think about the implications of Sandino's story. Both in life and in death, he serves as a warning against the present course of United States policy in Nicaragua.

title: ARGENTINE MILITARY IS CALLED UNEASY
description: Weeks of prosecutions and public denunciations of the military's human rights abuses have produced an uneasy mood in the armed forces, according to officers as well as civilians close to the institution.

title: SCOUTING
description: Playing It Safe

title: COAST UTILITY'S WRITEOFF ON NUCLEAR PLANT
description: The Pacific Power and Light Company, trying to extract itself from its involvement in northwest nuclear plants that have been closed or are undergoing a construction slowdown, said today that it wrote off $228 million in 1983.

title: TOP EASTERN COLLEGES REPORT UNUSUAL RISE IN APPLICATIONS
description: Despite a decline in the number of students graduating from high school and a rise in costs to students to almost $15,000 a year, applications to private colleges in the Northeast are reaching record proportions, especially at the most highly selective institutions.

title: RESIDENTS OF CLOGGED EAST SIDE AREA BATTLE AGAINST INFLUX
description: A school bus lumbered eastward, out of the crawl of narrow Lexington Avenue into narrower 59th Street. Parting the sea of pedestrians who seem to shuttle between Bloomingdale's and Alexander's, it stalled athwart the crosswalk, blocked by a crosstown bus trying to squeeze past a motorboat on a trailer.

title: 1,000 BLACK WORKERS TO SHARE $15 MILLION AWARD
description: Illinois and Cook County will pay more than $15 million to hundreds of black current or former welfare workers in an award announced today.

title: Helping the Homeless
description: THERE they were, the stars of television, movies and the theater, milling around Bonwit Teller's expensive Tourneau watch counter last week, smiling for the photographers, being polite to reporters, drawing crowds of curious shoppers and tin-cupping for the city's thousands of homeless and hungry women.

title: OLYMPIANS MAKING THEIR N.H.L. DEBUTS
description: The Islanders are waiting for Pat LaFontaine and Pat Flatley. The Rangers are waiting for James Patrick.

title: SCOUTING
description: Making a Switch

title: Economic Calendar
description: Listed below are the scheduled release dates for major economic indicators to be released this week.

title: WORK FIRST PRESENTED IN 1905
description: ''Cherubin'' was the 19th of Jules Massenet's 29 surviving operas, and counts as one of the most obscure of the lot; Sunday night's Carnegie Hall performance apparently marked its American premiere.

title: A MIXED U.S. OLYMPIC PERFORMANCE
description: It was Sunday afternoon and Phil and Steve Mahre had just completed a one-two sweep of the men's slalom race.

title: Dividend Meetings for Monday's paper/McCue/Fin News
description: Dividend Meetings

title: DESPITE ITS ANOMALIES, NEW HAMPSHIRE IS A KEY CANDIDATE PROVING GROUND
description: With the Iowa Democratic caucuses completed tonight, national attention is turning to New Hampshire and its often unpredictable but critically important primary, set for Feb. 28.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: SMART WOMEN. By Judy Blume. 316 pages. G. P. Putnam's Sons. $15.95.

title: Red Brigades Threaten Another U.S. Diplomat
description: Letters sent to Italian news organizations purporting to come from Red Brigades guerrillas today threatened the life of another United States diplomat in the aftermath of last week's killing of Leamon R. Hunt, director general of the multinational force in Egypt's Sinai Peninsula.

title: Bridge: Danger May Seem Obvious If One Can See All the Cards
description: There are some plays that are relatively easy to see with all four hands in view, but fiendishly difficult in practice because a lurking danger is not apparent.

title: Nuclear Cutback
description: The Westinghouse Electric Corporation said it would close its Offshore Power Systems operation by Sept. 1.

title: INMATE KILLED IN ESCAPE BID IS LINKED TO SINDONA
description: An inmate who was killed while trying to escape from the Metropolitan Correctional Center in lower Manhattan Sunday night had been scheduled to appear at an extradition hearing today with Michele Sindona, the Italian financier.

title: VIGOR SEEN AGAIN FOR ECONOMY
description: Only a month ago, there was a toning down of economic forecasts as a stream of data seemed to suggest that the economy was slowing. Now the emphasis is being reversed.

title: Teen-Ager Deported By Mistake Is Found
description: A 15-year-old Santa Ana boy mistakenly deported to Mexico five days ago was found today wandering outside the downtown San Diego police station, officers said. Police Officer Dennis Doremus said a ''citizen contacted us and told us he was out there on Harbor Drive across from the police station.''

title: G.M. to Acquire Terex
description: The General Motors Corporation plans to acquire the business of Terex Ltd. of Scotland, which has been in receivership since last November. G.M. said today that that it expected to complete the acquisition this month. Terms were not disclosed.

title: MUNITIONS MAKERS
description: To the Editor:

title: SEEDLINGS DOT NEPAL'S ONCE-BARREN SLOPES AS COUNTRY BATTLES FOREST CRISIS
description: THE Nepali woman smiled widely, the gold rings in her ears and nose flashing in the afternoon sun, as the foreigners crossing her path began to pepper her with questions. Was she aware that she could obtain free tree seedlings from the nearby nursery? ''Yes,'' she replied, ''in fact, my family took about 70 seedlings - some fruit trees, many for fodder and some for firewood.''

title: FRENCH TRUCKERS END MANY BLOCKADES
description: Truckers withdrew more than half their road blockades throughout France today as political tension declined, reducing inconvenience for travelers.

title: SOME EXPERTS SAY EDB RISK IS SMALL
description: The pesticide EDB, at the levels currently being found in foods, poses little immediate risk to consumers, according to several leading scientists and regulators.

title: Comings and Goings
description: The New Jersey Generals traded Steve Doolittle , a reserve linebacker, to San Antonio for a future draft choice. The Generals made their final squad cuts yesterday but witheld announcing them until today while they continue to try to trade. . . . The New Orleans Breakers announced that the tight end Dan Ross would join them today.

title: POLL FINDS ORGANIZATION LED TO MONDALE VICTORY
description: Walter F. Mondale's sweeping victory in the Iowa Democratic caucuses was a triumph of organization, and his support came mainly from middle-aged and older voters, according to a New York Times/CBS News poll of caucus participants.

title: DESPITE ITS FAME, LAKE PLACID IS QUIET IN WINTER
description: Between plains of snow carved by swirling winds, a sawhorse blocks the driveway of a motel at the foot of Whiteface Mountain.

title: 10 in Wisconsin Primary Seek to Succeed Zablocki
description: Six Democrats and four Republicans seek their party's nominations Tuesday for the Congressional seat held for 35 years by Clement Zablocki, the Democrat who headed the House Foreign Affairs Committee. Mr. Zablocki died Dec. 3.

title: 3 Hurt as Ohio Bridge Falls
description: The 300-foot Oak Street Bridge, which carries traffic over Lincoln Park on Youngstown's east side, collapsed about 2:15 this afternoon, sending a tractor-trailer and a car hurtling about 100 feet into a small ravine and injuring their three occupants.

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL

title: America in Hock to the World
description: This year Americans will probably buy $100 billion more goods and services from abroad than they sell. As a result, the United States will soon become a net debtor, for the first time since World War I owing more to foreigners than they owe us.

title: Article 261058 -- No Title
description: The Treasury market has not fully digested $16.25 billion of notes and bonds auctioned earlier this month, but the Government's need for cash to finance the budget deficit is great enough that the Treasury is proceeding tomorrow with the regular monthly auction of new two-year notes.

title: CABLE-TV FIGHT FOR MANHATTAN
description: The message in the full-page advertisements in New York newspapers earlier this month was clear and direct: '' 'Flashdance.' That's what Time Inc.'s Manhattan Cable subscribers will be missing, because your cable system doesn't offer Showtime, the 24-hour total entertainment channel, or The Movie Channel, the 24-hour all-movie service.''

title: STATEN I. AND JAY GAIN SEMIFINALS
description: Staten Island raced to a big early lead, then coasted to a 98-65 victory over City College yesterday afternoon as it opened its defense of the City University of New York basketball championship.

title: 100 Jackson Supporters Busy in New England
description: More than 100 supporters of the Rev. Jesse Jackson climbed into buses today for a daylong campaign swing through southern New Hampshire.

title: DEVIL'S BAG TAKES FLAMING PREP
description: Devil's Bag, whose early speed last year made him one of the great 2-year-olds ever to race, today showed the maturity and late speed that may make him as great a 3-year-old by coming from off the pace to win the Flamingo Prep Stakes at Hialeah Park.

title: Japan's View Of Yen's Rate
description: The swift recovery of the United States economy and the strength of the dollar are causing the low exchange rate for the yen, the Japanese ambassador to the United States said today.

The notes are offered continuously by G.M.A.C., Merrill Lynch Capital Markets and Salomon Brothers. Proceeds would be used to buy receivables or repay other debt, the company said.

description: The clear highlight of Melville Brown's Sunday evening piano recital at the Abraham Goodman House was a panoramically conceived and, for the most part, skillfully executed performance of the Sonata No. 3 in F minor (Op. 5) by Johannes Brahms.

description: President Reagan's news conference tonight will be broadcast live at 8 P.M., Eastern standard time, on the CBS, NBC and ABC television networks, and on CNN, the Cable News Network.

A nacelle is the housing that encloses an aircraft engine. The equipment will be installed on the Gulfstream IV executive jet and the Fokker 100 medium-range passenger transport.

description: One year after he joined the Mets as a shy rookie, Darryl Strawberry reported early for spring training today and said: ''If things go the way they did last year on this club, I'll have to speak out.''

description: The Honda Motor Company said today that it would increase production of motorcycles by 70 percent this year at its factory in Marysville, Ohio. The company said it would produce about 70,000 motorcycles with engines of at least 1,000-cubic-centimeter displacement at the plant, compared with 41,000 in 1983.

description: Joseph J. Sanchez is in an unusual position for an American automobile executive these days. While most of his colleagues have to justify what went wrong with the domestic auto industry, the manager of Oldsmobile is busy explaining why things are so good.

title: WEDNESDAY, FEBRUARY 22, 1984 International
description: Emergency arms aid for El Salvador in advance of Congressional approval is being seriously considered by the Reagan Administration, according to Secretary of State George P. Shultz. (Page A1, Column 6.) Nicaraguan elections on Nov. 4 were scheduled by the Government. The date, which is earlier than Managua previously announced, is two days before the United States Presidential election. (A3:4-6.)

Proceeds would be used to finance banking and non- banking subsidiaries.

description: Alexander B. Adams, a conservationist, author and former chairman of the Nature Conservancy in Washington, died of an acute abdominal infection Sunday at the Norwalk (Conn.) Hospital. He was 66 years old and lived in Westport, Conn.

description: b-Net loss.

The company is listed on the Pacific, Boston, Midwest, and Philadelphia stock exchanges.

title: Sabres Defeat Flyers by 5-4
description: Phil Housley's tip-in of a rebound at 4:09 of overtime gave the Buffalo Sabres a 5-4 triumph over the Philadelphia Flyers tonight and extended their victory streak through seven games. They have won 13 of their last 14 road games.

title: Spring Signals
description: New Yorkers have their own ways of telling when spring is en route, and the signals have nothing to do with snowdrops and cardinals. What they look for are chives at the supermarket, forsythia at the florist's and shad roe at the fishmonger's.

title: Catherine Barrett, 80, Dies; Led National School Group
description: Catherine Barrett, former president of the National Education Association, died Saturday at Hamot Medical Center, Erie, Pa., after a long illness. She was 80 years old and lived most of her life in Syracuse, N.Y.

description: A 36-year-old man was sentenced yesterday to 25 years to life in prison for robbing a woman of $14, the Bronx District Attorney's office said.

description: Deere & Company, citing increased efficiencies and cost reductions, yesterday reported a profit of $2 million, or 3 cents a share, in its first fiscal quarter, compared with a loss of $28.5 million a year earlier.

description: The year-ago share earnings reflect 3-for-2 stock split paid Feb. 15, 1984.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE;
description: LAFF RIOT As art exhibitions go, the one at Master Eagle Gallery, 40 West 25th Street (691-1660), through March 16 is a thoroughly laughable one. Of course it's intended to be, because it is ''Cartoon '84'' by members of the Cartoonists Association. On the walls are 216 cartoons by more than 50 masters of the art whose work has tickled readers of publications that run from The New Yorker and Playboy to Seventeen and The Saturday Review.

title: ALFONSIN'S DIFFICULT ROAD TO DEMOCRACY
description: President Raul Alfonsin's first 10 weeks in office have been more than auspicious. But his rise to power is only the first step on a difficult path toward democracy in Argentina. In order to attain democracy, several major obstacles will have to be overcome.

description: To the Editor:

description: Poor patients without Medicaid coverage will now be billed at city-run hospitals based on what they can afford, no matter how high their charges actually are, city officials said yesterday.

description: The Marine contingent in Beirut today formally started its pullback to United States Sixth Fleet vessels offshore.

description: With a chuckle and a shrug of his shoulders, Paul Brown admitted that in recent months he had become much keener on the idea of miracles.

description: The worst moment of the Winter Olympics occurred in Minneapolis. Only 50 people, mostly relatives, turned up Monday to greet the returning American hockey team. No banners or bands. Our boys had lost, which was somehow felt to be a disgrace. They let down flag and country - and embarrassed a great American network bent on turning Olympic gold into prime-time lucre.

description: It was called Arf 'n' Arf - a soft drink for dogs that was sold in six-packs.

description: ''Where Is Franklin Jacobs?'' That was a headline in a local newspaper a couple of years ago.

title: Times Pressroom Foreman Named Director of Printing
description: Dominick Marsicano, general foreman of The New York Times pressrooms in Manhattan and Carlstadt, N.J., has been named director of printing for the newspaper and will add plate making and paper handling to his responsibilities.

title: BATTLING TO BE NO. 1 IN RADIO
description: For more than three years, 106.7 on the FM dial in New York was WKHK, one of the city's two stations featuring country-and-western music - a sound it illustrated by showing cowboy boots in place of K's as its call letters. But late last month, WKHK became WLTW. The LT stands for light music, and that is what - to the initial consternation of WKHK's nearly eight million listeners and the anxious hopes of the station's owners - is now playing on 106.7.

title: REPORT CRITICIZES RADIO FREE EUROPE
description: A Senate Democratic staff report says the managers of Radio Free Europe and Radio Liberty have so weakened the controls over program content that commentators hostile to the United States are allowed to broadcast to Soviet bloc audiences.

title: CHARTER TO SPIN OFF INSURANCE UNIT
description: The Charter Company announced yesterday that it would spin off its insurance subsidiary to stockholders in an attempt to reduce investor confusion about its two businesses.

title: ISRAEL BOMBS 4 SITES IN LEBANON AND PATROLS PART WAY TO CAPITAL
description: Israeli planes bombed targets in the mountains east of Beirut today, and Israeli officials announced that a patrol of armored vehicles had advanced nearly half the distance from the Israeli line to the capital before withdrawing.

description: It's the busy season for our old friend Conventional Wisdom, but he didn't hesitate when we called for advice on our way to the Iowa caucuses.

title: NEW VIDEO MOBILITY
description: With videotaping fast replacing home movies as a popular hobby, the electronics industry is exploring different ways to make portable video equipment lighter and smaller. Hard on the heels of Kodak's entry into the video field with a new, incompatible 8-millimeter format intended to shrink the size and weight of portable video gear are RCA and Konica - taking quite a different approach to video mobility.

title: PEERING DOWN THE U.S. MAIL ROUTE
description: William F. Bolger, the nation's 65th Postmaster General in a line that began with Benjamin Franklin, grimaced slightly as a visitor recalled a recent episode in which even Senator Bob Dole poked fun at the United States Postal Service.

title: Delay on the Waterfront
description: Technology has ravaged New York City's waterfront. The disintegration of rail networks, the growth of trailer-trucks and the containerization of cargo have left city planners with few clear hints of how to use the harbor. But taking time for reflection may also mean losing opportunities to save jobs. Decisions are needed.

title: SIGMA-ALDRICH CORP reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
Pitcher Gets Chance to Adjust
description: In his second game in the major leagues last season, Ray Fontenot stymied the Kansas City Royals on one earned run and five hits in six and one-third innings and gained his first major league victory. Twelve days later, the Yankees' left-hander pitched against the Royals again, but they battered him for five earned runs and nine hits in four and one- third innings.

title: Eagle-I.B.M. Settlement
description: Eagle Computer Inc., which makes a personal computer compatible with those made by the International Business Machines Corporation, said yesterday that it had agreed to a permanent injunction that ends a copyright infringement suit brought by I.B.M.

description: Enstar Indonesia is a unit of Enstar Corp. which holds the outstanding common shares.

Miss Hunter, accompanied by the alert pianist Brian Connelly, chose her material entirely from the repertory of our century, offering fluent performances of music by composers as diverse as Camille Saint-Sa"ens, Jacques Ibert, John A. Lennon, and Ross Lee Finney.

Beverly Sills, the company's general director, made the announcement yesterday, the 40th anniversary of the City Opera's first performance.

description: The Supreme Court ruled unanimously today that Connecticut could not ban double- trailer trucks from its highways.

description: The Scene: The Downtown Restaurant

description: THE wine business, as well as wine enthusiasts, is concerned about an antidrinking campaign that seems to be gathering a momentum unparalleled since the end of Prohibition half a century ago.

description: State Senator Gerald D. Kleczka was apparently nominated today in a Democratic Party primary for a special election April 3 to fill the Congressional seat left vacant by the death of Representative Clement J. Zablocki last December.

description: A convicted burglar with a record of 21 arrests since 1975 was sentenced today to a maximum prison term of 7 1/2 to 15 years.

title: CORRECTION
description: A Jerusalem dispatch Jan. 25 on the visit of Chancellor Helmut Kohl to the Yad Vashem memorial carried an inappropriate translation of a biblical quotation he inscribed in German in the register. As it appears in the standard German Bible - rather than the King James Version - it should have read, ''Even thus, He draws thee out of the jaws of anguish, and sets thee in a comfortable place where there is no further oppression.''

description: * Casio Computer Co., London, is offering $80 million of five-year bonds, with equity-purchase warrants, through Daiwa Europe Ltd.

description: Secretary of State George P. Shultz said today that the Reagan Administration is considering giving El Salvador emergency military aid, without waiting for Congress to act, so its army can maintain pressure on the insurgents in the coming election period.

title: CONGRESSMEN RETURNING TO CAPITAL TELL OF VOTER CONCERN ON DEFICIT
description: Legislators from both parties said today that voters in their home districts seemed increasingly worried about rising budget deficits, which threaten to approach $200 billion in this fiscal year.

title: Jumblat Plans U.S. Visit
description: The State Department said today that Walid Jumblat, Lebanon's Druse leader, had applied for a visa to visit the United States next month. A spokesman at the National Press Club said he was scheduled to speak to the group on March 7.

title: MIKHAIL A. SHOLOKHOV, SOVIET AUTHOR, IS DEAD
description: Mikhail A. Sholokhov, author of ''And Quiet Flows the Don'' and other works that won him the Nobel Prize for Literature in 1965, died today in a Cossack village in southern Russia, an official announcement said. He was 78 years old.

title: AVANT-GARDE: 2 COMPOSERS
description: THE concert presented Sunday night at the Kitchen was a duel of sorts. On one side of intermission was Remko Scha, a composer who is visiting professor of artificial intelligence at the University of Amsterdam, who is interested in ''the spontaneous emergence of musical and visual form'' out of natural and mechanical systems.

title: BILL MOYERS STUDIES OLD NEWSREELS
description: THERE are Americans in their 20's who have never seen a newsreel, though for more than 50 years newsreels, imperfect, often frivolous, even fraudulent, shaped our Weltanschauung, defined our purpose and told us who we were. Fashion shows, flagpole sitters and poodles wearing funny hats were big in newsreels; so were floods, fires and the London blitz. Newsreels are the subject of ''The Reel World of News,'' a first-rate segment in the first-rate series ''A Walk Through the 20th Century With Bill Moyers,'' on Channel 13 at 8 o'clock tonight.

title: 'A RACE' BY PING CHONG
description: ON the surface, the ceremony might be recognizable to parents of high school seniors, but, from the very first, it is clear that something outlandish is afoot. This is graduation day in Ping Chong country, perhaps circa 2084, and it is a tantalizing futuristic voyage. The play, a performance piece at La Mama Annex, is called ''A Race,'' and, as is customary with this theatrical visionary, the title has a brace of possible meanings: it could refer to a tribe of unearthly creatures, a collective drive toward a rite of passage or the course of life itself.

title: THE RE-ELECTION VALUE OF AN ARMS INITIATIVE
description: President Reagan's chances of combining good policy and good politics with progress on strategic arms control during his Presidential campaign are seriously on the wane. Yet even at this late date there may still be an opportunity to break the impasse and, not incidentally, help the President's re-election efforts. His own commitment to arms control may be greater than is commonly perceived, and so may be Moscow's. If that is the case, he can only help himself by now moving forward toward serious negotiations.

title: OPERA: 'ARABELLA' IN SEASON'S DEBUT AT THE MET
description: RICHARD STRAUSS'S opera ''Arabella,'' his last collaboration with the poet Hugo von Hofmannsthal, is a curious hybrid - part operetta, part murky dalliance with sexual role-switching, part melodrama and part folk ritual. But at its frequent best it can be magical, and the Metropolitan Opera's 1983 production, which rejoined the repertory Monday night, makes about as good a case for it as could be made today.

A few nights later, Miss Neidish appeared in an East Side town house wearing a starched white apron and serving canapes to people she went to college with. As she explains, ''When you're a dancer, that's just what you do between jobs.''

description: A 40-year-old New York City police officer, carrying a copy of the Walt Disney film ''Snow White and the Seven Dwarfs,'' was arrested by F.B.I. agents at Newark International Airport yesterday on charges of illegally duplicating and distributing copyrighted material, a police spokesman said.

title: '3 THINGS THAT WE MUST DO TOGETHER'

title: Woodley a Steeler
description: With Terry Bradshaw's future still uncertain and with no experienced backup, the Pittsburgh Steelers had been looking for a seasoned quarterback. Yesterday they got one, David Woodley, who led the Miami Dolphins to the Super Bowl in January 1983, then lost his starting job last season to the rookie Dan Marino. To get him, Pittsburgh sent Miami a third-round choice in the May draft, the 79th selection over all, and a conditional third-round choice in 1985 that could be higher if Woodley plays extensively next season.

description: Doyle Alexander , who had seven consecutive victories, a club record, at the end of the last American League season, was missing yesterday at the Toronto Blue Jays' first official workout.

title: FIRE POSTSCRIPT: 2,000 STUCK IN TUNNEL
description: Two thousand Metro-North commuters were stranded for about three hours in the Park Avenue tunnel in trains without working lights or ventilation systems during the Jan. 30 derailment and fire, a spokesman for the railroad said yesterday.

title: Steel Output Up
description: Crude steel production in 29 non-Communist industrial countries rose 20.1 percent in January, to 39.4 million tons, from 32.8 million tons a year earlier, the International Iron and Steel Institute said today. The agency said crude steel output was up 7.2 percent from December, when 36.7 million tons of steel were produced.

description: Claude Hopkins, a pianist who led one of the most popular big bands to come out of Harlem in the 1930's, died Sunday at Park View Nursing Home in Riverdale, where he had been a patient for the last three years. He was 80 years old.

title: Bond-Ratings Cut For Texaco, Getty
description: Moody's Investors Service said yesterday that it had lowered its bond ratings for both Texaco Inc. and the Getty Oil Company in the wake of Texaco's successful takeover offer for Getty.

title: Israeli Budget Lists Trims
description: Israel's Finance Minister, Yigal Cohen-Orgad, introduced a $22.7 billion budget today and told Parliament that Israeli living standards would revert this year to the level of 1982 because of the need to secure foreign currency. The budget provides for Government spending cuts ranging from 7 percent to 10 percent in development and food and fuel subsidies, as well as in social and economic supports. Mr. Cohen-Orgad said the cutbacks, along with an increase in exports and a sharp decline in imports, would help reduce this year's $4.1 billion payments gap by $1 billion.

title: Scuffle in British Coal Mine
description: An crowd of about 600 miners protesting job cuts today confronted Ian MacGregor, chairman of Britain's state-run coal industry, and he fell over a fence in a scuffle. He was trying to leave the offices of Ellington coal mine here when the crowd reportedly pushed up against him. Mr. McGregor, an American, had come to the mine to make an underground visit, but the protest forced him to cancel his plans.

description: The French police said today that truckers, ignoring a Government warning, had expanded their road blockades to almost every main highway in the country.

Whether she was speaking before the National Association of Broadcasters or the House Committee on Aging, she complained about ''ageism'' in advertising and ''the negative images and stereotypes that make old people look sick and bothersome and boring.''

By the time he took the field for his first workout, he was a bit more willing to be a center fielder, but he was not too thrilled about it.

title: THEATER: 'BROKEN EGGS'
description: THE title of Eduardo Machado's new play, ''Broken Eggs,'' refers to that famous political proverb often attributed to Lenin: ''You cannot make an omelet without breaking eggs.'' The play's characters are the broken eggs - a family of upper-middle- class Cubans who lost everything when Fidel Castro's revolution forced them to flee their homeland in the early 1960's. But in ''Broken Eggs,'' which is set in Los Angeles in 1979, the family isn't doing all that badly anymore. Mr. Machado's characters have more jewelry, Lincoln Continentals, swimming pools and Valium than they know what to do with.

title: VIRGINIA HOUSE DEBATES A HOLIDAY TO HONOR ITS HEROES, OLD AND NEW
description: To its supporters, it would be something of a secular All Saints' Day: a combined celebration of the birthdays of Robert E. Lee, Thomas J. (Stonewall) Jackson and the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. It would be, they say, a chance to combine the Virginia holiday honoring the two Confederate generals with a new holiday honoring the modern hero of the civil rights movement.

description: The Supreme Court, in a victory for the Internal Revenue Service, curbed a popular tax-avoidance device today by ruling that an interest-free loan from one family member to another is subject to the Federal gift tax.

Reasonably enough, he tried to buy time with the standard device of a study commission. But it produced no useful conclusions, and his office has made no evident progress in sorting out real issues from pretenses.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE;

When Gutenberg's movable type arrived, the art of illuminated manuscripts went the way that manual typewriters seem to be going nowadays, although illuminated manuscripts lasted for 200 years after printing began.

description: -time silver polisher for Christie's Fine Art Auctioneers, he spent a workweek hand-polishing a 33-inch replica of the 1876 vase made by Tiffany and presented to William Cullen Bryant on his 80th birthday. With sponges, soft toothbrushes, a supermarket-brand silver polish and surgical cotton, Mr. Schlegel disassembled and carefully cleaned the vase, estimated to be worth $7,000, in his work space in the Christie vault.

title: CONCERT: FRED SHERRY, CELLIST, AT Y
description: ELLIOTT CARTER'S 1948 Sonata for Cello and Piano has become a sort of milestone in 20th-century cello repertory. It is a work that at once looks backward - invoking the traditional sonic and stylistic differences of the cello and piano - and forward - treating those very peculiarities as its subject matter. The cello sings; the piano percusses.

title: BANKER AND REALTY EXECUTIVE
description: Thomas Howard Quinn, a banking, insurance and real-estate executive in New York for 50 years, died Monday at Columbia Memorial Hospital in Hudson, N.Y. He was 81 years old and lived in Manhattan and in West Ghent, N.Y.

title: REP. McKENNEY IS ACCUSED OF ARAB-BOYCOTT VIOLATION

title: Consumers Power
description: The Consumers Power Company said it is seeking wage reductions for 800 union workers involved in its long-delayed $4.4 billion Midland nuclear power plant so savings can be used to hire additional workers to speed construction. A Consumers spokesman said the utility had asked the Bechtel Power Corporation, the principal contractor, to invoke a clause in its contract that gives Bechtel the option to reduce wages for the 800 affected workers by up to 10 percent. About 5,200 workers, including about 800 Consumers employees, are currently involved in the project, which is tentatively scheduled for completion by mid-1986.

title: INSECTS AND PLANTS: SIGNS AND SOLUTIONS
description: Where do plant bugs come from? Even the meticulous indoor gardener will ask this question at some time or other, for no matter how well plants are cared for, they do appear.

title: COMEDY SPECIAL STARS DELUISE WITH FRIENDS
description: DOM DeLUISE returns, tonight at 9 on ABC, for another television special with some of his friends, including Dean Martin, Telly Savalas, Zsa Zsa Gabor, Shelley Winters, Scott Baio, Rich Little, Marian Mercer and Orson Welles. An odd lot, indeed, but this edition of ''Dom DeLuise and Friends'' is far more successful than the first one several months ago.

title: POST REAFFIRMS REPORT ON JACKSON COMMENT
description: The Washington Post, which reported last week that the Rev. Jesse Jackson had used the term 'Hymies' to refer to Jews and 'Hymietown' to refer to New York, said yesterday that Mr. Jackson made the comments on Jan. 25.

title: WIDE IMPACT SEEN IN LABOR DECISION
description: Sal Valente, president of the Bildisco Manufacturing Company, says the fact that his company is still around is a testament to how well the bankruptcy system works.

title: BIG IRANIAN DRIVE CONFIRMED BY IRAQ
description: Iraq said early today that Iranian forces had begun a major drive on the southern front aimed at the Iraqi oil port of Basra.

description: A National Academy of Sciences study made public today further reduces the estimate of how much the atmosphere's protective ozone layer is being depleted by man-made gases from aerosol spray cans, refrigeration and other sources.

description: Two fugitives from a prison work gang shot and killed a retired tire dealer at a family cookout, then took his wife hostage on a five-hour drive across Tennessee before releasing her early today, the police said.

description: Year-ago results have been restated to include only Optical Coating's equity in the earnings of Applied Solar Corp. and to reclassify interest income from sales to other income.

title: U.S. SEES BIAS AT STATE POLICE ACADEMY
description: The Justice Department charged today that racist behavior by officials at the New York State Police Academy had sharply reduced the number of black and Hispanic recruits to complete the course successfully in 1981.

title: U.S. IS ORDERED TO PAY BENEFITS TO MANY IT CUT
description: A Federal appeals court today ordered Margaret M. Heckler, the Secretary of Health and Human Services, to obey, with an exception, an injunction restoring disability benefits to nearly 400,000 former Social Security recipients.

title: Olympian Again at 92
description: A 92-year-old retired court clerk who won the silver medal in the 1,500- meter run at the 1912 Olympics in Stockholm has been chosen as one of the thousands of runners who will carry the Olympic torch from New York to Los Angeles to start the 1984 Summer Games.

FINANCE/NEW ISSUES ; Two Wall Street Firms Offer Long-Term Notes
description: Wall Street securities firms are infrequent borrowers in the note and bond markets, but two major houses have announced plans to sell long- term issues in coming weeks.

title: Tip for Carl Lewis
description: If Carl Lewis is going to break Bob Beamon's 16-year-old long-jump record of 29 feet 2 1/2 inches, he'd better change his technique.

title: Bullet Hits Car, Grazes Youngster
description: A 5-year-old child riding in a car driven by his mother on West 96th Street, between Riverside Drive and West End Avenue, was grazed on the forehead yesterday morning by a bullet that pierced the rear window of the car and went out the windshield.

title: Goodyear Tires
description: The Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company said it would invest $250 million to convert its Tyler plant's production from bias-ply tires to the more popular radial tires.

description: A Saudi Arabian mediator met today with Lebanese leaders amid reports that some progress was being made toward an agreement between Lebanon and Syria for resolving the Lebanese crisis.

description: Henry M. Doebler, a lobbyist for the Long Island Lighting Company, has been dismissed, according to legislators and their aides here. Mr. Doebler is the son of Errol W. Doebler, who was the chairman of the utility in the late 1950's.

title: U.S. AND BRITAIN IN ACTOR TRADE WAR
description: THE Mark Hellinger Theater will be unexpectedly dark on March 17. The British musical ''Poppy,'' which was scheduled to open that night, has been canceled. The investment was in hand, the London notices were promising, but the producers and Actors Equity could not agree on how long the English cast could play on Broadway before being replaced by Americans.

title: Harry Carl Herman, 67, Head Of Labor Relations Company
description: Harry Carl Herman, head of a labor relations consulting company in New York City, died of a heart ailment last Friday at North Miami General Hospital. He was 67 years old and lived in Boca Raton, Fla.

title: A MAN MENACING IND RIDERS IS SLAIN
description: A man wielding a two-foot-long metal pipe that had been honed razor sharp at one end was shot and killed by a transit police officer on a Manhattan subway platform after he menaced passengers on a train, struck a conductor and attacked the officer, the authorities said yesterday.

title: WRITE IN REAGAN, DEMOCRATS ARE URGED

title: CONGRESS STUDY DISPUTES REAGAN ON DEFICIT TREND
description: The Congressional Budget Office, in its first analysis of President Reagan's budget for the fiscal year 1985, estimated today that his proposals would produce rising deficits for the next several years rather than the moderately declining trend the Administration projected.

title: Milwaukee Road
description: The Soo Line Railroad Company has bid $40 million in cash for the assets of the ailing Milwaukee Road railway. United States District Judge Thomas R. McMillen reopened the bidding earlier this year to accommodate the late Soo offer.

title: Unbeaten Stecca Captures Title
description: Loris Stecca of Italy captured the World Boxing Association superbantamweight title tonight by stopping Leonardo Cruz of the Dominican Republic, the champion, in the 12th round of a scheduled 15-rounder.

title: SPINKS TAKES LIFE IN STRIDE
description: Dennis Rappaport was talking: Subliminal motivation, 5,000 exercises for the upper stomach, 5,000 exercises for the lower stomach, 175 miles of running up mountains. Stuff like that.

description: A Senate Judiciary subcommittee today canceled its discussion of a bill that would bar Americans from renting prerecorded video cassettes unless the tape's copyright owner approved.

title: 2 Suing Golden Over Party Vote
description: The two men defeated by Borough President Howard Golden for Democratic leader of Brooklyn have asked a Federal court to invalidate Mr. Golden's selection on the ground that it resulted from a process that violated minority voting rights.

title: Man Is Acquitted In 'Death' Scheme
description: A Federal jury acquitted a Staten Island fire marshal yesterday of charges that he helped fake a friend's drowning in return for part of a $600,000 life-insurance policy.

title: COURT HEARS CHALLENGE TO POCKET VETO
description: Congress clashed with the executive branch of the Government at a court hearing today on the constitutionality of President Reagan's move last year to pocket veto a bill linking his power to give military aid to El Salvador to progress in protecting human rights there.

title: DEVILS BEATEN AS PENALTIES SPOIL RALLY
description: The Devils' excellent checking and intensity in recent games disappeared in an 8-5 loss to the Winnipeg Jets tonight at Byrne Meadowlands Arena.

title: Anne Gary Pannell Taylor; Ex-Sweetbriar College Head
description: Anne Gary Pannell Taylor, president emeritus of Sweetbriar College in Virginia, died after a long illness at Goodwin House, an Episcopal retirement home in Alexandria, Va.

title: Dr. Carter Ties Track Mark at Hialeah
description: Dr. Carter, widely hailed as the only 3-year- old who might beat Devil's Bag in the Triple Crown races this spring, gilded those hopes today by tying a track record while scoring a 17-length victory in the $23,450 Dan Chappell Handicap at Hialeah Park.

title: Chicago Utility
description: The Commonwealth Edison Company said in its annual repport that its five- year construction budget through 1988 is $5.25 billion, a decrease of $200 million from the amount budgeted for the five years through 1987.

Biogen Will Patent Interferon Product
description: Biogen said today that it would be granted the world's first major patent for a product made through gene- splicing: a form of interferon that appears useful in the treatment of colds.

title: Danish Trade Deficit
description: Preliminary figures show Denmark's trade balance swung to a deficit of $144 million in January from a surplus of $70 million a year ago.

title: TRANS-NATIONAL LEASING INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
NEW HAMPSHIRE PUBLISHER IS GONE, BUT PAPER'S FOES ARE NO BETTER OFF
description: For the moderates, the liberals and the Democrats in general who took heart three and a half years ago, thinking that The Union Leader's attacks on them might lose their strength and cutting edge after the death of its caustic publisher, William Loeb, the news from here is otherwise.

title: VOLUNTEERS HELPING HANDICAPPED IN GARDEN
description: The Queens Botanical Garden is looking for adult volunteers, including the elderly, to work one day a week with handicapped teen-agers on the garden grounds.

title: SENATE APPROVES DEATH PENALTY FOR SOME CRIMES AT FEDERALLEVEL
description: The Senate voted today, 63 to 32, for a bill to allow the Federal Government to execute terrorists, spies and people who attack Presidents.

title: Steel Merger Is Discussed
description: Lawyers from the Justice Department's antitrust division met today with lawyers from the LTV Corporation and the Republic Steel Corporation to discuss how the two companies will proceed in an effort to win the department's approval for them to merge.

title: SPLENDOR IN THE BATH: THE LATEST AMENITIES
description: JUST as the family or rumpus room of the 1950's was the ''growth'' area of the house, the master bathroom - combined with the master bedroom - is now emerging as an important feature in new houses and apartments. In a state-of-the-art model home built north of Houston to accompany last month's National Association of Home Builders' annual convention, 25 percent of the entire two-story, 1,500- square-foot, 3-bedroom house was devoted to the combined master bedroom/bathroom suite. Together, they were almost a small apartment within a house that had otherwise grown smaller. At the convention itself, water-jet baths, spas, steam baths, saunas and tanning and fitness machines occupied what seemed to be a disproportionately large part of the 16-acre display areas in Houston's Astrodome and Astrohall.

title: All Charges Dismisssed In Arizona Riot Case
description: A judge today permanantly dismissed riot and assault charges against 19 members of a religious sect.

title: CITY'S LAST CRUISE-LINER PIER CLOSES FOR NOW

Valerie Tysliava, 69, Is Dead; Ran a Lithuanian Newspaper
description: Valerie Tysliava, the publisher of a Lithuanian-language newspaper, died Saturday at her home in the East New York section of Brooklyn. She was 69 years old.

title: ALVARADO SAYS SCHOOLS NEED REPAIRS
description: Budget cuts dating to New York City's fiscal crisis of the mid-1970's have left the city's school system with buildings that are ''literally falling apart,'' Schools Chancellor Anthony J. Alvarado said yesterday.

title: 2 Seek Control Of Belknap Inc.
description: Two separate groups informed the Securities and Exchange Commission of moves to acquire Belknap Inc., a hardware distributor based in Louisville, Ky.

title: DONOVAN APPEARS AT LABOR PARLEY IN FLORIDA TO DEFEND THE PRESIDENT
description: Secretary of Labor Raymond J. Donovan, without an invitation by labor's top leadership, made an appearance at the labor movement's annual winter meeting today, saying that many working-class people would vote for Mr. Reagan in the Presidential election, as they did in 1980.

description: There were 14 weeks in the latest quarter compared with 13 weeks in the year-ago quarter. The company is in the process of switching from a fiscal year ending in June to a fiscal year ending in December.

title: B.C. UPSETS SYRACUSE, 90-88
description: A sophomore guard, Stu Primus, scored a basket at the buzzer and another as the overtime expired tonight to give Boston College a 90-88 Big East upset of Syracuse.

title: New Fire at University

title: PENTAGON MOVES TO SIMPLIFY CHAIN OF COMMAND TO BEIRUT
description: The Defense Department has established a new military command in Lebanon on a much shorter leash from Washington in an effort to give authorities here tighter control over operations there, Pentagon officials said today.

description: SEVEN weeks after the breakup of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company, many consumers remain confused about what happened and why, and they are asking basic questions: Who will fix a broken phone? Who will supply long-distance service? What will the costs be?

description: Chris Mullin admits there were times when he missed his old teammates early this season, particularly when St. John's lost seven of eight games and fell far behind in the Big East Conference.

WFTV, an affiliate of the American Broadcasting Companies, has a 28 percent share of the Orlando-Daytona Beach-Melbourne television market, SFN said.

description: Mortimor S. Gordon, a lawyer and industrialist, died of a heart attack Tuesday at Lenox Hill Hospital. He was 78 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: NAZI-HUNTER TELLS OF HER EFFORTS
description: Beate Klarsfeld, a pursuer of Nazis who recently went to South America to campaign against sanctuary for war criminals, said yesterday in New York that Paraguayan officials had assured her they would arrest and deport Josef Mengele, the former Auschwitz doctor, if they could find him. But she said the officials, the Minister of the Interior and the head of the Supreme Court, asserted that he could not be found.

title: SHULTZ SKEPTICAL ON NICARAGUAN VOTE
description: Secretary of State George P. Shultz called on Nicaragua today to allow international monitoring of its elections, scheduled for Nov. 4. He expressed skepticism that there would be what Americans regard as fair elections.

title: 2 SET FOR EARLY PRISON RELEASE
description: Willie Wilson and Jerry Martin, two of four members of the 1983 Kansas City Royals serving sentences at a Federal prison in Texas for cocaine convictions, were scheduled for early release Thursday, prison officials said tonight.

title: SWENSEN'S INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
A.M.C. Claim
description: The American Motors Corporation has won a $2 million claim against Iran, which canceled Jeep orders during the 1979 Islamic revolution. An A.M.C. spokesman in Detroit said the auto maker filed a $5 million claim and settled for $2 million plus an order for $55 million worth of Jeep kits.

title: Smoking in the Sky
description: Any week now, the Civil Aeronautics Board expects to decide whether to prohibit smoking on flights of less than an hour. Prodded for years by an anti-smoking group, Action on Smoking and Health, and a court, the board finally reversed itself and has seriously studied a ban since May.

title: EXILE'S RETURN TO GRENADA: A HAS-BEEN OR A HERO?
description: If recent polls are any guide, the 100,000 residents of this tiny island nation in the Eastern Caribbean are not enthusiastic about the prospect of choosing a new government soon.

title: Kean Picks New Treasurer
description: Governor Kean said today he would nominate the State Banking Commissioner, Michael M. Horn, to the post of State Treasurer when the State Senate convenes on Thursday. If confirmed by the Senate, Mr. Horn would replace Kenneth R. Biederman, who has resigned, effective in mid-March.

title: TEXTONE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Shares outstanding figures reflect the public offering of 351,000 new common shares in September.

title: Required Reading Diplomatic Firehouse
description: Sir Oliver Wright, the British Ambassador to the United States, speaking to the International Center of Florida and the Florida Council of International Development, Jan. 31:

title: COUNTRY STYLE, OLD AND NEW
description: APUBLISHING executive, Pat Ross, left, an ardent collector of folk art, decided recently to open a store to sell old and new country-style handmade things. Lee Stanton of Rogers Butler Baskett designed the interior of Sweet Nellie and Mrs. Ross stocked her shop with antique quilts ($295 to $4,000 each), hand-woven blankets, throws and coverlets ($175 to $1,000), handmade rugs (from $10 a square foot), pillows ($28 to $100) and furniture ($125 to $2,000). Sweet Nellie, at 1262 Madison Avenue, at 90th Street, is open Monday to Saturday, 10 A.M. to 6 P.M.

title: WILLIAMS, T.E., PHARMACEUTIALS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss.

title: DEMOCRATS UNITED
description: One piece of news out of the Iowa caucuses was the triumph of Walter Mondale. Another, less noticed, was the emergence of a Democratic consensus on foreign policy: a position critical of President Reagan's whole approach to foreign affairs as dangerously adventurous and militaristic.

title: KEY UNION AIDE CRITICIZES KILEY ON LABOR TALK
description: A key labor official criticized the chairman of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority today for suggesting that Civil Service and union membership be eliminated for all supervisors and managers in New York City's transit system.

title: THE APOLLO REOPENS, HEARTENING HARLEM
description: It was amateur night at the Apollo, and the evening, wrapped in razzmatazz, seemed like old times.

title: MOHASCO CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net losses. Results include gains from divestiture program transactions equal to 5 cents a share for the latest year and 72 cents a share for the previous year.

title: IRISH DEFEAT JASPERS, 63-58
description: Coach Gordon Chiesa of Manhattan College was worried all day yesterday that his star player, Tim Cain, wouldn't be well enough to play against Notre Dame last night because of an ankle injury.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: THURSDAY, FEBRUARY 23, 1984

title: Nucorp Charges Seen
description: Richard L. Burns, former chairman of Nucorp Energy Inc., said he expects the Securities and Exchange Commission to charge him with influencing Nucorp's stock price and participating in a pre-billing scheme.

title: BOOTHE FINANCIAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
DON'T AID CENTRAL AMERICAN POLICE
description: Among the recommendations of the Kissinger commission on Central America surfacing again now as proposed legislation is a provision that would lift the ban on United States aid to national police forces in Central America - in short, a revival of 1960's-style counterinsurgency aid. A decade ago, as the Vietnam War was ending and the ''Vietnam syndrome'' was beginning, Congress passed a law banning United States assistance to the police and internal security agencies of foreign governments. It should stand by its original wisdom in rejecting such programs.

title: Johnson Finishes 13th in Downhill
description: Competing for the first time since winning the gold medal in the Olympic downhill last Thursday, Bill Johnson of Van Nuys, Calif., finished 13th today in a downhill race of the North American Ski Trophy Series.

title: HOME IMPROVEMENT
description: -TO-USE, fast-working paint rollers, combined with water-thinned latex paints available in almost every conceivable color, have made interior painting simpler than ever. In spite of these advances, those who do their own painting are all too often disappointed with the results. In most cases this is not the fault of the paint; it results from poor preparation or planning. And sometimes it is a matter of not being familar with the basic techniques involved.

title: WELLCO ENTERPRISES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
LABYRINTHINE WORLD OF COMPUTERS
description: Last August the Office of Management and Budget sent out a questionnaire to the 20 largest agencies of the Federal Government.
