description: Women Outrun Expectations

title: GERMAN IN ROME DENIES HE SOUGHT TO HELP NAZIS
description: A German physician mentioned in a 1947 report to the State Department as a smuggler of Nazis out of Italy under the protection of the Vatican has denied that he knowingly aided Nazis and said he had actively opposed them and had been imprisoned and mistreated by them.

title: LAST-MINUTE AGREEMENT AVERTS HAWAII PUBLIC EMPLOYEES' STRIKE
description: A strike by 40,000 state and county workers was averted 15 minutes before the deadline today with the help of Gov. George Ariyoshi, who promised to seek legislative approval of new two-year contracts for four public service unions.

title: UNIFAST INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Including extraordinary gains of $20,916 for the quarter and $32,916 for the 6 months. Year-ago share earnings have been adjusted to reflect a 10 percent stock dividend on July 18, 1983, and a 50 percent dividend on Nov. 30, 1983.

title: GRENADA CHARGES EX-LEADERS IN KILLINGS
description: As crowds shouted ''Hang them all!'' 18 of Grenada's former political and military leaders appeared in court today to answer charges related to the coup that prompted a United States-led invasion last October.

title: MORE WOMEN OWNING BUSINESSES
description: The number of small businesses owned by women has risen in recent years, but the earnings of those companies still lag far behind those owned by men, according to a new study by the Small Business Administration.

title: Radio and TV Plan To Broadcast Debate
description: Tonight's debate among the eight major Democratic Presidential candidates at St. Anselm's College in Goffstown, N.H., will be broadcast live on radio and later on television.

title: GAIN SEEN IN DETERRING TEEN-AGERS' DRUG USE
description: Teaching teen-agers how to say no to drugs in the first place may be a better way to deal with their drug use than tougher law enforcement or treatment, researchers say.

title: STATEN I. AND LEHMAN IN FINAL
description: Until the final 10 minutes last night, the Dutch Shoe, symbolic of the City University basketball championship, seemed about to take a long step out of the trophy case in C Building of the College of Staten Island, where it has been for three years.

description: The State Liquor Authority,

title: Builders Charged With Tax Evasion
description: The owners of one of the contracting companies for the Richard J. Hughes Justice Complex here and their company were charged with lying about their incomes and with trying to evade income taxes, state officials said today.

title: TREASURY DETAILS PLANS TO END TAX 'ABUSES'
description: The Administration described in detail today proposals for major tax-law changes intended to eliminate a wide range of tax-shelter and accounting ''abuses'' and to raise $12.3 billion in revenue over the next three years.

title: Debt Issues
description: * Chrysler Financial Corp. is issuing $206.05 million of six-month commercial paper in Europe.

description: Nine Long Islanders have been charged with hazing a 16-year-old student during a fraternity initiation.

title: Canada Delivers Protest To U.S. on Acid Rain
description: The Canadian Government delivered a strong diplomatic protest to the State Department today against the Reagan Administration's failure to seek reductions in air pollution believed to cause acid rain.

title: No Headline
description: E.P.A. Reopens Study Of Asbestos in Schools

title: GALANOS'S WINNING WAY WITH CHIFFON
description: WHEN the blonde model in the sparkly, short, peach and apricot chiffon dress came down the runway, the normally sedate audience went wild. This was the spring-summer showing by James Galanos, the Los Angeles-based designer who always introduces his clothes in New York. Fashion is, to him, a serious business. He doesn't jazz it up with music, dance or any special theatrical effects. The clothes are the thing for this designer.

title: NICARAGUAN JEW SEEKS U.S. RELIGIOUS ASYLUM
description: A 22-year-old Nicaraguan Jew has made a 'highly unusual' request for religious asylum in the United States, asserting that life in his homeland is 'impossible' for Jewish people, immigration officials said Monday.

description: The Chinese Government denied today that it was involved in a plot to smuggle sophisticated United States technology to China.

description: President Reagan accused House Democrats tonight of having ''begged away'' from his call for bipartisan moves to reduce the Federal deficit.

title: HOW 3 YEARS HAVE CHANGED CBS NEWS
description: As CBS News approaches the third anniversary of Dan Rather as the anchor of ''Evening News,'' journalists and executives at the network say that those three years have been a time of important changes in style and content and in the personnel who manage the leading network news organization.

title: Technology; Network Links For Computers
description: M OST major computer manufacturers deny they are in the computer business any more. Instead, they profess to be leaders in the ''systems business,'' selling ''system solutions'' that insure customers will not be left with a bunch of disparate components, unable to communicate with one another.

description: The Cabinet today granted $566 million in Government subsidy toward development of a new Airbus Industrie airliner, matching an amount committed by France.

description: Stock prices finished moderately lower yesterday in heavier trading, with issues responding to specific news developments registering the largest moves.

description: A Federal appeals court declared in Manhattan yesterday that patients who were involuntarily committed to mental institutions should receive adequate treatment.

title: Let Alaska's Oil Flow
description: Naturally By law - indeed, five laws - the United States prohibits exports of Alaskan oil. The nominal reason is national security. The controlling reason is protectionist politics. The ban should be repealed.

title: 11 HINDUS KILLED IN PUNJAB UNREST
description: Violence erupted again in the northern state of Punjab today as gunmen identified as Sikh terrorists attacked Hindus.

title: EDITORS' NOTE
description: Under this heading, The Times amplifies articles or rectifies what the editors consider significant lapses of fairness, balance or perspective.

title: Koppers-Inland
description: The Koppers Company of Pittsburgh said it would take the necessary legal actions, including appeals, to reverse a $74 million jury verdict in favor of the Inland Steel Corporation. The verdict, rendered Tuesday in a trial in an Indiana circuit court, came in a lawsuit in which Inland charged that Koppers had breached a contract in the construction of a blast furnace and coke battery. In addition, Koppers said it had been awarded $10 million on a counterclaim for funds not paid under the contract.

title: PICKING TOOLS THAT DO THE JOB AND LAST
description: MANY gardeners have heard that they must dig a $10 hole to transplant a $5 plant but that it will take a $35 spade to do the job right.

title: Tests for Net Aide
description: Herman Kull , the Net assistant coach who was hospitalized with chest pains before Tuesday night's game against the Philadelphia 76ers, was found to have suffered a heart attack and will be out eight weeks, the club said. The 45-year-old Kull, who was stricken while jogging near his home in Montville, N.J., was in guarded condition and resting comfortably at Morristown Memorial Hospital, where doctors were conducting tests to determine the severity of the attack.

title: SFN COMPANIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-Including a gain of $2,315,000 on the sale of a unit.

title: State Bonds Sold
description: Underwriters led by the Chase Manhattan Bank sold $100 million in New York State general obligation bonds at yields ranging from 5.25 percent for bonds due in 1985 to 8.20 percent in 1994, 9.25 percent in 2004-5 and 9.40 percent in 2008-14. The bonds were rated A by Moody's and Ax by Standard & Poor's. According to underwriters, about $40 million of the issue remained unsold by late in the day.

title: Advertising; D.D.B's Upbeat Outlook
description: S INCE Doyle Dane Bernbach is one of the ad agencies for the International Business Machines Corporation, it was no surprise to discover an I.B.M. Personal Computer all white and shiny behind the desk of Barry E. Loughrane, president and chief executive of D.D.B's domestic operation.

title: DEMOCRATS EXPECT HARD SENATE FIGHT
description: After a disheartening summer and fall, Senate Democratic strategists finally received a lift when they recently persuaded former Gov. William Winter of Mississippi to declare his candidacy for the Senate seat held by Thad Cochran, a Republican completing his first term. But the Democrats still acknowledge they face an uphill fight to regain control of the Senate.

title: Belgian Inflation Rate
description: Consumer prices in Belgium rose eight- tenths of 1 percent from mid-January to mid-February, bringing the inflation rate for the previous 12 months to 7.7 percent, the Government said today.

title: The U.N. Today Feb. 22, 1984
description: SECURITY COUNCIL

title: GORMAN-RUPP CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
GLENN SHIFTS TO NEW HAMPSHIRE AND THE SOUTH
description: Senator John Glenn, his stunning defeat in Iowa only two days behind him, today virtually abandoned his efforts in another caucus state, Maine, and moved to shore up his strength in New Hampshire and the South.

title: UNIONS LOSE AS HIGH COURT BACKS COMPANIES IN BANKRUPTCY FILINGS
description: The Supreme Court, in a sharp setback for organized labor, ruled unanimously today that a bankruptcy court may free a company from its union contracts without requiring proof that the company would otherwise face imminent failure.

title: By Eva Hoffman;
description: THE WANDERING JEW. By Stefan

title: Presidential Hopeful in Jail
description: Hugh Bagley wants to be President. But first he has to get out of jail. Mr. Bagley, a flea market operator, is one of 30 candidates listed on next Tuesday's New Hampshire Democratic primary ballot. But the 53-year-old candidate, who qualified for the ballot by paying a $1,000 filing fee, was arrested at his home in Keyes, Calif., Monday night on a Tulare County warrant charging him with contempt of court and six traffic citations, and was being held in the Tulare County Jail after failing to post $1,000 bail.

title: REECE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net losses.

title: 'LA CAGE' RAISES TOP PRICES
description: ''La Cage aux Folles'' is raising its top ticket price $2.50 to $47.50 on July 2, making it the most expensive show now on Broadway and the second most expensive in Broadway history, behind the $100 for the eight-and- a-half-hour ''Nicholas Nickleby.''

title: SHOOTINGS BRING SECURITY EFFORTS AT PENN STATION
description: Security was increased and closed- circuit television was reinstalled yesterday at Pennsylania Station, where an Amtrak engineer was shot Tuesday. He was the sixth person to be wounded in the area since April, apparently by the same gunman.

title: U.S. TO TEST AIR BAGS ON FORDS
description: The Federal Government announced today that it would buy 5,000 Ford automobiles equipped with air bags, both to test the safety devices and to encourage automakers to equip new cars with them.

title: I.R.A. Member Ordered Deported
description: An appeals court ruled yesterday that a member of the Irish Republic Army who escaped from prison in Ireland should be deported, but the court granted a five-week delay so he can take his case to the United States Supreme Court.

description: BASEBALL

description: b-Includes an extraordinary credit of $371,000. c-Net loss.

title: NEWS SUMMARY THURSDAY, FEBRUARY 23, 1984 International
description: The mission of the Marines in Lebanon is not over despite their move to ships off Beirut, President Reagan said. In a televised news conference, he said the Marines could conceivably return if doing so improved their ability to protect the Lebanese Government. (Page A1, Column 6.)

title: G.H.R. Proposal
description: Creditors of the G.H.R. Energy Corporation, a Louisiana oil and gas company that has been in bankruptcy proceedings for a year, asked that John R. Stanley, president, be replaced by a board of directors supervised by a court-appointed trustee. The creditors, owed about $1 billion, made the proposal at a hearing before the Federal District Bankruptcy Court here. They also asked that the banks surrender 20 percent of their secured payments to unsecured creditors. Mr. Stanley's attorneys vigorously opposed the proposal.

title: LA PETITE ACADEMY reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Jordan Severs Its Ties To Libya After Attack
description: Jordan severed diplomatic and political relations with Libya today over the destruction of the Jordanian Embassy by rioters in Tripoli last week, the official Jordanian television said.

title: PRESIDENT ASSERTS MARINES IN BEIRUT STILL HAVE A ROLE
description: President Reagan said tonight that the mission of the United States marines in Lebanon was not over, despite their move to ships off Beirut, and that they could conceivably return if that would help protect the Lebanese Government.

title: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES ; Fannie Mae Rates For Debentures
description: The Federal National Mortgage Association announced interest rates yesterday of 11.25 percent for $250 million of three-year debentures and 12 percent for $150 million of seven- year debentures, both of which are offered at a price of 100.

title: ROCKWOOD HOLDING CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Quotation of the Day
description: ''But as long as there's a chance for a peaceful solution, we're going to try and see if there's any contribution we can make to achieving that.

title: Russian Priest Dismissed
description: The newspaper Turkmenskaya Iskra of Ashkhabad in Central Asia has reported that the Rev. Pyotr Rassokha, a Russian Orthodox parish priest in the Turkmenian city of Mary, had been dismissed for stealing collection money, selling unlicensed candles and indulging in illegal religious activities.

title: French Soldier Killed, 2d Wounded by Mortar
description: A French soldier in the multinational force was killed in shelling between Moslem and Christian factions in and around Beirut today, a French spokesman said.

title: MESA BIDS TO RAISE GULF STAKE
description: In a move to put more pressure on the Gulf Oil Corporation, T. Boone Pickens, head of the Mesa Petroleum Company and of an investor group trying to take over Gulf, announced yesterday that his group would offer $65 a share for 13.5 million shares of Gulf and wage a proxy fight against Gulf's top management for control of the company.

title: Bond Prices Set 6-Month Low; Rise in Rates Is Predicted
description: Interest rates rose yesterday as bond prices fell to their lowest levels since early August amid predictions of higher rates still to come, new data showing a robust economy during January and February and large inventories of notes and bonds on dealer's shelves.

title: TRANS MOUNTAIN PIPE LINE CO LTD reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-After an extraordinary loss of $72,000. c-Including a special gain of $24,000. The company is listed on the Toronto and Montreal stock exchanges.

title: New Owners For Track
description: Roosevelt Raceway has been sold by the Gulf and Western Corporation to a group of private investors and will continue to operate as a harness-racing track.

title: Advertising; Pony Plans Spot for Networks
description: For the Pony people, who make what were once called sneakers and are now know as athletic shoes, the time has come to add a new dimension to their advertising, and a new medium as well.

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL

title: Salvador Politician Shot Dead at Home; 4th Slain in 2 Years
description: A rightist Salvadoran politician was shot to death today as he left his home here. There was no immediate claim of responsibility for the slaying.

title: Bridge: When One Has Two Aces, What Should Be the Lead?
description: Some 40 years ago a wise British writer, Skit Simon, posed the following question: If you are going to be on lead with two aces against a small slam in a suit, should you double?

title: G.I.'S WILL TRAIN IN HONDURAS AGAIN
description: Senior Reagan Administration officials said today that United States military forces, which have just completed a major training exercise in Honduras, would be sent to that country to train each year for the foreseeable future, perhaps for as long as 20 years.

title: State Seeks More Classes For Diploma
description: The State Education Commissioner presented revised requirements yesterday for all high school students in New York State that call for an extra year of social studies, mathematics and science in order to graduate.

title: Theater: Revival of Homecoming'
description: In the fine revival of Harold Pinter's "Homecoming," everything - including the enigmatic pauses - still works. The effect on the audience continues to be chilling and puzzling.

title: Auctions
description: AMONG 19th-century European paintings and drawings to be offered at auction by both Sotheby's and Chritie's next week are major works by J.M.W. Turner, William Adolphe Bouguereau and Jean Francois Millet. Outstanding in the sale next Wednesday at 10:15 A.M. and 2 P.M. at Sotheby's, York Avenue and 72d Street, is an 1842 Turner watercolor on paper, "The Splugen Pass," described by John Ruskin in "Notes on Turner" (1878) as "The best Swiss landscape yet painted by man.

Death of Boy-in-Bubble as 'Amazing' as Life
description: David, the bright, cheerful boy who spent all but the last 15 days of his 12 years of life in a sterile plastic bubble, had a death "as amazing as his life," his doctor said today.

title: Harlem Dance Theater Performing in Brooklyn
description: Karen Brown was born in Okmulgee, Okla., a town not otherwise noted for producing ballerinas. But Miss Brown, a leading member of Dance Theater of Harlem, has another distinction. She is one of those dancers who is as compelling in plotless ballets as in dramaticworks that require her to portray a character. And New Yorkers will have a chance to see her dance both kinds of role when Dance Theater of Harlem performs at the Brooklyn Center for the Performing Arts at Brooklyn College tonight through Sunday afternoon.

title: BRAZIL IS STUDYING USE OF HERBICIDES
description: Brazilian officials have begun investigating whether the use of herbicides to clear a strip of jungle for a power transmission line may have played a role in the deaths of 40 settlers in the Amazon region two years ago.

title: A NEW LEADERSHIP PROGRAM TO HELP HISPANIC WOMEN
description: ''It would have taken me a lifetime to learn what I did in the last few months, '' said Elizabeth Garcia, discussing the Public Affairs Leadership program for Hispanic women that she had just completed.

title: CALVIN EXPLORATION INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
APPEALS COURT REBUFFS U.S. ON BABY JANE DOE RECORDS
description: A United States appeals panel in Manhattan yesterday upheld a lower- court ruling to bar the Federal Government from examining the medical records of a severely handicapped infant at a Long Island hospital.

title: News Summary; Friday, February 24, l984
description: International

title: Hawaii Company Averts Vote Fight
description: Alexander & Baldwin Inc. said it had reached agreement with its largest shareholder, Harry Weinberg, on the election of directors at the company's annual meeting April26. Mr. Weinberg has agreed not to wage a proxy contest, according to the company, which is involved in shipping, sugar production and property development.

title: Briefing
description: For the Wheels of Progress

title: Chrysler Rebounds In Quarter and Year
description: The Chrysler Corporation reported today that it earned $118.3 million, or 91 cents a share, in the fourth quarter of 1983 and a record $700.9 million, or $5.79 a share, for the year.

title: BILL TO PERMIT FEDERAL PROSECUTION OF CAREER CRIMINALS PASSES SENATE
description: The Senate today approved a bill that would allow Federal prosecution of weapon- carrying career robbers and force those convicted to serve at least 15 years in prison. The vote was 92 to 0.

title: Nets Defeat Pacers On a Closing Surge
description: For a long time tonight, it looked as if all the Nets had accomplished earlier this week by defeating the Philadelphia 76ers, one of the league's best teams, would be undone by a listless performance against the Indiana Pacers, the worst team.

title: Around the Nation; Augusta Hostage-Taker Is Sentenced to 10 Years
description: Charles R. Harris, the unemployed man accused of crashing a gate at the Augusta National Golf Club and taking hostages while President Reagan was there last fall, was sentenced today to 10 years in prison.

title: Power Plant's Promise
description: To the Editor:

title: Sports People; Estimate Revised
description: The $700,000-a-season figure that has been widely reported as the worth of David Woodley's three-year contract with the Pittsburgh Steelers appears to be far too high. According to a source familiar with the agreement, Woodley, the quarterback who was traded to the Steelers from the Miami Dolphins on Wednesday, will rece ive a salary of $350,000 in the first year, $425,000 in the second and $500,000 in the third. In addition, he gets a $75,000 signing bonus and a $200,000 loan at 4 percent interest.

title: The Editorial Notebook; George McGovern's Toy Train
description: George McGovern had an inspiration last weekend. There were just two days left before the Iowa caucuses and he was casting about for a location.

Controller Cited in Crash
description: Navy investigators say an air traffic controller with a drinking problem was at fault in a runway collision that killed three men last November, The Florida Times Union has reported. A Navy memorandum issued the day of the crash, Nov. 8, 1983, said Petty Officer First Class Michael F. Jones ordered a jet to taxi across a runway where another jet was rolling for a takeoff at Cecil Field. It also concluded that the taxiing plane, an S-3A Viking anti-submarine jet, was traveling too fast when it collided with the A-7E Corsair attack jet.

title: Advertising; Western Air Campaign
description: The biggest media for the $12 million ad campaign of Western Airlines that is about to break are newspapers and magazines.

title: Demand Helps Sweden
description: Strong demand for floating-rate notes in the Eurobond market has allowed Sweden to sell a $500 million issue with the longest maturity ever seen in the Euromarket and with a much lower interest rate than it paid last October.

description: Friday TRIBUTE TO PAUL JACOBS
