description: b-After a loss of $28,244 from discontinued operations. c-Net loss after a loss of $314,673 from discontinued operations. Year-ago results are adjusted for a change in accounting methods.

title: WNYC Fails to Carry Debate
description: The Democratic Presidential debate last night was not carried as planned by WNYC-AM radio in New York City because the station did not receive necessary programmin information from the National Public Radio Network, according to Lawrence Miller, program manager for the station. The information included how long the broadcast was and then the breaks would occur. A spokesman for the network said the information was sent to all radio stations on a teletype machine and that only WNYC-AM reported problems with receiving it.

title: ECKERD, JACK CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 28
LYPHOMED INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Five Hours of 'Lace'
description: TWO weekends ago, Channel 4 unveiled a mini-series based on Tommy Thompson's best-selling novel "Celebrity." Last week, Channel 2 began unfolding Sidney Sheldon's "Master of the Game." And now Channel 7 is brining forth Shirley Conran's "Lace," a celebration of sex and money that runs for five hours, the first three of which can be seen Sunday at 8.

title: CUSTOM LABORATORIES reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss.

title: TRIANGLE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss. Share earnings have been adjusted for 10 percent stock dividends in December 1983 and December 1982.

title: ESSEX CHEMICAL CORP reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: Results for the latest year include a loss of 17 cents a share from discontinued operations and a gain of 44 cents a share on the sale of the company's Pro-Seal operations. Results for the 1982 year include a loss from discontinued operations.

title: INTER-REGIONAL FINANCIAL GROUP INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $10 million for the quarter and $37,585,000 for the year. c-Net income after losses from discontinued operations of $5,669,000 for the quarter and $4,089,000 for the year.

title: John MacVane Dies; Radio Correspondent
description: John MacVane, a leading network raido correspondent for more than three decades until his retirement in 1977, died of a heart attack Jan. 28 at a hospital in Brunswick, Me. He was 71 years old and lived in South Portland, Me.

title: New York Day by Day; Saved From the Shredder
description: What, wondered John E. Bourke, did the post office do with those mounds of undeliverable magazines that he saw at the Lenox Hill station on East 70th Street?

title: Pope Offers a Blessing For New York to Koch
description: Mayor Koch told Pope John Paul II today that everyone in New York City--Roman Catholics, Jews, Protestants, humanists and non-believers--loved John Paul, and the Pope extended a blessing to all the people of the city in return.

title: How Marrow Transplant Worked, or Didn't Remains a Puzzle
description: The life-saving uses of bone marrow transplantation have expanded dramatically in recent years, but as the death of the boy known only as David shows, the treatment does not always succeed, nor are its failures always easy to explain.

title: CONSOLIDATED NATURAL GAS CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
CORRECTION
description: %TAn article in Business Day Wednesday about New York radio stations misstated the number of listeners toWKHK, now WLTW. There are about 800,000, according to Radio and Records, a trade publication.

title: Lilco Estimates Rises For Shorehan Costs
description: The Shoreham nuclear power plant will cost at least $4.1 billion and wil not go into commercial operation until July 1, l985, according to the Long Island Lighting Company.

title: AHMANSON, H.F., & CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes extraordinary gains of $36,000 for the quarter and $82,000 for the year. c-After an extraordinary loss of $38,000. d-Net loss after an extraordinary credit of $440,000.

title: Advertising; Agencies Announce New print Assignments
description: This is the week for new business for Needham, Harper & Steers/New York; Herman & Rosner, and McCaffery & Ratner: All three have won new accounts in the print field.

title: Music: Scriabin by Muti and Philadelphians
description: "Art," Scriabin said about his Third Symphony, "must unite with philosophy and religion in an indivisible whole toform a new gospel." On Wednesday night in Avery Fisher Hall, Riccardo Muti led the Philadelphia Orchestra in a rare preaching of that symphonic gospel, which the mystical Russian composer subtitled "The Divine Poem."

title: GENERAL BINDING CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 1
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $767,000 for the quarter and $2,527,000 for the year, a loss of $2,242,000 from the disposal of discontinued operations, a gain of $415,000 for the quarter and year on the sale and leaseback of land and a building, and a gain of $427,000 for the year from the repurchase of outstanding debt. c-Net income after a loss of $426,000 from discontinued operations. d-After a loss of $1,625,000 from discontinued operations.

title: Senate Votes Shipping Bill
description: The Senate today approved a compromise bill to grant shipowners sweeping immunity from antitrust laws.

title: Hernandez Denounces Moffett
description: Keith Hernandex of the Mets today angrily denied "innuendoes" on cocaine involvement that he said had been cast by Ken Moffett, former head of the Major League Baseball Players Association.

title: Friday Sports
description: Basketball

title: SUBARU OF AMERICA INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
Art: Views of Upheaval In Roger Brown Show
description: It has got to be quite difficult these days to step into a gallery in SoHo and not see some political art. "Survival art" might be a better name, since the politics in question are in almost every case the politics of survival. Irrespective of the level of debate, the sheer ubiquity of the preoccupation cannot fail to strike even the most frivolous of visitors.

title: SQUIBB CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Including a gain of $27 million for the quarter and year from the early extinguishment of debt and a loss of $27.6 million for the quarter and year from the disposal of operations in certain Latin American countries.

title: Shad Asks Shift on Liability
description: The chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission disclosed today that he had proposed making corporate executives liable for violations of the Federal securities laws, rather than corporations themselves.

title:
Pop/Jazz;
Lord Burgess Back Tonight With Songs of Caribbean
description: WHEN Harry Belafonte shot to worldwide fame in the l950's singing such songs as "Jamaica Farewell," "Day-O" and "Island in the Sun," the fortunes of the man who wrote those songs of the Caribbean as well as three dozen others in Mr. Belafonte's repertory rose along with the singer's.

title: ZIMMER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
STANDARD MOTOR PRODUCTS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
TEXAS AIR CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Marshall Field Fills Post of President
description: Marshall Field & Company, a division of the Batus Retail Group, yesterday named Burnett W. Donoho president and chief op erating officer to replace Thomas R. Bagan, who will leave the company.

title: Music: Haydn 'Creation'
description: THE earlier of Haydn's two, grand, final oratorios, "The Creation," is a popular staple nowadays. In addition to the four performances being offered by the New York Philharmonic just now-the first of which was last night in Avery Fisher Hall-there will be a college version at the Symphony Space on Tuesday and a performance at Carnegie Hall by the New York Choral Society on March 3. Six "Creations" in 10 days, all told.

title: The Speech: John Glenn; 'We're Talking Aout Trust, Basically'
description: Candidates seeking the Presidential nomination make dozens of speeches in their campaigns. The content often varies, depending on where a speech is given and who is in the audience, but a body of material appears, with only slight variation, in nearly every such speech.

title: Broadway; Mamet's new play about real estate to open in March.
description: YEARS ago, when he was an out-of-work actor in Chicago, David Mamet took a job as a typist in a real-estate office. "It was a skill my mother said I could fall back on," says Mr. Mamet, who later turned the skill to more interesting use, writing plays. He remebers the salesmen in the office as "the most driven guys I've every met: They were selling worthless land in Arizona and Florida to unsuspecting people, and they had to make the sale to eat."

title: Film: 'One Man's War,' Set in Paris
description: "One Man's War" was shown as part of the 1982 New York Film Festival. Following are excerpts from Janet Maslin's review, which appeared in the New York Times on Oct. 8, 1982. The film opens today at the Public Theater, 425 Lafayette Street.

title: At the Movies; Polanski's pirate movie is set to sail
description: In his current autobiography, "Roman," Roman Polanski mentions the pirate movie he hoped to make after "Chinatown," and his disappointment when the project was tabled. New Mr. Polanski has a Spanish galleon under construction in Malta, and his movie is under way. By telephone from Paris the other day, Mr. Polanski said that Michael Caine had informally agreed to star in the $25 million production, which he sescribed as a "comedy-adventure." The film will be distributed by MGM/UA, and shooting will begin in June, much of it in Tunisia.

title: CONGRESS PANELS TAKE FIRST STEPS FOR BUDGET CUTS
description: Congress's tax-writing committees took initial steps today toward drafting a deficit-reducing package for the next three years.

title: Steel Merger Plan Discussed Again
description: Officials of the LTV Corporation and the Republic Steel Corporation met today with J. Paul McGrath, chief of the Justice Department's antitrust division, to discuss alternatives to their proposed $770 million merger.

title: Renaissance Concert
description: The New York Renaissance Band will present performancs from the first known book of printed music tomorrow night at 8 at Alice Tully Hall.

title: The City; Fire on Third Ave. Routs Hundreds
description: Fire broke out in an acetylene tank in a 31-story office building on Manhattan's East Side yesterday, forcing the evacuation of hundreds of people.

title: Money Fund Assets Rise
description: Assets of the nation's money funds, on a seven-week rise, climbed to their highest level since May 1983 in the week ended Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute said yesterday.

title: Deficit? Who Cares?
description: Members of Congress have returned from a 10-day recess with the news that the home folks are concerned about what President Reagan has once again referred to as "your deficit" - as if he had nothing to do with those staggering budget shortfalls that may reach $250 billion annually by 1989.

title: Publishing: A Caper With A Ludlum
description: "THE AQUITAINE PROGRESSION" by Robert Ludlum will be published March 15 but the novel has been available since last Friday at several Barnes & Noble bookstores in Manhattan. Yet copies of the book were not scheduled to be shipped to the chain, or to any other East Coast bookstores, until last Saturday.

title: Lester Bowie Quintet
description: The trumpeter Lester Bowie will lead a quintet plus three singers in "From the Root to the Source," a program that encompasses jazz, pop and gospel, tonigh through Sunday at Seet Basil (242-1785), 88 Seventh Avenue South. Sets begin at 10 and 11:45 P.M. and 1:30 A.M.; there is a $7.50 cover and a $5.00 minimum.

title: Ex-Stewardesses vs. United
description: Doris Cooper Baxter, who is known to her friends as Daiquiri, got her dream job as a United Airlines stewardess in July 1967.

title: Executives
description: * Belding Heminway Co., a manufacturer of industrial threads and specialty fabrics, has elected to its board Louis J. Lefkowitz, former Attorney General of New York State.

title: SIMCO STORES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 28
Article 205009 -- No Title
description: The Gulf Oil Corporation has offered to pay $70 a share, or $1.52 billion, to buy back the 13.2 percent stake in the company held by T. Boone Pickens and a group of investors trying to take over the company, Mr. Pickens told the Securities and Exchange Commission yesterday.

title: Advertising; JWT's Earnings Soared In 1983 After Bad 1982
description: From the disastrous results of 1982,the JWT Group soared in 1983, ending with earnings of $17.6 million, up from $267,000.

title: CHURCH & DWIGHT CO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Trading Halted In Tymshare
description: Trading in the shares of Tymshare Inc., operator of one of the nation's largest data-transmission networks, was halted on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday afternoon pending an announcement. Tymshare, which earlier was close to a merger with the McDonnell Douglas Corporation, was rumored yesterday to be a target of Honeywell Inc. Tymshare stock last traded at $15.25, up $1.50.

title: U.S. Seeks Limits on Ex-Bell Units
description: The Justice Department has urged a Federal judge to sharply limit the manner in which the seven former Bell System companies may enter new lines of business and to make it clear they are not going to be allowed into the long-distance market any time soon.

title: WESTMIN RESOURCES LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The company is listed on the Toronto and Vancouver stock exchanges.

title: Family Rights in Injury Suits Upheld
description: New York State's highest court ruled yesterday that, under certain circumstances, anyone who sees a member of his immediate family killed or seriously injured because of the negligence of another person may recover damages from him for emotional distress.

title: EL CHICO CORP reports earnings for 12wks to Feb 10
description: b-Figures are not available because the company was a unit of Anheuser- Busch Co. during that period.

title: Scouting; Maternity Leave
description: The Women's Tennis Association, the union for the female professionals, has sought ways in the recent months to solve special eligibility problems for its members.

title: White House; Hints of Flexibility on Nuclear Arms Talks
description: President Reagan still believes the Soviet Union's leadership reserves the right to "commit any crime, to lie, to cheat" to further its goals, as he said in 1981. He still believes also Soviet Communism is "the focus of evil in the modern world," as he said last March.

title: The Theater: Savage Amusement'
description: The decaying city landscape, in which jerrbuilt high-rise apartments quickly become new slums, is the setting for Peter Flannery's "Savage Amusement." In this British play, now running at The American Stage Company, guerrilla warfare has broken out among squatters, raiding bands of delinquents and the faceless operators of the wrecking ball.

title: Advertising; A Cosmo Parody
description: The people who put together Playboy, the Parody, last year have now decided to make some more money with a twit at Cosmopolitan.

title: Anita Ramani Is Wed To K.M. Hathiramani
description: Anita Ramani, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Pitumal Ramani of Kobe, Japan, and Bombay, India, was married yesterday to Kumar M. Hathiramani, a son of Kamala Hathiramani of New York and Bombay and the late Mohandas Hathiramani.

title: Scouting; Generals' Film Gets Hazy Rating
description: Because the New Jersey Generals have so many new players and a new coach, a film of the team's only exhibition game could have been a valuable scouting tool for the Birmingham Stallions, the Generals' opponent on Sunday in an opening game of the United States Football League.

title: VIACOM INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Including a nonrecurring gain of $10,835,000 reflecting sale of Showtime to joint venture and reserve against advance made to Cable Health Network. Year-ago results have been restated to reflect the company's acquisition of KSLA-TV in Shreveport, La., in June 1983.

title: Democrats' Tax Challenge
description: In a bold and ambitious effort to reduce budget deficits, tinged with political maneuvering, Democrats on the House Ways and Means Committee agreed today to press for $51.2 billion in tax increases over the next four year.

title: SMITH LABORATORIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-Net loss.

title: The U.N. Today;Schedule Feb.24, 1984
description: SECURITY COUNCIL

title: Sports People; Justin to Miss Opener
description: The Generals moved the cornerback Kerry Justin off their roster yesterday and prepared to play their opening game, Sunday against the Birmingham Stallions, without him. Justin who jumped from the Seattle Seahawks this winter, left training camp for Los Angeles a week ago because of the illness of his mother, and he has remained there.

title: Of Landmarks Law And Hardship Cases
description: To the Editor:

title: The Fears of Christians on a 'Frontier' in Lebanon
description: "This is the frontier," said the driver named Tony as his Mercedes crept around the curve in the mountain road. "If something happens, it's going to happen here."

title: 90TH BIRTHDAY FOR JOURNAL OF PALM BEACH SOCIETY
description: In 1894, when alligators were still residing in the swamps of what was being transformed into the premier resort town of Palm Beach, Fla., and long before they began showing up on short-sleeved sport shirts, The Palm Beach Daily News was born.

title: Wickes Reaches an Agreement With Creditors
description: The Wickes Companies said today that it had reached an agreement in principle with representatives of more than 250,000 creditors, thus clearing the major hurdle in one of the largest bankruptcies in corporate history.

title: CHRYSLER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes a writedown of $223,900,000 of the company's investment in Peugeot S.A. c-Net loss. d-Includes a gain of $239,000,000 from the sale of Chrysler Defense Inc.

title: The Region; Trucker Arrested In Connecticut
description: A trucker was arrested this morning on charges of driving a tandem trailer truck on a state highway without the special license required in Connecticut, the state police said.

title: FEDERAL REALTY INVESTMENT TRUST reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-Includes a gain of $2,611,000 on the sale of real estate. c-Includes a gain of $513,000 on the sale of real estate.

title: Art: A Jim Dine Venture In the World of Bronze
description: It's risky to pass it along, but one way to feel like an artist is to take a small plaster reproduction of the Venus de Milo, cast it in wax and wreak on it many changes. Of course, it helps to be an artist before rushing to the art-supplies store -- preferably to be Jim Dine, a painter and printmaker turning sculptor, who recently conceived of the idea. And apparantly it worked, for there's a plethora of "Venuses" in Mr. Dine's current exhibition of bronzes, drawings and prints at Pace Gallery, 32 East 57th Street.

title: MUNFORD INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Mini-Mills: Steel's Bright Star
description: On the site of a defunct copper smelter in this bustling industrial city just 30 miles southwest of midtown Manhattan stands one of the nation's most successful steel mills.

title: Former Air Force Chief Detained in Argentina
description: The Supreme Council of the Armed Forces today arrested a third military commander who led Argentina to its defeat by Britain in the 1982 war over the Falkland Islands.

title: WILLIAMS, W.W., CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss after a pretax charge of $1.5 million for the writedown of assets.

title: South African Output
description: South African manufacturing output rose 4.3 percent in November from October but was up just 3.4 percent from November l982, the Government's Central Statistical Services said today. Among the sectors that fared best in the year to November were beverages, footwear, chemicals, plastics and glass.

title: Rangers End Slide at 2
description: The Rangers struggled with their memories last night but eventually recalled how to hold on to a lead. They hung on for a 4-2 victory over the Quebec Nordiques at Madison Square Garden to snap a two-game losing streak.

title: HECK'S INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a loss on disposal of assets of $979,000. c-After income from discontinued operations of $497,000 and a net gain on the sale of assets of $4,816,000.

title: FITCHBURG GAS & ELECTRIC LIGHT CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Songs by Modugno
description: The Italian singer and songwriter Dominico Modugno, who wrote "Volare," "Ciao, Ciao, Bambina" and other songs, will open a series called "International Music Stars" tonight at 8 at the Nederlander Theater, 208 West 41st Street. Mr. Modugno will appear through March 10. The number for show times and prices is 921-8000.

title: Police at Russian's Door Pose a Mystery
description: Policemen took up stations today outside the apartment of a dissident Marxist historian, barring foreigners from visiting him.

title: Fraud Inquiry On at Columbia Pictures TV
description: Columbia Pictures Industries Inc. today announced that it has been cooperating for the last several months with a Los Angeles County District Attorney's investigation of allegations of embezzlement, kickbacks and forgeries in the company's television division. Columbia stated that it was conducting "a detailed audit by its internal auditors" and declined futher comment.

title: Clinic for Turkey Hunters
description: If you've been having difficulty convincing yourself that most of winter is behind us, a visit to the remarkably diverse seventh annual Outdoor Exposition in Suffern, N.Y., may be what is needed.

title: China Trade On View
description: TWO HUNDRED years ago, on Washington's birthday, the 360-ton Empress of China sailed from Lower Manhattan for Canton, and thus became the first ship from the United States to trade with China. The bicentenial is being marked this weekend by exhibitions of the exotic wares brought back in the trade with the Orient at four New York museums and an auction gallery.

title: Senate in Jersey Supports Force By Homeowners
description: Vera Spagnola, a 65-year-old woman who shot and killed an intruder in her Paterson apartment last year, sat in the New Jersey Senate today and watched as the lawmakers passed a bill that would strengthen the right of the public to use deadly force to protect their homes and businesses.

title: FLORIDA GULF REALTY TRUST reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
Around the Nation; Judge Releases Six Held in School Dispute
description: A judge today ordered the release of six fathers jailed for three months for refusing to answer questions about the illegal Faith Christian School which their children attended.

title: Books of The Times
description: VENICE SIMPLON ORIENT-EXPRESS. The Return of the World's Most Celebrated Train. By Shirley Sherwood. 160 pages. Illustrated. Weidenfeld & Nicolson/Beaufort. $19.95.

title: SYNTEX CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
Campaign Notes; Election Panel Grants $100,000 to McGovern
description: The Federal Election Commission today awarded George McGovern $100,000 in matching funds. The action made Mr. McGovern the last of the eight major Democratic candidates to become eligible for matching funds.

title: Advertising; People
description: Vincent Trovati, Donald Masterson, Ernie Smith, Robert McCaffrey and Hanno Fuchs appointed executive vice presidents of Sudler & Hennessey, a subsidiary of Young & Rubicam.

title: Science and Art Meet at La Mama
description: In his theater, Ping Chong synthesizes art forms- music and dance, movies and still photography, painting and sculpture - creating and then furnishing architectural environments. With his current play, "A Race," at La Mama Annex, he has expanded his vision from his earlier chamber works such as "A.M./A.M. - the Articulated Man" and "Anna Into Nightlight." Though it runs barely more than an hour, "A Race" is an epic adventure about the coming of age of an unearthly tribe of near humans.

title: President Vetoes Legislation Authorizing Water Research
description: President Reagan vetoes legislation Tuesday authorizing $180 million over five years for research projects dealing with water resources. He said it was time for states and private industry to take over the job.

title: CORRECTION
description: An Associated Press dispatch yesterday on a Federal court order to restore disability benefits to some former Social Security recipients erred on the number of people affected. The ruling, by the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit, applies to 34,000 people in the circuit's nine Western states.

title: BRIEFS
description: Debt Issues

title: Zasnussi's Unapproachable'
description: Krzysztof Zanussi, the Polish director, has made some good films, including "Family Life" and "Contract, " but "The Unapproachable," which opens today at the Vandam Theater, is not one of them. Actually, it's not even Polish. It was made in West Germany two years age, in English, with Leslie Caron, who is still most attractive and still basically French, playing opposite a young actor named Daniel Webb, who is, I assume, English. The setting is a Berlin suburb, but it could be the moon.

title: Governor Announces Arts Awards Winners
description: Governor Cuomo has announced the names of the winners of the 1984 Governor's Arts Awards. The awards, which were discontinued in 1976 becuase of the state's financial problems, will be presented March 13 in Albany.

title: GOULD INVESTORS TRUST reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a loss of $43,000 from the disposition of rental properties and mortgages. c-Includes a gain of $50,000, or 4 cents a share.

title: U.S. Namibia Mission to Monitor Disengagement
description: The United States announced today that it was setting up a mission in Windhoek, the capital of South-West Africa, to help monitor the disengagement of South African and Angolan forces from the border area and to promote a lasting cease-fire.

title: INDAL LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Lung Cancer is Linked To Rise in Death Rates
description: Cancer death rates would have declined over the last three decades in the United States if it were not for an increase in lung cancer and other cancers related to smoking, according to a report issued Tuesday by the Environmental Protection Agency and the National Cancer Institute.

title: Around the World; Brunei Celebrates Freedom From Britain
description: The tiny southeast Asian sultanate of Brunei formally celebrated its independence from Britain today before kings and leaders from some 70 countries.

title: Flamingo Outlook Intensifies
description: There are still 72 days until the Kentucky Derby, but here at Hialeah it feels like only 9. The Derby is traditionally run on the first Saturday in May, but it will seem as if the race has been moved up to the first Saturday in March when Devil's Bag and Dr. Carter meet in the Flamingo Stakes March 3.

title: Concert: Da Capo Players
description: The Da Capo Chamber Players' "salute" to British contemporary music Tuesday night at Carnegie Recital Hall may not have been the widest-ranging, most up-to-date survey imaginable: Too many of the pieces were in over-familiar idioms, composed 10 or 20 years ago and unrepresentative of even their own composers' best work. But the concert was easily redeemed at the end with a performance of yet another major work -is "masterpiece" too strong fro a score only two years old? - by the man who has clearly established himself as the dominant figure in British music today, Peter Maxwell Davies.

title: LAUREL ENTERTAINMENT reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income

title: Sports People; Drug-Related Slump
description: The Atlanta Braves' Claudell Washington, who completed a drug rehabilitation program last fall, took part in his first spring workout yesterday and said he used cocaine "semi-regularly" last season and blamed the drug abuse for his prolonged slump.

title: Contraceptive Risks Assessed
description: A comprehensive medical study indicates that women who use contraceptives face no increased risk of death, researchers at the Federal Centers for Disease Control said today.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article about the Engelhard Corporation in some copies of the Business People column on Wednesday incorrectly described the merger between Salomon Brothers and Philipp Brothers. Philipp took over Salomon.

title: New York Day by Day; Still Dealing at 94
description: "On your 100th birthday," Edward S. Gordon said to one of his vice presidents, Henry Baker, "we'll have a party for you in Madison Square Garden."

title: Restaurants; A tiny bistro in the Village.
description: LE CAFE DE LA GARE has all the trappings trucked away on Perry Street, near Washington Street, almost as far west as you can go in Greenwich Village, surrounded by semi-industrial buildings and a scattering of brownstones. A brass-and -wrought-iron French bakers rack holds loaves of bread at the back of the dining room, the tables are covered with red-checkered cloths, the stucco walls and pressed-tin ceiling are painted peach, and the young chef works in a kitchen that only a Manhattan apartment dweller would put up with.

title: Art: Ella Bergmann On Her Own at Last
description: During her lifetime, the German artist Ella Bergmann (1896-1971) almost always exhibited with her husband, the artist Robert Michel - and, in fact, she joined her name to his, as Ella Bergmann-Michel. Yet many feel that as an artist, her talent was superior. Though taking no stand in the matter, for its current show of her inventive abstract drawings (through March 17), the Virginia Zabriskie Gallery, 724 Fifth Avenue, at 57th Street, has nevertheless seen fit to give back to the artist - alone at last - her own unhyphenated name.

title: Campaign Notes; G.O.P. Women Form A Speakers' Group
description: Betty Heitman, a leader of the Republican National Committee, today announced the formation of a 38-member group of women to give speeches around the country supporting the re-election of President Reagan.

title: Around the Nation; Reactors Restarted After 4 Breakdowns
description: Four reactor shutdowns in four days, one set off by a slamming door and two by workers jarring equipment, have prompted the Nuclear Regulatory Commission to order an extensive review at Florida Power and Light Company's Turkey Point generating station.

title: Advertising; Chiat/Day Adds Drexel
description: Chiat/Day, which has won eight accounts during the last 12 months, added a ninth in the New York office yesterday - Drexel Burnham Lambert.

title: KATHLEEN HOAGLAND
description: Kathleen Hoagland, an author who wrote on Irish themes, died Tuesday in Rutherford, N.J., where she had lived for 50 years.

title: Sports People; Young Ponders Choice
description: Steve Young, the all-American quarterback from Bringham Young, said he was seriously considering an offer from the Los Angeles Express of the United States Football League but was finding it hard to give up his dream of playing in the National Football League. "I'm struggling, he said after visiting the Express offices in Los Angeles.

title: War on Drugs: A Cry From the Trenches
description: To the Editor:

title: Panel Urges State to Let Sloan-Kettering Get New Scanner
description: An advisory council urged the New York State Health Commissioner yesterday to reverse himself and permit the Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center to acquire a nuclear magnetic resonance scanner, an expensive diagnostic device.

title: North Western Bonds Priced
description: A $75 million issue of the Chicago and North Western Transportation Company's 14 1/4 percent consolidated mortgage bonds due in 2004 is offered at a price of 98.43, to yield 14.50 percent, through underwriters led by Salomon Brothers.

title: Bristol to Be Sold
description: The Bristol Corporation said it had agreed to be acquired by the W-H Corporation, a closely held investment company based in Houston, for $16 a share, or a total of $42.9 million. Bristol, which makes plumbing, wire and cable products, said the merger would be considered by shareholders at a meeting scheduled in May.

title: ENERGY RESOURCES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $51,000 for the quarter and $38,000 for the 6 months.

title: Lebanese Delegate Supports Proposal for New U.N. Force
description: Lebanon's representative here gave qualified support today to a French proposal to send an international force to the Beirut area.

title: GALAXY OIL CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a $6,500,000 writedown of oil and gas properties.

title: Business Digest; Friday, February 24, l984
description: The Economy

title: 3 MORE ARRESTED IN SHOOTING OF OFFICER ON STAKEOUT
description: Three more people were arrested yesterday and charged with attempted murder in the shooting Monday of a plainclothes police officer on a stakeout in a vacant Harlem apartment.

title: WILEY, JOHN & SONS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Share earnings and shares outstanding for the latest periods reflect the sale of 418,000 shares of Class A common stock in July 1983. Net income for the year-ago periods reflect charges for foreign currency losses of $797,000 for the quarter and $1,408,000 for the 9 months.

title: Pepsico Units May Be Sold
description: Pepsico Inc. said that it was considering selling its transportation business, which consists of North American Van Lines Inc. and the Lee Way Motor Freight Company.

title: Democrats Vie for Position In Calm, Mannerly Debate
description: In the most mannerly debate of the Democratic Presidential campaign, Walter F. Mondale, John Glenn and Gary Hart maneuvered for position tonight in what increasingly has become perceived as a three-way contest in the New Hampshire primary next Tuesday.

title: Connecticut Weighs What to Do About G.E. Pact
description: There have been meetings with the Air Force, sessions to plan strategy and plenty of hand-wringing.

title: Behavior Modification Is Not Brainwashing
description: To the Editor:

title: KIRK COLLINS
description: Kirk Collins, a cornerback for the Los Angeles Rams football team, died Wednesday at Anaheim Memorial Hospital of gastroeasophageal cancer.

title: WINN ENTERPRISES reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Including a nonrecurring gain of $7.6 million from the sale of a hotel. Revenue increases reflect the acquisition in 1983 of Knudsen Corp. of Los Angeles and Mountainwest Savings & Loan Assn. of Ogden, Utah.

title: Pillsbury Realignment
description: The Pillsbury Company said yesterday that it had formed a new executive office. Winston R. Wallin, who was the company's president, becomes vice chairman.

title: General Felt Buys Stake in Masonite
description: General Felt Industries said yesterday that it had bought 6.3 percent of the shared of the Masonite Corporation and might seek to acquire the rest of the company.

title: CANADA SOUTHERN PETROEUM LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss. The company is listed on the Pacific, Toronto, Montreal, Boston, and Philadelphia stock exchanges.

title: Fed Opposes Check Delays
description: The Federal Reserve Board yesterday asked banks not to offer to delay the disbursement of checks for their customers, a process it called an "unsafe and unsound banking practice.

title: Hungary Reports Crime Rise
description: Crime in Hungary rose 8.4 percent in 1983 compared with the previous year, officials said today. The public prosecutor, Karoly Szijarto, said 151,000 known criminal acts were recorded last year, 30 percent of them "serious."

title: Stage: Two Actors In 'Woza Albert'
description: IN "Woza Albert" a new theater piece from South Africa, the gifted actors Percy Mtwa and Mbongeni Ngema play a wide variety of roles in a mosaic of roughly two dozen scenes. One of those scenes seems to summon up all the cruelty of apartheid.

title: CROWN CORK & SEAL CO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
DEAN FOODS CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: 1983 figures represent results for a 53-week period.

title: CORRECTION
description: A news analysis articlein Metropolitan Report Feb. 13 about defects in the city's bus fleet misstate d the number of buses bought by the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey for the Transit Authority. The purchases, since l980, have numbered l,354.

title: Around the World; Philippine Judge Orders Recess in Ambush Trial
description: A judge today ordered a week-long recess in the trial of nine churchmen, including three priests, accused of ambushing and killing a mayor and four aides in 1982.

title: Yaakov Levinson, 52; Israel Banker a Suicide
description: Yaakov Levinson, an Israeli banker, committed suicide today. He was 52 years old.

title: Art: Political Subjects
description: The New Museum of Contemporary Art, at 583 Broadway, near Houston Street, sees it as its responsibility to mount topical and controversial exhibitions. "Art and Ideology," on through March 18, approaches the loaded issue art and politics from a particular point of view that really does not lend itself to a gallery or museum exhibition at all.

title: Federated Fills Post
description: Norman S. Matthews, 51 years old, executive vice president of Federated Department Stores, was elected yesterday as a vice chairman and a director. The company has two other vice chairmen, Donald J. Stone and Will M. Storey.

title: Scouting; One of the Guys
description: The Milwaukee Brewers, American League champions in 1982, dropped to fifth place last season in the American League East, costing Harvey Kuenn his job as manager. His replacement is Rene Lachemann, who was let go as manager in Seattle last June, less than a year after leading the Mariners to a 76-86 record, the best in their seven-year history.

title: Required Reading
description: Runaway Spending

title: Israeli Planes Bomb Targets Near Beirut
description: Israeli planes bombed targets in the mountains east of Beirut today in what the Israeli radio said was an attack on Palestinian guerrilla bases.

title: CAPITAL HOLDING CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
FIRST CITY FINANCIAL CORP (VANCOUVER) reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes an extraordinary gain of $4,700,000. c-Includes an extraordinary gain of $3,100,000.

title: ROBERT P. KOENIG, ENGINEER HAD HEADED MINING CONCERN
description: Robert P. Koenig, a mining engineer and a former president of the Cerro Corporation, died Tuesday during a cruise to Singapore. He was 79 years old and lived in Oyster Bay, L.I.

title: JESSAMYN WEST, AUTHOR OF STORIES ABOUT QUAKERS IN INDIANA, DIES
description: Jessamyn West, the author of popular short stories and novels about Quakers set in her native Indiana, including ''The Friendly Persuasion,'' died here early today. She was 81 years old.

title: HARCOURT BRACE JOVANOVICH INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss

title: Pizza Time Talks
description: Pizza Time Theater Inc. said it is talking with several companies in an effort to sell its Sente Technologies Games subsidiary. Pizza Time, which posted losses last year, said it was planning to sell the unit because it has been under financial pressure. "We are not in a position to support the growth of Sente," the company said.

title: Advertising; Doyle Dane Is Agent For I.B.M. at Networks
description: The International Business Machines Corporation has two ad agencies, Doyle Dane Bernbach and Lord, Geller, Federico, Einstein, a subsidiary of the JWT Group. Until last year, each had a piece of the corporate assignment as well, with D.D.B. doing the the television advertising and Lord, Geller, the print.

title: Foli Eager to Aid Yanks Despite Contract Dispute
description: Tim Foli may or may not have a guaranteed contract with the Yankees through 1987. He may or may not have regular position with the Yankees this year. Whatever, Foli refuses to worry about those matters. He arrived in the Yankee camp today with one intention: getting ready for the season.

title: HARRY FISDELL, 56, NEW YORK OFFICIAL OF NEWSPAPER GUILD
description: Harry Fisdell, local representative of the Newspaper Guild of New York and its executive vice president from 1975 to 1980, died of a heart attack Wednesday at his home in Little Neck, L.I. He was 56 years old.

title: While Koch Travels in Europe, Mayor' Brezenoff Is in Charge
description: When Deputy Mayor Stanley Brezenoff arrived at Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center on Monday afternoon to visit a wounded police officer, hospital employees recognized him and asked whether the Mayor would be coming. They didn't know that the Mayor was already there-- Mayor'Brezenoff, that is.

title: AMERICAN BANKERS INSURANCE GROUP INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Judge Rules for Cribbs
description: A Federal Judge ruled today that Joe Cribbs, the verteran running back of the Buffalo Bills, could jump to the United States Football League and play for the Birmingham Stallions. One immediate effect of the decision was to place Cribbs in a Stallion uniform for the team's season opener, on Sunday at Birmingham against the Generals.

title: Stocks Cut Losses In Heavy Trading
description: The stock market, in a dramatic late turnaround, managed to pare some of its earlier sharp losses and finish mixed in the heaviest trading in more than two weeks.

title: Campaign Diplomacy
description: Both the President and his opponents have worked out the ground rules for this year's campaign diplomacy. Although each side will huffily deny collusion, these eight precepts have been agreed to:

title: New York Day by Day; Like Mail in January
description: Insult-added-to-injury department: The notice of the Jan. 23 meeting of the Federation of Jewish Philanthropies was mailed to Representative Bill Green on Jan. l3. It arrived in his office on Feb. 13.

title: Trial Delay Predicted
description: An attorney for five former soldiers charged with killing four American churchwomen says his petition for new testimony could postpone the long-delayed trial another year.

title: Advertising; Science 84 Is Seeking Ads for Special Issue
description: In November, the American Association for the Advancement of Science will celebrate the fifth anniversary of its consumer magazine - currently called Science 84 - with a special issue on the theme "20 Discoveries That Shaped the 20th Century."

title: Quotation of the Day
description: "He is a rather charming man, although he is not of a party that I have the highest regard for." --Mayor Koch, speaking of Mayor Ugo Vetere of Rome, a Communist.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Chapman Energy Inc., a Dallas-based oil and gas exploration company, said it had agreed to acquire Rodman Inc., a closely held oil and gas concern in Oklahoma City, for about $10 million.

title: Union Chiefs Confident of Mondale in the Primary
description: Political operatives from unions around the country, privately exuberant over labor's role in the victory of Walter F. Mondale in the Iowa caucuses, are confident that labor will deliver again for Mr. Mondale in New Hampshire.

title: BENTLEY STONE, BALLET TEACHER
description: Bentley Stone, a ballet teacher and dancer, died of a stroke on Feb. 10 in Northwestern Memorial Hospital in Chicago. He was 75 years old.

title: CALLAHAN MINING CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes a gain of $810,000 from the sale of discontinued operations. Year-ago share earnings are adjusted for a 3 percent stock dividend paid April 1, 1983.

title: Subway Doors Opened 32 Times On Moving Trains, Report Shows
description: Car doors opened on moving subway trains at least 32 times in the last 21 months, according to reports filed with the Transit Authority.

title: French Truckers Want Some Respect
description: It was just before noon. A nasty wind from the north snapped at the men standing alongside the trucks parked across the highway. Loulou from Aulnay - reddish sideburns, burgundy leather jacket, yellow cowboy boots - came forward and explained just what would happen if the Government used force to break up the drivers' blockades that are paralyzing the French road network.

title: The Region; Elevator Mishap Kills L .I. Student
description: A 19-year-old Syracuse University student was killed today when he was caught between a dormitory's elevator doors and dragged 30 feet before falling to his death, according to the police.

title: Durables Orders Rise 1.1%
description: Factory orders for durable goods rose 1.1 percent during January, spurred by a huge jump in demand for steel and other metals, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: Around the World; Solidarity Radio Appeals For Election Boycott
description: The Solidarity radio went on the air in Warsaw tonight for the first time since October to broadcast an appeal by underground leaders for a boycott of local government elections in June.

title: Making a Campaign Issue of Reagan Work Habits
description: The Presidential news conference Wednesday night brought the nation the rare sight of President Reagan, an enormously self-confident politician, being asked to defend his performance in the White House and out West at his ranch.

title: Around the Nation; Detroit Layoff Policy Declared Discriminatory
description: The seniority layoff policy used by the Detroit Police Department takes away gains made by minorities through affirmative action policies, Federal Judge Horace Gilman ruled Wednesday.

title: Dining Out Guide: Chinese in Midtown
description: Following is a summary of reviews of restaurants that have appeared in The New York Times. Stars are followed by the date of original publication. Prices are current.

title: Arkansas Wins by 6
description: Four Arkansas players were in double figures to pace a 55-49 Southwest Conference victory over Texas Tech tonight, setting up an important game with Houston Sunday. The Razorbacks, 22-4 overall, raised their conference mark to 12-1.

title: A Myopic U.A.W. Bill
description: Two decades ago, the common wisdom was that "what is good for General Motors is good for the country." Until this misconception was, fortunately, reappraised, it guided Government action. Now, the United Automobile Workers would have us believe that what is good for the U.A.W. is good for the public. The union is not only wrong but also shortsighted. The public, is one of the losers.

title: Bishops Protest Train Carrying Atom Weapons
description: Twelve Roman Catholic bishops in the West urged their parishioners today to join a "prayer vigil" along the route of trains carrying nuclear warheads to Trident submarine bases in Washington State and South Carolina.

title: ROLLAND INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss.

title: BACARDI CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Sales figures represent sales net of excise taxes.

title: DR PEPPER CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss. Year-ago results are restated for a pooling-of-interests acquisition.

title: Play About Dahlberg
description: "Miss Lizzie," a play by Luigia Miller based on the life of the writer Edward Dahlberg, wil begin performances tomorrow at 8 P.M. at the Baldwin School, 160 West 74th Street.

title: DATAPOINT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-Includes a gain of $741,000 for the quarter and year from the early extinguishment of debt.

title: Reagan Campaign Is Reported to Have Chosen Della Femina for Advertising
description: Jerry Della Femina, a New York advertising executive known for his irreverent style, is expected to be chosen director of advertising for President Reagan's re-election campaign, according to knowledgeable officials.

title: WINKELMAN STORES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 28
Iraq Says Its Forces Have Crushed A Major Iranian Drive Near Basra
description: Iraq said today that its forces had crushed an Iranian attack near the southern Iraqi oil port of Basra.

title: Conoco's Alaska Oil Production
description: Conoco Inc., a unit of E.I. du Pont de Nemours & Company, said crude oil production would begin in early 1986 from the Milne Point field on Alaska's North Slope at an initial rate of 30,000 barrels a day. Conoco operates the field, in which it has a 60 percent interest.

title: Emhart Names New President
description: The Emhart Corporation said yesterday that it had named William C. Lichtenfels, 56 years old, as president and chief operating officer.

title: LCS INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
TOCOM INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
I.C.I. Earnings Double
description: Imperial Chemical Industries, Britain's largest industrial company, said today that pretax profit more than doubled in 1983, to the equivalent of $897.5 millin, from $375.5 million in 1982. Revenues also soared, to $25 billion, from $13.1 billion. Pharmaceutical and agricultural product sales, especially in the United States, accounted for the bulk of the profit increase.

title: Economic Scene; Market Slide: Impact Spreads
description: Election years are supposed to be good for the securities markets, but 1984 is proving to be an exception. At the start of the year, there was a brief run-up in the stock market, with the Dow Jones Industrials almost reaching 1,300 on Jan. 9. But that was the top. Since then, there has been a steady grinding down of values, with the Dow at ,134.63 yesterday.

title: Around the Nation; Trial in Gang Rape Case Opens in Massachusetts
description: Several men in a bar here "were cheering like at a baseball game" while they watched fellow patrons rape a woman last March, the prosecution said today at the opening of the trial in the case.

title: BLAIR, JOHN & CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Results for the latest quarter include recurring costs equal to 20 cents a share from the relocation of the company's New York based offices.

title: U.S. Air Force Procurement's Thrifty Ways
description: To the Editor:

title: IMMUNO NUCLEAR CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
Campaign Notes; 5th Republican Enters Utah Governor Race
description: State Senator Karl Snow, a professor of public administration at Brigham Young University, announced his candidacy Wednesday to succeed Scott M. Matheson, a Democrat, as Governor.

title: Women Add a Certain Pizazz to Portugal's Politics
description: When feminist groups in Portugal look back over the past 10 years, the victories they count up would make women in the United States gape in astonishment.

title: Jo Durie Upset by Miss Mesker in 3 Sets
description: Marcella Mesker has been in this northern New Jersey community for so long that she knows every restaurant along Route 10 and has already done her laundry three times.

title: Cowboy Music
description: Junior Daughterty, a fiddler, singer and guitarist who has won more than 200 fiddle contests, will perform cowboy songs and Western swing tunes tonight at 8 at the Alternative Museum (966-4444), 17 White Street in TriBeCa. Tickets are $7, or a Theater Development Fund voucher and $2.

title: INQUIRY IS CLOSED ON CARTER PAPERS
description: The Justice Department said today that it had found "no credible evidence" that a crime was committed when Ronald Reagan's 1980 political campaign obtained briefing materials prepared for President Carter.

title: Music: Classical; 5 Grand Voices Of Concert Scene
description: "My voice is a gift from God and nature," the bass-baritone Simon Estes said last week. "I think I was given a very unusual voice." "I think my personality and the sound of my voice go together, hand in hand," the soprano Kathleen Battle said.

title: Music: Pop; A Coloratura Jazz Singer
description: MAUREEN McGOVERN is a rarity in pop music-a late bloomer. Still typed in some people's minds as "the disaster singer" and "the movie-theme queen," for her recordings of songs for "The Poseidon Adventure" "The Towering Inferno" and 'Superman," the 34-year-old singer has only recently shown herself to be a vocal wonder woman, at ease in any idiom from classical to jazz.

title: New York Day by Day; Singing With a Point
description: Just as Miriam Friedlander, a City Council member, was about to testify, a woman strode forward, pushed her aside, placed a cassette tape recorder on the podium, turned it on and --to the tune of "Hello, Dolly"--began singing what she called a "Strip-a-Gram."

title: The Evening Hours
description: For Bella Abzug, the setting for her book-signing party could not have been more appropriate. "This house," she said. "We were here when Eleanor was here."

title: Key Rates
description: Kenny Index, Kenny Information SystemsSalomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: How to Abolish Parole
description: New York's parole system, already under serious attack, probably cannot survive its apparently fatal lapse in leaving George Acosta on the streets last week to face a charge of murdering a police officer. Edward Hammock, the Parole Board chairman, has been properly held accountable by Governor Cuomo for the failure to respond when Mr. Acosta's parole status should have been reviewed.

title: Sports People; Flyers Trade Holmgren
description: Paul Holmgren, a 27-year-old wing who signed a new two-year contract with the Philadelphia Flyers yesterday afternoon, was traded last night to the Minnesota North Stars for Paul Guay, a member of the United States Olympic Team, and a third-round choice in the 1985 draft. Holmgren, who was drafted by the Flyers from the University of Minnesota in the fifth round in 1975, played in two All-Star games and is regarded as one of the league's more effective power-play specialists.

title: TORONTO DOMINION BANKS (CANADA) reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: The company is listed on the Toronto, Montreal and Vancouver stock exchanges.

title: The City; Charges Widened Against City Aide
description: Federal prosecutors announced yesterday that a grand jury had expanded corruption charges against Alex Liberman, New York City's director of lease negotiations.

title: Feb. 11-20 Car Sales Jumped 73.3%
description: Sales of new American-made cars soared 73.3 percent in the mid-February selling period from a year erlier, the manufacturers reported today.

title: Coleco Hires Executive To Head Its Adam Unit
description: Charles Winterble has been hired from Commodore International to take charge of electronic products deveopment at Coleco Industries.

title: Agee and 2 Partners Form Software Venture
description: William M. Agee, the former corporate chieftain, has joined with two other executives to form a new computer software company called Uniform Software Systems.

title: CROWN CENTRAL PETROLEUM CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Caution Urged on Networks In Projecting Voting Results
description: The chairman of the House Telecommunications Subcomittee recommended today that the nation's three television networks show restraint in broadcasting election results before voters have cast their ballots.

title: Scouting; Ray a General?
description: Darrol Ray, going into his option year with the Jets, will sign a contract before training camp starts, his agent Gary Wichard, said yesterday. But Wichard hinted that could also mean the New Jersey Generals.

title: BELL NATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a charge of $2,200,000 due to the cumulative effect on prior years of a change in loan fee income recognition.

title: Around the World; Heavy Combat Reported Near Cambodian Camp
description: Vietnamese troops and Cambodian rebels battled today near a major camp of the non-Communist Khmer People's National Liberation Front, Thai military sources reported.

title: DREYFUS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Year-ago share earnings are restated to reflect a 2-for-1 stock split distributed in October 1983.

title: Nelson Schaenen Dies at 81; FormerHeadofSmithBarney
description: Nelson Schaenen, retired president of Smith Barney & Company, investment bankers, died Wednesday of complications following surgery at New York University Medical Center. He was 81 years old and lived in Delray Beach, Fla.

title: Sports of The Times: Carol Lewis, Herself
description: When Carol Lewis was younger, she papered every inch of her bedroom with photographs of her favorite performers, always reserving the place of honor for Mikhail Baryshnikov.

title: WRIGHT-HARGREAVES MINES LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Including special gains of $795,000 for the quarter and $6,681,000 for the year.

title: Israelis Worry About an Iran Victory
description: Both Israeli military intelligence specialists and civilian analysts expressed concern today over Iran's current offensive into Iraq and the apparent intensity of the fighting.

title: The Region; Police Seize Drugs Worth $15 Million
description: Two men charged with possession of 82 1/2 pounds of cocaine were arrested today in a state police campaign that has netted 20 suspects and $25 million in cocaine since Jan. 1, authorities said.

title: Applications by Unemployed For Benefits Steady in Week
description: A total of 344,000 new applications for unemployment checks were filed in the week ended Feb. 11, the same as in the previous week, the Labor Department reported today.

title: MYERS INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Belgian Prices Up
description: Belgian wholesale prices rose eight-tenths of 1 percent last month from December, putting prices 10.9 percent above the January l983 level, the Economics Ministry said today.

title: MEDTRONIC INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Israel Bids U.S. Explain Contacts With P.L.O.
description: Israel asked the Reagan Administration today for an official explanation of the nine months of secret contacts the Administration had with the Palestine Liberation Organization through an American intermediary, an Israeli Embassy spokesman said today.

title: Market Place; Nuclear Problems Of Utilities
description: The decision to buy, sell or hold shares of electric utility companies facing difficulties with nuclear plant construction has confronted many investors in recent months. Some stocks have dropped sharply as a result, but the decision-making process continues unabated.

title: REBEL ARMY UNITS TAKE UP POSITIONS IN WESTERN BEIRUT
description: Rebel units of the Lebanese Army reappeared on the streets of West Beirut today under the control of Shiite and Druse militia leaders opposed to President Amin Gemayel.

title: New York Day by Day; What's in a Name ?
description: Overheard in Gotham: Earnest waiter to customer at the Century Cafe: "Try the linguini --it's very straightforward."

title: The Region; Racial Bias Denied By State Police
description: There is no discrimination against black and Hispanic recruits by the New York State Police, the division's superintendent said today in response to charges by the United States Justice Department.

title: Sights on Gnat in Budgetary Swarm
description: It is somewhat symptomatic of the wondrous ways of Congress that some lawmakers, casting around for ways to reduce President Reagan's proposed $925.5 billion budget, have zeroed in on one of the least costly of all federally financed programs: the $15 million annual expenditure for Presidential libraries.

title:
ABOUT REAL ESTATE ;
MIDTOWN CONDOMINIUMS STRESS TOWERS' 'SMALLNESS'
description: It is location, developers usually say, that determines the appeal of a property, but the builders of two residential condominiums in tall midtown Manhattan towers assert that, for those who can afford it, ''smallness'' is an additional cachet.

title: Livestock Close Mixed; Meat Prices Off Sharply CURRENCY MARKETS; Dollar Declines Again; Gold Prices are Mixed
description: Prices of livestock futures were mixed and meat prices were sharply lower yest

title: Islanders Defeat Blues, 5-1
description: It seemed like old times for Islander fans. There was Mike Bossy, scoring the go-ahead goal for the Islanders late in the second period. Then, in the three-goal Islander third period, there was Brian Trottier scoring with an assist from Bossy at 13 minutes 4 seconds. And in the net, there was Billy Smith, turning back 31 St. Louis shots in near-playoff form.

title: Diner's Journal
description: GREAT SHANGHAI is a nine-month-old restaurant at 27 Division Street in the heart of Chinatown, with an ambience something like Grand Central Terminal on the Friday night of a holiday weekend. It specializes in the maritime cuisine of Shanghai, and one of its best dishes is Oriental fondue, which features impeccably fresh seafood, as well a host of other ingredients.

title: EDITORS' NOTE
description: Under this heading, The Times amplifies articles or rectifies what the editors consider significant lapses of fairness, balance or perspective.

title: Serling's Best TV Plays at Museum
description: To people raised on television, Rod Serling is still the narrator of "The Twilight Zone," that series of O. Henryesque stories in which aliens turn out to be human, humans find out they are mannequins and space travelers who reach forbidding planets discover they are really on earth.

title: CRONUS INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $692,000 for the quarter and $797,000 for the year. c-Net income which includes income of $583,000 from discontinued operations. d-Includes income of $1,322,000 from discontinued operations. Year-ago results are restated to reflect the discontinuance of the company's agricultural equipment segment.

title: PLESSEY CO PLO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 30
description: Share earnings are per American Depositary Receipt.

title: Eek-a-Mouse to Sing
description: The reggae singer Eek-a-Mouse will perform tomorrow at Irving Plaza (477-3728), 17 Irving Place, at 15th Street. Tickets are $10, and music will begin sometime after midnight.

title: U.S.-E.E.C. Trade Talks
description: American negotiators will make a final effort next week to resolve a trade dispute with the European Economic Community over specialty steel, officials on both sides today.

title: HARSCO CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
America, Be Patient With the Philippines
description: The scenario unfolding in the Philippines looks depressingly familiar. Vast protest movements fill the streets of Manila. An authoritarian President shows signs of physical deterioration. Armed Moslems and Communists battle the military in the countryside. The security forces had some, unexplained role in the murder of the opposition leader Benigno S. Aquino Jr. Moderate opposition leaders call for the removal of American military bases vital to the strategic balance in Southeast Asia. The national debt is more than $25 billion and an enormous payment or reluctant rescheduling must take place this year.

title: Two Key Interstate Links in Massachusetts
description: To the Editor:

title: The Right String for El Salvador
description: Is George Shultz making a liar out of George Bush? In December, the Vice President journeyed to El Salvador with a warning: Cleanse the armed forces of the death-squad killers or forfeit hope of more American aid. There has been no cleansing. Yet now the Secretary of State unashamedly resurrects some vly-blown arguments to jultify a further flood of aid without even a string attached.

title: Fruehauf Recalls 220
description: The Omaha plant of the Fruehauf Corporation has recalled 220 furloughed employees to meet increased demand for tank trailers and to build portable bridges for the Army, according to the plant's manager, Richard Glazer. employees to meet increased demand for tank trailers and to build portable bridges for the Army, according to the plant's manager, Richard Glazer.

title: JLG INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
H.U.D. WON'T RENEW GRANT FOR AGENCY IN SOUTH BRONX
description: The Department of Housing and Urban Development will no longer automatically renew a $1 million grant to the South Bronx Development Organization, officials said today.

title: Basque Politician Assassinated
description: Hooded gunmen shot and killed a prominent Socialist politician today, and officials in Madrid said the act appeared to be an effort to disrupt the elections Sunday in the Basque region.

title: Sports People; Happy Homecoming
description: Scott Hamilton and Rosalynn Sumners were given rousing welcomes when they arrived home after the Winter Olympics. Hamilton, who won a gold medal in men's figure skating, was greeted by about 500 people when he arrived in Denver, and Miss Sumners, the women's figure-skating silver medalist from Edmonds, Wash., was welcomed by a crowd of about 300 in Seattle.

title: U.S. Leads in Davis Cup
description: John McEnroe and Jimmy Connors, America's top two tennis players, defeated their Rumanian opponents today in the first round of the Davis Cup to give the United States a 2-0 lead.

title: CONSUMER PRICES UP 0.6% IN MONTH, MOST SINCE APRIL
description: A surge in food prices pushed the Consumer Price Index up six-tenths of 1 percent in January, the largest increase since April, the Labor Department reported today.

title: DUQUESNE SYSTEMS reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
SHAER SHOE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss.

title: ARTILLERY BATTLES ERUPT IN LEBANON, ENDING BRIEF LULL
description: Heavy exchanges of tank and artillery fire erupted across a broad front here tonight, ending a daylong lull in fighting that followed a cease-fire announced by a Saudi mediator.

title: DOW SOARS 30.47 AFTER LONG SLIDE
description: Stock prices exploded upward yesterday when a sharp technical correction sent many of the recently depressed issues soaring in very heavy trading.

title: LONG ACTIVE IN POLITICS, WOMAN RUNS FOR HOUSE
description: In 16 years in public life Dudley W. Dudley has worked for scores of Democratic candidates, served two terms in the State Legislature and is in her fourth term as the only woman ever to serve on the five-member Governor's Council.

title: MAN, 23, FREED FROM CITY JAIL, HELD IN MURDER
description: A man released from jail last November after a Federal court ordered a reduction of the population in the city's jails was charged yesterday with murdering a friend.

title: DEATH IN AUTO ACCIDENT TESTS FANS OF THE BRUINS
description: At 6 o'clock one recent evening radio station WHDH was preparing for the dinnertime lull in its call-in show, ''The Mike Miller Program.'' The host threw out a question to encourage debate, and the usually quiet segment was suddenly filled with agitated participants.

title: CRUTCHER RESOURCES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Including a gain of $841,000 from the early extinguishment of industrial bonds.

title: PATENTS
description: Generating Low-Cost Electricity

title: PLAN WOULD TRIM REAGAN ARMS PLAN
description: Congressional negotiators agreed today to consider a leading Senate Republican's proposal to cut President Reagan's request for military spending authority next year.

title: SCOUTING
description: Power Memorial Has New Setback

title: GTI CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $38,000 for the quarter and $277,000 for the year.

title: WASHINGTON REAL ESTATE INVESTMENT TRUST reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31

title: TV: WATCHING BIRDS IN THEIR NESTS
description: ''The Masterbuilders,'' part of public television's ''Nature'' series, is distinguished by its fine photography - of birds, their nests and their behavior. Some birds build scarcely any nests at all; they do not need them. Others build architecturally sound structures, the works, we are told, ''of true craftsmen.'' This pleasant film, although it may seem to be focusing only on nests, is looking at avian society, its mores and customs as well. It will be shown on Channel 13 tomorrow night at 8 o'clock.

title: CHERNENKO IS SALUTED AS A FRIEND OF THE ARMY
description: Defense Minister Dmitri F. Ustinov said today that the selection of Konstantin U. Chernenko as party chief had the ''unanimous approval'' of the armed forces, and that Mr. Chernenko was giving ''great attention'' to strengthening Soviet defenses.

title: FRENCH TRUCKERS SOURLY LIFT BLOCKADES

Continental Illinois
description: Directors of the Continental Illinois Corporation are expected to consider replacing Roger E. Anderson, 62 years old, as the company's chairman and chief executive at a regular board meeting scheduled for Monday, according to banking sources in Chicago. The bank has been suffering from a high level of problem loans, especially to the energy industry, as the result of its aggressive lending policies during the 1970's and early 1980's.

title: Industrialist's Body Found
description: The body of an industrialist who disappeared with his wife in December was found in the Illinois River Thursday. Dental records were used to identify the man, Elmo Batterton, 55 years old, the police said. The police said they did not find the body of his wife, Edna Batterton, 59, or the couple's automobile, in which they were last seen Dec. 11. Mr. Batterton owned or had a major interest in farms, manufacturing concerns, a construction company, a grain company and real estate holdings.

title: Albert V. Olivieri, 70, Founder Of the Yoo-Hoo Beverage Co.
description: Albert V. Olivieri, founder and former president of the Yoo-Hoo Chocolate Beverage Company, died Tuesday. Mr. Olivieri, who was formerly of Hasbrouck Heights, lived in Hollywood, Fla., and was 70 years old.

title: Warner Seeking Re-election

He is unopposed for the Republican nomination and has raised over $1 million for his campaign. Only one Democrat has declared for the Senate seat held by the former Secretary of the Navy, Edythe Harrison of Norfolk, an outspoken civic activist.

title: Taiwan and Alaska Oil TAIPEI, Taiwan, Feb. 24 (AP) - Taiwan could help reduce its huge trade imbalance with the United States if it was allowed to purchase oil from Alaska, a Government official said today. Wu Mei-Tsun, Economic Deputy Minister, said at a news conference that he supported a proposal in the United States Senate to amend a law that currently bans the shipment of Alaskan crude oil to foreign countries. Taiwan had a record trade surplus of $6.68 billion last year, and this has led to United States demands for Taiwan to purchase more United States goods. ;  Bonn Trade Deficit
description: West Germany's current account slipped to a 600-million- mark deficit in January from a 5.5- billion-mark surplus in December, the federal Statistics Office said today. The deficit is the equivalent of about $228 million at current exchange rates.

title: CIULLA SUES OVER DISCLOSURE
description: Anthony Ciulla, the race-fixer and Government witness, filed suit against two major thoroughbred racing organizations and their officers yesterday for revealing his assumed identity and secret location.

title: S.E.C. INQUIRY AT CBS NEWS

description: Even among experimental modern- dance choreographers, Kenneth King ranks among the most cerebral. And yet the remarkable aspect about his work is how strongly it also appeals to the senses.

title: NO MAJOR DISEASES CITED IN AGENT ORANGE SPRAYERS
description: Veterans who sprayed the herbicide Agent Orange in the Vietnam War and sometimes got doused in it are not suffering from an abnormally high rate of major diseases but have some inexplicable health problems that must be watched, the Air Force said today.

title: President to Name Admiral As Head of Aviation Agency
description: President Reagan said today he would nominate Vice Adm. Donald Engen, retired, a staunch safety advocate who is a member of the National Transportation Safety Board, as the new head of the Federal Aviation Administration.

title: CABARET: MAUREEN MCGOVERN
description: During Maureen McGovern's program at Freddy's, 308 East 49th Street, where she will be singing through tonight, she projects an astonishing number of vocal personalities, each with a full individual definition. She uses a range that extends from a minimalist delivery that borders on Blossom Dearie (And why not? She is singing one of Miss Dearie's songs, ''I Like You, You're Nice.'') through a moving, darkly colored a capella treatment of ''The Last Time I Saw Paris'' to some Valkyrie whoops that blend with piccolo peeps on ''Stars and Stripes Forever.''

title: A RESIGNATION ATALEXANDER'S
description: Alexander Farkas, the 53-year-old president and chief executive officer of Alexander's Inc., will resign on July 28 to pursue other interests, the company said yesterday. Robin L. Farkas, chairman, said he would assume the chief executive post and that a new president would be sought for the major New York retail chain.

title: AUDITION LINE OF 2,000 FOR 'CHORUS LINE' FILM
description: Outside, there were mobs of hopefuls waiting on 45th street in a line that stretched down the block. Inside the Royale Theater, groups of dancers, their faces taut with tension, learned a quick routine and did their steps. Most would see their hopes evaporate more swiftly than the sweat on their faces.

The administration should avoid, at all costs, a repeat of the state's 1974 bailout of Consolidated Edison, in which the state forked over about $1 billion without any guarantees of reciprocal economic benefits from Con Ed.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST SATURDAY, FEBRUARY 25, 1984
description: The Economy Consumer prices rose 0.6 percent in January, the largest increase since April, pushed up by higher food prices. Economists said bad weather had caused the spurt in food prices and the data did not signal a resurgence of inflation. Nonetheless, inflation fears are growing. (Page 1.) Consumer prices in the metropolitan area rose 1 percent, largely because of increases in the costs of food, transit fares and fuel oil. (39.) Congressional negotiators agreed to discuss slowing the rise in military spending as one step toward reducing budget deficits. The suggestion was put forward by a Republican Senator, but the White House rejected it, at least initially. Democrats said the proposed slowdown, to 5 percent, from 13 percent, was not enough. (1.)

title: NEWS SUMMARY SATURDAY, FEBRUARY 25, 1984 International
description: A brief cease-fire in Lebanon was broken by heavy exchanges of tank and artillery fire across a broad front in Beirut. The fighting resumed after a cease-fire announced by a Saudi mediator. (Page 1, Column 6.) Assessment of the marines' mission in Beirut by military officers found that shelling by 16-inch guns on the battleship New Jersey was less effective than hoped, that a new device for spotting enemy artillery worked well and that the venerable C ration may be a thing of the past. Many officers also said that the biggest problem was that political leaders had not carefully defined the mission for the military, thus the mission was never fully understood down the chain of command and by the troops in the field. (1:5.)

title: U.S. EVALUATES BATTLE LESSONS IN MIDDLE EAST
description: Military officers, starting to assess 18 months of experience in Lebanon, have found that shelling by 16-inch guns on the battleship New Jersey was far less effective than hoped, that a new device for spotting enemy artillery worked well and that the venerable C ration may be a thing of the past.

title: Arrows Sell Grgurev
description: The Arrows have sold their top scorer, Fred Grgurev , to the Memphis Americans, apparently as part of a cost-cutting program by the financially strapped New York club. Grgurev, who has been tied with Stan Stamenkovic of Baltimore for the scoring leadership in the Major Indoor Soccer League, said he had been told by Arrow officials that his guaranteed three-year contract made him a logical choice for a trade. The Arrows, who did not say how much they were getting for Grgurev, said that the forward did not fit in with the mixed offense favored by their new coach, Jim McGeogh .

title: Honda-BL Car for U.S.
description: Honda, which got a foothold in the American auto market by selling one of the world's smallest cars, has decided to go after the more profitable luxury car market in the United States. The American Honda Motor Company will join with BL Ltd., the British maker of Jaguar cars, to produce an expensive sedan in Britain for export to the United States, a source at Honda said today. The new car will not carry the Honda name because the company wants the public to think of it as unrelated to Honda's small-car line, a spokesman said.

title: NUMISMATICS; A NAME CHANGE AT THE UNITED STATES MINT
description: In numismatic circles, the United States Mint has seldom been referred to by any other name. From now on, it's official. On Jan. 25,Mint Director Donna K. Pope announced that her agency had scrapped the old designation as the ''Bureau of the Mint'' and substituted ''United States Mint.'' ''I felt that the term 'bureau' was a confusing one to the public,'' Mrs. Pope explained. ''It did not clearly identify us as the historic Mint of the United States. Additionally, the 'bureau' designation conjures up too many negative images of the stereotyped bureaucrat, images which do not fit our aggressive marketing programs.'' Various private mints have sprung up in the last two decades. The Franklin Mint has become widely known among large segments of American society. To some extent, private mints have tended to blur distinction from the government mint. By simplifying its name, the United States Mint presumably hopes to underscore the difference. The legislation establishing the national mint, in 1792, referred to it simply as ''the Mint.'' Subsequent legislation, beginning the following year, expanded this name to ''Mint of the United States.'' With passage of the wide-ranging Coinage Act of 1873, it formally became a bureau of the Department of the Treasury. According to Mrs. Pope, the latest name change was approved by Treasury Secretary Donald T. Regan. In prior years, she noted, the U.S. Customs Service and the Internal Revenue Service both had discontinued use of the word ''bureau'' as part of their formal names.
