description: Four years ago, Tyrone almost never went to school. Now, the 11- year-old from Manhattan says he wants to be a ''computer genius.''

title: CATHOLICS AREN'T COLLARING ENOUGH PRIESTS
description: The flood of candidates that filled Roman Catholic seminaries 20 years ago has slowed to a trickle. The number of American priests is at an all-time low and some specialists in church affairs predict the clerical population will sink to half its present size by the year 2000.

title: BUILDING A WORLD'S FAIR
description: JOSEPH GIOVANNINI is a reporter for The New York Times.

title: AT 25, FRANCE'S NEW WAVE STILL SURGES THROUGH MOVIES
description: G ive or take a few months, this year is the 25th anniversary of the Nouvelle Vague, that New Wave of young French filmmakers who, first by their sometimes outrageous statements and then by the extraordinary films they made to support those statements, forever changed the look of - as well as the way we look at - movies.

title: DANCE: NEW 'COWBOYS' IN IMPROVISED WEST
description: Ishmael Houston-Jones and Fred Holland had an idea of great potential interest in their new ''Cowboys, Dreams and Ladders,'' performed Thursday at the Kitchen, where it will play through tonight. The improvisational theater-dance piece would explore images of the West, from real- life cowboys to childhood dreams. An added interest would be that those cowboys, like Mr. Houston-Jones and Mr. Holland, were black. But the 50- minute work never added up to more than the sum of its scattered individual parts.

title: THE LIMITS OF ISRAELI POWER MIRRORED IN LEBANON TURMOIL
description: JERUSALEM T HE full dimensions of the Israeli-American setback in Lebanon have not yet been realized but the outlines are being drawn with growing clarity. The implications go beyond Lebanon; they involve the capacity of the United States and Israel to influence the complex flow of events in the Middle East.

title: WEEK IN BUSINESS
description: The Supreme Court dealt a blow to organized labor when it ruled unanimously that a bankrutpcy judge can free a company from its labor contract obligations if the company can show the contracts are substantial ''burdens'' to its long-term recovery. Organized labor had sought to require companies to prove they were in imminent danger of failure before contracts could be broken. In a more divided opinion, the court ruled 5-to-4 that once a company has filed a bankrutpcy petition, it can unilaterally end all labor contracts, while it is waiting for the court's ultimate permission. The rulings involved the Bildisco Manufacturing Company of New Jersey and its 1980 bankruptcy filing, yet it supported actions by the Wilson Food Corporation, Braniff Airways and Continental Air Lines, which filed for Chapter 11 reorganization last year and unilaterally ended all contracts with their unions. The Court also gave a victory to the I.R.S. in its long-running battle over interest-free loans made by one family member to another. The court ruled that in such a loan, any forfeited interest on the part of the lender constitutes a ''gift'' to the recipient and is subject to Federal gift taxes.

title: THE REGION
description: A Reason Not To Lean on Doors

title: CRITICS' CHOICES
description: David Henry Hwang's ''The Dance and the Railroad,'' a lyrical dramatic ballad about the immigrant experience and the expansion of the American west, was an Off Broadway success in 1981, first at the New Federal Theater and subsequently at the New York Shakespeare Festival's Public Theater. The production alerted theatergoers to the artistry of the playwright and of John Lone, his leading actor, director and composer.

title: Nuts and Bolts
description: To the Editor:

title: Frances Scheller Engaged
description: Mr. and Mrs. Sanford G. Scheller of Wilton, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Frances Aileen Scheller, to Mark Steven Lavin, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Marcelino E. Lavin, also of Wilton. A June wedding is planned. The future bride's father is a vice president of the St. Regis Corporation in West Nyack, N.Y.

title: AIR RAIDS CLAIMED BY IRAN AND IRAQ
description: Iraq and Iran both reported air raids against civilian targets today and continued heavy fighting in the marshes along their southern border.

title: ISLANDERS WIN
description: Neither the Canadiens nor the Forum cause visitors much fear these days. The Canadiens, with 21 Stanley Cup banners hanging from their rafters, have lost 30 games this season - their most since the 1950-51 season. And they have lost 15 in the hallowed Forum, a team record.

title: THEATER: 'SPLIT SECOND,' A CRISIS OF CONSCIENCE
description: On a lonely West Side street a black policeman arrests a car thief, handcuffs him and waits for his backup patrol to arrive. The thief, who is white, tries to cajole the officer into releasing him, and after that approach fails he showers him with a torrent of racial insults. Silently, the policeman listens, and we can feel him bristling with years of suppressed rage. Finally, pushed past the breaking point, he takes out his revolver and shoots the man through the heart, turning off the stream of abuse.

title: Rally in a Brazilian City Asks Direct Elections of President
description: Tens of thousands of people staged a peaceful rally here Friday demanding that Brazil abolish its electoral college system and return to direct elections of the President.

title: DON'T 'CASH OUT' FOOD STAMPS
description: The report of the President's Task Force on Hunger recommended that the $13 billion- a-year food stamp program be ''cashed out'' and replaced by block grants to the states, which would then assume responsibility for distributing the money to the poor. The task force cited Puerto Rico's 18-month experience with a similar program, asserting that it had been a success well worth replicating in the United States. ''The elimination of food vouchers,'' the task force said, ''would make the system more efficient, simpler to manage, less expensive to administer and would reduce the stigma associated with participation.'' What such an approach would do, however, is fundamentally transform a food assistance program into an income-maintenance or guaranteed-income program. And this was far from Congress's original intent.

title: HART SAVORS THE SPOTLIGHT'S GLOW
description: CONCORD,N.H.

title: IDEAS & TRENDS
description: Either Way They Slice It, More Are Poor

title: SCHOOLYARD KILLER: CULT AND DRUGS SEEN AS CLUES
description: Police officials said today that they were still not sure why a former member of the People's Temple cult opened fire on a playground full of children Friday, but they speculated that the reason was rooted in drugs, alcohol and dark memories of the Rev. Jim Jones. ''We really don't know what his motive was,'' Sgt. Tony Sanchez of the Los Angeles Police Department said, ''but we've been told he had a reputation for acting irrationally sometimes.''

title: The Traffic Prevention Department
description: Thank you, Nelson Burack, for dicovering and bringing to light the T.P.D. - the Traffic Prevention Department - in your article Jan. 8 (''The Secret Traffic Department,'' Opinion Page). Many of us have wondered who or what was behind the apparent conspiracy to inhibit the traffic flow on Long Island. You have found them - the T.P.D.

title: ART FOR POLITICS' SAKE GETS SHELTERED UNDERGROUND
description: Since the crushing of Solidarity by martial law - the war, it is always called here - many of Poland's writers, actors, artists and other intellectuals have gone into ''internal emigration.'' They refuse to produce their work for the official market. Instead, they are channeling their talents into an emerging underground cultural life, which ranges from art exhibits held out of briefcases to thriving clandestine publishing houses issuing popular books and scholarly journals.

title: ; Middle Class
description: To the Editor:

title: LONGTIME CUOMO AIDE TO OVERSEE HIS OFFICE
description: Governor Cuomo has selected Ellen E. Conovitz, a longtime aide, to supervise appointments to state jobs and to direct the day-to-day administration of the Governor's office.

title: Filipino Warns U.S. Against Change in Aid
description: Defense Minister Juan Ponce Enrile has suggested that any cuts in American military aid could lead the Philippines to reconsider its mutual defense agreement with the United States.

title: THE DIVIDED LINE OF STUART LITTLE'S FATHER
description: E. B. WHITE

title: NEW JERSEYANS
description: W HEN Clarence D. Chang of Princeton went home to his native China recently, he was welcomed as a ''Hollywood-style'' celebrity.

title: Hockey Season Ending for Colleges
description: College hockey's regular season ends Tuesday evening with the final five games of the Eastern College Athletic Conference Division I schedule. Playoffs in the E.C.A.C. and the Central Collegiate Hockey Association begin with quarterfinal rounds next Friday and Saturday evenings at the home rinks of the top four teams in each league. The Western Collegiate Hockey Association's first round takes place this weekend.

title: RECENT RELEASES
description: Catholics, a Fable Starring Trevor Howard, Martin Sheen and Cyril Cusack. Written by Brian Moore; directed by Jack Gold, 1973 Family Home Entertainment 86 minutes. $59.95

title: SPAIN BOLSTERS ROLE IN LATIN AMERICA
description: Spain is sending a ''mini Peace Corps'' to three Central American countries as part of an effort to increase its influence in the region.

title: Constance Shattuck and Kenneth J. Kolman Wed
description: Constance Merwin Shattuck and Kenneth J. Kolman were married yesterday at the Harvard Club on Commonwealth Avenue in Boston by Rabbi Albert Axelrad.

title: HART IN NEW HAMPSHIRE: THE RESPONSE BY YOUTH
description: Ruth Ann Baxter is 26 years old, a student of drafting and the mother of two small children. Her husband's union, the operating engineers, endorses Walter F. Mondale for the Democratic Presidential nomination, but Mrs. Baxter will vote for Senator Gary Hart in the New Hampshire primary Tuesday.

title: Amherst Trustees Vote To Close Fraternities
description: The Amherst College board of trustees announced today that the college's eight fraternities would be closed, effective June 30.

title: A DAY THAT LASTED A YEAR AT MARULANDA
description: A HOUSE IN THE COUNTRY

description: I T was sometime around 1800 when Hachaliah Bailey put

title: U.S. GENERAL CALL MEXICO MOST CORRUPT IN REGION
description: The chief of the United States Southern Command characterized Mexico as ''the most corrupt Government and society in Central America'' in testimony this week before Congress.

title: Deficit Politics
description: If all the proposals for cutting the Federal deficit were laid end-to-end, the revenue surplus might confound even the most ardent budget-balancers. But the real risk in the current rush to do something is that the issue will be drowned in campaign politics, with no one in power examining what really needs to be done.

title: FREEING MARKETS
description: Susan Lee, a senior writer for Business Week, also teaches economics at Columbia University. TYRANNY OF THE STATUS QUO

title: Hylah Brown to Marry Christopher John Riley
description: -1-14, 2 lines Announcement has been made by Catherine Young Brown of Englewood, N.J., of the engagement of her daughter, Hylah Lydecker Brown, to Christopher John Riley, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Joseph G. Riley of Waltham, Mass. The wedding is planned for May.

title: VIDEO WORK ON DIFFERENT WAVELENGTHS
description: T here is really no esthetic link between Mary Lucier and Dara Birnbaum, save for the fact that each is a video artist and each has created a special video environment for a public space, one uptown, one downtown. Their work is poles apart. Miss Lucier, remaining within the visual-arts tradition, views the screen as an animated canvas for lyrical landscape imagery; Miss Birnbaum takes her cues from the content of commercial broadcast television itself, using video to explore and satirize it. Yet seeing both of these cleverly designed multi- screen installations gives the viewer a sense of two directions - one an interest in video as an extension of traditional media, the other a concern with video as it relates to television itself - prevailing in a medium that, for all its innovative talents, is still in search of a supportive audience.

title: STATE'S STORM CENTER WARNS DRIVERS OF HAZARDS
description: E VEN though most of the winter's snow melted away in February, workers at the State Department of Transportation's Storm Center in Wethersfield are still prepared to assist motorists in the event of early spring floods or a late winter storm.

title: NEW YORK INTELLECTUALS-- UP FROM REVOLUTION
description: I*SIT surrounded by memoirs written by the New

title: ALASKA SHOWS BIGGEST RISE IN POPULATION SINCE CENSUS
description: Alaska, with a population increase of 19.2 percent, has the highest growth rate of any state this decade, the Census Bureau says, although it is still one of the least populated. There were 479,000 residents in Alaska when the bureau counted last year.

title: HEADLINERS
description: Mario Moreno Lopez left home without a certain green card recently, and it cost him a lot more than the inconvenience of not being able to charge a meal. Mario, who is 14 years old, was picked up by immigration officials on a sweep of illegal immigrants in Santa Ana, Calif., where he resided legally with his father.

title: ACCORD ON 68TH ST.
description: A group of determined West Side residents who opposed the development of a tall, though legal, mid-block apartment building on West 68th Street have won a compromise with the developer. They will now see an 11-story building, rather than one of 19 stories, rise on their block between Central Park West and Columbus Avenue.

title: NEW METHODS FOR PRINTING COLOR AT HOME
description: Making color prints used to be a laborious process requiring precise time and temperature control of many solutions, but now there are several new methods that make color printing easier and faster in as little as 60 seconds. Some processes also make it possible to turn favorite black-and-white prints into colored or toned images that are as pleasing as they are effective.

title: A LOOK AT NEW CORPORATE TACTICS TO BOLSTER THE VALUE OF SHARES
description: or, at least, are teetering. Gulf Oil and Getty Oil - Nos. 9 and 24, respectively, on the Fortune 500 list for 1983 - may soon lose their freedom just as Bendix and Conoco did before them. It matters little that these companies are among America's mightiest; they still became easy marks for the ravenous advances of others. Their sin was simple - they failed to keep their stock price high enough to fend off attack. And if such giant oaks of business can tumble, what about the smaller acorns that make up most of corporate America?

title: Scientists Finger 'Killer Star' in Dinosaur Deaths
description: IN 1802 a schoolboy named Pliny Moody found an enormous, three-toed fossil footprint outside South Hadley, Mass. - evidence, many thought, that huge birds had inhabited the Connecticut Valley.

Macy & Company in New York, to Richard John Claiden, an assistant vice president of the Manufacturers Hanover Trust Company, took place yesterday in New York. The Rev. Daniel Cassiero performed the ceremony in the Lady Chapel at St. Patrick's Cathedral.

title: ALLIES IN EUROPE SEEK BIGGER ROLE
description: The United States' allies in Europe have begun to try to bring a greater measure of European identity and decision-making to their military policies.

title: HAZARDS OF THE INDOOR TRACK SCENE
description: T he noise sounded like a starter's pistol, but was from a far

title: BREAKING THE MUSEUMS' MONOPOLY OF SHOWS OF QUALITY
description: M USEUMS outside the big cities usually monopolize the art scene with their exhibitions, much as shopping malls appear to have the upper hand in retailing.

title: 8 DEMOCRATS GIRD FOR KEY PRIMARY IN NEW HAMPSHIRE
description: Amid shifting political fortunes, the major Democratic Presidential aspirants are preparing for a New Hampshire primary vote that could help decide the length of the nomination contest.

title: Kashmiri Accused in England Of Indian's Fatal Kidnapping
description: A 27-year-old Kashmiri was arraigned today on charges of kidnapping an Indian diplomat who was found shot to death near here three weeks ago.

title: SURGEONS TO START IMPLANTING ELECTRONIC DEVICE TO AID DEAF
description: A tiny artificial ear designed to help 65 percent of the nation's deaf people will be implanted in 20 people within a year and the first operation will be performed in three to four weeks, according to a surgeon at the University of Utah.

title: Dawn Chaplen to Wed Mark Donovan in May
description: -1-14, 2 lines Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Frederick V. Chaplen of Farmington, Conn., of the engagement of their daughter Dawn Marie Chaplen to Mark Edward Donovan, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert G. Donovan of Armonk, N.Y. The wedding is to take place May 5.

title: RICHARDSON IS STANDOUT AS NETS DEFEAT KNICKS
description: In the first days after Micheal Ray Richardson's controversial reinstatement last December, the Nets tried to shield him from the pressures surrounding his return by closing his first practice session and by keeping him out of a game against his former team, the Knicks.

title: 9 SENTENCED IN FRAUD SCHEME
description: Nine people have been sentenced on a variety of charges in connection with an insurance-fraud scheme in which 18 others are accused of slaughtering race horses to collect insurance money.

title: THE ART OF STAYING IN BUSINESS
description: MORRISTOWN A CQUIRING worthwhile antiques for sale is the stock- in-trade that preoccupies many of today's dealers.

title: FOLK-ROCK: A REFLECTIVE JOHN PHILLIPS
description: ''This is a song about one of my wives who wanted to commit suicide; I can't remember which one,'' said John Phillips, by way of introducing a new tune called ''Skyjacked'' at the Bottom Line Thursday. Written in a cheerful folk-rock style, ''Skyjacked'' has a grisly lyric in which a man, watching a woman cut her wrists, accuses her of emotional blackmail.

title: New & Noteworthy
description: IN SEARCH OF EXCELLENCE: Lessons From America's Best-Run Companies, by Thomas J. Peters and Robert H. Waterman Jr. (Warner, $8.95.) Two management consultants distill eight principles from studies of successful American companies in their ''highly readable and sensible'' best seller. Our reviewer, Fran R. Schumer, observed that ''In Search of Excellence'' locates ''the secret of business success not in the head but in the heart'' and finds ''that 'excellent' companies are distinguished by good old-fashioned values.'' FLOATING DRAGON, by Peter Straub. (Berkley, $3.95.) Peter Straub's sixth novel ''may be his best, or at least his most harrowing,'' Richard Freedman said in his review. The peculiarly modern dragon of this vastly entertaining novel by the best-selling author of ''Ghost Story'' is DRG, an insidiously deadly gas that escapes from a chemical plant in the commuters' town of Hampstead, Conn., ''but there's another dragon, in the form of an ancient curse, on hand to decimate the largely affluent, if weird, inhabitants.''

title: China
description: To the Editor: Orville Schell's article on Peking's Jianguo Hotel (Travel, Nov. 28) gives the reader the very clear impression that China's first Western-run hotel meets the standard of true world-class hotels.

description: Those who develop large tracts of land, and the so-called spot builders who put up custom houses on individual lots in established neighborhoods.

title: Christine Goban Is Married
description: Christine Hilary Goban and Andrew Seth Black, both lawyers in New York, were married yesterday at the C. W. Post Chapel in Greenvale, L.I. Rabbi Nathaniel Schwartz and the Rev. Paul Ruggiero, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony. Mrs. Black, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Francis T. Goban of Hicksville, L.I., graduated from Marquette University and the New York Law School. Mr. Black, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Jerome Black of New York, graduated from the State University at Oneonta and the Ohio Northern University School of Law.

title: Susan Fuller Has Nuptials
description: Susan Kathleen Fuller, a daughter of Rear Adm. Robert Bryon Fuller, U.S.N., retired, and Mrs. Fuller of Jacksonville Beach, Fla., was married yesterday to Lieut. Comdr.

title: SCALING HAUTE COUTURE
description: ven at fashion's luxurious peak, the haute couture, one designer occupies a loftier perch than others, and has for some time. If anything, Yves Saint Laurent's new spring collection, which was shown last month in Paris, has even more firmly entrenched his grip on the summit.

title: CRIME
description: Richard Grayson is to the turn-of-the-century Paris procedural what Peter Lovesey is to the Scotland Yard procedural of Victorian England, and while Mr. Grayson's Inspector Gautier of the S^urete is not as well-known as Mr. Lovesey's Sergeant Cribb (thanks to the latter's television shows), he is an equally interesting, resourceful figure. In background, however, he is entirely different - higher in rank and social status, better educated and much more sophisticated.

title: SHUBERT'S SONATAS POSE A LIFELONG CHALLENGE...
description: S chubert pursued the piano sonata for a lifetime, though it was a form that ran against his natural inclinations as a composer. The songs are at the core of Schubert's work, and their lyrical elegance and mysterious ambiguity of mood are best translated into pianistic terms in short, individual pieces - the ''Moments Musicaux,'' for example, or the Impromptus.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: In the article entitled ''Ticket Tips and Other Information'' (Travel, Feb. 12), under the section for La Scala in Milan, the listing for the United States offices of C.I.T. Tours Corp. should have stated that the travel agency provides opera ticket reservations for clients only. However, it is not necessary to be a client of the agency to buy opera tickets at its Milan office.

title: President Renews Call For Prayer Amendment
description: President Reagan today repeated his call for returning prayer to public schools, saying, ''The pendulum has swung too far toward intolerance against genuine religious freedom.''

title: Data Update
description: Conventional mortgages have fixed rates and terms, with payments that amortize the debt by the end of the term. Rollovers have short terms, do not completely amortize the debt and usually commit the lender to renew at the prevailing rate of interest.

description: States Stiffen The Standards On EDB in Food

description: DAVID YEADON is the author of ''Secluded Islands of the Atlantic Coast,'' to be published by Crown in May.

title: RUNNER READYING FOR OLYMPIC GOAL
description: C RAIG MASBACK, a runner who has beaten seven of the top eight Americans competing for a spot on the Olympic team in the 1,500-meter event, was sitting recently in a Manhattan hotel suite with friends, watching himself on television in the Olympic Track and Field Invitational that had been held the day before at the Meadowlands Arena. Mr. Masback, however, was not racing in the meet; he had described it as an expert commentator for CBS Sports.

title: F.B.I. HOLDS 2 MEN IN DEFENSE DEPT. BRIBERY CASE
description: Federal agents said tonight that a Defense Department employee and a New York City businessman had been arrested and charged with soliciting more than $600,000 in bribes in exchange for information on a military contract.

title: SEXUAL MATTERS GETTING MORE ATTENTION IN COURT
description: American courts, responding to new health concerns and changing sexual mores, find themselves delving with increasing frequency into what were once considered purely private matters.

title:
GARDENING;
GROWING BLUEBERRIES IN THE BACKYARD
description: W HEN European explorers and settlers first set foot on North American soil, they found blueberries growing wild. Until 1906, wild blueberries were the sole source of this delectable fruit.

title: Laura Flanagan Bride Of Kenneth H. Bowen
description: Laura Anne Flanagan, a daughter of Col. Eugene P. Flanagan, U.S.A., retired, and Mrs. Flanagan of New York, was married yesterday to Kenneth H. Bowen, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Alfred H. Bowen of Riverdale, the Bronx. The Rev. George Costagan performed the Roman Catholic ceremony at Holy Trinity Chapel at the United States Military Academy at West Point, N.Y.

description: W HEN the Tooth Ferry came to Shelter Island recently, a lot of people called the police to complain. In this instance, the vessel was not for transporting teeth, but a 125- foot wooden fishing boat of rustic cut owned by a dentist.

title: KOCH'S INVECTIVE COULD MAKE HIS FOES VINDICTIVE
description: The popularity of disk jockeys who abuse their listeners represents the latest fad in the radio business. But if industry executives had been paying attention to Mayor Koch, they would have known long ago about the appeal of the insult.

title: BUOYED BY THE BEACH
description: WALTER GOODMAN is a reporter for The Times.

title: 'On Glory's Course'
description: N GLORY'S COURSE,'' James Purdy's new novel, is ostensibly about the 1930's. In it, Mr. Purdy dramatizes at length the long past ''fall'' of Adele Bevington, the beautiful, aristocratic 50-year-old damned belle dame of Fonthill, a tiny Midwestern town of suffocating insularity. Roughly 30 years earlier Adele had been persuaded by both her lover, the wealthy George Etheredge, and her father to give up her illegitimate son. Since then, it seems, Adele has spent most waking hours staring out of the windows of her hilltop mansion, hoping to catch a glimpse of her own flesh and blood coming out of the local movie theater. She hasn't seen the boy since infancy, yet somehow she believes he is alive and well and still in town.

title: Papal Nuncio in Chile Criticizes Government
description: The Papal Nuncio in Chile, Archbishop Angelo Sodano, has criticized the military Government, saying it lacked courtesy and respect for Pope John Paul II in refusing to grant safe-conduct to four leftist guerrillas who sought asylum in the Vatican mission.

description: Speculum Musicae, now in residence at Columbia University, remains one of our pre-eminent new- music ensembles. Thursday night, the group presented a varied program in the McMillin Theater, under the auspices of the Columbia-Princeton Electronic Music Center.

title: HOW MULTIPLE CASTS OF 'CARMEN' CAME TO HARMONIZE
description: E van Bortnick, one of the four singer-actors now alternating in the role of Don Jose in Peter Brook's ''La Tragedie de Carmen,'' was so charmed by the sweet flirtatiousness of one of the alternating Carmens, who recently left the show, that he always felt like a cad doing her in at the end.

title: NEW U.S. ISSUE DISPLAYS NATIVE ORCHIDS
description: The United States Postal Service likes to put out stamps with flowers. Florals are attractive and highly popular with people who buy stamps as the state flowers and birds issue demonstrated.

description: -time fiddle contests around the country, made his New York debut Friday at the Alternative Museum.

description: Robert Krulwich is the economics and business correspondent for National Public Radio. PRESCRIPTIONS FOR PROSPERITY

title: No Headline
description: The Boy in the Bubble David, the boy in the bubble, died last week from complications of an attempt to give him the immune defenses he had lacked since birth. All but the last 15 days of his 12 years were spent confined within plastic.

title: STORE WITH CHILDREN IN MIND
description: First there was Wicker Garden, a Madison Avenue shop specializing in wicker furniture. Then, when Richardson Scurry was born, Pamela Scurry opened Wicker Garden's Baby next door to her first store. It sells clothes for infants and toddlers. Richardson is now 4 years old and has been joined by his sister, Kristina, 2. Last week, their mother opened a third shop, Wicker Garden's Children, across the street from the other two. The new shop can dress boys and girls up to size 10 and includes shoes.

title: DONATIONS PASS $2.5 MILLION
description: The 72d annual appeal of The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund will end this week with a record total in contributions of more than $2.5 million from about 13,000 donors.

title: HAKAN HAGEGARD- A BARITONE WHO REFUSES TO BE TYPECAST
description: Mark Steinbrink is a freelance writer.

title: ALVARADO BIDS TO END PANEL'S ROLE IN LICENSING OF SCHOOL SUPERVISORS
description: The Board of Education and the city's Schools Chancellor are planning to submit legislation in Albany to eliminate the role of the Board of Examiners in the licensing of principals, assistant principals and other supervisors.

title: Steve Howe's Ordeal
description: Steve Howe, the Los Angeles Dodger relief pitcher who has been suspended for this season because of problems related to the use of cocaine and alcohol, says the use was not the problem. ''When I was using, there were no problems,'' he said during an interview in his attorney's office outside Los Angeles.

title: I.R.S. OFFERS HELP ON FILING
description: -tax filing looms, the Internal Revenue Service, in cooperation with several county organizations, is again offering special assistance. Two free programs are designed to aid elderly, handicapped and low-income residents in preparing their tax returns.

title: No Headline
description: Subway Service Halted When Train Kills Man

title: IT'S A BONNY ISLE FOR BIRDERS
description: It is fair isle. Perched in the middle of the North Sea, it sits midway between the Shetland Islands, the most northerly in the United Kingdom, and the Orkney Islands, just off the top of Schotland. The first views, whether by air or by sea, are formidable. High sandstone cliffs surround Fair Isle and powerful waves crash against the rocks. On top, the island is covered by a gentle counterpane, green treeless moorland spiced with heather, tidy holdings called crofts and hundreds of Shetland sheep.

title: TASTY TIDBITS LURK IN THE MET'S NEWS OF NEXT SEASON
description: T he genuine, deep-dyed opera fan is insatiable, a creature who greedily consumes every scrap of information about the art and the craft of lyric theater, true or false, real or rumored. No detail of a beloved soprano's precocious infancy is too trivial to overlook. No tenor's recipe for Chicken Appoggiatura is too gummy-sounding to be clipped and filed. No superannuated diva's ghost-written memoirs are too fatuous and self-serving to be bought, lent to friends and heatedly discussed in lobbies. The addict needs his fix of opera dope, especially in the dreary depths of February. There is no such thing as too much opera news, or a wrong time to shoot it up.

title: Alice O. Johnson, a Physician, to Marry

title: Why Students Leave In the Senior Year

title: ...OR GOING INTO THEIR BONDAGE
description: -haired woman with the sweet smile and the bright blue ribbon adorning her chest from shoulder to waist, blocks my way as I try to enter my bank on a Monday morning at 10 o'clock. I nod, attempting to move past her with a smoothly executed double side step to the left. She mirrors my move and blocks my path just enough to keep me from getting any farther.

title: Wide Search Conducted For 2 Armed Fugitives
description: Law-enforcement officers conducted a wide search today for two armed fugitives who are said to have committed murders and kidnappings since they fled prison a week ago.

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS Dr. Seuss' Bleak Polemic
description: Before Theodor Seuss Geisel published ''And to Think That I Saw It on Mulberry Street'' in 1937 he had been a successful advertising copywriter and a political cartoonist. That has seemed irrelevant to the hundreds of millions of children and adults in more than two dozen countries who have grown up with his fanciful tales and distinctive cartoonish drawings.

title: FROM WATERBURY TO FILM STARDOM
description: F OR Nick Apollo Forte, life was a string of appearances from Colorado to the Catskills, where he would play the piano and sing his heart out in smoke- filled lounges to audiences that sometimes consisted of two or three sleepy patrons.

title: BILINGUALISM'S GOAL
description: Mine is a Spanish-speaking household. We use Spanish exclusively. I have made an effort not only to encourage use of the language but also to familiarize my children with Hispanic culture. I use books from Latin America to teach them to read and write, and I try to maintain close contacts with Spanish- speaking relatives. Instilling in my children a sense of family and ethnic identity is my role; it is not the role of the school system.

title: House Creating Special Unit To Study Worldwide Hunger

title: PRIVATE ANNUITIES FOR DO-IT-YOURSELFERS
description: MENTION the word ''annuity'' and most people yawn and think of insurance companies, the usual source of such payments. Yet annuity agreements can also be drawn up among private parties and can be a potent tool for reducing income and estate taxes. They are, in essence, quid pro quo arrangements that allow elderly individuals to shift the ownership and management of substantial assets to younger relatives while keeping the family wealth within the family.

title: SCIENCE FICTION
description: In a sense, the hero of the first two volumes in a projected trilogy that truly deserves the label ''epic'' is Charles Darwin. In HELLICONIA SPRING (Berkley, paper, $6.95) and HELLICONIA SUMMER (Atheneum, $16.95) Brian W. Aldiss writes science fiction on the grandest possible scale. He writes of the evolution of cultures, of entire species, of the ever-changing physical environment that shapes and is itself shaped by the forces of life. Yet he does not forget - what true Darwinian could? - that the key unit of evolutionary change is the individual, struggling, sometimes blindly and sometimes with hard-earned foresight, to survive and multiply.

title: Havlicek, Jones in Hall
description: John Havlicek and Sam Jones, who played together on six championship Boston Celtic teams, will be inducted into the Basketball Hall of Fame together April 30 at Springfield, Mass. They will be joined by Jack Gardner , the former Kansas State and Utah coach, whose teams won 70 percent of their games during his college coaching career that spanned 38 years.

title:
BUSINESS AND THE FAMILY;
'FLEX-TIME' WEAVES JOB AND FAMILYY
description: NO one thinks it unusual when Sarah Shipley, a senior applications analyst at the Control Data Corporation, takes a work break to change her 9-month-old daughter, or when she fixes lunch for her 3-year- old daughter and reads her a story. That's because Mrs. Shipley works at her home in Dallas on what is known as a flex-time schedule. Back in April 1981, Control Data's Dallas office installed a computer terminal in Mrs. Shipley's home so she could continue her work as a programmer while she raised her family.

title: CREATIVITY AND THE CORPORATE MAN
AID TO CENTRAL AMERICA CAN WORK
description: Critics of the Kissinger commission's report say its proposal for large-scale economic aid is flawed on three counts: It's too big; Central America cannot manage it; and a major aid program won't produce long-term economic, social and political development. I reject all three charges. The program is no larger than needed to change the region's economic and political environment. It takes into account the region's limited management capacity. It can work - if the region's governments adopt sound economic and social policies.

title: ...WHILE HIS SONGS EXERT THEIR MELANCHOLY MAGIC
description: ''T he art of music here enshrined a rich possession but even far fairer hopes.'' Franz Grillparzer wrote this famous epitaph in 1828 for his friend Franz Schubert, dead from syphilis at the age of 31. Although the young composer left an astonishing legacy - hundreds of songs, nine symphonies, several operas and a good amount of chamber music - it remains a forgivable temptation to speculate on what might have been. After all, during the last year of his life, Schubert had attained a new maturity: As fine as much of his earlier work had been - and ''Gretchen am Spinnrade,'' which he tossed off in a single afternoon at the age of 16, is one of the most perfect songs ever written - the composer's last pieces have a power and poignancy unique in the annals of music.

description: The slaying of a father and his son as they sat in a car in Brooklyn was apparently drug related, the police said yesterday. The father, Arturo Coto, 57 years old, of Franklin, Ohio, and his son, Raul, 31, of Astoria, Queens, were killed by an unknown gunman Friday in the Bushwick section. The police had said earlier that the two were brothers.

title: Paul Randelman Engaged to Wed Lynn L. Congdon
description: Mr. and Mrs. Robert G. Congdon of Oakland, Calif., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Lynn Louise Congdon, to Paul Randelman, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Arthur Randelman of Trenton and Atlantic City. An April wedding is planned.

title: ;  Glamorous Times In Bellport
description: Patricia O'Flanagan Corley ended the first paragraph of her charmingly written piece about Bellport (''Once Upon a Summertime in Bellport,'' Opinion Page, Feb. 5) by writing, ''Nowhere, however, has its once glamorous past won mention.'' And then she didn't mention any aspects of its once glamorous past.

title: OIL BLAST IN BRAZIL SHANTYTOWN KILLS 100
description: At least 100 men, women and children were reported killed today in an oil pipeline explosion that destroyed part of a shantytown on the outskirts of a southern Brazilian town.

title: CONCERTGOERS MUST CHOOSE FROM THREE
description: M USIC lovers will have a difficult decision to make next Sunday afternoon, when three highly appealing concerts are scheduled. At 3 P.M., the Laurentian String Quartet, with Paul Ukena as guest baritone, plays Mozart, Schoeck and Bartok at Sarah Lawrence College (call 337-0700 for reservations) in Yonkers. At the same hour, Doris Yarick- Cross, the new head of Yale University's voice department, sings favorite soprano arias by Verdi, Puccini and Strauss at the Hudson River Museum (963-4550). And at 4 P.M., the Ossining Friends of Music Society presents the Westchester debut of the Vienna Octet at the high school in a recital that includes Mozart's ''Eine Kleine Nacht Musik'' and the Schubert Octet (271-4657).

description: A fire in a crowded movie theater here killed five people Friday night, officials said. Eight of the more than 500 in the audience were injured, two of them seriously.

title: CHALLENGES IN KEEPING WOMEN'S TENNIS GROWING
description: N OW is a good time to stop, look back, look around and look ahead to women's tennis in 1984, the year that marks the 100th anniversary of the first women's tennis match played at Wimbledon. It's a good time to get a sense of where the game has come from and where it is going. Perhaps even more than the fans, it's very important for the players to understand and appreciate the evolution of women's tennis.

title: CWoTeacher in Private Schools
description: Catherin Baldwin Woodbridge, a teacher and administrator at private schools for girls in Manhattan for 29 years, died Friday at St. Luke's Hospital. She was 79 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: CENTRAL AMERICAN AID-A WASTE
description: President Reagan is asking American taxpayers to give $8.4 billion for economic assistance to Central America over the next five years. It would be a waste of immense sums. Ironically, it would also strengthen precisely the forces that the President wants to destroy.

title: BECKETT HONES HIS GRIM, EXQUISITE ART
description: B ack in 1969 I was invited to the world premiere of Samuel Beckett's ''Breath.'' Since I had already read the text, I knew that this meant driving some 70 miles to see the curtain go up on a heap of rubble while invisible lungs slowly inhaled, then slowly exhaled. Add a faint cry at the beginning and another at the end, and you had a play, if play it was, lasting perhaps a minute and adding nothing to Pozzo's celebrated outburst in ''Waiting for Godot'': ''One day we were born, one day we shall die, the same day, the same second . . . they give birth astride of a grave, the light glimmers an instant, and then it's night once more.'' It hardly seemed worth the journey. So I said no, sorry, I've read the book, and stayed at home watching television instead.

title: PICASSO
description: John Russell is the chief art critic of The New York Times. By John Russell OSTERITY WILL BE DUMBFOUNDED THAT IN New York, and indeed in the United States as a whole, we took so long to see the point of late Picasso. The artist died in April 1973. In February 1981, a show of his late paintings at the Pace Gallery in New York made it clear that, to quote one review, ''one of the things that we most need is a thoughtful and independent survey of the work of Picasso in old age.'' It took time, but as of this Friday and through May 6, we can see ''Picasso : The Last Years, 1963-1973'' at the Guggenheim Museum. Not only will the work be there in depth, but we shall see it in isolation, rather than as an appendage to one of the most glorious careers in 20th-century art.

title: 'VALUE OF NAMES' LOOKS BACK AT 50'S
description: T HE aftermath of the investigations of the House Un- American Activities Committee in the 1950's - the unhealed wounds and the ruination of relationships - are the concerns of the playwright Jeffrey Sweet in his new play, ''The Value of Names,'' at the Hartford Stage Company in Hartford.

title: HUMANE INSIGHTS FROM THE WORLD OF ISLAMIC MINIATURES
description: G ood news from Syria, Lebanon and Iran may never have been in shorter supply, but in the Islamic rooms at the Metropolitan Museum a timeless perfection presides. I know of no interior space in New York City more seductive than the room that was brought over intact in its every detail from a house built in the great city of Damascus in the year 1707. A niche points the way to Mecca. Colored marble, chopped and chiseled, makes for the most glassy and elegant of floors. The ceilings are celestially high. Light peeks in high overhead through panels of stained glass. Porcelain, velvet, embroidery, painting, calligraphy, wood gilded and fretted - all are put through their paces. Sofas rise only to ankle height. A very small fountain chuckles away at our feet. It is a privilege to see domestic spaces as nobly ordered as these.

description: China's President, Li Xiannian, gave a rare television address today urging the nation to make a success of ''socialist ethics month'' in March. Longtime foreign residents in Peking could not remember when a Chinese leader had made a television appearance like it.

title: NEW CHALLENGE

TAXING MULTINATIONALS;
THE STATES HAVE MADE IT A NIGHTMARE
description: THE Nightmare: You just received your 1983 income tax

title: SHELTERS OFFER STREET YOUTHS HAVEN IN CITY
description: It is the unrelenting pain of the streets that Peter recalls most vividly.

title: PAY AND SPACE ARE IRKSOME TO LEGISLATORS
description: HARTFORD W HEN a staff member at the State Capitol has to call one legislator at his regular job, he disguises his voice or gets someone else to place the call. The legislator's employer knows the staff member's voice and complains about the lawmaker getting too many legislative calls at work.

title: ABORTION DEBATE RATTLES LISBON'S RULING COALITION
description: The uneasy coalition of Socialists and Social Democrats that has governed Portugal for eight months has managed to hold together despite formidable internal strains. But now it has run into trouble over an unlooked-for issue - liberalization of Portugal's stringent antiabortion law.

title: NIKOLAIS'S STYLE IS EXCLUSIVELY HIS OWN
description: A curious and little noted aspect about Alwin Nikolais - whose company closes at the City Center tonight - is that his work defies imitation. True, some of his former students, when they first struck out on their own, adopted his use of props and fabrics as extensions of their bodies. A few employed his mixed-media techniques on a small scale.

title: 2 CINEMAS TURN TO ARTS FILMS
description: L ONG ISLAND'S moviegoers are becoming more sophisticated consumers of films. At least that is what two theater managements are betting on.

title: KOCH OFFERS CITY'S VIEW ON A KEY HOUSING QUESTION
description: Mayor Koch outlined in a letter this week New York City's position on what promises to be a major housing issue in this year's legislative session.

title:
CABLE TV NOTES;
CAN BRAVO MAKE CULTURE PAY?
description: Steve Knoll frequently reports on the television scene.

title: TIBET'S 'EXILE GENERATION'
description: COPYRIGHT c 1984 BY JOHN F. AVEDON

title: HOMELESS SHELTER OPENING AT AIRPORT
description: WHITE PLAINS C ALLING it ''a move in the right direction,'' County Executive Andrew P. O'Rourke announced last week that the county planned to open a 19-bed shelter to serve as a temporary residence for some of the county's homeless men and women.

title: CRITICS' CHOICES
description: Jazz America, a weekend festival of jazz at Lehman College's Center for the Performing Arts in the Bronx, has assembled an impressive lineup for the end of the week. On Friday at 8 P.M., Buddy Rich and Gerry Mulligan will both lead big bands.

title: WRITIER'S WORKSHOP AT AGE 5
description: Bernard Asbell has made a specialty of writing on education and has taught writing at Yale and Clark Universities. S ANY AUthor knows, you can't write when somebody is standing over you, watching, waiting for the next word. But I stood there and watched. This young author, totally absorbed, wrote and wrote and wrote.

title: U.S. Yacht Officials Back Use of Kevlar
description: The United States Yacht Racing Union has announced that it will permit the unrestricted use of Kevlar in sails for grand prix ocean-racing yachts, effective immediately. The ruling ends 18 months of turmoil caused by the decision of the Offshore Racing Council, the sport's international authority, to ban in part the use of Kevlar in sails starting in 1984.

title: WHEN THE STYLE OF AN ANSWER OUTWEIGHS THE CONTENT
description: T his is the year of a Presidential campaign; it is also a year of questions and answers. Television debates proliferate; Presidential news conferences take on new meaning. On television, candidates answer questions differently than they do in print. It is incumbent on them to look good while responding to questions, a requirement that impinges on and shapes their answers. How a candidate appears to answer a question is at least as important as the content of his answer, and the trick is to appear to be giving an answer even when there is no answer to give. Consequently, candidates do not always answer the questions they are asked; they answer instead the questions they wish they had been asked. Examples abound.

description: SMITH CLUB AUCTION

title: A LESSON LEARNED: GROWING OLD IS A GROWING EXPERIENCE
description: W HENEVER I come back from the nursing home, I want to write a book about my father-in-law, George. He is 88 years old, a down-to- earth man and he has taught me everything that is important to know about growing old.

title: AS HUMANS MILTIPLY TO THE BRINK OF EXTINCTION
description: To the Editor:

title: Q&A Nonprofit Ownership Question:
description: Our 43-unit apartment building was taken over by a nonprofit organization as part of its extensive real-estate holdings. The units are rent-controlled or rent-stabilized. Do we retain the same rights that we had under the previous profit-making ownership? . . . E. W. S., Manhattan

title: Hart Says White House Will Cut Social Security
description: Telling elderly people that his call for a new generation of leadership ''encompasses all generations,'' Senator Gary Hart of Colorado said today that President Reagan, if re-elected, ''will further try to erode the Social Security system'' to pay for ''the dangerous and unnecessary nuclear arms race with the Russians.''

title: Baker and Dole Stump For Reagan in Primary
description: President Reagan's re-election committee, unable to produce its candidate on the New Hampshire campaign trail, sent surrogates today to tout the Administration's economic record.

title: Dragons of Winter
description: A friend in the Arctic writes that scientists now believe that the hollow core of a polar bear's individual hairs acts as a kind of solar cell, transmitting the sun's energy into the bear's hide: When he suns himself on an ice floe, he may feel as warm as a turtle on a log in Georgia.

title: Extension for Altobelli
description: The Baltimore Orioles have extended the contracts of General Manager Hank Peters and Manager Joe Altobelli.

title: REPORTER'S NOTEBOOK: A NAPPING JUROR AND PLODDING DETAIL AT OLMEDO'S TRIAL
description: As the corruption trial of City Councilman Luis A. Olmedo of Brooklyn and two other men went through its fourth week, a juror fell asleep one day last week. His head rested on his left shoulder, his eyes were shut and he appeared serenely removed from the proceedings in Federal District Court in downtown Brooklyn.

description: To the Editor:

description: February 26, 1984Fiction

title: DANCE: JAPANESE TROUPE
description: In 1959, the New York City Ballet played host to the dancers and musicians of the Japanese Imperial Household in their American debut. The court dances they presented are known as Bugaku, while the style of music is Gagaku.

title: A CONDOMINIUM FOR ARTISTS
description: Last year's search for outer-borough work space by a New York graphic designer and architect who had been priced out of the Manhattan loft market has resulted in the development of a commercial condominium for artists and designers in Brooklyn.

title: South Africa Sentences Wife Of Ex-Leader of Black Rebels
description: The wife of the former secretary general of the African National Congress has been sentenced to four years in prison for singing banned songs and speaking favorably at a funeral about the black nationalist organization.

title: POPE WORRIED ABOUT ANTI-VATICAN REGIMES
description: The Vatican has become increasingly concerned about what it sees as efforts by governments to alienate Roman Catholics from loyalty to the church, according to officials here.

title:
BUSINESS AND THE FAMILY;
WHEN VIOLENCE AT HOME AFFECTS WORK
description: WHEN a woman reported for work with facial cuts and bruises for the third time, her supervisors grew concerned. Checking records at the Minnesota company's health maintenance organization, they learned that the woman's teen-age daughter had recently been raped and that her two preschool children had also received emergency room treatment twice within the past six months. The woman steadfastly refused to discuss what had happened to her, but her work was suffering and it was apparent to supervisors and co- workers that there were serious problems within her family, probably from an abusive husband.

title: CONTROVERSY SWIRLS ABOUT TRAFFIC CIRCLE
description: T HE Doughty Boulevard traffic circle in Lawrence is an attractive feature of the neighborhood to some residents and a dangerous nuisance to others.

title: A SERIES OF DISCUSSIONS FOR BOOK LOVERS
description: I N southern Connecticut, avid

title: EXPERTS URGE STRENGTHENING L.I. POWER LINKS
description: A panel of energy experts and environmentalists agreed today that strengthening Long Island's power links to the rest of New York State could ease rate increases facing customers because of the construction of the Shoreham nuclear plant.

title: HOW THEY DEAL AND MULTIPLY
description: AN affectionate Jewish family of

title: MISS NAVRATILOVA TAKES TITLE
description: The loser spoke like a winner today after the final of the United States Women's Indoor Championships. ''If it would have been a smear match, I'd be discouraged and angry at myself,'' Chris Evert Lloyd said after her 6-2, 7-6 loss to Martina Navratilova. ''But I played better than all last year against her. Most of the games, I was in it full blast. I'm very encouraged.''

title:
PHOTOGRAPHY VIEW;
WHY HARLEM'S JAMES VAN DER ZEE ISN'T IN THE HISTORY BOOKS
description: J ames Van Der Zee had two careers in photography. The first was as a neighborhood photographer in Harlem during the 1920's and 30's. The second, as a national photographic celebrity, lasted from 1969, when his work of the 20's and 30's was prominently featured in the exhibition ''Harlem on My Mind'' at the Metropolitan Museum of Art, until his death in 1983 at the age of 96.

title: EDWARD T. DOYLE
description: Edward Thompson Doyle, a stockbroker and a former mayor of Sea Girt, N.J., died Friday at his home in Sea Girt. He was 88 years old.

title: JOSEPH S. IMIRIE
description: Joseph S. Imirie, a former Assistant Secretary of the Air Force, died here last Sunday after a long illness. He was 67 years old.

title: Miss Pollard Has Nuptials
description: Wendy Joan Pollard, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William A. Pollard of Devon, Pa., was married yesterday to Kurt Parant Metzger, a son of Jeanne C. Metzger of Rumson, N.J., and the late Samuel Metzger. The Rev. Dr. C. Vincent Wilson performed the ceremony at the Presbyterian Church of Chestnut Hill in Philadelphia.

title: Liverpool Strengthens Title Chances in Soccer
description: Ian Rush and Michael Robinson scored goals to give Liverpool a 2-0 home victory over the Queens Park Rangers today and improve Liverpool's chances of retaining the English League soccer title.

title: NEW OFFICES FOR WESTERN NASSAU
description: A new 200,000-square-foot office building in western Nassau County near the New York City line, built last year by the Manhasset Realty Corporation and recently sold to the Mack Company, a Rochelle Park, N.J., real-estate company, is ready for occupancy.

title: Kimberly Jean Macfarland Is Engaged to David Bond
description: The engagement of Kimberly Jean Macfarland to David Bond has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. David Bronson Macfarland of Greenwich, Conn., parents of the future bride.

title: Caroline Johnson to Marry
description: Mr. and Mrs. William C. Johnson Jr. of Daytona Beach, Fla., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Caroline Virginia Johnson, to Brian James Bellis, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Theodore Bellis of Wantagh, L.I. Miss Johnson and her fiance, who are studying for master's degrees in geology at North Carolina State University in Raleigh, graduated from Brown University.

title: Lucy Hazen Eyre To Wed a Banker
description: -1-18, 2 lines Mr. and Mrs. Henry N. Eyre Jr. of Farmington, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter Lucy Hazen Eyre to M. Bradbury Marston, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Garth Marston of Boston. The wedding is take place in August.

title: NOTED WITH PLEASURE
description: Some passages from current and recently published books that we find particularly appealing.

title:
DINING OUT;
OLD CHINESE SPOT AMONG THE NEW
description: P ENG'S GARDEN has had strong as well as weak moments since opening four-and- a-half years ago. The relatively small menu, based on Hunanese cuisine was unusual for the time, and promising. Since then, places declaring their allegiance to one region of China or another have inundated the county, and perhaps in the glow of their fresh dazzle, established restaurants seem pale and staid. However, recent visits to Peng's Garden suggested a rejuvenation. The kitchen turned out some snappy dishes.

title: MEESE COULD BE IN FOR THE THIRD DEGREE
description: The hearings in which the Senate Judiciary Committee will consider the nomination of Presidential Counselor Edwin W. Meese 3d to replace William French Smith as Attorney General promise to be among the most lively of such recent events. Panel members opposed to Mr. Meese have carefully staked out issues to raise this week in hopes of helping their cause, and White House allies have been no less diligent in preparing what may amount to a defense.

title: CITY OPERA: TOURING COMPANY IN 'LA BOHEME'
description: One of Beverly Sills's priorities when she became general director of the New York City Opera in 1979 was to establish a subsidiary touring company. The project took several years to evolve into its present form, the New York City Opera National Company, and there was even a season with no tour at all. But to judge from the performance of ''La Boh eme'' offered here Wednesday night - the closest the company is getting to New York City during its five-week 1984 tour of the East, South and Middle West - Miss Sills is achieving her intended aims admirably.

title: ARMarry Robert Glen
description: Alixe Reed, a daughter of Adrian P. Reed of Centreville, Md., and Ariane Wellin of Greenwich, Conn., plans to marry Robert Maxwell Glen, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Dulaney Glen of Pfafftown, N.C. The wedding is to be in May.

title: NEW MUSIC FROM OLD DISKS
description: I n my student days, I once took a history course fetchingly titled ''Emergence and Persistence.'' It explored

title: A TRUDEAU MYSTERY: IS HE BOWING OUT OR IN?
description: There is much speculation here over a recent disclosure that Prime Minister Pierre Elliott Trudeau, who swims exactly 44 lengths each morning in the pool at his official residence, is having a pool installed at his own home in Montreal.

title: TESTNG THE LIMITS OF RESTRICTIVE ZONING
description: For suburban communities living atop their drinking water, ''upzoning'' has become a new panacea, a seemingly no-fuss, low-cost cure for pollution worries. A community concerned with keeping its underground reservoir clean simply ups the zoning of its undeveloped land - typically from one unit per acre to one per five acres. The higher standard means more open land, which allows rainwater to pass untainted through the ground and into the aquifer.

title: 100,000 REFUGEES FLOOD ZIMBABWE
description: Zimbabwean officials say about 100,000 Mozambicans, many of them starving, have inundated Zimbabwe's northern and eastern border areas in the last few months.

title: Eleanore Reed To Wed Ensign
description: Mrs. Horace Reed 3d of Durham, N.H., has announced the engagement of her daughter Eleanore Merrill Reed of Coronado, Calif., to Ens. Peter Douglas Coffin, U.S.N.R., the son of Mr. and Mrs. David Douglas Coffin of Hampton Falls, N.H. A May wedding is planned.

title: CIVIL RIGHTS COMMISSION MAJORITY VS. A NATIONAL CONSENSUS

description: Teams in the United States Football League have signed a number of college players regarded as probable choices in the first or high in the second round of the National Football League's draft, scheduled for May 1. The U.S.F.L. held its draft on Jan. 3-4.

title: U.S. Tops Rumania in Cup
description: John McEnroe and Peter Fleming, who have never lost a Davis Cup match in five years as a team, raised their record to 12-0 yesterday as they led the favored United States to an insurmountable 3-0 lead over Rumania in a Davis Cup first-round series in Bucharest, Rumania.

title: Belcher Reports
description: Tim Belcher , the right-handed pitcher signed by the Yankees who was later selected by the Oakland A's from the free-agent compensation pool, reported to the A's camp yesterday in Phoenix. Belcher became the center of a controversy when the Yankees' protested his selection because New York signed him after it had already made up its list of players protected from the free-agent compensation pool and was thus left unprotected.

title: MILLIONS FACE HIGH RATES BECAUSE OF NUCLEAR PLANTS
description: Electric rate increases of 25 to 50 percent or more are looming for millions of customers in nine states because of billions of dollars in excess costs at 14 nuclear plants scheduled for completion in the next few years.

title: GOSH,PLEASE DON'T BLAME IT ON RIO
description: There's this 15- year-old nymphet (played by an 18-year-old girl named Michelle Johnson) in ''Blame It on Rio.'' She's a nice, healthy kid. Just got rid of her retainer. And the minute she hits the beach in Brazil, she whips off her shirt, revealing an awesome front porch, and proceeds to seduce her father's best friend, a married man played by Michael Caine. Then, unrepentant as Genghis Khan, she starts writing ''I love you'' in the sugar at the breakfast table, and just generally driving poor Mr. Caine crazy.

SPEAKING PERSONALLY;

title: CONSUMER RATES
Moscow Accuses U.S. Of War Against Aeroflot
description: The Minister of Civil Aviation accused the United States and its allies today of declaring war on Aeroflot through sanctions, ''open provocations and terroristic acts'' against the Soviet airline.

description: M IRABELLE, a French country restaurant in St. James, opened a little over two months ago, and it has already become difficult to obtain a reservation on weekday evenings. All the tangible elements that one would like to think contribute to the success of a restaurant function beautifully here.

title: Ann Elizabeth Wilbur Will Be Bride Of Andrew McCulloch Next August
description: Mr. and Mrs. James Benjamin Wilbur 3d of Geneseo, N.Y., and Manchester, Vt., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Ann Elizabeth Wilbur, to Andrew Houston McCulloch, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Andrew Carruth McCulloch of Greenwich, Conn., and New York. An August wedding is planned.

Dayton of Wayzata, Minn., was married in Manhattan yesterday to Gordon Herron Ritz Jr., the son of Mr. Ritz and Mrs. Drew C. Simonson, both of Wayzata. The Rev. Charles Amstein performed the ceremony at the Madison Avenue Presbyterian Church.

title: Protecting Drinking Water
description: The article ''Aquifers Studied by U.S.'' (Jan. 22) reported that the United States Geological Survey is working on a computer model of the ground water system in the aquifers under Nassau and Suffolk. This is good news, since replacement wells for those that have been closed because of toxic contamination can be located where there is ''pure'' water.

title: NORMA MURRAY ERVIN
description: Norma Murray Ervin, a former president of the Fire Island Association and Mayor of the Village of Saltaire, L.I., died of cancer Friday at her home in New York City. She was 67 years old.

title: Sapienza of Dartmouth Wins 3,000-Meter Title
description: Jim Sapienza, a junior from Dartmouth, captured the 3,000 meters for the second straight year during the 1984 Heptagonal Games indoor track and field championships today.

title: W. W. Parish Jr. Weds Carol Brill
description: Carol Rebecca Brill, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Nicholas Brill of Bloomington, Ill., was married yesterday to William White Parish Jr., a son of Eleanor Graves of New York and Chilmark, Mass., and the late Mr. Parish. The Rev. Bryant Kirkland performed the ceremony at the Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church.

title: DEFOLIANT STUDY SETS OFF DEBATE
description: Both sides in the continuing legal dispute over the effects of the herbicide Agent Orange in the Vietnam War asserted today that an Air Force study vindicated their opposing positions.

title: DOWN AND UP IN THE BRONX Good Deal New one-family homes in Charlotte Garden, formerly a tract of South Bronx devastation. A busy industrial park just below the Cross Bronx Expressway. A job training program for home relief clients. An air of cooperative optimism in the Bronx. These are all partly the work of the South Bronx Development Organization, headed by a redoubtable city planner, Edward Logue.
description: Forty percent of his group's support, about $1 million a year, has come from the discretionary funds of the Department of Housing and Urban Development. Suddenly the money is in trouble.

title: LINCOLN CENTER QUARTET TO PLAY AT THE 'Y'
description: WEST ORANGE T HE Emerson String Quartet, recently appointed as the only resident quartet of the Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center, will perform here next Sunday night at the Y.M.- Y.W.H.A. of Metropolitan New Jersey.

title: BAR GROUPS BATTLING MEMBERS OVER ADS
description: NEWARK W HEN New Jersey's lawyers and law firms won the right to advertise in print in 1979, county bar associations across the state worried that unseemly advertisements would tarnish the profession's image.

title: THE CAREFUL SHOPPER
description: For Umbrellas, An Open and Shut Place Zip Jack Custom Umbrella in Yonkers specializes in the manufacturing and repair of patio, chair, beach and rain designs. Emanuel Dubinsky, a co-owner, used to do all sorts of repairs on leather, suede and zippers beginning 35 years ago in the Bronx, but now the heart of this wholesale and retail business is working with decorators, designers and architects and doing the custom silk-screening on commercial orders, among them the Promenade Cafe at Rockefeller Center. Zip Jack also makes those ubiquitous Schweppes, Perrier, Kahlua and other beverage logos on umbrellas for restaurants and malls nationwide and sells them retail as well.

title: British Airways Retaliates
description: British Airways today withdrew an offer of a 4 percent pay raise retroactive to Jan. 1 in retaliation for a one-day strike Friday by flight attendants and warned that further stoppages would bring a one-year suspension of employees' special air travel discounts. The strike, which came after flight attendants rejected the offer, affected about 30,000 travelers, although officials said most were rebooked on other airlines.

title:
SPEAKING PERSONALLY;
CAUGHT IN A SECRET LIFE IN THE SMALL HOURS OF THE MORNING
description: P ICTURE yourself a housewife. Not the Beverley Hills version, but something more banal. You know - the woman with a kerchief in her hair, wearing undesigned jeans and sneakers with the tongues flopping out.

title: WINTERING ISRAELI STYLE
description: NITZA ROSOVSKY, assistant curator of exhibits at the Harvard Semitic Museum, is the author of ''Jerusalemwalks'' (Holt, Rinehart and Winston).

title: RETRIAL IS SET IN GUYANA SLAYING
description: A Federal judge here has set Sept. 4 as the date for the retrial of a former member of the People's Temple in the slaying six years ago of United States Representative Leo J. Ryan in Guyana.

description: T he older and younger generations are still having at it, but I think I detect a shift in the wind toward fairness.Even a scrupulous fairness. Am I wrong?

title: Diane E. Hines To Wed April 28
description: Mr. and Mrs. Roger A. Hines of Greenville, Del., have announced the engagement of their daughter Diane Elise Hines to Dr. Lawrence Edward Kay, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert S. Kay of Madison, N.J. The wedding is to take place on April 28.

title: THE DECOR IS A KNOCKOUT
description: T HE decor at Greenstreet is so exhilarating it sets a tone of high anticipation. You enter beside an attractive bar into a dramatic burst of greenery. Green is everywhere - in the carpet, the brick walls, the napkins on the white tablecloths and the accents of growing green plants.

title: GATHER YOUR ARTICHOKES WHILE YOU MAY, THE SEASON IS NIGH
description: A RTICHOKES, perhaps the most elegant of vegetables, are merely edible thistles. But during the Renaissance they enjoyed a reputation for being an aphrodisiac. According to the late Waverley Root, Catherine de Medici, who is said to have introduced them to France, ate so many that a contemporary chronicler recorded that she ''liked to burst.'' A shocked elderly woman of the period, wrote: ''If one of us had eaten artichokes we would have been pointed at in the streets. Today young women are more forward than pages at court.''

title: A CRITICAL PERIOD AHEAD IN THE BATTLE FOR SURVIVAL
description: T ODAY the United States Football League becomes accountable - on its playing fields, at the stadium box offices, wherever television sets are alive. After months of calling attention to itself, the league opens its second season in search of a larger audience for its product and an identity its bankers can agree upon.

title: ; 'Sportsman' in 20th Season
description: A BC's remarkably successful ''The American Sportsman'' series begins its 20th season today at 2 P.M. The first show is, as one might expect, a stirring combination of brilliant photography and physical challenge, this time involving a team of expert kayakers making the first attempt to run a long stretch of the brawling Stikine River in British Columbia.

title: THE SQUEEZE IS STILL ON AT THE STATE ARTS COUNCIL
description: The actor Maurice Schwartz used to say of his audiences, ''They wanted theater as they wanted bread.'' The arts industry in New York State today has reversed the equation, telling Albany that if the state wants art the artists need bread - the colloquial loaf that is green. But in the Legislature, those priorities collide with a larger agenda of programs and needs. The hungry can't eat art; roads can't be paved with it and, when New York City stood on the verge of bankruptcy in 1975, the bills couldn't be paid with it.

Now the main concern - especially for town and village officials watching municipal marinas on the South Shore and Fire Island, as well as for others watching boating facilities in the private sector - is how much damage the thawing ice will do to bulkheading and docks.

title: OPERA: LEONIE RYSANEK AND ANNIVERSARY GALA
description: LEONIE RYSANEK is no ordinary soprano, and the gala concert last night at the Metropolitan Opera House celebrating the 25th anniversary of her company debut was no ordinary event. It consisted of concert performances of two complete acts from Wagner operas, the second of ''Parsifal'' and the first of ''Die Walk"ure.'' By the end, the combination of her emotion and that of the audience erupted into a delirium of cheering, with Miss Rysanek literally cowering from the barrage of bouquets.

title: A TIME OF TESTING FOR ROBERTSON
description: FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla.

title: COSMOS AT IMPASSE ON STADIUM DATES
description: The United States Soccer Federation and the Cosmos have reached an impasse in attempts to resolve scheduling conflicts at Giants Stadium that jeopardize what both consider the key to soccer's success in this country - the staging of international games.

title: NEW CHAPTER FOR LEBANON
description: The departure of the United States Marines from Beirut's international airport marks the end of one phase of American involvement in Lebanon. But the almost simultaneous shellfire from the battleship New Jersey against targets ashore has left unclear what happens next for United States policy.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''You see that surf, I'm going in it. We did our job, I'll put it that way.

title: Foul Play Rejected In Student's Death
description: Detectives said yesterday that they had ruled out foul play in the death of a 20-year-old Fordham University student who was found hanged in his parents' Mount Vernon, N.Y., home Friday. It was the fifth apparent suicide this month in Westchester and Putnam Counties.

title: QUARTERLY ROUNDUP OF SALES AND EARNINGS OF 286 COMPANIES
Breakers May Sign Dupree
description: Marcus Dupree, the former star running back from the University of Oklahoma, could be with the New Orleans Breakers of the United States Football League soon, the team's owner, Joseph Canizaro, said today.

title: L.I. Firefighter, 18, Charged in Arson
description: A young volunteer firefighter was charged with twice setting fire to an unoccupied house in his neighborhood here, damaging it the first time and destroying it the second.

title: CANDIDACY OF JACKSON HIGHLIGHTS SPLIT AMONG BLACK MUSLIMS
description: R. SHIPP

title: ASPIN WOULD SPUR MILITARY RESERVES
description: The chairman of the House Armed Services subcommittee on military personnel, Representative Les Aspin, proposed a six- point program today that he said would strengthen the nation's military reserve forces.

title: EDWARD T. DOYLE
description: Edward Thompson Doyle, a stockbroker and a former Mayor of Sea Girt, N.J., died Friday at his home in Sea Girt. He was 88 years old.

title: 40 YEARS LATER, THE MESSAGE OF MONTE CASSINO: PAX
description: Forty years later, when the monks file in silently for Vespers and fill the basilica with the medieval harmonies of Gregorian chant, it is almost possible to forget.

title: 'Ethics Month' in China
description: Senior Chinese leaders took up shovels and spades and dug holes for trees today as China undertook its third annual ''Socialist Ethics Month'' campaign. Nearly one million people took part in cleaning and tree-planting ceremonies in Peking, the official New China News Agency said.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article about Coleco Industries in the Business People column Friday incorrectly reported the time when Charles Winterble left a former employer, Commodore International. He left 18 months ago, and his departure was unrelated to any recent resignations at Commodore.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: A Face From the Past

title: LEGISLATIVE CHIEFS TO PRESS CUOMO ON HIRING
description: In what some lawmakers describe as a challenge to Governor Cuomo's handling of the state budget, legislative leaders have agreed on a measure that would set the precise number of workers the Governor should hire at four major state agencies.

title: No Headline
description: Copter Bandits Missed $12 Million Army Pay

title: MISSISSIPPI STATE 74 ALABAMA 70
description: -Ken Harvey hit a layup and a free throw with 4:59 left to give Mississippi State a lead it never lost.

title: Revisionism in China: Maids Are in Demand
description: Domestic service, once reviled as exploitation, is making a comeback in Peking as living standards rise and family life styles change.

title: HOPES DWINDLING FOR RATE DECLINE
description: Hopes for lower interest rates this spring have not vanished, but they have faded because recent economic data show strong growth that many analysts expect will put upward pressure on rates.

title: Couple's Deaths Believed Suicide
description: Elmo Batterton, and his wife, Edna, whose bodies were found in a river along with their luxury car, may have committed a ''double suicide,'' the Peoria County coroner suggested today.

title: VOTE NEAR IN SENATE ON EXPORTS
description: The Senate is expected to act this week on one of the session's most hotly debated measures: a bill to set the rules under which the President may restrict exports to Communist or other countries, even allies in Western Europe.

title: BATTLES PICK UP ON BEIRUT'S GREEN LINE
description: Fighting increased today along the line dividing Christian and Moslem parts of the capital, and shells crashed into residential neighborhoods on both sides of the boundary.

title: HOUSTON CLINCHES TITLE TIE
description: Akeem Olajuwon, Michael Young and Alvin Franklin sparked a second-half comeback as Houston rallied to defeat Arkansas, 64-61, today and clinch at least a tie for the Southwest Conference basketball championship.

title: BEST JOB CHANGES FOR WOMEN LISTED
description: Women, youths and the elderly are more likely to find jobs with small businesses than with large ones, a Government study concluded.

title: Swiss Voters Uphold National Conscription
description: Swiss voters upheld the national draft today, a firmly anchored tradition that all able- bodied men must be ready to take up arms in defense of their Alpine homeland.

title: REV. SERAFIM SURRENCY
description: The Rt. Rev. Serafim Surrency, a church historian who held the honorary title of archimandrite of the Russian Orthodox Church, died last Thursday at Roosevelt Hospital. He was 58 years old and lived in New York City.

title: 76ERS LOSE FOURTH STRAIGHT
description: The Lakers beat the 76ers today, 101-99, for Philadelphia's fourth straight loss, the team's longest losing streak since the 1978-79 season.

title: Audit Cites Laxity In Prison Payrolls
description: The Department of Corrections could save more than $3 million a year with better control over the payrolls at the state's 43 correctional facilities, Comptroller Edward V. Regan said in a statement accompanying an audit released today.

title: FOLK: LORD BURGESS SINGS
description: SINCE Irving Burgie began supplying Harry Belafonte with the West Indian songs that helped make Mr. Belafonte famous almost 30 years ago, Mr. Burgie has largely given up his own performing career as a singer of Caribbean songs, for which he used the professional name Lord Burgess.

title: RANGERS VICTORIOUS BY 4-3 IN OVERTIME
description: What happened to the Rangers last night should not happen to a Stanley Cup contender. They won, 4-3, on Mark Osborne's goal with 2 minutes 18 seconds gone in overtime. But for nearly 40 minutes, they played one of their worst games of the season against one of the league's worst teams, the Pittsburgh Penguins.

title: 'YOU CAN MAKE A DIFFERENCE'
description: Candidates seeking the Presidential nomination make dozens of speeches in their campaigns. The content often varies, depending on where a speech is given and who is in the audience, but a body of material appears, with only slight variation, in nearly every such speech.

title: ABROAD AT HOME
description: By Anthony Lewis Correction: In a recent column I mistakenly said that Walter Mondale had not endorsed a nuclear freeze. He was in fact an early supporter of a mutual, verifiable freeze.

title: MusicNoted in Brief
description: Israeli Chamber Group Plays at Carnegie

title: NORMA MURRAY ERVIN
description: Norma Murray Ervin, a former president of the Fire Island Association and Mayor of the Village of Saltaire, L.I., died of cancer Friday at her home in New York City. She was 67 years old.

title: Indianapolis Tries To Acquire Colts
description: Mayor William H. Hudnut of Indianapolis confirmed today that the city was negotiating with Robert J. Irsay, the Baltimore Colts' owner.

title: U.S. PLANS NO MORE CUTS IN BEIRUT EMBASSY
description: State Department officials said today that despite the possibility of increased fighting in the Beirut area, the United States intends to maintain its diplomatic offices there.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: Aviation Group Inc., Raleigh, N.C., an all-cargo service air carrier, has formed a new unit to be called the Aviation Services group and named Charles H. Bell to be the unit's president and chief executive officer.

title: MATTINGLY IS UNHAPPY OVER OFFER
description: The Yankees have yet to announce the signings of John Montefusco last October and Roy Smalley last December, so it is not surprising that they have not announced the more recent signings of Ray Fontenot and Andre Robertson.

title: LEVENTHAL AND WAGNER LOOK BACK AT CITY HALL
description: After more than four years as the chief deputies to Mayor Koch, Nathan Leventhal and Robert F. Wagner Jr. resigned recently - Mr. Leventhal to become president of Lincoln Center and Mr. Wagner to take a teaching fellowship at Harvard University.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: POETS Monday night, after the weekend's escapism, is a night for poets and lecturers, not necessarily on the soberly heavy side, but in modes that are literary or intellectual. Tonight at 7:30, for instance, Writers in Performance holds the floor at the Manhattan Theater Club, 321 East 73d Street (472-0600). This is a series now in its 13th year of putting writers on, live, in front of an audience. They represent the widest range of current writing, from film writers to poets and letter writers.

title: PITFALLS IN TRYING TO FIX 'COMPARABLE WORTH'
