description: To the Editor:

title: MONDAY, FEBRUARY 27, 1984 International
description: Withdrawal of the U.S. marines from Beirut was completed, 17 months after they were sent to Lebanon. The bunkers they had occupied around the airport were immediately taken over by Shiite Moslem militiamen and rebel Lebanese Army units. Soon after the last marine had left, two American warships fired on Syrian gun positions in the hills. The Italian and British contingents in the multinational force have also left, leaving only the 1,250-man French unit in Beirut. The French are apparently waiting for a United Nations force to replace it. (Page A1, Column 6.) Fighting worsened in Beirut between Moslem militiamen and Lebanese Army soldiers along the green line dividing Christian and Moslem parts of the capital. Residential neighborhoods on both sides of the boundary were shelled. (A6:1.)

title: OPTIMISM ON STEEL TIE
description: Representatives of the Republic Steel Corporation and the LTV Corporation are scheduled to meet with Justice Department officials later this week to continue their discussions over how the two companies can restructure their proposed $770 million merger to satisfy the department's antitrust guidelines. The outlook is brighter that an agreement can be worked out.

title: IRT Subway Repairs Will Disrupt Service
description: The Transit Authority said yesterday that subway service would be rerouted on several lines for track and structural repairs.

title: NOT ALL NAMES FAMILIAR IN NEW HAMPSHIRE VOTE
description: For a choice, not an echo, in this Presidential primary season, New Hampshire is the place to be.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Incentives for Landlords

title: Futures/Options Farmers Hoping For Crop Record
description: UNLESS a climatic disaster like last year's drought in the grain belt occurs this season, the growers of the nation's three major crops - corn, wheat and soybeans - will try to set production records. If they succeed, it would cheer inflation watchers and bring gloom to the Administration just before the November elections.

title: WHEN 1x1x2-2
description: To the Editor:

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Aerobics for a Cause

title: CREDIT CARD SURCHARGE BAN ENDS
description: A law barring merchants from charging extra for purchases made with credit cards is expiring Monday, opening the way for retailers to impose surcharges against the more than 55 million American households that use credit cards.

title: Lockridge Takes Mayweather's Title
description: Rocky Lockridge ended Roger Mayweather's reign as World Boxing Association junior lightweight champion today with a devastating overhand right knockout punch just 1 minute 31 seconds into the first round of their scheduled 15-round title fight.

title: GERMAN INDUSTRY SHIFTING TO SOUTH
description: Slowly, as years of recession and lagging demand have weakened the once-formidable steel mills and coal mines of the Ruhr, economic power in West Germany has been shifting from its gritty, industrial north to trim, growing cities in the south.

title: Maurice Tabard Dies in Paris; French Fashion Photographer
description: Maurice Tabard, a French photographer who worked in the United States and was commissioned by Harpers Bazaar, died Thursday at his home in Nice, news reports said.

title: BRITISH RACE IS ON IN MICROCOMPUTERS
description: Just as in the United States, leading computer companies in Britain are homing in on the booming microcomputer market. In the process, solid homegrown competitors, several of which hope to become high-volume international players, are confronting the American companies.

title: NAVY LIMITS ITS GUNFIRE ON BEIRUT TO RETALIATION
description: Spokesmen for the Department of Defense said today that, under the rules of engagement governing United States naval gunfire and air strikes in Lebanon, attacks were limited to firing back after hostile fire had been aimed at Americans.

title: TAX-EXEMPT VOLUME WILL INCREASE
description: After this week's auctions of Treasury bills and $6 billion of five-year notes, the market in Government securities will start a four-week respite during which the only financings will involve bills and two-year notes.

title: The Editorial Notebook; The Science of Prize-Giving
description: Edward Fredkin is no misanthrope, but if he has his way the world's best chess player will one day not be human. Mr. Fredkin has offered a $100,000 prize for the first computer to win the world chess championship. That goal drew visibly nearer last month when a computer received a Master rating in tournament chess, and a $5,000 prize from Mr. Fredkin.

title: STATES ARE MOVING TO CONTROL COSTS FOR HEALTH CARE
description: State legislatures across the country are moving vigorously to try to reduce the rising cost of health care.

title: The Darkness Called Iran
description: Some of our most poignant letters are from Wilmette, Ill., headquarters of the Bahai faith. They bear the names of men, women and children killed in Iran for ''crimes against God.''

title: Youth Kills Six-Foot Lizard
description: In these days of Dungeons and Dragons, Rodney Cameron is about as close to a real dragon slayer as might be found in Ohio. The 19-year-old used a .22-caliber rifle, not an enchanted sword, to bag an African lizard nearly 6 feet long. He found it in a pond in his family's backyard.

title: 35 YEARS OF GAME SHOWS SURVEYED
description: SHORT film clips or video clips are bigger than ever on television these days. You name it - bloopers, histories of rock- and-roll, stand-up comics, newsreel footage, even commercials - and eager producers are running to the archives to paste together a ''special'' around the subject. What's more, viewers seem to like these recycling exercises in nostalgia.

title: No Headline
description: Use of Newark Airport Surpasses La Guardia

title: BLACK-TIE AUCTION IS SERIOUS BUSINESS TO LONGHORN BREEDERS
description: It had the look and feel of a designer show of the latest in fashion: the audience of black-tied Texans in $500 boots and ten-gallon hats and their wives in elegant gowns, plus two or three Europeans looking slightly bemused at it all.

title: HOUSE BILL PROVIDES FUNDS FOR TEACHING OF KEY LANGUAGES
description: The House has passed a bill that would provide $150 million in grants for teaching foreign languages in an effort to improve Americans' ability to communicate with people in foreign countries on national security and international trade matters.

title: SPORTS WORLD SPECIALS
description: Spoiling for a Fight

title: POP: ADAM ANT AT RADIO CITY
description: ADAM ANT and the Romantics, two acts that together sold out Radio City Music Hall on Saturday, aspire to vastly different concepts of rock-and- roll glory. Adam Ant, who was the headliner, is a leader of the so-called new romantics of English rock.

title: Labor's Stake in Bankruptcy
description: Should the bankruptcy laws be a path of escape for companies stuck with high-cost labor contracts? The Supreme Court has now ruled that union contracts can indeed be abrogated as part of an effort to save a company in a ''Chapter 11'' reorganization. But organized labor argues that bankruptcy is becoming a ploy for union busting. It wants Congress to exempt union contracts from renegotiation.

title: Home Oil Prices Dip in the State
description: Home heating oil prices have dropped slightly following January price increases averaging 20 cents a gallon, the executive director of the Consumer Protection Board, Richard Kessel, said today.

title: ADVERTISING
description: Accounts

title: Cranston to Drop A Challenge to Hart
description: Alan Cranston said today that his supporters in New York would drop their challenge of Gary Hart's petitions to qualify him for that state's April 3 primary.

title: JAPAN FACES BIND ON FARM IMPORTS
description: Takako Matsuno wrote to the Yomiuri, the nation's largest newspaper, with a complaint the other day.

title: Sibson Takes Title
description: Tony Sibson of Britian regained the European middleweight boxing title Saturday with a majority decision over Louis Acaries of France. There were no knockdowns in the 12-rounder. Sibson, who attacked relentlessly, was staggered in the seventh.

title: GENERALS DEFEAT STALLIONS BY 17-6
description: The New Jersey Generals opened their second season with a modest triumph today, not gaudy but promising.

title: CURRENCY TRADER RELEASED
description: J. David Dominelli, the embattled financial adviser who cultivated the image of an astute currency trader, was released today, shortly after midnight, after being confined for 10 hours in a Federal prison for contempt of court.

title: Advertising; Accounts At Y. & R., Ayer Shift
description: A S last week came to a close, N. W. Ayer and Young & Rubicam were party to a pair of account moves involving two of Ayer's oldest clients - Dart & Kraft Inc.'s Dairy Products Group and the American Telephone and Telegraph Company.

title: Higher Heat Bills Cited
description: Americans spent nearly $700 million more than normal to heat their homes and offices in January because of below-normal temperatures in much of the East and South, according to the Government. The January chill, added to bitter cold in December, raised the nation's seasonal heating bill to $35.6 billion, $1.7 billion more than normal for this time of year.

title: THE OUTLOOK FOR ISRAELIS: NEW THREATS
description: Israel's military position is less secure and its strategic future more threatened than seemed possible 20 months ago, according to senior Israeli intelligence and operations officers at headquarters here and officers and soldiers in Lebanon. Some officers say they advocate a withdrawal further south in Lebanon, back to the Litani River instead of the more northerly Awali.

title: Reagan Criticized on Rights
description: The American Civil Liberties Union said today that the Reagan Administration was undermining civil rights law in a way that ''could plunge the country back into historic patterns of race and sex discrimination.''

title: MIDWESTERN 'MONEY MAKER'
description: Carl H. Lindner, the Cincinnati financier, likes to hand out index cards with neatly typed sayings. One of his favorites reads, ''I don't understand balance sheets very well, but I do understand people very well.''

title: PPB'S THAT CAN HURT
description: To the Editor:

title: Vienna Museum to Send 75 Old Masters to U.S.
description: A major exhibition of 75 Old Master drawings from the Albertina Museum in Vienna, including works by Michelangelo, D"urer, Raphael, Bruegel, Rembrandt, Watteau and Poussin, will be shown at the National Gallery of Art in Washington, Oct. 28 to Jan. 13, and the Pierpont Morgan Library, March 8, 1985 to May 26, 1985. Some of the drawings, including D"urer's ''Praying Hands,'' have never been shown outside the Albertina.

title: Red Wings 4 Black Hawks 2
description: Brad Park scored his 200th career goal, and Steve Yzerman and Bob Manno got goals in the second period as Detroit won its fifth straight.

title: The Calendar
description: Monday

title: 'HILL STREET' RATINGS DROP EVALUATED
description: A hit television program can be a delicate thing. It often requires nurturing and gentle care to keep it in the best of health. A good example of that principle is NBC's showcase drama, ''Hill Street Blues,'' the Thursday night police program that in recent years has given the network a double reward - the praise of critics and reasonably large audiences.

title: JACKSON ADMITS SAYING 'HYMIE' AND APOLOGIZES AT A SYNAGOGUE
description: The Rev. Jesse Jackson acknowledged tonight that he had used the word ''Hymie'' in a private conversation to refer to Jews.

title: IN BUFFALO, A GALA BALL RECALLS BLIZZARD OF '77
description: The band played ''Let It Snow.'' Gloria Lehmann remembered being stranded overnight in the Prudential Building. David Shumsky talked about how he ''just tried to survive.''

title: BUSINESS DIGEST MONDAY, FEBRUARY 27, 1984
description: The Economy

title: ADVERTISING
description: New Yorker Earnings

title: BRIEFING
description: C.I.A. Without Glamour

title: MUSIC NOTED IN BRIEF
description: Renaissance Band Does Italian Works

title: IRAN AND IRAQ ISSUE CONFLICTING REPORTS ON FIGHTING
description: Iran's press agency reported that Iraqi planes bombed two Iranian cities today, killing 67 people and wounding more than 230 others

title: STATE-OF-THE-ART FORUM ON U.S. POLICY
description: To the Editor:

title: Woman and Son Found Slain on L.I.
description: A woman and her son were found slain yesterday in their home in Oceanside, L.I., the Nassau County police said.

title: SPORTS WORLD SPECIALS
description: Tennis Fashion Show

title: Question Box
description: QUESTION: Team A in a National Football League game has the ball on its 20-yard line. The quarterback throws a pass to the tight end on the 25-yard line. The tight end advances 5 yards and tosses a backward pass to a running-back teammate. He goes the rest of the way for a touchdown. Who gets credit for the 80 yards gained, or is the yardage divided?

title: Cerebral Hemorrhage Strikes Taiwan Official
description: Prime Minister Sun Yun-suan underwent emergency surgery for a cerebral hemorrhage today and was recovering in satisfactory condition, officials reported.

title: OUTDOORS: PERSONALIZED CARTRIDGES
description: O N fall afternoons many years ago, when I was leading the family cow home to be milked, I often passed by a meadow where a few of the men of the town had gathered to shoot clay pigeons tossed out before them with a simple hand trap.

title: P.S.A.L. Playoffs Resume Thursday
description: With most of the strongest teams in contention for the Division A title, the Public Schools Athletic League basketball tournament advances to the quarterfinal round Thursday and Friday.

title: MUSIC NOTED IN BRIEF;
description: Anton Kuerti at Piano For Beethoven Sonatas

title: ABSTRACT STRUCTURE WILL STAND APART
description: AT first glance, nothing seems more implausible than the controversial plan by the architect I. M. Pei to erect a An Appraisal glass pyramid in the middle of the courtyard of the Louvre Museum. How could the French, who pride themselves on being rigid guardians of their cultural heritage, desecrate this great landmark? But whatever else can be said about this startling plan, which has been personally approved by President Francois Mitterrand, it is not as inconsistent as it might first seem. There is a long tradition of dramatic, almost brazen gestures in French architecture and urbanism, of plans and structures that shatter the serene neo-classicism that makes up the basic fabric of Paris.

title: WHEN HER OFFICE IS AT HOME
description: GONE are those delightful moments of comic banter around the water cooler. Gone are the trusty colleagues who could always be relied upon to put wild ideas into perspective. And gone are the distinguished title and niche in the company that provided a very special sort of identity.

title: Free the Prisoners, Walesa Suggests
description: Lech Walesa urged Poland's Communist authorities today to free political prisoners and said he and his advisers were working out plans to help remedy the nation's crippled economy.

title: ADVERTISING
description: A $20 Million Week at K.& E. Kenyon & Eckhardt had a $20

title: Olympic Artifacts At the Metropolitan
description: Ancient Grecian artifacts depicting Olympic sports events are on permanent display at the Metropolitan Museum of Art, Fifth Avenue at 82d Street.

title: Venezuela Interest Rates
description: The Venezuelan central bank has decided to establish a selective system of interest rates intended to stimulate the agriculture and housing industries, an official communique said.

title: RESIDENTS UNDER SIEGE OF CANDIDATES' BARRAGE
description: In the final days before the primary Tuesday, the expensive campaign strategies crafted in Washington and New York have come to earth. The barrage descends, and on the bleak, gray stretch of Waterman Street in a working-class district, the people in their clapboard houses are under siege.

title: Nuclear Panel Move Resisted
description: An effort by the nuclear industry to thwart more Government-ordered safety improvements to power plants is being rejected by Federal regulators.

title: DANCE: 2 ETHNIC VIEWS
description: ART RESOURCES FOR TEACHERS AND STUDENTS INC. was founded 14 years ago on the Lower East Side to offer training in Chinese and Hispanic art forms to young people. On Saturday at Pace University's Schimmel Center, several teachers at the institution presented a program of dances derived from both cultures.

title: 5 of 13 Cars Pass All Tests
description: Only five of 13 new automobiles tested by the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration have passed all the safety criteria of the Federal Government, according to the Center for Auto Safety, a privaate consumer group. The center which obtained the test results under the Freedom of Information Act, said Friday the five vehicles met the safety criteria when crashed at at 35 miles an hour. The cars were a Chevrolet Cavalier convertible, a Pontiac Fiero, a Dodge Daytona, a Chevrolet Corvette and an AMC Jeep CJ-7.

title: LID ON TECHNOLOGY FLOW ABROAD SAID TO EXCEED RECOMMENDATIONS
description: A staff report to the National Academy of Sciences has concluded that the Reagan Administration's effort to restrict the flow of technology to foreign nations is far more restrictive than the limits recommended by an academy panel 18 months ago.

title: BROAD GAINS MADE IN 4TH-QUARTER PROFITS
description: With the majority of quarterly profit reports in, most major corporations reported higher earnings for the fourth quarter of 1983 compared with the corresponding period a year earlier, thanks to the economy's strong climb from the deep recession that ended in the fourth quarter of 1982.

title: Nets Still Question Mark
description: ''One shot!'' the coach was yelling. ''Hold it!''

title: Addendum
description: * People magazine is increasing its circulation rate base 5.8 percent, to 2.75 million, from 2.6 million, with the July 2 issue.

title: V. S. KHACHATURIAN
description: Vava Sarkis Khachaturian, a painter in the second half of her life, died of cancer Saturday in Saint Luke's Hospital. She was 89 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: BASQUE VOTERS FAIL TO GIVE CLEAR MAJORITY TO MODERATES
description: After a violent campaign in the Basque country, the moderate Basque Nationalist Party retained its hold on the regional Parliament today. But it did not gain the clear majority that would allow it to rule unchallenged.

title: OLYMPIAN'S DEBUT IN N.H.L. A SHUTOUT
description: Mario Gosselin, the Olympic goaltender playing his first National Hockey League game, turned aside 26 shots today to lead the Quebec Nordiques to a 5-0 victory over the St. Louis Blues.

title: GOVERNORS' PANEL URGES TAXES AND SPENDING CUTS TO REDUCE DEFICIT
description: The executive committee of the National Governors Association called upon the Administration today to increase taxes and avoid linking income taxes to inflation to help reduce the projected deficit by more than half.

title: Sohio Quits Shale Project CLEVELAND, Feb. 26 (Reuters) - The Standard Oil Company (Ohio) has announced that it is pulling out as a partner in the $2.5 billion Paraho-Ute oil shale project in Utah.
description: The action follows Friday's announcement that Sohio and two partners in another Utah venture, the White River oil shale project, have withdrawn their application with the Synthetic Fuels Corporation for Federal financial aid.

title: REAGAN'S BAY OF PIGS
description: As U.S. Marines depart Lebanon, mission unaccomplished, let us examine the series of misconceptions and blunders that brought about Mr. Reagan's Bay of Pigs:

title: ADVERTISING
description: Badillo/Compton Office

title: Mt. McKinley Searchers Believe Climber Is Dead
description: Two mountain climbers who searched Mount McKinley for Naomi Uemura said today they had found scraps of his provisions in an ice cave, but that they believed he had fallen to his death.

title: FLYERS DEFEAT ISLANDERS
description: In a tumultuous game in which the Flyer goaltender got an assist and the referee left with a knee injury, Philadelphia ended the Islanders' winning streak at four games tonight with a 5-3 victory.

title: Heptagonal Track Is Won by Penn
description: Dave Pharr set a meet record in the 500- meter run, anchored the victorious 1,600-meter relay team and led Penn to the team victory in the Heptagonal indoor track and field championships today at Princeton's Jadwin Gym.

title: Texas Official Terms President 'Muy Loco'
description: State Agriculture Commissioner Jim Hightower drew shouts of ''viva'' and a standing ovation from 500 members of the United Farm Workers of America today by attacking President Reagan as ''very crazy'' in Spanish.

title: No Headline
description: Harvard Editor Ousted For Being an Impostor

title: Viewtron Assigns Videotex to D'Arcy
description: D'Arcy-MacManus Masius has been assigned a small piece of business that could have a very bright future in the communications and information age. It is the Viewtron videotex service being operated in south Florida by the Viewdata Corporation of America, a subsidiary of Knight- Ridder Newspapers, and A.T.&T. Consumer Products.

title: More Than $1.4 Million Paid for Copley Portrait
description: The family of Thomas Gage, the British general who was military governor of Massachusetts at the time of the American Revolution, have sold a famous portrait of his wife to a New York gallery.

title: MONDAY SPORTS Basketball
description: Knicks vs. Atlanta Hawks , at Madison Square Garden, 7:35 P.M. The Knicks lost to the Hawks in overtime in Atlanta on Friday night, their third loss to them in three games this season. Without a victory in the last five games, the Knicks are in their longest losing streak of the season. (Television - MSG, 7:30 and 1 A.M.; WTBS, 7:30 P.M. Radio - WNEW, 1130; 7:30 P.M.)

title: Louisiana Official Says Primary Will Be Held
description: The Louisiana Secretary of State, Jim Brown, says the state's Presidential primary election will be held April 7, as scheduled, even though the Legislature voted to cancel it.

title: Truck Driver Killed by Car
description: A tow truck driver was struck and killed by a car early today while trying to hook up a disabled vehicle to his truck, the Suffolk County police said. The victim was identified as David Weidenhammer, 28 years old, of Levittown. Sgt. Brian Malone said the accident happened at the intersection of Route 109 and the Southern State Parkway at 3:38 A.M. He said Mr. Weidenhammer was hit by a car driven by Joni Calichio, 27, of Lindenhurst. She was charged with driving while intoxicated, the sergeant said.

title: Super Bowl For Yanks?
description: GEORGE STEINBRENNER has taken some teasing in the past - perhaps even a trifle bit in this space - for forcing his modest background in the compulsive structure of football into the less regimented world of baseball.

title: PRIMARY BATTLE MOUNTS AS HART SAYS HE'LL BE 2D
description: The battle for position in the first Democratic Presidential primary of 1984 took on a more aggressive tone today as Senator Gary Hart of Colorado predicted that he would defeat John Glenn for second place.

title: ROZIER HELD TO 27 YARDS AS OUTLAWS BEAT MAULERS
description: The Oklahoma Outlaws used a 12-yard pass from Doug Williams to Derek Hughes today to beat the Pittsburgh Maulers, 7-3, for their first United States Football League victory.

title: Giants to Get Expos' Oliver SCOTTSDALE, Ariz., Feb. 26 (AP) - Al Oliver, the National League batting champion two years ago for Montreal and one of baseball's top hitters during his 15-year major league career, was traded today to the San Francisco Giants for the pitcher Fred Breining and another player, it was reported. The trade was confirmed by John McHale, the Expos' general manager. The other player from the Giants was not named.
description: The Giants called a news conference for Monday morning to announce the deal, which was made after another trade fell through that would have brought Bill Buckner from the Chicago Cubs, according to the Oakland Tribune and the San Francisco Chronicle.

title: Leonard Bernstein Bruises Rib in a Fall
description: The conductor Leonard Bernstein suffered a bruised rib Saturday night when he fell from a podium after conducting a performance of the Vienna Philharmonic Orchestra.

title: 4 CHILDREN DIE TRYING TO ESCAPE BLAZE IN NEWARK
description: Four children were killed early this morning as they tried to flee through a back door of their burning frame house in this city's North Ward, fire officials said.

title: Angola Truce Imperiled, South Africa Says
description: Foreign Minister Roelof F. Botha said tonight that South Africa had expressed ''extreme concern'' to the Angolan Government that black guerrilla activity was endangering a three-week- old cease-fire.

title: Veta-Seiscom Tie
description: The Veta Grande Companies, acting as part of a group, filed an amended 13D report with the Securities and Exchange Commission disclosing that the group holds 30.2 percent of the stock of Seiscom Delta Inc. The report said that the shares had been bought as an investment and that the group might acquire 50 percent or more of the stock or dispose of the securities.

title: Who, Us?
description: Just in time for the 1984 campaign, Attorney General William French Smith finds ''no credible evidence'' of criminality by anyone on the 1980 Reagan staff. Indeed, no sign of a crime when someone got briefing books from Jimmy Carter's camp.

title: MORE AMERICANS SENT TO SALVADOR
description: In the last year, the number of United States officials working in El Salvador has risen substantially, official figures show.

title: Deere to Pay Penalty
description: Deere & Company has agreed to pay a $109,000 civil penalty to settle charges that it violated a law prohibiting companies from aiding the Arab boycott of businesses tied to Israel, the Commerce Department said. Between November 1981 and May 1982, the maker of farm equipment, through its West German distribution center, furnished 109 items of information to four Arab countries. The items certified that goods Deere was supplying were not of Israeli origin, the department said Friday.

title: Interest-Free Banks in Iran
description: Iran will introduce interest-free banking in accordance with Islamic law in four months, its central bank governor was quoted today as saying.

title: MAKER OF BICYCLES TURNING OPTIMITSTIC
description: Vulnerability to the fads of youth is nothing new to bicycle makers. Skateboards and roller skates, in their day, captured the interest of young people who might otherwise have bought bicycles. But nothing, industry executives say, compared with video games.

title: BUSINESS PEOPLE
description: Filling of Post Aids Flexi-Van Control

title: A.M.C. Offering
description: The American Motors Corporation said it would sell 10 million common shares to the public and add another 3 million to its employee pension funds. In addition, the French auto maker Renault - the principal holder of A.M.C. stock - will buy another 11.1 million shares of A.M.C. stock so its holdings in the company remain at 46 percent, A.M.C. said. A.M.C. said the proceeds of the offering would be used to develop new products. The offerings will put the number of common shares outstanding at 106.4 million, up from 82.2 million at the end of last year.

title: DANCE: PREMIERE OF 'SONGS OF MAHLER'
description: SOME concertgoers find Mahler's music grandiose. For others, it is only lachrymose. But no one can deny its high seriousness and total sincerity, and ballets to Mahler are often almost painfully sincere.

title: REPORTER'S NOTEBOOK: LABOR AND THE ISSUE OF LEBANON
description: The Executive Council of the American Federation of Labor-Congress of Industrial Organizations said in a statement last week that President Reagan's Lebanon policy ''has failed.''

title: WINNER TAKES NOT ALL
description: To the Editor:

title: HEAD OF WILLIAM MORRIS JOINED MAILROOM IN '53
description: When Lee Stevens was hired 31 years ago to work in the mailroom at the William Morris Agency in New York, he did not venture to think that one day he would become president of the nation's largest talent management company. ''And if I did think of it,'' he added, ''I kept it to myself.''

title: Trump Thinks Big As Generals Open
description: Donald Trump, who deals in 68-story skyscrapers, waved toward the 62,300 people crowding the two-tiered block of Alabama real estate known as Legion Field and decided that things were looking up in the risky business of confronting the Establishment of professional football.

title: Washington Watch; Fed Search Nearly Over
description: WASHINGTON T HE White House, which is running late in its

title: MACHINE TOOL ORDERS UP IN JANUARY
description: Machine tool orders in January jumped more than 26 percent from the previous month and were more than double those in January 1982, an industry association reported yesterday. But shipments fell considerably.

title: ADVERTISING;
description: Jason Robards will star in a $16 million television and print advertising campaign to promote I.D.S./ American Express.

title: AMERICAN PRIEST KILLED IN BEIRUT
description: An American priest, the Rev. James Michael Finegan, was killed by shellfire today in the Ashrafiye neighborhood of predominantly Christian East Beirut, a police spokesman said.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: A Night at the Opera, Without Opera

title: Appeals Court Bars Release Of Chicago Slayer of 1940's
description: A Federal appeals court Friday blocked the release of William Heirens, convicted 38 years ago in a series of murders. The killer scrawled a message to the authorities: ''Catch me before I kill more.''

title: Dalai Lama Deplores A 'Bamboo Curtain'
description: The Dalai Lama, Tibet's self-exiled god- king, said today that China has built a Bamboo Curtain on its border and an Iron Curtain in its mind to keep out good ideas.

title: AQUINO'S PARTY TO TAKE PART IN VOTE FOR ASSEMBLY IN MAY
description: The party of the slain opposition leader Benigno S. Aquino voted unanimously today to take part in elections scheduled for this spring.

title: RULES FOR PARTIES PROPOSED TO CURB DRINKING AT RUTGERS
description: Rutgers University officials have proposed guidelines for private parties on campus that include requirements that they be registered in advance and that food and soft drinks be available whenever alcoholic beverages are served.

title: SHOREHAM SAFETY ISSUE IS NO 'CHARADE'
description: To the Editor:

title: SURROGATE MOTHERS: PROBLEMS AND GOALS
description: Under other circumstances, the married couple and the single woman who sat down together on a recent evening at the Infertility Center of New York would probably never have met. But they did meet, to discuss the possibility that the woman be artificially inseminated with the husband's semen, carry a child through pregnancy and relinquish it to them upon birth.

title: ; PITFALLS IN TRYING TO FIX 'COMPARABLE WORTH'
description: To the Editor:

title: ANONYMOUS BENEFACTOR WILL LEAVE N.Y.U. UP TO $15 MILLION
description: An estate with an estimated value of $11 million to $15 million has been pledged to New York University by a benefactor who has requested anonymity, Dr. John Brademas, the president of N.Y.U., said yesterday.

title: SAFETY RULES AND LAXITY CITED AS DRIVING UP REACTOR COSTS
description: Electric utilities attribute many of their problems in building nuclear power plants to excessive and unpredictable governmental regulations and the legal and political obstacles generated by the antinuclear movement.

title: BBDO to Acquire Thompson-Leeds
description: Big general agencies, whose growth is frequently slowed by client conflict problems, in recent years have taken to acquiring specialty communications companies in health care, direct marketing, public relations, sales promotion or graphics. Until now they seemed to have overlooked point-of-purchase advertising, which is any product promotion at the retail level with a little pizzaz.

title: Debt Issues
description: * BP Housing Acceptance Corp., a new affiliate of A. G. Becker Paribas, has filed for $500 million of Ginnie Mae collateralized bonds, Series 1984- A, through A. G. Becker Paribas.

title: Miami Cubans Object To Jane Fonda Visits
description: Publicity appearances by Jane Fonda at two Miami department stores were canceled today because of a bomb threat and pressure from the conservative Cuban exile community, department store officials said.

title: Dividend Meetings
description: Following is a partial list of dividend meetings for the week of Feb. 27, 1984: MONDAY Allen GroupRio Grande IndusBlair (John) & CoWatkins-JohnsonRepublic Corp

title: Winter Sports ; SLALOM RACE WON BY MISS MCKINNEY
description: Tamara McKinney, the defending overall World Cup champion who just missed winning an Olympic skiing medal, gained her first victory of the year today by winning the slalom at the United States Alpine championships.

title: MILES AND GAF OFFICIALS TAKE GENEX POSITIONS
description: The Genex Corporation, which manufactures specialty chemicals using new biotechnology techniques, has named a Miles Laboratories official to be its new president.

title: Police Try to Link Tear-Gas Attacks
description: Investigators say there may be a link between tear-gas bombings that occurred a day apart at the State University Center at Buffalo and York University in Toronto.

title: TRIAL FOR ERNIE KOVACS BECOMING A DOCUDRAMA
description: Docudramas and biographies have become a commonplace on television, but occasionally a genuinely dramatic and unfamiliar true story promises to redeem the genre. ABC's Circle Films began shooting this week on ''Ernie Kovacs: Between the Laughter,'' a two-hour film dramatizing one period in the life of the comedian who enchanted television and film viewers in the 1950's.

title: No Headline
description: RIGHT IN HER SOUL. The Life of Anna Louise Strong. By Tracy B. Strong and Helene Keyssar. 399 pages. Random House. $22.95.

title: ARAFAT AND KING HUSSEIN RESUME TALKS ON COORDINATING POSITIONS
description: King Hussein of Jordan and the Palestine Liberation Organization chairman, Yasir Arafat, met here today for talks that are expected to focus on coordinating their approach to the Middle East peace process.

title: CURRENT INTEREST RATES
description: Tax-Exempt Bonds*9.80

title: PROSECUTOR'S APPEAL TO DROP CONVICTION SETS STAGE FOR BATTLE
description: A prosecuting attorney has asked that a conviction won by his office be dismissed because of doubt about the defendant's guilt. The judge refused to set aside the verdict, setting the stage for an unusual legal contest.

title: Conrail Trains Collide In Pennsylvania
description: Two Conrail trains collided, derailed and caught fire today, injuring at least two railroad workmen and causing auevacuation of nearby residents as a precaution.

title: Psychiatrist's Former Wife Wins in Suit Over Injections
description: A jury has awarded $6.5 million to Ann C. Sleeper, who, in a lawsuit, accused her former husband, a psychiatrist, of subjecting her to experiments including injecting her with her own urine.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Keeping Track

title: MISS NAVRATILOVA INTIMIDATING FORCE
description: Virginia Wade's eyes crinkled and she smiled as she observed last week that Martina Navratilova ''doesn't even sweat, except for maybe one little wet patch on her back.''

title: MOSLEMS MOVE IN
description: The United States Marine contingent completed its withdrawal from Beirut today.

title: The U.N. Today Feb. 27, 1984
description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY

title: Listed below are the target release dates for major economic indicators scheduled to be released this week.
description: Monday

title: THEATER: 'MY NAME IS ALICE,' AT AMERICAN PLACE
description: ''A. . . MY NAME IS ALICE'' is the less-than-inspiring title of a delightful new musical revue in the cellar of the American Place Theater. And when I say cellar, I'm not exaggerating. ''Alice'' is being performed in a small and airless room, reached by elevator. The show has few production values, odd curtain times (never 8 P.M., except on Sundays) and only a piano for a band. It's amazing how little any of that matters, however, when there's fresh talent on display almost everywhere you look.

title: PEI'S PYRAMID DESIGN FOR THE LOUVRE SPARKS DEBATE IN PARIS
description: Its enemies refer to it as Pharaoh Francois's Pyramid. Its supporters consider it a brilliant architectural project.

title: MEESE, IN BLACK AND WHITE
description: Some public confrontations transcend their immediate purpose and serve to define a nation. The Senate Judiciary Committee's examination of the qualifications of Edwin Meese 3d to be Attorney General and, in that connection, a review of the civil rights policies pursued by Mr. Meese as White House counselor and the Justice Department during the Reagan Administration is such an occasion.

title: SPORTS WORLD SPECIALS
description: Positive Images

title: TALKS NOT BOGGED DOWN, AGENCY DIRECTOR ASSERTS
description: A little less than a year ago, a majority of the Foreign Relations Committee advised the Senate that Kenneth L. Adelman was ''not qualified'' to be director of the Arms Control and Disarmament Agency. But Mr. Adelman survived what he calls his ''confirmation ordeal'' by a vote of 57 to 42 on the Senate floor and says he is engaged in an effort to rejuvenate the agency, which many people had feared he intended to purge.

title: Columbia Wins Ivy Fencing Title
description: The Columbia men's fencing team captured its first Ivy League championship in 10 years when it defeated Princeton, 17-10, at Levien Gymnasium yesterday, ending a string of eight straight years in which Pennsylvania won or shared the title.

title: KOCH, IN VISIT TO BERLIN, TAKES IN EAST AN WEST
description: As Mayor Koch arrived at Checkpoint Charlie, the Allied crossing point of the Berlin Wall, East German border guards busily snapped his picture. The Mayor saw them and waved. ''I'm here,'' he shouted. ''It's me. It's me.''

title: CAN'T TELL THE HEAVIES WITHOUT PEEK AT THE FLAGS
description: Cabinet officers have flags. So do under secretaries. Not just the Stars and Stripes, but departmental and agency colors that subtly but graphically denote size and sort of authority.

title: 2 INCIDENTS STILL HAUNT MARYLAND
description: COLLEGE PARK, Md.

title: Bridge: Furhmann and Wieland Win Greater New York Tourney
description: The annual Life Master-Newcomer Tournament of the Greater New York Bridge Association was won Friday night by George Fuhrmann of New York and Richard Wieland of Norwalk, Conn.

title: McGovern Appoints New Campaign Director
description: George McGovern announced tonight that a Hawaii businessman had taken over as his national campaign director.

title: ADRIFT IN SALVADOR, WITHOUT A RUDDER
description: Even as one of President Reagan's policies collapses, in Lebanon, another carries us more deeply into the morass of El Salvador. Optimistic spokesmen acknowledge that we are in for a long struggle, but insist we are on the right road and making progress.

title: INFORMATION OFFICIALS DESTROYED RECORDS ON BLACKLISTED SPEAKERS
description: Officials of the United States Information Agency said today that the agency had destroyed records indicating why certain people had been barred from participation in an overseas speakers program sponsored by the Federal Government.

title: PARK AVE. RESIDENTS WANT A NEW DELI TO GO
description: Kyung-Sung Choi thinks that a 24- hour delicatessen selling some fruits, vegetables and other foods is just what Park Avenue needs. He has not been in this country long.

title: NOLAND CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Including gains of $192,000 for the latest year and $48,000 for the previous year from property sales.

title: JOSEPH H. TAGGART, EX-DEAN AT BUSINESS SCHOOL OF N.Y.U.
description: Dr. Joseph H. Taggart, dean emeritus of the Graduate School of Business Administration at New York University and the holder of several government economics posts, died yesterday at his home in Manhattan. He was 81 years old.

title: COHU INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After losses of $100,000 for the quarter and $314,446 for the year from discontinued operations and losses of $100,000 for the quarter and $70,000 for the year on the sale of discontinued operations. Year-ago revenues include a gain of $205,672 from the sale of land.

title: FUTURES/OPTIONS Oil Up Sharply on Fear Of an Iranian Blockade
description: International oil prices on the spot market rose sharply yesterday in response to fears of an Iranian blockade of the Strait of Hormuz, one of the main lifelines for the world's oil supply.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: A TIME OF PASSION. America 1960-1980. By Charles R. Morris. 270 pages. Cornelia & Michael Bessie/Harper & Row. $17.50.

title: U.S. SURGICAL IN SETTLEMENT TO RESTATE EARNINGS
description: The United States Surgical Corporation agreed today to reduce its previously reported earnings from 1979 through 1982 by $26 million, after the Securities and Exchange Commission accused the manufacturer and seven officials, including its chief executive, of violating Federal securities laws.

title: American Equity
description: The American Equity Investment Trust said it had rejected an unsolicited proposal from a West Coast investor to acquire all the outstanding shares of beneficial interest in the trust.

title: Lawyers of Dissidents Criticized in Warsaw
description: The authorities today criticized a group of lawyers who have defended clients from the banned Solidarity union and other dissidents.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Strategist for Men

title: CORRECTION
description: An article by The Associated Press in Business Day on Friday, about Imperial Chemical Industries, misstated the company's revenue figures. Revenues rose 12 percent in 1983, to $12 billion, from $10.7 billion in 1982.

title: WALKER IS UNSURE ON PLANS AFTER '85
description: Herschel Walker said today that he did not know what team he might be playing for after the 1985 United States Football League season, when his contract with the New Jersey Generals expires. But Donald J. Trump, the team's owner, has made it clear that retaining the rights to Walker is a primary objective this year.

title: Schools in Pact On Substitutes
description: The Board of Education and the United Federation of Teachers have signed an agreement on the first contract for day-to-day substitute teachers - known as per diem substitutes - in New York City's public schools.

title: FOR L.I. SHOPPERS, IT'S A SUPERSTORE
description: Among the malls and supermarkets that dot the suburban landscape, a new type of store has opened to keep up with what retail experts say is the changing nature of the suburban family.

title: RIBI IMMUNOCHEM RESEARCH reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Charges at L.S.U.
description: Two former football players at Louisiana State have told N.C.A.A. investigators that L.S.U. athletes received payoffs, cars, clothes and other illegal gifts. Donald Polk, a former quarterback, and Clyde Bishop, a former wide receiver, described a network of wealthy alumni that players nicknamed ''money men'' who financially subsidized individual athletes during their football careers at the school.

title: REAGAN AND GOVERNORS MEET AMID SIGNS OF DEFICIT CLASH
description: President Reagan and his budget director, David A. Stockman, today held out little hope to the nation's Governors that the Administration would accept immediate tax increases or military spending cuts to reduce the Federal budget deficit, according to several governors.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * American Management Systems Inc., Washington, a computer systems and consulting company, has appointed Paul Oliver a vice president.

title: Mortgage Backing For Nevada Stock
description: The Coast Capital Corporation, a subsidiary of the Coast Savings and Loan Association of Las Vegas, Nev., is introducing the first public issue of mortgage-collateralized adjustable- rate preferred stock. Underwriters led by Goldman, Sachs & Company are offering 3.5 million shares at a price of $50, with an initial dividend yield of 10 3/8 percent.

title: CENTRAL RESERVE LIFE reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
THE BOUDIN TRIAL
description: Kathy Boudin is not a sympathetic figure. Although she has never been charged with personally committing violent acts, she was associated with people who have been convicted for attacking a Brink's truck in Rockland County and killing a Brink's guard and two police officers in the process. Her own trial on charges related to those crimes is in the jury-selection phase; the prosecution is seeking a 75-year sentence.

title: Joint Maneuvers in Poland
description: Soviet, Polish and East German troops carried out military maneuvers in the west and northwest of the country today, the Polish press agency said. The agency did not say when the maneuvers began, when they would end or how many troops were involved.

title: RIGHTS REPORTS STILL CALL KILLING BY ITS NAME
description: To the Editor:

title: AMERICAN MANAGEMENT SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss

title: DEL LABORATORIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
PAROCHIAL AID QUESTION TO BE DECIDED
description: The Supreme Court, continuing its active re- examination of the permissible boundaries between church and state, agreed today to rule on the constitutionality of a Michigan program of public aid to parochial schools.

title: PUNTA GORDA ISLES INC reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
ABOUT EDUCATION ; CRITICAL COMMISSION IS CRITICIZED
description: -like powers: they issue stern commandments but are not responsible for seeing them obeyed. If subsequently things get better, the commissions reap the credit; if nothing happens or things get worse, the fault lies elsewhere. With all eyes on what is wrong with the schools, who has time to look for what is wrong with their critics? The answer: Paul E. Peterson and the Brookings Institution.

title: SATELLITE SYNDICATED SYSTEMS reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Alaska Man Confesses Killings of 17 Women
description: An Anchorage businessman has admitted killing 17 prostitutes and topless dancers over a 10-year period according to a confession filed in court today as he was sentenced to spend the rest of his life in prison on a series of guilty pleas.

title: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES;
description: Texas Instruments is selling $150 million of 11 7/8 percent Eurobonds due in 1991 at a price of 99 3/4 to yield 11.93 percent, through underwriters led by Morgan Stanley International.

title: B.P. Cancels Oil Rig Order
description: The British Petroleum Company said today that it was canceling its order for an $88 million oil rig from the Scott Lithgow shipyard, dealing the troubled Scottish shipbuilding industry its second major blow in three months.

title: People
description: * Stephen Bayer has joined Chiat/ Day New York as a senior vice president.

title: U.S. INDUSTRIES RECEIVES OFFER TO TAKE IT PRIVATE
description: U.S. Industries announced yesterday that it had received a proposal from Kelso & Company, New York investment bankers, that would take the company private and leave institutional lenders and Kelso with a minority interest.

title: Kissinger's Views 'Harmful,' Bonn Says
description: Proposals by former Secretary of State Henry A. Kissinger for a radical overhaul of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization are ''more harmful than useful to the alliance,'' Alois Mertes of the West German Foreign Minstry said today.

title: West Europeans to See El Salvador's Election
description: Britain, the Netherlands and Belgium said today that they would accept an invitation from El Salvador to send observers to its presidential election next month to see whether it is fair and democratic.

title: Talking Business with Pierre Gousseland of AMAX ; Pickup Seen In Minerals
description: AMAX Inc., a major mineral and energy development company, has responded to recent losses with an extensive diversification program. Indeed, the company now describes itself as the world's most diversified minerals company.

title: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES ; City Offers $250 Million Of Bonds at 6% to 10.3%
description: New York City's largest bond sale since its return to the public bond market in 1981 is under way through underwriters led by Goldman, Sachs & Company. The city is offering bonds yielding from 6 percent for maturity in 1985 to 8 1/4 percent in 1989, 9 1/2 percent in 1994, 10.2 percent in 2002-04 and 10.3 percent in 2013.

title: RANGERS OBTAIN STOUGHTON
description: The Rangers traded the defenseman Scot Kleinendorst to Hartford yesterday for Blaine Stoughton, the Whalers' leading career goal-scorer.

title: MUSIC: DEBUT OF SERGIU CELIBIDACHE
description: IT is not often that a 72-year-old

title: INTERAND CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
FORDHAM WINS, 80-69, ON 80.5% SHOOTING
description: Steve Samuels connected on all 11 shots from the floor to lead a superb shooting performance by Fordham as the Rams scored an 80-69 victory over Fairfield in the opening round of the Metro Atlantic Athletic Conference playoffs tonight at the New Haven Arena.

title: KNICKS TRIUMPH, END SLIDE AT 5
description: Ray Williams, who played a key role in the Knicks' loss to Atlanta Friday night, played a key role last night as the Knicks beat the Hawks to snap a five-game losing streak.

title: U.S. Judge Lifts Order On Detention of Minors
description: Nine hundred and seventy-four children held for up to four days in Immigration and Naturalization Service detention centers were again eligible for release or deportation today after a Federal district judge lifted a temporary restraining order barring the immigration service from deporting unaccompanied illegal alien minors.

title: Nixon Writes McGovern On Phrase From Debate
description: George McGovern said today that he received a congratulatory letter from his opponent in the 1972 Presidential election, Richard M. Nixon.

title: Statewide Bancorp
description: Statewide Bancorp of Toms River, N.J., said that its board would meet today to consider an unsolicited acquisition offer from Midlantic Banks Inc. The offer calls for Midlantic to pay either $26 a share in cash or $26 a share in value with a package of Midlantic securities.

title: MCDONNELL TO BUY TYMSHARE
description: After backing away from a preliminary agreement two months ago to purchase Tymshare Inc. for $378 million, the McDonnell Douglas Corporation said yesterday that it had reached a definitive agreement to buy the California-based data transmission company for $307.5 million.

title: AYDIN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
HOUSTON INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-Net loss The company attributed the increased earnings in the latest 3 months primarily to the after-tax writeoff of $168 million for the Allens Creek Nuclear Project in December 1982.

title: FACES AND MEMORIES FROM MCGOVERN'S PAST REAPPEAR IN NEW HAMPSHIRE
description: Their beards are sometimes flecked with gray now, and their arms often hold small children. But their hearts have not lost the memory of a special moment in their lives, George McGovern's campaign for President in 1972, a campaign that was launched with a surprising second-place showing in the New Hampshire primary.

title: KEYSTONE INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After income from discontinued operations of $1,273,000 for the quarter and $1,107,000 for the year. c-Net loss d-After losses from discontinued operations of $4,626,000 for the quarter and $4,841,000 for the year. The year-earlier share earnings were restated for the 5 percent stock distribution in May 1983.

title: PATRICK INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes an extraordinary credit of $46,000. c-Including a net gain of $1.3 million from the sale of assets.

title: Foote, Cone to Acquire Latin American Agency
description: Foote, Cone & Belding Communications has agreed to acquire Siboney Advertising, an agency with nine offices in Latin America as well as one in New York that does advertising for the United States Hispanic markets. Siboney, with 1983 billings of $54 million, could well be the largest independent agency south of the border.

title: MISSISSIPPI VALLEY AIRLINES reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Riposte to Koch

title: Thomas Marston, 79, A Former Yale Curator
description: Dr. Thomas Ewart Marston, a former curator at the Yale University library, died Saturday at his home in The Plains, Va. He was 79 years old.

title: Manila Ready to Exempt Politicians From Arrest
description: The Philippine Parliament approved legislation today to exempt political opponents of President Ferdinand E. Marcos from arrest and detention for any anti-Government statements they may make in the parliamentary election campaign this spring.

title: DIAMOND-BATHURST INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
COURT SPARES SLAYER WHOSE PARTNER DIED UNDER SAME LAW
description: A Federal appeals court today struck down the death sentence of an Alabama convict,saying the law under which he was sentenced, and under which his accomplice had already been executed, was unconstitutional.

title: Alcan Spending
description: Alcan Aluminium Ltd. plans to increase capital spending to $450 million this year in conjunction with an anticipated 7 percent increase in industry shipments. Last year, with world metals markets still recovering from a recession, Alcan spent $382 million on capital works, the lowest level in five years.

title: ARAFAT AND HUSSEIN CONFER ON A JOINT POLICY
description: King Hussein and Yasir Arafat held a second day of talks here today.

title: TUESDAY SPORTS Basketball
description: Holy Cross vs. Iona , 7 P.M., and Army vs. St. Peter's , 9 P.M., Metro Atlantic Athletic Conference tournament, quarterfinals, at New Haven Arena.

title: JUDGE TEMPORARILY BLOCKS HIGHER RENTS FOR 150 APARTMENTS IMPROVED BY LANDLORDS
description: A State Supreme Court justice yesterday temporarily enjoined the owners of 150 apartments in Brooklyn and the Bronx from collecting rent increases they have been allowed in exchange for building improvements. A group of tenants is suing to overturn the system used in 900,000 rent-stabilized apartments for compensating landlords for capital improvements.

title: Tennis Begins at 30
description: Billie Jean King and Rosie Casals, who have been instrumental in the success of women's professional tennis, will announce plans today for a new circuit. The new venture will be for players over 30 years of age, and several well-known players have already joined, according to Miss Casals.

title: TEXFI INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 27
description: b-Including extraordinary tax credits of $34,000 for the latest period and $26,000 for the year-ago period.

title: PENNSYLVANIA ENGINEERING & MANUFACTURING reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
JACKSON'S CANDOR IS PRAISED BUT REMARK IS CRITICIZED
description: Most of the Rev. Jesse Jackson's rivals for the Democratic Presidential nomination praised him today for acknowledging his private characterization of Jews as ''Hymies,'' though they cautiously criticized him for the remark itself.

title: IONICRON INC reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss

title: HEALTHAMERICA CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a tax credit of $1.6 million. c-Net loss

title: KNOLL INTERNATIONAL reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-After extraordinary tax credits of $162,000 for the quarter and $475,000 for the year.

title: CORPORATE POPULIST
description: ROSABETH MOSS KANTER is a star this year on the corporate conference circuit, earning up to $12,000 a lecture and $15,000 for a workshop consultation in which she tells top managements how to run their companies.

title: THE RICH GET RICHER
description: HICKSVILLE, L.I.

title: ANIMATED MOVIES CREATED AT HOME
description: THE promise of personal computers was that they would open up a whole new world. But what exactly has computing done for the average persons lately? Not much, when you get right down to it.

title: Pratt & Whitney
description: Pratt & Whitney Aircraft said it was laying off 370 non-production workers and recalling 200 production workers. The layoffs will primarily involve hourly and salaried employees at the East Hartford plant. The company, a division of the United Technologies Corporation, said the layoffs were not the result of the recent Air Force decision to award most of a jet engine contract to the General Electric Company.

title: COMMUNICATIONS SATELLITE CORP (COMSAT) (N) reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
CONCERT: MISS MARGALIT
description: IT was clear even from her opening performances of two of

title: A CLASSICAL SCHOLAR AND POET
description: Richmond Lattimore, a classical scholar and a poet whose translations of ''The Iliad'' and ''The Odyssey'' became standard texts in many schools, died of cancer on Sunday in Rosemont, Pa., where he lived for many years. He was 77 years old.

title: Louis Wright, Scholar, Dies; Headed Shakespeare Library
description: Dr. Louis B. Wright, director of the Folger Shakespeare Library from 1948 to 1968, died of cardiovascular disease Sunday in his home in Chevy Chase, Md. He was 84 years old

title: APARTHEID VS. PRINCIPLE
description: To the Editor:

title: No Headline
description: Tennesseans Reported Armed for 2 Convicts

title: LATE RALLY SENDS DOW UP BY 14.86
description: A late rally, spearheaded by heavy institutional buying, sent stock prices up sharply yesterday for the second consecutive session. The biggest gainers were announced or rumored merger candidates.

title: STAGE: A TALE BY AND WITH KAYE BALLARD
description: ''HEY, MA . . . KAYE BALLARD,'' the one-woman show that opened last night at the Promenade Theater, is a nostalgic, oddly reticent autobiography, a resume of the comedienne-singer's career that tapers off after the failure of the 1973 Broadway musical ''Molly.''

title: Giants Get Al Oliver
description: The San Francisco Giants traded for a former National League batting champion today, but the player was Al Oliver of Montreal and not Bill Buckner.

title: CITIBANK'S MANILA BRANCH DECISION
description: A decision by Citibank not to repay from other branches more than $550 million worth of deposits frozen in its Manila branch has angered some members of the international banking community. It has also further complicated the path to resolving the Philippines' foreign debt problem.

title: INFORMATION AGENCY TURNS DOWN OFFICIALS'S REQUEST FOR TRANSCRIPTS
description: Officials of the United States Information Agency said today that they had refused a formal request from the Archivist of the United States to review transcripts of telephone conversations secretly recorded by the agency's director, Charles Z. Wick.

title: No Headline
description: Tanker Sinks in Gulf After a Crippling Blast

title: SPACECRAFT TO FOLLOW COMET PATH
description: A team of 20 American and European astronomers has chosen a bright, short-period comet named Kopff as target for a mission in which a spacecraft will intercept the comet, fly around it at a range of six miles and then sail along with it at a greater distance as it approaches the sun.

title: ICE DANCE ON MET STAGE
description: THERE will be dancing at the Metropolitan Opera House in late July. But for the first time in Lincoln Center's history, the dance will be on ice, as the John Curry Skating Company glides into the Met for seven performances, starting July 24.

title: Plastic Credit for Uncle
description: ''Credit cards have become part of Americana,'' says New York's Senator D'Amato to justify a further Federal ban on surcharges for their use. Omnipresent they are: 600 million of them in American wallets.

title: COURT REJECTS HEUBLEIN SUIT
description: Heublein Inc.'s bid to recover $30 million from the General Cinema Corporation was turned down today by the Supreme Court. The Court, without comment in Heublein v. General Cinema, No. 83-1111, refused to revive Heublein's suit.

title: CANADIAN OCCIDENTAL PETROLEUM LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Sumitomo's Swiss Plan
description: Sumitomo Bank Ltd. said today that it was contemplating the purchase of a controlling interest in the Gotthard Bank of Switzerland. Analysts said the acquisition would give Sumitomo access to the Swiss franc bond market.

title: U.S. Seeks Information On Canceled Primary
description: The Justice Department has asked Louisiana to give it more information before it can pass on a state plan to eliminate the state's Presidential preference primary.

title: Singapore Sees Economic Gain
description: Construction of a mass transit system and large public housing projects will help Singapore's economy continue to expand this year, the economic survey of the Ministry of Trade and Industry said today.

title: FIGHTING FLARING IN LEBANON AGAIN
description: With political negotiations apparently snagged, fighting intensified today in Beirut and in the nearby mountains between anti-Government militiamen and Lebanese Army troops.

title: CREDIT MARKETS Interest Rates Move Higher
description: Interest rates resumed their upward march yesterday, as securities dealers cut prices and raised yields to levels they hoped would attract investors to recent and prospective offerings by the Treasury.

title: ARCO PLANS FORMAL BID FOR GULF
description: The Atlantic Richfield Company is preparing a takeover bid for the Gulf Oil Corporation, banking officials disclosed yesterday. Gulf rejected an informal offer of $11.6 billion from Arco a few weeks ago. Now there are indications that Arco's formal offer may involve as much as $13 billion.

title: Texas Utility Debt
description: Ratings Lowered

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''Do the residents of Park Avenue want to look out the window at vegetables? They most certainly do not.'' - Shirley Bernstein of Park Avenue. (A1:5.)

title: SCOUTING
description: Practice, Practice

title: NEW WORDPLAY FOR 'CARMEN'
description: ''I NEED a one-syllable word for outlaw,'' Sheldon Harnick, the lyricist, asked the two dozen actors seated around him.

title: CUSHMAN ELECTRONICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss.

title: DRESSING UP FOR SPRING AND SUMMER EVENINGS
description: The party season doesn't stop with the spring equinox. For many people, it accelerates. In addition to black-tie events, for charity or just for fun, informal get-togethers proliferate. The hostess's ''Don't dress'' means that men can wear blazers or even tie a sweater around their neck if they choose.

title: SHIFTS AT CONTINENTAL ILLINOIS
description: David G. Taylor, vice chairman and chief financial officer of the Continental Illinois Corporation, today was named chairman and chief executive of the troubled bank holding company, succeeding Roger E. Anderson, 62, who retired under pressure from a group of independent directors.

title: ENERGY FACTORS reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-The company said there are no comparable year-ago figures because results reflect operations only since Oct. 5 when Energy Factors acquired Applied Energy Inc., a unit of San Diego Gas & Electric.

title: PETROLITE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
Kellogg Profit Declines by 3%
description: The Kellogg Company said today that its fourth-quarter earnings fell 3 percent from a year earlier but that profit for all of 1983 was up 6.5 percent.

title: Kaypro and Mitsui
description: The Kaypro Corporation said it had entered into a preliminary agreement with Mitsui & Company to market a new Mitsui computer on the Kaypro label. The manufacturer of portable computers said the Japanese model was a ''high end'' addition to the Kaypro line and said it would be priced close to the International Business Machines Corporation's Personal Computer. The company said that in three or four months it would also begin shipping a transportable, I.B.M.-compatible computer.

title: SCOUTING
description: Razors and Barbs In Yankee Camp

title: DYNAMICS CORP OF AMERICA reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
IRRADIATION IN LIEU OF EDB: CAUSE FOR CAUTION
description: To the Editor:

title: POP: MODUGNO SINGS
description: -year-old Italian pop singer and composer who became world famous in 1958 for his recording of ''Volare (Nel Blu di Pinto di Blu),'' opened the International Music Stars series of concerts at the Nederlander Theater on Friday.

title: WHEN A JUDGE ORDERS 'CHEMICAL CASTRATION'
description: To the Editor:

title: PREMATURE CHILDREN SHOW RISE IN A BAFFLING EYE DISORDER
description: DOCTORS in the United States and abroad are increasingly concerned about the incidence of a disorder in premature newborns that often leads to blindness.

title: U.S. SAID TO HALT HUNT FOR FORULA TO SAVE LEBANON
description: Reagan Administration officials said today that the United States was no longer actively involved in trying to produce a formula for a political settlement in Lebanon.

title: GROMYKO AFFIRMS MIDEAST PEACE BID
description: Foreign Minister Andrei A. Gromyko today affirmed a Soviet offer to help forge a Middle East peace settlement through an international conference.

title: No Transfers For J. David
description: Foreign banks holding accounts for J. David & Company, the investment and currency trading concern, have yet to transfer any money back to the United States, although most have acknowledged receiving orders to do so, a lawyer for a Federal Bankruptcy Court said today. J. David is facing an investors' petition that the firm be put into bankruptcy because it has not repaid some of the investors.

title: BARYSHNIKOV TO REMAIN AS BALLET THEATER HEAD
description: Mikhail Baryshnikov will remain as artistic director of the American Ballet Theater.

title: EAST GERMAN DEFECTIONS WORRYING BONN
description: West German officials expressed concern today that attempts by East Germans to flee to the West could jeopardize moves toward better relations between the two Germanys and harm the chances of others to leave legally.

title: Sound Investment for the Homeless
description: Charity that begins at home . . . neighbors helping neighbors . . . communities solving their problems in their own way. It sounds like grist for one of President Reagan's inspirational radio addresses.

title: OSHA, UNDER COURT THREAT, FILES PROPOSED FARM SANITATION RULES
description: Under a threat of contempt by a Federal judge, the Occupational Safety and Health Administration has taken its second tentative step since it was sued in 1972 to protect the health of farm workers, the largely migrant ''stoop laborers'' who pick the country's fruits and vegetables.

title: CREDITORS SEEK TO OUST THE HEAD OF GHR
description: The turbulent command of John R. Stanley, who twice piloted his Gulf Coast energy company into bankruptcy, may be coming to an end at the hands of his creditors.

title: RIO GRANDE IN TALKS WITH SUITORS
description: Rio Grande Industries, a railroad holding company with minor interests in trucking, real estate and computer time sharing, said yesterday that it was holding preliminary talks with other companies on being acquired.

title: RUSSELL, BURDSALL & WARD CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Including income of $819,000 for the quarter and year from discontinued operations and tax credits of $288,000 for the quarter and $427,000 for the year. c-Comparable year-ago results are not available because the company changed its fiscal year-end.

title: KELLOGG CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The latest quarter net includes a gain of 18 cents a share from divestment transactions, whereas the year- earlier period included net exchange losses.

title: ALLEGHENY BEVERAGE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Share earnings reflect a 3-for-2 stock split on Jan. 15.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Memories of La Guardia

title: Chess: Tournament in Reykjavik
description: Johann Hjartarson and Helgi Olafsson of Iceland and Samuel Reshevsky of Spring Valley, N.Y., tied for first place in the 11th Reykjavik International Tournament. Each was awarded $3,666.67 for his score of 8-3 in the 60-player Swiss system competition.

title: OUTCOME OF BASQUE VOTE: GOING FROM BAD TO WORSE?
description: A new element of instability has crept into the Basque government as a result of the elections Sunday for a regional parliament. How this will affect the long and tortuous process of coming to terms with separatist terrorists in that northern region of Spain is difficult to determine, officials say. The party that has governed for the last four years, the moderate but still intensely regionalist Basque Nationalist Party, or P.N.V., made a strong showing but nonetheless lost an effective working majority.

title: Edwin Moses Wins Sullivan
description: Edwin Moses, the world record holder in the 400-meter hurdles, was named tonight as the winner of the James E. Sullivan Memorial Award for 1983 as the nation's top amateur athlete. The 28-year-old Moses, of Laguna Hills, Calif., was selected from a field of 10 finalists for the award.

title: DATUM INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Including an extraordinary gain of $144,000 for the quarter and year. c-Net loss

title: Offer for Belknap
description: The Concord Corporation, which is owned by David A. Jones, chairman of Humana Inc., said it had acquired Televest Inc.'s 25 percent interest in Belknap Inc. and will start a tender offer this week at $24 a share for all Belknap shares it does not own.

title: MEXICO DENOUNCES A U.S. GENERAL WHO CALLED IT A SECURITY PROBLEM
description: Mexican officials denounced as silly and dangerous today an American general's remark that Mexico could be ''the No. 1 security problem'' for the United States.

title: First Peoples
description: First Peoples Bank of New Jersey said its auditors, Ernst & Whinney, now believe that they will be unable to certify the bank's 1983 financial statements because of recent developments in pending shareholder litigation against the bank. A bank spokesman would not comment on the developments in the suits, involving charges of mismanagement, but the company said the auditors believe the developments may impair the bank's independence. If Ernst & Whinney does not certify the financial statements, a default could be touched off under the bank's contemplated merger with Midlantic Banks Inc., according to First Peoples.

title: OPERA: LEONIE RYSANEK'S 25TH ANNIVERSARY GALA
description: LEONIE RYSANEK is no ordinary soprano, and the gala concert Sunday night at the Metropolitan Opera House celebrating the 25th anniversary of her company debut was no ordinary event. It consisted of concert performances of two complete acts from Wagner operas, the second of ''Parsifal'' and the first of ''Die Walk"ure.'' By the end, the combination of her emotion and that of the audience erupted into a delirium of cheering, with Miss Rysanek cowering from the barrage of bouquets.

title: Escapee Gives Up
description: A convicted prostitute, believed to be suffering from AIDS, surrendered to a public defender here today, six days after she escaped from a drug treatment program.

title: FIVE EGYPTIAN TOMBS EXCAVATED NEAR NILE
description: FIVE tombs said to be those of leading figures under Ramses II, who ruled Egypt and much of the eastern Mediterranean 3,000 years ago, have been found in the Nekropolis at Sakkara, 15 miles south of Cairo and three miles west of the Nile River, according to the Egyptian newspaper Al Akhbar.

title: TERADYNE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Year-ago share earnings restated to reflect a 2-for-1 stock split in July 1983.

title: ST. JOHN'S DEFEATED IN OVERTIME, 82-81
description: Greg Monroe, a freshman guard, hit a 15-foot jumper with 2 seconds left in overtime to give Syracuse an 82-81 victory over St. John's last night at Alumni Hall in Queens.

title: U.S. TO RESOLVE CONTRACT BATTLE
description: THE General Accounting Office is expected to rule next month on an effort by the Bank Street College of Education to overturn the awarding to Harvard University of a $7.6 million Federal contract for a new center for the study of educational technology.

title: A NEGLECTED U.S. PRIORITY IN LATIN AMERICA
description: To the Editor:

title: GARN BARGAINING ON TRADE POLICY
description: Senator Jake Garn, chairman of the Senate Banking Committee, has sought to block the possible nomination of Wendell W. Gunn, a White House trade officer, as Assistant Secretary of Commerce for Trade Administration, trade officials in the Administration said today.

title: PEDAL POWER: HIGH SPEEDS ACHIEVED
description: Bicycles have have remained largely unchanged in the 100 years since the ''safety'' bicycle, with its two equal-size wheels and chain drive, replaced the unstable, dangerous high-wheeler of the Victorian era.

title: STEMMING THE FLOW OF HIGH TECHNOLOGY
description: A struggle between military officials who want to stem the flow of advanced technology and ideas to the Soviet bloc and scientists and industrialists who want to preserve as much open technical communication and trade as possible has been heating up in recent days.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Babcock & Wilcox , a New Orleans- based unit of McDermott International Inc., an energy services company, said it had received a $31 million order from the Tennessee Valley Authority to upgrade three boilers at a plant near Drakesboro, Ky.

title: A SKETCH ISSUED OF MAN SOUGHT IN RAIL SHOOTING
description: The police released an artist's sketch yesterday of a man wanted for questioning in the shooting of an Amtrak engineer in Pennsylvania Station last week.

title: TO INSURE NUTRITION
description: Americans have now read two reports on hunger. One was published by the President's Task Force on Food Assistance, which as a group was almost totally unqualified for the job. A far better analysis - widely overlooked - was presented by the Citizens Commission on Hunger in New England.

title: MAINE PUBLIC SERVICE CO reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
PEOPLES DRUG TO BE ACQUIRED
description: Peoples Drug Stores Inc., one of the nation's 10 largest drug retailers, is to be taken over by Imasco Ltd., a diversified Canadian company, in an agreement valued at nearly $320 million, it was announced yesterday.

title: GOODY PRODUCTS INC reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-Including an extraordinary gain of $1,131,000 from the sale of land.

title: Fibak May Return
description: A truce may be near between the sports authorities in Poland and the country's leading tennis player, Wojtek Fibak . Fibak, rated 29th in the world, has not played for Poland's Davis Cup team since the decree of martial law in December 1981, partly to protest the crackdown and partly because the Davis Cup competition interfered with other engagements.

title: BRAUN ENGINEERING CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss

title: HIGH COURT UPSETS CITY NUCLEAR BAN
description: The Supreme Court refused today to hear New York City's challenge to a Federal regulation that would require the city to open its highways to trucks carrying nuclear waste.

title: DUNKIN' DONUTS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 28
Top Hartmarx Officer To Retire at Year-End
description: Jerome S. Gore, chairman and chief executive of the Hartmarx Corporation, plans to retire Dec. 31 at the age of 65 and will be succeeded by Richard P. Hamilton, the company announced.

title: REPORTS TO POLICE QUESTIONED IN NEW BEDFORD RAPE TRIALS
description: The woman who says she was raped on a pool table in a New Bedford bar last March said today that she might have exaggerated the number of her assailants in her original account to the police because she was tired and distraught.

title: GRENADA RECEIVES AIRPORT PLEDGES
description: Grenada has received pledges of $24 million to complete construction of an airport that was begun here in 1980 with Cuban funds and labor, the leader of the island's interim Government said Sunday night.

title: Q&A
description: Q.

title: Devil's Bag Runs
description: Devil's Bag, the undefeated early favorite for the Kentucky Derby, worked a strong mile in 1:37 3/5 this morning at Hialeah Park in preparation for the $300,000 Flamingo Stakes Saturday. Two rivals, Dr. Carter and Time for a Change, are expected to give the colt the first test of his career.

title: SIMPLICITY PATTERN CO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
IVACO INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss There were no earnings applicable to common shares in the latest period after preferred share dividends.

title: METS' TERRELL WINS PLACE WIHTOUT FUSS
description: In a camp filled with young men advertised as pitching ''phenoms,'' Walt Terrell is an exception: he isn't one.

title: BARBECON INC reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-After a writedown of goodwill of $853,000. c-After a writedown of investment in a joint venture of $200,000.

title: Officers Subduing A Man Are Bitten
description: Seven police officers were injured - including one who was severely bitten on the forehead - while subduing a man shouting biblical passages yesterday in front of a grocery store in Howard Beach, Queens, according to the police.

title: Ill Congressman Giving Up Post
description: Representative Edwin B. Forsythe, Republican of Moorestown, is seriously ill with cancer and will not seek re-election this year to his eighth term in Congress, Governor Kean said today.

title: OLYMPIANS JOIN ISLANDERS
description: Over in one corner, between Stefan Persson and Clark Gillies, Pat Flatley sat with a smile on his face and chatted with his new teammates.

title: 'Lace' Leads Ratings; 'Star Wars' in 2d Place
description: The first installment of ''Lace,'' ABC's two-part film about a pornographic film star's search for her mother, won handily in the audience ratings on Sunday night, beating the first network telecast of ''Star Wars'' on CBS and a repeat broadcast of ''Urban Cowboy'' on NBC.

title: EVALUATION RESEARCH CORP reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
Oiler Streak at 8
description: A goal by Dave Hunter 2 minutes 10 seconds into overtime lifted the Edmonton Oilers to a 6-5 victory over the Winnipeg Jets tonight.

title: ANGOLA-SOUTH AFRICA CRISIS RESOLVED
description: Western diplomats here said tonight that South Africa's month-old peace agreement with Angola, mediated by the United States, appeared to have withstood its first crisis.

title: Comings and Goings
description: Kenny Smith, a North Carolina point guard out of action for four weeks with a fractured left wrist, has been cleared by a team doctor to return to action and could play Wednesday against Georgia Tech. Smith, a 6-foot-2-inch, 160-pound freshman from Queens who had been a starter, was injured in a game Jan. 29. . . .
