John Ogrodnick, the leading scorer on the Detroit Red Wings with 78 points, fractured his left wrist in Sunday's 4-2 victory over Chicago.

title: LAW SCHOOL TEACHER WROTE ON PROCEDURE
description: Richard Arens, a professor of law at the University of Bridgeport and an authority on criminal procedure, died of a heart ailment Sunday at St. Vincent's Medical Center in Bridgeport, Conn. He was 62 years old and lived in Bridgeport.

title: Debt Issues
description: * Consumers Power Company's $85 million of 15 percent bonds due in 1994, rated Ba-1 by Moody's and BB by Standard & Poor's, were offered at 99.365 to yield 15 1/8 percent, through underwriters led by Morgan Stanley.

title: WOMAN'S TOUCH HELPS HISTORY SHAPE ANNAPOLIS
description: In the early hours of every morning Annapolis seems to recapture the 18th century. The graceful spire of the Statehouse looks down on a quiet city dotted with old mansions, on streets lined with houses that toll off the centuries and on a harbor bristling with tall masts.

title: Bridge: Eight Teams Survive as Play Starts in the Grand National
description: Knockout play in the Grand National Team Championship began Sunday at Adelphi University in Garden City, L.I., and a field of 32 teams from New York City and Long Island was cut to eight.

title: THE RANGERS' PRO SPECTATOR
description: Mark Morrison officially gave up his temporary status as professional spectator on Sunday night. There were times in the 1960's, not long after Morrison was born, when a cynic could claim that a job with the New York Rangers did not guarantee that a hockey player should be considered a professional. But Morrison's nine games as a Ranger during the 1981-82 season led the International Olympic Committee to rule Morrison ineligible to play in Sarajevo, Yugoslavia, and turn him into a tourist.

title: 'TRANSFORM THE WORLD: PEACE AND JOBS'
description: Candidates seeking the Presidential nomination make dozens of speeches in their campaigns. The content often varies, depending on where a speech is given and who is in the audience, but a body of material appears, with only slight variation, in nearly every such speech.

title: Mondale Gets Backing Of Boston's New Mayor
description: The Democratic candidate, Walter F. Mondale, won the endorsement of Boston's new Mayor today as the two toured the city's Long Island Shelter for the Homeless. Mayor Raymond Flynn called Mr. Mondale a ''fighter for social justice.'' The Mayor said the shelter was ''a symbol of our common philosophy of government.''

title: PENINSULA FEDERAL & SAVINGS LOAN reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-Net income including a gain of approximately $10 million from the sale of an office building.

title: WOODHULL: PROGRESS, BUT PROBLEMS PERSIST
description: When Brooklyn's Woodhull Hospital opened its doors 15 months ago, after 6 years of delays and huge budget overruns, it seemed that the worst of its troubles might be over.

title: HEALTH-MOR INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
DESPITE HIGH COST, SOME UTILITIES FEEL COMPELLED TO FINISH REACTORS
description: Even as a growing number of electric utilities are abandoning unfinished nuclear plants, others are pressing on, driven by a combination of regulatory and financial incentives.

title: G.M. Set to Recall 7,200 Employees
description: The General Motors Corporation said today that it would recall another 7,200 workers by June, bringing to 90,000 the total number called back by the company since January 1983, the peak month of unemployment in the automobile industry.

title: New Managing Editor Named For Foreign Affairs Quarterly
description: Peter Grose, a senior fellow in Middle Eastern studies at the Council of Foreign Relations, has been named managing editor of its quarterly Foreign Affairs, effective April 1, the council announced yesterday.

title: TV FILMS WILL USE MORE SOCIAL ISSUES
description: More made-for-television movies with social and political concerns are being planned by the three networks. The reason is the ratings successes scored by such films as ''The Day After,'' which dealt with nuclear war, and ''Something About Amelia,'' which was about incest.

title: TV PROJECTION OF IOWA VOTE ASSAILED
description: The three major television networks came under bipartisan criticism today for their projection of the outcome of the Democratic caucus in Iowa before most of the voters in the state had cast their ballots.

title: SOUTHLAND CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
GRUMMAN STOCK SUITS DISMISSED
description: A Federal judge in Uniondale, L.I., yesterday dismissed two suits seeking damages from the trustees of the Grumman Corporation's pension plan for buying Grumman stock at a high price to fend off a 1981 takeover attempt by the LTV Corporation.

title: WINFIELD CRITICAL OF STEINBRENNER
description: Dave Winfield's reluctance to discuss his feelings about George Steinbrenner, who will pay him $1,645,704 this year, lasted only the first 15 minutes of his spring training.

title: New Talks on Colts
description: Mayor William Donald Schaefer of Baltimore talked to Robert J. Irsay, the owner of the Colts, about keeping the National Football League franchise in that city and, asked afterward if he was optimistic or pessimistic, said, ''I'm nothing.'' He said he had a ''a very fine conversation'' by telephone with Mr. Irsay from his Chicago office, and that the owner was considering an offer from Indianapolis and is continuing negotiations with Phoenix and New York.

title: POWELL INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
REGAL INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income.

title: UNCERTAINTY HERALDING FIRST PRIMARY
description: New Hampshire will hold the first Presidential primary election of 1984 Tuesday amid growing uncertainty as to whether former Vice President Walter F. Mondale will receive the commanding majority of Democratic votes that seemed likely a week ago.

title: Key Rates
description: Kenny Index, Kenny Information SystemsSalomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: ONE ENLISTS IN THE CAMPAIGN AGAINST WASTE...
description: It was billed as the world's most expensive Christmas tree, decorated entirely with overpriced military equipment and spare parts. There were, for example, a $9,606 Allen wrench that was worth 12 cents, a $1,118 plastic stool cap worth 17 cents, a $2,043 nut worth 13 cents, a $7,417 antenna motor pin worth 2.4 cents and a $1,075 bolt worth 67 cents. The tree's total market value was $110.25, but the Defense Department had been asked to pay a total of $101,119 for the trimmings.

title: 'REFUGE,' FUTILE SEARCH FOR MIDLIFE SOLUTIONS
description: WITH the kind of tight budget that is endemic to public-television projects, the ''American Playhouse'' series goes into contortions occasionally in order to fill its schedule. A couple of weeks ago, for instance, it went back a decade or more to revive a theatrical-release film called ''Nothing But a Man.'' Now, tonight at 9 on Channel 13, it has found, no doubt for a bargain price, a 1980 independently produced film entitled ''Refuge.'' This 90-minute production strives mightily to be meaningful. Unfortunately, it is rarely more than relentlessly glum, almost smugly so.

title: ...WHILE ANOTHER ENDS DUTY TOUR
description: In his three years as Administrator of the General Services Administration, Gerald P. Carmen has tilted at the windmills of Big Government, seeking to banish what he considered waste and mismanagement in Federal departments and agencies.

title: TUESDAY, FEBRUARY 28, 1984 International
description: An American withdrawal from talks on Lebanon was affirmed by the Reagan Administration. Officials said that Washington was no longer actively involved in trying to produce a political settlement in Lebanon and was willing to leave it up to the Lebanese and other Arabs to try to work out a solution. (Page A1, Column 6.) Fighting intensified in Beirut and in the nearby mountains. On the first full day after the pullback of United States Marines from the airport to ships offshore, there were clashes between anti-Government militias and Lebanese Army troops. (A10:1.)

title: GOING OUT GUIDE;
description: CLASSICS Classicists who may wince at the modernity of the new skyscraping I.B.M. building at 590 Madison Avenue, at 57th Street, will find immediate solace one flight down, in the I.B.M. Gallery of Science and Art (407-6100), where tribute is being paid to the glory that was Greece.

title: GOTAAS-LARSEN SHIPPING CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss

title: CORRECTIONS
description: A chart in Business Day yesterday with an article about the American Financial Corporation included erroneous information supplied by the company on its relationship with Reliance Group Holdings. American Financial holds 26.3 percent of a Reliance preferred stock issue, not the outstanding shares. Reliance is privately owned.

title: AIDE PICKED FOR SERVICES AGENCY
description: President Reagan, ending weeks of speculation, today named Jack Courtemanche, a White House aide, to be the next head of the General Services Administration.

title: CLOSING POINTS ARE PRESENTED IN OLMEDO TRIAL
description: A Federal prosecutor urged a jury yesterday to convict City Councilman Luis A. Olmedo of Brooklyn on corruption charges, saying that ''you've seen over these past five weeks the anatomy of a deal - a payoff'' and that Mr. Olmedo had conspired in extorting it.

title: Brooke Shields in Revue
description: Brooke Shields, a Princeton freshman, will get a chance to display her singing and acting talents to classmates in a student-written musical variety revue, ''Revel Without a Pause.'' The 18-year-old Miss Shields was one of about 150 students who answered a casting call.

title: SEXUAL FANTASIES: WHAT ARE THEIR HIDDEN MEANINGS?
description: RESEARCHERS know that sexual fantasies tell much about one's sexuality, but just how much they tell has been debated for decades.

title: 30 Die in Nigeria As Islam Militants Brawl
description: More than 30 people were killed today in the northeastern Nigerian city of Yola in a clash between riot policemen and people believed to be followers of a militant, fundamentalist Moslem leader killed three years ago, the Nigerian press agency reported.

title: STEEGO CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-Net income. Share earnings reflect a 5 percent stock dividend paid in January 1984.

title: Retail Prices Up in France
description: French retail prices rose seven-tenths of 1 percent in January after an increase of three-tenths of 1 percent in December, the National Statistics Institute said today.

title: DANCE: 2 ACTS BY MISS MOSS
description: OUTSIDE the Ethnic Folk Arts Center on Sunday afternoon it was cold and wintry. Inside, it seemed like a summer day, thanks to Judith Moss and Dancers, who presented ''Tangle, Dive, Catch, Slide,'' a new two-act work by Miss Moss.

title: UPSTATE REPRESENTATIVE ANGERS SOME STUDENTS BY LINKING THE DRAFT TO AID
description: Representative Gerald B. H. Solomon, a Republican from Glens Falls, N.Y., who used to delight in chiding Gov. Nelson A. Rockefeller as being too liberal, has become the bane of some college students and officials.

title: INTERFACE FLOORING SYSTEMS reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 1
AFTER 5 YEARS, U.N. LEBANON FORCE HAS AIR OF PERMANENCE
description: The United Nations force that came to Lebanon's southern hills in 1978 was called an interim unit.

title: RELIABILITY INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss.

title: RICHARD PATON, EYE SURGEON
description: Dr. Richard Townley Paton, an ophthalmologist who founded the Eye- Bank for Sight Restoration in 1944 in Manhattan, died yesterday in Southampton, L.I. He was 82 years old and lived in Southampton.

title: BUSINESS PEOPLE ;
description: Management Team To Change at PPG

title: Panthers Defeat Blitz on a Kick
description: Novo Bojovic's 20-yard field goal as time ran out lifted the Michigan Panthers to a 20-18 United States Football League season-opening victory over the Chicago Blitz tonight.

title: VW Brazil's 1983 Loss
description: Volkswagen do Brasil S.A. said today that it posted a net loss in 1983 of about $5.7 million. The company had a profit of about $1.8 million in 1982. Volkswagen said a sharp drop in sales in the second half had helped to cause the loss.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: TUESDAY, FEBRUARY 28, 1984

title: ATOP PORTUGUESE POLITICAL HEAP, TWO IS A CROWD
description: The rivalry between the Prime Minister of Portugal, Mario Soares, and the President of Portugal, Antonio Ramalho Eanes, is taking on a crabbed, vinegary edge now that there is a whiff of another political season in the air.

title: MISS NAVRATILOVA FACING NEW HURDLE
description: The Virginia Slims Championships, which begin tonight at Madison Square Garden, will have a three-of- five-set final, the first time that has occurred in a women's tennis tournament since 1902. And the new format could provide a rigorous test for Martina Navratilova, the tour's finest athlete.

title: BROWN GROUP INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 28
4 SENATORS DENY ARMY BUILT ILLEGALLY IN HONDURAS
description: Four Republican Senators returned today from a weekend tour of Honduras and disputed charges that the Reagan Administration had built semipermanent military installations there without Congressional approval.

title: U.N. PUTS OFF VOTE ON LEBANON TROOPS
description: The Security Council met in closed- door session today to consider a French proposal to authorize sending United Nations troops to Beirut amid indications that Soviet-Western differences might threaten the plan.

title: FOSTER WHEELER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Results for the latest periods reflect a pretax provision of $5.5 million for the quarter and year for estimated expenses related to the closing of the company's Mountaintop, Pa., plant and a gain of $4,950,000 for the year on sales-type lease transactions. Year-ago results have been reclassified to conform to the 1983 presentation.

title: So Talk About Arms Talks
description: For their own separate reasons, President Reagan and Konstantin Chernenko are said to be exploring the chances of a meeting in the next few months. But the President has ruled out a mere ''get-acquainted'' session and it's unlikely that the frozen substance in arms control talks can be thawed in time for a summer summit meeting. One way out is to spend a few profitable days soon talking about talks, to plan a revival of this vital diplomacy.

title: The U.N. Today Feb. 28, 1984
description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY

title: U.S.F.L. Needs an Identity of Its Own
description: The nicknames certainly are

title: SCOUTING
description: Walton Switched

Lessons of the Jackson Flap
description: The ultimate enemy in American politics is ridicule. It's hard enough to run for President when your opponents are politicians. You know you're in big trouble when the comedians start circling overhead.

title: ROHR INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
Couple Offered Help In Freeing Son in Cuba
description: An Allentown couple who believe their 20-year-old son is in a Cuban prison have pinned their hopes on the Rev. Jesse Jackson's promise to try to secure his release.

title: PROVIDENT BANCORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Texas Company Loses Chairman to Thrift Unit
description: The American Century Corporation of San Antonio said yesterday that its board had accepted the resignation of John H. Roberts Jr. as chairman and chief executive.

title: SYLVAN DAVIS
description: Sylvan Davis, the editor and publisher of The Rockland County Times since 1974, died of a heart attack Sunday in the Pascack Valley Hospital in Westwood, N.J. Mr. Davis was 57 years old and lived in Old Tappan, N.J.

title: Lilco Aide Resigns
description: The director of communications for the Long Island Lighting Company, Michael R. Patterson, resigned yesterday, effective May 1.

title: CREDIT SURCHARGES HELD UNLIKELY BY RETAILERS
description: Retailers said yesterday that they would not impose a surcharge on credit sales, in the wake of the lifting of the ban on such charges. To do so, most said, would hurt credit sales, which represent at least 50 percent of their total business - and probably would draw strong, adverse reaction from consumers.

title: NATIONAL PRESTO INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Advertising; New Push For Paint At Borden
description: T HE people at Borden Inc. found

title: NOTES ON FASHION
description: WHOEVER thought a little polo player could cause so much trouble? Not Ralph Lauren, apparently. Since 1974, when he received a trademark on that emblem, he has been using it on his Polo collection. Now he and the United States Polo Association are involved in a suit over the use of the horseman.

title: Pakistan Frees Six Who Led Opposition
description: Pakistan's military Government, in a surprise move, freed six opposition leaders from detention today.

title: ; LEONARDO AS PEDDLER OF HIS WEAPONS IDEAS
description: To the Editor:

title: Israeli Cautions Arabs About Meeting Arafat
description: West Bank Arabs who went to Amman to encourage King Hussein and Yasir Arafat to cooperate on a Middle East policy were warned by the Israelis today that they were forbidden to meet Mr. Arafat.

title: KATY INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $281,000 for the quarter and $608,000 for the year and the latest quarter also includes a gain of $912,000 on the sale of the product line. c-After losses from discontinued operations of $211,000 for the quarter and $812,000 for the year and extraordinary gains of $19,000 for the quarter and $862,000 for the year. None of the results include the operations of the Missouri-Kansas- Texas Railroad Co., an unconsolidated subsidiary. The 1983 results include a net gain of $912,000 on the sale of a product line in the fourth quarter of 1983. The final net earnings include gains on the sales of securities of $4,113,000 in 1983, including a loss of $5,000 in the latest quarter, and gains of $641,000 in 1982, all in the 1982 quarter. The losses from discontinued operations reflect equity in the operations of an unconsolidated insurance subsidiary sold in the first quarter of 1984. The extraordinary gains in 1982 are due principally to early extinguishment of debt in 1982.

title: STRANGE ANIMALS THRIVE ON POISON IN SHALLOW WATER
description: LOS ANGELES A COLLECTION of bizarre marine life forms of a type thought to exist only around geothermal vents in the deep ocean have now been found thriving in much shallower bodies of water located throughout the world.

title: 11 CHARGED WITH DAMAGING A TRAIN
description: Eleven Westchester County men, returning home from a New York City automobile show Saturday night, harassed other passengers and caused $4,500 in damage to a commuter train, the state police said today.

title: CENSUS REPORT SAYS AFTER-TAX INCOME FELL IN 1981
description: The Census Bureau said today that after-tax income of American households declined slightly in 1981 despite a reduction in Federal income tax rates.

title: MONDALE LEAD OVER NEAREST RIVAL IN POLL SETS NONINCUMBENT RECORD
description: With Senator John Glenn continuing to fade and no new challenger emerging strongly, Walter F. Mondale now holds the most commanding lead ever recorded this early in a Presidential nomination campaign by a nonincumbent, according to the latest New York Times/CBS News Poll.

title: VALMONT INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
SUNSHINE MINING CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss.

title: HAVERTY FURNITURE COS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The share earnings reflect 5-for-4 stock split paid in February 1984.

title: MUBARAK'S WORTHY DIPLOMACY
description: Israelis and Egyptians have been addressing each other more angrily in recent weeks than at any time since Anwar el- Sadat's visit to Jerusalem in 1977 - while the Administration, fearing another Middle Eastern setback, looks on apprehensively. The harsh words focus on the peace strategy of Egypt's President, Hosni Mubarak, which, though controversial, hardly threatens long-term American or even Israeli interests.

title: Arsonist, 17, Gets 5 Years' Probation
description: A teen-ager charged with setting four fires last summer in West Hartford's Jewish community was sentenced today to five years of probation and ordered to continue psychiatric treatment.

title: GAMING & TECHNOLOGY reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss.

title: BEFORE A CHILD TRAVELS ALONE
description: A dozen mothers arrived bright and early the other day at the Parents League for a seminar on preparing a young child to travel alone in the city. They took notes, asked questions and listened to some of the pitfalls related by Gretchen Lengyel, who conducted the meeting.

title: No Headline
description: Snowstorm Moves East After Hitting Midwest

title: BRIEFING
description: Capital Issue

title: GOVERNORS AND OTHERS IN DISTRESS
description: The importance of being governor is being tested by chief executives of Rocky Mountain states. Two of them recently announced they had had enough.

title: LUBRIZOL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The 1983 earnings include a gain on the sale of investments of $10,458,000.

title: Market Place; Analysts' View Of Masonite
description: T HE Masonite Corporation, the country's leading producer of hardboard, possesses all

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Star Visits Prisons

title: CITY COUNCIL UNIT VOTES TO APPROVE A FIRE-SAFETY BILL
description: Endorsing the broadest change in New York City building law in years, a City Council panel yesterday approved a bill requiring dozens of fire-safety measures in new and existing hotels, stores, offices, schools, hospitals, restaurants and nightclubs.

title: The dust has settled on the Air Force's Great Engine
description: War between Pratt & Whitney and General Electric, but now there is another battle for Pentagon gold looming among industrial giants. Call it the Great Tin Can War.

title: American Air Weighs Order
description: American Airlines is negotiating for the possible acquisition of as many as 67 McDonnell Douglas MD-80 airliners at more than $20 million each, industry sources said yesterday. Al Becker, a spokesman for the airline, said of reports that the deal actually had been concluded: ''We have no deal with anyone yet.

title: 'Split Second' Scheduled
description: ''Split Second'' by Dennis McIntyre will run through March 11 at Intar Stage Two, 508 West 53d Street. The play will be performed Wednesdays through Sundays at 8 P.M. For reservations: 387-l089.

title: DELHI TENSE OVER SIKH ISSUE
description: With more than 3,000 paramilitary troops on guard here, this tense capital was partly shut down today by a general strike called by a Hindu group to protest against violence by Sikh militants.

title: A.T.& T. Seeks Review
description: The American Telephone and Telegraph Company, warning of a ''devastating'' effect on its earnings, petitioned the Government today to reconsider two recent decisions involving charges that long-distance carriers are to pay to local telephone exchange companies.

title: NO BETTER WAY?
description: As the Iowa caucuses and the New Hampshire primary of 1984 pass mercifully into history, they've raised again the serious question whether there's no better way than this to pick a Presidential nominee - possibly the next President of a great nation.

title: IMS INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $2,899,000 for the quarter and $3,579,000 for the year. c-Net income d-After a loss of $3,362,000 from discontinued operations and a loss of $18,175,000 from disposal of discontinued operations.

title: 4 Sentenced As Drug Runners
description: A Federal judge sentenced the captain of an English freighter seized with $90 million in hashish to 10 years in prison today, saying he was ''pouring poison into the veins'' of America.

title: Spring Flood Outlook Is Likened to 1983
description: The outlook for flooding in regions of the United States where records were set in floods last year is more of the same this spring, the National Weather Service warned today.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: An item in the Briefing column on the Washington Talk page Feb. 9 incorrectly described the nature and sponsorship of an appeal for a Guam Presidential plebiscite on Feb. 28. The appeal was made in an ad placed by Operation Begin (Begin the Election in Guam Instead of New Hampshire) in The Pacific Daily News, published in Agana. No plebiscite is scheduled, but Guam is to hold a Presidential caucus April 28.

title: FLIGHTSAFETY INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Computer Strikes Out
description: After a yearlong experiment, the Oakland A's have concluded that their touted computer is more expensive than it is worth. As a result, its use will be sharply curtailed this year and it will no longer be taken with the team.

title: Colombian, 31, Gets Life In Amtrak Siege Case
description: Evangelista Navas Villabona, a 31- year-old Colombian, was sentenced today to life in prison for killing his sister and allowing his infant nephew to die in a three-day siege aboard an Amtrak train in October 1982.

title: PERRY DRUG STORES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
DISCOVERIES
description: 1.*From Pack to Tote

title: FUTURES/OPTIONS Gold and Silver Fall As Oil Flow Continues
description: As oil continued to be shipped through the Strait of Hormuz yesterday, many traders in precious metals futures decided to convert recent paper profits into cash. Fears that the Iran-Iraq conflict would cut the amount of oil moving through the narrow strait had contributed to the recent rise in gold and silver prices.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: Articles in Business Day on Monday and yesterday about surcharges on credit card purchases misstated the expiration date for the prohibition on such charges. It ended at 12:01 A.M. yesterday.

title: CITY EXPANDING USE OF COMPUTERS TO MONITOR PEDIATRIC CARE
description: The recent use of computers to help monitor and evaluate the pediatric care given children at two municipal hospital clinics has proven so effective it is being expanded, city officials said yesterday.

title: Dougherty Deal
description: The Dougherty Brothers Company said it had signed a letter of intent to be acquired by Owens-Illinois Inc. for the equivalent of $17 a share in stock.

title: OUR RISKY BASES IN HONDURAS
description: Despite the claims of four Republican Senators just back from Honduras that United States bases there are only temporary, the evidence clearly suggests that the bases are permanent - and a danger to our foreign policy interests.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE;
description: GHOST STORY In a city where diversity has always been the order of the day and where special theater companies abound - performing black, Jewish, Irish, Spanish and other works for the general public - the Pan Asian Repertory Company has over the last seven years taken its place as an professional institution reflecting work and culture of those whose roots are in the Far East.

title: THEATER: 'MENSCH MEIER,' SET IN WEST GERMANY
description: WHEN a play puts an audience to sleep, chances are that something is wrong with the play. But when a play makes theatergoers squirm in their seats, mutter in exasperation and storm out at intermission, the author may be doing at least something right.

title: WYLE LABORATORIES reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-Net loss. c-After a loss of $710,000 on the sale of discontinued operations.

title: BIG AMERICAN AIR ORDER EXPECTED FOR MCDONNELL
description: American Airlines is expected to announce today an order for 67 or more McDonnell Douglas MD-80 142- passenger airliners at a cost of more than $1.3 billion.

title: WEST BANK ARABS URGE ARAFAT-HUSSEIN UNITY
description: A delegation of prominent West Bank Arabs today urged Yasir Arafat, the Palestine Liberation Organization chief, to devise a joint approach with King Hussein of Jordan on negotiations with Israel over the fate of the West Bank.

title: PITTSBURGH GIVES A LUNCHEON TO TRY OUT A NEW CIVIC IMAGE
description: When I say the word 'Pittsburgh,' '' Mayor Richard Caliguiri said yesterday to a Manhattan luncheon assemblage, ''tell me what comes into your mind.'' After a moment of silence, he reconsidered: ''No, please, don't say it. I know what you must be thinking.''

title: Panel Backs Louisiana In Bid to Drop Primary
description: A commission of the Democratic National Committee, ignoring the Justice Department, today approved Louisiana's plan to drop its Democratic Party primary and switch to a caucus.

title: LETTER: ON SHELTERS
description: -ILL HOMELESS

title: What to Do After Lebanon: Nothing
description: As The Economist warns with cousinly affection, how Americans now think about the Middle East may be more important than anything they recently tried to do there. The British journal begs us not to confuse a punch on the nose with the end of the world - and to distinguish clearly between failing in Beirut and an unfailing commitment to truly vital interests like Israel and oil.

title: OLMEDO JURY STARTS DELIBERATIONS
description: A jury deliberated for six hours yesterday without reaching a verdict in the trial of City Councilman Luis A. Olmedo of Brooklyn and two co-defendants, Carlos Castellanos, chairman of Community Board 1 in Brooklyn, and Edmundo Roman, former chairman of Community Board 4 in the borough.

title: SCORING SECONDARY FOR L.I.U. CENTER
description: On the floor of the old Brooklyn Paramount, where Murray the K once held rock-and-roll shows, the sound is different now.

title: BOSTON DIGITAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: Share earnings are fully diluted.

title: Fire Kills Woman; Suspect Is Held
description: An 84-year-old woman was burned to death in a Harlem tenement fire Monday night, and a resident of the building was held yesterday on charges that he set the fire, the police said.

title: BAY STATE GAS CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss

title: ALL SAFE
description: A jetliner with 163 passengers aboard skidded off the end of a rain-slicked runway at Kennedy International Airport yesterday and came to a halt with its nose in a marshy channel off Jamaica Bay.

title: U.S. APPEALS COURT UPHOLDS RAIDERS
description: A Federal appeals court today upheld a lower court finding that the National Football League had violated antitrust laws by attempting to keep the Raiders from moving from Oakland to Los Angeles. The decision was another setback to the league in its efforts to control the movement of its franchises.

title: Virginia Approves Holiday for Dr. King
description: A state holiday commemorating the birth of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. has been approved by the Virginia Legislature, ending a struggle of nearly a decade.

title: PROPRIETOR SUBPOENAS CURBED
description: The Supreme Court ruled today that a business organized as a sole proprietorship may, under some circumstances, refuse on constitutional grounds to answer a Government subpoena for its business records.

title: Ready to Report
description: John Candelaria, the Pittsburgh Pirate pitcher who failed to report to training camp on Feb. 18, has apparently resolved his differences with management and will report Wednesday. There had been reports that Candelaria had asked to be traded, but neither he nor the Pirates would discuss the reasons for his absence.

title: STONE CONTAINER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income.

title: Get to Know
description: Edwin Meese Tomorrow, five weeks after President Reagan picked him as Attorney General, Edwin Meese goes before the Senate Judiciary Committee seeking confirmation. The White House took its time preparing. The Senate should take no less care in examining the nominee, for it is being asked, in the process, to ratify the Administration's approach to law enforcement, civil rights and civil liberties.

title: SENATE VOTES TO RESTRICT NUCLEAR EXPORTS
description: In a setback for the Administration, the Senate voted today to halt sales of nuclear components, materials or technology to countries that have not accepted inspection safeguards under the nuclear nonproliferation treaty.

title: Accounts
description: * Fisons Corp. of Bedford, Mass., to Estin-Sandler Communications, for its ethical line of products.

title: A PRICE 'GUARANTEE' IN NUCLEAR UNIT BID
description: The Washington Public Power Supply System received a proposal today from three large contractors who want to complete - for a firm or ''fixed'' price - a nuclear unit on which construction halted last summer. The contractors said they could ''absolutely guarantee'' to do the job for less than the $1.5 billion the system budgeted for completing the unit.

title: Military Contracts
description: The Ingalls Shipbuilding division of Litton Systems Inc., based in Pascagoula, Miss., received an $822.4 million Navy contract, the Defense Department said. The company is to design and build the first of a new class of amphibious assault ships. In addition, the Grumman Aerospace Corporation, a unit of the Grumman Corporation, received a $323.3 million contract for 24 F-14 aircraft.

title: ALUMAX INC reports earnings for Year to Dec 31

description: b-Net loss

description: b-After net losses from discontinued operations of $38,000 for the quarter and $277,000 for the year.

title: CIVIC-GROUP LEADERS QUESTION TIMES SQ. PLAN
description: Leaders of several New York City civic groups yesterday sharply questioned, and in some cases criticized, the proposed $1.6 billion plan to redevelop Times Square.

title: Video Corp. Offer
description: A group led by Reich & Tang Inc., a New York brokerage, told the Securities and Exchange Commission that it considers inadequate an offer by the First Capital Holdings Corporation to buy the Video Corporation of America.

title: MICRO D INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
Quotations of the Day
description: ''We're not prepared to claim a position of front-runner, but I know in New Hampshire tonight, we buried the label of dark horse.''

title: BUSINESS PEOPLE

title: SOME FRESH IDEAS ON COOKING DRIED BEANS
description: CUISINES of the world abound with celebrated dishes based on beans and peas. There is cassoulet of southwestern France, dal of India, black bean soup and feijoada of Brazil, Mexican refried beans and chickpea soup, Middle Eastern hummus (chickpea puree), Spanish cocido (boiled beef and chickpeas) Italian fagioli Toscana (bean and pasta soup) and, of course, New England baked beans.

title: HIGH COURT BACKS REAGAN'S POSITION ON A SEX BIAS LAW
description: The Supreme Court today accepted the Reagan Administration's narrow reading of the Federal law that prohibits sex discrimination by schools and colleges that receive ''Federal financial assistance.''

title: IONA AND ST. PETER'S ADVANCE
description: George Blaney, the coach of Holy Cross, is finally convinced that Steve Burtt is one of the outstanding guards in the country. Burtt scored a game-high 27 points to lead Iona to a 73-66 victory over Blaney's Crusaders in the quarterfinals of the Metro Atlantic Athletic Conference playoffs tonight at the New Haven arena.

title: American Express Sets Kissinger Directorship
description: The American Express Company said yesterday that Henry A. Kissinger had been nominated to be a director.

title: LTV-Republic
description: The LTV Corporation and the Republic Steel Corporation postponed a meeting scheduled for Wednesday with Justice Department antitrust lawyers to discuss the companies' planned merger, which the department opposes as anticompetitive. The companies said they were not ready with a plan to meet objections.

title: Judicial Waves
description: The Congressional battle over

No Headline
description: Bridge:The Best Book of the Year May Be Already Available

title: NORDSON CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 29
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $2,082,000 for the latest first quarter and $729,000 for the year- ago first quarter.

title: SHREWD BET FOR A FEW POUNDS
description: It may seem that there is another division in boxing every few ounces, but as weight watchers know, ounces add up.

title: JAPAN'S DEFENSE POLICY
description: The new Japanese budget put forward in January may not significantly speed up the steady pace with which Japan has been improving its defense forces. But there will be no slowing of our defense efforts, despite considerable austerity in all other aspects of the budget. What's more, this military effort is only one aspect of Japan's comprehensive security policy, which rests on a triad of improvements in military defense, active diplomacy and economic cooperation.

title: Binney & Smith
description: Binney & Smith Inc. said the Newell Companies had acquired 15,500 common shares of Binney and had a six- month option to buy another 188,000 shares.

title: LOUISIANA EXECUTES MAN AFTER GOVERNOR REJECTS A FINAL PLEA
description: Johnny Taylor Jr., convicted of stabbing a man to death in 1980, was executed in Louisiana's electric chair early today, becoming the second prisoner to be put to death in the state in less than three months.

title: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES;
description: The Federal Farm Credit Banks Funding Corporation yesterday announced interest rates for four bond issues totaling about $3.62 billion.

title: U.S.F.L. Said to Lose Suit on Early Signings
description: A Federal judge has ruled that the United States Football League's regulation barring the signing of underclassmen violates the Sherman Antitrust Act, a league attorney said tonight.

title: AN INCREASE IN COST IS SEEN FOR A PRISON IN SOUTH BRONX
description: A state prison that is to be built in the South Bronx could cost twice the original estimate of $100 million and take at least twice as long to build as initially anticipated, according to state correction officials.

title: VOLCKER ASKS BIG BUDGET CUT
description: The country should not expect the Federal Reserve Board to support the economy's continued growth by averting a rise in interest rates, Paul A. Volcker, chairman of the Fed, told the nation's governors today.

title: POWERTEC INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 29
Jobless Rate Climbs To 8.1% in New York
description: New York State's unemployment rate climbed by 1.1 percentage points in January to 8.1 percent, reversing an 8-month decline, the State Labor Department reported today.

title: Jacobs Group Buys More of Tidewater
description: A group of investors led by Irwin Jacobs of Minneapolis told the Securities and Exchange Commission that it had raised its holdings in Tidewater Inc. common stock. The group said it bought 99,600 shares between Feb. 17 and Feb. 22, increasing its total investment to 977,150 shares, or 5.7 percent of the shares outstanding.

title: SIKH TEMPLE: WORDS OF WORSHIP, TALK OF WARFARE
description: The two boys were young, perhaps 6 and 12 years old, wearing black stocking caps over the topknots of their uncut hair that will be covered by Sikh turbans when they are older.

title: Marshall Is Admitted To Hospital for Tests
description: Justice Thurgood Marshall of the Supreme Court was admitted Monday to the Bethesda Naval Hospital for ''tests in connection with a case of bronchitis,'' the Court's press office announced today.

title: POPE SEES BETTER DAYS FOR CHINA'S CATHOLICS
description: Pope John Paul II said today that a day would come when Chinese Catholics on the mainland would again be able to practice their faith openly.

title: THE TIDE TURNS FOR THE ONLY FISH PURVEYOR IN EASTERN IOWA
description: It wasn't too long ago that when Howard Schwichtenberg mentioned fish to Iowans, they reacted as if he were a sea monster.

title: SLAYER IN ALASKA WAS JAILED IN OTHER CASES, JUDGE NOTES
description: A man who in the last week has confessed killing 17 women has repeatedly come to the attention of the police and the courts in Alaska over the last 13 years in cases that involve violence against women.

title: O.A.U. Called Paralyzed By Financial Problems
description: The acting secretary general of the Organization of African Unity said here today that the O.A.U. was nearing ''paralysis'' because members had failed to pay more than $43 million in contributions.

title: DENELCOR INC reports earnings for Year to Dec 30
COMPANY BRIEFS
description: * American Medical International Inc., a Beverly Hills, Calif., operator of hospitals, said it was discussing with the Creighton-Omaha Regional Healthcare Corp. a possible affiliation with Creighton University's 539- bed St. Joseph Hospital.

title: INSTEAD OF FEB. 29, CREATE JUNE 31
description: As far as instant research can discover (looking up ''calendar'' in the ''Columbia Encyclopedia''), the origin of Feb. 29 as Leap Year Day is irrational.

No Headline
description: Emory T. Clark Dead; Founded Oil Concern

title: COPING WITH AN OIL CUTOFF
description: A cutoff of oil exports from the Persian Gulf region, which has repeatedly been threatened by Iran during its three-and-a-half-year war with neighboring Iraq, would remove more oil from the world market than either the Iranian revolution of 1978 or the oil embargo of 1973.

title: GOVERNORS REBUFF REAGAN ON CUTTING BUDGET
description: After a sharp partisan debate, a majority of the nation's governors put themselves at odds with President Reagan today with a resolution asking for higher taxes and lower military spending to curb Federal budget deficits.

title: FARAH MANUFACTURING CO reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-Including a tax credit of $457,000.

title: SLATER ELECTRIC INC reports earnings for Year to Nov 30
description: b-Including a gain of $450,000 from the settlement of litigation. c-Net loss including a tax credit of $633,000.

title: U.S.F.L. Vote On Union Due
description: The players of the United States Football League will vote the first week in April on the issue of joining a union, according to an official of the Federation of Professional Athletes, an A.F.L.-C.I.O. union. Roy Jefferson, the former wide receiver of the Washington Redskins and a staff member of the federation, held an organizational meeting with the New Jersey Generals today at their training camp and predicted that the vote would be in favor of a union.

title: Jersey Bank Bid
description: Statewide Bancorp said its board had rejected an unsolicited merger offer from Midlantic Banks Inc., which had offered $26 a share for Statewide's 2.6 million shares outstanding.

title: STUDY SAYS STATE SHARE OF MILITARY WORK DROPS
description: New York State continues to suffer from a declining share of the nation's military prime contracts, according to a report prepared for Governor Cuomo by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York.

title: Pan Am Names Head Of Latin American Area
description: A. L. Rauschenplat, who started his career with Pan American World Airways in the Caribbean in 1958, has been named to head the airline's Latin American operations.

title: REPUBLIC HEALTH CORPORATION reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31

title: ON A DECADE OF MOTHERHOOD
description: NEXT month, I celebrate the 10th anniversary of my motherhood. I'll probably honor this occasion by taking five or six 10-year-old children out for a pizza and then to a roller rink, since experience has taught me that it's easier to let someone else do the cooking, entertaining and cleaning up. This simple lesson took an extraordinary number of party hats and homemade teddy-bear birthday cakes to learn. And while the children are skating around in circles, waving to me periodically as they pass my table on the sidelines, I'll sip a cup of tea and sink into deep reflections about how motherhood is going so far.

title: Lloyd's Wary Over Conflict
description: Leading marine insurers operating at Lloyd's of London expressed serious concern today about Iraq's claims that it had attacked oil tankers at Iran's Kharg Island terminal, but they lack confirmation of any damage and are maintaining their premiums for war risk insurance on tankers operating in the Persian Gulf. However, one after another, the insurers have extended a seven-day restriction on the period of coverage that had applied in the waters of Iran and Iraq to other Persian Gulf ports, where insurance coverage had run 14 days.

title: EXCELLENT SOURCE OF LOW-FAT PROTEIN
description: TOO many people still think of dried beans and peas as poor people's food, what you eat when you cannot afford meat and other animal proteins that are the focal point of most meals in today's affluent society. Beyond baked beans (typically eaten with pork or frankfurters), the lima beans in succotash and perhaps an occasional bowl of split-pea soup, the mainstream American diet does not contain many legume dishes.

title: THE DANCE: 'RITE,' BY MARTHA GRAHAM
description: WHEN Martha Graham came out for a bow at her dance company's opening last night at the State Theater, the audience sprang up instantly to cheer as no other audience does for any other choreographer in the world.

title: Kinnell to Read Poetry At Music Performance

title: WINE TALK
description: LOOKING back now, it seems as if great chardonnay simply appeared on the shelves one morning and has been there ever since. Actually it has been 30 years in the making. Chardonnay is the glory of our vineyards, although not even the most self-satisfied wine maker in the business would argue that the quest is over for something even better. There is some talk that sauvignon blanc may be the chardonnay of the 80's, but, really, it's only talk. Sauvignon blanc is, well, sauvignon blanc.

title: Major Nuclear Test Planned
description: The Department of Energy has scheduled a major nuclear test for Thursday morning, the first announced test since one Feb. 15 started a cave-in that injured 13 workers. Greg Cook, a spokesman for the department, said Thursday's test would yield an explosive force ranging from the equivalent of 20,000 to 150,000 tons of TNT, the largest test allowed under the treaty limiting nuclear testing. The test will be conducted at Yucca Flat, a desert area 80 miles northwest of Las Vegas.

title: Economic Scene; Trade Deficits Draw Concern
description: ARE trade deficits really so bad? In economic literature, deficits in trading accounts with other countries are often presented as neither good nor bad, but as the outcome of various forces, such as inflation rates, interest rates and foreign exchange prices, that change over time.

He will be replaced by Semyon Bychkov for the first two weeks and by Leonard Bernstein for the third, with different programs in each case.

title: HOW TO MAKE THE MOST OF MIDBLOCK SITE
description: Late in the 1970's Royco Development, a commercial and residential builder in Britain, sent Brian Rainbow to the United States to scout real estate properties for development. A result of Mr. Rainbow's nationwide search is Royco's first solo American venture: a $60 million, 270,000- square-foot Manhattan rental office building at 150 East 52d Street. (In partnership with Howard Ronson, another British developer, Royco built One Exchange Plaza in 1981, and later it was sold to Aetna Insurance.)

description: High winds and freezing rain combined to knock a tree into a power line near here today, blacking out the campaign headquarters of George McGovern as well as the homes of 3,000 area residents.

title: Bradshaw Jabs at Noll

Last week, when the Steelers acquired the quarterback David Woodley from the Miami Dolphins, Coach Chuck Noll mentioned Bradshaw's injury and expressed doubt he would recover enough to resume his career.

This is their only visit here this season. They routed the Nets, 147-124, earlier in the season in their arena. (Television - SportsChannel, 7:30 P.M. Radio - WNBC 660, 7:30 P.M.)

title: CONCERT: COMPOSERS ORCHESTRA
description: AT a time when it appears that all coherence is gone in musical languages, when eclecticism has become a virtue and orthodoxy a curse, there seems to be a revival of interest in grounding music in particular images or programs. Program music gives abstract sound coherence by providing a frame of reference, a map for the ear; every sound is recognized, identified with something known and familiar. The promise of such music is in making the familiar fresh; the dangers are in becoming so wed to images that the music is merely cinematic, only illustrative, not illuminating.

title: Warning by Jazz
description: The Utah Jazz are playing 11 games this season in Las Vegas, Nev., but the owner, Sam Battistone , says the team will not return next season if the Nevada Gaming Commission passes a pending resolution that would allow betting on games played in the city. The hearing on the resolution will be held March 15 before state gaming officials, who have been asked by several sports-book operators to allow betting on games the Jazz play there. Battistone and Commissioner David Stern of the National Basketball Association are fighting the resolution.

title: A BROOKLYN PRE-LENT FEAST ITALIAN STYLE
description: the origin of the word is the Latin for ''meat, farewell'' - traditionally ushers in the meatless Lenten period preceding Easter. In Italian the term is carnevale, and at Tommaso's, a restaurant in the Bay Ridge section of Brooklyn, where the pre-Lenten feasting began last Friday, Carnevale is the occasion for 10 days of hearty banquets punctuated with operatic flourishes. Carnevale at Tommaso's continues through the night before Ash Wednesday next week.

description: * Soap Opera Digest magazine increasing its circulation rate base 3.8 percent, to 675,000, from 650,000, and its advertising rates 8.5 percent, with the June 19 issue.

title: Disney Is Planning Park for Europe
description: Walt Disney Productions said today that it is negotiating with several countries to build a European Disneyland.

title: NEW RECORD BY EVERLYS
description: ''OUR story is really pretty simple,'' said Don Everly, one half of the recently reunited Everly Brothers. ''We broke up, back in 1973, because we couldn't get along. We had been singing together, and hadn't really been apart, since we were around 6 years old. It kept us immature, in a way, kept us from developing any individuality. But we took enough time, and we finally worked things out. Now it's difficult to remember what we were fighting about.''

title: SEARLE STOCK QUERY HELD 'SMOKESCREEN'
description: An Arizona scientist who traded in stock of G. D. Searle & Company because he knew that the company's artificial sweetener would be the subject of a negative report on the ''CBS Evening News'' says the widening attention focused on his transactions is a ''smokescreen'' to divert attention from the merits of the debate about the safety of the sweetener.

title: IRAQ RENEWS ITS WARNING TO SHIPPING
description: Iraq today renewed its threat to attack any ships approaching Iran's main oil export terminal. It also said that its troops had driven Iranian forces back from the last position they had captured inside Iraq on the southern front.

title: CONVICT RETURNS HOME
description: SET and filmed in the small Kansas town of Halstead, ''The Parade,'' tonight's television movie on CBS at 9 o'clock, skillfully spins a dramatic web that entraps a single family spanning three generations. The family's problems are eventually resolved by a plot gimmick that is not entirely convincing, but a fine cast - Michael Learned, Frederic Forrest, Geraldine Page and Rosanna Arquette - keeps this ambitious venture unusually absorbing.

title: MACY, R H, & CO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 28
description: Share earnings have been restated for a 3-for-2 stock split distributed on April 1, 1983.

title: SPW CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-Net income.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Coins for Charity

title: 'LIVE FROM LINCOLN CENTER' RATED A PLUS
description: Tonight's ''Live From Lincoln Center'' telecast, which is devoted to James Galway, Zubin Mehta and the New York Philharmonic, will be the 50th event in the series since its advent in 1976. As such, the program, which will be shown at 8 P.M. on Channel 13, represents a milestone in the cultural center's relationship with the television medium.

title: ERIE LACKAWANNA INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-There are no comparable year- ago figures because the current operations of the company began Dec. 1, 1982.

title: U.S. CONFIRMS NAVAL INCIDENTS IN STRAIT OF HORMUZ
description: The Defense Department said today that the United States destroyer Lawrence, operating in the area of the Strait of Hormuz, fired warning shots Sunday across the bow of an unidentified ship that approached within a mile.

title: TIERCO GROUP INC reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-Net income.

title: U.S. Plans D-Day Statue
description: Ambassador Evan Galbraith today accepted a parcel of land in Normandy for a statue to be erected to commemorate the D-Day landing of United States forces at Utah Beach in World War II. The parcel of 30 acres is at the village of St. Marie du Mont, where the Fourth Infantry Division landed in 1944.

title: DOUGLAS MATHEWSON
description: Douglas Mathewson, a retired New York lawyer and a professor of law at New York University from 1936 to 1967, died Saturday at a convalescent home in Windsor, Conn.

title: AMERICAN MOTOR INNS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
HELENA SUKOVA WINS, 7-6, 7-6
description: The most successful season of Jo Durie's tennis career came to a disappointing end last night when she squandered a commanding lead and lost two tiebreakers to Helena Sukova at the Virginia Slims Championships at Madison Square Garden.

title: HOW MUSCLE IS DIRECTED
description: ''THE BODY HUMAN: THE JOURNEY WITHIN'' is an artful attempt, mostly successful, to show how brain and body, working together, analyze, execute and create. Among other things, the one-hour CBS special looks at an architect, a singer, a boxer and a test pilot, showing how the work of each depends on the interplay of mind and muscle

title: WEDNESDAY, FEBRUARY 29, 1984 International
description: The U.S. has refused a Beirut appeal, according to Reagan Administration officials and Lebanese informants. They said the Administration had turned down a request from President Amin Gemayel for increased use of American naval and air power in direct support of his Government. (Page A1, Column 1.) President Amin Gemayel has decided to abrogate the May 17 Israeli-Lebanese withdrawal accord, according to Lebanese Government and opposition informants. He is expected to go to Damascus soon for a meeting with President Hafez al-Assad. (A10:1.)

title: FOOD NOTES
description: Afghan Bread

title: GAF CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After extraordinary credits of $22,364,000 for the quarter and $25,358,000 for the year. c-Net income d-After an extraordinary credit of $35,552,000. e-After income from discontinued operations of $5,303,000 and an extraordinary credit of $38,744,000. The company said that nonrecurring expenses in 1983 included a $26.1 million provision for shutdown of certain building materials plants and facilities and a $3.5 million reserve established in connection with the company's planned relocation of its headquarters to Wayne, N.J.

title: CASTINEAU SIGNS FOR $4 MILLION
description: After trading four key veterans in recent weeks, and after having lost three others to the United States Football League, the Jets have re-signed Mark Gastineau to a long-term contract.

title: Executive Found Guilty of Perjury
description: A Manhattan public-relations executive was convicted Monday of perjury in connection with the slaying of a 22-year-old actor who had been spurned by the executive's daughter.

title: THE PUZZLING SILENCE ON LEBANON
description: After a policy failure, or abrupt shift in policy such as the recent one in Lebanon, the general rule of thumb within administrations is blame thy brother before he blames you. It is usually a time for settling old scores and for unloading pent-up recriminations.

title: COLLEGES EXPECTING LITTLE IMPACT FROM RULING
description: College officials said yesterday that the ruling by the Supreme Court in the Grove City College civil rights case would reduce the pressure on them to combat sex discrimination, especially in athletics. Most added, however, that they expected the practical effects to be negligible.

title: CONGRESSIONAL AUDITORS DOUBTFUL ON SAVINGS ENVISIONED BY PANEL
description: The major recommendations of President Reagan's commission to reduce Federal costs would save much less money than the panel asserted, Congressional auditors said today.

title: U.S.-E.E.C. TRADE PACT
description: The United States drew back from a confrontation with the European Economic Community today by dropping an attempt to have the 10-nation group condemned for retaliating against American restrictions on imports of high-quality steels.

title: AN OLD WEST CEMETERY FOR JEWS IS REDEDICATED IN TOMBSTONE
description: Eighteen months ago Al Turner, a local historian, led a small group to an abandoned Jewish cemetery from the 1880's.

title: U.S. INSTRUCTORS AGAIN TRAINING LEBANON TROOPS
description: Despite the recent defeats of the Lebanese Army and the transfer of United States marines from Beirut to ships offshore, American Army trainers have resumed instructing new soldiers for a fighting force loyal to the Government of President Amin Gemayel.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Vietnam Memorial Contest

title: MONARCH INVESTMENTS reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
Market Place; Searching For Secure Investment
description: G IVEN the recent problems with Washington Public Power Supply System bonds, Baldwin-United annuities and utility stocks destroyed by nuclear plant cost overruns, where should conservative investors put their money? Even the ultimate ''widow and orphan'' stock, American Telephone and Telegraph, has been split into eight unknown issues.

title: Stephen V. Morris, 74, Dead; U.S. Diplomat for 25 Years
description: Stephen Van Cortlandt Morris, a retired career diplomat, died Friday at the Georgetown University Hospital in Washington after a long illness. He was 74 years old and lived in Washington and Lenox, Mass.

title: U.S. SAID TO REJECT LEBANON REQUEST FOR FIRE SUPPORT
description: The Reagan Administration has turned down an appeal from President Amin Gemayel of Lebanon for increased use of American naval and air power in direct support of his Government, Administration officials and Lebanese sources said today.

title: Extension of Credit Surcharge Ban
description: The Senate tonight unanimously approved an extension, until May 15, of a ban against imposing a surcharge on customers' purchases with credit cards. The ban expired at 12:01 A.M. today.

title: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES ; Yields Are Adjusted on City Issue
description: Prices and yields for New York City's $250 million issue of Baa/BBB rated bonds were adjusted by varying amounts, underwriters led by Goldman, Sachs & Company announced yesterday. When municipal bonds are sold through negotiation between the issuer and underwriters, as is the case in the city's offering, interest rates are often adjusted upward when investor demand is lacking or are reduced when demand is strong.

title: Wilson Hog Plant
description: The Wilson Foods Corporation said it had agreed to sell its Cedar Rapids, Iowa, hog slaughtering and processing plant to the Kesef-Mazal Corporation of Elizabeth, N.J., for about $16 million. Wilson, of Oklahoma City, said the sale was part of its plan to reduce its commodity fresh pork business and to increase sales of value- added fresh and processed pork products, which carry higher profits.

title: SAUNDERS LEASING SYSTEM INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss

title: JERRY MARTIN TO GET TRYOUT WITH METS
description: Jerry Martin, who was released from Federal prison last week after serving 81 days on cocaine charges, will join the training camp of the Mets Thursday for a tryout at his own expense and with no guarantee of a job.

title: MACY'S NET RISES 12.9%
description: R. H. Macy & Company, continuing its strong trend of recent years, said yesterday that its earnings rose 21.9 percent in its second quarter, to $97.5 million, or $1.93 a share, from $80 million, or $1.60 a share, the year before.

title: ADS AND WOMEN: WINNERS AND LOSERS
description: WOMEN Against Pornography, a feminist organization, awarded a record nine plastic pigs for advertising campaigns that it considered ''demeaning to women and girls'' yesterday, and four Ms. Liberty awards for ''prowoman ads.''

title: PACIFIC GAS TRANSMISSION CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: THE SUPPLY-SIDE REVOLUTION: An Insider's Account of Policy making in Washington. By Paul Craig Roberts. 327 pages. Harvard University Press. $18.50.

title: SUPERIOR SURGICAL MANUFACTURING CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Round for Frazier
description: A Superior Court judge in Woodbury, N.J., has cleared the way for the eventual dismissal of a weapons charge against Joe Frazier, the former heavyweight champion.

title: SCOUTING
description: Sure Shooting

title: WESTVACO CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
The U.N. Today Feb. 29, 1984
description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY

title: Citicorp Paper
description: Citicorp sold $100 million of 91-day commercial paper at an average rate of 9.677 percent, up from 9.638 percent a week ago. It also sold $50 million of 182-day paper at an average rate of 9.743 percent, up from 9.607 percent. The bank holding company sells 91- and 182-day paper weekly.

title: SOME JERSEY TOWNS, GIVING IN TO COURTS, LET IN MODEST HOMES
description: By late summer, the prosperous people living in newly built $210,000 town houses on a gentle slope here will have new neighbors moving into unadorned condominiums selling for $35,000 to $60,000.

title: Foreign Minister Says France Could Pull Unit Out of Beirut
description: The French Foreign Minister, Claude Cheysson, said today that French troops could not stay in Beirut if the warring Lebanese factions were not reconciled.

title: 2 Agencies Pick Up Account Assignments
description: Two other account assignments affect Tromson Monroe Advertising and HBM/Creamer.

title: 6-Year Sentence In L.I. Kidnapping
description: A North Babylon woman who admitted kidnapping a 17-month-old girl at a shopping center in Lake Grove last May was sentenced today to a prison term of 6 to 18 years, the maximum penalty for the crime.

title: REVLON INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Accord Reached In Bus Strike
description: The New York Bus Service and its more than 400 drivers and mechanics represented by Local 100 of the Transport Workers Union have reached a tentative contract agreement after a 10-week strike, company and union executives said yesterday.

title: U.S. Petroleum Data
description: In millions of barrels except refinery utilization

title: Koch 'Would Not Vote' If Jackson Faced Reagan
description: Mayor Koch said yesterday that he would not endorse or support the Rev. Jesse Jackson if Mr. Jackson became the Democratic Presidential nominee.

title: SCOUTING
description: Easy Listening

title: VERNITRON CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Showtime Plans Switch
description: Showtime Entertainment, a client of Benton & Bowles since December 1981, asked the agency to participate in an agency review, and it declined.

title: PHILHARMONIC TO PRESENT 'HORIZONS'
description: The New York Philharmonic will present a sequel to its Horizons '83 contemporary music festival at Avery Fisher Hall, entitled ''Horizons '84: The New Romanticism - a Broader View,'' the orchestra announced yesterday.

title: MANHATTAN NATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
SELECTERM INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
STATE AND CITY DEBATE CLEANUP OF TOXIC WASTE
description: In a cleanup effort that has cost New York City $5 million so far, city and state officials are debating who should pay for clearing many of the toxic waste sites in the five boroughs.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article on the Rev. Jesse Jackson and Jewish organizations misidentified Hyman Bookbinder in some editions yesterday. He is Washington representative of the American Jewish Committee.

title: GENETIC LABORATORIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
TELEVIDEO SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
Comings and Goings
description: Ray Handley, a Stanford assistant for the last two seasons, has been named offensive backfield coach for the Giants. He replaces Bob Ledbet ter, who died in October. . . . Albert Cova, the world 10,000-meter champion, heads a team of 21 Italian runners who have entered the World Cross-Country Championships at the Meadowlands on March 25. . . . Fred Lebow, the director of the New York City Marathon, said that the field for the race Oct. 28 would be increased from 17,000 to 18,000.

title: TOP HEALTH-CARE ISSUE
description: To the Editor:
